column3: Dhanush Sridhar - 2018103021
Document 2

column2: ['Please have some compassion for these amazing creatures!  Elephants are  natural nomads and are not meant to be kept in captivity in zoos!  In the wild, they  are accustomed to walking hundreds of miles each day.  But in the zoo, no matter  how big their enclosures look to zoo visitors, they are tiny compared to the open  land in the wild.  It has been proven that zoo enclosures are terrible for the  physical and mental health of elephants.  Even with poaching, the average life of  an elephant in the wild is much older than an elephant in captivity!  All the  remaining elephants in zoos should be transferred to reserves and sanctuaries,  where they can live out their lives in giant expanses where they are free to roam  and forage.  Please, I implore you, help these brilliant, magnificent animals.', 'It is imperative that living conditions for elephants be improved in zoos and  circuses.  It should be required that living space for such enormous animals be  large enough to acommodate them comfortably (i.e., The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and PAWS in California have hundreds to thousands of acres) and that  they be allowed the freedom to roam and socialize.  Prolonged chaining, standing  for hours in their own excrement, being confined to barn stalls and suffering social  deprivation are conditions that no living creature should have to endure.   Additionally, the use of bullhooks and other tools of intimidation are cruel,  unnecessary, and should be outlawed.  With the inhumane conditions that so  many elephants live under, it is no wonder that captive elephants suffer from  neurotic behaviors.  No animal under human domain should have to go through  what elephants in circuses and zoos endure during their lifetimes.  Because we  have the power to change their lives for the better, why wait another second to get  the ball rolling?  Thank you for your attention to this matter.', 'Elephants are not given a fair treatment in zoos and circuses. We must remember  that in their natural habitat, these majestic wild animals are used to walk long  distances and socialize with other individuals of their own species. Their living  conditions at zoos and circuses can hardly emulate life in the wild. Intense  confinement, unnatural life conditions (like extreme weather, constant traveling,  unfit shelter, forced movements/positions, etc.) and social deprivation can cause  them to suffer a range of physical and mental illnesses (like arthritis, foot  diseases, digestive problems, neurosis, etc.). Many circuses and zoos train them  by using force, domination and violent tools such as bull hooks, electric prods and  chains, which exacerbate their physical and mental problems and also break their  spirits. I applaud the Detroit Zoo for putting their elephants welfare first and giving  them away to a sanctuary where they can have a better life. Hopefully, many more  will follow! I urge the authorities to protect these beautiful animals by making sure  the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) requirements are met and violators are prosecuted  and severely punished. Thank you!', 'All animals need to be treated with care and respect.', "Circuses and many zoos control elephants through the use of force and  domination, aggressive use of bullhooks, and prolonged chaining. In many zoos,  elephants are confined to barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when zoos are  closed, and in zoos in cold climates, elephants often spend weeks at a time  indoors during cold winter weather.  Elephants are the world's largest land mammals, and they require significant  amounts of space. In fact, in the wild, they can walk up to 30 miles a day. The  leading causes of death in captive elephants are foot disorders and arthritis, which  are caused by prolonged chaining, intense confinement, and forced inactivity.  Since 2000, more than half of the 49 elephants who have died at zoos accredited  by the Aquarium & Zoo Association never reached their 40th birthdays, dying far  short of their 70-year life expectancies.  Because of their intelligence, complexity, sensitivities, and unique social and  physical needs, elephants suffer immensely in small, unchallenging captive  environments. To make matters worse for elephants, in circuses, every instinctual  behavior is subject to discipline. If elephants reach for grass, try to comfort  friends, or extend their trunks to smell something new or different, they get hit with  bullhooks. If they blow a trick during a performance, they get beaten afterward.  Despite the fact that elephants fare miserably in captivity, zoos and circuses are  vociferously defending the status quo.   The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", "I am writing to express my support for all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country.  I am asking the USDA to create touch new standards to include: 1.  The use of bullhooks should be prohibited.  The purpose of these is to inflict pain, no more and no less.  In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury and suffering to elephants. 2.  Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats--similar to The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee.    These animals and their complex emotional and physical needs simply deserve no less.", 'These gentle, intelligent and sociable creatures need accommodations, handling and activities that are healthful. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California.', 'Elephants must be provided a healthy environment within which to live. PERIOD!  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and  well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space.  Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural  conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ?  including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic  behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer  from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in  captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day  standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they  are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their  own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in  barn stalls for extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use  of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices.  These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to  those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over  which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'The use of bullhooks, electric prods and chains should be made illegal in the  realm of elephant training. they have only one use: to cause pain; and that is  unnacceptable.  These animals are too smart and sensitive to undergo such  treatment.', "I am concerned that ALL animals be treated as humanely as possible, especially those held in captivity in spaces very different from their natural habitat. ELEPHANTS have typically been kept in spaces much too small for their size resulting in needless injury and disease.   At the very minimum, I urge you to enforce regulations under the Animal Welfare Act, If we cannot uphold regulations now in force what's the point of making changes?  Would they fall in to disuse also?  Animals should not be subject to weapons such as bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices or other instruments of force unless other lives are in danger. Large animals need large spaces and freedom to move. Confining them to small spaces and doing so with chains or other restraints is unnecessarily cruel. If I treated my dog in this manner I would surely be reported and convicted of animal cruelty. Please have the same consideration for large animals in our zoo environments.", 'Please help us take better care of the elephants of the world. Caretakers should  never be allowed to beat elephants, or to use a prod to handle them. Captive  Elephants are better cared for in a large preserve area such as ones in Tennessee  and California. Please stop the abuse of the elephants.', 'PLEASE ENSURE ELEPHANTS ARE TREATED IN A COMPASSIONATE  MANNER.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.   Please ensure that elephants are treated humanely!', 'The USDA should recognize that the current regulations on animal welfare are not  sufficient for the protection of captive elephants.  We know that even the loose  regulations currently on the books are very difficult to enforce, and due to recent  science, very dated.  The USDA should convene and guide an  industry/governmental working group that would help produce an NPRM that takes  into account all the lessons learned and research of the last twenty years in terms  of captive elephant husbandry.  The US Government should take a leadership role  in meshing the recognition that conservation of habitat is touted as the ultimate  reason for zoos and other entertainment fora.  It should certainly take these  industries at their word in terms of requiring that wild habitat be conserved, and  that captive elephants be given the proper environment necessary to allow them to  lead as healthy and as normal lives as possible.  It is our duty to these animals  that have no choice in our decisions.  Most importantly, it is urgent that the USDA  understand that recent science has shown that elephants are extraordinarly  intelligent, and have much to share with the human race.  We can do what is right,  or we can allow these wonderful creatures to die from our ignorance, cruelity, and  greed.', "I am writing to request that you support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act, and creating tough new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants.   The clear reason we need change is self explanatory, in the suffering of animals kept in an unnatural environment. Elephants were designed to travel continuously, that is what keeps their feet and legs in an optimum performance level. Imagine keeeping a horse, who was also designed to travel at least 20 -30 miles a day, imagine that horse locked up in a boxstall for it's entire life....get a vision of his hooves and legs, muscle mass, etc  Anything LESS for the Elephants, than the reasons below is clearly distress to the animal.  The reasons the USDA must take action include:   Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being. My grandchildren do not partake in any way shape or form a *circus* that utilizes the suffering of animals as it's *entertainment*. It is no lie about how you get an 8000# elephant to stand on it's trunk, you use a WHIP and a BULL HOOK. Standing and dancing is not natural for elephants, they do it out of FEAR and SUBMISSION. The control comes from force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to elephants.   Accordingly, he Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement. It is time to get elephants OUT of the ZOO. Send them to Tennessee so they can roam free for the remainder of their natural life.  As it is obvious, elephants are big animals who need big spaces. In way too many zoos and circuses, this is not the case,  they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.   Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs, elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher standards than the ones that currently exist. The fact that elephants remember each other, after decades of being separated shouuld be statement enough about their intelligence.  It is definitely time to cut the chains and free the elephants, there is no reason in this new age of humanity that the suffering of ALL animals in zoos and circuses is even tolerated. I remember being a kid, I remember when this little carnival like thing came town in Minnesota 40 years ago, and they had an elephant, and I rode the elephant. My life was not better or worse for that experience....but it still haunts me that I partook in that elephants life of misery.", 'Animal Welfare-Elephants  I think conditions for captive elephants should be improved, ie, more space for  exhibitors to provide large, indiginous, climate-appropriate environments similar to  those at Elephant Sanctuary in Tenn. and PAWS in California.  They provide  hundreds and thousands of acres where the animals can roam, socialize and  maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices should  be banned.  Zoos in circuses are not giving the animals the above necessities that the animals  need.  The ANimla Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants  with adequate space are following this.  The animals are in locked spaces for too  many hours and they suffer greatly.  This is not how these animals were meant to  live in comparison to native elephants living in the jungles.  These animals are  highly intelligent and much higher standards are needed to meet these  necessities.  This is a must!  Too much time has elapsed for these animals living  in squalid conditions.  IF the USDA is compassionate these rules must be  followed.', "I'm writing in support of efforts to improve conditions for captive elephants in  America, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act and creating new standards to:  *Provide large, naturalistic, appropriate environments (similar to The Elephant  Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California)  *Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices, and other  instruments of force against elephants.   Elephants are intelligent, social animals and deserve to be comfortable and happy.  When the above-stated requirements aren't met, they're condemned to a life of  misery and suffering. We have to improve conditions in zoos or release them to  sanctuaries that provide the comfort and amenities that they need to live, not just  exist.", 'It\'s well known to anyone who cares enough to inquire that zoos and circuses are  hellish for elephants.  They all suffer not only from lack of space, but from  unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually causes a range of  preventable ailments; arthritis, foot disease, reproductive/digestive disorders, also  neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing and attacks on trainers.   It is also known that elephants as well as all captive animals are subjected to  barbaric training with cruel tools that should be outlawed like the bullhook, whips,  clubs, electric devices. These methods takes it\'s toll and animals can and have  turned violent when they reached their breaking point. When is it going to be more  clear that it\'s simply "not natural" for them to be subjected to confinement and  torture? That their breaking point as a result of prolonged captivity and torture is  also a danger to people and themselves.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Please right this wrong for  those creatures that cannot speak for themselves. Thank you.', 'Im not the best writer. This sums it up for me.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.', "I wish to urge the humane treatment of elephants which should include not using  bullhooks, chains, and other cruel methods that inflict pain and suffering. I also  would urge regulations that require housing that is spacious and consistent with  the size of these enormous animals and some measure freedom of movement. I  feel that it is also only natural that they be provided an environment that attempts  to emulate their normal habitat. Sensibly, if this cannot be done ,they shouldn't be  held in captivity at all.", 'zoos are NOT giving elephants the conditions required for their health and well  being. the AWA requires that zoos provide adequate space, zoos are NOT  providing this space, in particular the Los Angeles ZOO. elephants are large  animals that need much space, this is not happening at zoos and is contributing  to a whole host of problems from poor circulation to arthritis to nurotic behavior,  like head swaying and head bobbing to premature death. zoos control elephants  by force and domination with a bull hooks and they chain elephants for an  extended period of time', "Thank you for accepting public comments on this topic.  I'm pleased that you   are considering taking action to help care for these captive animals.  Any facility  that houses animals, especially those that use them solely for profit, should be  held to some standard of accountability.  Too many people are more than willing to  sacrifice the well-being of animals to create a little extra profit.  They are not being  given enough space to exercise.  The floors are not appropriate --- many stores  and restaurants have low-impact floors for their employees, why not have  something similar for a creature that weighs thousands of pounds?  Please help  make sure these creatures are treated humanely.", 'I am writing to support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space  requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in IDA?s Citizens?  Petition) and creating tough new standards that: ?  Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  ?  Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices, and other  instruments of force against elephants.  as in my personal experience seeing elephants in zoos and/or circuses, I feel  sorry for them and if I am a parent who wants my children to be operly educated.  Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But, in too many zoos and  circuses, they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions, and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the  zoo is closed. And in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended  periods during the cold winter months.   Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination, and aggressive use of bull hooks and prolonged chaining. These  methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to  elephants.  thank you.     6. Because of their intelligence, complexity, and unique social and physical  needs, elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments.  Because of  these unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.', 'Please consider having regulations for the care of captive elephants in circuses  and other performing acts. Elephants are highly social animals who travel up to 25  miles a day in the wild. They are kept in chains, separately from others, all day  and night long until they perform. This stresses them physically and emotionally. Highly stressed elephants can become dangerous to their human handlers. Elephants should get exercise daily, and be kept in barns or corrals with other  elephants. They need the touch and companionship of other elephants to thrive. Thank you for your consideration', "First I want to thank you for giving the public a chance to share our opinions on this matter.  Many elephant trainers have written about their training methods and they all revolve around  abusing the animal in order to put fear in them to become submissive. This is a disgusting  practice! Circuses are meant to entertain people; is it entertaining to see an elephant struck or  the fear and sadness in its eyes? I think not. I do not support circuses, but as long as they will  be allowed, then I will rally for the animals to have as much comfort they should be provided.  The circus is a business revolving around its performers, animals included, but they do not  receive any benefit as a human worker. They were taken from their homes, crammed in a cage  alone, and now beaten until they perform a trick that they would never have learned in the wild.  How humane is that?! The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have  only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban  on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury,  and suffering to elephants. Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate- appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in  California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize,  and maintain their health. Please do not allow handlers of elephants influence your decisions  when making laws or regulations to protect the animals they are training. Go undercover yourself  and you will see the horror that you have enabled, but have the power to stop and enforce. Just  look in the eyes of the elephant and you will have all of your answers. None of them are happy  and it breaks my heart to see it. Will you please help them?", 'There can be no doubt in any sensible person\'s mind that elephants are social  animals that require an enormous amount of space to live.  That same sensible  person cannot argue that elephants don\'t suffer and cannot feel pain.  This is an  undisputed fact!  They should have sufficient space to move freely (as closely as  possible to their natural habits) in zoos and circuses.  The Animal Welfare Act  should guarantee them this but this is, sadly, not the case.  It also should protect  them from painful "training tools" such as bull hooks and electric shock prods and  cruel means of confinement such as being chained in one place for hours.   America must move away from cruel means of entertainment just as we have  moved away from slavery and displaying disabled people in circuses.  This is a  natural progression of a civilized society and, as such, we don\'t need to inflict pain  on another living being or sentence then to a lifetime of confinement and isolation.', 'I am writing in support of significantly improving the welfare of elephants in captivity  in the United States.   *Zoos and circuses are failing to provide elephants the space and conditions they  need and deserve. As a result, I hope the USDA will require those who exhibit  elephants to provide these animals large, natural and climate-appropriate  environments. In fact, exhibitors should be required to provide conditions similar to  those found at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee.  *Zoos and circuses should not be allowed to use bullhooks, electric shocking  devices, chains, etc. Circuses should not be allowed to ship elephants across the  country in boxcars as though they are furniture. Doing so is outdated, archaic and  inherently cruel.', 'Would you put a whale in river? Neglect should be punishable by law and not  ignored because it involves four-legged beings. Please make this go away', "Elephants in zoos and circuses often have to stand on a concrete slab.  This  causes health problems with their feet.  Elephants roam up to 30 miles per day in  large social herds, so they obviously need lots of room to roam in zoos and  circuses.  In the wild, elephants are free to roam, eat fresh vegetation, bathe in  mud holes, and other natural behaviors.  These reasons are why all exhibitors of  elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to  those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in  California.  These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which  elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.   An elephant's skin is so sensitive, she can even feel an insect bite.  That is why  the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force  must be strictly prohibited.", 'I would like to implore the government to put an end to the abuse of elephants that  is currently done in the name of entertainment.  These majestic mammals should  not be submitted to the abuse of being held in small spaces, indoors, and  subjected to aggressive control methods.  These animals are being treated unfairly  and die after a horrible and short life in captivity.  It is the responsibility of the  government to protect these animals from this type of abuse.  I believe that we  need strong legislation that will put an end to the abuse of elephants.  While many  people for years have silently protest this abuse of elephants by not attending  events where they are used for entertainment ? it is now time to move beyond  silent protest to actively mandating an end to this unconscionable treatment.   Please keep me informed of your progress on this issue.', "The majority of elephants kept in zoos and circuses are not provided with adequate space, social or environmental stimulation and they unnecessarily suffer from physical and mental health problems as a result. Elephants are highly social and intelligent animals, and zoos and circuses simply cannot adequately provide for their most basic needs.  The *only* acceptable environment for elephants kept in captivity is sanctuary that mimics their natural habitat-- with thousands of acres to roam and other elephants with whom to socialize. We o
column3: ['Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.   I believe it\'s essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren\'t for these facilities. I have personally taken hundreds of guests through dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest and know firsthand that the staff\'s expertise and dedication to the animals is second to none.  As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  As a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.   If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.  Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day. With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.   Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.   I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.  Thank you.', 'The Dolphin exhibits are highly educational for children and should continue, however, there should be larger enclosures mandated for the dolphins.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please do not take away the only opportunity future generations have to learn how to care for the animals.  So called "Animal Rights" advocates who want action now forget that if our children don\'t learn how to actually care for the animals more and more will become extinct.  SeaWorld, Busch Gardens and other facilities like them give kids the chance to care.', 's a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.     IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  PLEASE -the requirements for our marine animals are NOT what people thought was adequate 30 yrs ago!!   We know more about the animals in captivity now and these old rules are NOT HUMANE --please do the right thing and listen to the scientists and allow our marine animals that have to be in captivity live in adequate space -  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I believe it is important for the guidelines to be based on science and not emotion. Careful attention to scientific research on this topic is needed.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I support the use of Marine Parks for the education of the public. As long as they are not capturing wild animals. Which I know Seaward does not.A', 'I support accredited zoological facilities, aquariums, and marine parks. I personally have been inspired by my experiences since childhood. I congratulate APHIS for evaluating and making improvements where necessary to offer the best practices for care of these incredible animals. I am concerned that individuals and groups opposed to marine mammals in a zoological settings misuse the process of updating marine mammal care regulations in their attempts to end the display of marine mammals. They do so by encouraging APHIS to impose rules which are not necessary, counter to decades of successful care programs and processes, and impede the great education and conservation work done by the zoological community.  I encourage APHIS to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based upon on the merits of applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards; in cases where insufficient literature exists, input and observation of successful practices within the industry should be strongly considered.I have worked in the marine mammal care field for over four years and have enjoyed educating and inspiring aquarium guests during our interactive programs with dolphins. Our interactive programs are overseen by experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers.  Given the tremendous safety record related to supporting interactive programs at our facility and other marine parks throughout the country, I personally do not see a need for APHIS to impress animal welfare regulations related to interactive programs.', 'Please do not let new regulations further endanger marine life. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I HAVE HAD THE  BEST VISITS AT THE DOLPHIN RESEARCH CENTER!!!!  I HAVE HAD MANY HOURS AND DAYS TO REALLY SEE FOR MYSELF HOW WELL THE STAFF CARES FOR THE DOLPHINS AND SEA LIONS  AND HOW MUCH THE STAFF AND TRAINERS CARE FOR ALL THE VERY BEAUTIFUL ANGELS!!!!N AND LET ME ADD, THE DOLPHINS AND SEA LIONS TRULY LOVE THE STAFF AND TRAINERS!  THE GROUNDS AND LAGOONS ARE ALWAYS TAKEN  CARE OF! THERE HAS ALWAYS BEEN PLENTY OF STAFF AND TRAINERS THERE WORKING AND HELPING WITH THE ANGELS! THEY  WORK WITH THE ANGELS, WITH ONLY POSITIVE BEHAVIOR TOWARDS ALL THE ANGLES, NEVER  NEGATIVE! IF  THERE IS A BEHAVIOR PROBLEM, THE TRAINERS AND STAFF GO OUT OF THEIR WAY  TO LET THE  ANGELS SHOW  THEM THE BEST WAY THEY CAN, AND ANGELS AND TRAINERS  WORK IT OUT! EACH ANGEL IS DIFFERENT AND THEY WILL ALWAYS DO WHAT IS BEST FOR THE DOLPHIN AND SEA LION!  THE ANGELS ALSO HAVE A SAFE PLACE TO GO IF THEY DON'T FEEL THEY WANT TO DO THE PROGRAM THAT TIME AND LET ME ADD, SOME OF THE ANGELS  LIKE TO JOIN IN EVEN IF IT IS NOT THEIR SESSION AND ALSO TO HELP THEIR BUDDY OUT IF THEY DON'T QUIET GET THE HANG OF IT!!!! THERE IS SO VERY MUCH LOVE THERE, ITS A VERY BEAUTIFUL PLACE!!!!!  I COULD REALLY GO ON AND ON!!!!", "Thank you for your continued commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.   I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities. My husband and I recently had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest Oahu. We also watched many sessions between the dolphins and trainers. In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's expertise and dedication to the animals.  And the strong bond between the marine mammals and their caretakers was very evident.  As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation. They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.", 'I am a marine mammal trainer at Blank Park Zoo and have been a professional animal trainer for more than five years. column4: ['The National Women Involved in Farm Economics (WIFE) organization does not support this proposal for importation of fresh (chilled or frozen), maturated, and deboned beef from the specified 14 regions in Brazil into the United States. The risk and potential for catastrophic impact due to the introduction of FMD into U.S. cattle herds is not worth the small amount of trade that would be gained.   Our National WIFE policy states: WIFE urges prohibiting the importation of livestock from any country that experiences outbreaks of serious zoonotic diseases, including pests, until scientific evidence demonstrates the disease and/or pests have been eradicated or fully controlled and there is no known risk of further spread.  FMD is one of the most economically damaging animal diseases in the world. Brazil is not a country considered completely free of FMD with certain regions and adjacent countries having confirmed cases as recent as the past decade.  Although FMD is not a food safety concern, nor a threat to public health, but it does permanently affect the health, productivity and well-being of infected animals, spreading rapidly and also has an indirect impact on the livelihoods of ranchers and producers caring for those livestock.  Therefore, the National WIFE organization does not support this proposal for importation of fresh (chilled or frozen), maturated, and deboned beef from Brazil.   Sincerely,  Whitney Klasna National Women Involved in Farm Economics Beef Committee Chair', 'I do not want to import beef from Brazil. I vote NO! Support our cattle ranchers here in the United States. We do not want an outbreak of FMD. It is way to risky.', "United States beef producers and researchers have worked tirelessly for many years to reach the goal of being Foot and Mouth Disease-free without vaccination. This is not a designation to be taken lightly and opening up trade to import beef from Brazil is a serious threat to the herd health of our nation's beef supply and the health of ALL cloven-footed animals. The disease is easily transferred from one vector to the next (via vehicles, clothing etc) and could devastate our already low beef herd. Please listen to the thousands of producers who do not want this trade partnership to go through - I would MUCH rather pay higher prices for beef now than open up trade with Brazil and pay astronomically higher prices for beef after the American beef herd has been decreased even further. Please please please pay attention to these comments.", 'As a cattle veterinarian, producer and rancher, from one of the highest cattle producing states in the US,  I am appalled at the idea of importing fresh meat from Brazil. Known Foot and Mouth outbreaks still occur in South America, and our safe and wholesome beef produced in the USA would be completely devastated by FMD introduction. Do you not remember the photos of Britain and the carcasses being burned in huge piles when they had an "accidental\' release of FMD?  In this case, USDA would be "purposefully" risking the safety of the US beef herds, one of the main goals of their job is to protect from harm. There is no way that USDA can control the Brazilian slaughter houses completely, removing safeguards, managing cross contamination that is inevitable. There is no such thing as a little FMD that can be tolerated.   South American vaccinates much of their beef against FMD, a practice not done in the US. There is no certainty that symptoms of FMD may not be hidden, yet the animals may carry or transmit the FMD virus. This is not acceptable practice going into a country free of FMD.   We produce enough beef in the US to feed our people. We need to be able to compete with high quality exports to nations that do not want any chance of FMD. Cheap beef from nations with substandard health management practices  and known suceptibility to bribery and malfeance, should not be a reason to jeopardize our sought-after beef from US ranchers and farmers.   Do not allow beef from Brazil into the United States of America at any time. Short term profit should not cloud the directive of the USDA to prevent importing ANY risk to our cattle herds here. Label all meat according to origin and you will see how the US consumer is concerned about source and trust in where their meat is produced.   With sincere concern, Katrin Kolder, DVM', 'I am Jay Evans and independent Rancher and Ranch Consultant involved in the Stocker, Feeder and Cow Calf Segments of Beef Cattle Business and I oppose the USDA APHIS proposed a rule to amend regulations to allow the importation of fresh (chilled or frozen) beef from a region of 14 States in Brazil into the United States. \uf0b7 The region of 14 States covered under the proposed rule include: Bahia, Distrito Federal, Espirito Santo, Goias, Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul, Minas Gerais, Parana, Rio Grande do Sul, Rio de Janeiro, Rondonia, Sao Paulo, Sergipe, and Tocantins. \uf0b7 The consequences of an FMD outbreak in the United States would be extremely high in terms of disease-related costs, loss of animal life, trade losses and severe psychological effects on farmers and farming communities. \uf0b7 The most recent outbreaks of FMD within the proposed export region in Brazil occurred in 2006. \uf0b7 USDA APHIS does not consider the countries of South America to be FMD-free with the exception of Chile. \uf0b7 Outbreaks of FMD have occurred in Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, all countries that had been classified as FMD-free without vaccination or FMD-free with vaccination by the OIE prior to the FMD outbreaks. \uf0b7 FMD has not been eradicated from Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela, and Peru. \uf0b7 While we support expanding export markets based on internationally sound science, concern exists regarding the possible increased risk for the introduction of FMD into the U.S. with the future implementation of this proposed rule. \uf0b7 Our concerns for the possible increased risk of introducing FMD into the U.S. through the proposed rule are also shared by a group of eight United States Senators who signed a letter, January 23, 2014, to the Secretary of Agriculture, Tom Vilsack, asking for an extension of the comment period to provide adequate stakeholder review of the proposed rule and supporting documents. \uf0b7 \uf0b7 Concerning the APHIS risk assessment for the Region in Brazil, the release assessment, exposure assessment and consequence assessment appear incomplete with regard to the necessary steps and requirements outlined in the international standards as described in the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Chapter 2.1. \uf0b7 We urge APHIS to perform a quantitative risk assessment for the risk of FMD from the importation of fresh, maturated, deboned beef from a Region in Brazil into the United States in order to reduce subjectivity and to provide a better analysis of uncertainty and the effectiveness of mitigation measures for the FMD risk, given the high consequences of this risk. APHIS performed a quantitative risk assessment in 2002 for the risk of FMD with the importation of fresh beef from Uruguay, a country like Brazil, also considered by the OIE to be FMD free with vaccination practiced. \uf0b7 USDA APHIS needs to strongly consider updating the 1995 scientific information used to verify the exposure assessment and the resultant data used to establish the FMD exposure risk. \uf0b7 APHIS needs to refocus the consequence assessment to align with the scope of the risk assessment. \uf0b7 As a critical part of the regulatory impact analysis associated with the proposed rule, APHIS should perform a comprehensive up-to-date economic analysis to identify the economic consequences to all of the affected commodity groups in U.S. animal agriculture from a possible FMD outbreak in the United States. \uf0b7 Furthermore, if the proposed rule should move forward, APHIS needs to consider the development of an ongoing APHIS oversight protocol to monitor Brazils compliance with risk mitigation beyond the usual port of entry testing. \uf0b7 We cannot comfortably rely on a self-reporting system in Brazil to mitigate the U.S. risk for FMD. \uf0b7 Our concerns are for the resulting economic and animal health consequences should FMD enter the United States as a result of the proposed rule. \uf0b7 The APHIS regulatory analysis highlights the possible consumer benefit from the import of 40,000 metric tons of fresh beef annually from Brazil but, fails to address the economic impact on consumers for the possible risk for the introduction of FMD virus to the United States and a resultant FMD outbreak \uf0b7 The risk to U.S. agriculture and to our cattle producers is far too great and the economic and animal health consequences far too significant to move forward with this proposed rule without first absolutely establishing that an attitude of willingness for compliance and a sophisticated infrastructure are present in Brazil to allow for the consistent performance of all FMD risk mitigation measures. Thank You for your consideration, Jay C. Evans', 'Threatening the devastation of the US beef industry with Hoof & Mouth disease, at a time of historically low cattle numbers cannot be justified; just for the short term goal of cheap beef.  There is no way that Brazil can control the flow of beef through the borders of its vast districts & regions.  So even though areas are certified Hoof & Mouth disease free, they cannot guarantee that the meat they ship is disease free.  There have been many articles published about the lack of infrastructure in the Brazilian interior.', "In my opinion, it would be unwise for our country to import beef from other countries that don't require the same regulations as the USDA does here in America. We currently have rules in place for our beef production because it prevents the spreading of diseases or illnesses from being transmitted to humans through our meat. What is the point in having certain rules and regulations for our beef cattle here, if we our just going to import unregulated beef from separate countries? It's important to consider the reasons why the USDA has the job that they do and realize that it is for the well being of the public.", 'I think it is short sighted and foolish to put the food supply of the USA in jeapody by importing beef from Brazil where foot and mouth disease is common.   It is also extremely uncaring , selfish and greedy to put the livleyhoods of USA cattle ranchers in danger by multi-national meat importers who care only for themselves and not the consumers and producers of beef in this country.   Importing beef from Brazil to break the cattle market that would put cattle producers out of business is extremely anti american in my opinion.   The risk of spreading foot and mouth disease is high and we could end up like Europe did a few years ago destroying the cattle herd numbers that are very low now as it is.   Do not import of beef from Brazil!!!  Frank Timmons', 'I am very concerned about uncooked beef being allowed to enter the US from Brazil.  I worked with a Brazilian farm coop in 2005. I worked closely with Brazilian producers while evaluating the live cattle  supply potential.  We were exploring the possibility of building a beef packing plant at Londrina, Brazil.  I also owned a packing plant in Uruguay.  I can assure you that if you create a price bias between states in Brazil by allowing the importation of beef from certain areas, that there we be an illigal flow of cattle to those areas of higher prices.  I am also certain that cattle will cross the border from Paraguay.  Hoof and mouth disease can be carried by wind-born dust, dirt on tires and shoes, and by wild animals.  This fact alone makes receiving fresh meat from certain areas high-risk.    An outbreak of hoof and mouth diesease in the US would devistate the whole industry!  Weigh the pros and cons of this proposal and you will see that the additional risk is in no way justified.', 'Cattleman support free trade of live cattle, beef and/or beef products with foreign countries that have PROPER ANIMAL HEALTH AND FOOD SAFETY PROTOCOLS IN PLACE,  Argentina and Brazil lack these protocols and have NOT been successful in controling foreign diseases such as foot and mouth diseases.  For this reason we are OPPOSED to this proposed rule that this importation from these two countries.  Billy & Linda Mann', 'Re: Docket No. APHIS-2009-0017         Regulatory and Analysis and Development         PPD, APHIS         Station 3A-03.8         4700 River Road, Unit 118         Riverdale, MD         20737-1238  Title: Importation of Beef: Region in Brazil  April 14, 2014  I am David Winters and appreciate the opportunity to provide comments on this proposed rule.  I am a cattle and sheep rancher from southwest Texas and have also been involved in importing and exporting cattle, sheep and their products for many years.  From the standpoint of being personally involved in international trade I am acutely aware of many of the benefits of opening livestock trade across international borders.  I have also served on the Texas Animal Health Commission and thus am familiar with many of the challenges facing trading partners as they try to facilitate business in a science-based manner.  While the theoretical risk of introducing Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) from this region in Brazil from fresh and frozen beef is low provided the stated controls and in place and functional, I find that there are several issues and items lacking in the Docket and supportive material that should be addressed:  \tA qualitative risk assessment was done as stated and the concluding results reported.  However APHIS apparently relied heavily on site visits by agency professionals and I have not been able to locate or review the specifics that were assessed.  For example, if deficiencies were found how were they corrected and if measures were recommended by APHIS, how were they addressed?  APHIS has, in some cases, conducted quantitative risk assessments when considering regionalization requests such as this one.  I believe that due to the beef export potential from this region and the seriousness of the disease concerns, a quantitative risk assessment should have been done and the results made available with this docket.    \tIf this region in Brazil is provided access to the U.S. market for fresh and frozen beef, that action is likely to raise the value of beef exports from that region and cause an economic incentive for trans-shipments from other unapproved areas/regions.  In my opinion, APHIS should but has not in a direct way outlined how the FMD risk from trans-shipments would be prevented.  \tThe conditions that APHIS outlined in the proposed rule (as were applied to Uruguay) are appropriate in my opinion, although risk was assessed differently for Uruguay, however ongoing verification of implemented risk-control measures by Brazils Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food Supply (MAPA) is not stated other than to state that periodic inspections of slaughter establishments by APHIS representatives can be made.  I believe that it is important to establish a more rigorous and routine system of verification of risk control measures is very important in this case.  In the case of national program diseases in the U.S. for example, states report annually on their status and how they are addressing various issues.  In conclusion, I strongly recommend that APHIS address the content in these three points above and, if the findings warrant it, re-propose the rule along with all of the supporting documentation.  Respectfully submitted,  David Winters', "Please do not allow imported beef from Brazil.  I was in Ireland on a visit around the time Foot and Mouth broke out over there.  This country does NOT want to go through that.  Once you open the door to chilled/frozen beef, it won't take much to transition to live beef.  As a beef producer, our government should be protecting our marketing interests, not undermining them.  Sincerely, Terry Henderson", 'FMD is a serioius issue, we must be above the impulse of bringing beef from other countries that not cleared of FMD just to bring down consumer prices for a product. American products for American people! We deserve saftey. Thanks Clint L Englehart.', 'The importation of beef from Brazil is simply far to dangerous. One case of FMD would devastate the livestock industry in this country. The livestock industry is a large enough part of the nations economy that this would have crippling effects to the nation as a whole. National security is at risk here.', 'DO NOT Bring Brazilian Beef into our Country!!! There are already enough problems, and recalls on our own homegrown food products without allowing imports from a region known to be riddled with an out of control health risk to American livestock and people!  Importing Brazilian beef is an irresponsible and dangerous move on so many levels. DO NOT BRING IN BRAZILIAN BEEF!!!', "USDA's proposal to import fresh and chilled beef from 14 states in Brazil is anti-American, irresponsible and dangerous to the health of our American beef herds and the American people. It will increase our risk of introducing FMD, destroy our cattle markets, and drive even more U.S. cattle producers out of business.   The cattle business is more than a business for most of us beef producers, it has been a way of life for families for many generations. We have lived up to our government's regulations and rules to insure we produce a quality product that America can be confident in feeding their families without worry of disease. We raise THE BEST beef of any place on this earth!! Why would we want to bring in outside disease and inferior product from another country. What jobs will be waiting for all the people who are put out of jobs and careers, because some person who is sitting in an office in a big city has decided  America needs to buy a cheaper product? That person probably has never even set foot on a ranch yet we seem to be destined to be dictated by their ideals.  Please reconsider this proposal.", 'This proposal is gambling with the future health and safety of American livestock producers.  The USDA should be taking steps to bolster US producers not undermining them with the import of foreign potentially dangerous meat.  Please DO NOT move forward with allowing these imports.', "This is insanity for a number of reasons, but the most shocking is that this branch of our government, who is supposedly responsible for the safety of our food supply, would even consider bringing Brazilian beef into our country! By bringing cattle into the USA from a country that is KNOWN to be a large harborer of foot and mouth disease, you put, not only our own FMD-free cattle at risk, but you threaten to put our own beef producers, who are already struggling to stay afloat, out of business by causing a drop in the price of beef.  This price drop will be short lived if FMD invades our herds and millions of cattle must be slaughtered to prevent it's spread.  Please don't be penny wise and pound foolish and above all, protect our food supply and more important, protect OUR FARMERS!!", 'No, we cannot allow this importation to happen, we have got to start protecting the U.S.', 'If we allow USA to purchase Beef from Brazil again we will be running into the same problem we had years ago.  The FMD will be back and you will be getting Americans sick all over again.  Also, think of how many farmers you will be putting out of bussiness.  The price of importing beef will drive down the price of the domestic beef.  Which in turn will put the farmer in America out of bussniess.       Lets be dependent on ourselves where you have control over the product that you are getting.   NO TO EXPORTING BEEF FROM BRAZIL', "Importing cattle from Brazil will open up the US to possible Foot and Mouth disease.  We do not need this.  The United States cattlemen work very hard to keep their herds BSE free, and do not need imported beef endangering our BSE free herds.  Nor do we need this disease in the US.endangering our citizens!! I can't believe the USDA would even consider this!", 'As a provider of inputs to those in the US whom rely on the cattle industry, I would like to vote no on allowing fresh beef imports into the US.  I feel the risk to the US cattlemen with the possibility of a FMD outbreak is too great and far outweigh any potential benefits to the American consumer of beef.', 'Stop beef imports from Brazil. We have enough foreign imports and do not need beef from other countries.', 'I oppose the importation of beef from a region in Brazil.  The risk of a foreign disease being introduced into our food supply is too great.  The economic impact of a FMD outbreak would be catastrophic and would set us back decades.  Our first priority is our own country, our own farmers and ranchers and our own consumers  The answer is NO!', 'I am against this proposal.  I do not believe that the Brazilian beef industry is regulated closely enough in regards to infectious disease unlike producers in the US.  I feel bringing their product in would be irresponsible.  I also feel quite strongly that we should support our producers here at home before supporting a foreign competitor.  Thank you for your time.', 'We do not agree with the importation of beef from specific Brazilian states.  We do not feel it is worth the chance you are taking when it comes to bringing in diseases from other countries.  This could be very costly, if, in fact,  an outbreak were to occur.  Please reconsider stopping this amendment to current regulations.', 'The opening of parts of Brazil for export of beef to the US seems questionable.  While there may be control of FMD in the proposed area, the attraction of an export market could attract the movement of cattle into the region from areas where FMD is not under control.  We have too much to lose from a FMD outbreak in the US.  I see what is happening with spread of Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea virus and its mutations in the pork industry of the US and hope never to see the same in  livestock affected by FMD.', 'After the hit the beef industry in South Dakota took last fall this is the last thing that we need.', 'Destroying the American farming economy is High on the list of FDA required regulations it seems, almost like destroying healthy foods. Necessary regulations to stop diseased imports are bypassed as we become a toxic dumping site for the chemical industry. Organic and safe food be damned!.  Dont forgey to radiate and add toxic slimes, colorings, antibiotics-chemicals, and preservatives to our foods or else! and dont forget to give us over to GMOs.   FDA, do your job, stop the corruption.', 'I thought USDA years ago was formed to help keep farmers and ranchers in the USA informed and also help to keep you informed on latest developments and new information. Well this is the second time in several months that we have been asked to send our opinion on what the USDA is doing. I am getting tired of it as this is my busy time with calving and storms and then come in to hear the agency that is supposed to be working for you is again more interested in some poor foreign country or a big packer. Well I am done with your damn surveys and literature you put out, so take me off your list.', 'Regarding the USDA relaxing rules on importation of fresh or chilled beef from origins not known to be free of FMD:  This is a very dangerous move for the US cattle industry, especially since there will be no possible way to ensure that the disease can be kept at bay with a move like this.    Our cattle markets will be devastated with an outbreak of FMD.  It will not only effect us domestically, but also all of our beef exports.  Another way our markets will be hurt is by cheap Brazilian beef coming to our shores and driving our domestic beef values lower.  I plead with you to listen to the hardworking US family farmers and ranchers instead of the meat packing industry led by JBS, the giant Brazilian packer, who will stand to reap huge profits if this ruling is allowed to go forward.  Charles Weinreis on behalf of Weinreis Brothers', 'I do NOT approve of this.', "There is no need to open our market up to FMD risk from none attainment  countries. The rewards to Meatpackers doesn't match the financial and emotional ruin of depopulation to regain control of FMD on our farms", 'Since when is the USDA responsible for the price of beef in this country one way or the other? If so,Where were you when it was selling for less than the cost of production in this country? Not sure who is or was doing the thinking for you folks on this one but this decision is not in the best interest of the beef industry in the U.S. And one last point did anyone of you ever take econ 101 in college? SUPPLY and DEMAND !!!!!!!!!', 'It is unlawful to allow a foreign meat product into this country that would hurt the markets of the United States Cattleman.    Why would you allow a foreign product into this country that would put or food industry at risk?    Do not allow the importation of Brazilian meat!!!!', 'We in the US do not need to go through what happened in England in 2001. APHIS is out of their minds to think this idea is is safe.', 'I am very concerned for APHIS to allow such importation.  I worked for APHIS in UK during the FMD outbreak in 2001 and saw first hand the devastation.  Not only the material losses to an industry, but the human emotions.  The hardest thing I had to do was to tell a farmer that he had IT and we will have to destroy his herd.  I do not have confidence in the Brazil or Argentina governments to do things the right way.  I have been in both countries and saw the corruption and infrastructure that could allow FMD or other FAD to enter the US. The cost is just too high to take a chance.
