I herd two presentations by Dr. Clifford which were very well done, but I was not convinced .', 'I feel that the importation of any meat could pose a great risk that foot and mouth could make its way into this country Just look back to what it did in England just a  few years back it would setback the animal industry for a very long time we can not afford to let this happen now or in the future.  Do not let this happen.', 'As a citizen of the United States, a beef consumer, and a person with an interest in the American beef market, I want to make my wishes clear.  The United States should NOT allow the importation of any form of beef from Brazil.  Risking the health of and reputation of our own cattle herds with the possibility--however remote--that foot-and-mouth disease could be introduced within our borders, is absolutely senseless and completely irresponsible.  Why risk the introduction of a disease that has been contained outside the US for decades?  This could also negatively harm our ability to export cattle and beef products to other countries.  Do the right thing for our own economy; do not import cattle and beef from Brazil.', "The Independent Beef Association of North Dakota (I-BAND) strongly opposes the importation of beef from Brazil.  Please refer to North Dakota State Veterinarian's, Dr. Susan Keller, DVM, comments in the letter she sent you.  The health risks of importing beef with diseases from other countries with known outbreaks could be devastating to our own beef herd and agricultural economy.    Kenny Graner, President", "I object to the importation of beef from Brazil.....they have Hoof and Mouth Disease and we don't need it here....it would spread across the US in a matter of days and wipe out our buffalo, deer, elk, antelope, mountain sheep, mountain goats, tame sheep and goats as well as the cattle..... AGAIN we DO NOT NEED beef from Brazil.......", 'It is irresponsible to import beef from Brazil.  The only possible reason for this is to import cheap beef to drive domestic prices.  USDA should be ashamed for even considering importing beef from Brazil.  If Hoof & Mouth disease were introduced to the United States, it would not only be determined to the livestock industry, but it would also devastate the wildlife populations and totally disrupt commerce.  This proposal needs to be stopped Completely!', 'To those involved:  I strongly disagree with the importation of Brazilian beef into the United States.  The potential risk to American beef producers far outweighs any benefits to the American public.  Such an action as allowing the importation of Brazilian beef put the livelihood of thousands of American beef producers throughout the United States at risk.  Thank you for your attention to this matter, CS   Corey Swisher Assistant City Manager/Finance Director City of Whitefish, MT 418 E. 2nd Street P.O. Box 158 Whitefish, MT 59937 Ph: 406-863-2405 Fax:  406-863-2419 Email:  cswisher@cityofwhitefish.org Web:  www.cityofwhitefish.org', 'National Women Involved in Farm Economics (WIFE), request the Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) to extend the comment period for an additional 60 days, Docket #: APHIS-2009-0017, "Importation of Beef From A Region in Brazil".  This proposed action has the potential to impact trade, food safety, and the health of the United States livestock herds. Extending the comment period 60 days will give stakeholders additional time to discuss and comment on this issue, of importing fresh or chilled beef from a region not declared free of Foot and Mouth Disease, which affects all cloven-hoofed animals.  Sincerely, Mary Ellen Cammack Natl.WIFE Area 1 Director', 'There are too many unknowns and no good way to oversee that Brazil will adhere to the high standards of the U.S. Continuing with this proposed rule would put the American people at risk.', 'I urge you not to import beef from Brazil. With the risk of foot and mouth disease being imported into the US it is not worth the perceived  benefits. If FMD were to enter our country it would decimate the whole livestock industry and shut down all of our export markets not to mention the havoc in our own grocery stores.', "I am very concerned about the proposed rule and the possible harm to the US beef industry should FMD arrive here.  I would hope that US officials would confirm more suitable quarantine, vaccine, inspection and slaughter requirements are instituted in Brazil before their beef is imported here.  As a beef producer I have enough challenges in producing safe, healthy and high quality products for our consumers - I don't need another one to deal with.  My family has been involved in the beef industry for over 80 years and we have worked hard to grow and develop our operation so that more family members and future generations can carry on our business and way of life.  The additional risk to wild cervids, bison and other species is also of great concern to me.  Don't sell us out as part of another trade agreement.", 'I am a USBeef producer and I am very concernd about the inportation of beef from Brazil.Here in the US we work hard to keep our cattle healthy and Beef safe. This issue is not about  Money but the health of cattle in the US.', 'please do not import cattle from a country that has a FMD problem! Why would the american government subject their farmer/ranchers and the consumers to a life and death health issue and financial loss from importing livestock from a country with FMD.', 'We all need to be more concerned with aspects of meat coming into our country from a nation with foot and mouth. The us beef industry is just now becoming more profitable if this flesh foreign beef comes into our country that could kill are progress in our industry.', 'I am expressing opposition to the proposal to allow importation of Brazilian beef.  It appears that the benefits certainly do not outweigh the risks.  If Americans believe the price of beef is now high, the price would be very high if Hoof and Mouth Disease were introduced into the country.  It would be a huge hit to the beef industry that supplies a source of safe, high quality protein for our citizens of both high and low incomes.', 'As a cunsumer I would not be in favor of this, I would not like my food source to be compromised, I sure hope our Goverment does not approve this', "This is serious business. We need to not allow imports of livestock and their byproducts from countries that don't have the same animal health and food safety standards that the US has. If we allow these imports there is a huge risk of bringing serious diseases for our animals and people into this country. The US has worked hard to erradicate these diseases in our livestock population
column5: ['These magnets are awesome and it would be a great folly  ban them.', 'Buckyballs and like tools are products that encourage creativity in people of all ages. They\'re a fun and interesting way to play with and understand the principals of magnetism.  However, these objects are dangerous in the hands of small children, and every precaution should be taken to keep these out of the hands of children. To this end, Buckyballs has done an adequate job at expressing the danger by printing the "Keep Out of Reach of Children" label on the packaging of each unit.  If further regulation is to be imposed on Buckyballs and such products, it should should be to increase the visibility and urgency of the warnings already printed on the packaging, not the outright banning of these products. Banning these products is not the best long term solution for the children of America. Only education and responsible parenting can truly keep our children safe, not more laws that hurt more people than they help.  Thank you for your consideration.', 'This is one of the most gross-overreaching of the nanny state I have ever seen: done as always under the guise of "public health."', "This is an issue of personal responsibility. Bleach, and Drano are also dangerous if swallowed, but we aren't banning them because we hold the owners responsible for their own actions.", 'Dont make these magnets illegal.  They are not a hazard.  More people are killed skateboarding than by ingesting bucky balls.  This is skewed policing and should stop.', 'The complete prohibition of magnet sets falling within the guidelines of the proposed rules (e.g., Buckyballs) unnecessarily limits personal freedom and deleteriously downplays the role of parents inwellparenting. Certainly, specifically in the case of Buckyballs, these products are not marketed to children. What\'s more, they bear highly visible and explicit warnings about their potential dangers as well as clear indications of their intended uses. If children get a hold of these and do something unfortunate or stupid (depending on a child\'s age), it\'s because parents let them.  The notice cites "1,700 ingestions of magnets" treated in emergency rooms over the course of three years (roughly 570 a year) as an unreasonable risk of serious injury. But, what do those numbers look like in context? What do they look like next to the population of the U.S.? What do they look like compared to the total number of emergency room visits each year? My guess is a fraction of a fraction of a percent. I believe government needs a far better reason than "somebody might do something stupid" before it bans products.  Thank you for your consideration.', 'How can you think of banning this when trampolines are considerably more dangerous then some magnets.  You could put warning labels and the like on the product when purchasing it', "Creating arbitrary laws governing free sale of any product based solely on the possible risk to children and idiots is ludicrous.  Liberty should never be taken so lightly as to regulate the actions of free people where they should be free to assess for themselves the risk incurred.  Such laws are reckless and irresponsible.  The assumption that warnings don't work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tonguing their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.", 'I have a daughter, and I understand the risk posed by magnetic toys. As a parent, I exercise my responsibility to keep my daughter safe.   Banning toys which are fun and can be used safely is an overreach to protect a few.', "This is silly. Kids put everything in their mouths; magnets, as well as a million other household objects that could harm them. Might as well ban everything that you can fit in your mouth if you want kids to stop choking. Even then, they'll find something harmful to ingest. Worry about bigger things like pesticide poisoning and toxins.", 'These products, which are clearly not marketed to children, are being unfairly targeted.', "I think the proposal to ban magnetic spheres is complete overkill.  Label them, sure, that's a reasonable response.  Banning them is over reaction of the highest order.", 'Enough when all the rules and regulations.  The USA is becoming a nanny state/country where all our freedoms are being stripped away.  I strongly oppose this ban.', "There are an almost infinite number of choking/swallowing hazards. You simply cannot manage them all (and frankly, you shouldn't be trying). Parents should (be allowed to) manage their own children. Individuals should be able to buy what they want (and store it properly, if applicable). Government agencies which try to infringe our freedoms should be closed.", 'The notion to ban a toy because of bad parenting is beyond me thousands of kids get injured a year on bikes, trampolines and other toys.  Magnetic toys such as this should simply not be given to children below a certain age.', 'I disagree with the banning of these magnets. It\'s very silly and won\'t really help anyone.          This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', "These magnets are quite dangerous for our children.  This is a toy waiting to be a disaster.  They do not appear to have any redeeming value once you've taken care of a patient who has ingested 2 to 3 of them and has perforated his intestine.", "I strongly oppose your measure to ban buckyballs and zen magnets, simply because they are lethal if swallowed by children.  You should not need to crush legitimate businesses that are creating and selling these fun magnets simply because of parents' negligence.  If a parent leaves a child unattended in the presence of buckyballs or zen magnets, that is a lack of responsibility and they should be held responsible for any injury or fatality that results, not the creators of these magnets.  This proposed ban is simply ridiculous, and would put hundreds of people out of a job.  I oppose this ban and I strongly urge you to repeal it before it's too late.", 'This is a perfect example of government over-regulation.  If you ban everything a few people manage to injure themselves on, there will be very little left.  And these do have educational value.', 'Attempting to ban a product on the assumption that people do not pay attention to warning labels is bullshit and you know it.', "Same person who submitted comment CPSC-2012-0050-0317  It is not practical to ban things simply for being dangerous to children when  ingested.  The average household contains many dangerous chemicals, small  objects, and electric appliances which pose greater danger to humans of all ages  than do magnets.  One of the responsibilities of parenthood is to create an  environment where these risks are minimized.  Taking such responsibility seriously is  far more effective at keeping children safe and healthy than any government ban.   If parents can manage to prevent their children from ingesting household items  more ubiquitous than toy magnets (such as thumbtacks, drain cleaner, alcoholic  spirits, and gasoline to name a few) then surely they don't need a ban to mitigate  the risk of magnet ingestion.   It is important that toys for children be safe.  To that end, these magnets should  probably not be marketed to children.  But the responsibility of government to  regulate must reasonably stop there, considering the many more dangerous  products which are not banned.", 'Please do not ban Bucky Balls or other magnetic science education toys. These toys are essential to getting children to be interested in science and related career fields and cause very few injuries and already contain warnings against use by young children.', "Growing up in the 1980s there was no limit to the toys on the market that could injure us if our parents didn't take the time to make sure we were safe.  Parents need to supervise their children more and be more aware of what their kids are playing with and how they are playing.", 'Label, warn, exculpate but do not ban.  Scissors are more dangerous, glass bottles, too- a ban is a ridiculous over-reaction to a an occurrence of injury so low as to be statistically insignificant.  Which moronic wife-of-a-Congressman got her panties in a bunch over this?  Really.', 'These are great around the office, and as a responsible adult I should retain the liberty to bask in the happiness they bring to my life.', "On the banning of Buckyballs, these are labeled as not being a child's toy. These are for adults. Buckyballs explain how dangerous these are. This is another case of one person ruining something for everyone else. Keep them out of reach of children, animals, anything that would think swallowing magnets is a good idea, etc.", 'US coin currency can cause similar injuries in children; before you ban a scientifically interesting and educational toy please stop to consider the freedom of choice.  People are still given the coice to smoke even if it is killing them; let people choose to buy whatever toys they want.  Simply provide the adequate warnings!', "I think it's ridiculous to ban these magnets because a few children aren't intelligent enough to use them, especially when they're not marketed as toys for children.", 'Other alternatives? Zen Magnets, who sell their product only online, have had no incidents. Where as I am sure Bucky Balls, who sell in major market stores, have a few incidents;  "a few" in comparison to trampolines or balloons, which are specifically targeting children.   So one alternative could be to remove the product from sale on shelves, then the consumer would be forced to purchase online where irresponsible kids have no credit to purchase. This would:  1. allow parents more control and time to educate themselves on the "toy"  2. allow the mature, responsible adults who enjoy creating and de-stressing using these magnets to continue enjoying them for their proper use 3. allow innovators to continue developing new uses for these magnets  I believe this to be an acceptable alternative that does not require the unreasonable action that you have proposed here against companies who have had little to no incidents.', "You cannot ban magnets because they pose an ingestion hazard for small children!  Motor Oil also poses an ingestion hazard, but we do not ban its sale...  What is wrong with you people? This is beyond stupid. Where the hell do you get off even pretending you have this kind of power?  This is what's wrong with America right here. You should all be ashamed of this ridiculous pile of crap.  You cannot curtial the business that sell these magnets or the consumers who enjoy using them.. This is insane.", 'There are far more dangerous and non-educational products marketed towards children that pose a higher hazard risk than Magnet sets.  Please refrain from legal action.', "I have an idea how about parents actually parent their own kids instead of wanting/hoping/making the goverment do it for them. It's a toy with small parts. Don't give it to them to play with and store it out of the reach.of tiny little hands. Legos have small parts too. How about we ban them as well? But, since they don't interfere with medical devices, I guess small plastic pieces are ok.", 'There is no real reason to ban educational products like this. Any child safety concern can be alleviated by warnings and not marketing as a toy for small children.', 'I DO NOT FEEL THESE ARE A HAZARD TO THE RIGHT AGE GROUP.  WHERE ARE THE PARENTS TO TEACH THIER CHILDREN HOW TO USE THESE ITEMS AND WHAT AGE GROUP TO KEEP THEM AWAY FROM.    PARENTS SHOULD BE DOING THIER JOB.', 'These toys have been some of the best toys ever received by me. I would like to voice my support of keeping them legal.', "Banning the sale of magnets is absurd. When you consider that chemicals, poison, cigarettes, alcohol, explosives, and firearms are all regulated items that are available to the general public.  Banning the sale of any item will just encourage a black market.  I'd recommend that these items be available for sale, but kept out of the reach of children at the retailer and require an ID. It should be the responsibility of adults to keep these out the of hands of children in the home.", 'I highly dislike this ban, it takes away a valuable learning tool. I think there needs to be some amount of personal responsibility in a persons life. I think this is a dumb ban.', 'Very important topic.  Magnet ingestion is extremely dangerous and parents are unaware.  It can result in devastation of the GI tract.  Moreover, foreign body retrieval is an unnecessary cost to the health care system.', "ok now, this is just ridiculous. what, do we not have any personal freedoms anymore? and you are going to tell me that MAGNETS are something that we should even remotely be concerned about considering all that is going on in the world? people can choose what they wish to purchase, and if they can't read a safety warning that is their own fault. it is unconstitutional that something like this be mandated. If safety is the concern, why have we not yet banned our federal government? I've never personally witnessed a greater cause of death and suffering in my life than what the us government is responsible for... so lets not nit pick, why don't we actually target something that matters. plainly ridiculous.", 'I fully support the proposed ban. Being a practicing pediatric gastroenterologist, I have been alarmed by the increasing cases of foreign body ingestions over the last decade, in general, and thse special magnets in particular. I have also seen some of the catastrophic events resultant to magnet ingestions. The numbers of ingestion do not tell the full story;the effects do. Several surgeries to fix perforated bowel, burns and possibilty of the need for long term support with IV nutrition and a potential need for small bowel tarnsplantation-all sobering thoughts and a reality check. We need to take them off the market!!', "Please do not ban these magnets.  This is a silly rule that would solve no problems, for no people.  Heck, even if you did swallow some they could be easily passed with no difficulty.  Don't turn this into a nanny state for no good reason!", 'It would be easy for the government to stop companies from selling magnet spheres from inside the US.  However, its unclear exactly how the CPSC would stop importation of rare earth magnets of specific quantity, size, strength, and marketed purpose.  Over 97% of all rare earth magnets are manufactured China, and seeing as how impossibly burdensome of a task it would be for US customs to filter out certain times of magnets, the CPSC would really only be shutting down US companies.  So even though there is ZERO record of anybody swallowing magnet SOLD BY US, magnet spheres will become harder to obtain than ammunition in America because they are an ingestion hazard.  This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings," while never addressing the arguments against theirs.  If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy "Voice-of-Reason" Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:  \tThe assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress. \tThe ban is overly broad.  There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed:  Children under 5 tonguing their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings.  And the ban includes products (like Zen Magnets) that have not demonstrated similar risks. \tThese magnets have much more utility and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.  Thank you for your consideration.', "The proposed ban is overreaching and unreasonable, and would destroy at least one American business with no reported incidents involving their products. Zen Magnets are sold online to informed consumers, and as a result have not been involved in any of the reported child injury cases. This is blatant proof that removing small magnet sets from children's retail stores, and regulating their sale would be a successful alternative to an outright ban. The CPSC is aware of this situation and makes no accusations of injuries in their filing against Zen Magnets, yet is still determined to shut down the American small business for the failings of other resellers. Unfortunately in this case, the CPSC has decided that intimidation is favorable to regulation, and that Americans are incapable of being informed and responsible caregivers.", "The thought of banning magnet sets purely because they are harmful if swallowed is ludicrous. There are vast quantities of things that are not meant to be ingested that can cause serious harm or death if it occurs, many of which are found in almost every home in America.  Improper use of a countless number of every day items can be dangerous. The answer is to inform consumers. I suppose we should ban hair dryers because they can electrocute you if exposed wiring comes in contact with water, and you become the shortest path from the electricity to ground? Or cleavers because you could chop your fingers off if not careful? Or perhaps we shouldn't sell bleach and other cleaning chemicals, as if you were to mistakenly drink it you could poison yourself.  I don't understand how this got beyond the first conversation about it. Someone with some common sense should have put their foot down on this mind bogglingly ludicrous proposition, before wasting everyone's time with it and attempting to put American companies out of business. Pathetic.", 'As a Pediatric Gastroenterologist, I support these standards.  Rare earth magnets are very strong, sufficiently so that ingestion of multiple magnets can lead to perforations of loops of bowel requiring surgical repair.  While I acknowledge that the intent of the manufacturers and distributors is not to have children and adolescents ingest the magnets, unfortunately currently labelling has not prevented a large number of ingestions and injuries from occurring as has been reported in the Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and  Nutrition. These magnets need to go away--they are dangerous as has been reported.', "I own several sets of spherical magnets. I have for several years, and to date, have yet to ingest any of them. the idea that the federal government needs to prohibit the manufacture of this product, but doesn't see fit to intervene upon the manufacture of ammunition, guns, tobacco, et al, is ludicrous.", "I strongly disagree with a proposal to ban items such as BuckyBalls. They are fun. Don't be a buzzkill. Thanks.", "I disagree with the findings in this document.  Over the three year period Jan 1, 2009 to Dec 31, 2011 your own data showed at most 6000 cases of magnet related injury by children (all magnets, not just these sets).  More specifically, your data indicates a probable number of injuries around 1700 and only 50 specific reported incidents.  In 2009 alone, there were 4564 children confirmed killed by automobiles[1].  By your own logic, we should also ban the sale of automobiles since automobiles have a fatality rate almost 90 times greater in just that one year than injury rate over a 3 year period.  But we don't do that, because automobiles are for adults, not children (and they're marketed as such).  And like these magnet sets, when used by a responsible adult, they are harmless, educational and fun.  Any product, event or other interaction is dangerous when used irresponsibly.  It should not be this agency's responsibility to regulate responsible use, which is what this document proposes.  [1] http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm61e0416a1.htm", 'This is foolish. Regulations should not be imposed on such a broad scale. There is no way for government policy to guard against the foolishness of people. People will always be foolish. Banning the tools of their foolishness does nothing. There will always be more tools.', 'A blanket ban or prohibition would be a short-sighted and drastic over-reaction that does not resolve the primary issue at hand; the risk of injury due to ingesting of foreign bodies including magnets.  Was the possibility of adding a bitterant coating considered? Is there even any consideration towards mass community outreach/educating the public? (a PSA with the Ad Council comes to mind) Is there even any consideration towards educating the medical community especially if some incidents required a third or fourth opinion?  What about other foreign bodies such as button batteries which seem to pose a greater danger to children, including confirmed fatalities? (source: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6134a1.htm and http://www.poison.org/battery/stats.asp)  Same with coins. (source: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16157391)  More children have been treated for drug poisonings (excluding misuse and abuse) between 2004 and 2005 than the number estimated between January 1, 2009 to December 31, 2011. (source: http://www.cdc.gov/homeandrecreationalsafety/poisoning/poisoning-factsheet.htm and http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=CPSC-2012-0050-0001 )  More children have died due to heat-stroke in cars on average for that same period (2009: 33, 2010: 49, 2011: 33, 2012: 29 as of study date) than those injured by high-power ball magnets that "meet the above  definition of \'magnet set,\'" (38 cases) or by this type of magnet (5) combined (43 cases combined). (source: http://www.nhtsa.gov/DOT/NHTSA/NVS/811632.pdf and  http://ggweather.com/heat/deaths.jpg and http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=CPSC-2012-0050-0001 )  Public interest can be better served by promoting safe practices, awareness both in the general public and the medical communities as a blanket ban does not rule out all potential dangers of ingesting foreign bodies including magnets of any size.', 'Trampolines are marketed toward children and cause many more emergency room incidents per year than bucky balls.  This product is great for teaching science to kids and is also great for adults to learn and play with.  Please do not ban these products.', 'I am a resident of Montana currently attending Montana Tech of the University of Montana in Butte Montana. I have had my Zen Magnets for two years and let me just say; they are a life saver! From all the stress that college has presented me, I sometimes become so frazzled from all the homework and exams I have that the only way I can relieve stress is by making sculptures with my magnets.  Now I understand that the whole banning of the magnetic spheres is due to the fact that they can be lethal if swallowed. I understand that. First and for most, when I received my magnets two years ago, the first thing I noticed when I open the package was the warning label that stated that stated the magnets may be lethal if swallowed so the companies are definitely putting out an effort to ensure the safety of people who tinker with these magnets.Secondly, it is not the manufacturing companies fault for having issues with fatality due to magnets. Sure the magnets are very strong hence \'super\' magnet but that is all part of the product. Think of fireworks for example. the fireworks clearly state the warnings that go with the product and the danger of the firework is all part of the product. The problem with the fatalities from the magnets is parents are not watching their children when their children are playing with the magnets and do not notice the children placing the magnets in their mouths! Another reason is that some people are not "intelligent" enough to be playing with these magnets. It is their fault, not the manufacturing companies!!  If you are definitely sure of banning the spherical magnets, you might as well ban fireworks while you are at it. Compare the number of fatalities that are caused by fireworks accidents compared to the number of fatalities caused by spherical magnets. I guarantee the number of fatalities from magnets is much, much lower that the number from fireworks accidents.', 'To whom it may concern:  Please do not stop the selling of Zen Magnets, I enjoy them and they are a great stress reliever at my very stressful job.  Thank you', "The proposed ban on magnet spheres should not go through. Looking at the statistics for trampolines and skateboards - both marketed to children - these are both much more dangerous than the magnet spheres on the market.  Not to mention the over 5,000 childhood gun-related deaths every year!  Magnet spheres provide an enjoyable and somewhat educational way to pass the time. They don't present a serious public health hazard; ingestion represents a serious misuse of the product.  Please focus regulation on products that represent real and substantial risks to children. Leave magnet spheres alone.", "Slap a warning on them! They're awesome to play with. Parents need to watch their kids, not regulators. Science rules!", 'I do not believe that these magnets should be ban.', "I can't believe that this is even an issue.  Don't punish magnet manufacturers for bad parenting.  Anything found in a house could potentially pose a health hazard.", 'I am writing over concerns of these magnet sets.  They are not safe.  I have seen not only small children swallow these with disastrous consequences but also teenage children who inadvertently swallow them because they are using them as facial jewellry.  For example I saw a teenage girl who was using two magnets on either side of her tongue as a tongue ring when she swallowed them.    For children and teens who swallow these powerful magnets - it is costing the health care system many unnecessary dollars and causing the children untold trauma as they magnets may cause perforation and lasting damage to their gi tracts.    I feel strongly that these magnets should be banned.', 'Please do NOT ban spherical magnets. These are a fun and educational way to learn about magnetic forces.  All magnets of all kinds and shapes can be swallowed or injure, this does not in turn require a ban it requires education.', "Don't ban Bucky Balls. They are educational and people are learning as a result of them.", 'I would like to say that this proposed suit is a massive overreach of government regulation. These devices are very safe if used properly, and they encourage mental and cognitive development as well as creativity. Furthermore, I would consider these toys to be much safer than many commonplace, non-prohibited activities, especially automobile driving.  There is a very tangible benefit to these products that will be lost should these proceedings continue, not to mention the fact that this action is too drastic considering the low prevalence of substantial safety risks.', 'This proposed rule is the literal definition of a "nanny state" rule. The proposal targets not only products which have harmed people, but companies which have never once had a complaint filed against them. It also treats adults like children, and assumes that all parents are incompetent.   The way to deal with this is not regulation, but education. Making it so magnets are harder to purchase than ammunition solves nothing at all.', 'I have just been made aware of the proposed rule regarding magnet sets.  I have been the owner of such a set of magnets for some years as have other members of our family.  They have not only provided innumerable mind-stimulating hours  they have also provided an insight into the magnetic interrelationships that exist in many geometric formations that I would never had discovered without these magnets.    I have never experienced any non-optimum condition or circumstance arising from the use of such magnets and have in fact encouraged others to discover such sets of magnets because of their appeal.  No doubt due to their size they can be swallowed by anybody who so chose, however they pose far less risk to children or even adults than even the mildest of mind-altering drugs that are "completely safe."   There is no valid reason that I am aware of to propose much less pass legislation concerning the sale and use of magnets of this nature.', 'These earth magnets are made in colors and sizes that make them attractive to children. Children have being swallowing these in large numbers and they have become a major health harzard. They should be removed or restricted in the marketplace.', "I love these little magnets.... Please don't ban them. They should not suffer for the mistake very few kids make. Other products are more harmful to children and they remain on the market.", "Surely there are more important products that you should be looking into.  This poses a miniscule danger to the public.  Please don't respond to anecdotal scares with regulation. These are innovative products that spur curiosity, inventiveness and a greater understanding of physics and real-world practicality.", 'I hope that the committees and individuals who are evaluating this legislation use common sense when deciding on this regulation. Why should this type of product be prohibited in a sweeping ban because ingestion can harm children? There are many more products that are dangerous to children that are freely available to be purchased at retailers. Let parents be responsible and let the rest of us have access to these enjoyable toys. If you think parents may be uninformed about the dangers of the toys to children, then just simply require adequate warning labels. A ban however, is far from necessary.', 'Stop regulation of adult desk toys. This is ridiculous. This should fall to parental oversight, not governmental oversight.', 'I urge the  Consumer Product Safety Commission to uphold the ban on the small magnets that have caused serious injury and death in small children.  These magnets are easily eaten by children and often result in holes in the bowel needing surgery.', 'Why not educate people instead of just withdraw a great product?', 'Sculptable magnets are a toy for adults, and should continue to be available for sale for that purpose. I urge you to not make any additional regulations that would prevent this type of commercial activity.', 'I submitted a comment [below]: I believe these [rules are in violation of] 706(2)(a) as they are arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion. This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing under 556&557 should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.  These organizations have worked with the CPSC and done everything needed, and now the organization is acting in such a manner contrary to their previous prior dealings with the effected companies.  As a consumer, I think the CPSC is overreaching. Personal responsibility is key. We don\'t let children play with ball bearings, and we have not banned every magnet out there because of the potential (ab)use by children. Parents should be responsible and not let these ADULT TOYS fall within their hands.  I believe that there shou
column8: 140, -- Dear Sirs,   Please do not consider allowing foreign beef from Brazil or any other country in to the US beef market.80, -- This could result in health hazards and economic devastation on the US beef supply As a register voter, I cannot support this action2, -- The disease is easily transferred from one vector to the next (via vehicles, clothing etc) and could devastate our already low beef herd.84, -- If this is allowed, the imported cattle would be immersed into the food stream without consumers ever knowing they were eating meat from Brazil.105, -- It is time to support fellow citizens --the American ranchers and not allow Brazilian beef into the United States.116, -- HMD is easily transmissible and the beef health and safety protocols of other countries are not as stringent as in the United States.109, -- i AM A COW CALF PRODUCER IN TEXAS, should have never got this far.15, -- That person probably has never even set foot on a ranch yet we seem to be destined to be dictated by their ideals.61, -- Even myself, an avid meat eater, can no longer afford to eat beef more than a couple times a week.60, -- However, economic arguments either for or against importing hold no water at all.112, -- It has the largest cattle population of the country.3, -- Do not allow beef from Brazil into the United States of America at any time.3, -- Short term profit should not cloud the directive of the USDA to prevent importing ANY risk to our cattle herds here.112, -- The risk of reintroducing FMD back into the United States is low according to APHIS.112, -- Any chance of reintroduction at all is to high a risk.112, -- It would destroy our cattle markets, cost the economy millions of dollars a year and drive even more cattle producers out of business.131, -- Yellowstone Park felt it was politically correct to choose the no management  option for Yellowstone bison.
column9: 137, -- I oppose changes to the current rule we have in place which prevents importation of meat from Brazil.8, -- I worked with a Brazilian farm coop in 2005.16, -- Please DO NOT move forward with allowing these imports.100, -- Everything has increased in price, and does each year because of the middle man, not the weather.46, -- The additional risk to wild cervids, bison and other species is also of great concern to me.36, -- I have been in both countries and saw the corruption and infrastructure that could allow FMD or other FAD to enter the US.4, -- ? FMD has not been eradicated from Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela, and Peru.3, -- There is no certainty that symptoms of FMD may not be hidden, yet the animals may carry or transmit the FMD virus.10, -- APHIS has, in some cases, conducted quantitative risk assessments when considering regionalization requests such as this one.131, -- The recent Foot and Mouth outbreak in Europe was probably caused by illegally imported pork that was thrown out without being coked.126, -- WHY does the USDA feel the need to harm domestic agriculture?10, -- In my opinion, APHIS should but has not in a direct way outlined how the FMD risk from trans-shipments would be prevented.4, -- ? APHIS needs to refocus the consequence assessment to align with the scope of the risk assessment.131, -- The United States is host to a lot of wildlife.4, -- ? We cannot comfortably rely on a self-reporting system in Brazil to mitigate the U.S. risk for FMD.131, -- There are feral hogs in at least 38 states.131, -- How would you contain the disease in Yellowstone Park?
column10: 20, -- Importing cattle from Brazil will open up the US to possible Foot and Mouth disease.108, -- This country has been plagued with the most contagious disease disease known to cattle - foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD).126, -- Brazil has more than twice as many cattle as the United States, and the Brazilian herd is growing.61, -- All of my life I have been fiercely loyal to my community, state and country.60, -- Three, there are less cattle in U.S. herds because of prolonged drought on grazing lands.84, -- This proposal is not good for U.S. farmers and ranchers and it is not good for families.54, -- We have a very low rating for policing our standards on other countries.129, -- America will never be rid of this disease if this proposal is approved.3, -- We need to be able to compete with high quality exports to nations that do not want any chance of FMD.112, -- Tracking of boxes of meat aren't being tracked by lot #'s affecting traceability.131, -- Wildlife cannot be vaccinated, contained, or sacrificed for the good of the herd as livestock are.60, -- In Brazil, deforestation, overgrazing, soil compaction and adverse impacts to water quality are widespread.131, -- They preserved Brucellosis in the bison and spread it to other wildlife.131, -- That political move is costing millions yearly and the cost is adding up fast.131, -- Other countries are banning U.S. pork because of the new PED virus in North American hogs.131, -- They are right to do so and the U.S. should not risk importing the Foot and Mouth Disease virus.
column11: 29, -- Well this is the second time in several months that we have been asked to send our opinion on what the USDA is doing.61, -- I have watched mom and pop businesses disappear due to lack of local support.65, -- Likewise, any USDA protocols should be substantiated by sound, scientific evidence and that animal health regulations not be used as non-tariff trade barriers.10, -- For example, if deficiencies were found how were they corrected and if measures were recommended by APHIS, how were they addressed?60, -- In summary, it looks like this is much ado about nothing from the U.S. standpoint.131, -- Some tourists would have to undergo decontamination before returning home.
column12: 118, -- There is also the possibility that various countries, such as South Korea and Japan, etc.131, -- Older animals usually survive and may suffer chronic health problems after recovering.
column13: The US Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) has proposed allowing imports of beef from Brazil that could potentially contain foot and mouth disease. I do not agree with allowing the United States to import beef that could potentially contain foot and mouth disease from Brazil.
column14: Importing cattle from Brazil will open up the US to possible Foot and Mouth disease . This country has been plagued with the most contagious disease disease known to cattle - foot-and-mouth-disease (FMD)
column15: APHIS does not feel it is worth bringing in diseases from other countries . The most recent outbreaks of FMD within the proposed export region in Brazil occurred in 2006 . Currently there are 47,856 veterinarians in Brazil and only
column16: Whitefish City Manager/Finance Director Corey Swisher opposes changes to the current rule we have in place which prevents importation of meat from Brazil . Swisher: "I am also tired of paying for poor quality items imported from China
column17: The additional risk to wild cervids, bison and other species is also of great concern to me . I want to protect my body and my family's bodies as much as I possibly can . Our family has been in the cattle ranch

column2: ["I would also like to see the enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act's adequate  space provision at zoos and circuses along with all other means of appropriate  care for elephants.  It is a horrifying thought that items such as bullhooks, chains,  and electric hotshots are used to control such animals.  I am speaking out to ask  for improvement in living conditions for elephants and all other animals in zoos and  circuses.  Thank you.", 'It is bad enough that we have them locked up in cages.  At the very least those cages should be  the best that we can make.  This should be a no-brainer.  So many have said it so much better  than I ever could:  "Our task must be to free ourselves...by widening our circle of compassion to embrace all living  creatures and the whole of nature and its beauty."  - Albert Einstein  "The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are  treated" - Mahatma Gandhi  "When a man has pity on all living creatures then only is he noble."  --Buddha  "Compassion for animals is intimately connected with goodness of character; and it may be  confidently asserted that he who is cruel to animals cannot be a good man."  --Arthur Schopenhauer  "The animals of the world exist for their own reasons. They were not made for humans any more  than black people were made for whites or women for men." --Alice Walker', 'please save elephants', 'Elephants are very social and sensitive creatures. They should never be confined  in small spaces or forced to perform unnatural acts. They do not belong in  circuses or zoos. It is a contradiction in terms to state that children learn about  elephants in zoos unless you count being exposed to lies as learning. Instead of  viewing elephants as they normallly behave children view miserable animals  swaying back and forth without performing one natural act as in the wild.   Elephants need vast areas in which to roam and other elephants in which to  interact. They are highly intelligent creatures traversing miles each day in natural  settings. It sickens me that for profit and greed these majestic creatures are being  tormented. Breeding elephants in capitivity does not work. Those born in captivity  die which is another travesty. Bullhooks and harsh treatment should never be  allowed. It is appauling that so many circuses and zoos have been abusive to  elephants and the USDA has done little. I am asking you to now step up to the  plate and truly protect elephants instead of the special interest groups abusing  them.  Thank you for your time and cooperation.', 'Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.  Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the  zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended  periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.', 'To Whom It May Concern, I want to add my voice to those urging the USDA to improve enforcement and  standards for captive elephants in the US.  I support all efforts to dramatically  improve living conditions for captive elephants in zoos, circuses, etc.', 'Please improve the standards for the elephants. They are in captivity and thus  being so their lives are shortened. But giving them the best medical treatments,  enough exercise, and good living conditions will help. It just makes sense if we  take care of them they will stay alive longer and we can keep them in the zoos  and shows l know my daughter loves to see.', 'Let?s go Sci Fi here. There is water on Mars. We manage to get there to search out life forms. These life forms are intellectually superior and infinitely resourceful. They welcome us into their system as exhibitions, to be displayed as curiosities and encouraged to perform for their pleasure. You, your mother, father, brother, sister, wife, children, or any combination thereof, are in this group.   You are not provided sufficient space or healthcare while indentured and spend long hours chained up standing in your own excrement. You feel pain (arthritis), humiliation, and resent being prodded with bullhooks to perform or obey commands. What are you going to do about it?  In my little scenario, you are the elephant. Do something about it! Enough said.', 'As a citizen of the United States of America, I feel very strongly about providing  humane treatment to elephants.  If I had a choice, no animals would be allowed to  travel around the country in horrendous conditions.  However, if that is not  possible, I believe that we should at least make their living conditions humane.  (1)  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require  for their health and well-being.  (2)  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants  with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  (3)  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space,  but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range  of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  (4)  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  (5)  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination,  and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  (6)Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', "I am an avid supporter of both The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and The  Performing Animal Welfare Society in California who are outstanding leaders in  the care of retired, old, and ailing Elephants and who are willing and able to  provide the medical, emotional and physical care they need and deserve.  Both  TES and PAWS are accredited by the Association of Sanctuaries (TAOS) whose  philosophy and guidelines focus on meeting the elephants' needs rather than  forcing them to conform to a man-made system that often disregards their needs.  TAOS guidelines mandate not only much more indoor and outdoor space but  better quality of space, and prohibit the use of chains, bullhooks, electric prods,  and other punishments that are allowed in the AZA system!  Elephants in the wild are already experiencing enormous pressures from loss of  habitat and poaching. By removing more elephants from their homes, zoos are yet  another threat against their survival. Between the early 1960s and late 1980s, the  captivity industry captured and imported 368 baby African elephants. Forty-three  percent of those elephants are already dead. In fact, of the 92 who died just since  1990, 92 percent never even reached the age of 40. In the wild, elephants can live  to be 70. Captive elephants have suffered enough. Zoos must begin phasing out  their elephant exhibits by ending any future attempts to breed them or capture  more elephants from the wild.    Furthermore, Zoos, like circuses, are part of the entertainment industry, and use  elephants solely for financial profit.  NO ONE is inspired by seeing unhealthy,  neurotic elephants in zoo enclosures where, because of their intelligence,  complexity and unique social and physical needs, elephants suffer.  Unless a zoo can increase their standards of quality care to the level of what an  accredited Sanctuary like TES and PAWS can offer them, I am against zoos  having ANY Elephants.", 'I would like to ask that you see that elephants get the best care possible.  Which  would mean enforcing the Animal Welfare Act in every zoo and circus.  Most of  these places do not provide sufficient care for their elephants and you can change  this situation.  Thank you.', "Please -- do something about these poor elephants that we've put in zoos for our  own entertainment.  It's just wrong to take an animal from its natural habitat & put  it in a zoo simply for our pleasure -- plain & simple.  It's just wrong!  No human is  going suffer or feel like his/her life is incomplete by NOT seeing animals in zoos.   At the very least, please insist that the USDA comply with the AWA regulations &  please support the IDA petition.  I also ask you to seize the elephants who are  suffering in our zoos.  Elephants are suffering from many illnesses, including  arthritis.  As an arthritis suffer myself, I KNOW how awful it can be.  I know how  awful I'd feel if I were taken from my habitat & put into a cage for others to view.   How would you feel?  Please take action on these matters.  Thanks.", 'Please improve all living conditions for elephants in zoos and captive in circuses,  etc.  These animals are intelligent, gentle and deserving of living conditions similar  to the Elephant Sanctuary.  Why do we continue to whip-train and make them do  things they were not born to do? Thank you.', 'My belief is that elephants should have signifacantly large areas to roam in.  The  small areas provided by zoos is not sufficient for the animals health.  Chaining an  elephant down as done by travelling circuses is inhumane treatment and should  not be allowed.', "Please help the elephants...don't make them another endagered species.", 'Please require zoos and circuses to give elephants and all animals adequate  space and freedom.  It is common knowledge that these animals spend most of  their days chained or confined to small living spaces. This is so inhumane and  unnecessary. It has been proven that elephants experience many of the same  emotions as people including grief and do not deserve to spend their lives living in  misery. Please really consider this when making your decisions.', 'It?s heartbreaking to hear about elephants suffering and dying in the circus. On  August 5, 2005 Ringling Bros destroyed an 8-month-old elephant named Riccardo  after he suffered irreparable fractures to both hind legs when he fell off a circus  pedestal. And in 1999, Benjamin, a 4-year-old endangered baby elephant who had  been removed from his mother before she could teach him to swim, stepped into a  pond while the circus was traveling through Texas and drowned as he tried to  move away from a trainer who was poking him with a bullhook. These are just two  examples of the many elephants that have cruelly and senselessly died while  forced to be a part of the circus. While elephants can live to be 70 years old,  since the year 2000 over 25 elephants have died in zoos before reaching the age  of 35.  It?s time that people reject entertainment that entails the suffering of elephants.  Elephants, who in the wild roam over large distances, should not spend the  majority of their lives traveling in all sorts of weather conditions with chains on  their feet.  Elephants are extremely intelligent, social animals. Circuses, as well as zoos are  unable to provide elephants with a large enough area to roam, and with proper  stimulus.  In order for elephants in the circus to be shown "who?s boss" they are beaten with  bullhooks, whips, axe handles, and shocked with electric prods.  In addition to being cruel to the elephants, patronizing circuses with elephants  acts is also dangerous to people. Since 1990, rampages by captive elephants  have resulted in 65 human deaths and more than 130 human injuries.', 'There is absolutely no reason, excuse or need to justify using animals for entertainment purposes. We are ALL part of the same creation and if MAN is to be on "top of the food chain" then he should  be and feel responsible for animals\' welfare and survival instead of using and abusing them in  unnatural and cruel conditions. Government should hear its people and the cries of creatures who depend on us . This is the 21st century---let\'s begin to see the Universe as totally connected.And DO something  about it.', 'Please consider that elephants need to receive much more humane treatment.   They are currently allowed to be chained for long hours and live is very confined  spaces.  They are prodded and physically tormented in order to make them  behave in certain ways.  This is uncivilized and in a society that wants to be  viewed as a representative of humane care and compassion, this type of treament  of animals sends a strong negative message to the rest of the world.  Please push  for regulations that will afford compassionate treatment of elephants.', 'Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this  requirement. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation  that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and  foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like  swaying and head bobbing. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at  least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months. Circuses and  many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and aggressive use of  the bull hook and prolonged chaining. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to  provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary  in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide  hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and  maintain their health.', 'Please help this poor animal they dont deserve life sentence', '1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when  the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for  extended periods during the cold winter months.   5. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These  methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to  elephants.   6. Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs,  elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these  unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.', 'In reference to Docket No. APHIS-2006-0044-Animal Welfare; Elephants I support all efforts to drastically improve living conditions for elephants in this country. The level of cruelty with which these animals are treated by circuses, some zoos and other animal entertainment venues is appalling.   I?m requesting that you create tough new standards in the handling and treatment of elephants in this country, including enforcing the adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act.  Also, the use of bull hooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants should be prohibited.  Bull hooks cause severe pain and fear, and sometimes substantial injuries. In fact, baby elephants have been known to die from being beaten with bull hooks.    Exhibitors of elephants should provide large, climate appropriate areas where the elephants could live in an environment that is similar to what their natural habitats would be. Since they are very social animals, they should be able to interact with other elephants.', 'Zoos and circuses simply DO NOT provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being.     In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.   An estimated HALF of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of EUTHANASIA in captive elephants.    Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'I strongly support strict and immediate enforcement of the federal Animal Welfare  Act (AWA) at zoos and circuses.  Too often elephants suffer due to inadequate  space, unnatural conditions, lack of exercise and social deprivation. We are all  extremely aware of how intelligent elephants are and how deeply devoted they are  to family members.  We must do what is right and what is best for them', 'Most zoos and absolutley all circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their physical and mental health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. <br><br> In zoos and circuses elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing (I have personally seen these in the elephants who used to be at the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago). An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. <br><br> Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Personally, I no longer attend circuses for this reason.  I have seen video footage and the unbelievable cruelty circus elephants endure and it is gut-wrenching.  If you have any doubt about the validity of claims of circus cruelty, go the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals website www.circuses.com and watch the footage.  <br><br> Circuses and some zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are completely unnecessary and must be outlawed IMMEDIATELY. In my opinion, if you have to use these cruel tactics to control these animals, you should not have them in the circuses or zoos in the first place.  End of story.<br><br> Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, naturalistic environments for the elephants.  Gold standard examples of such surrounding are those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. <br><br> The bottom line is we human broughts these animals into captivity, and we continue to breed them in captivity, for our entertainment.  We therefore have a moral obligation, and we should have a legal obligation, to treat these elephants with a higher level of compassion and respect than they are currently receiving.', "One need only see elephants in the wild to understand how cruel and wrong it is  to keep them in captivity, whether in a zoo, or in a circus, or any other unnatural  environment.  Elephants are social animals and travel together in herds over  hundreds of miles.  In order to stay healthy they need to live in the environment  they were meant to be in, meaning a place where they roam free, eat the food  nature provides them, socialize with their own kind, and have dirt, not cement  under their feet. To keep an elephant chained up, as is done in a circus setting, or  to limit it to an enclosed space consisting of an acre or sometimes less, as is  done at a zoo is simply not an acceptable way to treat these wonderful creatures.   Instead of seeing them at a zoo or circus where they are unhappy captives, they  can be viewed on websites such as National Geographic's, where they can be  observed in the wild as they were meant to be.  I urge you to ban the captivity of  elephants in any capacity, and to allow the ones currently in zoos and circuses to  be sent to an elephant sanctuary where they will at least be together and have  more room to roam around.", 'Elephants need to have freedom for their health and well being which zoos and  circuses are not providing.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.  Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation  that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and  foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like  swaying and head bobbing.  Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the  zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended  periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres  over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.', "To be perfectly honest I think a closer look needs to be focused on the elephant  Santuaries than at zoo's and circus. Most zoo's take very good care of the  elephant's and the  elephant's have a better life at the zoo's. They get a better  quality of food and medical treatment at zoo's. Where they possibly do not at  these santuaries because the elephant sancuaries are not regulated by the USDA  or or any animal welfarfe agency. Most zoos also house bull elephants where the  santuaries will not take bulls. I have observed the handling and care giving of many  elephants at zoos and i have found nothing wrong with the treatment. I have not  seen a keeper need to use the elephant hook nor have I seen elephants chainedfor  extended periods of time. I am not saying every zoo is perfect and maybe some  do need a look at but to be realistic the zoos should get more money for these  beautiful creatures. As for circuses I do think these smaller zoos that are popping  up should not have elephants or any exotic animals for that matter. But as for the  Ringling Brothers circus they have a wonderful facility for their elephants in Flordia  and they will also donate an elephant to zoos that may have on;y one elephant. I  strongly feel the closer look needs to be on these sancuaries. I think they are  cruel and not an acceptable establishment to house and keep elephants.", "I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive elephants in the U.S.,  where zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and  well-being. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces, but in too many zoos and circuses they  suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range  of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive  disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. To make matters worse, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day  when closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the  cold winter months. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and  aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those  at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their  health. The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force must be  outlawed. The New York Times magazine just featured a story on how humans are basically driving elephants  crazy. What's even sadder is how similar we are to them, obviously not physically, but emotionally.  They need our cooperation - after all, we SHARE the planet. Thank you for your consideration,", 'In the wild, elephants walk many miles each day. (While we were in Kenya, we  saw many herds of elephants--and none of them were suffering from foot disease!)  There is no zoo that has enough space to house elephants in a natural and  healthful way. Standing for many hours each day--or being confined to a small  space leads to painful--and often fatal--diseases of the legs and feet. Thhose unfortunate elephants that now live in captivity should be sent to spacious,  well-regulated and inspected elephant sanctuaries.', 'I emphatically support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive  elephants in the USA.  This includes enforcing existing adequate space  requirements under the Animal Welfare Act, and by creating tough new standards.  All exhibitors should be required to provide large, naturalistic climate-appropriate  environments   No elephant shall be kept alone but rather with other elephants of its  species...Asians with Asians, Africans with Africans..just as in the wild.  ABSOLUTELY PROHIBIT the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices  and other instruments of force used to coerce and punish elephants  Of particular concern to me is the African elephant Maggie, at the Anchorage Zoo. It is utterly inhumane to keep this poor elephant in the artic environment she is  kept in.  How cruel that she is alone, has to stay locked indoors for most of the  year, and undoubtedly suffers psychologically.  Please help Maggie by overriding  the zoo board and the AZA and have her sent to The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee where she can live with other African elephants in total freedom and in  a more natural and comfortable climate.', "I support all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country. Please create tough new standards,  with mention to the following: ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'Considering the size of these magnificent creatures and their natural habitat  needs for food and community, captivity at zoos and in circuses is incredibly  inhumane treatment as none of these facilities can provide adequate space to  meet the basic needs of these highly intelligent and social animals.  In fact, Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to  21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling  in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   I hope in my lifetime I will see an end to the cruel practice of having captive  elephants in circuses and zoos. Thank you!', "The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos & circuses provide elephants with  adequate space.  Neither Zoos or circuses currently meet these requirements.  In these venues, elephants suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and  social deprivation that cause irreparable damage to their physical & mental health.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggresive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs,  and electrick shock devices.  These are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at the Elephant Sanctuary in Tennesses and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California.    Actually, in my opinion we don't need to capture any wild animal just so we can  look at them.  Thank you for your time.", 'Elephants in the wild typically walk 10 to 20 miles each day.  They need large areas of land to maintain their physical health.    Zoos and circuses cannot and do not provide adequate space for elephants.  Zoos and circuses also confine these animals indoors for many hours a day during cold weather.  These unnatural conditions often lead to foot disease which is painful and can eventually cause death.  Force is often used to control elephants and
column3: ['I am a supporter of accredited zoological facilities and aquariums and marine parks and have been personally inspired by my experiences at Georgia Aquarium.  I applaud APHIS for evaluating, and where necessary, updating the regulations by objectively assessing the latest peer reviewed science and input from industry experts on the best practices for care of these incredible animals.
