I am concerned that individuals and groups opposed to marine mammals in a zoological settings misuse the process of updating marine mammal care regulations in their attempts to end the display marine mammals.  They do so by encouraging APHIS to impose rules which are not necessary, counter to decades of successful care programs and processes, and impede the great education and conservation work done by the zoological community.  I encourage APHIS to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based upon on the merits of applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards; in cases where insufficient literature exists, input and observation of successful practices within the industry should be strongly considered.', 'My name is Heather Franklin.  I am a former Sea World and Discovery Cove marine mammal trainer and a professional animal trainer of 18 years.   I have had the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the regulations and would like to submit the below comments for consideration.  The additional regulation components specific to interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of programs. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation, or how further regulation would benefit marine mammals.  As a trainer, I feel that if interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, programs in which trainers bring marine mammals, such as, but not limited to pinnipeds, into a public area under stimulus control.  I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best.   Each animal is so different.  So many factors go in to how long each session should run and what they will entail for each particular animal.  In my professional experience working in an interaction program, the amount of interaction time each animal had per day could vary depending on many details including but not limited to: recent and long term behavioral history, social structure/hierarchy, and breeding behaviors.  The training team makes an approximate plan for how the day\'s training and programs will run, but it ultimately is up to the animals how the day flows, not legislation.  To put regulations/time restrictions on trainers and animals seems counterproductive.  We treat animals as individuals and need the flexibility to provide an individualized training program for each of them.  Training is not one size fits all, nor is one size is best for all.   In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day. With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.  As a trainer, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Again, one size does not fit all.  One particular behavior that is harmless in one animal can be a pre-cursor to something completely different in another animal. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an INDIVIDUAL, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    Trust animal care and training professionals to make the best decisions for their animals. They have dedicated their lives to the animals in their care!  I would like to thank APHIS for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and that you did not feel compelled to unnecessarily change regulations. Thank you!', 'I am writing to express my support of revision to the Animal Welfare Act and to ask to go beyond that - even more revisions are required to protect marine mammals in captivity.  The proposed update does address deficiencies in the current law, most particularly "swim with dolphins" programs which are unregulated and have been since 1999.  I support the proposed ruling to provide sufficient shade to animals in outdoor pools so the animals can get out of direct sunlight.  More space in the pools is also needed, and while this isn\'t in the  proposed update to the law, it should be.  The pitiful sized pools that these animals have to spend their entire lives in is horribly cruel and inhumane.  No reason at all why they shouldn\'t be given more space except for the people who don\'t want to pay for it.  Revised laws should make them give the animals better living conditions, including more space.  The overall improvements suggested in the proposed rulemaking are necessary to improve animal welfare and should be adopted and expanded upon.', 'Decisions should be based on fact and research. Please do not let the ever-changing social climate to de-rail decades of research and species conservation.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  The animals deserve the best, and Seaworld is the best.', "Please do not take the learning from the new generations of students, i.e. the children.  They are truly our future and hopefully they will learn more than the generations who have come before them.  We all share what we leave on this planet, and my grandchildren gain more knowledge every encounter.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Children need to be able to see these animals being cared for up close.  A book doesn't make it real for them. Please make sure the children and future generations can continue to learn up close.", 'Please make your regulations based on facts not on hype.  We need marine mammal facilities and zoos and animal parks.  Both to learn about and to save animals, as well as connect them with the public.  Please base any new or updates to your rules on facts not a small percentage of manipulative activists who through the internet and liberal media outlets can appear larger than they are.    If people cannot make personal connections with animals in the safety of these facilities they are not personally moved at all to care about them or the enviroment or to take actions to protect it.  "Touch the heart, change the mind".  This is what these facilities bring a chance to connect with your heart and change your way of thinking.  They have steadily improved over the years in ways you well understand.  Please stand in the gap with truth and base any updates on proven research not manipulative activism.  Thanks for all you do!  I have personally been educated as a biological sciences major at university and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to and observations at SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for and about by animal care experts.  They are not only taking care of these animals but they are well educated in the sciences and have taken the time to answer many of my questions regarding these topics.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding, caring and respectful appreciation of the wildlife in the natural world.  Encountering these animals at parks like seaworld causes me to appriciate how wonderful they are in a way that i simply have NEVER been able to in the wild.  I think of that social connection that i made with animals in parks when i think of those animals in the wild and that visual memory of what that animal is like in my personal encounter is what invests me into protecting that animal i will never or seldom see in the wild.  Thank you for your part in keeping that connection available to millions of people like me.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks as well as zoos and wild animal parks for years to come.  I know you will probably get many form letters.   I want you to know this is one that i have taken the time to modify and include my actual thoughts and feelings.  I hope someone is able to take the time to read it.  And stand up for these wonderful facilities that truely do facilitate our learning and touch are heart to change our mind.  Interaction thats what makes us really care.  Thank you.', 'Dear Dr. Kohn,  Orca in tanks captivity issues such as confined spaces, 0 underwater acoustics/brain enrichment, motionless at the surface for 20 hrs/day, water quality and more can easily be solved with seaside sea pens. There are hundreds of very well protected sea pen sites to chose from. As a captain I often have to seek out safe anchorages for the storms to pass. A seaside sanctuary would have to be located in a similar safe and secure natural harbor.   The animals would continue to need 24/7 human care and protection for the rest of their lives. The public would still have access. The scientists and researchers would have more opportunities to do research and with more meaningful results. It is a simple win win win situation. The change would be a protracted event that could so easily be implemented,... animal by animal.  The biggest challenge for a seaside sea pen sanctuary would be taking care of the humans not the orca.  I encourage you to research sea pen options and create new captive regulations that would make it economically more feasible for the captive industry to pursue sea pen alternatives instead of expanding the concrete holes, building expensive shade covers, installing larger circulation pumps with more chlorine, etc.  The concrete tank confined orca will thank you.  I thank you for listening, Michael Parks', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please support the life-saving care that SeaWorld and other related facilities give to the marine life and do whatever is needed to keep these facilities in full operation.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  The treatment of marine wildlife in captivity is heartbreaking to witness, and needs to be scrutinized in depth, and policies updated... or abolished entirely.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I support marine mammal  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'As a former member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.     IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Our Family trip to SeaWorld to experience real animals was fantastic. My two teenage boys were in awe of the killer whales and dolphins. They respect nature, and their environment. We as a family could never afford these experiences in the wild and we know that SeaWorld cares for and respects the animals in their care as well.', 'As a zoo volunteer I can attest that zookeepers, administrators, management and staff, who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, always  make of the welfare of those those animals their first priority.    They consistently work to provide those animals with opportunities for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with and work to assure that proven best-practices are adhered to. The proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.    If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.    Finally, the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors causes concern. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.   I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.  Tanya Rose', 'Sea World has been an important part of our life in our family. We have 3 children who have all been impacted in a positive way by the amazing things going on at Sea World!  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.
