It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for your
column4: ['I, as a cattle producer and consumer of the United States of America and the State of South Dakota, oppose the importation of any beef from the country of Brazil. Brazil has clearly demonstrated that it lacks the ability to regulate and eradicate the Foot and Mouth Disease, and if imported I feel this would put the cattle industry of United States in grave danger.  I oppose this proposed rule.  Shawn Fox Mobridge, South Dakota', 'Yes, the national beef herd is small now. But calf prices are high and ranchers will increase their herds. If you allow this imported beef  prices will drop and the national herd will get smaller and  the United States will loose its food self sufficency! And this is even more likely if Foot and Mouth Disease is spread to the USA.  Ranching is hard work and very cash intensive compared to other buisnesses, please keep the financial reward at a level that permits ranchers to operate.', 'I am opposed to allowing the importation of beef in any form from Brazil. Doing so would greatly increase the risk of introducing Foot and Mouth disease to the US and would be disastrous to our cattle industry and our economy. A Foot and Mouth Disease outbreak would cause a dramatic increase in the cost of beef for US consumers and would be an even further setback to the cattle industry. We are already at a record low cattle inventory and the destruction of animals required by an outbreak would be devastating. I own a small farm and raise cattle as part of my operation. The cost of expanding my cow herd is already very expensive. Why add another risk to producers when there are already so many others that are out of our control? I strongly recommend against adopting this rule.', 'Brazil has active hoof and mouth disease, it is not worth the risk to the US cattle industry to allow this importation. Keep the US foremost in your thoughts and plans.', 'As a cattle producer I am very much opposed to any cattle or beef imported from any part of Brazil !!!', "I am a ranch wife and mother of a large family, who mostly live and work in ranch country.  Do not allow the interests of a few to undermine beef production here in our homeland.  Ranching is really the only viable option to sustainably manage most of the rangeland in our United States.  If you break the ranch producers, what will take their place?  On one hand, the USDA is seeking ways to keep young people actively ranching out here in the Western states, and on the other hand, USDA APHIS is actively seeking to sabotage and undermine that very same effort.  Stop working against your very own country and turning it into a wasteland.  Stop imports from damaging our own producers both in the market and through exposure to FMD and other possible diseases. I am submitting this on behalf of my children and grandchildren as well as in my husband's and my own best interest to keep rural communities and schools and tax bases in stable condition enough to continue into the future.", 'Please do Not allow Brazilian beef, goats cloven food into US to eat. Pamela Campus', "Having the safest food supply in the world I don't know why we would endanger it with bringing in a known disease that would destroy what is left of the US cattle Industry.", 'This will surely result in Foot and Mouth Disease in USA.  We cant even keep donkey meat out of our imported beef products', 'The proposed rule talks of risk mitigation; yet, here in the U.S. there are periodic meat recalls when the "system" breaks down, the most recent being the 8.7 million pound recall by Rancho Feeding Corp.  While there is an ongoing criminal investigation, the fact remains that meat recalls are a fact of life in the U.S. and that there are system breakdowns.  If meat recalls due to system breakdowns cannot be eliminated domestically, how can "mitigation" of risk be accomplished when a foreign nation and a host of transportation issues are involved?  Any importation of fresh meat from a nation that has FMD results in an INCREASED RISK, regardless of "mitigation" measures.  A FMD infection from Brazil would be devastating for the United States Cattle industry.  The question needs asked:  qui bono? -- who benefits?  Certainly not American ranchers.  That USDA/APHIS would even promulgate this rule is shocking,  irresponsible and an abdication of statutorily imposed obligations.  But again, much of what USDA does today--livestock ID/traceability being another example--is contrary to the interests and expressed concerns of U.S. ranchers.  USDA promulgates rules but never listens to those affected by its rules.  As a cow-calf producer whose income is derived solely from our operation, I am vehemently opposed to the proposed rule.', "I am strongly opposed to this.  Our government is currently spending staggering amounts of money to harass the people that provide us with clean, safe, healthy beef and to cause the reduction of our own beef production.  We shouldn't at the same time be planning to import beef that will endanger the health and safety of US wild and domestic animals.", "I am strongly against the importation of Brazilian beef. This will impact the price of beef and will be one more obstacle for the American farmer who struggles enough the way it is. The price of feed,equipment, and lease rates have followed the rise in cattle prices the last 5 years and will more than likely not decrease with the drop in price this would create. I also believe it would put the U.S. herd or it's consumers in jeopardy by introducing hoof in mouth disease or other diseases we are not aware of yet. I believe this is a step back for the American farmer and America in general.", 'This has got to be the most idiotic importation ever considered.    I attended the Foreign Animal Laboratory in the later years of 1988-1990.  Just prior to that time , we were told that Foot & Mouth Virus had  gotten out onto the Plum Island!  This island was covered with lots of head high brush-- & had a population of deer!  Because of the possible of deer being able to swim to the mainland (possible, not feasible)-- the Army was brought in & every deer was killed!  While there, every few days we went outside , while smoke bombs we used inside.  All of us watched from leaks from those old Laboratories !   Those old buildings did developed leaks !!!     I am so pleased that new facilities are being build in Manhattan, Kansas !!!  The most frightful foreign animal has got to be Foot & Mouth !!  DO NOT CONSIDER MEAT IMPORTS FROM ANY COUNTRY THAT HAS IT!!!!   Sincerely, Allan T. Kimmell,  DVM', 'I strongly oppose the importation of beef or any other animal product from any region of Brazil. Hoof and Mouth (Foot and Mouth) Disease is by all practical measures ubiquitous and it is blatantly reckless to claim that areas of Brazil can be declared disease fee.  It is a disease that is easily spread with or without human interventions and the virus has been shown to persist in animal products long into periods of cold storage. It is nothing short of a miracle that the US has not experience a Hoof and Mouth outbreak but I believe such an outbreak would be swift and inevitable if this importation is allowed. Please DO NOT allow the importation of Brazilian Beef.', 'I am against the inportation of live cattle, fresh and/or frozen beef from Brazil.  Your first responsibility is to protect the U.S. cattle from hoof and mouth diease and mad cow diease, both of which are in the Brazilian cattle herds.  Why try to destroy the U.S. live cattle industry.  This is as dumb as moving the Plum Island research facility into the heart of cattle country as there are always leaks.  Thank you.', 'Products coming from Brazil are not regulated and could bring in diseases and unsanitary products.  We cannot risk that happening to us.', "There is too much danger of bringing foot and mouth disease into the U.S. if you allow any beef to be brought here from Brazil. Our country is free of that disease but if you allow Brazil's meat to be brought here, we are likely to start having outbreaks. No matter how careful they promise to be, there's too much danger.", 'This rule should not be implemented!  This country does not need to be exposed to FMD from any country that has it.', 'Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the proposed rule that would allow the importation of beef from several states in Brazil. As President of Minnesota Farmers Union (MFU), and National Farmers Union (NFU) Secretary, I am writing for thousands of farmers across the country.  NFU policy is clear in its position regarding importation of livestock products from countries that have a history of unresolved foot and mouth disease (FMD). The following is an excerpt from the recently adopted grassroots policy statement from NFU members:  Livestock health is critical to production agriculture and our nations ability to provide a safe food supply. Achieving the necessary means to ensure livestock health is a priority for NFU. We support good animal husbandry practices as the primary means of livestock health maintenance, as well as the following initiatives to ensure livestock health: Ban livestock, animal protein products and meat imports that would jeopardize U.S. efforts to eradicate livestock diseases including BSE and Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD);  We strongly oppose the proposal to resume importation of fresh beef from the fourteen Brazilian states listed in the federal register notice. Our members contend that FMD from that region of Brazil still poses a significant threat to U.S. livestock herds. Any changes to the current ban could pose substantial threats to family farmers, ranchers and the general public due to the very real possibility of transmission of FMD to U.S. livestock, resulting in eroded consumer confidence in our food supply.   MFU is concerned by rulemaking processes at the USDA that may weaken disease protection measures critical to protecting domestic livestock from the introduction of FMD and other animal diseases, particularly from Brazil. Inconsistencies between animal health disclosures reported by the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) and the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), erode our confidence in the safety of beef imports from countries with a history of FMD presence and a poor food safety record. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recalled Brazilian cooked and canned meat on three occasions in 2010 due to drug contamination.   Previous import bans implemented by USDA have divided our trading partners into sub-national geographic regions that are largely insulated from other livestock-producing areas, thereby limiting risk of FMD transmission. The fourteen states that are being considered by this USDA rulemaking process are but one of the four regions in Brazil. The last case of FMD in the fourteen-state region in Brazil was in 2001. Even though the fourteen Brazilian states in question are considered to be FMD-Free by the OIE, regular vaccinations are required. Brazil has not been able to prevent the spread of FMD into its borders from neighboring countries, and as recently as 2011, Paraguay reported two outbreaks of FMD within 250 miles of the Brazilian border.   MFU members are proud of the disease prevention system that has been in place for livestock in the United States, which has not had a confirmed case of FMD since 1929. This is an advantage to be developed and must not be put at risk. There are very few positives associated with allowing livestock products from regions of Brazil that are known to have a history of FMD to be brought into our country. There are many possible undesirable outcomes from such an arrangement. Importing Brazilian beef and other livestock products is a risk not worth taking.  U.S. farmers and ranchers are known throughout the world for the high standards to which livestock herds are raised and our long-standing disease prevention efforts. In the rare instances when disease has impacted a portion of the livestock herd, economic devastation has followed. When Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) was first identified in the U.S. in December of 2003, sixty-five of our trading partners eventually put partial or full bans on our beef. According to a Kansas State University study, the U.S. beef industry lost between $2.9 billion and $4.2 billion in 2004 alone because of BSE. Rural America should not again be subjected to severe losses simply because of lax standards for animal imports.  The economic costs of an FMD outbreak in the United States would be tremendous. A 2002 study conducted by Purdue University and the Centers for Epidemiology and Animal Health at APHIS found that if an epidemic similar to the outbreak that occurred in the U.K. in 2001 were to strike the United States, a loss of $14 billion in U.S. farm income (in 2002 dollars) would result. This includes costs of quarantine and eradication of animals, a ban on exports, and reduced consumer confidence.   On behalf of MFU members, I urge USDA to defend family farmers and ranchers by turning back this attempt to loosen restrictions on imports from countries that are affected by FMD. Thank you for your consideration.', 'I do NOT support the importation of beef products (frozen or not) from Brazil.', 'Please do not let these imports come into America.  Farmers and ranches strive to keep our meat supply safe and our beef healthy.  It is time to think of Americans and their livelihoods.  I am not convinced that the beef coming from Brazil is foot and mouth disease free.  Lets make other countries have as strict of regulations as Americans do in all aspects of imports.', 'Allowing beef imports from a country that has FMD is the equivalent of playing Russian Roulette with the US Meat supply.  This proposal is slightly more ignorant than placing the National Disease Lab in Manhattan, Ks. This is the most contagious disease known.  It will escape the lab. It will be imported from Brazil if this is allowed. Randall Hinde, D.V.M.', 'I am in favor of importing chilled and frozen beef from Brazil.  The price of beef has hit record highs every week.  A few years ago the beef industry was concerned at the increase in the price of corn would cause the consumer to pay more.  They have no concern now whether the consumer pays more or not.  They tried to destroy the ethanol industry (and still are)  to get cheap corn with no concern for the corn grower.      If the meat from Brazil is chilled or frozen, that should pose no danger of diseases to the cattle industry.  They want the import gates closed and the export gates wide open, and that on top of an already short supply of beef.  $250 per hundred calves and $150 per hundred fats is unbelievably high.  The fat market is five times higher then when I feed cattle.        Please allow frozen and chilled beef from Brazil to help lower prices to the consumer.', 'NO imported meat from any country which has, or is adjacent to, a country/region with known FMD!', 'Please do not do this!!! We do not want hoof and mouth disease to spread through our livestock! What will happen to all of the small farmers?  Please do not do this!  Bad idea!!  Stephen W.  and Elizabeth Albery  John 3:17', 'It is very irresponsible to potentially put American beef producers at risk to the highly contagious Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD), and force producers to manage a disease that does not exist in this country.  Paraguay imported Brazilian beef from supposedly FMD free areas; now Paraguay is infected with FMD.  I also think this is an attempt to manipulate the live cattle market with captive supply. The USDA has already allowed Brazil to control the beef packing and processing segment with JBS.  We should not sell their beef!   I am vehemently opposed to importing Brazilian beef!  Protect American beef producers and agriculture.', "Stop this now, we don't need to depress our livestock market. With the blizzard in the midwest, the producers don't need a depressed market when they are trying to recover. We also don't need anymore disease's coming into this country.", 'I vote against the importation of beef from Brazil due to the overwhelming possibility of contaminating American foods with Hoof and Mouth Disease.', 'As a veterinarian and a beef producer; I oppose the importation of beef from Brazil.  Our nations beef farmers need our support, particularly from a bio-security perspective. FMD in the USA would be catastrophic to beef, dairy and swine production and consumer supply.   Secondly, my visits to Brazil to look at beef and dairy production have given me an understanding that their current system does not have comparable quality assurance for the animals, the product, and particularly their workers. I do not believe we should expect American producers to meet environmental, animal welfare, quality assurance, and labor standards, but then allow importation of product that may not be held to the same expectations and requirements.   Third, our US beef herd has shrunk to its lowest level in 50 years. We need economic incentives to increase our national herd. We will not accomplish this with importation of product from Brazil.', 'Importing beef from a "region" in Brazil is not a good idea.  The proposed rule describes a "region" in Brazil that is surrounded by and part of a larger region of South America that is not free of FMD.  While the proposed rule praises the steps that have been taken by the Brazilian government to make it more likely that they can "control" an outbreak should it occur in the "region," those measures will not keep an outbreak from occurring in the first place.    The most effective way to keep FMD out of a "region" in Brazil that is surrounded by and part of a larger region of South America that is not free of FMD is to offer no financial incentive to bring cattle or other livestock from the larger region into the FMD free "region."  If the FMD free "region" is allowed to export beef to the United States, this will cause a significant increase in the value of cattle in that "region." This increased value will be a huge financial incentive to bring cattle from the larger region into the FMD free "region."  These cattle that people sneak into the FMD free "region" will sooner or later bring FMD with them.  That FMD will sooner or later get exported to the United States. A good example of how difficult it can be to control a border is the border between the United States and Mexico.  The financial incentive to cross illegally makes it impossible to keep people from crossing illegally. If you offer a financial incentive to bring cattle into a "region," those cattle will come to that "region\' whether or not it is legal.  The proposed rule compares FMD free "region" in Brazil to the nation of Uruguay. However, the FMD free "region" in Brazil is much larger than the nation of Uruguay, with much more border to protect.  Also, it is not a nation, it is a collection of states.  I live in Texas, which is bordered by four states and by Mexico.  It is much easier to get cattle to and from the neighboring states than it is to get them to and from Mexico.  The comparison to Uruguay is not relevant to the issue of importing beef from a "region" in Brazil.', 'Do not pass this rule, allowing fresh beef to be imported to the US from Brazil and Argentina.  If there is ANY chance that FMD could come into the country through these means because they do not have as strict protocols as the US and other countries we trade with than it should not be allowed.', "First let me say I have no ties to the beef industry.  I also will say that it is a rare occasion (a couple times a year) that I eat any kind of beef because I don't care for it.  This idea of allowing beef into this country that comes from a country that has hoof and mouth disease is just ridiculous.  The reasoning is also foolish-to bring down the price of beef.  If that disease is re-introduced into this country and thousand of cattle have to be killed because they have contracted it, that certainly will not bring down the price of beef.  Whoever thought that this was/is a good idea needs to be fired.", 'Importation of beef from Brazil should not be allowed. The risk of transmission of FMD is too high. Inability to inspect or control disease laden cattle should prevent importation.', "I am a rancher in Central Texas. I am opposed to importing fresh beef from Brazil because of the high risk of FMD (foot-and-mouth disease). There is a history of FMD in Brazil and countries that surround it have it now. Just one case in the USA could wreck our export markets like the first Mad Cow case did in 2003. It has taken 10 years to recover from Mad Cow. Just think what harm many cases of FMD would do to our industry and the nation's economy as well. Certainly a costly war against FMD would emerge and our inventory of beef cattle would spiral down - 320 million Americans would be negatively impacted, not to mention, our border neighbors. This rule to allow fresh beef from Brazil is unreasonable. DO NOT PASS IT.", 'I think anyone working for the USDA that proposes we import livestock or meat from countries known to have foot and mouth disease needs to be fired! They have no business receiving a paycheck from the American public.  The same goes for ANY of our elected officials that allow JBS to manipulate and control our beef markets.', 'I do not think it is a good idea to import beef from Brazil because of all the health issues asscoiated with Brazilin beef. We have so much better inspecting rules and why risk both human health and our beef industry inorder to have cheap food. The beef  industry is in a high cycle right now and it wil cycle back down eventually. Importing beef is too much of a chance to take with our food supply and the health of our people.', 'I would like to say that letting South American cattle in. Either on the hoof or otherwise. Could be a very big health risk and could devastate the US cattle market. It could make it unsafe for years to come, in the consumers eyes.   Therefore I am very much opposed to any such move.   Jerry Mader', "FORGET IT   YOU REQUIRE MEXICO AND CANADA WHICH ARE OUR PRIMARY TRADE PARTNERS UNDERGO MAJOR DOLLARS IN DISCOUNTS FOR  COOL . WHERE IN MEXICO'S CASE THESE ARE CATTLE THAT ARE GRAZED FED AND KILLED IN THE US  I SAY AGAIN DO NOT APPROVE THIS", 'Allowing the importation of raw beef from countries with foot and mouth disease would border on criminal negiglence.', 'This is one of the many disconcerting issues left in the hands of the USDA.  By simply looking at the list of possible communicable livestock diseases that would inevitably be introduced into the U.S., it should be apparent that the importation of foreign beef/meat would ultimately wreak havoc on our native livestock, as well as our own health.  The disease potential aside, the USDA cannot account for the quality of the meat being imported.  Based on the loose regulation that is currently rampant in our food system (and by loose, I mean the chemical concoctions and antibiotics that are still used to raise U.S. livestock and plant foods), we cannot rely upon the USDA to have our best interest in mind.', "Brazil's beef and other animals are highly diseased with hoof and mouth disease and other deadly diseases. The US does NOT need this nasty stuff,  nor do we want it.  It will harm our farmers and our animals AND OUR PEOPLE.", "Did I read the article correctly 'USDA to invite Brazilian beef into the U.S. despite FMD problems'? The USDA admits it could break the U.S. cattle market and make us susceptible to FMD. Are they absolutely out of their minds? I would think that the common sense approach if you KNOW of these potential consequences would be to avoid them at all costs. I shake my head in amazement at yet another government boondoggle that affects the American citizens in negative way. It makes me think that they are purposely trying to destroy this country. It makes my blood boil.", "I am completely 100% against the importation of Brazil beef into the United States.  We do not need a flood of foreign meat into this country ever.  But to even think about it at this point and time would be devastating to US Ranchers.  Our cattle market prices at this time are good but they need to stay this way.  Importing Brazilian meat would bring these prices down and wreck our markets.  Our farmers and ranchers have been through many tough times lately between drought and severe  fall storms that have greatly impacted our cattle industry in the Midwest.  There are many operators who are still trying to catch up from reducing or selling off their herds to due the latest drought.  High feed costs during this period set them back as well.  Plus the severe winter storm earlier this fall that drastically killed thousands of head of cattle in the Dakotas, Wyoming, and Nebraska.  This storm impacted so many ranchers by great loss of percentages of numbers in their cow herds,  thus reducing this year and further years income.  We need prices to sustain to keep people operating in the cattle industry.  These ranchers need to be able to catch back up and stay in business as well as give young people an opportunity or hope of getting into the cattle industry and be able to make a living.  Increased farming due to government guarantees on crop loss or disaster has decreased grazing available because more and more grass is being broken and farmed.  This has lead to increased cost for grazing leases.  So considering devastating losses and increased costs to raise livestock, now more than ever we need prices to maintain.  Our industry CANNOT take a reduction in market prices.  Letting Brazilian beef into the country will lead to market prices falling.  Your actions will decide the fate over our American ranch family's.  Make the right choice and deny the importation of Brazilian beef.  Leon Garrett Pierre, SD", 'No, do not import beef from Brazil. Didn`t have enough trouble with BSE from Canada a few years ago. Why are you playing Russian roullete with the cattle industry?', "Why are we even considering this? Are we Stupid or what? First why would we import beef from a third world country that does not have the same health guide lines as we do? Second, Hoof and mouth does not need to be brought back to the US. And third, don't we raise enough beef here in the US, Healthy Beef! And why would you want to put the American Ranchers and Farmers out of business. We are already importing beef from other country's.", 'The proposal to import fresh and chilled meat from 14 states in Brazil very irresponsible. How can you possibly ignore the extremely high risk it would pose to AMERICAN cattle, AMERICAN producers and AMERICAN consumers. Please think like an AMERICAN (for once!) and please do your job to protect AMERICANS. As cow/calf producers in South Dakota, we work and spend, to protect our cattle and keep them healthy. Do not put us at an extremely high risk of FMD. Please. We need our markets strong so AMERICAN producers may continue to do what we do best: raise the best and safest beef in the entire world. Thank you for taking the time to read the comments from your fellow Americans. Duane and Carla Jobgen', 'Following extensive background research, I have the following concerns: *Concerning the APHIS risk assessment for the Region in Brazil, the release assessment, exposure assessment and consequence assessment appear incomplete with regard to  the necessary steps and requirements outlined in the international standards as described  in the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Chapter 2.1. *It is my understanding that USDA APHIS does not consider the countries of South America to be FMD-free with the exception of Chile. Outbreaks of FMD have occurred in Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, all countries that had been classified as FMD-free without vaccination or FMD-free with vaccination by the OIE prior to the FMD outbreaks. FMD has not been eradicated from Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela, and Peru. *There is significant concern regarding the willingness, committed resources, and  infrastructure of Brazil to consistently perform adequate risk management in order to mitigate the risk for the introduction of FMD into the United States through the importation of fresh Brazilian beef. *The consequences of an FMD outbreak in the United States would be extremely high in  terms of disease-related costs, loss of animal life, trade losses and severe psychological  effects on farmers and farming communities. The United States has not experienced an outbreak of FMD since 1929. *While the APHIS regulatory analysis highlights the possible consumer benefit from the import of 40,000 metric tons of fresh beef annually from Brazil it fails to address the economic impact on consumers for the possible risk for the introduction of FMD virus to the United States and a resultant FMD outbreak. **The risk to U.S. agriculture and to our cattle producers is far too great and the economic and animal health consequences far too significant to move forward with this proposed rule without first absolutely establishing that an attitude of willingness for compliance and a sophisticated infrastructure are present in Brazil to allow for the consistent performance of all FMD risk mitigation measures.', 'Do not let Brazil import fresh cut beef because the risk of importing hoof and mouth disease is too great.', 'We have safe food and want to keep it above reproach. Why jeopardize our safety allowing imported food from known areas with problems. Do NOT allow this to occur.', 'National Women Involved in Farm Economics (WIFE), requests the Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) to extend the comment period for an additional 60 days, Docket #: APHIS-2009-0017, "Importation of Beef From A Region in Brazil". This proposed action has the potential to impact trade, food safety, and the health of the United States livestock herds. Extending the comment period 60 days will give stakeholders additional time to discuss and comment on this issue, of importing fresh or chilled beef from a region not declared free of Foot and Mouth Disease, which affects all cloven-hoofed animals.  Whitney Klasna National WIFE Beef Committee Chair', 'Do not import any beef from anywhere in that country and endanger animals in the US... the amount that would come in would be negligible as to the consumer and would not help higher prices to the consumer, but would endanger all of the beef cattle and many more animals and humans in the USA.  Robert Dennis Red Owl, SD', 'I am opposed to the importation of beef from Brazil and Argentina do to animal health concerns and their inability to control diseases that could drastically harm the US Beef Industry.', "US beef producers cannot afford the unbeliveable risk of importing beef from a county with known FMD. We eliminated it - don't haul it back in!", "Importing beef to America from Brazil, where FMD (foot-and-mouth disease) is a huge problem, afflicting hundreds of thousands of cattle, is a huge mistake. Not only will this decimate cattle prices for American ranchers, but if FMD is introduced into the U.S., it will decimate our herds. Farmers and ranchers have enough to worry about without having our own Department of Ag fighting against us. This is an irresponsible and dangerous act that the USDA is attempting. Importing fresh and chilled beef from 14 Brazilian states can only harm American farmers and ranchers. If we're lucky, it will only hurt our bottom line. If we're unlucky, it will introduce FMD and decimate our herds. Please think of American cattlemen when you make your decision on this. Thank you for your time.", 'PLEASE DO NOT IMPORT FRESH BEEF OR LIVE CATTLE FROM BRAZIL. I have been a cattle producer all my life and have gone through many ups and downs in this business but have always believed that it is an industry vital to the United States. We have a  safer product for consumers in the U.S. than anywhere in the world. It is ridiculous to jeopardize the safety of the consumers or the cattle herd here in the U.S. by importing cattle from a country with less inspection standards than we have here. All it takes is one FMD infected animal imported from a country known for Foot and Mouth Disease to cause enough damage to the entire cattle industry that the industry may never fully recover. I ask you to make your decision based on facts, not on the wishes of those wanting to make more money at the expense of producers here in the United States.', 'This legislation could potentially destroy the cattle i
column5: ["I respectfully request that these proposed rules and regulations, specifically to ban the sale of magnets and magnet sets with a flux index above 50, be withdrawn and no further rules or regulations be imposed.  The magnets in question have been plastered with warning signs and 'Adults Only' labels that clearly outline the hazards of the magnets. It is up to parents to understand the hazards and keep the magnets out of the reach of children.  Regulations of this sort are a slippery slope. Banning the sale of an item that, when properly used, causes no harm sets a dangerous precedent. Thumbtacks shouldn't be given to children, either, but often come in bright colors and interesting shapes. A swallowed thumbtack can be as dangerous to a child as a magnet, yet it would be considered ludicrous to propose banning them.  The government shouldn't be in the business of banning inherently innocuous products. If said product can cause harm when used IMPROPERLY, then regulated warnings and labels are in order, not the complete ban of the product.  Please, let common sense rule the day. Reactionary and unnecessary regulations are a burden, not a boon, to society.", 'Do not proceed with this statistically-ridiculous magnet ban!  The scale of ths intervention far outweighs the perceived risk and is a classic example of government over-reach.  Household items such as toilets, buckets, cleansers, etc., which cause annual child fatalities, should be a focus of intervention efforts long before something as provincial as novelty magnets are attacked.  Leave them be!', "This is a simply ridiculous, for the past couple years it has been clearly marked in magnetic desk toys that they aren't for children. They come plastered with warnings about said ingestion issues, and to keep them away from kids. That's the biggest concern I have is not that they can be hazardous if swallowed, but that there is the thought that we need to ban them because parents are not active enough in realizing what a child of a certain age should be playing with. I've used magnet sets for years to reduce the swelling in my knuckles. Being able to have something malleable like these spherical magnetic sets helps keep my hands from cramping, and nothing else I've tried seems to work. It's no good that children have gotten hurt, but instead of banning the sale of them all together, simply restrict the sale of them to those over the age of eighteen.", "Please do not ban the most non-violent, stress-relieving, educational activity.  I know Nanodots the company. I have worked with them for a short time. I allow my nine year old son to play with their products, and he does so safely.  With Nanodots he creates geometric structures and replicates models he sees in youtube videos.  From my own experiences with the product and while watching him, it's very much an educational and creative outlet when used as stated on the packaging.    I believe there are alternatives to make this type of product safer that have not been included in this rulemaking. Nanodots has since developed a bittering substance on their product that I found to be extremely effective, yet it wasn't one of the options in this NPR.  With more magnets being sold within the US it is very important that you create a STANDARD  in order to keep kids safe from all types of magnets; the real issue at hand according to your NEISS injury data.   I also believe that incidents happen, because people simply do not think about the consequences. As soon as they understand the risks, they will be more much more alert. Instead of banning the product, I would make the producing companies run a nation-wide TV advertising at their own expense and educate adults and kids on safe use of magnets. This will prevent injuries from a wide range of magnets still available on the market and not subject to the ban, but potentially harmful.   In two words, I propose to introduce strict Standards for the product and compulsory Education of the population. Our young generation needs an activity, which develops their creativity and aimed at building rather than destruction. The more time our kids spend away from violent computer games and movies, the healthier the nation will be.", "There are a great many products on the market than can be harmful. It's not clear to me why buckyball magnets and similar products are being targeted so fiercely. They provide hours of safe, intellectually stimulating entertainment, and serve a useful educational purpose, as well as enabling artistic endeavors. Please don't ban them from sale. Work with the manufacturers to educate the consumer about possible safety issues. Parents should be taking responsibility for this particular safety aspect; we should not all have to suffer because of negligent parenting.  There is nothing inherently unsafe about these products, and there are thousands of products on the market that are much more dangerous.", 'Zen magnets have provided hours of mental stimulation, physical dexterity, 3-dimensional exploration, suprise and delight to me, my wife, children and grandchildren. They are a tool to personally experience the unlimited wonders of science and explore our creative side of our world experience.            As a society, we kill over 30,000 people a year with automobiles. We regulate with laws, rules, training and accept/live  with the results.  No amount of laws, regulation or bans around any human activity has changed our collective rate of death. It is still one per birth. Risk comes with the experience of life.      An outright  ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings.      Put on warnings, just as we do for automobiles.       Education holds the key for our advancement as a society.  Read to your children. Teach kids to read, for the love of it. Honor and pay teachers, the rest will follow.', 'Clearly the CPSC does not have enough to do.  The recommendation of this proposed rule to ban the sale of this class of magnet set rather than requiring a warning is draconian.   The CPSC has now decided to protect us from individual irresponsible behavior.    Since the CPSC appears to have run out of products in an effort to protect consumers, I would like to suggest that they look into the products sold by major seed companies.  I\'m thinking about seeds coated with neurotoxins to kill insects.   These neurotoxins persist into the food chain.  Let me spell that out: "they\'re getting into the food the consumer consumes."  The consumer doesn\'t get to make a choice here.   With magnet sets the consumer can make a choice:  No! don\'t let little children play with these magnets; No! don\'t stick this powerful magnet in my nose.  The role of the CPSC is not to protect consumers from themselves.   It is to protect consumers from dangerous products where the danger is hidden and the consumer is either not aware of the danger or has no choice in the use of the product.   Sets of magnets are clearly products where the consumer can read a warning and can make the choice.', 'Bucky balls are awesome!', "Given the extraordinarily low number of medical incidents (and zero mortality rate), we should not be wasting government funds regulating this novelty item. It is a novelty item for adults and a few parents negligence should not spell the end for this product.   We might as well start banning guns, pharmaceutical drugs, back yard trampolines, slip 'n slides, and many other items actually marketed to and given to minors which actually result in death or serious injury.  The CPSC should be ashamed for wasting so much time and money on this crusade. Spend your attention on products which actually hurts kids.", 'I assume you guys will next be banning Legos, MMs and every other thing on the planet that can be swallowed.   For the future!!!!!', "I think you are way off the mark on this one.  Don't you think you should mention the parents have a responsibilty to supervise therir children?  Nothing is mentioned about parents responsibilty, nothing about how to safely store these magnets, Nothing!!  You just willy nilly decided to go after a company that was doing good things, providing jobs etc.  Get a clue, Not everything is lethal.", 'Im opposed to the Banning of Zen Magnets from the market. CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations need to realize that these product are sold to individuals who are old enough to use theme in a safe and productive manner. If a child does get a hold of them it is the owners responsibility to the child and not the company fault.', "We all want to live in a world where risk is averted. To suggest that outlawing these tools of creation, clearly marketed and sold to those who have the capacity of using them safely, is the most absurd overreach of formal power i've seen. I stand by the belief that responsible regulation is an important foundation to public safety. This is not that. This is a knee-jerk reaction. I beseech you to reconsider this ban on sphere magnets.", "I'm sorry but this ban is absolutely stupid. Put a warning label on them like every other toy. You wouldn't ban knives because you could cut yourself. Don't ban these awesomely fun toys.", "These magnets have far too many useful purposes for a ban.  While teaching physics, I use them to model chemical bonds, as well as to model certain electromagnetic principles.  In addition to being educational, they are just plain fun and stress relieving.  While they should not be marketed to children (and they are not most commonly), this is not a reason to restrict their distribution.  Why have these magnets been singled out for this draconian measure, whereas items like balloons, bikes, and even popcorn (which can be choked on, as with the balloons) have not been.  Is it because there is no lobbyist group associated?  On a per use basis, their 'dangers' are less than miniscule, and while I empathize with the parents of injured children, there are inherent risks to unsupervised play in unrecommended manners.  Don't push into a ban.", 'These magnets should not be banned. It should be up to parents/ guardians to parent their children not the rest of us.', 'Do not ban the sale of these products. Responsible individuals should not be punished because some parents are unable to mind their children.', "Please don't get rid of such a fantastic product.", "These magnets are great. It seems to me that banning them because they are dangerous is ridiculous. They are clearly marketed to adults not children. Don't ban them. Just continue to make sure they don't get into the hands of children", 'I wish to register my opposition to the proposed "Safety Standard for Magnet Sets", which would effectively prohibit their sale in the United States. I do not agree with your judgment that they are "unreasonably hazardous", nor do I consider them sufficiently hazardous to warrant the remedy you recommend. Indeed, lowering the power of such magnets to the level in the proposed rule would render them useless.  These magnets are not marketed as toys, and have not been marketed to children, though I would actually consider them perfectly suitable for children of normal intelligence 12 years of age or older. I think that banning their sale to adults because of possible hazards to small children is unacceptable, and is an excessive application of your regulatory power.', 'As a citizen and consumer, I believe that this proposed rule will cause economic harm and will stifle innovation. The number of reported injuries from these products is similar to the number of attributable deaths from waterbourne illness from EPA regulated municipal water supplies. We do not regulate the structural composition of other small, dangerous and attractive items that are likely to be in a household setting with a child like prescription drugs, detergent pellets or button batteries; yet each of those items can very easily have equally as dire consequences if ingested. I think that a better use for government time and resources would be to focus on enforcing existing regulations on imported toys and novelties that have illegal levels of lead and dioxin. This seems to be a focused effort to persecute a small number of companies that have to this point been very compliant and proactive in promoting safety. This conduct does not engender the behavior that this administration promotes as far as cooperation with private companies and carries negative connotations to consumers.', 'I am a pediatric gastroenterologist.  I have needed to endoscopically remove four of these magnets from a young child who swallowed them.  The magnets had separated and were pinching her stomach lining, which was turning color.  It was fortunate that we acted quickly to scope, or else she would have perforated.  These magnets are dangerous and should be taken off the market.', "This is a very unreasonable course of action given the amount of these magnets that have already been sold, and are still available elsewhere.  If there was a concern, there should have been a study done before it became a widespread medical issue, and pending those results, appropriate measures taken to ensure adults are aware of the dangers, and consequences, of giving these to children.    I'd much rather see an age limit requiring actual ID checks placed on the purchase of these products, and appropriate consequences for adults found giving them to children, than have the product simply removed from the market.  Since when is it a gun manufacturer's fault if the child of a negligent parent finds a gun and shoots someone or themselves?  If the product is marketed to adults, institute legal consequences for selling to minors, don't hold the manufacturer responsible for the negligence and ignorance of parents.", "Don't ban them! If you are too young to play with them, your parents shouldn't buy them. If you are old enough that it isn't their responsibility and still have problems, maybe that person should be investigated, not a harmless toy.", "A product having the capability to cause harm does not necessarily mean it will. Banning a product due to it's harm potential only makes sense if you ban every product with the potential to harm. Cars, guns, motorcycles, even cows kill an estimated 21 people on average a year, yet we are not banning flank steaks. While I do not have the statistics, I am sure we could find another children's toy that has resulted in far more injuries, Legos for example. My sister had to be taken to the hospital when she was a baby for jamming one of the police men in her ear, and I cannot even count the times I have stabbed my foot while walking around my room as a child. The point is, these magnet sets are fun, and I know more adults than children who own these, if you actually looked at the product and marketing I would propose that they are targeted towards an older audience. If we are to ban magnet sets, I propose we also ban cattle, Legos, lighters, cars and electrical outlets, as they also have much potential for harm. Perhaps a more simple solution would be to ban parents who do not properly supervise their children, as it is their responsibility to make sure a product is used safely.", "This is madness. These products clearly state that they are not intended for children and that they pose a risk if ingested. Any reasonable adult can use these magnetic products safely and without incident. Just because there are a few irresponsible parents or guardians out there doesn't mean that we should deny a product to the adult public because of child safety risks when it isn't intended for them in the first place. There should be clear and simple labeling on these products (which there is) to ensure that even the adults with an elementary grasp of logic and the English language can understand the risks to children - but they shouldn't be removed from the market because of a few people were irresponsible.", 'I believe that these products are safe.  While there are some dangers associated with them when used improperly, this is true of many products on the market today that go unquestioned.', "Reject these regulations.  There is no such thing as perfect safety.  It is the parents' duty to protect their children.  Merely because a product is unsafe if misused, is no basis for a ban.  This is overreach, safety madness, and bureaucracy run mad.", "I believe these [rules are in violation of] 706(2)(a) as they are arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion. This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing under 556&557 should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.  These organizations have worked with the CPSC and done everything needed, and now the organization is acting in such a manner contrary to their previous prior dealings with the effected companies.  As a consumer, I think the CPSC is overreaching. Personal responsibility is key. We don't let children play with ball bearings, and we have not banned every magnet out there because of the potential (ab)use by children. Parents should be responsible and not let these ADULT TOYS fall within their hands. There are far more things that are more dangerous to children and yet marketed to them where these are not called toys and specifically are aimed at adults and have blatant and numerous warnings.  Consumers everywhere are asking you to reconsider and allow these products to continue to be sold to responsible adults.", "Magnets are not the problem. If you drink too much water, it could be fatal. Why don't we ban water next??", "I don't believe there should be a ban on magnets of any size or shape. It should be up to the purchaser to maintain control over these objects, and not at fault of the items themselves! A ban on the sale of magnets is ridiculous.", 'There is not unreasonable risk nor injury associated with the allegedly hazardous magnet sets.  The anecdotal evidence and limited case studies listed in the proposed rule do not evidence what can legally be called an unreasonable risk.  While the agency cites to one death and other cases requiring abdominal surgery due to these larger magnets, there was little information connecting (a) the magnets; (b) the unreasonable risk; and (c) why an out-and-out ban on these larger magnets is the correct rule to promulgate.  Before the agency creates a final rule banning these larger magnets, there must be more evidence showing why alternatives to this ban cannot be made and why a total ban on these magnets is the last possible alternative, with cost-benefit analysis.  Only then, after more information connects this unreasonable risk to a need for a total ban can the rule be properly made.', 'As a U.S. citizen and consumer, I would like to state I am strongly opposed to the proposed prohibition/ban on magnets as described in the Safety Standard for Magnet Sets.  The magnets are NOT defective.  The magnets do NOT pose an unreasonable risk, a risk yes, but not an unreasonable risk.   I cannot understand the CPSCs overzealous attack on magnets, especially when there are products like balloons and detergent pods still on the market.  The CPSC does not appear to be using the same standard for magnets as the one used for balloons.  Balloons have killed more children than any other childs toy and it continues to kill children every year.  Yet the CPSC feels that education and warning labels are sufficient for balloons.  How then can the CPSC say warning labels will be ineffective for magnets, but are just fine for balloons?  If this ban is successful, I fear a dangerous precedent will be set.  Where will such bannings stop?  The government cannot mandate common sense.  There is a saying You cant fix STUPID!  Accidents happen, but the statistics on magnet injuries come no where close to the stats of other dangerous products.  Which makes me ask again, WHY is the CPSC so dead set on banning these magnets?  I am not the only citizen that feels the CPSC is overstepping its bounds in this instance.   If you take the time to review the essays at the following link, you will find 200 essays written by concerned citizens stating why they are opposed to this ban.  http://zenmagnets.com/index.php?p=1_18_CPSC_Press_Release  The decision you make here will have far reaching repercussions.  Please be sure you are making a correct and just decision and not a knee-jerk reaction to someone crying wolf.', 'Please do not ban these magnet sets.  These items are not inherently dangerous should one use them as directed.  They are not toys, are labeled appropriately, and should not be treated as such.  However, to ban such items is akin to banning bicycles because someone could hit a curb and crack their skull.', 'I do not feel as though Zen Magnets and other spherical magnets of the like should be banned from sale in the U.S. As an owner of one set of Zen Magnets I enjoy the stress reduction and fun that comes from messing around with them.   I feel that if someone is old enough to buy them online then they are smart enough to know that they could be a potential choking hazard and take the necessary precautions to make sure that they are not ever in the hands of small children.  They are no more dangerous than any other toy on the market today and that is why I am commenting and signing this petition.', "Please don't ban buck balls. Just require better safety information on each package.", 'Stop the ridiculous treatment of private business. Hold persons accountable for their own actions. Save the balls', 'The use of small spherical magnets should be regulated, not eliminated.  Standard warning labels should be sufficient for this purpose.', 'I have children in my home, 5 to be exact, and they all know very well that they do not touch my small items on my desk. It is only a child hazard if you are not watching your children. If your children are taught properly to not touch dangerous things, then they will not.', "I bought a set of these as an adult and know many others who have. I feel that Buck Balls took very good caution in marking these as not intended for children, especially on their website and packaging. It's unfair for the CPSC to effectively ban a product when a bulk of their customers are adults buying it for their own amusement.", 'I do not support any recall or mandatory modification of magnet sphere sets. As a parent I share your desire to prevent harm to children; however empathy can only go so far. Common sense and individual responsibility are far more important to the welfare of our children than restrictive regulation.   It is assumed sets dramatically increase the likelihood of injury. The data from NEISS states 6100 magnet injuries occurred 2009-2011 with 1700 from magnet sets, 0 dead. This data suggests magnet sets cause less than 28% of total incidents. This merely reflects increase due to available product, not purpose.   70% of these injuries are to children under 5. It is a parents responsibility to ensure that their child is safe. The increase in danger posed by magnets is unimportant; even pocket change can kill under the right circumstances. It is not your job to keep my children safe, it is mine.   20% of injuries are from teens who should know better than to put such objects in their mouth. We cannot protect them from their own idiocy.  Another fallacious premise is that magnet sets are more dangerous than other small objects because they dont look dangerous, and are attractive to children. According to NEISS data for 2009-2011, 10,000 injuries and 18 deaths involve balloons, much greater than magnets. This inconsistency is telling.  The proposed remedies would be equally disruptive to the livelihood of these companies and the hobbies they support. If regulatory action requires companies to lower the flux rating of the magnets from what their current products possess, rendering them useless for magnet sculpture enthusiasts. Additionally, it would make any future purchases incompatible with their current supply, putting further burden on the consumer.  My tax dollars would be put to better use elsewhere. This will do nothing but put people out of work and deprive responsible adults from a unique creative experience.', "There are many things which are hazardous to ingest: drainer fluid, medicine and even vitamins in big quantities. There are many things which are a hazard to small kids: even plastic bags. As an expectant father, of course I would like nothing more than to keep my little girl safe. And I will.  Keeping my kid safe means I will make sure that her parents and care-takers keep her away from any hazards. It does not mean we need to stop selling things which might be a hazard to her -- other people, or even me, might use them responsibly. It is up to adults to behave in an adult way, using things in a responsible manner. This is why I can drive to my local pharmacy and get Biotin to keep my fingers healthy, even though for small kids, it would be a dangerous substance.  Introducing government regulation will not solve the problem, but it will cost American jobs and it will cost the government money to enforce and it will make us, ultimately, a worse place to live in. Let us assign responsibility where it should properly lie -- at the hands of parents, committed to their children's safety, and not at the hands of an indiscriminate ban.", 'As a Pediatric GI specialist, clinician educator &parent, I am requesting that these magnets be removed from the Commercial market.  They are dangerous and potentially life threatening.  I have personally taken care of patients (most are normal preadolescents or teens who inadvertantly swallow them after using them as fake tongue or lip studs) who have had complications including bowel perforation.  At minimum, there must be labeling to inform the public of the risks of ingestion.  As a mother of 2 young kids,  I never allow these in my home.  Taking theses off the market would prevent a lot of medical procedures, promote better public health/safety & in turn save significant healthcare dollars due to cost of procedures & hospitalizations in people who are generally otherwise healthy.', "These magnets should not be banned simply because anything else in this reality would endanger a child regardless. Why blame magnets? Why not blame marbles, lead pencils, soap, cleaning chemicals, etc... while we're at it? Adults play with these magnets just as well. Just simply because a few children chose to swallow the magnets, it should solely be on the parents since they've allowed their own children to play with it.", "These magnets are no different than bleach. You wouldn't let your kid get a hold of bleach. This is a parenting concern, not a regulatory concern.", 'To whom it may concern at the CPSC,  Your ban on magnet set toys is ridiculous. I cannot understand why you are attacking the companies selling the magnets, and not the parents who are irresponsible enough to let their children ingest magnets. The distributors, and the companies selling magnetic toy sets are making every effort to let people know of the dangers involved with ingesting and playing with high powered magnets. should we ban bullets because they are used to kill people? or guns because they are a tool for self defense or hunting even though they can also be used to harm people? the fault is not with the magnets, nor with the companies selling them. the fault lies with irresponsible people who do not take necessary precautions to ensure children or themselves do not risk their health by ingesting an item not meant for ingestion.  You need to stop this outright witch hunt against these companies and instead make it understood or mandatory that precautions must be made before and after purchasing magnetic toy sets. Again I would like to reiterate, that the fault is not with the companies, but with the individual who lacks responsibility to ensure the safety of people who might ingest (through accident or known intent) these toys. Banning them is not the solution.   Thank you for your consideration of this problem.', "Sell these magnets to adults and educate people on the packaging of the risks.   Trampolines, skateboards, and pogo sticks are far more dangerous yet they are still sold for people of all ages.  Don't make something illegal just because there are a few stupid people out there that think it is okay to let their kid play with toys unsupervised.     A big warning on the front about adult supervision is appropriate.", 'This regulation is putting a ban on a toy that was never designed for children to use. Yes, it may look friendly enough, however this hobby toy comes with a rather clear warning about swallowing the magnets. This ban is also the result of parental neglegence, and under no circumstance should the government become responsible for irresponsible parents. Those who neglect the warnings that come with the product should not be able to do such a thing. If the government feels so compelled to be involved, at least make an official age limit (and warning) to make it clear this product is only for adult use. Bit do not ban the product outright.', 'The outright banning of a product, based on the fact that it can be dangerous to unattended children, seems so out of line with American values that I\'m having troubled we are discussing it. You should not legislate broader society to safeguard against ignorant or irresponsible parents.   Any number of items sitting around my household could be banned under a similar line of "for the greater good" type thinking. Household cleaners are extremely toxic and typically stored at a level young children reach. Outlets don\'t come with built in insulating plastic safety inserts and are less than a foot from the floor. I\'m sure some children have injured themselves with both of these items. While individual instances are tragic they are not widespread.   The bottom line is individual responsibility for one\'s actions has been and should continue to be a hallmark of American society. If you introduce a product into your home that has characteristics that could injure your children and don\'t take the necessary precautions you are negligent. Not governing agencies that required labeling of these risks. Not manufacturer\'s who provided warnings.', "Please don't ban magnetic toys! This is a parental issue, not a policy one. As long as there are warnings on the packaging, these toys should be available.", "This is not right, you should NOT be regulating a product that is no risk to an adult. There are THOUSANDS of items out there that children can choke on. You can't start banning all of them. Big warning labels, like all toys with choking hazards, but at the end of the day it has to be the responsibility of the children's guardians - be them the parents, family member, teacher, ect. - to know what may be dangerous for children to choke on and to keep it away from them.  Please DO NOT PASS THIS RULE - if you do it's a travesty to the free market and the democracy we live in!", 'The proposed rule is an overreaction.  Please get an economist to look the statistics of the number of magnets sets sold and the number of people who have come in contact with those sets vs. the number of incidents of people swallowing the magnets.  The number is going to come into hundred thousandths (.000001) as a percentage.  The risk is miniscule.  Rare earth magnets have brought me countless hours of joy and it is a shame a ban is the proposed solution.', "Please don't ban them. :(", 'I believe this Safety Standard in a "knee jerk" reaction to a perceived probem. Product warnings and consumer education should be enough of a requirement. There should be some responsibility placed on the purchaser of the product. After all, if we took action for every "dangerous" product, we would be banning almost every product that could cause an injury. Examples could include, bicycles, trampolines, and pools. After all, all of these products can cause horrific injuries when used improperly. If there is a defect in a product that can cause injury when used properly, then by all means, we should look at legislation to limit injury. We should not however ban a product, if used properly and as intended, simply because it "could" be dangerous. At what point do verge into the realm of becoming a "nanny state" who know better than its own people what
column8: 64, -- Why even take the risk of presenting foot and mouth disease into the worlds best beef industry in world?45, -- How can you possibly ignore the extremely high risk it would pose to AMERICAN cattle, AMERICAN producers and AMERICAN consumers.55, -- Is the USDA-APHIS certain they can adequately control health and environmental issues surrounding imported beef?111, -- Brazil has foot and mouth disease in the country and we cannot afford the risk if allowing this product into our country.41, -- I shake my head in amazement at yet another government boondoggle that affects the American citizens in negative way.57, -- Due to the cost of maintaining the herds during a drought, the increase in prices now, may only break even for the rancher.42, -- There are many operators who are still trying to catch up from reducing or selling off their herds to due the latest drought.56, -- Also, an influx of beef from a country the size of Brazil would ultimately bankrupt a large proportion of our ranchers and farmers.127, -- My cattle and my lifestyle are important to me, and I take pride in bringing a healthy, safe product to the market for consumers.22, -- Please allow frozen and chilled beef from Brazil to help lower prices to the consumer.143, -- Why should the USDA be allowed to put our US producers at such risk?143, -- USDA seems to be in favor of allowing cheap beef into the US market to depress US cattle and beef prices.143, -- This proposal is anti-American, totally irresponsible and dangerous and should be stopped immediately.57, -- No matter how powerful we think we are, we do NOT control how things are done in other countries!109, -- They can worry about the consequences instead of the ranchers and consumers in the United States.57, -- - Just one slip up - what will that cost ?- possibly the whole beef industry in the U.S.        Who is going to suffer?42, -- Letting Brazilian beef into the country will lead to market prices falling.18, -- This is an advantage to be developed and must not be put at risk.140, -- Thank you for taking time to read this letter and for considering my points.18, -- Importing Brazilian beef and other livestock products is a risk not worth taking.18, -- In the rare instances when disease has impacted a portion of the livestock herd, economic devastation has followed.18, -- The economic costs of an FMD outbreak in the United States would be tremendous.
column9: 45, -- The proposal to import fresh and chilled meat from 14 states in Brazil very irresponsible.79, -- If imports from Brazil come into this country this will have a negative impact on our industry.111, -- It would be devastating if the US contracted foot and mouth disease and history has shown us that it can be transferred thur meat.107, -- The last outbreak in the UK was caused by feeding a relatively small amount of cooked, waste food to hogs.125, -- Do not allow the import of Brazilian beef ... support our own USA industry.5, -- Stop working against your very own country and turning it into a wasteland.46, -- The United States has not experienced an outbreak of FMD since 1929.53, -- Please think of American cattlemen when you make your decision on this.29, -- A good example of how difficult it can be to control a border is the border between the United States and Mexico.109, -- It is much more important than any political pressure to allow imports from Brazil.29, -- The proposed rule compares FMD free "region" in Brazil to the nation of Uruguay.68, -- Fifth, allowing the importation of the beef in question further extends the extremely deleterious vertical integration of the meat oligopoly.29, -- Also, it is not a nation, it is a collection of states.73, -- I believe in global trade but in this case prevention is the best option.57, -- Please do NOT allow the beef imports from Brazil!
column10: 23, -- NO imported meat from any country which has, or is adjacent to, a country/region with known FMD!102, -- it would spread across the US in less than a week and completely decimate the livestock industry....to say nothing of our wildlife..........63, -- We do not need to take the chance of helping bring in this disease that would decimate the US Cattle/Dairy Industry2, -- We are already at a record low cattle inventory and the destruction of animals required by an outbreak would be devastating.2, -- I own a small farm and raise cattle as part of my operation.29, -- This increased value will be a huge financial incentive to bring cattle from the larger region into the FMD free "region."29, -- These cattle that people sneak into the FMD free "region" will sooner or later bring FMD with them.73, -- In addition, rural tourism was halted to prevent the foot and vehicle traffic from transmitting the disease further.71, -- FMD would seriously harm the livestock industry in the US leaving farmers and ranchers with little choice but to go out of business.9, -- But again, much of what USDA does today--livestock ID/traceability being another example--is contrary to the interests and expressed concerns of U.S. ranchers.18, -- The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recalled Brazilian cooked and canned meat on three occasions in 2010 due to drug contamination.71, -- Estimates from USDAs own economic model estimate that US cattle producers will be harmed by as much as $316 million per year!18, -- The fourteen states that are being considered by this USDA rulemaking process are but one of the four regions in Brazil.18, -- The last case of FMD in the fourteen-state region in Brazil was in 2001.29, -- I live in Texas, which is bordered by four states and by Mexico.18, -- According to a Kansas State University study, the U.S. beef industry lost between $2.9 billion and $4.2 billion in 2004 alone because of BSE.18, -- Rural America should not again be subjected to severe losses simply because of lax standards for animal imports.18, -- This includes costs of quarantine and eradication of animals, a ban on exports, and reduced consumer confidence.
column11: 110, -- Short term security is going to turn into long term problem.75, -- They do not have the regulation that are required in the USA.109, -- If they belong to the same owner, they rarely have health papers for their travels.144, -- We deserve our time to make our operations solvent.144, -- Insurance, fuel, fertilizers, equipment costs have skyrocketed over the last couple of years.22, -- $250 per hundred calves and $150 per hundred fats is unbelievably high.144, -- WE grow a quality product and don't need it tainted by outside influences that do not meet our own standards.140, -- In all do respect, I find this very contradicting and stupid.
column12: 109, -- Cattle travel back and forth between states/counties all of the time.12, -- This island was covered with lots of head high brush-- & had a population of deer!
