column2: ['well i feel that some big changes are needed for these huge smart social  animals...the area most are given to live is like you living in a small garage for  ever!!! think bout it ...it is cruel!!! and wrong so PLEASE lets do what is right and  give them more humane living corters', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses  currently meet this requirement. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer  not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation  that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis,  foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as  swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from  arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia  in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining,  spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the  year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure  extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo  elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn  stalls for extended periods of time. Circuses and many zoos control their  elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other  tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These  instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants must  be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.   How would you like to be locked up inside your house for the rest of your life?   These beautiful, intelligent creatures deserve better. We have no right to lock them  up the way we have up to now. Do the right thing...the moral thing!!', "Using elephants for recreation by display is absolutely UNACCEPTABLE!  These amazing creatures belong in their own natural habitat. It's time to stop  exploiting and killing elephants.", 'Please improve the standards of care for all animals who are being used for  human enjoyment.  Thanks.', 'The elephants in Zoos and circuses suffer greatly.  Studies show that these  wonderful creatures need lots of room and social interaction with other elephants.   Zoos and circuses don?t permit this.  In addition, both zoos and circuses use  chains, bullhooks and other weapons on elephants ? this should not be allowed.  I am in favor of passing any laws or enforcing existing laws such as the Animal  Welfare Act in order to protect these poor captive elephants.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically and immediately improve the living conditions  for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space  requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens  Petition) and creating tough new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.  I watch the live web cam from the Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee on a daily  basis and cannot believe how happy the elephants are.  Zoo elephants do not  exhibit the same behaviors as elephants who are allowed to roam free.  Elephants  are not our pets and we should not treat them so.', 'I would like to provide the following information, hopefully to aid you in making a decision that reflects the need for improving the conditions in which these creatures live.          Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the social and environmental conditions that are necessary to maintain their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act mandates zoos and circuses to provide elephants with adequate space. Zoos and circuses are currently in violation of this requirement.      In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.     Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time.    Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.    Please consider these comments as you make your decision.  Thank you.', "If there must be zoos and circuses please abide by the Animal Welfare Act.  It's  the right thing to do for these animals who have no voice and no choice.  Thank  you for your time.", 'Zoos and circuses are not even close to giving elephants the conditions they  require for their health and well-being.Circus in particular is torture. The animals  travel 50 weeks a year. These are creatures that would normally walk 15 miles a  day!   They suffer horribly from joint pain  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide  elephants with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this  requirement.   Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos  and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions  and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable  ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive  and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head  bobbing.   Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours  a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through  force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged  chaining.   I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large,  naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary  in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can  roam, socialize and maintain their health.   The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force must be outlawed.  Please review the film footage IDA has  that shows a terrorfied baby elephant choosing to drown (he does die) rather than  return to the "trainer"with a bullhook.  I will NEVER take my child to an animal circus and the only zoo we will visit is a  sanctuary. Please takes steps to address this.  THE USDA has been aware of  the abuse of elephnats for too too long and your job (as we are paying  for I beleive ) is to protect the animals not the business that pours money into the  suffering... Thank you For the animals', 'I am concerned that some animals in captivity suffer from TB which can be  dangerous for people and other animals.  We have a responsibility when taking  and elephant to make sure that this large animal is properly fed and has enough  space for physical exercises.  All laws and regulations governing these noble beasts should be enforced.', "? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", "- The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. - Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'My family and I strongly support new policies which would improve and enhance  the lives and environments of elephants kept by circuses and unaccredited zoos.   We have learned that in too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only  from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that  eventually cause a range of preventable ailments--including painful arthritis, foot  disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as  swaying and head bobbing.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged  chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11  months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and  forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices.  These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  It is a disgrace that our government would allow these cruel and  inhumane conditions to continue and to participate in such brutal treatment of  these majestic and intelligent animals through indifference and ignorance.  We  urge you to enforce a new policy requiring that exhibitors of elephants provide  large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and the performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California.   The American people expect no less.  Thank you.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing, adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that will: 1) Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health. 2) Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices, and other  instruments of force frequently used against elephants today.  Change is drastically needed as:  1) Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being, besides forcing animals to perform being a deplorable  activity, in and of itself 2) The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space and zoos are not meeting this requirement 3) Elephants are big animals who need big spaces but in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing 4) Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when  the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for  extended periods during the cold winter months. 5) Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These methods cause  constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to elephants. 6) Because of their intelligence, complexity, and unique social and physical  needs, elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of  these unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.', 'We need to improve the lives of elephants and other animals subjected to being a  part of the circuc. Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', 'I strongly urge you to provide specific regulations for the care and housing of  elephants in circuses and zoos.  Elephants suffer daily under the guise of  entertainment, enduring torturous training with whips, hooks and electric shock,  as well as injuries, confinement and needless deaths.  Zoos and circuses should  be mandated to meet standards that provide humane treatment of elephants,  including housing, transportation and medical care.  Thank you for your consideration in this matter.', "Circuses and many zoos control elephants through the use of force and  domination, aggressive use of bullhooks, and prolonged chaining. In many zoos,  elephants are confined to barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when zoos are  closed, and in zoos in cold climates, elephants often spend weeks at a time  indoors during cold winter weather.  Elephants are the world's largest land mammals, and they require significant  amounts of space. In fact, in the wild, they can walk up to 30 miles a day. The  leading causes of death in captive elephants are foot disorders and arthritis, which  are caused by prolonged chaining, intense confinement, and forced inactivity.  Since 2000, more than half of the 49 elephants who have died at zoos accredited  by the Aquarium & Zoo Association never reached their 40th birthdays, dying far  short of their 70-year life expectancies.  Because of their intelligence, complexity, sensitivities, and unique social and  physical needs, elephants suffer immensely in small, unchallenging captive  environments. To make matters worse for elephants, in circuses, every instinctual  behavior is subject to discipline. If elephants reach for grass, try to comfort  friends, or extend their trunks to smell something new or different, they get hit with  bullhooks. If they blow a trick during a performance, they get beaten afterward.  I support the following measures in regards to the health and safety of these  elephants:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'I am writing to ask that the standard for elephant care be improved. The Animal  Welfare Act needs to be enforced with these animals.  Elephants are frequently  mistreated and living in conditions that are inhumane.  These animals need our  support and require federal intervention on their behalf.  Please enforce the AWA  so that these helpless animals be treated with respect and dignity.', 'Elephants in zoos and circuses are suffering due to inadequate space, unnatural  conditions, lack of exercise and social deprivation.    For these reasons, I strongly urge you to dramatically improve the standards for  captive elephants.  Thank you for your consideration.', 'I strongly urge the USDA to respond to the IDA petition and issue an interpretive ruling that enforces the Animal Welfare Act regarding the care, transport and general husbandry of elephants in captivity.  I ask you to promulgate specific standards for elephants.  They are animals of high intelligence, complex social structure, large size, physiology which demands large spaces for movement and resting.  Forbid the use of bullhooks (ankus), chains, electric prods and any other devices of cruel domination and "control".  Require many acres for them to walk - with different substrates and also ponds and mud wallows. I have observed elephants in many, many zoos.  The standards are pathetically inadequate to provide for the health of these animals - both mentally and physically.  As proof of this, note the high rate of elephants dying at half the normal life expectancy .  Or elephants living with extreme health problems such as arthritis,  osteoporosis, and internal organ damage from living in small spaces, on concrete, not allowing for the movement that their bodies are made for!  We have condemned them to a terrible life. I have observed elephants in circuses.  They are chained, they are physically forced to perform tricks which take a terrible toll on their bodies.  The shows are not true entertainment but performances of pain.   I have visited 2 sanctuaries and see how allowing elephants to live as elephants can restore a high degree of happiness to animals that have been abused by humans in the worst possible ways. I have observed elephants in the wild in Kenya.  Elephants living in their amazing family groups teach us how to be better human beings!  They are full of majesty and empathy and life-long family bonds.   WE have an obligation to protect these animals with high standards of care and I ask the USDA to do so.', 'Elephants in circuses and zoos are not provided with adequate living conditions  and care.  They are not given enough space and could not be given enough space  since they are being confined in cages, very small pieces of land, or chained.  In  circuses they are beaten with bullhooks until they obey the trainer.  Elephants are  very intelligent and sociable creatures.  They become lonely and depressed when  they are taken away from or separated from their families.  They should not just be  given more space and less beatings with a bullhook.  Elephants should not be  used in entertainment such as circuses, nor should they be confined in zoos  where most of the time they are given limited amount of space and no natural  habitat.  No matter what the animal welfare standards are for elephants in zoos  and circuses they will many times be ignored and not enforced.  Elephants should  remain in the wild where they belong or in elephant sanctuaries where they are  free of bullhooks, chains, and confined areas.', 'I do not believe we have the right to keep elephants in captivity. I believe it is  morally unjust and reprehensible. I could see if it were a matter of human survival;  if it were a matter of us or them. But our reasons for keeping these intelligent,  enormous and majestic animals in captivity are based on selfishness, self- indulgence, and profit. It is disgusting, how we as humans believe we have the  right to treat another living thing any way we wish, simply because we can.  However, if elephants are going to be imprisoned by humans, the least we can do  is require and force the keepers of these animals to provide them with adequate  living space. I hope you will improve the enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act for  the sake of all animals in captivity, as well as strengthen the regulations regarding  the care and treatment of elephants specifically.', 'It pains my heart to see elephants being treated so badly. Elephants are giants of  the forest and deserve to be treated with more care. The government needs to do  whatever needs to be done to improve their living conditions. Elephants are not our  puppets to put up a show whenever we want. I would in fact be more than happy  with an action as drastic as banning elephants from all circuses and zoos.', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being. This is cruel to allow them to be treated in this way. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health. Please do your part to protect these great  animals from the people who only want to make money.', 'I am a firm believer that elephants should not be allowed in zoos or circuses.   Circus zoos spend the majority of their day spent in chains and undergo  brutal "training."  There is no zoo that can provide an elephant with the space or  habitat an elephant really needs. Elephants are suffering a range of ailments  specifically due to the fact that they are in captivity. This is not right.', 'To Whom It May Concern:  I strongly urge that high standards be set for the health and welfare of all  elephants! Every elephant should be entitled to live in a natural habitat and to  socialize as a herd member. No elephant should ever spend its life chained in   solitary confinement within a concrete jungle!   Elephants are herd animals whose social structure compels them to interact with  one another. These highly intelligent creatures laugh and weep with each other.  They also support and care for one another whether one be strong or weak.  Elephant herds celebrate new life , care for the sick and infirmed with love and  compassion and bury their dead with dignity.  The time has come for our society to give elephants the respect, freedom and  proper care  they so richly deserve.   Thank you .', 'Elephants are suffering due to inadequate space, unnatural conditions, lack of exercise and social  deprivation. Please give them greater protection. Thank you.', "Captive elephants are physically, socially and emotionally abused.  Present conditions are in violation of the Animal Welfare Act.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots and other instruments of force are cruel and would suggest to zoo and circus attendees that such harsh and painful methods to control the elephants' behavior is acceptable when in fact, it is not.    Zoos and circuses should consider the Elephant Sanctuary and the Performing Animal Welfare Society's sanctuary in Georgia to be models for how their elephants should be treated.  Until there are changes to the status quo, there will be a great uproar by the public to see that elephants are more humanely treated lest the zoos and circuses suffer a severe drop in attendance and loss of revenue.", 'Recent research into the health of elephants housed in 35 United States AZA  accredited zoos shows numerous problems with foot disease and degenerative  forms of arthritis and joint disease. Research also suggests that these health  problems can be linked to a lack of space for adequate exercise and hard packed  or unnatural substrates the animals are typically housed on. Zoos need enforced  regulation calling for changes to address these issues. If US Zoos  cannot provide the animals with healthy living conditions, they should not be  allowed to continue housing this species in captivity.', 'Elephants are very intelligent animals that should live in their natural habitat not in  prison like captivity.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.   Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments  of force against elephants.   Stop bringing elephants to this country, they need to live in their natural habitat not  in horid conditions in captivity.', "Elephants and all other animals deserve better than circuses and zoos provide for  them.  They are intelligent beings with feelings.  Kids and adults alike have so  many more things to keep themselves occupied in today's world of electronics  and tv that it just seems so 18th century to have zoos and circuses (not that it  was ok then either).  Do the right thing and make sure these animals in these  places are treated as if they were in the wild and can be themselves.  Can you  blame them that they freak out once in awhile.  It's like when you have a dog in a  kennel that never tastes freedom, then they get out that one time and they just go  for broke trying to run and jump and be free.  Who's fault is it that the dog takes  off?  It sure isn't the dogs fault.  You would do it to.  Whatever the lobby people  say and offer can't be worth the feeling you will have inside knowing that you  helped out even one animal to be free.", 'I am in favor of dramatic improvements in the standards for captive elephants held  in U.S. zoos and circuses. Currently the health and well-being of elephants are being compromised due to  lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation. This treatment leads to  painful foot conditions as well as neurotic behaviors like swaying and head  bobbing. Many zoos and circuses also control elephants through force, domination and the  use of bull hooks and prolonged chaining.    - Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.     - The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.  One only needs to look into the eyes of one of these great creatures for a moment  to see the humiliation and pain that is suffered at our hands in order to spark the  compassion that is necessary to change the fate of these animals.', 'As a concerned citizen and animal lover, I would urge you to please thoroughly  review the deplorable and inhumane conditions that elephants are kept in in  circuses and zoos and implement more stringent laws and guidelines to protect  these magnificent and highly intelligent animals.  Thank you very much for your time.', "Elephants require special conditions that zoos and circuses are not giving for their health and well- being. Elephants need big spaces to roam and get important exercise. They suffer when they don't  get adequate socialization. These are but a couple of the terrible ways they are treated in zoos and  circuses.    Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those  at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain  their health.", 'I am writing to express my concern about the plight of captive elephants both in  zoos and circuses.  Elephants are suffering from cramped spaces, chains, unnatural climates, the  wrong social structure.  Teaching the public about elephants that are kept in these  conditions is misleading.  To the average zoo/circus visitor, they see that it is  all "rosy".  The truth is,  it is a horror show behind the scenes.  I don\'t understand how the AZA can constantly change the natural age for  elephants, if one is euthanized in their 30\'s or 40\'s the zoo officials state that is  old for an elephant, what they fail to state, that in the wild elephants live far  beyond that age, and that because of the unnatural life of a captive elephant  forced to perform or stand on cold hard concrete year in and year out, is
column3: ['Having been to Sea World myself many times, I can not believe there are those who feel their animals are mistreated. Sea World has not only inspired me to love our aquatic friends, but has already filled my young daughters with a respectful and loving attitude towards all animals. They have been inspired to take better care of our planet and respect nature. For example, the rescue turtles especially have shown them how animals can be harmed from careless humans. Sea World has given these animals a safe home where they are cared for daily. I feel many of these injured animals would not survive long on their own.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  It would be a sad loss for future generations to miss the opportunity to experience Sea World and all it has to offer. Apart from seeing these animals in their natural environment, which most visitors to the parks would never have the chance to do, there is nothing quite as inspiring as being so up close to experience their interactions with each other and their caretakers. Without places like Sea World so many people, including myself would never have gotten the opportunity to enjoy these magnificent creatures. We would lose the chance to instill that love and respect for animals in future visitors young and old.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Help us', "I am a student pursuing a marine science degree.  The up close encounters with animals is what inspired me to pursue my life's passion.  Without these facilities, I would never have known about the study of marine science.  There must be a higher emphasis on STEM for students to encourage them to engage in STEM and find a career in that field.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", "I work directly with the millions of volunteers, staff, and guests that are welcomed at Georgia Aquarium each year. I have had the experience of seeing guests of all ages see aquatic animals and ecosystems they may never see in their lifetime and strike a deeper understanding of the one world ocean that connects us all. Having the opportunity to teach volunteers and staff about the beauty of our animals: teaching them how to engage with our guests has been a great privilege. All of us at Georgia Aquarium are committed to providing our guests with a positive and impactful experience to inspire conservation of our aquatic world. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of people the ability to see magnificent animals and learn more about them. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practices standards. How are we going to know how to save these creatures if we don't have the means to study and learn about them. Through scientific study and research  several animals have been upgraded on the IUCN list recently, I think due to organizations like ours that inspire guests to help save these animals they may never have a chance or opportunity to see in the wild.", 'I wish you were at my house the days following a day at Sea World with my great grandson (almost seven years old).  Every day he was saying " Granny, did you know that and he would repeat facts he heard.  We managed a second day during his week with me. It was the same with the older grandchildren when they were young. There were many manatees that they have helped rescue recently. If they had not been rescued these manatees would now be dead.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'Please allow future generations to fall in love with marine animals as myself and my family have.  Without sea world this would not be a reality  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please allow sea world parks to care for these beautiful animals.  Without places like sea world, most children/and adults would never have an opportunity to see these animals up close and fall in love with them.  This in turn generates love for these animals and a want and need to learn about them and protect them    Please allow future generations these wonderful experiences.', 'In support of the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums, as well as the adoption of any new regulations based  solely on hard science and the best interest of animals as opposed to animal rights activist politics.  "Linda Pfeiffer, Meadow Glens School in Naperville, IL We went to Shedd Aquarium and Brookfield Zoo yearly with our first graders and always loved the dolphin show at Shedd  as well as observing animals at the zoo housed in habitats that were set up to resemble their natural habitats. We all learned from the information provided in all exhibits."', "Having waited many years for U.S. revisions of captive marine mammal standards, I was relieved to find these standards have finally been proposed by your agency. My relief quickly turned to disappointment, however, to discover the improvements barely go beyond requiring shade for the captive animals' enclosures, as well as easier access ramps for seals, sea lions and polar bears.  Not only did the amount of time INCREASE from two to three hours for swim with captive dolphin programs, not a single significant change to improve the lives of these long-ranging, highly intelligent animals has been proposed. There has been zero increase in the required space of the enclosures, a shocking and deplorable omission considering the needs of long-ranging cetaceans. In a tank that is allowed to be a mere 12 feet deep, an adult orca's fluke would drag on the bottom the tank if the orca was in an upright position. Also, there has been no noise restrictions or water temperature requirements per species proposed, and why is fresh water allowed for pinnipeds?!   APHIS, please re-assess these areas of great concern and upgrade your standards to more humane conditions that will actually improve the welfare of these complex animals. The public is becoming aware of the cruelty of captivity, and it behooves the government allowing this practice to regulate the industry to the highest possible standards based on science, not the needs of the captive animal industry. On the top of your agency's revisions list should be much more room for these intelligent, captive creatures to swim, and also somewhere to retreat from the natural aggression that arises in such stressful, small enclosures.", "Marine parks are a vital link between our increasingly detached public and our increasingly distressed marine world. The connection marine parks and interactive encounters provide is an invaluable tool in the effort to save this planet from ourselves. Without the awe instilled in children of all ages by these facilities the passion to do what is needed, to fund research and conservation will be diminished.   Regulation is an important part of any endeavor, especially one as multifaceted as the care of, and interaction with, marine animals. It is, however, equally important to implement those regulations in a fare and unbiased manner.  I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.  Too often emotion and rhetoric sway the outcome of debate and policy while sound science and often common sense are left in the mass-grave of the media battleground. Don't let our magnificent parks and all the irreplaceable work that comes from them fall victim to defamation and disinformation.", "Just a note in regards to my previous comment for navigation purposes:  My comment with ID APHIS-2006-0085-5127 was in response to Ms. Rose's comment with ID APHIS-2006-0085-4959", 'i have not altered the prepared letter below because it wonderfully expresses my personal feelings. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  My most sincere thanks for your generous consideration.', 'I believe in all the good works that SeaWorld does.  I have been visiting SeaWorld San Diego since they opened.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  There is no one else who would have rescued and nursed all the seals that have been in distress on our beaches this past winter if SeaWorld did not. Peta for all their noise did not even try to aid one poor marine creature.', 'Re:  Proposals for Dolphin Care:  My connection with, and love for, the Dolphin Research Center began in 2004 on my first visit there.  I was immediately drawn to the respect and love between the staff and the dolphins and sea lions.  I began a learning experience immediately.  I have participated in every program offered, including a week-long Adult DolphinLab.  I have watched so many people from other countries visiting DRC, I have witnessed a dolphin birth, watched and participated in many sessions.  I have viewed educational movies and watched research sessions.  My participation in recycling was reinforced by what I have learned from DRC.  I cannot imagine a life without access to the magnificent mammals at DRC.  They are a non-profit and I am extremely worried that actions proposed by APHIS will jeopardize their ability to continue the commitment to these animals and the education of the public.  Some of these sea lions and dolphins are rescues and non-releasable as well as those born there.  DRC is a FAMILY and no animal is ever forced to interact.    Research is ongoing and much remains to be discovered and shared with the public in years to come.  DRC has made contributions to the medical care of the animals and extended their lifespan.  I have read and experienced first hand the research being done at DRC/  I am aware of the proposals to mandate one trainer per dolphin in every interaction/program, as well as having one trainer observing each dolphin underwater as well.  In 12 years, I have never witnessed one single negative issue in the way programs are handled.  I have been safe and so have the dolphins.  The mutual enjoyment is priceless.  Making these changes will certainly negatively impact DRC.  I know their priority is safety.  It is working.  I know they will not compromise their mission, so adding so much additional staff will impact expansion programs and, most likely, cost of touring and participating in programs.  Less people will be able to afford the cost of learning about our oceans, these magnificent animals, and the need to educate our world before it is too late to preserve the oceans and the life within them.  Why do you propose to change what works perfectly well?  Please reconsider these proposals.  Please listen to all of us whose lives have been enriched by DRC.  Dolphin Research Center has made a difference and I just hope you are not going to disrupt their mission.', "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Instead of attacking we'll run and compassionate facilities, go after businesses that are cruel and abusive to animals i.e. Puppy mills, meat industry, commercial and recreational fishing, dumping trash in the ocean, designer pets. I and my family look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "This proposal is something these animals have needed for years. They are not currently housed in the right living conditions to suit the animals' needs, which shortens their lifespan and even sometimes causes health issues. I do not agree with these animals being held in captivity for our entertainment purposes, but if they are going to be, they need to be taken better care of. This proposal will allow the animals to have more space to swim around in, more natural temperatures of water and air, and better water quality so that the animals can live a somewhat better life. We owe it to these animals to make these changes, and because we are the ones who took them from their natural habitat we need to take responsibility and make their current environment more livable.", 'My families experience with the dolphin research center was remarkable. We have visited many zoos and centers however the dolphin research center really knows what they are doing. They seem to have a full connection with the dolphins as well as being very qualified.', 'stop KILLING MARINE MAMMALS!!!!', 'I work with field trip students that are educated at Marineland Doplhin Adventure in St. Augustine, Florida, which is owned by Georgia Aquarium.   We at Marineland are committed to educating guests and students of all ages about the animals that live there. Students are able to see marine mammals and experience a unique connection with these extraordinary creatures.    I believe that changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny many students the opportunity to connect what they learn in the classroom with real-world applications at an accredited zoo and aquarium. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. They seem to be well taken care of and great rapport between trainer and animals.', 'At Sea World Parks there is a comradery between myself, people from around the world and yes the animals too, especially the Orcas.  That cannot be replaced.
