It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'Please do not cave to the \'animal rights\' groups who want to eliminate ALL animals being taken care of by humans.  In their definition, our household pets, dogs and cats, fish and birds are being held "in captivity" and the animal rights groups want to have YOU do their bidding via regulations.  I have been to Sea World on both sides of the country many times and have NEVER seen anything wrong with animals or any mistreated of the animals and the parks have ALWAYS looked clean and neat and the animals well cared for.  Our family has learned so much about conservation and the care and appreciation of animals from our visits.  PLEASE DO NOT LET THE SEA WORLD PARKS GO BY THE WAYSIDE BECAUSE OF THESE ANIMAL RIGHTS PEOPLE WHO HAVE THEIR OWN AGENDA.  Find out for yourselves how many animals at Sea Worlds Parks have and continue to live longer than they would in the wild with the great care they receive.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please visit a Sea World park and see for yourself that what I have said is true. And write regulations stopping "the special interest groups" from closing our magnificent parks. The money that Sea World has to spend on defending themselves from the allegations of these groups is money that could be spent on making the parks bigger and helping more animals in captivity and the wild.', 'As a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you their charge.  IMATA members are our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding ecosystems and species to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient.  No matter the context the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for roburst, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to APHIS regulations related to marine mamm
column4: ["Dear Senator Thune,  We have a great deal of respect for you and the great state of South Dakota that you represent.  As 4th generation farmer/ranchers, we reserve the right to inform you of our feelings and concerns for our industry.  As cattle producers we value our livlihood and know that you do too.  We are vehemently oppsed to the importation of meat from Brazil.  As a known country with a FMD problem we cannot in good conscience accept that USDA, the very department set up to protect the American farmer and rancher, is considering this potentially devastating move.  In this business of cattle production, every day brings with it enough natural torments to try our resolve but to have such a blatantly man-made decision that could eliminate a score of cattle producers through no fault of their own is unthinkable and unconscienable.  We are asking that you support us in this battle and stand up to the USDA's decision to import Brazilian beef.  We are counting on you to be our voice.  Thank you.  Nina Kunz", 'I beg you not to allow imports of meat or livestock from ANY country with FMD. It will not only destroy the livestock industry, but will cause a horrible financial deficit.', 'I am totally opposed to the importation of beef from  Brazil.   Currently in the USA we are watching PEDv spread though the pork industry.  Even with knowledge that PED is in the USA and how to keep it from spreading we are loosing millions of little pigs.  That is sad, but the true sadness is the fact that those pigs represented paychecks for American farmers and their families.   PED continues to spread and many dollars and valuable protein which would have gone in to the food system is gone.   The fact the that risk of transmission of FMD from chilled meat is not a comfort to United States Ranchers.  PED affects only pigs; FMD can infect multiple species and would shut down the export of meat from the US to other countries.  The US meat industry can not take even a small risk in that area.  In Montana we have a Designated Surveillance Area where cattle are tested for Brucellosis on a regular basis.  The risk of brucellosis transmission from elk to cattle is only .00024 percent, yet there were four cases of brucellosis transfer from elk to cattle in the DSA in 2013.     The US cattle, hog and sheep industries can not take the "low risk" of transmission of FMD.  The risk must be zero or less. Again I am opposed to the import of meat from ANY country with FMD in it\'s livestock.', 'Please for the love of our bountiful nation do not allow this to happen. I age and source all my cattle. This is a label that is adhered to the animal all the way through to harvest. I am willing to put my name and address onto every animal I produce so the world knows I am Proud of the the protein I am providing. I am telling the consumer my food is safe to eat and it is of the utmost quality. Show me where that stamp is on imports! Our nation demands our goverment safeguards the public with a wholesome, abundant, affordable food supply that is produced by American\'s. With imports the goverment can not guarantee this right. A very wise man once told me" John, You can not manage what you do not measure." My question to you is just how does the USDA intend to measure food safety in a foreign country?  John J. Merrill  1338 CR 2310  Sulphur Springs, Tx. 75482-6893  817-832-5286', 'I agree with the idea of importation of beef from Brazil. In fact, I believe that this rule is necessary because it would be beneficial to consumers and buyers in the U.S. financially and would also stimulate the economy in Brazil as well, especially within the particular regions where the cattle are raised. International importation and exportation is beneficial to all countries involved. Both the producers of beef and consumers would realize gains in profit as well as an increase in capital and management welfare. According to page thirteen of the policy analysis given by APHIS, "For all sectors, the net welfare change would be a gain of 0.02 percent, with consumer welfare gains of $354 million outweighing producer welfare losses of $165 million." Furthermore, what people who disagree with this policy do not realize is how little this trade agreement would effect our own economy. David Harbour of Stinnett, Texas recently commented on the proposition saying, "Allowing imports of fresh beef from Brazil into the U.S. is a bad idea because of risk of introducing diseases to the U S such as foot and mouth disease which would be catastrophic to the U S."  Many people fail to realize the true extent of how much beef would actually be imported into the U.S. market. The policy analysis document that APHIS provides states that only three possible scenarios would take place if the policy were to be enacted, with them being either 20, 40, or 65,000 metric tons of Brazilian beef with 65,000 MT being the highest possible amount of beef allowed to be imported. However, in comparison to the roughly 12 million MT of beef produced in the U.S. annually, the impact of imported Brazilian beef into the market would be insignificant. The document then goes on to state that "If the United States were to import 40,000 MT of beef from Brazil, total U.S. beef imports would increase by less than 1 percent." Lastly, the government of Brazil itself has taken measures to rid their land of the Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) which is of primary concern to the APHIS agency. Since the mid-1990s, the programs instituted by the Brazilian government have made significant progress in lowering the risk of the disease being present, as the majority of the southern states (in particular the cattle-producing regions of Mato Grosso do Sul and Paraa) have observed little to no presence of FMD. In the event of an outbreak, Brazil has the capability and infrastructure to contain and stop it, and would also have to certify that the beef does not originate in any area that has been placed under restriction for FMD until 12 months after the last case in the area has been dealt with, according to the continuation policy that would be enforced by APHIS if such a case were to occur. Again, this policy would prove to be a positive one, benefitting both countries by lower U.S. beef prices and stimulating a developing Brazilian economy, while ensuring the quality and health of the meat given to the general public.', 'Subject: Docket APHIS-2009-0017  Dear Sir or Madam, My name is Larona Ganaway and I am submitting this comment to oppose the regulation changes that will allow the importation of chilled or frozen beef from the designated region in Brazil into the United States. This comment focuses on the risk of animal disease- foot-and-mouth (FMD) and swine fever. Also, concerns of the impact it may have on U.S. cattle groups, our markets and consumers if beef is imported from Brazil to the U.S. The question is will importing beef from Brazil be a burden rather than the problem resolver of the tight supplies of beef in the U.S.? Based on analysts imported Brazilian beef would not be enough to ease the tight supplies in the United States.   Foot and mouth disease and swine fever re highly contagious viral diseases of cloven-hoofed animals. They are both dangerous and destructive communicable diseases of ruminants and swine as stated in the background of the proposed rule. Section 94.1 of the regulations contains criteria for recognition by the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) of foreign regions as free of rinderpest or free of both rinderpest and FMD. Section 91.11 restricts the importation of ruminants and swine and their meat and certain their products from regions that are declared free of rinderpest and FMD but nonetheless present a disease risk because of the regions proximity to or trading relationships with regions affected with rinderpest or FMD. Although certain regions of Brazils beef is considered free of the ruminants and swine all of Brazil is not consider free of FMD. Brazil has had in the past outbreaks of FMD in 2000-2001 and 2005-2006. Although today there has not been any outbreak, however the safety of beef is still at risk.   The USDA should not approve imports of fresh Brazilian beef due to the risk of causing an outbreak.  Thank you for allowing me to comment.', '\uf0b7 -  The most recent outbreaks of FMD within the proposed export region in Brazil occurred in 2006. \uf0b7 -  USDA APHIS does not consider the countries of South America to be FMD-free with the exception of Chile. \uf0b7 -  Outbreaks of FMD have occurred in Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, all countries that had been classified as FMD-free without vaccination or FMD-free with vaccination by the OIE prior to the FMD outbreaks.    ***These three points alone beg the question "Why are we even seriously considering this?"   My operation has just recently recovered financially from the "mad cow" scares that we had a few years ago that shut off our export markets and decimated the cattle industry due to the sudden drop in prices that occurred and took far too long to recover from.  About the time we recovered from that, we\'ve had several years of recurring drought.  Now things have finally turned around for us and our government is thinking about undertaking what I consider to be a very risky move with very limited potential rewards. ***      -  The APHIS regulatory analysis highlights the possible consumer benefit from the import of 40,000 metric tons of fresh beef annually from Brazil but, fails to address the economic impact on consumers for the possible risk for the introduction of FMD virus to the United States and a resultant FMD outbreak \uf0b7 -  The risk to U.S. agriculture and to our cattle producers is far too great and the economic and animal health consequences far too significant to move forward with this proposed rule without first absolutely establishing that an attitude of willingness for compliance and a sophisticated infrastructure are present in Brazil to allow for the consistent performance of all FMD risk mitigation measures.      -  We cannot comfortably rely on a self-reporting system in Brazil to mitigate the U.S. risk for FMD.', "I certainly do not wish to see Brazilian beef coming to the US as long as there is FMD in that country regardless of how small the risk of transmission might be.  The reason that the product is cheaper is because it is an inferior product to begin with and also because of the FMD risk other world economies do not want it either.  It is not our duty to serve as a dumping ground for this product.  Our domestic cattle producers have been through a difficult period with drought, blizzards, depressed cattle prices and inflated feed costs and they really don't need help from our government or Brazil to again depress prices when things are finally looking positive.  I work in allied industry and my livelihood depends on these producer's profitability.", 'Northern New Mexico Stockman\'s Association, represent approximately twenty thousand ranchers and farmers in New Mexico and Colorado. The majority of our producers are minorites, Hispanic and Native American (Indians). In behalf of our minortiy families are comments are the following:  1. We do not support USDA in their proposed rule to allow the import of "Brazil Beef" into the United States. 2. We are very concerned about the health risks this process would impose on our people and livestock industry. 3. We believe this USDA Rule and proposed Brazil Beef import would damage the economy of our rural communites and our minority producers ability to sustain themselves. 4. We are very disappointed that USDA and the current administration would propose and support the Brazil Beef Import. 5. We belive that the USDA proposed Rule and effort is a violation of our "Civil Rights" as minority livestock producers socialy and economicly. 6. We are very concerned that USDA is not protecting our rights to fair trade for minority producers and the ability to better themselves. 7. American Beef is Safe and thats what we demand for our families and foremost our children "in our communities and accross the nation".  Note; I\'m the Vice President of NNMSA.', 'I oppose importing  beef from Brazil with the danger of infecting our beef and other livestock.', 'It is insane to expose the U.S cowherd to the foot and mouth disease and risk the ruin of our beef supply just for  quick profit for multi-national corporations. our government is suppose to protect us.', 'Please do not allow cattle from Brazil to be imported into the United States! The USDA is subjecting all livestock producers in the United States to diseases that could harm their farms and animals, one of which is foot and mouth disease.  This is completely unacceptable.  Cows, sheep, goats, pigs, buffalo, antelope, deer basically all cloven-hoofed animals (domestic or wild) are susceptible.  Its can spread rapidly from farm to farm destroying whole herds of cattle.  Countries are recognized by the World Organization for Animal Health in three categories with regard to FMD: 1.  Foot-and-mouth disease present with or without vaccination. 2.  Foot-and-mouth disease free with vaccination; or 3.  Foot-and-mouth disease free without vaccination. The United States is recognized as FMD-FREE without vaccination so why does the USDA APHIS seek to jeopardize the health of our livestock? PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW CATTLE FROM BRAZIL INTO THE UNITED STATES!', "I own and manage a family farm and ranch operation.  The largest part of our family operation is raising cattle.  This is my livelihood.  I am strongly opposed to allowing any importation of fresh beef from Brazil and Argentina.  The idea of this from an animal health perspective is crazy!  It is common knowledge that these countries possess foot and mouth disease (FMD).  This disease can be transported via fresh beef to this country!   USDA can NOT guarantee the safety from FMD or other diseases that we may not even be aware of!  Let's be realistic, their standards for food safety are not even close as to what is required here.  Also, let us not forget, their governments have been known to be corrupt at times with people taking payoffs!!!  It would actually be in their best interests for us to have an outbreak of FMD!!!!!!!!!!!!  USDA should be protecting American agriculture and its producers, NOT taking risks to jeopardize its viability.   From a market perspective, this opens the door for the country with the largest cattle inventory in the world (Brazil).  There is only one direction prices will go in the U.S. when they get in the game and that is down, down, and down!  Their producers are not held to same standards as producers in the U.S., in other words, their products are not as safe and their cost of production is a lot less.  This proposal is BAD, BAD, BAD for American producers!", 'Brazil has been shipping their beef to our country for years. In the 60" S  I was hauling box meat off of ships stamped quarantine. I do not know if it was sold in stores or not. All I hauled went to military bases for our boys to eat. They are sending their box beef here. That is enough. We do not need their livestock here to destroy our ranchers and farmers. Americans can raise our own stock. Please everyone vote against this. Do not let anything else happen to ruin our country. God Bless America', 'I am against the importation of fresh meat from an area in Brazil that is so close to areas with foot and mouth disease.  The  risk is too high.  If there was an outbreak in the US, meat prices would skyrocket, and transportation would be shut down over a large area.  We should make every effort to keep our food supply safe.', 'The concept of importing Beef from from foreign nations is not only bad from a potential health aspect of the transmission of Foot & Mouth and other potential pathogens, but is unnecessary as we currently have small US ranchers who would be harmed from the unnecessary importation of Brazilian Beef.', 'My husband and I are full time cattle farmers here in the USA. We work 7 days a week because we are committed to raising superior flavorful beef. Americas cattlemen and women have worked hard to produce quality beef that is safe for everyone to enjoy. If the USDA allows Brazilian beef in the US despite possible FMD problems in their cattle, what does this say to us? We think it shows blatant disregard for the health and safety of the consumer and our valued cattle! USDA should not be allowing beef into this country from Brazil because of the good chance that FMD (foot and mouth disease) could be brought into this country. Please protect our cattle and our livelihood and save our farms.', 'Please help to protect our farmers/ranchers by not opening our boarders to imported beef.', 'Strongly oppose approval of importation at this time due to insufficient data proving meats to be safe from serious and detrimental health factors', 'Beef from Brazil has the connotation of "Hoof and Mouth" disease.   If you are going to allow it into the country please only allow "cooked" meat products.', 'My name is Jay Smith and I ranch on the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation located in Northcentral Montana.  Our family ranch is Indian owned for 5 generations.  We have spent the lives of all of these generations trying to build our cowherd to what it is today.  Our livelihoods are solely derived from our cattle as well as the livelihoods of many others under our employment as well as the economically distressed local communities that we raise our children in.  We speak in complete opposition to this proposal to allow the importation of Brazilian beef.  The risk taken by this is far too great to our cowherd as well as the cowherd of the U.S. nation. The value we may gain by taking this risk is so little that it cannot be warranted.  We are not in need of this beef.  If Foot and Mouth disease should be detected in the U.S. our exports would be shut down leading to a huge crash in the Beef market that would make the BSE market collapse in 2003 pale in comparison.  This crash could last for years devastating an already contracted U.S. cowherd which has been in reduction due to the widespread drought, urban encroachment, and an ever increasing aged rancher.  Please do not put at such risk the efforts, businesses, and livelihoods, of so many of us Cattle Ranchers present and past . Put simply the Risk is not warranted and is far too great.', 'The US farmers and ranchers do not need the risk of FMD brought into our country. We raise enough beef in the US to feed our citizens safely.', 'U.S. citizens should be able to freely trust the safety of their food.  Bringing in cheap food should not be at the cost of citizens health and U.S.  livestock producers livelihood.  Brazil has too recent BSE and hoof and mouth to be considered safe.  Do not consider bringing in these products.', 'I object to the proposed rule for two reasons:  1.  It exposes US cattle herd to a measurable risk without significant benefit to the US.  2.  It hurts already distressed US farmers by exposing them to increased foreign competition and lowering the prices at which they can sell their product.  This accelerates the "race to the bottom" in US food quality and security by making the paramount consideration lowering consumer prices to the detriment of health, environmental and security concerns.', 'I am writing to object to the proposal to import Brazilian beef into the United States.  As a former member of the State Animal Industry Board and as a third generation cattle producer, we have worked diligently to control disease in our cattle and limit outside contamination.  There are no guarantees that livestock of any age brought in from a foreign country will not jeopardize our cattle and ultimately, our livelihood.  We would ask that this proposal be dropped and allow United States producers to continue to provide a safe product for our consumers.', 'I  am Daryl Larson from McPherson, KS and I am a cattle producer who is very concerned with the possibility that the USDA is even considering allowing imports of beef, of any type, from Brazil or anywhere in South America. I can not believe you would even think about putting the USA cattle industry, part of my lively hood and a large part of our food supply at risk by doing this. Please come to your senses and put a stop to this nonsense.', "As a veterinarian and a cattle producer, I am strongly opposed to our letting in any beef products from Brazil or any other country with foot and mouth disease unless it is proven to have been properly cooked. An accidental introduction of foot and mouth disease into this country would most likely cost billions of dollars to the livestock industry and strain an already out of control federal budget.  What is the purpose? Do we need more lower quality cuts of meat? If so, I am sure there are other countries that could supply them. Brazil won't allow us to export beef to them because of 3 Canadian cows and one highly suspect positive case from Texas 10 years ago. Why should be let this be a one sided playing field?  We should not, and cannot afford to put our livestock industry needlessly at risk!", 'No thank you, we have a hard enough time regulating ourselves, without trusting another country to sell us products that are safe for consumers.', "The United States of America is free of Hoof and Mouth disease. The importation of Brazilian origin fresh meat and live cattle will endanger the health of wildlife and livestock therefor putting our domestic food supply in danger. If it ever infected our wildlife it would be vertually imposible to eradicate          Importing Brazilian beef will cause a devaluation in the US beef cattle prices to unpredictable levels. There is absolutly no benifit to the US beef producer by importing beef from Brazil.          Our government should not let a large corporation put our beef industry in jeopardy or any other industry for that matter.         We have the right to free interprise here in this nation,  but we shouldn't let large corporations put our livelyhood in danger.          Do not allow Brazilian meat and cattle to be imported into the US!!!!!!!!!", 'This here is a prime example of what our countries problems are.  WHY on earth would we EVER import beef from ANY other Country when we as AMERICANS raise beef and are the cattle industry!  Why take away from the American livelyhood.  Why bring these diseases into OUR Country.  Common sense people.  DO NOT IMPORT BEEF!!!!!!  Why hurt the American Cattle Industry!    Complete idiocity.', 'I know I don\'t have all the political/economic interactions/discussions at my disposal but after the F&M dilemma in the UK years ago and as a Diagnostic Lab pathologist and a retired US Air Force Public Health officer, I definitely advise we not open any pathway for F&M to enter the US and thus not import Brazilian beef. I\'d hate to say it\'s a safe practice and have it blow up in our face.   I agree with Dr. Arnold\'s assessment: "I do not believe the gain to consumers in lower prices for beef outweighs the risk of introduction of Foot and Mouth disease into the United States. As recently as 2011, Paraguay reported two outbreaks of FMD type O in the San Pedro region in cattle approximately 250 miles from the Brazilian border. According to Brazilian officials, illegal movement of animals from neighboring countries as well as mechanical transmission of the virus can and has resulted in introduction of the disease. Even though the risk of introducing FMD to the US is low if all of the conditions are met as outlined in the proposed rule, the risk is still present and must be viewed in light of the devastation it would cause to the US beef industry if an FMD outbreak were to occur; especially in the area of export trade losses. Importation of fresh beef also allows an opportunity for agroterrorism as this provides an avenue to intentionally introduce a foreign animal disease. I believe it is not in the best interests of US agriculture to change a law originally issued to protect our industry only to lower the price of beef to consumers.  I am also concerned that by supporting the beef industry in Brazil, the United States is supporting an industry we know nothing about. We know nothing about their animal care standards, antimicrobial use, or their environmental protection issues. The US beef industry is working hard to produce standards of animal care, to minimize the use of antimicrobials, and to protect the environment in and around farms and ranches nationwide. By blindly supporting the Brazilian beef industry, we may be condoning the very practices we target as harmful in the United States. Thank you for considering these comments in regards to the proposed rule."  Michelle Arnold, DVM, DABVP (Food Animal) Ruminant Extension Veterinarian University of Kentucky (859) 257-7190 michelle.arnold@uky.edu    Dr. Carney Jackson DACVP, DACVPM Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory University of Kentucky 1490 Bull Lea Road PO Box 14125 Lexington, KY 40512-4125 cjackson@uky.edu 859-257-6926', "Why does the government want to undermine our ranchers and farmers by jeopardizing the US cattle industry?  I will NOT buy Brazilian beef.  I will gladly pay more at the grocery store for beef produced right here in my own backyard that is safe and disease free.  Don't mess with our ranchers' livelihood.", "Wake up America!  Please do Not allow imports of beef from Brazil or anywhere else! The restrictions on American ranchers is so strict as to what we can sell and how it must be done, such as the Brucellosis tag in the ear.  Who is going to see that All of the animals in Brazil are up to our standards? USDA? No matter how powerful the U.S. thinks it is, we cannot control what and how things are done in other countries! In the '70's we were in the dairy business, things were going well, when the USDA opened the door to dairy imports and started exporting our grain!  Wow! dairies went out of business by the droves, ours included!  Now we are in the beef business, and our own country is about to strangle us again.  We have suffered for the past three to five years with drought, beef producers have had to sell out by the droves, due to no water.  Those of us who have managed to stay in are beginning to get a little price relief, only to find that the USDA - who is supposed to help the American producer, is about to allow beef product  imports.  How do you think that is helping America.  Yes, the prices are elevated now, but the ranchers will build back up and the prices will come down again - without  importing beef or beef products! I am writing this because I do not find my last comment listed on your comments page.  Please acknowledge All comments on this.  I cannot believe that as of today, only 279 comments have been posted.  Wake up America!", 'As a cattle producer in the U. S., I am not in favor of the proposed action. I am against the importation of beef from Brazil for the following reasons: 1. We cannot comfortably rely on a self-reporting system in Brazil to mitigate the U.S. risk for FMD. 2.  Our concerns are for the resulting economic and animal health consequences should FMD enter the United States as a result of the proposed rule. 3. The APHIS regulatory analysis highlights the possible consumer benefit from the import of 40,000 metric tons of fresh beef annually from Brazil but, fails to address the economic impact on consumers for the possible risk for the introduction of FMD virus to the United States and a resultant FMD outbreak 4. The risk to U.S. agriculture and to our cattle producers is far too great and the economic and animal health consequences far too significant to move forward with this proposed rule without first absolutely establishing that an attitude of willingness for compliance and a sophisticated infrastructure are present in Brazil to allow for the consistent performance of all FMD risk mitigation measures.', 'DO NOT IMPLEMENT THIS REGULATION!!!  As a US cattleman, with a family, I am asking this not even be considered.  Why would our own Government want to risk the safety of our food supply as well as the profitability of its cattlemen.  Agriculture is practically the only "producer" of a product in left this country anymore.  We have managed to out source every industry.  To maintain the safe food chain we currently have we must not allow this sort of activity. Brazil is a country KNOWN to have Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) why would we even consider allowing that risk into our country.  DO NOT IMPLEMENT!!!', 'This proposed rule is a poorly thought out proposal that endangers the entire American cattle industry.  The USDA cannot guarantee that FMD will not be introduced into the  U.S. by this shortsighted action.  I urge you to reconsider the impact this would have on cattle industry and the economy as a whole if FMD is introduced into the US.  This would be a catastrophe our industry and economy would be decades in recovering from.  Not to mention cattle prices are at an all time high and would be adversely affected by these imports.  But that  is secondary to the possibility of annihilating the cattle industry with the introduction of FMD.', 'THIS IS VERY CRUEL AND STUPID!  Why import beef when we have plenty here, and if Brazil has an excess to export, that means they have plenty as well.    More importantly, think of the stress and the horrible conditions these poor animals will have to go thru. You will be subjecting these gentle beings to cramped conditions for God knows how long.    HAVE SOME COMPASSION FOR GODS SAKE!  Look at what is happening in Australia, there is no need to transport live animals overseas.   Please cease ALL LIVE EXPORTS and IMPORTS!  Thank you A Compassionate American', 'It is in the best interest of not only cattle producers, but sheep and hog producers to not allow imports from Brazil. The US has been Foot and Mouth Disease free for 85 years! If this disease were to hit US soil, it could be devesating to the US beef, pork and lamb industries, driving food prices to all time highs and putting thousands of livestock producers out of business.', 'The New York State Grange, a rural family fraternity, represents 4,000 members across many communities.  Agriculture is of tantamount importance to our members.  Many of our rural communities depend heavily on a viable agricultural sector as an integral part of their economy.  We would like to register our comments in opposition to a change in  the regulations that would allow beef into the United States from Brazil. Although, exporting of agricultural products is a large sector of our economy, protecting that segment is important to continued growth and stabilization of our economy.  Allowing the importation of beef from Brazil would place an unfair burden upon our beef farmers.  The cost of production in Brazil has been documented to be lower than that of the United States.  This would allow Brazil to export their beef at a much lower price than beef that is produced in here.  By driving the price of beef down to an unsustainable price for our beef producers, this would cause a decline in those farmers and the potential loss of viable farm land.  It is also a well-documented fact that some of Brazilian cattle suffer from foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).  FMD has not been documented in the United States since 1929.  Brazil has also failed to report that it has detected FMD within their beef cattle population.  There have also been other cattle diseases that have not been adequately reported that would cause severe harm to the United States cattle population.  The possibility of exposing our beef population to FMD or other diseases is not an acceptable situation.    The New York State Grange believes that allowing importation of any food products from another country who does not meet our quality standards should not be allowed.  By requiring countries to meet our standards ensures that safety of our animals and the general populace from diseases that would cause harm.    Thank you for allowing this opportunity to submit our concerns regarding the changes in these regulations.   Cindy Benson-Pollard Legislative Director New York State Grange', 'WHY DO WE EVEN CONCIDER LETTING BRAZILIAN BEEF COME INTO THIS COUNTRY WITH THE HISTORY OF  HMD AND OTHER DISEASES.  WE ARE SOUTH DAK. PRODUCERS , HAVENT WE HAD A HARD ENOUGH TIME MAKING ENDS MEET WITH OUT YOU  TRYING TO GET CHEAP MEAT TO THE AMERICAN PEOPLE AND AN INFECT OUR HERDS.      ITS TIME TO PUT AMERICA FIRST   .MR AND MRS BRUCE SCHWARZ', 'Wes
column5: ['This is nonsense.  These magnets are important educational tools.  They should not be banned.  So you sell cigarettes with a warning label but ban magnetic spheres.  Nutty.', 'I am OPPOSED to this ban for the following reasons:  1) There are a huge number of dangers to children in the world.  It is the responsibility of caregivers to protect children, not the government.  2) This ban is inconsistent with other products that are readily available in the marketplace.  For example children have easy access to deadly chemicals in the form of household cleaners that are in almost every household.  Yet there is no proposed ban on bleach.  3) If you want to say that "bleach is not the same thing because children aren\'t attracted to it"  ... well what about adult medication that is flavored?  This stuff often looks and tastes like candy ... prime stuff for children to eat.  But you don\'t proposed to ban that do you?  4) You can even buy Uranium online and get it shipped to your house ... is that not more dangerous?  5) Besides the obvious arguments about governmental overreach this is a simple case of people who want a nanny-state and want to take away personal freedoms and liberties in the name of fear.  This reason alone should stop you from enacting the magnet proposal.  Thank you for taking the time to consider my comments :)', "Magnets should not be made illegal. Isn't that a bit ridiculous?", 'Leave the magnet industry alone.  There is no credible evidence that magnets have or will cause harm to consumers.  Why not spend your (our) money on something useful instead of forcing more opression on the people of this country. Get a life and give the people some value for all the money you waste by dreaming up more government regulation that is not needed to protect anyone.', 'As a practicing pediatric emergency medicine doctor and member of the American Academy of Pediatrics, I appreciate the opportunity to comment in support of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commissions (CPSC) proposed rule on safety standards for certain types of magnet sets.   As a pediatrician, my number one goal is to keep children safe. Yet, the powerful, tiny magnets contained in the toys and other similar products that would be banned under the rule are not safe for children. These products have caused unnecessary surgeries, debilitating injuries, irreversible gastrointestinal damage and other lifelong health impacts in infants, children and adolescents.   Despite efforts by the CPSC to educate the public about the dangers of high-powered magnet sets and improvements in manufactures warning labels, recent data provide compelling evidence that warning labels are just not working. Magnet ingestions and the injuries they cause to childrenwhich can include bowel perforations or fistulas, twisted bowels and severe infections, among other serious gastrointestinal injuriesare preventable. The most effective way to prevent ingestions is to ban the sale of high-powered magnet sets, as defined in the proposed rule.     Children sometimes swallow things they shouldnt, but these magnets pose special risk to children. Unlike other commonly swallowed products like coins or marbles, when these high-powered magnets are swallowed, endoscopic or surgical intervention is required in nearly all cases to prevent bowel damage.   Magnet ingestions by children are no longer a rare occurrence. While manufacturers claim there have been few injuries from ingestion of magnets sold as part of their magnet desk toys, the experiences of pediatric gastroenterologists across the country who are treating children who have ingested high-powered magnets suggest otherwise.   Thank you for all you do for children.', "I think that it's a shame to ban something outright under the guise of children's safety.  You haven't banned nails, or guns, or nail guns, or knives etc.  Put a warning label on the box, and let Americans continue to live their lives in freedom without the government jamming it's hand up our asses.", "This is an absurd rule.  The notion that I, as an adult, shouldn't be able to buy Magnets as desk ornaments, or refrigerator stickies, or for sculpture or whatever is ridiculous.  To pursue magnet makers generally because one chose to market to an inappropriate audience, to ban them, rather than require adequate labeling is an intrusion of the nanny state, the likes of which I can't really understand.  I hope reason prevails, and this Rule is not adopted, and people can sell magnets with reasonable labelling.", 'There are a large number of science experiments appropriate for older children that require the use of magnets. These magnet sets are perfect for such experiments and the advancement of young minds. Banning their sale has a detrimental impact on this educational experience.', 'I have seen these things used, and used carefully. There is no reason that I can possibly see these things being banned! As long as there is constant watch over those who do not understand that these things should not be swallowed, there is absolutely no reason whatsoever to deprive youth of these objects.', "NO!! Please, leave these magnets alone! They're too amazing! If anything, you can just as easily put a 3+ label on it right? What about other magnets? Are you going to ban ALL MAGNETS? Never mind, forget that don't even think about it. Don't do it. Just don't..... Please..................I have a family....... DON'T DO IT!  D:", 'These rare earth magnets are easily swallowed by both children and older individuals and when they do cause a medical emergency prompting evaluation with endoscopy and even surgery.  These are products that are inherently dangerous and should either be banned completely or have their sales significantly limited.', "As a grandmother of small children, I am concerned that magnets can be swallowed and cause severe gastrointestinal injuries, even death.   Your agency has been proactive about other swallowing hazards -- please realize that these magnets stick together and will not pass harmlessly through a child's intestines.    The Bucky Balls magnet sets are sold as toys.   Please hold this company accountable as you do other makers of products for entertainment.", 'Do not limit what is not harmful to people who use things correctly.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says: "The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress."  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products like Zen Magnets that have not demonstrated similar risks.  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'Do not punish everyone for the inability of a few parents being able to raise children properly.', 'This is an absurd interference in the market. Please stop trying to regulate humans into safety, it does not work and just makes people poorer.  Go retake econ 101 before you make another law please.', 'I am writing as an experienced pediatric gastroenterology nurse and as a mother. I am aware of the potential for children to put small, attractive items in their mouths and, also, the risk these small magnets pose to the intestinal tract when multiple are ingested.  I am for the proposed rule on a safety standard for magnet sets.', 'I have purchased Bucky Balls and find them to be a fun desk toy at my office.  I uses them when ever I need to gather my thoughts or just want to take a break. I would never assume these are toys for a child.  Adult supervision and responsibility are questionable when a injury occurs, rather than the manufacturing of this product.  Please do not ban a product because people can be irresponsible. If banning products based purely on the potential for someone to be hurt because they are not responsible then cars, guns, rocks, and heights are sure to follow.', "Banning any item because someone regardless of age is not using it properly isn't the road we should travel. supper glue, paint and random other things weren't banned because they were being misused.", "Please, our country cannot afford to hold the hand of every single person in the US. Let people be responsible for their actions.  We love our magnets and always explain the potential dangers involved to anyone that gets near them -- the same way that we explain to our kids not to touch the electrical outlets and to look before they cross the street.   Wouldn't your efforts be best to include warnings on products and to educate people about the benefits of your web site (which you are probably already doing)? I think that a majority of folks would agree that this is a good example of the government providing a worthy product.  But, banning something because it can cause injury or death under extreme circumstances is going too far. Just about everything in life would fall under this category. We have to be able to take responsibility for our environment and actions.", 'The lack of intelligence of some people should not harm the selling of a product.', "Use your brains, do your job correctly, and find an alternative. Label them, make them hard to find, make them expensive, do whatever you feel like doing just don't ban them. Try to keep this country the land of the free. Any american who is concerned with the well being of their child due to magnetic toys has the right to take their child and leave the country but I do not want my rights limited due to a parent's incompetence when it comes to the well being of their child. Make it an adult-store only toy.", "This is one of those Darwinism issues. Don't punish all of us because some of us are stupid enough to eat toys (or give inappropriate toys to our children).", 'This proposed rule on magnets is ridiculous. Yes, certain magnets can be dangerous if used improperly, but then again, so can thousands of other products found in almost every home. The solution here is not for the government to over-regulate by banning what is a perfectly safe ADULT product, but rather to ensure that proper warnings are made with the product at the store and on the packaging. We don\'t need the government to act like strict parents and keep these products from us -- we need PARENTS to take responsiblilty for their own children\'s safety (by securing magnets the same way dangerous chemicals, pharmaceticals or even simple matches are), and EDUCATING their children on what is proper and what is not. People talk endlessly about our "Nanny-state" telling us what we can and cannot do -- and I usually dismiss such talk as overblown hyperbole. But in this case of banning certain MAGNETS simply  because kids might be injured -- because their parents have not properly done their own job -- I am now feeling that we may in fact be going down this road of just such a "Nanny-state". I urge the Commission to take step back, and look at this in the big picture -- such a rule is really an overstepping of the role of government.  If this rule passes, ANYTHING potentially dangerous could also be banned! Why not ban matches next?  They are very dangerous when kids get ahold of them.  Or what about various cleaning supplies? -- good lord, children die every year from poisonings, but the products themselves are not banned (instead, other COMMON-SENSE solutions are applied, like safety caps/containers, plus warnings, and the parents\' responsibility of securing the products AWAY FROM CHILDREN). So why would we do anything different with magnets?  Why should a useful product be taken away from RESPONSIBLE consumers simply because there are a few irresponsible parents who are not willing or able to follow the safety instructions on the proper storage and safety of magnets?', "Please don't take away these highly fun and educational products.", 'The proposed rule is absurd.  Magnets are safe and very fun toys for adults and teenagers.  They should be kept out of reach of small children stupid enough to eat them, but this does not justify this kind of proposed regulation.  It is not the job of the CPSC to ban a set of safe and fun adult toys because a very small subset of people are bad parents and refuse to read warning labels or use an ounce of common sense.', "Banking Bucky balls is asinine.  The precedent set means you should also ban bleach, staples, power outlets and domesticated dogs and cats as all could pose a risk to children.  Let's put some faith in parents and let a fun desk toy survive.  Require them to change their name to do not swallow balls, but please don't ban them while allowing companies to create choking hazard like bullets and diamond earrings.", 'Please do not ban Buckyballs outright.', "Don't ban bucky balls if you are going to start banning things that hurt children you might as well ban the following: bikes, trampolines, pogo sticks, bb guns, lego bricks, and swings.", 'Keep magnet sets available to the public.', "Number of children I have: 0 Number of children who come to my house: 0 Number of Buckyballs in my house: 300, plus spares. Chance that a child will swallow any without breaking into my house when I'm not at home and searching through my desk drawer: none. No amount of legislation can replace parenting. If you have children, and you don't want your children to swallow magnetic balls, don't keep magnetic balls in your home, and don't leave your children unsupervised in places where there are magnetic balls that they may swallow. Why does this require a law that bans a product perfectly safe for responsible adults? I can understand not selling them at toy stores, plastering dire warnings all over the packaging, and banning their existence in day cares and schools, but banning them altogether is ridiculous.", 'These products are not marketed towards children, they have large warning notices on them and specifically say to be kept out of the hands of children. Banning them would be akin to banning forks because they can be trodden on.', "Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don't ban them!", 'Yes these are potentially dangerous.  So are kitchen knives.  Use them responsibly, require responsible labeling, keep them away from children, and let people continue to learn from them.', 'It is HIGHLY disappointing, and discouraging, to see my tax dollars being spent on such frivolous issues such as this.  Magnets are highly fascinating, and quite fun to mess with.  While I do understand that they dangerous to children, the responsibility of reassuring their safety falls onto the parents and/or guardians of the children.  The companies who make such toys, and the magnets as a whole, should not be held accountable to the point where an entire ban should be imposed.  Also, the sales of such magnets should be restricted to ADULTS; in essence, persons who are at least the age of 18 or older; banning magnets is far too invasive.  Essentially, I STRONGLY OPPOSE the ban of magnets, and urge the CPSC to cease their efforts in banning magnets.', 'Please do not ban these items! They have not only inspired me, but also entertained me. Just because a few people dont know how to handle them does not mean they should be banned! Just put a big warning label on them!', "I am a parent and a scientist. I've worked hard in my life to introduce a love of discovery and exploration of the natural world around us. Nothing beats a hands-on example, a tactile or visual experiment to spark a child's (or adults!) imagination.   I'm saddened to learn that this bill will restrict the sale of small magnets in the US. Yes, they can be dangerous, but so can a multitude of other things found in the world. I would not be opposed to restrictions on sale to minors, nor a tax whose proceeds go to magnet safety education (though I think the safety problem is overstated).   I OPPOSE a blanket BAN on the sale of a device, that when used properly, is a wonderful educational device.", 'Just because something is dangerous doesnt mean you ban it just make sure people know what they are dealing with (signs, waivers, etc). Why ban magnets when trampolines are byfar more dangerous. This makes no sense. Dont do it.', "Please stop the idiocy of banning magnets. Ban stupid parents who can't or won't control their children instead.", "These are great products with irresponsible buyers. Don't let the irresponsible early adopters ruin what can be a great product. Imagine what would have come of other industries if people started their use with swallowing the product despite warning.", "While it is regrettable that some have made bad decisions, such as eating magnet sets, they still provide a valuable learning aid to children (engaging their curiosity to magnetism, or by learning an important life lesson that not everything is meant for human consumption).  If banning these sets outright will prevent 400+ people of questionable sense from ingesting a few, millions will be deprived from the hours of entertainment and eduction that these sets provide. Furthermore, aren't there more important things to be spending state resources banning? How many fatalities and emergency room visits are caused by tainted food, or other common items that everyone assumes are safe for consumption?  Is it really the State's position to spend vast time and resources to protect 400+ people that are not capable of understanding a warning or providing their children a safe child environment?", 'The fact is, we want children and society at large to be safe and free from products posing unreasonable risk. But magnets and magnet sets are objectively not an unreasonable risk to anyone! A review of incident data from magnet injuries and an assessment of the proposed rulings likely effectiveness in reducing magnet injuries leads to the conclusion this proposed ruling is ineffective, bad for the economy, and likely to make matters worse as ignorance about magnet dangers remain prevalent.  A ban of magnet sets will not address the dangers of magnet ingestion. Tiny, powerful magnet ingestion injuries have been documented in the medical literature long before the introduction of magnet sets, as much as 4-years before magnet sets were invented! Small neodymium magnets are already very common in many swallowable consumer goods, including Lego products, fridge magnets, science kits and jewelry.  It is clear magnet injuries are mostly accidental, and occur as a result of consumer ignorance of magnet dangers. The prevalence of magnets in society will not go away even if magnet sets go away, and therefore the danger (and ignorance of the public) remains. We need medical practitioners trained and equipped to diagnose and treat magnet ingestions properly. This will reduce medical expenses and the need for more drastic medical interventions to resolve a magnet ingestion.  This proposed ruling does not consider the use of oral aversives or magnet safety practices that international markets have already successfully adopted. The proposed ruling also neglects the need for public and medical practitioner education related to magnet ingestion injuries. There is consensus in the medical community  education about magnet ingestion treatment and magnet dangers is desperately needed! Banning magnet-sets does not even address 10% of all the magnet injuries which occur in the USA! It is clear that this proposed ruling has not been developed to serve public interests.', "Seriously?  Nice country of freedoms you have there.  Don't punish the whole for the stupidity of the few (if any even).  You can sell smokes, but not magnets?  Guess magnets don't have enough lobbyists eh?  Put warnings on em if you have to, restrict the sale to adults if you have to, but to ban them?", 'This ban lays blame for these emergency medical situations at the wrong doorstep. Whether it be magnets, Lego bricks, or drywall screws; parents and guardians should intuitively know better that to put small, swallow-able objects in the hands of children who are incapable of using them properly. Banning these items serves no real purpose and ignores the fundamental problem of bad parenting.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:   The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market. ----- A child would not have access to these magnets in any case and would not be left where he/she could get to, so ingesting would not be a concern that I can see.  Adults who buy these are aware of the warnings and store their magnets properly.  Why take away such a fun, innovative honing your skills game. I suggest you take another look at what you really are setting presedence for if this should pass because ultimately we are talking about reading warning labels and if this one cannot be trusted can any of the warning labels on a.thing else be really trusted either????  .  CT', "Before you ban magnetic spheres, I hope you will take the time to consider what you're banning. We're not talking an industrial product, no a poison, not a malfunctioning device, not something with sharp edges. A product that can cause NO POSSIBLE harm when used outside of the body. There are so many products that can do damage if swallowed. What about paper clips, tooth picks, glass... the idea that this product is dangerous if swallowed is absurd reasoning. There are tens of thousands of products which are not to be swallowed and can be deadly. What about RoundUp? if you swallow RoundUp or any other pesticide it could kill you, yet it's in every Walmart and Lowes in the country. What would happen if a child swallowed a pack of push pins? I don't see anyone banning push pins... Why is that? I'll tell you now why this witch hunt is being tolerated at all. Because the people pursing it don't see the value in magnetic spheres. Because you won't miss them when they're gone you think you have the right to remove them from the fair market. Well I can't persuade you of their importance... I doubt that's even possible. Regardless, I do hope you'll consider at least one point. A young man was once so profoundly influenced by his observations of the effects of magnets on a compass that he went on to become the one of the preeminent scientific minds of all time. That man, of course, was Albert Einstein. When you remove a source of scientific or artistic creativity and learning, you might make it safe for a few negligent parents (and be honest, that's all this ban will do) but you might cost us in uninspired and uncreated future Einsteins.", 'I can report first hand that magnets are dangerous and easily ingested by children. On multiple occasions, we have encountered children in emergency rooms and have needed to take them for endoscopies and surgeries. I agree that the CPSC magnet ban is a really good idea.', "everyone should not be punished for other people's mistakes. give them an age limit, demand a different marketing program for the things, but do not ban them.", "Don't ban magnetic set they are good learning and imagination. They are just as safe as trampolines that are marketed to children.", "Don't ban these magnets! They fuel the drive kids need for science!", 'Zen Magnets and Bucky Balls should not be banned period.  Being in the healthcare industry kids swallow things all the time, things far worse than this and those products are not being taken off the market.  These actually have educational use while being fun to play with and states right on the box that they are not intended for small children.', 'Keep the balls!', 'This is absolutely ridiculous!', 'Please do not let parent\'s inability to teach their children proper human functioning to ruin a great toy.  We need to stop \'dumbing\' down for the lowest common denominator or else we will just be a bunch of lumps on floating space chairs a la "Wall-E".  Great, innovative toys needs to be continued to be made and designed.', "Dear CPSC, Please drop the complaint against magnet sets including Buckyballs so that they may resume selling. Consider me another one of the millions who believe that attacking small business and the freedom of adults to buy products that are harmless when used properly should not be a goal of any governing body. Please drop the case against buckyballs, buy yourself a pair for your desk and have fun with them. I have not met a single person who has not enjoyed this product because of the feelings of creativity and fun that they haven't felt since building cars with legos, crafting with playdough or designing with shrinky dinks. Let us adults have this one toy that is just for us. How many products can do that for us adults who otherwise mostly have bland lives which are highlighted by the shows we watch at the end of the day. What a sad existence we would live if we lived our lives limited to what the parental guidance that the CPSC dictates. Not every product should be subject ti a risk analysis, especially when your governing body can do nothing to calculate benefit in terms of creativity, happiness, joy, inspiration and fun these toys indisputably generate. By banning these products for all you know you just removed the potential to inspire the next great scientist.    I'm currently in law school, and it is the paternalistic regulatory goals of the government and your commission that inspire me as a law student so that I can defend fantastic companies like the creator of Buckyballs.", "The idea that a magnet toy marked to adults should be banned is overreaching and ridiculous.  These products have complied with your requirements/suggestions to label their hazards and age restrictions.  Cleaning chemicals are allowed to use dyes that make them resemble fruit juices and many times scents to match that pose a much greater risk to children's health but responsible parents and guardians keep them out of the reach of children and the same is true of these small magnets.  It is true that sometimes children do get access to dangerous things without their parents knowledge but that is when you contact your doctor to prevent any more harm, not demand that the dangerous thing be banned that you at one point found appealing or useful.", "Bucky Balls, Zen Magnets, and other magnet sets should not be banned. I beleive that these items should remain perfectly legal to purchase and use, and that banning them completely is an overreaction. There are many much more sane ways to combat the problem of people ingesting these, like, for instance, labelling them in such a way that would ensure people will know not to leave them around children unattended. Also, These are not the only dangerous product on the market. They are certainly not the WORST. I don't think this is an issue that the government should have authority over; If the magnet sets were as dangerous as you suggest they are, it should be up to the customers buying them to be responsible and not purchase them.", 'Rare earth, neodymium magnets are dangerous. While they are not advertised as toys, they are easily mistaken for toys and when found by small children and ingested they frequently lead to serious gastrointestinal injuries. As a pediatric gastroenterologist I have first-hand experience with the devastating consequences of ingested magnets. During the last few years there have been hundreds of cases of magnet ingestion. An  extremely high proportion of these children require painful procedures including surgery for their removal. The ban on magnets should not be looked at as a business decision. It is a simple choice of protecting our children from objects that are not necessary in everyday life.', "I know what magnetic spheres are, and I know what the hazards are.  I use them as a desk toy in an environment that it filled for 20+ year old adults who will not choke or swallow them.  I don't think it's the government's place to tell ME that *I* can't buy these because somebody else might be foolish enough to leave them within reach of their children.  If it is the feeling of the CPSC that something simply must be done, it should AT MOST be the mandatory inclusion of a warning label.  The proposed rulemaking would effectively shut down several prosperous small American businesses, and represents an onerous intrusion into the lives of private citizens.  There are MANY products on the market that are dangerous to children, and it seems to me that the entire problem with magnetic spheres is a marketing problem.  If the CPSC is concerned that these spheres are being marketed to children as toys for children use, then simply require them to be marked as 'for adult use only', with dire warnings about the consequences of allowing a child access to the product.", "We are advanced beings, not primitive life forms. If someone is dumb enough to eat it, no matter how old, then that's their own choice. But don't make it affect all the other people who would use the product correctly.", "I, like many others, love my sculpting magnet spheres.  They're incredibly interesting, simple and fun.  At the end of the day, I've been and seen more people be injured by stepping on a Lego brick.  Any hazard these objects may pose is entirely due to negligence of the owner, and should not be taken out on the vendors or their possible customers.  Almost everything on the toy aisle in stores have choking hazard warnings.  Why should magnets be banned for that same issue?  Even food can pose a hazard.", "I certainly understand the desire to ensure people's safety - However an outright ban is a poor solution. With proper safety warnings and education we can address the situation without banning perfectly useful and fun products out of the fear that they may be misused by an incredibly small portion of the population. We have other products on the market that are equally, or even more dangerous to children - we haven't felt it necessary to ban those entirely, so why the rush to ban magnets? Use child-safe containers, education, and warning labels to ensure responsible adults can enjoy magnets without endangering children, and trust them to be the responsible adults they are.", "This product is inherently important to the creative and imaginative minds around the world, and as the United States falls behind emerging countries else where, what will banning this product do? Granted, I can't imagine one little product, single handedly making our country the best out there, but what are we stopping by banning products that introduce future engineers to the power of magnets and design? Please don't take these away, I'm sure we can find another solution besides the out right banning of a potentially important teaching aide!", "Please don't ban Buckyballs! They are the single best desk toy for adults in stuffy office buildings and unlike some products designed for and marketed at children like Skateboards and trampolines these are not even sold for with children in mind. Please don't make the government anymore intrusive than it needs to be. Let them keep the warnings they have on them or have someone sign a waver but there is no reason at all to have them banned. People get hurt all the time. Cars are inherently unsafe, as are many thing
column8: 27, -- No thank you, we have a hard enough time regulating ourselves, without trusting another country to sell us products that are safe for consumers.132, -- Our industry has been extremely vigilant in keeping our beef supply safe and disease free and we do not need this added risk.109, -- Do we not produce enough cattle to market the products to the American people without diluting the market with inferior products from other countries?151, -- We need to keep our product safe therefore I do not agree with the present rule change to bring in Brazilian beef.28, -- Our government should not let a large corporation put our beef industry in jeopardy or any other industry for that matter.146, -- Who wants to buy beef from a country with one of the most contagious and devastating diseases known to our industry?67, -- It seems like the USDA and the federal government is trying to put the american farmers and ranchers out of business!111, -- We, beef producers, of the U.S. take pride in our beef and do our best to keep them disease free.144, -- (As stated earlier, the price in the store is probably not going to decline, which means just more profit for packers.)142, -- United States beef is the only way to go and the best beef you can get so don't ruin it.103, -- Get out of the office and realize how the American farmer is detrimental to this country and quit trying to ruin him.38, -- Brazil has also failed to report that it has detected FMD within their beef cattle population.103, -- It's sure too bad government workers get paid whether they work or not!38, -- The possibility of exposing our beef population to FMD or other diseases is not an acceptable situation.144, -- As you may know, ranchers support many small businesses, so being able to make these upgrades improve the economy of these small communities.118, -- This is preposterous to think that Brazil beef is comparable to USA beef and should be sold as "safe".144, -- I believe that JBS and other packers are not spending their money in the small local communities.)118, -- As mentioned above the standards for raising beef in the USA are very high and should be.106, -- Government Elected Official, please wake up and make the right choices for the best of all the American citizens and ranchers and cattle.144, -- Our nation cannot survive without our food supply being protected!)144, -- I strongly believe that is not worth putting our nations food supply at a costly risk!144, -- Most ranchers have put many years and hard work into their herds.144, -- The chances of them being infected with a disease that could wipe out entire herds is not a risk worth taking.)144, -- We appreciate your time in reading this letter and we hope that this rule will be strongly rejected.144, -- There is no need to increase our risk of introducing FMD or any other horrible disease to the U.S. people or animals.
column9: 14, -- I am against the importation of fresh meat from an area in Brazil that is so close to areas with foot and mouth disease.40, -- Brazil has a long history of footandmouth disease (FMD).38, -- Many of our rural communities depend heavily on a viable agricultural sector as an integral part of their economy.73, -- How do we know that the governments of Uruguay and Brazil  will actually inspect the meat as our own inspectors would.102, -- We do not have the ability to assure the integrity of the system.11, -- Countries are recognized by the World Organization for Animal Health in three categories with regard to FMD: 1.116, -- So, I ask, why would we go any further in how we do business with Brazil?6, -- -  We cannot comfortably rely on a self-reporting system in Brazil to mitigate the U.S. risk for FMD.49, -- Agriculture has borne the brunt of inflation since the depression.5, -- Brazil has had in the past outbreaks of FMD in 2000-2001 and 2005-2006.146, -- I am well aware that only multinational meat packers such as JBS will benefit financially from your proposal.106, -- We do not need more meat to drive down prices.136, -- The structural and management inadequacies at and around Pirbright must be addressed urgently and comprehensively.106, -- Farmers work the hardest for small pay, we only do it because it is in our blood and we love what we do.38, -- Thank you for allowing this opportunity to submit our concerns regarding the changes in these regulations.144, -- 4) There is good cooperation between Brazilian federal agencies and their international counterparts at land border crossings.136, -- Dr Anderson also proposes that steps should be taken to create an Independent Advisory Committee on Animal and Emerging Infectious Diseases.118, -- Please do not allow the import of fresh, cooled or frozen beef from Brazil.
column10: 38, -- The New York State Grange, a rural family fraternity, represents 4,000 members across many communities.0, -- As 4th generation farmer/ranchers, we reserve the right to inform you of our feelings and concerns for our industry.117, -- Foot and mouth disease, being such an extremely contagious disease, could spread like wildfire through some of our concentrated cattle feeding areas.64, -- The PS3 disease that is killing all of the hogs was imported from China.136, -- Lets learn from the 2007 experience in England on their last out break of the disease.12, -- It is common knowledge that these countries possess foot and mouth disease (FMD).28, -- Do not allow Brazilian meat and cattle to be imported into the US!!!!!!!!26, -- We should not, and cannot afford to put our livestock industry needlessly at risk!2, -- In Montana we have a Designated Surveillance Area where cattle are tested for Brucellosis on a regular basis.38, -- It is also a well-documented fact that some of Brazilian cattle suffer from foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).2, -- The US cattle, hog and sheep industries can not take the "low risk" of transmission of FMD.11, -- PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW CATTLE FROM BRAZIL INTO THE UNITED STATES!118, -- One common practice in this region the application DDT long since banned in the USA for its detrimental effects on wildlife and neurotoxic properties.102, -- This issue is much bigger than free trade agreements.146, -- Thank you,  Jeremy and Carrie Stadheim Fourth generation family cattle and sheep ranchers Reeder, ND 58649106, -- The US Cattle Ranchers clearly do not want Brazilian meat and the risk of foot and mouth disease here to destroy our herds.144, -- I believe this is extremely vague and needs to be addressed.144, -- 5) The U.S. has been importing cattle from Uruguay with no problems from FMD.
column11: 136, -- You have not provided adequate documentation to establish animal traceability and containment of diseases in South American countries.36, -- More importantly, think of the stress and the horrible conditions these poor animals will have to go thru.36, -- You will be subjecting these gentle beings to cramped conditions for God knows how long.90, -- Let the cattle producers in the USA provide the beef that we are capable of producing, given a few years of normal weather.36, -- Look at what is happening in Australia, there is no need to transport live animals overseas.84, -- Better think this thru a little better before you ACT boys!!103, -- We can not help that, God is in control.32, -- I am writing this because I do not find my last comment listed on your comments page.136, -- It would take a strategic overview of all aspects of animal health, transcending artificial boundaries defined by government departments.
column12: 136, -- Protection of our borders is critically important; this is not the time to add another dangerous product to our border inspection services.
column13: No thank you, we have a hard enough time regulating ourselves, without trusting another country to sell us products that are safe for consumers . Who wants to buy beef from a country with one of the most contagious and devastating diseases known to our

column17: This is not the time to add another dangerous product to our border inspection services . Protection of our borders is critically important .

column2: ['To whom it may concern: I have loved elephants all my life, since I was a little girl, and I have learned much  about these wonderful and unique animals. Please consider the fact that elephants are large mammals who need a very large  space to be able to live an appropriate life. In a Zoo or Circus, the environment  does not meet that requirement. Also in a circus the elephant is subjected to methods  we would call cruel and  abusive. Elephants are herd animals, they have social needs which must be met for them  to have a meaningful and dignified life! Overall I believe that we must treat them with respect and refrain from hurting  them, locking them up in cages, isolating them from their own or mistreat them in  any way! They are innocent creatures at our mercy! We must educate ourselves to find out what the right thing is for them and then  DO THE RIGHT THING!', 'Elephants belong in groups and most zoos isolate them alone and do not have  sufficient space for their mental well being.  Also putting them in a circus to do  unnatural acts is cruel treatment to a wild animals.  Most trainers use beating and  harsh training for them to perform.  Repitious steps and acts demean the grand  creatures that they are.  If treated humanely and not having to travel and perform  constantly would be acceptable but that is not the case (most circus elephants  perform 11 months out of the year).  They are chained in their stalls and treated  roughly.  They do not belong in this enviornment.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.
