Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.   I would like to see every elephant that is captive to be rehomed to a sanctuary or  wildlife preserve to live out their days with dignity and compassion with a herd in  the U.S.   No zoo should be allowed to keep an elephant unless their habitat is at  least 50-100 acres and they live in a group of FOUR (4).   No more elephants  should be bred or purchased for the zoo unless they have this kind of habitat in  their zoo.  Most zoos are too small.  Even other animals are kept in small  enclosures (lions, primates, etc.).', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and  well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space.  Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural  conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ?  including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic  behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer  from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in  captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day  standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they  are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their  own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in  barn stalls for extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use  of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices.  These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to  those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over  which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', "I am writing to please see the cruel and inhumane treatment that is being done on  these beautiful creatures, elephants. At zoos and circus's they are chained  beaten, I think you know the whole story. How could ANYONE let these beautiful  creatures suffer so humans can have entertainment. Whether you believe in any or  no God this is so horrible to do to a living gentle creature. And if an elephant goes  on the wild we shoot it for this reason, woouldn't you try to run and escape from  being tortured or turn on the torturer. 100% yes you would in a second. Please  change these guidelines.", 'I support, and encourage, any efforts being made to drasitcally improve the  treatment of captive elephants in this country. These new standards should be  tough and include the following:  1. Cruel, painful devices such as bull hooks, electric-shock devices, and chaining  should be banned. These things have been known to cause considerable pain and  suffering to elephants.  2. Captive elephants should be held in large, climate-appropriate environments  that resemble their natural habitat. it is important for elephants to live in this sort  of environment to maintain their health.   Thank you for taking the time to read this.', "In most zoo's that I have seen the elephant facility does not provide the animals  with enough room and the care is usually inadequate.  I feel we need stronger  regulations to require proper care and facilities for these gental giants.", 'The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space, and this needs to be addressed. If regulations are not enforced,  then the those in breach are making a mockery of the importance of governmental  rule-making.  Prolonged use of bullhooks and chains should be investigated at the same time,  as adequate space is only a solution if the elephants are allowed to use it.  Use of instruments of force, including electric hotshots, are inhumane ways of  handling animals that are already mis-treated and hence are uncooperative.  Regulations to prevent this mistreatment would go a long way to making the  experiences of zoos and circuses more palatable and enjoyable - for both the  visitors and the star attractions.', 'There is a general lack of federal oversite on the living conditions of what we  generally refer to as wild animals.  That is just the point.  These animals are the  result of thousands of years of evolution which have led them to be successfully  adapted to a certain way of life.  Through our 19th century approach to such  creatures, we have negated their innate natures, forcing them to live in conditions  which are singularly inappropriate and therefore inhumane and cruel.  Elephants,  for example, are highly social, migrating creatures.  By forcing them to live in  limited spaces, which are often unhealthy (both mentally and physically) as well  as lacking in essential hygiene, we are creating the ideal circumstances for them  to exhibit inappropriate and often dangerous - to themselves, their caregiviers and  the general public - behaviors.   Keeping such animals in captivity is obviously motivated by financial gain, a  significant part of which involves limiting expenditures which would guarantee the  animal\'s wellbeing - even in less than optimal circumstances.  If their stated  purpose is indeed to familiarize the human population with animals outside their  normal scope of experience, then these animals need to be protected and offered  as close to "natural" conditions as possible.  Without strict federal oversite, this  will not occur. As the species living at the top of the evolutionary ladder, we have a responsbility  not to exploit, but to preserve less species from our depradations.  And by  insisting on adequate living conditions outside their normal habitat for these  animals, we are teaching our chirldren and all future generations an important  lesson about life and responsibility. I therefore very strongly support strict federal guidelines and enforcement of  adequate living conditions for captive animals - in this particular case, elephants.', '# Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being. # The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. # In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. # Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. # Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. # Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses  currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new standards that:  1) Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  2) Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants.   The reasons why the USDA must take action include:   1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.   5. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to elephants.   6. Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs, elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher standards than the ones that currently exist.  Thank you for your consideration of these comments.', 'I and my colleagues are absolutely appalled at the conditions of elephants in zoos  in the US...the only acceptable home for them is like the Tennesee sanctuary....I  recommend that all elephants are moved to humane conditions as soon as  possible from their tortuous existance in American circuses and zoos.', 'I write in strong support of improving USDA standards for protecting captive elephants in the United  States. Under existing standards, elephants in zoos and circuses have suffered and continue to  suffer severe, life-shortening pain and distress. They are excessively confined, housed in facilities  that cause and contribute to injuries, and subjected to cruel punishment.  Existing standards permit these deprivations of elephant welfare. I join in calling on the USDA to  promulgate specific, objective regulatory standards designed to ensure a significantly higher level  of elephant care, and to implement these standards by aggressively inspect facilities housing  elephants.  Thank you for your consideration.', "I strongly feel there is a critical need to immediately terminate elephants living in  zoos and circuses. Their health, especially foot problems, is becoming  catastrophic. Since the AWA requires zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate living space, why isn't this being strongly enforced? Any intelligent  person can readily see there is a problem at zoos. The concrete surfaces are  brutal on elephant's feet and also contribute to severe arthritic conditions over  time. Zoos and circuses routinely house the elephants in close quarters at night  and during bad weather. This only makes the problems worse....they simply  cannot move around! As you well know, elephants are highly social animals and  have always lived together in herds. To have one or two elephants confined simply  for paying spectators to look at is basic animal abuse and the zoos/circuses know  it, but whether they will admit it is another matter. Why not require zoos to have  HUGE areas for large groups to roam or simply have the elephants moved to  approved sanctuaries?  This is not unreasonable. As for circuses, it is high time  that it be made unlawful for elephants to travel in these archaic conditions. Please  consider requiring elephant's living areas be substantially increased where they will  be allowed to roam as they have for centuries in the wild.", "The attrocious conditions that exist for elephants living in Zoo's and other animal  viewing areas is rephrehensive and must be brought to an immediate halt. The  Zoo's must be required to provide adequate dirt park like areas to eliminate the  horrible and inhumane medical conditions of these beloved animals or the Zoo's  must be required to transfer all elephants to appropriate Sanctuaries, Where the  elephants can live in environments more suitable and similar to their native habitat  and recieve proper medical treatment for their ailments. Historically most  elephants will respond rapidly to the new conditions and be able to live a normal  life expectancy. I served in the Vietnam War and saw many magnificent elephants  in the wild and those that I was close enough to view had none of the medical  problems the Zoo's have imposed on the elephants in captivity. This  BARBARIC,INHUMANE TREATMENT MUST BE STOPPED NOW!!!", 'Zoos and circuses can never satisfy the needs of elephants.   Elephants are a social herd and form life time bonds, they need to have their  young  around them for many years, they need to roam & forage over miles, they do  poorly in confined spaces, they develope health problems as a result of standing  on concrete/hard dirt etc and are prone to Post Tramatic Stress Disorder from  being held captive. Read this story on PTSD from the N.Y. Times  http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/08/magazine/08elephant.html Elephants exhibit swaying the head and shoulders, even the whole body, from side to side when confined. A behaviour exhibited by mentally ill  humans.  If I were to physically force another human into my custody this would  be ?kidnapping?.  If I were to make someone perform ?circus? acts, such as  standing on his or her head, or to keep them confined as a live prop on display this  is "forced labor", better known as  ?slavery?.  Say I were to use ankuses and sharp  hooks, whips, ropes, chains, cigarette lighters, sticks, axe handles, baseball bats,  metal pipes, electric prods, blow torches, and various forms of neglect  to make  someone do what I want ?this is TORTURE!  Yet these forms of dominance are  forced on elephants in zoos and circuses. A wild animal is NEVER domesticated. Even at the wonderful Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee, a caregiver was killed  this summer by an elephant she was caring for due to the animals horrible past  memories. The elephant later showed signs of remorse. I strongly ask that all zoos and circuses or any venue using elephants have their  permits/licenses pulled and allow the remaining elephants to be sent to an  accredited sanctuary and furthermore, no more breeding of elephants in the United  States. Thank you for your time and consideration.', 'I support the efforts being made to significantly improve conditions for captive  elephants in this, our great country.  I do not believe that zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions  they require for their health and well-being.  Elephants are big animals, we know  this.  And it has been documented repeatedly that these big animals need big  spaces. Unfortunately, in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of  space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that results in a number of  preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and debilitating foot disease to  reproductive disorders to preventable neurotic behaviors like swaying and head  bobbing.  As you are well aware, the Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses  provide elephants with adequate space. Yet most zoos are not meeting this  requirement. In addition, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least  12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. In the north, elephants in zoos are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres, over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  We  have seen example after example at The Elephant Sanctuary where the elephants  have enough room to roam, allowing them to physically and emotionally begin the  healing process and act like elephants!  Our zoos need to emulate these  institutions and stop the elephants from suffering needlessly cruel and inhumane  conditions.  Most importantly, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  The use  of bull hooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force must  be stopped.    All bull hooks should be outlawed.', "to whom it may concern  I understand that you want information from good sources on how elephants should be  treated and housed, well why don't you ask the experts and get the correct information  from. them. Ms moss and Ms Poole have made it a lifes work to study the elephants.. There are others, carol buckley,pat darby and may others that have a humane  concern  for the elephants,other than exploiting them for personal gain. We are one of  the most advanced countries in this world, lets show it to the rest of the world by  the  way we treat elephants and other animals. maybe we will all sleep better at nite.thank  you gretchen garel", "Elephants are highly intelligent and very social animals, that if allowed to roam  freely in their natural habitats, form close knit family units. As such, when they  are held in captivity they deserve our compassion, respect, and humane treatment  that puts their needs first. Space limitations severely restrict their movements and  most zoo's cannot provide adequate exercise for animals that normally walk many  miles in a day. Captive elephants have a high rate of painful arthritis and chronic  foot disorders that are often the direct result of standing and walking on concrete  floors and hard packed ground.  If elephants must be held captive and put on  display, then they must be provided with the space and conditions needed to  maintain their good health and thrive. I therefore support any new regulations or  policies that would greatly improve the handling, transport, care and humane  treatment of captive elephants.", 'I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive  elephants in the U.S.  Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.  Elephants are big animals and they need big spaces.  But  in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural  conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable  ailments ? from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive  disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  To make matters worse, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least  12 hours a day when the zoo is closed.  And, in northern zoos, elephants are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California.  These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The  use of bull hooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force  must be outlawed.  As a lover of all animals, a sincere admirer of elephants in particular, and a  grandmother of four animal-loving children I cannot bear to see these  impressionable children being led to believe that the way these wonderful, gentle  creatures are being treated is acceptable.  I cannot explain to them why these  animals are made so suffer so terribly and I?m ashamed to disclose to them that  their government consistently allows this kind of inhumane treatment.  Please, do not let this continue.', 'please do the right thing for these beautiful and massive animals', 'Captive elephants require far more acreage and socialization with their own kind than zoos and circuses can afford to provide. Zoos and circuses should not be permitted to keep elephants unless they can provide an environment that simulates a wild elephant\'s natural environment. People complain that if zoos or circuses do not have elephants, then children will never be able to see a live elephant, and I wonder, what is so terrible about that? Elephants are not native to the USA, and they do not exist for the benefit of US children. Everything that I "learned" as a child by viewing bored captive elephants, I have had to "unlearn" as an adult as I realize that these elephants were just existing, not living as elephants should live.  Given that a ban on captive elephants is not likely to occur, APHIS should definitely clarify the space and living conditions required for captive elephants, enforce the Animal Welfare Act, and promulgate specific standards for the care of elephants. Elephants require far more space than other wild animals. They cannot live on hard surfaces such as concrete, as their weight puts too much stress on their joints, resulting in joint problems. After all, concrete does not occur in nature. Wild elephants live with their family members and bond with other elephants for years, so captive elephants should never be forced to live alone or be separated from elephants with whom they have bonded for years. Elephants should not be forced to live in cold weather, so if northern zoos cannot provide a natural heated environment during winter, perhaps northern zoos should not be permitted to keep elephants during cold weather.  The behaviors that zoos force elephants to perform are ridiculous and should simply be banned. Elephants in nature do not wear clothes, balance on two legs, perform tricks, wear leg chains, or travel in small enclosures for hours in all kinds of weather. Trainers physically abuse elephants to "teach" them how to perform. The occasional elephant who breaks free and charges through crowds is demonstrating that the circus lifestyle is intolerable.', 'PLEASE enforce the Animal Welfare act at Zoos and Circuses where elephants  are suffering. Please help close inhumane elephant "exibits" .  Please help improve the terrible standards of care these beautiful creatures are  forced to endure, often beaten and neglected for years, untill eventually suffering a  slow painful death.', 'I support all efforts to improve conditions for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants.   Thank you!', 'Zoos and circuses don\'t give elephants the conditions they need for their health  and well-being.  They are supposed to roam freely and not stand on cement.  They  are supposed to be with family members who support each other.  Conditions in  zoos and circuses make the animals suffer for the financial gain of others.  This is  horrendous.  They "train" which is really torture these innocent animals with whips  clubs, hooks, and electric shock devices.  Performing is demeaning and unhealthy  for these majestic animals.  Leave the animals in their natural habitat, not in our  unhealthy habitat.', 'I do not believe in holding elephants captive for entertainment or educational purposes. Circuses, should not imprison elephants, let alone be allowed to abuse them with bullhooks, clubs, shock, chaining, etc. It is terrible and unacceptable. The misery and poor living conditions are an outrage and I believe elephants whom are now in zoos and circuses should be put into sanctuaries where they are safe and healthy. Please take action to improve the lives of elephants who are held captive in the United States. Thank you', 'I strongly support the petition submitted by IDA to improve the living conditions for  elephants currently residing in zoos and those confined to "perform" for  entertainment enterprises.  By developing a strict enforcement code for the care of  elephants in this country we will ensure humane treatment for these magnificent  animals.  I believe there is sufficient well-documented research showing exactly  what environment elephants need to maintain their health and well-being.  Zoos  and circuses do not provide the conditions that elephants require.  The well  publicized example of the Detroit Zoo abandoning its elephant exhibit and  relocating their two elephants to the sanctuary in California demonstrates how  enlightened and knowledgeable experts view the inhumane conditions currently  used to house elephants.  While we applaud the Detroit Zoo Director\'s decision,  there are still too many elephants left to endure a miserable life without the basic  needs of their species. I?ve recently returned from a trip to South Africa and Zimbabwe where I observed  many elephants in their natural environment.  Certainly a spectacular sight to  witness up to 100 elephants congregating at a water hole or a family unit of 6  swimming in the Zambezi, it is obvious to even the most casual observer that  these animals require large tracts of land to feed, roam, socialize, mate and  survive.  Since elephants in the U.S. can never live the life of a wild elephant, they  MUST be protected from cruel and inhumane treatment while also receiving the  proper care along with an enriched environment.  Our Government must provide the  necessary oversight to ensure that the regulations regarding elephant care and  treatment are strictly enforced.  Modifications to those regulations should be made  to recognize the current irrefutable research on providing elephants with conditions  that meet their physical, mental, and emotional needs.', 'I fell that zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painfu
column3: ['Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Humans are called to be compassionate caregivers, protectors and stewards of the planet and its beings. Helping not harming. To create an environment  where all beings are treated with respect and compassion. Never to die needlessly or cruelly. These vulnerable, innocent beings have the right to live "cruelty-free" in peace.   Humans, believing to be superior, must use their superior intellect to research other options. Someone, with any intelligence, can solve and resolve this for a humane outcome that is compassionate and benefic for animals.  "We must remember in our dealings with animals that they are a SACRED TRUST to us.  They cannot speak for themselves." Harriet Beecher Stowe  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "Our family has had the privilege to have participated in three separate encounters with Dolphin Quest.  Each of these experiences were in the Islands of Hawaii.  We were impressed with the companies treatment of our family and our children's experience too.  Most importantly they had the animals well being and health as a priority.  As adults my children look fondly back on that interaction as an educational experience.  You could tell that the employees cared about the animals and had a personal mission to provide the best care.  In those encounters we had safety instructions on how to interact in the animals best interest.  We witnessed during the week at the Hotel the dolphins having free play time and did not observe any negative interaction.  If these types of experiences do not exist for the public we will lose the ability to connect the future generations to the needs of these animals.  Being close to the dolphins triggered many meal conversations regarding how we can protect them and help the wild populations.  I am not a employee of this company nor know anyone who works there personally.  Please help them stay in business doing good for both Marine animals and Humans. ", "It is impossible to humanely keep marine mammals in captivity. Rules and regulations can lessen the negative impact on the animals but they cannot make the captive conditions humane. Keeping these animals in captivity is akin to keeping a condor in a cage. Even a large tank, a salt water pond, lake, or lagoon will be but a drop in the world these animals naturally inhabit. They will not encounter, meet, or have the opportunity to form new relationships with new acquaintances nor will they have the opportunity to break off the ones forced upon them in a captive setting. Novelty is essentially nonexistent in a captive setting.   The recent change in perspective on the way chimpanzees would have to be maintained in captivity in order to approximate an ethnologically appropriate environment is germane to any discussion about the appropriateness of a captive environment for marine mammals. An honest evaluation of the needs of chimpanzees led the NIH to recognize that the minimum standards needed to achieve a semblance of a humane environment meant that it would essentially be impossible to hold them in a setting that allowed close observation and manipulation of those animals.   The physical space needed to provide marine mammals a humane captive environment may be impossible to manage in a commercial setting; it may be impossible altogether. I urge the Agency to revisit the matter and to look at the issue without concern for the financial costs to exhibitors. Engineering standards for enclosures and care that meet the animals' physical and psychological needs should be the only concern in the promulgation of rules and regulations governing their care and confinement.", 'This past summer we visited Dolphin Quest and stayed for a week at the Khahala Resort on Oahu. The staff was very conscientious of the health and well being of all of the dolphins   The experience I think made more people aware of the struggle of dolphins in the wild. My daughter was totally against doing the experience until we got there and saw what great care the Dolphins were under. They swam at night and the area was very large for them. The staff were very protective of the dolphins and were very knowledgable about the needs of each dolphin. I think many of the dolphin experiences outside of the US should be put out of business however, I believe Dolphin Quest does everything to ensure the well being of all of their dolphins.  Thanks for your time', 'Sea World saves Whales! Without Sea World humans would be bothering the Wild Whales.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I have had the pleasure of working at Georgia Aquarium for almost three years now. I am very lucky to have the opportunity to educate hundreds of guests everyday. My first memory of explaining how wonderful the aquarium is, was when a guest looked into Ocean Voyager and asked if the Whale Shark was sad swimming in circles all day. I told them that in fact, we have FOUR whale sharks, who live in that habitat, and that they free swim. When they asked what that meant, I told them that the habitat is so big, that our Whale Shark experts haven't been able to track a swimming pattern and they seem to be content, which means that they are acting as they would in their natural habitat. They were blown away. I also went further to explain how whale fin soup is made, and how Georgia Aquarium is one of the foremost leaders in making Whale Shark hunting illegal.  The fact that the aquarium has so many different animals and trainers that care for them blows me away.  I started working here as an Atmostphere Performer, and now I am studying to become a marine mammal trainer. I hadn't had the opportunity to see a dolphin, seal, beluga, or sea lion until I started working here. I loved learning about how well these animals have thrived in Human Care. I love educating on what we can do as humans to protect their natural habitat for future generations. I believe in Edutainment. Educating, without letting people know their learning. I think Georgia Aquarium does just that!", "My name is Colleen Peel, and I have been working with marine mammals for three and a half years.  I am a member of IMATA and am currently a trainer at Dolphin Quest.  I have had the opportunity to review the proposed regulations, and would like to submit the following comments for consideration.   The additional proposed regulations seem unjustified because to my knowledge, there is no peer reviewed scientific research that demonstrates the need for these additional regulations.  Dolphin Quest is proud to uphold the highest standards of care for our animals.  Our animals are well-loved and well-cared for.  Through my experience, I have seen these animals touch the hearts and minds of people of all ages from all over the world through interactive programs.  They inspire conservation and empower those that they meet to make a difference to help their wild counterparts and their ocean home.    I am fortunate to have been able to form a strong bond with these animals.  Through these relationships, we are able to learn from one another.  These animals' lives are very enriching, filled with play, learning and mental and physical stimulation.  This is a true sanctuary for them.  Because of the strong bonds that we have formed with our animals, I feel as if it is most beneficial for us to spend our days with them, enriching their lives rather than having to focus on managing additional superfluous regulations.    I would like to thank APHIS for their diligent commitment to animal welfare, and hope that you take the opinions of animal welfare professionals into consideration.    Thank you for your consideration.", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Zoos and marine parks are important to the education of adults and children about the beauty and diversity of animals.  By learning more about animals in a zoo or marine park setting,  we can learn the need to protect animals in the  wild.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Please, I ask for your compassion for these noble creatures!  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "I agree with this proposed rule one hundred percent, but before finalizing the rule I believe there should be some revisions made. The current proposal ignores scientific evidence gained over decades. I agree fully on all the improvements to the standards like getting ramps for the older injured seals, sea lions, and polar bears so they can exit the pool more easily. I feel like these are just minor changes though compared to what could be put in the rule.  \tI believe that the agency should make some changes to the space requirements. Recently, there has been a lot of research using very advanced tagging technology to monitor movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially polar bears. They found that a lot of these species travel large distances and dive deeper than people thought which makes the current minimum space requirements way to small. Science also now says that sea lions, seals, and sea otters also need a lot more space. The space standard was set over 30 years ago and have no supporting scientific evidence supporting it. For example, the Orcas, (killer whales) have a space that has a diameter twice as wide and a depth that's half as deep as an average adult orca is long. An Orca wouldn't be able to even position itself vertically if it wanted to because its tail would be touching the bottom.  \tAlso, standards that were set have been bent quite a bit. For example, the standard interaction time with dolphins went from 2 hours a day to 3 hours without any scientific facts supporting that decision. Also I believe there should be noise standards. For example, at Sea World, there is firework shows directly over the marine mammal enclosures. There are also massive amounts of cheering and screaming during hours of business there. Overall, I believe that we need to realize that marine mammals are not meant to be kept as pets for entertainment, but if society absolutely must need this type of entertainment, then we should give these beautiful creatures a home that more resembles a home, not a prison.", 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  I have been an animal care crew volunteer for 6 years at the Marine Mammal Center (TMMC) in Sausalito, CA. I have observed how respectfully each marine mammal is treated and given a second chance at life. TMMC is highly regarded for its care. I also researched captive facilities for 30 years -interviewing trainers and staff. The most important thing that stands out for me is that many facilities are severely lacking in space.   Regarding marine mammals on display at theme parks - and NOISE -  I would ask you to go to a casino with many loud slot machines and music blaring and see how long you would wish to inhabit that space. These marine mammals have no choice in loud theme parks. The constant noise "in season" of roller coasters and music blaring must be incredibly stressful.  I have watched orcas "head lobbing" before a performance, dragging their tail flukes on the bottom of a cement pool...because the pool is not even as deep as they are long. Please write some standards that increase pool sizes!  Please do not allow any increase to cetacean interaction time. These magnificent marine mammals should not be forced to interact with humans in swim programs or entertainment programs. This is not educational - it is cruel. Reduce the time they spend with humans...please do not increase it.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "The first time I visited SeaWorld, it was obvious to see the love between animals and trainers.  In the many years since, I've seen SeaWorld rescuing sea life in San Diego often.  I believe SeaWorld is providing education and strongly support them.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'As pass holders for years, I believe they take great care of all there animals and also help those that get injured. I believe they should be allowed to continue doing what they do  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  They take great care of all the animals and go above and beyond to make sure they are cared for.', 'I have dedicated my thirty-year career and my life to improving the welfare of exotic animals -- both "captive" and "wild" -- across the globe. It was a visit to SeaWorld while in high school that set me on this course.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  It\'s not the fault of SeaWorld or other aquaria that our natural world is in such a state of decline. To appease activists seeking a convenient outlet/target for their frustration at (ultimately) unchecked human population growth and carelessness would be a mistake.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Free the Lobsters from their restaurant tanks and the parakeets from their cages, but LET SEA WORLD CONTINUE TO BE A BEAUTIFUL AND EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE FOR THE PEOPLE TO LEARN AND APPRECIATE OCEAN LIFE.', 'I am requesting that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and are in the best interest of the animals.', 'Dear Sirs:  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please use science as a guide in any new regulations for marine and all animals at parks or Zoos.', 'Our family has been a visitor to Gulfarium Marine Adventure Park on Ft WALTON Beach Forida for many wonderful years.  It has been invaluable in not only teaching my kids and now grandchildren a love and appreciation for marine life but also has instilled in them an appreciation for these people who take such good care of the animals.  We have had many encounters with the trainers who have always demonstrated their love for the Dolphins, sea lions, etc.  the facility is always clean and the utmost care is taken to keep the animals safe and healthy.  It is easy to see their love and also the love from the marine life who live there.  The personnel have taken considerable time with us on each visit to relay information
column4: ['I am writing to express my opposition to any importation of meat from Brazil.  We, in this country, are able to furnish consumers with meat that is safe.  We have the ability to produce an ample supply if there was no interference in our marketplace. Why would our own government want to force US producers  out of business due to the importation of a potentially unsafe product from any foreign country?  Please stop any moves toward that end.', "I strongly object to allowing the importation of beef from Brazil because doing so would jeopardize American cattle. Brazil is a country known to suffer from Foot and Mouth disease which would put all American cattle producers at risk. We have worked hard to make our beef the best in the world. Please don't throw away generations of sweat, toil, and tears on imported beef.", 'I am opposed to the importation of beef from Brazil!', 'I am a beef cattle verterinarian from south central Nebraska and I believe the proposed rule to allow importation of Beef from Brazil (or regions of Brazil) provides too much risk for the introduction of foot and mouth disease (FMD) into our country.  There are several reasons I believe the risk is too high for introduction of FMD from Brazilian beef.  Although there are regions of Brazil that are deemed free and have been deemed free from foot and mouth disease for some time we also know other regions are not.  We know Brazil has used a combination of vaccination, quarantines, stop movements, etc to control the disease howver we do not know how close the disease is to cattle in the deemed free zones.  It certainly is unclear  that the seperation zone is adequate in Brazil to provide absolute assurance that airborne and vector spread will not occur.  Vaccination for FMD is a standard practice in Brazil and we have no idea if animals were not vaccinated if the disease would come back.  Because Brazil continues to vaccinate for FMD I believe it shows that they are not comfortable in their own risk assesments or preventative measures.  Why should the United States trust their system when its clear they are not comfortable stopping the practice of vaccinating for FMD?    I believe that we need absolute assurance that the product arriving in United States would have no risk in bringing live virus to our country.   Deboned beef as a commodity is likely low risk in harboring live virus however we do not have studies or models that conclude the risk is negligible enough that we risk our nations beef supply.  The OIE itself does not know what the risk would be and says so in its 2009 report.  It would be my recommendation that the US not import beef from a country that has been endemic with FMD for many years until risk assesments, models, and further science proves the risk to be negligible.', "As a cattle raiser in NE Texas I am strictly opposed to importation of beef from any country that does not control diseases in their animals that may be transmitted to our beef supply here in the U.S.  Our country has worked hard to control diseases in our food supply and therefore our prices for our beef here in the US reflect that.  If this is a move by the USDA to lower our prices by flooding the market with foreign beef then this needs to be stopped.  I have yet to see a steakhouse in my home town on any given night, that is not at capacity with patrons.  If beef is too high, don't you think that the rule of supply and demand would dictate our beef prices.  It its too high, it doesn't sell and prices go down.  If people are buying and the supply is low then prices will remain high.  I say leave it alone and let the market decide where the price will be.  For once in several decades, the cow calf operator can finally see a profit.  Lets keep that way, at least till the cow numbers increase.", "The UK took a 20% hit across the board for production ag - not just beef production.  What Is the reward here???  I'm sure there is all kinds of money to be made by interests that don't have to endure the consequences of FMDV contamination in ou herd.  Aren't we a beef producing country.  This will only negatively affect our own livestock markets.  Haven't we destroyed enough manufacturing in this country, outsourced enough labor or brought in enough illegal labor... Do we really need to risk production ag in the US?  It's all risk and no reward for production ag who bares all the risk.  The protocols in place in brazil all depend on self reporting by producers, chilling beef to inactivate FMDV even tho it can remain active in blood clots etc.  why open the door voluntarily?", 'Why would the USDA consider allowing the importaiton of Brazilian beef be allowed when the pork producers have been coupled with a known disease but of unknown origin? Nations who are willing to meet our standards of quality should be on a consideration list but only after substantial documentation. It doesn\'t take other countries but a mili-second to turn away a ship of American beef product at the hint of a concern. We shouldn\'t have the need to be concerned with " whats on the boat" if we don\'t allow te import of question to begin with.  Even though cattle prices are at an all time high and cattle inventories are at a 60 year low, the allowance of Brazilian beef or  other increases of imports from approved nations that are sub standard to our home raised product should not be allowed.', "100% Against the importation of beef from Brazil.  This importation will hurt the agricultural families of the United States in more than just the prices of beef.  The high probability/possibility of reintroducing foot and mouth into the US, and therefore destroying the US herds and more than likely introducing into Canadian herds as well, is more devastating to herd owners than the price.  The chance of infection and the spread of the disease would be detrimental to ranchers herds due to slaughter (even if they weren't tested positive but if they had been exposed) and would also increase the price of beef for the American consumers.", 'We oppose the rule for importation of beef from the region of Brazil, Into the United States, Thank you', "This is a terrible idea. We have excess farmland here, we don't need to bring cows all the way from Brazil just so some middle-class family can save twenty cents. Really, who is getting a few billion dollars off of this deal? F*** them for screwing our planet.", "Importing cattle from Brazil would be devastating to the US Beef Industry.  The money involved in this proposal is obviously coming from some where, not that it matters, but we need to think before passing regulations and laws that have the potential to be this detrimental to our industry and the families that work so hard to build it up.  We have one of the safest food supplies in the world, why would anyone jeopardize that.  I understand their need to find a market for the products, but importing food with different standards/inspections is not what we need.  APHIS should be aware of all that our countries' producers do to provide the most healthy and safe product we can.  Why would they be OK with bringing in foreign product of lesser standards?  I would also say that COOL would prevent this from ever happening!", 'The proposed importation of Brazilian beef frightens me.  I am confident the United States produces beef that is safe for my family.  I do not have that confidence with Brazilian beef.  For example there is a possibility imported Brazilian beef may bring non-indigenous or irradicated diseases, microorganisms, parasites, etc. to the United States.    I don\'t want this imported beef to jeopardize the safety of our food supply.  If Brazilian beef is allowed into the United States, I hope it is labeled "Product of Brazil" so I am not fooled into believing it is a safe American product.  I am not confident the Brazilian slaughter plants treat animals as humanely as the United States.  I want to be assured Brazilian cattle are slaughtered with the same care and oversights that are required in the United States.    I am also concerned that Brazilian slaughter plants are not as sanitary as those in the United States.  I do not want beef from a foreign country that does not meet or exceed American standards.  Please do not jeopardize the safety of the American food supply.  Do not allow the importation of Brazilian beef into the United States.', 'I would like  to voice my opposition to the importation of beef from Brazil. Their recent history of Foot and Mouth disease tells me that introducing that into our country\'s beef supply could be devastating. Our nation\'s farmers and ranchers strive to produce the best product possible for our customers, and this move could put generations of them out of business. I say "generations" because we have three generations currently on our family ranch and we are not unique to the industry. Also, the American consumer does not deserve to be subjected to less than quality beef. Perhaps the fact that the USDA is even considering such a move may mean that the USDA directors need to be more in touch with agriculture.', "We like many other concerned citizens would like to take this opportunity to comment on the proposed importation of beef from Brazil. We are fourth generation US cattle producers. Brazil is known to have FMD prevalent in their herds. This is a seriously damaging disease and it is an unwise idea to take action that would increase the risk of FMD disease to our US producers. There is no good reason why we would knowingly import the FMD pathogen into the US, doing so could cost US cattle producers and the US economy millions of dollars. The US has been free of FMD since the 1920's. If anything we should be ensuring FMD is not introduced and strengthen our import restrictions by not allowing beef imports from Uruguay (also a FMD state). We are blessed to have not been impacted by FMD from Uruguay, why would we want to push our luck? We should not be importing potentially infected beef into the US. The impact of such a careless decision will be felt in the rural and agricultural community. The irresponsible, careless and dangerous proposed rule will put the cattle producer, their livelihood and the well-being of farm/ranch families in peril. The US government and USDA should not even be considering such a reckless policy decision. Please know that we feel by bringing beef from Brazil into our country you are putting our livestock industry in harms way. America's cattle producers and consumers expect more from our government than this careless and rash policy. Sincerely.", "While stringent procedures can theoretically avoid a foot and mouth outbreak in the United States, human error still exists.  The severity of Foot and Mouth outbreak would be devastating to ranchers.  This disease would kill cattle that have taken years to breed for superior genetics.  The disease would also devastate the market price. I lived through the BSE market crash.  If the happened again I would give up.  There is not enough money to be made in raising beef to offset the risk of importing fresh beef from Brazil.  Who will be the losers?  The cow calf producers that loses his cattle due to death. The LIP program will help some but won't keep me in business.  Without the cow calf producer and the calves we raise, the beef industry doesn't need feedlots, packing plants, purveyors and others.  Jobs will be lost; community unemployment will go up.  Economic devastation.   We need food raised in the United States to have our own food security.  Unless we add Brazil at the 51st state, we need to keep our national beef herd healthy.  Don't allow importation of Fresh Meat from Countries with Foot and Mouth. Even if the county has so called 'regions free of foot and mouth'.   The Risk is too great.  I can't afford another 'BSE like' market collapse due to human error.    They can ship cooked meat.", 'I strongly feel as a producer and as a scientist with a Master degree and 40+ years of experience that the Importation of Beef from Brazil is an extremely bad idea.  The risk to the US animal industry as well as the US economy is just too great.  Consumers think the price of food is high now, if FMD gets introduced into the US, food prices will sky rocket.  There is not enough vegetable protein available as consumer accepted products to replace the lost animal protein if FMD is introduced to the US. The taxes collected from the AG industry will cease and a expanded welfare class will happen.  There is not enough money in agriculture to withstand FMD if it should be introduced into the US.', "Importing beef from Brazil and Argentina sounds to me like a purely political plan which does not consider the safety and quality of the beef to be eaten by the US consumer.  We should not risk importing hoof and mouth disease which was eliminated here years ago. Hoof and mouth disease in the US would devastate our domestic beef industry and ruin our beef export markets as well.  We don't need this imported risky beef.  The US can supply its own beef needs.", 'Importing additional meat into the United States will negatively change the market price of feeder and stocker livestock currently owned. This will cause many small and medium sized cattlemen to go out of business and as a result lower the price received for calves at weaning time this fall. Because there will be fewer people competing stocker calves the cow calf producers will have a smaller income and will have less incentive and fewer resources to replace their older and open cows and this will result in an even smaller national cow herd. If we allow the national cow herd to decrease farther our nation will become dependent on other countries for beef as we are for oil. This would be most unfortunate and The United States would loose some of its self sufficiency. we must not allow America to become dependent on other Countries for food. Please do not allow this to happen.', 'I am not in favor of this. It will increase our risk of introducing FMD into this country and would have an adverse effect on the cattle business. And we would lose more of the smaller producers. This will not be a positive move for the producers in this country.', "This is irresponsible and dangerous and a slap in the face to the cattlemen in our own country!!! I don't know about YOU, but I certainly don't want Foot and Mouth disease to be brought into our beef supply.  Please don't do this!!!", 'We strongly oppose the importation of beef from Brazil.  We cattle producers are finally receiving decent prices for our beef.  The importation of beef from Brazil will introduce the risk of foot and mouth and/or BSE contamination in our market.  The importation of Brazilian beef will lower our prices and threatens both our domestic and export markets because of the disease that is known to exist in Brazil. It is critical to our livelihood that you not allow the importation of Brazilian beef.  Thank you. Bernard and Laura Barnaud  (family owned operation of 50 head of cows, two bulls and 20 replacement heifers)', 'As with many US ranchers, I oppose this rule because of the risk to the US beef market getting devastated by poor quality foreign meat with a history of disease.   The ONLY way I would ever agree with this rule is if there were strict labeling requirements present at the consumer level.  Then people would know what they are buying and it is not American made, or regulated as such.  Absolutely no live animals should be considered.  That is the only way you could do this and protect the US cattle industry from potentially billions in losses from a recall.  Of course, Brazil would probably whine about labeling but we have to stand up for our industry.  Label or no deal.', 'In its supplementary background information, APHIS states that it has "reviewed Brazil\'s FMD control and eradication program...and concluded that the program is effective...."  It further briefly discusses Brazil\'s vaccination practices, traceability, surveillance, and diagnostic laboratory capabilities.  How can APHIS conclude i) that Brazil\'s FMD control and eradication program is effective when its program has not successfuly eradicated the disease and ii) given Brazil\'s failure to eradicate FMD, how can there be any real confidence in that nation\'s infrastructure and its capability of preventing the exportation of FMD to the U.S.?', "I am a livestock owner in Wyoming.  Everyday the ranchers and farmers battle to put  high quality food on the consumers table.
