We vaccinate our livestock and try to keep them free of disease, healthy in every way and work them with minimal stress. I take issue with the proposed rule and here is why: 1-FMD has been prevalent in Brazil and if introduced through imports into this country this disease could wipe out whole herds.  Families would be left with nothing to produce.  The livestock industry would be devastated by this disease. 2-American meat is inspected for safety and quality levels.  Introducing foodstuff that could harm the consumers trust in our American product would hurt the American's rancher and farmer ability to market their product. 3-We should be doing everything in our power to increase the economy in America instead of offering to open our doors to inferior or potentially harmful products that will compete with American home grown substance.   4-Our country is hurting and needs more marketing power and as safe as product as we can produce.  All it takes is one bad element and the consumer will start to question whether America has their best interests as a goal. Please do not accept this proposed rule, Please do not extend it, Please just drop this rule because of its strong potential to cause devastating harm to American industries.  There are other things we can import from Brazil that do not carry the eventual certainty of introducing a fatal disease into America.  We want to produce healthy high quality food for American consumers help us to do so without imported threats of disease. Thank you.", 'Why would you sacrifice the american beef industry with hoof and mouth disease, from the importation of brazilain beef, with the risk of devistating the ag economy, the food supply, and the jobs that are generated from the ag industry.  Also it would jeopardize the wildlife in this country from the very hoof and mouth disease that Brazil has been unable to control for many years now, and cause more vast spreading of the disease.  Large corporate america should not be able to influence the free enterprise system in America with foreign policy and products.  It is absoulutely mandatory that we control our beef cow numbers and price levels to a level that we can survive on in a small family ranch, because these very families are able produce the beef cheaper than large corporate america and higher quality.  The importation of beef directly effects beef production in the family farm or ranch.', "As a Kansas Cow/Calf Operator I am completely against the importation of fresh or chilled meat from an area with known FMD outbreaks in the relatively recent past.  I have no confidence in either Brazil or APHIS's ability to determine if all meat to be imported is actually free of this extremely destructive disease, and we are woefully unprepared to deal with an outbreak in the United States.  The direct economic consequences of such an outbreak would be disastrous for operators such as myself, and for a host of supply chain vendors upstream, and consumers downstream.  APHIS has neither the funds nor ability to deal with such an outbreak, and taking such a chance for only a minimal benefit to our beef consuming public stretches the risk to reward ratio completely beyond reason.  I ask that you take the only action open to protect American consumers of beef, and producers, and reject this rule as irresponsible.  Rex Savage", 'I am against allowing the importation of Brazilian Beef into the United States. The United States has been considered free of hoof and mouth disease since 1929. It is foolhardy to take even a "small" risk that could allow one of the most contagious animal diseases known entrance into our environment. This is a virus that is always evolving. Britain had an outbreak in 2001 that devasted many livestock farmers.  This is not just about a commodity. APHIS is tinkering with national food security and people\'s livilihoods. Just as small producers are more likely to be affected by the increase in imports, they will also be more proportinately hurt should there be a foot and mouth outbreak. National policy should be  made in the best interests of American producers. Small farmers are important!', "Our family owns and operates a beef cattle business in Gunnison, CO and does not support allowing import of fresh and chilled beef from Brazil because of the risks it poses for the markets of the United States.  The history of problems with FMD in this region of the world is too prevalent to take the chance of harming the cattle markets of the U.S. with just one case of FMD entering our area.    Even USDA's own data states there is a risk and this action will decrease profits for producers in the United States without any increase of exports to Brazil.  Our family doesn't understand why this action is even being considered.  Please do not allow this to happen.", "The business of cattle production in the United States has taken enough hits from imported animals, or beef product, that we don't need any more relaxation of import standards.  The fact that Brazil is not, completely, FMD free is only bolstered by the fact that nearly all of it's neighboring countries are also not FMD free.  The USDA and APHIS are charged with the protection the US cattle business NOT the Brazilian cattle business regardless of the deep pockets of the Brazilian beef processors. The USDA should have as its first priority the safety of the US consumer and the US beef business. It is imperative that this rule be vacated and the US be protected!", 'As a former USDA Veterinary Medical Officer and former rancher, I am very concerned about this rule allowing beef from Brazil to enter the US.  I am concerned about diseases that may affect the livestock industry in the US - mad cow, foot and mouth, etc.  Also, ranching is a tough way to make a living and imported beef will depress the market substantially.  It is not fair to the US ranchers to decrease their already small income.', "Seriously???? we have way too many things imported from other countries!!!  And many of the items that are non food items have had problems (ie china using lead paint in children's toys, etc).  Why try to crush another industry in the United States!!!  Again, we import too many things as it is, which has lead to companies in the US closing and our economy being as bad as it is today with a lack of good paying jobs.  First and foremost we must take care of our citizens, why ruin the beef industry as well??  I honestly don't know what the government thinks when allowing other countries to import anything at our detriment.  I don't care if there will be FDA regulations, what I care about is taking more away from the beef producers!!! If this is passed I will refuse to eat any beef from other countries.  We have to start looking at what we as a country can do to improve our economy!!  Seriously!!!!", 'BEING ON THE BORDER OF TEXAS AND MEXICO, DISEASE TRANSMISSION IS A ISSUE THAT MUST BE TAKEN SERIOUSLY.  ALLOWING IMPORTATION OF BEEF FROM ARGENTINA AND BRAZIL WOULD NOT BE WISE.  UNLESS THOSE COUNTRIES CAN STEP UP THEIR DISEASE PREVENTION AND AT LEAST MATCH STANDARDS SET FORTH BY THE UNITED STATES, WE ARE ASKING FOR A TRAIN WRECK. AS A PRODUCER AND AN AGRICULTURE SCIENCE INSTRUCTOR I AM ADAMANTLY OPPOSED TO ALLOWING THIS TO TAKE PLACE.  THE FACT THAT LABOR AND INPUT ARE LOWER IN THOSE COUNTRIES ALSO RAISES CONCERNS ABOUT COMPETITION IN THE UNITED STATES MARKETPLACE.  IT IS HARD ENOUGH TO TURN A PROFIT IN OUR CURRENT ECONOMY.  ALLOWING ANOTHER COUNTRY TO ENTER THE MARKET PRODUCING A PRODUCT THAT HAS FAR LESS MONEY INVESTED COULD HURT SMALL PRODUCERS LIKE MYSELF.', "I have enjoyed a life in the US Cattle Industry. All with a close view of genetics exports. My company has produced and exported bull semen for 60 years now. I have done a lot of business in Brazil. I have traveled there several times. My company has dealt with the USDA and APHIS for decades. All of this experience tells me that importing beef from Brazil is not worth the risk. FMD is only one aspect of concern. The risk is one thing. Depending on the USDA and/or APHIS to FULLY regulate is quite another. I am not willing to bet my life's work on either.", 'I am a third generation cattle rancher from Belvidere South Dakota who strongly opposes the importation of fresh, frozen and chilled beef and live cattle from Brazil, Argentina and any other country or country that borders a country that has FMD.  I strongly urge USDA/APHIS to rescind this proposed rule.  In the proposed rule APHIS admits there is a minimal risk of introducing FMD to the USA.  This is of no comfort to me as in the past USDA /APHIS has said there was a minimal risk of FMD in South Korea, Japan, South Africa and Argentina and within a very short period time in some case as little as  6 months these countries had an epidemic out break of FMD which involved the mass slaughter of millions of livestock and wildlife.  The Department of Homeland Security has spent billions of dollars to prevent terrorism in the USA so why would another department of the United States Government want to invite the risk of economic genocide to not only the livestock industry of the United States but the entire economy of the USA.  To allow fresh and chilled beef from Brazil, a country known to have FMD, is taking a foolish risk  that could very easily result in the introduction of FMD to the USA. In the event FMD were introduced in the USA it would cause economic ruin and devastation to all industries in the USA as all commerce would shut down tourism included. All we have to do is look back to what happened in Great Brittan around the turn of the century.   FMD is a disease that is highly contagious and very difficult to contain. The disease can be carried on the wind on a humid day up to sixty miles. The incubation period for the FMD is 14 days with 3 days to confirm meanwhile the disease is spreading.  The way that livestock move in commerce it would be nearly impossible to contain.  The best defense the USA can have is to keep fresh, chilled beef and cloven hoofed livestock from entering the USA from countries known to have FMD and countries that border FMD infected countries.  Brazil and other countries that have FMD can export meat to the USA if it is cooked for the appropriate time and temperature so people on low incomes will be afford to buy canned and cooked meat. So to say that the USA needs to import fresh and chilled beef to help low income people afford beef is not necessarily true.    I think it is high time that USDA/ APHIS started protecting the US livestock industry from disease as it mission statement says instead of continually trying to appease the interests of foreign governments and their meat packer allies.', 'Why would you, the USDA, want to jeopardize the herds here in America, and our beef farmers ways of life? This is not only a unsafe health risk, but also a financial hit to our already slumping economy. As a country that is FMD free with no vaccines, it is not a smart move to take the chance to bring it back to the states where lives can be destroyed, both human and livestock lives. Do not allow this to happen on our soil.', 'We, as family ranchers, (over 100 years in existence), are adamantly opposed to the importing of Brazilian beef.  Our two daughters and my brother are involved in our ranching operation and all of us believe this would be a huge detriment to our beef operation.    They have had numerous outbreaks of FMD so why would we want to risk it bye  importing some of their products into our country.  The Merck Veterinary Manual cites "FMD is endemic in most of South America" and as far as treatment and control, it says "The most effective preventative measure is to prohibit introduction of animals or animal products into FMD-free countries . . . . ."!  Please do not allow their possibly contaminated products into our country and risk our livelihood that we have worked for over 50 years to establish.  The consequences of an FMD outbreak in the United States would be devastating to the livestock industry!', 'This proposal to import fresh and chilled beef from 14 states in Brazil is anti-American, irresponsible and dangerous.   This will increase our risk of introducing Foot and Mouth Disease into our American Cow Herd, destroy the U.S. cattle market and drive even more U.S. cattle producers out of business.   At a time when some of the cattlemen in this country are trying to rebuild herds due to Blizzards or drought, this will only drive down the prices of the US production.', 'The South Dakota Stockgrowers Association strongly opposes the adoption of this proposed rule to allow 14 states in Brazil to export fresh and chilled beef to the United States based on risk of Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) contamination in the United States, and negative impacts to the United States beef market.  The South Dakota Stockgrowers Association (SDSGA) was founded in 1893 and since that time our mission has remained unchanged, to promote and protect the South Dakota livestock industry.  Today we represent over 1,000 ranch families in South Dakota.  On behalf of those members and inline with our mission, we ask for consideration of the following points:  1.\tFMD is the most contagious disease known to animals like cattle, sheep, hogs and deer. FMD is endemic in South America and USDAs own analysis concludes that, there is a risk of reintroduction from adjacent areas into the proposed exporting region."  SDSGA cannot support opening of these Brazilian markets when a risk of FMD is prevalent.  USDAs analysis of border security in Brazil and disease control through the ports of export does not satisfy our concerns that FMD remains a serious risk. No risk of FMD introduction to the United States is acceptable.  Additionally, USDA has not included a potential introduction of FMD to the United States into their cost analysis.  Controlling, managing and recovering from an FMD outbreak in our country would be nearly impossible for the independent livestock producers that we represent. 2.\tUSDA admits that imports of cheap Brazilian beef will harm U.S. cattle producers. USDA states, "The fall in beef prices and resulting decline in U.S. production would translate into reduced returns for producers in the livestock and beef processing sectors."   USDA\'s economic model estimates U.S. cattle producers will be harmed by as much as $316 million per year.  SDSGA is seriously concerned about the impact that this will have on U.S. cow/calf and smaller feedlot producers while the packing industry will only benefit from the purchase of cheaper products.  We cannot support USDAs implementation of a rule that will negatively impact the independent producers of the U.S.   At the same time, Brazil imports only a negligible amount of beef and is not expected to import any significant volumes of U.S. beef.  Meaning that the risk of both market impacts and disease outbreak do not carry any benefit for U.S. producers.  3.\tFinally, SDSGA strongly urges USDA to extend the comment period for this rule.  Given the gravity of this rule and the serious potential impact to the United States cattle industry, USDA would be prudent to take a slow and measured approach to consideration of comments and further analysis of this proposal before moving forward.  We intend to submit more thorough comments regarding the impact of this proposed rule if we are allowed more time for consideration and explanation.  Thank you for your time and consideration of our comments.  At this time we reiterate our opposition to this proposed rule and encourage USDA to either repeal this proposal or at the minimum, extend the comment period for consideration.  Respectfully Submitted,  Silvia Christen, Executive Director South Dakota Stockgrowers Association', "Please do NOT allow beef from Brazil to come into the USA.  I am a rancher on a ranch that has been in my family for over 100 hundred yrs.  I would like our ranch to be able to continue on for yrs to come but by allowing Brazil to bring beef into our country you will drive down our cattle prices plus you
column5: ["I just want to say that a couple of years ago I gave a set of ZenMagnets to my two great-nephews who both have ADD. The youngest is now 12. They played with them for hours. That was the best gift I have ever given them (or their parents).  It would be a shame to deprive others of that opportunity.   You can put warning labels on packaging but you can't force people to read and follow safety rules. People being people are going to do stupid things. They are going to do things and get hurt. Are you going to ban knives because someone might hurt themselves while cutting their dinner?  It's ridiculous to ban a good product because someone might get hurt if they don't follow safety rules.", 'I think that immediately banning this product is rash. Before simply getting rid of it forever, I think that some of the steps preceding this sort of ban should be taken first. Anyways, It is a very fun toy, and I think it should be given a chance.', 'Death and destruction. Israelis bombing the Gaza strip. Guantanamo Bay.  The manufacturing base of the USA moving to China.  Macro things in life that are important.   Prohibiting magnets is such a minor issue in the overall scheme of things, you should be ashamed of yourself for wasting (yes, that is the proper word) time and money on the off chance that that an unsupervised child eats magnets. I have magnets, and love them.  I will even make you a deal... If you (I\'ve no idea who "you" might be) can explain magnetism, I will support your cause. Hey, Ill even make it easier... if you can explain either magnetism or gravity to me, I will buy in to your nanny state philosophy.   With no scientific basis other than "$h!+ happens", a little piece of happiness is  possibly being regulated out of existence.Have you done a risk/reward analysis? How many people have actually been hurt by Zen Magnets or the like? The saying is that patriotism is  the last refuge for a scoundrel, I would say legislating behavior "for the kids" is the last refuge. Sorry. I don\'t need your help. Thanks anyway.  In anticipation of Big Brother eliminating one of lifes pleasures, I will buy several sets of magnets while possible.  Isn\'t it clear that Big brother is sticking its nose where it ought not be stuck in this case?    Please reject the proposed rule, and the world will be ever so slightly improved.  Thanks           .', 'A ban on these products is an over-reaction.  There are thousands of everyday substances and products that pose a higher risk of injury or death.  Age limitations are a more appropriate solution.', "I'd just like to say that I think it's completely asinine to punish the entire population because a few people are irresponsible magnet owners. I agree that perhaps a bigger warning, and maybe an age restriction should be implemented, but to ban them completely is downright stupid. I vote NO to the ban.", 'Please find something more useful to do then waste any more time on this Standard. Trash this proposed standard immediately and apply energy to something that actually is a threat to safety.  Prioritize!', 'Please don\'t ban these. Banning needs to be only for serious health threats like lead paint toys. Just make them do a better job of included a "do not swallow" label and up the age of play on the products and let consumerism live on.', "We don't need to be a nanny state for toys. Might as well ban forks and electrical outlets. Anyone who cannot properly supervise their kid or keep these magnets put away to prevent them from ingesting them should not be a parent in the first place.", 'The ban on Bucky Balls is ridiculous! Just because ignorant adults lets their kids around small magnetic balls (no pun intended) is their fault, not this companies nor similar companies! I don\'t see why skateboards aren\'t banned (since skateboards have killed and injured more people than Buckyballs) And what about balloons? They KILL more people than you would think, because kids are ignorant (at this age, yes) and it is up to the parents to BE PARENTS AND WATCH THEIR CHILDREN. It is the same with a gun, I wouldn\'t leave a handgun or shotgun lying around my house if I have a child, but these ignorant parents who if can\'t watch their children enough to stop them from swallowing magnets, should not be allowed to be living with their kids since they themselves are a hazard! They have  warning labels for Christ sake!! This would be morally and politically invalid and wrong of you and something tells me that the person who started all of this probably had their child swallow one, ans is all butt hurt and being a major pussy fart on this whole damn country. You seriously have no lives, and if you do this, a lot of people are not going to like you, and if any political figure says anything about shutting you down or firing a bunch of you, or anything in general about you, I will vote for them and inform everyone I know, and tell them to inform everyone they know, so your asses can bake in the heat and the shitstorm you are creating because of some Jimmy two toes dumbfuck that ate a magnet and had to have surgery because he picked up a metal ball and thought, "Hmm, I wonder what this tastes like!!!"  You make me sick, and I formally hope you fucking swallow one of these magnets. Taste the rainbow.', 'Please dont ban the use/sale of simple magnets...this is rediculous', "Magnets are awesome. Don't get rid of my Bucky Balls!", 'Can we ban cars too? They kill hundreds of people because an adult does something stupid while driving. The world would to TOTALLY safe without these and cars!', 'I do not approve of this regulation, in particular the resultant banning of Buckyballs and similar products. There are many products that are more dangerous than small magnets, in particular trampolines, which are marketed directly to children. I believe that warning labels would be a far more appropriate solution to the potential hazards posed by Buckyballs, and ask that you reconsider this regulation.', "An absurd rule, warnings work or they do not, but you can't pick and choose which products you want to decide play by different rules regarding warnings.", 'Its absolutely ridiculous to ban a product that was already clearly labeled to keep away from children. I dont see how banning them is going to stop children from doing stupid things.', 'as a father of a ten year old and a thirteen year boys i know what is to to have to watch what one buys or the surrounding one is in to make sure my kids are safe, when they were younger and more curious they would get into things that they were not supposed to or they would try to get things that fancied them. if a product is to be banned is because it will harm anyone due to mislabeling or wrongful advisement of how it works or what it contains. banning a product because it has caused great misfortune is actually misleading the buyers or users of other products that they will always be safe. banning these magnets does not undo what has been done but creates a continuous false sense we are protected. one must always be vigilant of ones surroundings with our children instead of banning these products you should be giving ways for parents and other adults better ways to be aware of they are doing and following there fears.', 'Please do not prohibit the manufacturing or sale of high-powered magnet sets. It is an unreasonable and overly harsh action to take against what are essentially learning toys. These toys are clearly intended for individuals with enough reason and intelligence to use them properly. This is an unnecessary safety standard.', "Please don't ban spherical magnets. while they may be harmful to those who consume them, that sort of instance occurs extremely rarely. you must have a credit card in order to buy them, which means that every single person who possess such toys is an adult deemed responsible enough to be financially independent. And the ones who gave them away as gifts gave them to children they believed were responsible enough to handle them. since 2009 there have been 22 instances in which people have been hospitalized as a result of consuming spherical magnet toys. Not one of them resulted in a fatality. That is 22 out of the 2.2 million sets that have been sold. Each set contains 216 magnets, meaning there are at least 475.2 million magnets in circulation at this moment. Of those, about 44 have caused any harm at all. Not even a fatality, just harm. (that's another thing, it requires the consumption of at least 2 of them to become harmful, but consuming more than 2 does not significantly increase your chances of harm) the chances of your set killing you is 1/10,822,727, or a 0.000009% chance. let's put that in perspective: 30,196 Americans died in car accidents In 2010. The population of the US in 2010 is 308,745,538.  Meaning approximately 0.009% of the US population died in a car accident. Meaning on average 0.00002% of the US population died in a car accident per day in 2010. meaning that in 2010 the guy who delivers the magnets to your door is about 200 times more likely to die while doing so than you are to ever get injured as a result of your magnets.", 'Buckyballs and other small magnets are both a stress reliever for millions of people and an outlet for expressive and creative ideas. They allow older children to explore the concepts of space and shapes, and help to develop spacial awareness. To ban or outlaw them would be a mistake of epic proportion .', "Don't ban these items. They're cool and fun and keep people interested in science.", 'Please do not ban BuckyBalls, Zen Magnets, Etc.  THey are not nearly as bad as trampolines, pogo sticks, or swimming pools and yet they are still legal!  It is not fair, these toys are science based, and promote curiosity and imagination.', "These magnets are not harmful when used in the proper manner. So the banning of them by the gov't is unneeded. Just regulate the sale of this item to children, and give explicit instructions for parents.", "Bucky Balls, and similar items, don't need to be banned.  If there is ample evidence that they are potentially dangerous, a warning will suffice.  Their benefits outweigh the potential risk.  Please leave well enough alone.", 'Banning of these items is logically unwarranted. Mandatory labeling would and should suffice.', 'A ban on magnet sets is not necessary. The toys are enjoyed by adults as much or more than children, and and are marketed as such. Warning labels or possibly a restriction on sales only to adults would be more than enough. There are far more dangerous items available for children on the market right now.', 'The number of dangerous items that can be easily obtained by a child in a home is numerous.  If we expand that list to include items that are not dangerous by nature, but whose misuse could result in a hazardous situation, the list becomes endless.  To think that we as a nation cannot make our own decisions, but instead must have regulations put in place to protect us is appalling.', 'These magnets are awesome', "Please do not ban magnetic educational toys which are sold only to adults with clear warning labels listing the safety hazards to the user and children. There's products are educational and less dangerous than many other toys targeted to young children (latex balloons) which have virtually no warnings at all. Banning these products sale to adults is an excessively stringent and unfair resolution when compared to the small Risk they propose. More appropriate solitons exist such as packaging them in child proof containers.", 'Kids will always be stupid, let them learn and suffer the consequences.', 'Yes. Buckyball are dangerous if swallowed, and children are definitely more often swallowing things they shouldn\'t more often than adults. This is, i assume, why Buckyballs are packaged with a clear warning indicating that Buckyballs should be kept out of the reach of children. This is a very simple premise. If you do not want children to be eating things they shouldnt, than keep them away from children.   It isn\'t a question of how dangerous these products are, its a question about exposure and poor parenting. "Keep Away From All Children!" the warning reads. Yet there are comments I have read here that show blatant disregard to the warnings.   Obviously, parents and physicians alike would like to see less magnet related injuries, but it is up to these very people to see that young children do not get a hold of these objects.', 'DO NOT BAN these items for the sake of science and education. This document is a obstruction to science and physics. It is an abomination of words. No such laws like these to ban inadamant objects should even be allowed.', "This is ridiculous you will ban these magnets that were not intended for children but YOU WON'T BAN CIGGARETTS!! That is absolutely crazy you guys are blowing this way out of proportion. CIGGARETS KILL THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE A DAY AND THESE MAGNETS HAVE NOT EVEN KILLED ANYONE( not that I know of). I THINK YOU GUYS SHOULD JUST STOP THIS AND BAN CIGARETTS BECAUSE THEY ARE MORE DANGEROUS. THIS IS SUCH A SHAME!!!!", "These are clearly not toys for children. There's absolutely no reason to ban them.   Plenty of other things that aren't toys for children could be harmful if they swallowed them, like paperclips or fishing hooks.", 'The sale of multiple magnet sets results in significant morbidity and even mortality when ingested or aspirated. They should be banned.', 'Kitchens can be dangerous. Chemistry sets can be dangerous. Shop tools can be dangerous. As are electrical outlets. But we balance that danger with supervision, with education, with caution, against the benefits of letting our children (and youths, and adults) learn through them.   The dangers are real. The right course is not to ban such magnet sets without exception, but to educate people as to the dangers such items pose and how to appropriately protect children from such dangers.', 'Banning high powered magnates like these outright is just public safety gone mad.  Due to a vocal minority, and adults not being responsible with their possessions, legitimate consumers of these products will no longer be able to purchase them.  If regulation is required, a ban is not the way.', "These are desk gadgets that come with warnings regarding allowing your child to play with them. The fact of the matter is they're not marketed to nor intended for children. They are meant as stress relievers and such for adults. To legislate and indeed ban them would be irresponsible on the part of the CPSC. It would encourage parents to continue to ignore warnings and intended use of an item at the risk of the children. They are the ones who should be chastised; not observing warnings is akin to their putting the child in harm's way. It is not the manufacturer who is at fault.   These magnets are not inherently dangerous when used as intended. As an individual who sustained permanent ankle damage from a moon bounce, I can attest that there are objects out there which are far more likely to injure an person during normal use.   If you intended to pursue legislating objects which can be dangerous to a child when swallowed, I would suggest contacting the US Mint and requesting that all coins be increased in size until they are no longer a threat. Pennies minted after 1982 should be addressed in particular given that zinc toxicosis can lead to vomiting and bleeding ulcers. Watch batteries are also of concern. They can become lodged in the intestine and burn a hole within a few hours.  If you are bound and determined to impose some sort of new regulation, I would not be opposed to larger warning labels and requiring proof of age prior to purchase. I also would not have an issue with having the purchasers sign a statement in which they express understanding the risks involved with using the magnets in ways which are not intended and that they will endeavor to be responsible with their purchase.", "Outright banning a magnet, just because of it's dangerous nature if ingested, is downright ludicrous.  If Bucky Balls and Zen Magnets are banned, why stop there?  Why not ban CFL bulbs?  They contain mercury and would definitely kill anyone if ingested.  What about alcohol and tobacco?  They're INTENDED to be ingested and will kill you with sufficient quantity.  Perhaps jacks should be banned as well, as those pointy parts would surely do some damage if some kid ate them, and they're bite sized!  Moth balls, and lead ball bearings as well.  And I haven't even gotten to the plethora of personal care products such as various makeups, nail products, hair dyes, etc that are outright toxic to anyone, children or not.   My point is that Bucky Balls and Zen Magnets should clearly be labelled as dangerous if ingested, but to ban them outright only serves to discourage an interest in magnetism, and to discredit the United States Government in the eyes of anyone with the most basic knowledge of science.", "As a parent of a three year old and a consumer of products, I feel that this attack is completely uncalled for. If I want to purchase an adult product that happens to be magnets, I have a right to do so. If my child gets hurt because I am careless that's my fault. My house has six steps on the staircase leading from the main level to the bedroom level. If my child falls down the steps and gets hurt, should I sue the person that built the house? NO. The government does not need to babysit my child. That's my job. Do not let government take away my rights as a responsible adult because of those that are irresponsible parents. Thank you.", 'These pose no risk to adults, and they are not designed for small children who will put them in their mouths.   Please re-think the need for this regulation, which will effectively shut down a successful business.', "I am a purchaser of magnet spheres called zen magnets. I use them to relax and build my focusing abilities because of my motor tics brought on from anxiety. If I lose the right to use this, it may set off my symptoms. I do not think I should lose my right to purchase these because some other people cannot read labels and aren't educated.", 'NOOOO!!!!!! These magnets are not only extremely fun to play with but amazing educational tools in shaping models and obviously with that many small magnets you can do some amazing magnetic physics experiments. These are great educational tools and the best thing to do would be to make sure that people that buy them are 18.', 'This is a silly regulation that serves no good purpose.', '"Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don\'t ban them! And as Zen Magnets pointed out in a statement, "...there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them. That is a good thing." ~ Brent Rose via Gizmodo  I have to agree.', 'I am writing in opposition of the prohibition of magnetic toys as described in "Safety Standard for Magnet Sets."    I am a PhD candidate at the University of California at Berkeley in the physics department.  I believe these magnetic sets can be incredibly valuable for educational science outreach programs to teach magnetism, atomic binding, crystal structure, phase transformations, as well as many other fundamental concepts.  BuckyBalls, specifically, are well suited for this due to their small size and high field strength.   Magnets of inferior strength are not sufficient and larger magnets would be impractical to build large structures.  It is unfortunate that there have been 22 incidents with these magnetic sets since 2009, but I believe this is a small number in comparison with the number of injuries among 0-14 year olds in 1994 alone from glass (9,000) and knives (250).  I think we are better off as a country with these products, than without them, due to the educational benefit to adults and teenagers (under supervision).  I have no financial interest any magnetic set company.', 'Please do not ban magnet sets.  Playing with magnet sets spurs creativity and imagination.  Most household items will cause harm if misused.  They are labeled accordingly.  Do so with magnet sets as well.   Thank you.', 'Banning these toys makes no sense. Parents should be more responsible. Go ban cigarettes.', "There is no reason to ban these magnets. If any problems are caused by them, it was the user's fault, and not the magnets. Lets keep them available for the people that are mature enough to use them.", "Banning these fascinating objects would be stupid and wrong. I know that many other people have made much more scientific arguments or those based in law. As a general consumer and thinking adult, I simply wanted to give you my opinion. Just please don't be stupid.", "you want to ban bucky balls? People need to be accountable for their own idiocy, it isn't your place to coddle morons.", 'I strongly believe that magnetic spheres pose no more of a threat to children than many other toys on the market.  Legos are one prime example of another dangerous object marketed as a toy.  We generally deal with these sorts of things by labeling them clearly as not for children under the appropriate age.  Why should that method not be applied here as well?', "We appreciate your safety concerns about magnets  However, they're clearly labeled for safety with warnings and this is a personal right issue.  Just for some people's ignorance in following labels, the rest of the population is denied access to their use.     We believe these magnets should still be allowed to be sold, as there are plenty of dangerous things on the market.  It is up to the consumer to use discretion", "I own multiple sets of 'Bucky Balls', and have small children. From experience, education in the form of better packaging, customer disclosures, waivers, etc. are more effective than banning completely, which could impact jobs, and deprive of the fun and imagination expanding uses of magnets.   Thanks for your time", 'do NOT ban our freedoms, even in small steps', "The magnet sets I am familiar with (Buckyballs) are clearly marked with their hazards and are in no way marketed toward children. As an adult, I'm flummoxed why your judgement is better than mine when it comes to the toys I can play with. As an adult, I can control access to any potentially-dangerous items that my children may have access to. It's called PARENTING & it's what we responsible adults do.  Please allow adults to exercise their own judgement on what they bring into their home. What's next - steak knives?", 'Against regulation. Except labeling for adult use and/or supervision.  Parents are liable in most of the cases described. Why not focus the attention and resources on the irresponsibility of the adults who provide these products to children. Common sense dictates you do not give ball bearings (whether magnetized or not) to a child.   Regulating the product as described will diminish the very properties that make it successful and it might as well be banned outright to prevent people from wasting their money on an inferior product.   An overseas market, where there is no regulation, will certainly become a means to an end.', 'Why ban Bucky Balls? It is not their fault for children misusing them. There are many more dangerous things out there than magnets. Just as Bucky Balls say, trampolines are much worse, and marketed towards children! At least Bucky Balls are somewhat educational.', "I am against a ban on magnetic balls.  While I do believe there needs to be regulation to protect consumers from dangerous products.  The intent cannot be to eliminate danger, for surely this is impossible as we are neither omnipotent nor omniscient.  More importantly, regulation should be careful when trying to protect consumers from themselves.  At some point the consumer must be responsible for protecting himself.  Magnetic balls are not inherently dangerous.  They do not explode.  They have not sharp edges.  They are non-toxic by touch or inhalation.  The danger in question here comes only from ingesting the balls.  One might wonder why rocks would not fit the same category.  People must be trusted to not eat rocks, or if they do, suffer the consequences.  People should be free to do that if they choose and be responsible for what happens as a result.  Similarly, people must be trusted to not eat magnetic balls.  Furthermore, the report indicates 1,700 cases in 2001.  The US has a population of 311 million.  The prevalence of this risk is 0.0005%.  Surely the are innumerably more important risks on which to focus.  I hope you're not thinking of removing stairs from households (which account for 1,300 deaths per year).  Surely a warning label would suffice to protect consumers.  I do believe the government has already worked with the producers to develop one that is being used already.", 'To whom it may concern,  Please do not let this ban on the magnets go through.   If you look around a house, almost anything can be potentially dangerous to a young child.  While extra warning labels of the dangers presented by kids swallowing magnets would be acceptable, banning them outright is a heavy handed draconian way of dealing with the situation.  I\'m not sure who reads this, and chances are it\'ll just be another tally in a pile of "against", but I hope the law makers use better common sense than just banning an item that hold so much benefit to children in learning about science.   Thank you.', 'As a pediatric gastroenterologist I have been involved with many cases of magnet ingestion.  I have personally seen 2 perforations from them in children and numerous other cases where I have had to remove them with an endoscope.  These magnets are very powerful and extremely dangerous.  Most families are unaware of the danger and do not seek help until too late.  There is no need for these magnets to be on the market as toys.  Due to there inherent risk they should be taken off the market.', "Please stop wasting my money going after bucky balls.  This is a bad use of my federal income taxes, which total over $20,000 each year.  Why don't you guys maybe regulate the creation of currency instead?  Just a thought.", 'A ban on magnets is ridiculous!', "Using parental inability to watch their own children and regulate their behavior as a reason to discontinue or ban a product is wrong.  Should we ban everything that kids get into when our back is turned that hurts them, like alcohol and cigarettes?  How about anything that starts a fire, like matches or lighters?  Don't get so choosey....", "DO NOT ban bucky balls science is important don't you get that????", "YOU CAN'T REMOVE MY FREEDOMS! ...but seriously, just label the item and make people sign a waiver to buy these magnetic balls.", 'I am disappointed that this is what the CPSC is choosing to spend its funding on.  I have written this post a couple of times since I have strong feelings about this - I love the magnet sets under discussion.  They are a great toy and while the proposal mentions that there are products available that provide a "safer" substitute, I do not believe that is the case.  Certainly the products would not have taken off the way they have if that was the case.  As I see it, the question of whether or not to regulate this product boils down to a question of whether or not it is appropriate to ban a product because of safety concerns related to children using it inappropriately.  You cannot blame the manufacturers for this, they have placed several warnings in the sets that warn parents in particular that these toys are not suitable for children who continue to eat things.  I fail to find the argument that we shouldn\'t sell anything that poses a risk to children very compelling - as the same logic being applied to many, many other products would lead to their being banned as well (private swimming pools, for example).  I sympathize with the parents and pediatricians that have weighed in on the other side, but I would respectfully like to point out that keeping these in the home or not is a personal choice - removing these from your home or beginning an educational campaign about the potential dangers of high powered magnetic toys does not have to involve coercion.', 'I do not support any ban on these magnetic items.  Adults need to properly supervise children in their care.  I am careful to not allow stuff like this in my house near my children.  I do not believe these businesses should be unfairly impacted by your proposed ban.', 'I have owned a set of magnets of the type that would be banned by this rule, and have never even come close to swallowing them.  This rule is silly.  If I had my way, there would be no silly rules.', "Please keep these available.  Knives have sharp edges, 9-volt batteries are capable of shocking you, and yet we manage to use these just fine.  The government stepping in to ban magnets because of improper supervision is a helicoptor-parent waste of time and effort... please let us regulate ourselves, our toys and hobbies before we're reduced to a single ball that we have to share and can't throw hard because it might hurt someone.", 'DO NOT BAN BUCKYBALLS FOR THE STUPIDITY OF A CERTAIN FEW.', 'As a pediatric gastroenterologist, I have seen firsthand the dangers of magnet ingestions. There is damage to the GI tract lining within HOURS of ingestion. We also have had several cases of intestinal perforation when magnet ingestions went unrecognized.   There has been a definite increase in the number of these ingestions since manufacturers have popularized these magnet sets.', "To whom it may concern,  CPSC's logic for banning magnetic spheres is unsound. They (you) need to assess the reasons why this is necessary, and the benefits that such a ban would bring thereafter. I consider magnetic spheres to be an artistic medium, and would be devastated by the approval of such legislation. These are not dangerous. The only danger is you. So, please, I beg you, don't ban them.", "This magnets can kill or maim unsuspecting children. Ideally, they would be banned for public consumption. Even if classified as 'adult toys' or 'desktop distractions', they should be more tightly regulated.", 'I am an adult user of rare earth magnet spheres, both recreationally as a construction toy and professionally for making mechanical sculptures. I am appalled that they are under consideration to be banned when far more dangerous things like trampolines and skateboards are perfectly acceptable.', "I oppose this vehemently.  Rules like this further infantalize us as a society.  Consumers have some responsibility to use the products they buy safely.  Harassing a company endlessly is detrimental to our economy, and certainly doesn't help improve safety.  Sets such as Bucky Balls are marketed towards adults.  Each box has FIVE warnings that they are not intended for children.  At some point, we have to be responsible for our own behavior.", 'I can\'t believe that there is a proposal to regulate/eliminate the sale of "high-powered" magnets!  As a luthier, instrument repairman, & woodworker, these are indispensable tools!    High powered magnets are in wide use in a variety of applications, and their elimination will create a substantial hardship for many business in this country.  Parents need to learn to teach their children, and not rely on the government to "outlaw" items that could be dangerous.  To a child with no knowledge, ALL items are to be explored.  You going to outlaw knives next?  Perhaps fire?  Really!!', "No! A child can ingest a very large number of products, none of which have had to deal with such nonsense. Pin, paper clip, thumb tack, razor blade, anything from a sewing kit.   This is wrong.  If this passes, it will be a clear message to the universe that we are afraid. Afraid of our own shadows.   We must take a look at out past, and all the thing we have been involved in and endured. Not only are we still here, but we grew and learned from our experiences.  Evolution. Let us not try to stop the only filter we have left.  I want any person on the panel for deciding, to think back. Back to your child hood. Think of all the things that could and did go wrong. Most of us made it. Several hundred million in fact. Guess what. We are now running the world.  A few things like magnets isn't going to stop us. So lets stop pretending they might a
column8: 14, -- While stringent procedures can theoretically avoid a foot and mouth outbreak in the United States, human error still exists.1, -- Brazil is a country known to suffer from Foot and Mouth disease which would put all American cattle producers at risk.106, -- These things would ultimately cause an increase of production costs due to an increase in necessary veterinary and nutrition expenses.86, -- I hope the government can make sense of the issue and open their eyes to the importance of local, safe, quality food.25, -- I ask that you take the only action open to protect American consumers of beef, and producers, and reject this rule as irresponsible.61, -- I would ask you to forget this plan, this country still has outbrakes of E-coli using american beef.31, -- ALLOWING ANOTHER COUNTRY TO ENTER THE MARKET PRODUCING A PRODUCT THAT HAS FAR LESS MONEY INVESTED COULD HURT SMALL PRODUCERS LIKE MYSELF.23, -- Introducing foodstuff that could harm the consumers trust in our American product would hurt the American's rancher and farmer ability to market their product.58, -- Everything takes it's course, grain prices go up then come down, cattle prices go up then come down.30, -- We have to start looking at what we as a country can do to improve our economy!!13, -- The irresponsible, careless and dangerous proposed rule will put the cattle producer, their livelihood and the well-being of farm/ranch families in peril.58, -- US cattle producers are the worlds best and safest producers anywhere on earth.116, -- Don't forget the domino affect , start with the cow/ calf producer  and go on too the hardware owner, plumber, etc,etc.23, -- We want to produce healthy high quality food for American consumers help us to do so without imported threats of disease.73, -- I pray others will let there voices be heard and the government will ban this proposal.46, -- In my research, none of these countries import beef from Brazil (Economic Research Service, 2012).58, -- Think American USDA,  we are the best and safest.37, -- Meaning that the risk of both market impacts and disease outbreak do not carry any benefit for U.S. producers.148, -- Our cost of production can only be the same if we assume the same standard of living as our competitors.82, -- The economic effects of an outbreak will far outweigh any economic benefits real or perceived.79, -- Brazil has a control program for FMD since the 60s, exporting to the European Union and other markets.82, -- This is an unnecessary risk and should not be taken.40, -- We have the resources; lets use them before we start importing more food.148, -- Do you have the ability to handle the disease in the US?46, -- I find it ironic with this much information that should raise concern about this issue is from the very agency considering importing from Brazil.40, -- I do not want my children to be dependent on foreign source for food!148, -- We all agreed that the best prevention was stopping the disease before US soil.40, -- Invest in the next generation of agricultural producers, not foreign producers.40, -- Food production has to increase to feed 9 billion people by 2050.40, -- Lets get to work and be competitive and not apathetic!40, -- If this proposal is passed, someone in the federal government should be charged with crimes against its people and prosecuted to the fullest.148, -- Just because a plan works on paper does not mean that failures can not occur.
column9: 147, -- Sirs, As an accredited DVM I oppose the importation of products from Brazil from any species susceptible to FMD.23, -- Everyday the ranchers and farmers battle to put  high quality food on the consumers table.151, -- Even to think that it could be an option to import disease animals into our country.138, -- The introduction of FMD will shut down all industry functions because of  travel restrictions to stop the spread.46, -- The country of Brazil is mixed states of FMD free with vaccination and non FMD free zones  (Merlo, 2014).79, -- To be included in the list of country free from FMD with vaccination the member country shall: 1.100, -- Russia has decided not to allow Brazil to import into Russia.33, -- FMD is a disease that is highly contagious and very difficult to contain.89, --      Uruguay: On December 13, 2000, USDA/APHIS regionalized Uruguays department of Artigas, due to a FMD outbreak.79, -- The circulation of FMD virus has not been detected in the last 12 months;  3.110, -- The United States has not experienced an outbreak of FMD since 1929.14, -- We need food raised in the United States to have our own food security.148, -- It is becoming my opinion over time that the US does not want strong domestic agriculture in our country.14, -- Don't allow importation of Fresh Meat from Countries with Foot and Mouth.14, -- Even if the county has so called 'regions free of foot and mouth'.89, -- Nine years after Japans FMD status was okayed by USDA/APHIS, USDA terminated that status due an outbreak of FMD.40, -- Each person in the US is backing about $600,000 for the US; that is every man, woman and child.37, -- We intend to submit more thorough comments regarding the impact of this proposed rule if we are allowed more time for consideration and explanation.89, -- Such a proposal merely repeats a practice that effectively failed in the five, above-cited examples.37, -- Respectfully Submitted,  Silvia Christen, Executive Director South Dakota Stockgrowers Association46, -- Thank you for your time,  Glenda Burgess  Bibliography       Economic Research Service.148, -- Our local emergency management animal committee for Deaf Smith County met and we absolutely think it is a big problem.79, -- A risk analysis concluded that the fresh meat from Brazil (chilled and frozen) can be imported safely fulfilling the recommended conditions.79, -- Conclusion The U.S. Department of Agriculture has done an excellent job of risk analysis based on scientific knowledge.148, -- Previous generations of Americans eradicated FMD, now we are actually considering measures that could allow it back into our country.79, -- Currently, the scientific knowledge demonstrates that the meat from Brazil do not pose risk of transmission of FMD.79, -- Its sanitary program complies with rules of international reference.148, -- Free trade has a place but is never really free.
column10: 128, -- I am a 4th generation rancher from S. D.we raise cattle and sheep and we do it for a living.81, -- The report acknowledges that Brazil is known to have an outbreak of foot and mouth disease.123, -- it would spread across this country like Pved has spread through the hog industry-unstoppable.12, -- I say "generations" because we have three generations currently on our family ranch and we are not unique to the industry.37, -- FMD is the most contagious disease known to animals like cattle, sheep, hogs and deer.23, -- The livestock industry would be devastated by this disease.73, -- We are a small operation of 200 cattle and would be devastated at the loss of our income which supports 2 families.112, -- A 1924 outbreak required the slaughter and disposal of 109,000 farm animals and an estimated 22,000 deer.11, -- I want to be assured Brazilian cattle are slaughtered with the same care and oversights that are required in the United States.49, -- It would be unimaginable how terrible the effect could be to this countries livestock industry, and wildlife industry for that matter.110, -- Cattle, sheep, goats, deer, buffalo, and swine are all adversely affected by FMD, but the effects on cattle herds tend to be particularly devastating.79, -- c. There are official regulations for the early detection, prevention and control of FMD.58, -- We do not  want Brazil's diseases in our cow herds.40, -- We have stolen $5 trillion from 13 US Trust Funds and the balance of $27.3 trillion in on the backs of future generations.79, -- Currently, 89% of the herds of cattle and buffaloes, or 185 million head, are in FMD-free zone, which represents 60% of the national territory.46, -- Retrieved January 30, 2014, from United States Department of Agriculture: http://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/animal-products/cattle-beef/trade.aspx#.Uun0tIZK_mg      Mahy, B. W. (2012, March).46, -- Retrieved January 30, 2014, from Merck Veterinary Manual: http://www.merckmanuals.com/vet/generalized_conditions/foot-and-mouth_disease/overview_of_foot-and-mouth_disease.html      McGinnis, L. (2009, April).
column11: 77, -- Greetings,  The one word written twice in the above summary that is bothersome is "certain".111, -- These countries do not have to abide by the same regulations as the USA on pesticides and disease control.4, -- I have yet to see a steakhouse in my home town on any given night, that is not at capacity with patrons.28, -- It is imperative that this rule be vacated and the US be protected!48, -- There is always a way, standards are always manipulated, and penalties, are rarely enforced.139, -- Too few citizens and politicians would comprehend the gravity of the situation and the severe steps needed to implement a control / eradication program.77, -- Then there needs to be oversight by a third party (with consequences) for none compliance.82, -- The U.S. cannot constantly monitor the borders to be sure that no animal crosses the border that can carry the disease.
column12: 77, -- All products that enter the USA should be labeled the origin country.40, -- EGT is an Asian company and they have built 3 large grain elevators within 100 miles of my house in North Central Montana.33, -- The disease can be carried on the wind on a humid day up to sixty miles.33, -- The incubation period for the FMD is 14 days with 3 days to confirm meanwhile the disease is spreading.64, -- The best way of controlling any disease is by prevention.89, -- NINE DAYS LATER, additional FMD infections were discovered in South Korea and the proposal to regionalize that country was canceled.89, --  Japan: Perhaps congratulations should be in order here.
