column2:
['Please, I implore you to help stop the cruel and inhumane treatment of the beautiful and intelligent animals once and for all.', 'While I have no no degree in zoology or any claim to expertise, I have, however, read a good deal of literature about the way that elephants live in the wild. Zoos cannot begin to reproduce what these animals need to maintain physical and mental health. It\'s a travesty that with the knowledge that we now have about how these magnificent creatures are meant to live, that we continue to deny them humane treatment.

For their health and well-being, elephants need to walk, roam, and graze. They also need to live in social groups -- not isolated and deprived of the society of other elephants.

Please review the quotes from elephant experts below:

"[Even under the best of conditions], elephants are actually very poor candidates for life in captivity. . . . [I doubt] if a dozen elephants worldwide are in truly good psychological, behavioral, and social conditions. Their requirements are so substantial-it is probably beyond the capabilities of most zoos to even begin to resolve them." - David Hancocks, former director of the Woodland Park Zoo in Seattle, WA

"No captive situation, however attractive it may appear to a human, can possibly be adequate for the needs of an elephant in terms of space. An example is our 10 year old bull, Imenti, who walked 84 miles in 14 hours, turned round and walked back 100 miles in search of a friend. Even Tsavo, which is 8,000 square miles in extent, can be traversed by elephants in a matter of days - and is" - Dr. Daphne Sheldrick D.V.M., M.B.E., M.B.S., 1992 UNEP Global 500 Laureate, has worked with elephants for 50 years, both in a wild and captive situations, and is considered one of the leading authorities on the African elephant

"There are no substitutes for walking in a restricted environment, no enrichment strategies that motivate a captive elephant sufficiently, no boomer balls or tires that replace walking and no food dispensers that will create activity patterns in elephants that even come close to being beneficial to the long-term management of captive elephants. The absence of walking from an elephant program, considering the elephant is genetically programmed to move, must have dramatic long-term effect on the elephant\'s physical and mental stability and must ultimately affect it\'s longevity and propagation." - Walking, Outline of U.S.D.A. Elephant Course, Seattle, August 3, 1998

"Long periods of inactivity can and will be detrimental to the health and longevity of an elephant. To an animal that is programmed to move eighteen out of twenty-four hours, inactivity has a high price. Normally, the nail and foot tissue of an elephant is worn down during the long hours of walking over different substrates. Flexibility to wrist, knees and their joints is increased and maintained by the continuous movement of their daily activities. Foot problems, if not caused by injury, trauma or arthritic conditions of joints, are the end product of inadequate movement and activity. An elephant\'s foot will regenerate normally without elaborate pedicures, providing an exercise regime of mass movement and daily walks is sustained throughout the elephant\'s life. If an abscess develops and the elephant is maintained in an inadequate care system, re- infection will occur until the infection has reached the toe digits and surgery is need. Very few of these cases survive." - Alan Roocroft, consultant who has worked with captive elephants for over 30 years

When I began my zoo career 35 years ago, much less was known about elephants than is known today. We now understand that keeping elephants in tiny enclosures with unnatural surfaces destroys their legs and feet. We have learned that to breed naturally and rear their young, elephants must live in herds that meet their social requirements. And we have come to realize that controlling elephants through domination and the use of ankuses (sharply pointed devices used to inflict pain) can no longer be justified. - Les Schobert has been a curator at major zoos, including in Los Angeles and North Carolina.

', "Elephant deaths are a matter of physics Chicago Sun Times Letter to Editor by Les Golden The death of two elephants at the Lincoln Park Zoo should come as no surprise. While it is obvious that cold weather is bad for species that have evolved in tropical climates, understanding the death-inducing effect of confinement to concrete cells requires a rudimentary knowledge of physics (I have taught astronomy at the University of Illinois at Chicago). When animals take a step in their natural, sod environment, the concussion felt when the foot lands is muffled. When walking on concrete or pavement, no such effect occurs. This is why shoes are cushioned, and special running shoes are manufactured for those foolhardy enough to run on streets. The damaging effects exceed the obvious orthopedic ones. The concussive effect is proportional to the weight of the body. For massive animals such as the elephant, the effect is horrendous and is easily calculated. It can amount to three times the weight of the body. For a 5-ton elephant, that is a force of 15 tons -- as if the weight of seven automobiles is slammed into the body. Mammal bodies are composed largely of water, an incompressible fluid. When that force hits the elephant's body, the concussion is transmitted through the legs, and upward through all the organs of the body. The cells of those organs are ruptured. This occurs notably among the delicate cells of the alveoli of the lungs. That is the source of the well-documented prevalence of deaths due to tuberculosis, a disease of the lungs, among captive elephants and other large mammals. As the many organs in the body necessary for digestion are also damaged, emaciation is also a common occurrence. Damage to brain tissues results in dementia. Ruptured capillaries results in internal bleeding and anemia. All result from the continual concussive effects of 3G (three times the force of gravity) deceleration. It is as if the elephant experiences hundreds of minor automobile accidents each day. Confinement of large mammals such as the rhinoceros, elephant, giraffe and buffalo to concrete cells is a death sentence. After the first elephant death, the Chicago City Council ignored the plea of actress Gillian Anderson to pass a resolution asking for the return of the two surviving elephants to more suitable locations. As for the administrators of Lincoln Park Zoo, they may not have understood the physics, but after the death of one elephant, they should have put ticket sales behind animal welfare in their priorities. Sadly for the elephants, they chose not to. Leslie M. Golden, Oak Park http://www.suntimes.com/output/letters/cst-edt-vox28a.html He further writes: Here's the physics. The formula for acceleration is (v - w) / T, where w is the initial velocity, v is the final velocity, and T is the time interval for the change. It is reasonable to assume the velocity of an elephant's foot as it steps to be about 2 feet/second. When cushioned by sod, it takes about 1 second for the foot to come to rest, that is, for a zero velocity to be attained. That leads to an acceleration of (0 - 2)/1 = -2 feet/second-second. This compares to 32.2 feet/second-second acceleration of gravity. This is a mild deceleration, easily tolerated by the body, which has evolved over millions of years under that moderate stress level. If that elephant step, however, is onto concrete, the time interval for the change of velocity is only the fraction of a second needed for the elephant's foot pads to be compressed. This is between 0.1 and 0.05 seconds. The deceleration is then (0 - 2)/0.1 to (0 - 2)/0.05 or 20 feet/second-second to 40 feet/second-second. After years of confinement, the pads lose their resiliency, so that the time interval is reduced to 0.02 second. That yields a deceleration of 100 feet/second-second. That is three times the acceleration of gravity, and the well-known correspondence of w = m g yields a force equal to three times the weight of the elephant quoted above.", "I am writing to express my support of dramatic improvements in enforcement and the standards for captive elephants. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their good health and well-being. Anyone with an iota of common sense knows that elephants are large animals that require a lot of space. Too many zoos provide a severe lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually causes a range of preventable problems, from arthritis and foot disease to neurotic behavior such as swaying and head bobbing. In captivity, elephants rarely reach their anticipated life span of 70 years in the wild. From 2000 to the present, 47 elephants perished inside facilities accredited by the American Zoo and Aquarium Association (AZA) ? including Lincoln Park, Birmingham, Gladys Porter, San Francisco, Disney's Animal Kingdom, Columbus, Hogle, San Antonio, Houston, Los Angeles, Busch Gardens, Oregon, Rosamond Gifford Brookfield, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Jackson, Six Flags Marine World, Dickerson Park, Bronx, Have Trunk Will Travel, North Carolina, Point Defiance, River Banks, El Paso, Milwaukee, Denver, Omaha's Henry Doorly, St. Louis, and National Zoos. At least half died before the age of 40. Some facilities lost a number of elephants in recent years. Zoos, circuses, and other commercial venues are plainly unequipped to meet the complex physical/psychological needs of elephants. A simulated environment cannot replicate the wild where African elephants span a 120-square mile home range and walk at least 5.5 miles daily. Asian elephants cover up to 200 square miles and roam 5-14 miles everyday. Conversely, the AZA requires 1800 square feet per elephant. That's just .04 acres (compared to 640 acres in a single square mile) and roughly the dimension of six parking spaces. I fully support the citizen's petition from In Defense of Animals (IDA) that calls for enforcement of the federal Animal Welfare Act (AWA) at zoos and circuses. In fact, an ongoing lack of space, exercise, and social enrichment demonstrates the USDA's failure to uphold an AWA provision requiring zoos and circuses to maintain settings consistent with the welfare of elephants. IDA's petition also rightfully asks the USDA to seize elephants suffering from captivity-provoked infirmities. An estimated 50% endure chronic arthritis and foot abscesses from insufficient exercise and endless hours upon hardened surfaces. Some elephants succumb to zoochosis, a type of psychological distress, and tuberculosis also spreads among elephants in captivity. I strongly urge the USDA to demand compliance with the AWA, either through expanding environments to encompass hundreds of acres or by relocating elephants to free-range sanctuaries where they can move in groups, swim in watering holes, and indulge in dust baths. No manufactured exhibit, even those considered innovative or optimally maintained, can emulate the natural world. Thank you,", "The general living conditions for elephants held captive in North America zoos can be described as dismal at best. Current USDA rules and regulations leave major components of space and housing requirements open to the interpretation of zoo administrators. The USDA should REQUIRE at least two acres per animal, that the animal live in a climate as close to possible as it's natural habitat (i.e. why does Tiger Haven, a USDA licensed facility, in Jacksonville, Florida have 2 ARTIC foxes living outdoors?), and extensive enrichment opportunities. Zoos should be REQUIRED, not recommended, to have at least three elephants if they have any at all.", 'When an animal cannot be kept healthy or sane, then that animal must be removed from its situation. If that disturbs a business or a livelihood, it is justified. When elephants are kept in captivity, they, like all living beings, have specific needs. If they are not given access to ample living space, proper climate, food, water and natural ground, they are going to suffer hardship. Keeping elephants in miserly conditions does nothing to improve their condition in the wild, zoo propaganda to the contrary. I am in favor of any ENFORCED rulings that would improve life for captive elephants. Minimum acreage per animal, more interaction with their own kind, natural footing, banning any implement for training that causes pain to the elephant.', 'Elephants have been unethically held captive for years -- it is time for a major change.', 'These circuses are not only torturing elephants they put the public at risk for tuberculosis: August 30, 2001 According to an article on Salon.com titled, ?The Greatest Vendetta on Earth,? a 163-page deposition given by Joel Kaplan, a private eye who had handled security for the Felds for 20 years, stated, ?[Ringling] had some real problems with the elephants. ? I was told [by the circus veterinarian] ... that about half of the elephants in each of the shows had tuberculosis and that the tuberculosis was an easily transmitted disease to individuals, to human beings. ? I was asked by Chuck [Smith], through Kenneth [Feld], to find a physician who would test the people [in] the circus to see if they had tuberculosis but who would destroy the records and not turn them [in to] the Centers for Disease Control." It\'s plain that these circus people only care about making a profit, so much so, that they are willing to break laws and put the public at risk. Isn\'t it about time to end this madness? The USDA is supposed to protect the public, especially the innocent little children who go to the circus! The elephants and the public certainly need protection from these circus criminals.', "Zoos and circuses cannot give elephants the environment they need for a healthy, well-balanced life. Please consider requiring these places to give their elephants to the two elephant sanctuaries that exist in the U.S. The elephants have suffered terribly over the many years of captivity in zoos and circuses. They are treated badly and forcefully with bull hook and are sometimes kept chained up. They become crippled and eventually have to be put down when only living half their usual lifespan. I believe that the elephants' welfare should definitely take preference over the greed for money. Some zoos have been reponsible enough as to shut down their elephant exhibits. Thank you for listening.", 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act and creating tough new standards that: - Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS Sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. - Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants. These changes needs to be made. Zoos and circuses are NOT giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well being. My family has refused to see circuses or visit zoos that have elephants. The conditions are these facilities are inhumane and go against everything that an elephant is about. Elephants deserve much better. Thank you. Terace Lasal', 'I WRITE TO YOU IN SUPPORT OF IN DEFENSE OF ANIMALS ELEPHANT PETITION PLEASE PAVE THE WAY FOR THESE MAJESTIC AND INTELLIGENT ANIMALS TO LIVE IN GREATER COMFORT AND DIGNITY THAN CURRENTLY REQUIRED UNDER LAW AS GHANDI SO ELOQUENTLY STATED: "THE GREATNESS OF A NATION (AND CERTAINLY AN AGENCY) CAN BE JUDGED BY THE WAY ITS ANIMALS ARE TREATED"', "Elephants were not meant to be cooped up and used as performers. I haven't gone to the circus in 25 years and refuse to attend any with animals. It's obviously cruel, physically AND mentally. We are not a third world country. I can't believe that we permit this kind of cruelty.", 'My friend and pet care business owner, Maria Zoltek, educated me about elephants and the issues concerning captivity. She shared with me various websites including www.circuses.com and www.elephants.com and I became convinced that elephants do not belong in captivity (zoos and circuses). Change is definitely needed. Please improve conditions for captive elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new standards that: ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. The small spaces in zoos can cause arthritis due to lameness and insufficient mobility. ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants. Such highly social, complex and intelligent animals suffer pain and suffering under such cruel treatment. With today\'s technology (large screen TVs, videos, "ele\'\'cams, etc.), elephants can be filmed in their natural behavior in naturalistic environments. Watching elephants in a natural habitat where space allows them to behave naturally, would educate the public a great deal more than by watching elephants standing and acting unnaturally - swaying, bobbing, etc. -- in a zoo or circus environment. Thank you for accepting our petitions.', "Please support all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country. Create tough new standards, including the following: ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health", 'Thank you for the opportunity to give comment on the treatment of Elephants. These beautiful, intelligent and loving animals deserve so much better than confinment, abuse and exploitation. There was a recent article published on how elephants are beginning to relate to human beings as dangerous and hostile enemies. The article suggests that these animals are beginning to "fight back" from being killed by poachers, abused and exploited by heartless humans. Elephants have a highly socialized and altruistic community structure which requires space and opportunity to live in their natural environment. One of the key elements in an altruistic social structure is the ability to remember who is generous and helpful within the group and who is not. It makes sense that elephants would begin to remember who in the larger community behaves that way too. While they are adaptable, these confined conditions are not optimal for their needs and can sometimes lead to much suffering. As so many animals are becoming extinct everyday, I think it is worth taking a look at how we treat the most useful and friendly species on earth. We are already pushing so many animals off the land, we should make room for the elephants and treat them with the dignity and respect they deserve.', 'The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'On August 28, 2006, I visited the Carson and Barnes Circus in my hometown of Watertown, NY. I was motivated to visit the circus, before and during the show, and to bring my digital camera, because I had learned that the circus uses means of animal cruelty, especially regarding the elephants, so that the animals will perform tricks. I find this type of behaviour utterly appalling and believe that it must come to a complete stop. Around 11 o\'clock am, I drove by the circus. Four elephants were out in an unshaded yard. I returned at 1:30 pm and walked around the grounds, paying particularly close attention to the elephants. The elephants suprisingly stayed within a small patch of the yard, and were surrounded by metal poles connected by wire. It is only my educated hypothesis that these wires were electric; there would be no other way to keep four elephants within that small radius. In the elephant yard was a man reading a book. As I watched two of the elephants touch and hold each other\'s trunks, the man looked up and yelled at the elephants, discouraging any type of social interaction between the animals. I observed the elephants at the closest distance I felt was possible, and found that there were dark marks on one of the elephant\'s sides (to which the man later referred to as "shit stains"), and what seems to be some sort of indent on another elephant\'s upper front left shoulder. As I am no expert on elephants or animal health, it is unclear to me whether or not these are scars from electric rods or hooks, but I felt it was necessary to photograph anything I felt was unusual. I do know however, that, according to United States law, all circus animals must be provided with shade. When I questioned the man about the fact that, 2 1/2 hours later, the elephants still did not have any shade, he responded that whatever type of shade the elephants are usually provided with was broken, and was being fixed. The high temperature for the day in Watertown was 79 degrees Fahrenheit. If the elephants could not have had their shade fixed in 2 1/2 hours, an arrangement for makeshift shade should have been taken care of. There was also no water for the elephants. The man said they had been recently watered, but I have read on websites concerning elephants in circuses (particularly Carson and Barnes) that said that the elephants are not given water a few days before a performance so that they will not urinate during tricks. I also photographed the outside and inside of the elephant trailers, which the man had said holds two elephants. I found the length and width of the trailers to be shockingly small, with barely enough room for the elephants to lay down or turn around. The trailers that were provided for the human actors were much larger than those provided for the animals. Because I was scheduled to work, I was not able to return to the circus until 8 o\'clock pm. There was still no shade provided for the elephants. While the temperature was cooler at this time, the other animals in the circus continued to have shade. I cannot see any reason for the circus to assemble the shade for the elephants and then take the time remove it when the air becomes cool. I observed the elephants again, and this time saw red bands around their legs. I assume this was part of their costumes. I feel guilty for having paid for a ticket to support this torturous lifestyle the elephants live in, but I felt that it was necessary if I wanted to document and expose any type of cruel behaviours towards the animals. Some of the pictures I took show some sort of stick the trainers were using when the elephants were performing, and others are of the cruel tricks the elephants were forced to do. The one I find most appalling involves an elephant laying on the ground and having the two other elephants sit on it\'s head and back. Elephants are most certainly not known for their light weight. PETA wrote to Watertown\'s city council asking them to forbid Carson and Barnes from performing in Watertown, and showed the council the video of the elephants being treated cruelly during training sessions. I am embarrassed to say that the city council did not comply. Please help these elephants and stop the torture they endure during their life. Many are born, bred and live in a setting where they are frequently abused by the use of bullhooks, and are shocked with electric rods when they are too tired or too scared to perform tricks. They are kicked, screamed at or chained, and are forced to do unnatural and painful things for a few minutes of human entertainment. This is their entire life. Nothing, from the smallest insect to the greatest giant, deserves pain and suffering for any reason.', 'To Whom It May Concern: I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive elephants in the U.S. I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive elephants in the U.S.Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. To make matters worse, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force must be outlawed. Thank you for your consideration,', 'A significant number of elephants have had to be destroyed because of advanced joint and foot problems that stem from inadequate space in which to exercise, and hard surface areas on which to walk. Additionally, there are a number of elephants in zoos around the country that are currently suffering from the same conditions. Five or six experts in elephant care and elephant needs, with respect to healthy and humane exhibit space requirements in zoos, have all submitted a great deal of information with respect to the situation at the Los Angeles zoo, where an elephant recently died due to the zoo\'s failure to provide timely vet care. One need only to visit the website at "helpelephants.com" to read about several zoos that have had to destroy animals due to joint and foot problems brought on by inadequate conditions in indoor and outdoor exhibit areas. Elephants are by far the biggest attraction that zoos have, but unfortunately they present the greatest challenge to zoos to build an adequate exhibit area to resemble natural conditions for these incredibily intelligent and social animals. In the wild, elephants range over tens of miles each day, live in highly social herds and move most of the time. In zoos most of the time, elephants live in absurdly small areas that preclude them from getting adequate exercise, resulting in joint problems. Surface areas are mostly too hard due to the limited space, or are made of concrete, which is deadly too healthy feet.', 'The conditions of elephants held in captivity need to be drastically improved upon. I see elephants in circuses and zoos all the time that are confined to such small spaces. It is not right that we do this to them!', 'Please pass legislation seeking enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act?s adequate space provision at zoos and circuses for elephants. Please improve the lack of space, and bann unnatural substrates, unnatural social groupings, and the use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots, and other instruments of force commonly used to control elephants. Elephants are cruelly treated in circuses and should not be used for entertainment. If this is allowed the least the government could do is set high standards for their humane treatment and care for them with compassion, not electric hotshots and other instruments of torture. These animals were not put on earth to amuse man by being treated cruelly. They should be allowed to live normal lives not lives cooped up in zoos and circuses.', 'Please make it mandatory that elephants are allowed to roam freely in preserves. Circuses and zoos are not appropriate for these intelligent, beautiful creatures.', "I would like to let you know that i am appalled at the conditions elephants face in the circus and zoos. I will not be visiting these facilities at all and neither will my family and friends until strict laws are put in place to ensure these animals are no longer tortured. I urge you and reccommend the following be taken into account when making your rulings: ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health. Please it is imperative that we do not let madmen gain millions of dollars and have government supported abusive breeding grounds for madmen. I thankyou for taking this into account when making your decision. Please think of how you would feel if you were to witness the beatings these animals have to endure. Would you still think this is right. Remember humanity when making your decision and the statement' Do The Right Thing'.", 'Elephants should not be kept in circuses or zoos in the United States EVER! Circuses are notorious for the brutal forced domination they maintain over ellies to get them to perform for the paying customer. They are horrib
column3: ['I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  As long as SeaWorld and other facilities follow your regulations, I am in full support of Marine Mammal Facilities.', 'I have worked in the marine mammal care field for 3 years and have enjoyed educating and inspiring aquarium guests during our interactive programs with dolphins.  Our interactive programs are overseen by experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers.  Given the tremendous safety record related to supporting interactive programs at our facility and other marine parks throughout the country, I personally do not see a need for APHIS to impress animal welfare regulations related to interactive programs.', 'These places are needed to recover the marine mammals that are dying from oil spills and being injured.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please help marine mammals stay populated', "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thanks for letting Seaworld do for the animals what others don't do. They are the best well care animals. Don't let ignorance change that true.", "As an employee in operations currently at Dolphin Quest Hawaii, and a participant in programs at Dolphin Quest, Sea World, and other facilities like them, I can honestly say that the need for APHIS to increase regulation, and the concern APHIS has over the well being and safety of our animals, is unwarranted.  Here at Dolphin Quest it is quite clear that the safety and health of the animals is the top priority. From the top down, owners, management, training and front of house guest services, every single member of our team is committed and deeply invested in the welfare of our dolphins. I can attest to this as an employee, working with our wonderful training staff, but I can also attest to this as a participant and former visitor to places such as Dolphin Quest Hawaii.  As a university student at UCSB studying environmental science, caught up in the animal rights movement, I was on the fence about whether or not keeping animals like these under human care was helpful or not. I wondered as stewards of our earth, if as people we were doing the right thing. My sophomore year of college I visited DQ Hawaii and really got to talk in depth with the training staff here about what they do, how they do it, and most importantly why they do it. It was abundantly clear, as a visitor, that the training staff was of the highest quality, and that the dolphins were well loved and well cared for. It was also very clear, that facilities like Dolphin Quest are keystone pieces in influencing people to WANT to protect these animals.  So many people come to places like Sea World and Dolphin Quest that have never seen the ocean, much less seen a whale or dolphin. These interactive experiences are what really changes peoples minds. It's one thing to watch it on the Discovery channel or National Geographic, its another thing to be in the water, face to face with these amazing creatures.  What people don't seem to understand, even among the educated, is that without these kinds of experiences, how would you feasibly see one of these animals? How would you come to appreciate them? If it wasn't for zoos and aquariums, people would wouldn't know what a polar bear was, wouldn't know what a panda looks like, or a walrus, or a dolphin, or a beluga. These animals are next to impossible to see in the wild for the average human. And yet the average human can come face to face with a dolphin in the lagoon here at Dolphin Quest.   So, as an employee of Dolphin Quest, and as a kid who immigrated from a port city in Taiwan, to a small surf town in California, who grew up loving the ocean and loving these animals, I urge you to think about the facts.   Use the science at your disposal.  We both know that many of these stipulations in the new documents are not driven by scientific fact, and are merely assumptions made in the face of public pressure from a few outspoken sources. Places like Dolphin Quest and Sea World are not the enemy. Their interactive programs are incredibly enriching, for both the animals and the humans. Their trainers are top notch, experienced and dedicated. Simply put, they are the best. The decision to add additional regulation, to tie both the trainers hands and decrease interaction and stimulation of animals, is one that would be extremely negligent, and completely unnecessary.   Thank you for your time, and for considering my words. I know as an agency you will make the right decision for the well being of not only our animals, but also for the well being of our future generations.  Mahalo.", "Keep up with this life saving programs , these animals are the lucky ones,they couldn't be happier. It's a happy place for me too! I love Sea World and the zoo. I continue to support these facilities. Mary Harrison  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", "I am a final year veterinary medical student at the Royal Veterinary College in the United Kingdom and have been an active member of the animal training community since 2007.  I hold memberships with the AVMA (American Veterinary Medical Association), AZA (Association of Zoos and Aquariums), IMATA (International Marine Animal Trainers Association), IAAAM (International Association of Aquatic Animal Medicine), BVA (British Veterinary Association), and WAVMA (World Aquatic Veterinary Medical Association). In addition, I will become a member of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons following my graduation in July of this year. I have had the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the regulations and would like to submit the below comments for consideration.  I am in firm agreement with the proposed regulations regarding ventilation, as marine mammals can be particularly prone to respiratory illnesses. The threat of viral, fungal, and bacterial infections is far more pertinent than objectionable odours.    I am also in agreement regarding proposed regulations for shade in outdoor enclosures. Marine mammals are prone to certain ophthalmic diseases and specific neoplasias which are more likely following lengthy exposure to UV-light.  After performing a thorough literature search, I am unable to find peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for time constraints on interactive programming, or how such regulation would benefit marine mammals. I do support an increase in the amount of interactive programming (i.e. from 2 to 3 hours per day), however I struggle to support the overall notion that interactive sessions must not exceed 'x' hours per day per animal. It is my opinion that interactive programming itself is of benefit to the animals, as it provides a multitude of sensory and cognitive enrichment. Programming should be limited, however, if an individual animal demonstrates a specific need (e.g. neonates, pregnant or lactating females, ill animals, etc). This specific need should be assessed and determined by a qualified veterinarian.  Limiting interaction could decrease the amount of cognitive stimuli available for the animals. Many, if not all, of marine mammal interactive programs in the United States utilize classical and operant conditioning techniques based on positive reinforcement. A critical component of this is that the animals are provided with the opportunity to voluntarily participate in training sessions and interactive programming, and likewise are provided with the opportunity to refuse participation, if they so choose. The animals, therefore, regulate the amount of time they spend in interactive programs themselves; training staff simply provide them with multiple opportunities to participate throughout the day. (The inclusion of the 'buffer' areas could potentially benefit this concept further.)  I am in support of regulations that enhance the enclosure environments, or increase the amount of environmental enrichment available to the animals throughout the day. For example, regulations about the amount of shade provided to animals in enclosures, or that animals should have a minimum mandatory amount of time available to explore novel food items, toys, or conspecifics, would be of benefit, in my opinion.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary, and removes the opportunity for an animal to experience novel scenarios interacting with conspecifics. I am, however, in support of the proposal for at least one attendant being available to monitor each session, much the same way a lifeguard monitors a public pool.    I would like to thank APHIS for its diligent commitment to animal welfare, and for providing the opportunity for the public to share its opinion on the proposed regulations.   Best regards,   Jennifer Camilleri, (Hons) BSc Graduate Accelerated BVetMed and MRCVS Candidate Royal Veterinary College", 'Respectfully to the governing body of regulators:  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for your help and assistance', "Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.   I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities. Our family recently had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest. We also watched many sessions between the dolphins and trainers because our room was located by the water where the Dolphins lived and trained.  In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's expertise and dedication to the animals.    Our family has developed a respect for the environment after visiting this attraction at the Kahala.  We are aware of the way we treat the earth and try to live a better life, so these mammals will live a long, health life.", "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Without Sea World and Busch Gardens our children's children will never see certain species because they are endangered.  Let the parks continue to do what they do best.", 'Seeing the fish and mammals up close and personal at Sea World has given me a profound respect for nature and the miracle of varied life forms. What a tragedy if this experience were to be curtailed. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  With regard,', 'Thank you for your commitment to animal welfare.  I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience working with the animals as well as the most current science.   Marine parks and aquariums are essential because they educate the public about not only the animals themselves, but how to protect them in the wild.  They also teach about the importance of conservation and the environment and inspire many, including myself, to improve my daily actions to support the environment around me.  I have personally had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interaction program at Dolphin Quest.  I observed many sessions between the dolphins and their trainers and was impressed by how knowledgeable and dedicated the staff was to the animals.  I wish more people could experience these interactions to see just how much we can learn from marine parks and aquariums in how to protect the oceans and the world around us.', 'We the people love Sea World, we dont live near a Ocean so for us to go to Sea World is the world for us.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I been to Sea World many times so please dont let it be the last generation.', "o\tI have worked with marine mammals for 10 years.   I have been given the unique ability to inspire and educate guests through interactive programs with sea otters, penguins, sea lions, and dolphins as well as presentations with dolphins and sea lions.  Our interactive programs are overseen by experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers.  Given the tremendous safety record related to supporting interactive programs at our facility and other marine parks throughout the country, I personally do not see a need for APHIS to impress animal welfare regulations related to interactive programs. o\tI currently care for the southern sea otters at Georgia Aquarium.  We currently provide a home for five sea otters, 2 males and 3 females.  Our sea otters co-exist very well together and are managed through various social groups throughout the day.  We have three separate areas that not only allow variability and changes in social settings but also gives us the ability to observe how the animals interact when given all three spaces.  When they have the choice the sea otters generally choose to all be in either the same area or with at least one other otter.  I believe APHIS mandating separations would negatively impact the social behavior we observe with the sea otters in our care.  o\tI currently care for the southern sea otters at Georgia Aquarium.  We currently have a geriatric female that is 19 years old.  As her mobility has become a challenge and her ability to get out of the pool has become more difficult, we have explored various ways in which to assist her.  Installing a ramp proved ineffective to addressing her challenge as she refuse to use it.  Our team found that making adjustments in water level of her habitat was the most successful means of assisting her in and out of the water.  I feel APHIS's mandate that ramps be made permanent fixtures in all sea otter and pinniped enclosures is unnecessary and would not have supported the goal in this case.  As animal care professionals, we are charged with making whatever accommodations are necessary to help address any issue that arises in the care of these animals.  I feel that APHIS should accept water level adjustments be considered as an option in lieu of a physical ramp for young or geriatric animals to get out of the water when deemed necessary. o\tI have 8 years of experience working with California sea lions.  Working with this species has shown me the importance of sea lions having the ability to exhibit species appropriate social behavior.  I am confused by APHIS's suggestion to move this species to a Group II pinniped, even though the species has been successfully and safely managed in a zoological setting for many years.  Moving California sea lions to Group II would take away the opportunity for them to conduct appropriate social behaviors.  I recently had the ability to assist with rescue and rehabilitation of California sea lion pups through Georgia Aquarium.  There are an unbelievable amount of stranded, non-releasable sea lions and there only chance of survival is in human care.  Changing California sea lions to Group II would reduce the holding capacity for a species of animals that are direly in need of a place to live.", "SeaWorld's animal ambassadors inspire our grandchildren to care about and value them.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'I have worked in the marine mammal care field for over 12 years and have enjoyed educating and inspiring guests during our interactive programs with dolphins.  Our interactive programs are overseen by those of us that are experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers.  Given the tremendous safety record related to supporting interactive programs at our facility and other marine parks throughout the country, I personally do not see a need for APHIS to impress animal welfare regulations related to interactive programs.I have had the experience of seeing guests of all ages see aquatic animals and ecosystems they may never see in their lifetime and strike a deeper understanding of the one world ocean that connects us all. All of us at Marineland Dolphin Adventure are committed to providing our guests with a positive and impactful experience to inspire conservation of our aquatic world. Lastly, I work with the dolphins at Marineland Dolphin Adventure, an open air facility on the East coast of Florida. While dolphins at our facility are exposed to natural elements, including the sun, we have been trained to work with the animals in a manner in which we pay careful attention to the angle of the sun light so the dolphins are not looking directly into the sun. I have not seen the animals get sun burn or irritation from sun exposure.  We have a beautiful facility subject to harsh ocean winds so building a shade structure could be very difficult, expensive and unnecessary.  I fear the addition of excessive shade structures to limit exposure to the sun could increase risk to the dolphins if such a structure were to ever fail in a high wind storm.  I encourage APHIS to carefully review input from industry professionals and not impose regulations that are unnecessary.', 'We have been going to SeaWorld since we were children in the 1960s.  My husband and I have learned so much from them as have my nieces and nephews in more recent years.  The knowledge of the ocean that SeaWorld has taught us about is amazing.  Without their research there is so much we would never have known.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  SeaWorld is important to me and my family.  We hope you will keep the betterment of science in the equation for future generations of children to learn about the world of the deep that was once beyond our grasp.', "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.
