I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  It would be interesting to find out how many of these protesting animal parks or marine parks keep pets in their own home, in 'captivity'.  I'm sure they don't see it as hypocrisy.  I truly believe that children going to these parks value animals far more than if they had never interacted with them as my kids did and hopefully all our grandchildren will still be able to do.", 'They have always taken really great care of all of the animals. If they have been sick or needed something to help make them better, they have always made sure that they get what the animal needs.', "I am a frequent visitor to Gulfarium Marine Adventure Park in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.  During my visits, I have observed educational presentations and also spe
column4: ["Really, we don't have enough businesses already on the rope so we are going to set up conditions so that our food supply and associated businesses will now be subject to another foreign influence that will somehow turn out to be negative regardless of the low risk.  Stop the insanity now and keep restrictions in place.", 'I am appalled that you would be considering allowing the sale of beef from Brazil. The borders of the neighboring counties of Brazil are very lax and these countries have high incidence of F&MD. It would take one shipment of infected beef to topple our  US Beef industry. Why would we take that chance? I implore you to reconsider this decision to protect the interest of the US and its citizens.', 'Please do not allow import of Brazilian live cattle to the USA. We are FMD Free here and this could jeopardise our U.S. cattle producing industry. Thank you!', "I really think this is a bad idea. Due to the recent outbreaks in Europe, I don't want to put our country in an epidemic such as theirs.", 'I would ask that you do not consider or continue with beef imports from Brazil. "Any" risk of disease is foolishness, especially since our country has its own source of cattle and beef production, which is highly regulated and controlled. If the people still have a say, then I again ask to stop Brazilian beef imports and buy American beef.', 'The cost of a FMD outbreak in th U.S. would devastate the beef industry in the US that would require decades to recover. Why take the chance to get cheaper ground beef? I am totally against this proposal to import  ANY beef from Brazil.', "I'm not currently raising cattle, but am concerned about foreign animal diseases. Let's not lower our standards to satisfy politicians.", 'We absolutely do not need to take the risk of importing  God knows what kinds of disease and other problems from a country with a very unsavory track record of producing a completely safe and wholesome product.  The only reason this is being considered is that the big money packers and wholesalers have the juice to put pressure on our political and bureaucratic people of influence to write the rules to favor big business over the American farmer-rancher and the American consumer.  The whole idea is absolute crap.', 'As a veterinarian, and as a beef producer, I oppose the importation of beef from Brazil.   Our nations beef farmers need our support, particularly from a bio-security perspective.  FMD in the USA would be catastrophic to beef, dairy and swine production and consumer supply.    Secondly, my visits to Brazil to look at beef and dairy production have given me an understanding that their current system does not have comparable quality assurance for the animals, the product, and particularly their workers.  i do not believe we should expect American producers to meet environmental, animal welfare, quality assurance, and labor standards, but then allow importation of product that may not be held to the same expectations and requirements.  Third, our US beef herd has shrunk to its lowest level in 50 years.  We need economic incentives to increase our national herd.  We will not accomplish this with importation of product from Brazil.', 'April 22, 2014  Docket Number APHIS 2009-0017 Regulatory Analysis and Development PPD, APHIS, Station 3A-03.8 4700 River Road, Unit 118 Riverdale, MD  20737-1238  RE:  Docket Number APHIS 2009-0017, Importation of Beef From A Region in Brazil  The Iowa Cattlemens Association is the trade association for cattle producers in the state of Iowa, and represents more than 10,000 members. Our membership includes beef cattle producers, those who provide supplies and services to these farmers, as well as people who process, transport, prepare and sell beef to the American public. Last year, the Iowa beef industry generated over $5.5billion and 40,000 jobs for Iowas economy.  The current USDA APHIS proposal to allow beef imports to the U.S. from fourteen of Brazils twenty-six states is concerning because of the large economic risk to Iowa and U.S. cattle producers, as well as the health risk to the nations cattle herd.  Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) is considered a highly contagious viral disease, and the inability to control an outbreak is notable, as evidenced by its presence  in over 100 countries worldwide. Under current conditions, ICA does not support the proposed rule to import fresh beef.   Iowa cattlemen and women work diligently and pride themselves on their ability to produce plentiful, safe and nutritious beef for consumers. The U.S. has preserved FMD free status for nearly 100 years. The last documented outbreak of FMD in the United States occurred in 1929.  The reputation of U.S. beef cattle in the world and the resulting beef product is a result of our rigorous national bio-security programs, effective government regulations, and focus on animal health.   The Iowa Cattlemens Associations concerns arise after an analysis of the proposed rule. When looking to the bordering countries of Brazil, only one of the ten has been verified FMD free by the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE).   Our apprehension about the proposed import allowance from Brazil is reflected in a third party, objective, scientific review conducted  by a team of researchers from the University of Minnesota (UMN) College of Veterinary Medicine, Center for Animal Health and Food Safety, and the Center for Veterinary Population Medicine. Their study, APHIS Risk Analysis for the FMD Risk from Importation of Fresh, Maturated, Deboned Beef from a Region in Brazil into the United States, presents three convincing arguments that should drive USDA APHIS to reconsider the importation proposal: 1) a lack of consistency and verification within the USDA APHIS risk analyses documentation; 2) no transparency in research techniques used in the risk assessments; and 3) Brazils deficiencies in complying with U.S. importation regulations.   For these reasons, the ICA has significant concerns regarding the infrastructure, committed resources, and willingness of Brazil to consistently perform adequate risk management practices in order to protect the Iowa and U.S beef cattle herd from the risk of introducing FMD into the U.S. through the importation of Brazilian beef.   Although the USDA APHIS regulatory analysis highlights potential consumer benefits from the importation of beef from Brazil, it fails to address the economic impact on consumers if the FMD virus is introduced to the U.S. cattle herd.  Due to the lack of this vital information, ICA respectfully requests that USDA APHIS consider withdrawing their proposed rule to import fresh, maturated, deboned beef from Brazil into the United States.   We appreciate the opportunity to review and comment on this significant rule regarding beef products. We have great interest in working with USDA APHIS on the issues raised in our comments and to monitor implementation of any final rule.  Sincerely,   Ed Greiman President, Iowa Cattlemens Association', 'no brazil   beef   in USA .', 'Do not let Brazil beef in support our US beef industires', 'AFTOSA2   There are 3 issues that would negated the plans to import fresh beef from Brazil as proposed  In the 1970/80s there was research done by the USDA and Dept of Defense in Uruguay and published by Norman D. Heidelbaugh, VMD a former Associate Dean of Texas AM Veterinary School. If the lymph nodes were removed and the beef was treated with ionizing radiation, there was no aftosa virus detected in the fresh beef product. However if the Brazil product was treated the same method there are 3 additional factors that would impact the beef industry in USA as follows:  1. Canada has not approved the treatment of beef with ionizing radiation. The beef imported into USA from Brazil could not be co mingled with beef that might be exported to Canada  2. Canada is much more cautious about importing meat product from aftosa countries. Thus Canada would not allow beef from the USA to be exported into Canada even if it was not treated with ionizing radiation.  3. There have been incidences where frozen bulk meat in 25 KG blocks package were exported into USA from Australia. The regulations do not permit such meat to be exported into USA if the lymph nodes had not been removed. However I noted on occasions that this product still had the lymph nodes in the frozen package at the retail level where the product was to be ground and repackaged. Australia is a developed country, Brazil is not. It is doubtful that the product from Brazil could expect to have the lymph nodes removed even when it is required and inspected. Brazil has an international reputation where they do not abide and delivering meat and poultry product acceding to the sanitary regulations. Thus it is doubtful that the USA could expect to receive the fresh meat product where the lymph nodes were removed in all cases. The lymph nodes are where the aftosa virus is in high concentrations. Thus the chance of introducing aftosa virus into would be higher than expected.     Joseph Butterweck, DVM, DACVPM Fresno, CA', 'Dear USDA,  Do not allow the importation of beef from Brazil.  Brazil has recently had outbreaks of FMD, and we have kept this disease out of this country since 1929.  It makes no sense to import beef from Brazil and risk contamination to the U.S. beef supply.  By importing beef from Brazil that could have FMD, at a lower cost you are jeopardizing both the livelihoods of the beef producers in the U.S. and also affecting their bottom line.  This is an irresponsible proposal, I ask the USDA to to deny this proposed rule and look to the U.S. producers to meet their needs with quality uncontaminated beef.    Best Regards, Amy Schaffer', 'Please do not allow beef imports from Brazil into the U.S., it will harm the financial status of the U.S. cattle producers.  We have enough issues to contend with we do not need to have imported beef contributing to these issues as well.', 'Brazilian beef should not be allowed in the United States because of the health hazard to the beef supply,  because they have not shown sufficient evidence that is under control in their country or neighboring countries.  We need to be sure that our beef herds in this country are safe.', "The United States Livestock industry has been diligent in complying with animal health and food safety regulations.  This has benefited consumers and producers alike.  It is dereliction of duty to accept ANY risk to United States citizens, livestock industry, and consumers of USA meat products world-wide.   ANY BENEFIT (IF IT EXISTS) DOES NOT OUT WEIGH THE RISK.  I STRONGLY object to allowing any beef products entering the United States from countries with animal health and food safety standards that are not at least as stringent as those of the United States.   I urge the USDA to re-evaluate this deplorable proposal.  Brazil doesn't not have the protections and animal health track record of the United States and has a vested interest in not providing full disclosure of present and past animal health issues  that would impact any decision on this proposal.", 'NO!!! Do not do this.  I cannot even figure out why we would want to introduce more disease to our country.  This is an outrage, why are we considering this AMERICA?!?!', 'Permitting fresh beef imports from Brazil would be a very poor decision and would almost certainly decimate the whole North American  Livestock industry if Foot and Mouth Disease is imported with it.  This is a very real risk as the disease is present in parts of Brazil.  Prices for beef in the approved provinces would no doubt be higher so there would be incentive to move livestock from the infected areas and even other countries, such as Uraguay.  If contaminated beef is interduced to the U.S. it would then be very easy to get transferred to the feral pig and wild deer populations from garbage dumps and even picnic grounds.  After that it would be impossible to contain and lead to disaster for livestock producers.  My grandfather went through the  FMD outbreak in Texas and by his account it was heartbreaking to see the herds destroyed and buried.', "Please do not approve the proposed rule change on the Importation of Beef from countries with known Foot and Mouth Disease.  This would be a huge risk that could cripple the U. S. Cattle industry and farmers face enough challenges in today's markets already.  We should be working harder at keeping American markets safe for current and future generations not relaxing rules.", 'I do NOT approve. I am a vegetarian, but this is a matter of food security for EVERYONE.', 'Please take the time to consider all the elements of animal production and food safety before you make this decision. It would be very detrimental to the live cattle market the day that you announce that you would allow such imports. You have a very strong meat packer with close ties to Brazil that can and would manipulate the market. It would end all competitiveness and destroy the free enterprise system we have here in the US. All this would be done without the consideration of food safety. To even consider this decision brings to question the integrity of our own government agencies. Please do not allow this action to take place.', 'I would like to add some suggestion and ask some questions about this proposal: Which is the system used by Brazil to control the passage of cattle from their neighbors with foot and mouth disease? How you can determine if there is no infection or possible infections if the transmission of FMD is by patterns weather or through fecal matter of birds among others? How they control the laboratories and test of diagnosis? The laboratories from Brazil are state or private? I suggest that Brazil should have a traceability system that shows from the birth of the cattle to the slaughter. There are any test to ensure presence of e-coli and mad cow disease? There is a degree of monitoring there by USA to ensure that it wouldnt have irregularities? How can Brazil ensure the movements of the cattle in the country? What are the recommendations of the Committee of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures of the WTO (responsible for the Administration of the Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures)?', "I strongly opposes USDA's proposed rule for the importation of fresh, matured, deboned beef from regions in Brazil and Argentina.", 'Please do not let this happen! Support our own farmers and family farms here in the USA.', 'I would expect the USDA to be in the forefront to keep disease out of the USA regardless of the incoming source.  Our history speaks for itself.  Also, it is the responsibility of the USDA to insure that market prices remain profitable for the producer and affordable for the consumer aside from the fact that food safety be the #1 priority.  I have worked in the meat industry for 35 years and have always prided myself in providing our country with a safe meat product  that they could offer their family at the dinner table each night.  Why would you want to jeopardize that?  Do the members of the U.S. International Trade Commission want to feed unsafe Brazilian beef to their families even at half the price of U. S. beef?  I think not and neither do I.', 'As a consumer of beef products I am adamently opposed to the importation of Brazilian beef until there is absolutely NO chance of FMD contamination. The FDA & AFIS  have dropped the ball too many times in the past, and it will happen again. This is just plain wrong to subject the citizens of the United States to the very real probability of another food-borne illness or outbreak.', 'The Foot and Mouth Disease virus is endemic in Brazil.  Fresh and frozen Brazilian beef can spread the disease to the United States.  The virus is highly infectious and spreads quickly.  It infects animals with cloven hoofs.  Exposed livestock is usually shot, rolled into pits, and burned.  The U.S. is home to numerous susceptible wildlife species.  Exposed wildlife could not be contained and destroyed.  The U.S. would then become an endemic area.  Livestock can be vaccinated (partial success) but wildlife cannot. The initial infection is usually survived and the animal suffers a long and often incomplete recovery.  The last European outbreak was caused by imported pork that was thrown out of a restaurant.  The U.S. has uncontrolled feral hogs in 38 states that are rapidly spreading to other states.  For obvious reasons, meat imported from Foot and Mouth Disease infected countries is not welcome in countries that have healthy livestock and wildlife.', "To whom it may concern,  I as a member of The Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association strongly oppose the USDA's proposed rule for the importation of fresh, matured, deboned beef from regions in Brazil and Argentina. TSCRA supports free trade of live cattle, beef, and/or beef products with foreign countries that have proper animal health and food safety protocols in place; however, both Brazil and Argentina lack proper protocols and have not been successful in controling foreign animal diseases such as foot and mouth disease (FMD).  As you know, protecting the U.S. cattle industry from a catastrophic foreign animal disease, such as foot and mouth disease, is a major priority for all ranchers. FMD could cause a widespread quarantine and possible massive depopulation of the cattle herd in the United States, thus compromising national security, jeopardizing our beef supply, and costing our industry hundreds of millions of dollars. Thank you W.F. Baker", 'The importation of beef from Brazil will not only destroy the U.S. beef market, but could destroy the entire U.S. economy.  Brazil has had a major problem with foot and mouth disease.  If the U.S. gets this highly contagious disease every thing that moves will be stopped cold.  This disease not only affects cattle but all animals including wildlife. This is especially dangerous situation for our food supply not to mention for endangered species, as all animals with in 60 mile radius will have to be destroy.  Foot and Mouth Disease has a 14 day incubation period before any sign of sickness, can travel on the wind for 60 miles, and one infected animal could travel the entire length and with of the U.S. before it can diagnose.  This could be very easy for a terrorist to use to stop the entire economy.  Brazil can already import beef as long as it is already cooked.  Plus it took them 2 years to report a case of BSE, do we really want to trade with a country that will do something like that.  Plus what other countries will import cattle into Brazil so the can then be imported in the U.S. as "Brazilian Beef".', "As a fifth generation rancher, I am continually amazed by the efforts of our government to harm it's citizens.  The BSE shutdown was a crippling blow to the US cattle industry but one we have overcome through hard work and considerable expense. Why would the potential importation of a highly contageous virus like Foot and Mouth Disease even be a topic of discussion in this country.  Our part of the southwest has been desimated by four to five years of drought.  Our cattle numbers are half what they have historicaly been and we have struggled to remain a viable business.  Fortunately the reduced inventory has created increased value for producers and allowed them to meet the financial obligations created by the increased costs of production, ie., feed, fuel, fertilizer, insurance, etc.  We have tried to further enhance our profitability by marketing through value added programs that emphasize all natural beef and naturally colored mohair.  The emphasis on antibiotic and hormone free feeder calves not only effects the total pounds of beef we have to sell but creates a greater risk from disease.    People are more aware of what they put into their bodies than ever before.  They are demanding change from traditional production practices to maintain healthier lifestyles.and we are trying to provide beef that meets that demand.  A FMD outbreak would devistate that public confidence and put large numbers of producers out of business thus increasing our dependence on inferior foreign products at a inflated price to consumers.  I strongly oppose the importation of any comodities that do not meet the standards set by the USDA much less ones that have the potential to distroy not only an American industry but a way of life.", 'I am not in favor of importing beef from Brazil.  Please carefully consider the significant risks of Hoof and Mouth decease, and do not allow this to happen.  Thank You.', "Don't import beef from Brazil. The only benefit you are expecting is actually harmful: lowering the price of beef. Lowering the price of beef will reduce income for America's cattle ranchers, so that's a bad thing. Do what you can to support American farmers. Definitely don't implement programs that hurt farmers.", 'We are ranchers in TExas and are very very against bring foreign beef into the USA.  We do not need any foreign diseases brought in our healthy disease free herds.  We have plenty of our own beef here for the citizens here.   Whoever thinks this neeeds to happen needs to talk to the farmees and ranchers in this country.  They wil tell you that if the disease hoof and mouth got started here then there would be no more USA beef in his country.   I WOULD BE GLAD TO DISCUSS THIS WITH ANY POLITICIAN THAT WOULD LIKE TO DISCUSS THIS.  Thank you for listening to my opinion and hopefully this will NOT happen in the country.', 'I have been in the animal blood business for 25 years and my comment is related to Brazilian Fetal Bovine Serum.  This product is currently not allowed to import into the United States because of the same reasons meat is not allowed from Brazil.  Due to the cattle shortage in the U.S. and other areas the price of raw Australian Fetal Bovine serum is now $1,000 per liter and raw U.S. origin Fetal Bovine Serum at $300 per liter and raw Fetal Bovine Serum from USDA approved countries, Mexico, Canada, Panama is now over $200 per liter.  The price of raw Brazilian Fetal Bovine Serum is $70 per liter.  Prices have more than doubled in the U.S. for all the different origins of fetal bovine serum in the last 2 years and they will continue to increase as more people switch from Australian to U.S. origin.  Fetal Bovine Serum is used to produce human/animal vaccines, medical diagnostic tests and is also used in very large quantities in cell culture at universities and hospitals throughout the U.S.  It is a fundamental product for all cell culture research done in in the U.S. in relation to cancer and basically every disease known to man.  The biggest scientific breakthroughs in research are happening using Fetal Bovine Serum.  In Europe, Brazilian FBS has been used in cell culture for the past 20 years.  It is used as the primary product in cell culture research throughout Europe by 80% of the potential users.  Our European colleagues have been using Brazilian FBS with success for many years and are getting a high quality product at more than half the cost of what researchers in the United States have to pay.  With the current increase in prices and lack of supply the researcher at Harvard and Stanford is now and in the future going to be paying 5X to 10X more for US origin and USDA fetal bovine serum compared to what their colleague and or competitor in  Europe will be paying.   If the current market conditions do not change than eventually less cell culture research will be done in the U.S. because Fetal Bovine Serum will take up more of the limited budgets.  There just is not enough FBS in the U.S. to meet our demands and the U.S. needs to allow the importation of Brazilian FBS before the costs of vaccines get too high and the output of medical research gets affected.', "It is interesting and extremely frightening that you are considering allowing Brazilian beef into the U.S. considering their poor track record with Foot and Mount disease.  It only takes one case to destroy the stellar record that cattle producers here in the U.S. have established.  At one time the state of Montana was classified as a Brucellosis free state.  The cattle producers in Montana had spent millions of dollars ensuring that brucellosis was not present in any herd within the state.  There were strict regulations for cattle coming in from other states to ensure that the disease didn't come into the state from elsewhere.  Then in one flourish of a pen, that was destroyed when the governor of Montana extended the boundaries of Yellowstone National Park.  All that hard work and money was down the drain.  Please do not repeat this kind of mistake.  The cattle producers in the US deserve better.  Why should the US government be supporting other countries who are not concerned about the welfare of their livestock or the effect it can have on others?", 'Do we have a shortage of beef in the US?  Do we need the possible exposure or H&M?  Cattle men are finally making a profit and the GOVERNMENT wants to stab us in the back! It is about time that the US stops unfair trade Charity and thinks about OUR producers!  Once small to medium size beef producers are out of business and Corporate farms take over, what will the government do? The world produces most of our manufactured goods and now YOU want to have the world produce our food too,  FOOD SECURITY?', 'Please do not allow Brazilian beef into the United States.  Hoof and mouth disease is a grave concern for US consumers and domestic beef supply.  Imports from Brazil could devastate our domestic market and have a long term affect on consumer confidence in a safe food supply.  Do what is right for United States consumers and industries instead of catering to outside influence.', "I do not support your proposal to import beef from 14 states of Brazil with potential for FMD. I think it is irresponsible and reprehensible to risk importing this disease and threaten the American beef industry.  Really, don't you have something better to do?", "From an American rancher's point of view on this, it seems like it would be a slam. After all the hard work that has been put into marketing livestock why would anybody put the future of the United States beef industry on the edge. If the border was to open such as this situation it would put a huge worry and strain on the beef industry in America. It would lower our cattle prices causing ranchers to live on the fact that they might not be able to make a living or even pay bills. It could put the America rancher in financial trouble. It only makes sense to leave the border closed and to continue on with Americas ranching and marketing ways.", 'Last 5 years=tough cattle markets. Why? High corn prices. Why?Ethanol mandates and drought. FINALLY those of us left are STARTING to recover. Why? Decreased cattle supply=better cattle prices. Insert Brazilian beef=Pooooorer prices for the cattleman. We are still in a recession out here, let the USA cattleman feed the US population.', 'I do not believe we should allow beef import from Brazil or any other foreign country.', 'Both Brazil and Argentina lack proper protocols and have not been successful in controling foreign animal diseases such as foot and mouth disease (FMD).  FMD could cause a widespread quarantine and possible massive depopulation of the cattle herd in the United States, thus compromising national security, jeopardizing our beef supply, and costing our industry hundreds of millions of dollars.', "We do not need to impot beef from other countries that do not regulate beef coming into the USA , we have enough cattle in the USA , that's all we need is a out break of foot and mouth disease in our beef cattle , so HELL NO!!!!!!", 'I am strongly opposed to the importation of Beef or any cloven hooved animal products from any country with the presence of Foot and Mouth disease.    I have traveled to countries where FMD exists.  I know for a fact that although the veterinary service says they have controls in place.  The controls are not maintained.  I have seen with my own eyes how the system is manipulated.  In the case of Brazil.  When Russia banned meat products from the State of Goias.  The live cattle were then diverted to neighboring Brazilian states, that were not banned from Russia.  The trucks went straight from the farms in Goias to the slaughterhouses in Sao Paulo without any tire wash or any kind of treatment as should be the case. The economic impact on Beef prices would be negligble to the US Economy as we currently have import protocol in place with Non FMD countries.  My concern is the lack of controls in Countries such as Brazil.    We in the United States tend to be naive in thinking that other countries will follow the rules.  These countries do not and graft and corruption is a fact of life.  At the farm level and at the local level, the controls will not be in place and we will see FMD in this country, sooner than later should the APHIS Proposed rule go through.', 'In response to the proposed importation of Brazilian beef:  Respectfully I must strenuously disagree that the risks of re-introducing devastatingly contagious diseases in our national herds are unacceptable. Brazil has not the track record to justify the risks involved; nor have they been completely forth-coming or transparent with problems in the past. I am a rancher in the Nebraska sandhills, and I speak for very many others who have a vested interest in maintaining the integrity of our quality, health and safety of our cattle, and our markets. Thank you  Daph Hobelman  Lightning Valley', "This is so ridiculous and should NOT even be up for discussion. It is time for the US government to stop endangering us - stand up and be a savior for our own people for once instead of trying to save the world. Brazil's economy is doing just fine - they do not need us to buy from them. I find it extremely irresponsible and disturbing on your part that you would even consider allowing an import of beef that could potentially invite in Foot & Mouth Disease and who knows what other pathogens. Any outbreak or introduction of disease into our system would ultimately kill our own farmers lively-hood and potentially infect our own animals - you are seriously opening up a can of worms. Sure you can argue it will be regulated - but we all know - and I speak from personal experience as an Ex-Federal Government employee that all things start out closely monitored/regulated but once the dust and limelight settles - it becomes all too easy to look the other way. It's not always about the money - stop operating out of your pocket -get out of bed with the corrupt people and start doing what is right for once. The demise of this country began when we started going outside of ourselves - allowing outsourcing etc - be honest with yourself -each and everyone of us experiences it in some way almost every day.   I find it interesting that today in the news that 8.7 million pounds of beef is being recalled because it was deemed unfit for human consumption and dangerous - that was meat processed a YEAR ago - here is a classic example on how the USDA did not properly do their job! And you think it's going to be any different when it comes to monitoring imports- how foolish can you be? If they cannot be responsible for what is currently inside our borders there is absolutely no way in hell they will be any more proficient in monitoring what is coming from other countries. Classic example - remember the tainted pet food that killed tons of our animals from China.   On a side note: If the current beef shortage in this country is your motivation for entertaining this foolishness - then step in and help our own farmers recover - do not go out and invite in a myriad of problems. There are solutions that exist to save ourselves - pipe in water, bring down feed costs, etc. If we can run huge oil pipelines for the greed of the few then certainly to God we can pipe in water to parched fields for the betterment of all. Work on solutions here!!!  Bringing in beef from Brazil is currently way too risky a proposition especially coming from a country who is dealing with ongoing disease. This is potentially a major disaster waiting to happen if you allow this to go through - do you really want to take that risk?? I respectfully ask you to please do the right thing and say No to this option.", 'As a trained scientist and a beef producer I am continually amazed at our casual attitude toward agriculture. An outbreak of foot and mouth is complete devastatio
column5: ['This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:   The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market. Please reconsider the ban.', 'There are many toys and products currently on the market in the US that are capable of causing harm to children. Trampolines cause injuries. Legos cause injury. Toy cars cause injuries. Yet none of these products are explicitly banned in the United States. There is no reason for magnet sets to also be banned. Warning labels are a much better way to go.', "These magnets are not advertised as toys, nor provided for any explicit purpose.  They are science novelties and are suitable for learning, experimentation, and discovery by a variety of people.  At the most, a label may be required to warn against use by unattended children.  There are plenty of more dangerous household items, with fewer practical uses, which have not been subjected to similar witch-hunts.    There's no reason to ban the sale of these magnets outright.  There may be a danger associated with them, in very specific circumstances.  Make those circumstances well known and encourage responsible use.  Do not make them unobtainable.  Please.", 'Just placing a warning on the produce is sufficient.  And at some point the parent needs to be held responsible, not the manufacturer.', 'As a physicist, graduate instructor, and Los Alamos National Laboratory employee, I wish to strongly oppose the ban on magnetic toys. These magnet sets are of tremendous educational values, and I have used them in the classroom as well as at scientific community outreach events. The toys are clearly not for children, and are labelled appropriately as such. These toys are no different than other myriad products that are perfectly safe for adults but should not be played with or handled by small children. The risk of such toys to adults and to age appropriate children with proper supervision is minimal and much less than other daily activities such as driving etc.', 'Since this summer, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission has been threatening to sue Zen Magnets and Bucky Balls for what it claims are a rash of ingestion-related injuries. Kids who accidentally or intentionally swallow multiple magnets may have them pinch together on a section of their intestines, which requires surgery to remove. That doesn\'t mean that one of the best science-oriented toys ever created should be made illegal. Especially now, when our schools are struggling, and when it\'s been so hard to get kids interested in science.  Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don\'t ban them! And as Zen Magnets pointed out in a statement, "...there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them. That is a good thing.', 'Dont ban magnet sets. There are many other things that also cause harm to children. Why not go ahead and ban all those too?', 'Dont Ban them!  Why dont you ban trampolines? "There will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children."   Why dont we ban cars while we are at it? "And if its all summed up in a yearly basis,there are 5.25 million driving accidents that take place per year. Statistics show that each year, 43,000 or more of the United States population die due to vehicular accidents and around 2.9 million people end up suffering light or severe injuries. In a certain five year period, there had been recorded a 25% of the driving population who encountered or were involved in car accidents. It is also affirmed that car accidents kill a child every 3 minutes.Statistics on the number of car accidents taking place in every state or country is normally based on medical or insurance records filed."', "The products are clearly labeled and the use of the product, and the consequences of it being handled by a child, are solely the responsibility of the purchaser. There are any number of dangerous and hazardous products that can be found in any given household.  Should we just ban the sell of anything that is small enough to swallow or otherwise not covered entirely with copious amounts of rubber padding simply because there's a risk that a small child might get their hands on it? What of dangerous household chemicals?", "These sets are marketed towards adults and older children and have ample warnings prior to sale as to the dangers involved with younger children.  There is no need for further regulation of them.  What's next?  A ban on knives because they can cut us?  Really folks, take some responsibility and use products safely, store them safely and stop looking for the government to do your parenting.", "Used responsibly by young adults and adults alike, these magnets can be engaging and educational toys. There are many things that can be swallowed and cause harm, or cause other bodily harm that are much more widely available than these magnets and that are not regulated. Don't ban the Buckyballs!", "Preventing the sale of an item because it's found to be too dangerous is similar to gun control. The buyers and parents are the responsible party. Toys are harmless, ignorance and poor parenting is not.", 'Magnetic toys for children (i.e. Buckyballs) are very hazadorous to their health.  Their is a high possibility of swallowing the magnets as children often think they are candy or play with them in their mouths.  As a consequence, many emergent procedures are required to remove the magnets - upper endoscopy or surgery.  Additionally, there are also many cases where serious, dire complications have occured due to ingestion of the magnetic toys. It is possible for the magnets to cause intestinal perforations across the lumen. I truly believe that manufacturing for these toys must be stopped in order to prevent unnecessary surgeries, procedures or even death.', 'This proposal is a gross overreaction to an very unfortunate, albeit very rare, type of accident.  Of course rare earth magnets can be very harmful; but responsible sellers have always provided adequate warning and never marketed magnet collections as "toys" or targeted small children.  I have purchased many sets of magnets for artistic sculpture projects and they have brought great joy to my life.  It is my responsibility to ensure they are handled safely and kept out of reach of childre; and that is exactly what I do.  The relative risk magnet sets pose to children is miniscule compared to the risk posed by legitamate "toys" such as BB or Airsoft guns.  Yet warnings are sufficient for those products?  Common household objects pose a MUCH greater risk than those toys.  So why is a ban considered an appropriate action to take against magnet sets when it obviously wouldn\'t be an appropriate action for much more dangerous products?', 'This is taking regulation waaaaay to far. Come on... really? come on..magnets!', 'Please do not ban or pursue the federal lawsuit of Bucky Balls, and Zen Magnets.   These are a great asset for science and adult supervised activities for both children and adults.   Injuries due to lack of supervision should not be directed to the manufacture, but rather to the adult or parent.  Thank you', "This step against Magnetic Sets is ridiculous in the extreme. These spheres harm fewer people every year than the most mundane objects and activities. Examples of these have been given repeatedly, but a few- Pencils and pens, knives, trampolines, playing a sport, swimming, eating chicken, public transportation, riding a bike, playing on a playground, taking Asprin, riding in a car... I have more, but the point is made.   These magnetic spheres are not marketed to children and have safety warnings plastered all over them. If a person (or a child's guardian) chooses to ignore safety warnings the company who sold them the item simply cannot be held accountable. In fact- in most of these cases the parents should be held accountable for negligence.   Should a company that makes power tools be forced out of business because someone managed to misuse the equipment despite the safety warnings? Of course not!  The companies selling these magnetic spheres have taken every reasonable precaution. Magnetic spheres are obviously not a part of a human diet- and are no more deadly than if someone decided to be stupid one day and swallowed a couple of staples.   If these magnetic spheres were SUPPOSED to be put in your mouth as per manufacturer directions and fatalities occurred- sure, that would be an issue. But that is NOT the case here.  In the end- where would you draw the line? I'm honestly interested. Bleach is a dangerous substance, and has been used in the past in the act of suicide and poisonings. Is it right to ban bleach to prevent the next death, despite drinking clearly not being part of the intended use and multiple warnings on the bottle?  We humans are fragile things. Literally *anything* given the appropriate circumstances can kill us. The manufacturers of these products cannot be held accountable for blatant misuse.", 'I am strongly against banning Magnet Sets. If needed, they should have warning labels, but they should not be banned.', "I can think of many other more dangerous toys that should be banned before magnets......what's next?....bicylces?  This is going to cause more harm than good.  I enjoy magnets and should be able to have them if I choose.", "I urge you to reconsider the banning of these toys. These toys may very well be the best science-oriented toys ever created and they shouldn't be made illegal. Especially now, when our schools are struggling, and when it's been so hard to get kids interested in science.", 'Your NPR asserts that "in contrast to ingesting other small parts...magnetic properties of the object can cause serious...injuries".  Children are poisoned and suffocated from things that they swallow.  The more appropriate difference between the hazards of magnets and choking hazards is that a child who is choking needs attention in minutes or less to prevent suffocating to death.  A swallowed magnet, while requiring immediate attention, does so on the scale of hours if not days.  "The CPSC staff experts do not believe warnings will ever be effective in protecting children from this hidden hazard".  A simple, more just, answer to this concern would be to charge parents who fail to keep these products away from their children with neglect.   Table 1 is an absolute joke where "95.8 percent of the cases upon which the table was based were described as only possibly involving the magnets of interest" Even when counting that many "maybes" in the data there are still only 35 cases of emergency department assistance being required.  Contrast this against the 2.7m sets sold and the accidents for which this rule is intended to prevent is reduced to being completely trivial.  The Commission has failed to show that an unreasonable risk of injury exists given the low incidence of emergency care given and that swallowing incidents can be blamed on negligent of parents not an inherently unsafe product.', 'You are horrible for making these decisions and hounding the companies that make these magnetic products! Someone\'s business is now lost because of this. You\'ve harassed Buckyballs into deciding to stop manufacturing their product. You\'ve succeeded in what you wanted, to get the product off all shelves. But in the process of doing so, you have eliminated many jobs, something hard to come by in this economy, and someones business that they worked hard to build.  Not only that, you stayed blind to the fact that these products were intended for adults, not children! The people making the complaints had to have noticed the warning labels. There are several all over the packaging and inserts. You even have to sign something saying it is for adults when you buy online. The people making the complaints are more than likely the "sue happy" type. Unfortunately you have let them win and let the working class lose.', "I am one physician in a 5 member group of practicing Pediatric Gastroenterologist in Portland, OR.  We have been seeing several children who have ingested these dangerous high powered magnets in the last 6 months, producing urgent or emergent medical situations requiring extensive investigation (medical procedures) and in some cases, abominal surgery to prevent or repair the significant damage to these childrens' intestines caused by these magnets.  There is no need for these products to be sold on the market for entertainment.  I would support legislation that would ban or severely restrict the sale of these items in the USA.", 'People need to be responsible..period', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:    The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.   The ban is overly broad. The ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated risks similar to other behaviors.   These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.  Statistics should be provided by the CPSC to broadly demonstrate the comparable danger of zenmagnets to other banned products in order to show that a magnetic ball ban would  NOT be an anomaly among banned products instead of making arguments that try to redefine or, worse yet, negate reasonable safety standards.', "I believe that these magnet sets should not be banned so long as they are not marketed to children.  We do not ban the sale of knives because children could be seriously injured if they play with them, we just don't market them as children's toys.  BuckyBalls have had warnings on them for years that they are not to be ingested or played with by small children.  That should be enough.", 'Banning a product based off a rare situation is not productive. Sure, magnetic marbles pose a potential safety concern, but the concern is just that, potential. Like other products that warn parents of choking hazard due to small parts, at most, magnet sets should have to warn parents of the potential dangers.  I\'ll probably lose credibility but I must still bring up that the logic in banning magnet sets because of ingestion, even after warning, would have anything anyone has gotten stuck in their butt banned. A simple web search for "Rectal Foreign Bodies" will return many results to a paper that details the numerous objects that have gotten willfully lodged in a person\'s body. The point of bringing up inserting objects into the rectum is that it\'s unlikely anyone has seriously considered banning products due to curious idiots doing unwise things; children eating things is the same situation, only because "child" is the subject and not "drunk frat boy" are magnet sets being considered for a ban.  The ban has good intentions, but does not solve the underlying issue of lack of education. An individual has the right to know the possible dangers of a product, and the right to decide if they will purchase or use said product. An individual does not have the right to enforce their own decisions on others as it would infringe on the other\'s right to decide.', "These magnets are a useful and fun way to learn about magnets and their properties. Banning the item altogether shouldn't be done. Perhaps posting warnings or making the magnets available to purchase only for adults would be a better solution than banning them altogether.", "Rare earth magnets have been sold in hobby shops for years without issue or need for regulation to prevent ingestion. I believe the outright banning of the magnets is a heavy-handed and obnoxious way to address a statistically small number of incidents.  Alternative #4 suggests the use of childproof packaging and suggests this might be difficult to develop. I see no reason why responsible adults could not keep their magnet sets in the same child-proof canisters used to prevent children accessing medicine. Perhaps a different color plastic could be used to clearly distinguish the container from medicinal canisters.  Furthermore, I find much of the reasoning in the proposed rule speculative and unsubstantiated. There are many small items that would be hazardous for children to swallow that adults purchase and display on a regular basis. I would suggest that small items that are sharp or fragile may present the same or greater health risks when swallowed. I see no reason to single out magnet sets as a risk dangerous enough to require a ban.  This issue does not need to be addressed with a ban on a perfectly innocent product. It should be addressed by proper adult supervision of children and storage of their magnet sets. Anyone who raises children is aware swallowing small items is a hazard. Frankly, I believe the introduction of this rule is a waste of CPSC resources and consequently the citizenry's money.", 'Banning magnet sets is pointless over-stepping. People need to be able to choose for themselves. The Magnet sets are designed and marketed for adults. Plenty of warnings are on the sets as is.', "This is absolutely absurd.  I am a chemist.  I am allowed to use the chemicals I work with every day because I am of age.  If the government banned the sale of all of these things to everyone, even those mature enough, where the heck would our world be.  I'm not saying let kids use them, just don't ruin it for the rest of the world.", 'It seems like it is overkill to ban these magnet sets. they are not marketed to kids. They are targeted to adults. They probably should have a warning just in case but to ban them is unfair. Parents need to watch what their kids do and the govt banning this product will not help that.', 'Do not ban, or sue Zen Magnets or Bucky Balls for the manufacture of these magnificent toys and learning tools. With the limited number of injuries reported with these toys compared to the thousands upon thousands of injuries sustained by trampolines alone, the proposed safety standard and legal action are ridiculous. Hold the parents who purchase these responsible for lack of oversight of their children, not the companies who have no authority to oversee those who use (or abuse) their product. Make a waiver be required for purchase, add extra labeling, but do not perform the idiotic maneuver of banning these extremely capable tools for learning and engaged, productive distraction, simply because there are parents who use no forethought or have no capability to oversee their own children.', 'What a waste of government time and resources. Making them illegal because they are irresponsibly used but not inherently dangerous is akin to making cars illegal because sometimes people crash.', 'I cannot see any reason to regulate the sale of magnets to adults, that are meant for adults.', 'This is perhaps the most ridiculous overstretch of government authority I believe I have ever witnessed.  Around 30% of all choking deaths in infants and children were attributed to balloons.  So it stands to reason that balloons which are marketed as toys are more of a threat than magnetic desk toys which are not marketed as toys.  This appears to be a war on a single industry that flies in the face of logic, reason, and the very statistics that it claims as a defense.  If you are going to ban  magnets, then do balloons next.. perhaps pennies as well.. The absurdity of both of those statements should make it clear that you are in the wrong with this ban.', 'DO NOT BAN THEM', "Look, I grasp that there are people who are too stupid to own these, but... STOP SCREWING OVER EVERYONE just because you think you need to 'protect' them.  There is no justifiable reason to be banning these. It's ludicrous.", 'I feel the attempts to protect children using a sledge hammer tactic is completely unwarranted.  The basis to mask data with using ALL types of magnet related incidents to justify taking down legitimate companies is a stretch.    Again convincing the public that warning labels are useless just shows how well thought out the argument of a proposed ban is.  If this rule passes then it takes responsibilities out of parents who ignores warning labels and diminishes the rights of small businesses such as Bucky balls.  I vote a big fat NO and back to the drawing board for the CPSC.  Or better yet go after products that already have a higher incident rates for children and work WITH the companies as opposed to going around their backs like a shady bureaucrat!', 'Trying to ban Bucky Balls and Zen Magnets now?  How many more pathetic nanny regulations can you imagine it will take before the citizenry goes from rebelling against tyranny to outright rage?  Remember, rebellions are more organized, rage....  then we get to see chaos.  A little chaos now and then makes the most of wisest men.  Choose chaos, I dare you.', 'While I agree that these magnetic objects can pose a risk to children, I object to the government issuing a ban on these products.  Laws and government oversight should not become a substitute for parenting.', "The ban is unnecessary. Adults should be aware of what are in children's reach at all time, not only with these magnet sets but with anything that is small enough for a child to ingest. Placing a ban on these magnets would prevent the use of them as a fun, creative, and artistic medium.", 'to me there seems to be nothing wrong or harmful with the selling of magnets sets. As long as they were used under proper supervision, and knowledge that swallowing them should no happen. magnets sets allow for the mind to imagine new possibilities of ways to combine them into something fantastic. Nowadays kids need more imagination instead of all the technology floating around.', "Don't punish the company for the faillures of the parent", "Banning magnetic toys for safety reasons makes as much sense as banning steaks because babies can't eat them.  Let parents, not bureaucrats and the government, be responsible for their children's safety.", 'As a pediatric gastrointestinal doctor, and as someone on the front lines of seeing children, I know that kids swallowing things is an every day part of life. Imagine yourself a parent, and finding out that your "adult desk toy" could be the potential cause of life threatening damage to your child--where up to ONE THIRD of children who see these, and ingest them--and I\'m talking infants, older kids, even teenagers--can end up having emergent surgery because of potential bowel damage. This is an increasing occurrence, some may even say an EPIDEMIC, and is best prevented not by scolding parents, but by getting these objects off store shelves. Our nation\'s children have no voice in politics, and thus it is our responsibility to speak for them. I wholeheartedly support this ban!', 'I must express my opposition to the creation of new safety standards what would ban the sale of "collections of loose high powered magnets."   All of the evidence I have found point to this being an instance of the CPSC trying to solve a problem that America doesn\'t have. Companies making products such as ZenMagnets and Buckyballs have been vigilant in labeling their products as not being toys and include warnings notifying buyers not to give them to children.   There exist real, more pressing issues that pose actual threats to children, such as malnutrition and homelessness, both of which affect several orders of magnitude more children than the magnetic gadgets the CPSC is trying to ban the sale of.  I will be the first to support safety standards that make a material impact on the safety of children, but as it happens, this proposed rule is not one of them. Please reject this rule so that adults may be permitted to freely purchase these excellent products which, when used properly, are perfectly safe.', 'This ban is ridiculous.  Bucky Balls and the like are clearly labeled as a toy for adults only with choking/ingestion warnings all over the packaging.  A handful of parents who allowed these to get into the hands of children too young to understand not to eat them should not be a reason to ban a product.', 'This is a direct affront to adults everywhere. For starters, these magnet sets are products intended for and marketed to adults, this is made very clear on the web site. Because of this, the concern over children injuring themselves with these by doing stupid things like eating them is an entirely moot point. Children could also injure or kill themselves by ingesting bleach, their parents medications, and THOUSANDS of other more commonly available things but I dont see any effort to do away with those things. Why is that? Children are not supposed to have these so its not really the companys fault if they somehow acquire them and injure themselves or even die because of them. This possibility also should not ruin the product for the intended market. Not only that but in this time of a bad economy, is it really wise and in anyones best interest to go and take actions that shut down the small entrepreneurs legitimate business? The livelihood of some honest businessmen is at stake over this stupidity and I continue to be both mind boggled and outraged over this complete idiocy. Those proposing this ban should, at the very least, be sued by the small businesses that they are trying to ruin.', "Please do not enact this regulation. I use these magnets and find them to be highly educational for learning about regular geometric shapes. Don't waste my taxpayer money and don't destroy innovative companies.", "This is dumb and unfounded.  Magnets should never be banned.  Stop controlling other people's lives just over being politically correct.", 'Dear CPSC,  I am writing to oppose the proposed ban on magnet sets.    Please drop this effort.    While the goal of consumer protection is admirable, I strongly feel that it should be limited to warnings and education, and NOT banning of a viable product.  Consumers have a responsibility, as well as the government, in maintaining their safety, and should be entrusted with the ability to make choices in the marketplace.    Thank you for the opportunity for public comments.', "Parents shouldn't buy their children, knives, alcohol, or buckyballs.  But adults should not be prohibited from an innocent purchase due to the stupidity of the few.", 'These have never been marketed as toys for kids.  They keep us engineers entertained for hours on end.  One of my co-workers has created an entire chess set out of them!', "I believe that this the measures that would heavily regulate magnets is truly overkill. You cannot rationally ban these magnets, while leaving marbles as a legal toy.  They fall into the same type of danger, where a child could ingest them.  I understand that an infant could ingest these, but they could ingest a myriad of household items as well, and do just as serious damage.  It is a parent's responsibility to ensure their child's safety. They should be held responsible.", "If we ban bucky balls, then we've got a larger problem than just small magnets; the world is filled with dangerous items.  Oh, wait, that's why we put warning labels on everything.  So, for the love of a stress-relieving toy, please don't take away our bucky balls.", 'Responsible parenting is enough to keep us from losing a valuable product.', "Don't ban this item.", 'Magnets as toys are extremely harmful. As an Emergency Physician, I have had to remove magnets from toddlers. They are at risk for perforation of bowel and, in the case of my patient, nasal septum erosion.', "A broad ban for a consumer product that is dangerous if used improperly sets a dangerous precedent. Warning labels have been the tried and true safety measure for cases such as this, and there is not sufficient reason to deviate from them. The United States government has long respected an individual's right to determine the relative safety--or lack thereof--for any given product. Why challenge this decision for magnet sets, of all things?  There are countless products on the market that pose a danger when swallowed by children. Attempting to ban any of them is an effort in futility. Defining the line where something is appropriate to ban is too nebulous, and takes decision-making power from the consumer, especially if applied to a product that is harmless when used as directed. We aren't talking about radioactive waste for sale on the market, we're talking about magnets. The implication behind the ban is that the public is unable to properly use this product, and must be protected from themselves--a very poor message, and a poor basis for any decision.  Please halt this rulemaking. It has already been a massive waste of government hours and resources in getting this far. There is no significant public benefit to be had from banning something like this, and the precedent it would set is extremely troubling.", "Hello, This is completely ridiculous.  You may as well ban pencils because they are pointy or cleaning products because they are poisonous. I am sure that there are a lot more infant injuries/deaths because of house hold products than magnets. Furthermore, this is not a child's toy where the magnet can come loose and injure the child. This is a toy for teenagers or adults which should have the common sense to not swallow them.  This toy is no more dangerous than any other small toy that a child could potentially ingest. Yes it can cause a pinch if it is swallowed but other toys can be equally dangerous. The bottom line is that this toy is not meant to be used by children and parents have to be responsible enough to know this. Just like you cannot ban pools because kids drown in them and you cannot ban automobiles because negligent parents leave young children unsupervised in them.", "The CPSC should NOT ban magnet sets that carry appropriate warnings.  1. Magnets (such as those sold by Zen Magnets) have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard, than many other products on the market that are commonly found in homes.  It would be silly to ban everything in a modern home that presented a risk to people / children if used contrary to warnings or reasonable use.  Are we to ban kitchen knives; or weed killer; or steam irons; or nail scissors; or forks?  A child in Australia fell on a pencil and died when it went into into their mouth and penetrated their brain -- should we ban pencils because of a rare event like this, or should we say that parents should be more responsible?  The reasonable thing is to provide clear warnings and to have parents take responsiblity to ensure that adult things and children are kept apart.  The unreasonnable thing would be for governments to ban kitchen knives or weed killer or pencils -- or magnets.  Banning magnets would be a good example of a government intruding too far.  2. It is patently silly to assume that warnings don't work.  This would make a mockery of, and undrermine, past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress --
column8: 144, -- As a beef producer we work hard to raise the best meat in the world for our people to take home to there families.116, -- It will increase our risk of introducing FMD, destroy our cattle markets, and drive even more U.S. cattle producers out of business.19, -- We should be working harder at keeping American markets safe for current and future generations not relaxing rules.141, -- I feel that we would open our industry up to diseases and dangers that could drastlcly affect our ability to produce top quality product.127, -- What purpose is their in bringing in a product from a country that has a hard time regulating their own product?60, -- Prices will go back down gradually as the nations herd of safe, uninflected cattle rebuilds and keeps the gains right here in America.12, -- Thus Canada would not allow beef from the USA to be exported into Canada even if it was not treated with ionizing radiation.83, -- Finally the ranchers are able to make a living with the prices they are receiving now.95, -- The second reason is why take a chance of introducing Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) back into the US is just pain irresponsible.48, -- Lower beef prices will threaten an already low US herd.48, -- Defective food does not equal a low grade clothing designed to save consumers money!78, -- This is the most troubling section of the report for beef producers at all levels of the supply chain.145, -- Compare it to Apple using China's work force to make I pads.46, -- There are solutions that exist to save ourselves - pipe in water, bring down feed costs, etc.72, -- Issuance of the new rule should facilitate leading edge cooperation between MAPA, EMBRAPA, ANVISA, USDA, APHIS etc.95, -- So I wouldn't trust in Brazil letting us know about anything.145, -- It all starts here and the USDA is in a position where unfortunately they speak for these farmers and ranchers.72, -- Asian and European nations will acknowledge the rule and perhaps allow or facilitate more their markets for Brazilian beef exports.46, -- I respectfully ask you to please do the right thing and say No to this option.145, -- Go out tonight and buy an AMERICAN beef steak and support your AMERICAN beef producer!114, -- With the current regulation in place the United States has maintained low disease risks and negligible environmental effects.72, -- In today's world, having stronger relations with countries that share federalism, continental dimensions, pluralism, democracy and ethnic diversity is not such a bad thing.55, -- Considering the risks, the only rational response is not just to flatly reject the APHIS proposal.55, -- Congress should hold public hearings to determine who is responsible, and exactly how this dangerous proposal even saw the light of day.78, -- In conclusion, my hat is off to Brazil and the leaps and bounds they've made becoming a major factor in the international beef market.
column9: 137, -- Too much risk to import meat from a country with past history of Foot and Mouth Disease.13, -- Brazil has recently had outbreaks of FMD, and we have kept this disease out of this country since 1929.146, -- If this import regulation change is allowed, it will jeopardize our business, as well as almost all agriculture and supporting industries.114, -- Up to this point, sufficient research has not been conducted in regards to cost-benefit analysis.114, -- Although the APHIS considers the likelihood of exposure to FMD-infected species is low, the consequence assessment conducted shows severe potential impacts.27, -- The U.S. is home to numerous susceptible wildlife species.48, -- The importation of animals from areas known to have hoof and mouth disease is extremely scary to me.9, -- The last documented outbreak of FMD in the United States occurred in 1929.61, -- Does the USDA really want to be responsible for the killing of all wildlife in an area because of a fly.114, -- The United States should not be importing meat and animal products from countries that the APHIS does not consider free of FMD.114, -- From an economic standpoint, international trade generally does benefit both countries that engage in trade.12, -- Brazil has an international reputation where they do not abide and delivering meat and poultry product acceding to the sanitary regulations.12, -- The lymph nodes are where the aftosa virus is in high concentrations.9, -- We have great interest in working with USDA APHIS on the issues raised in our comments and to monitor implementation of any final rule.114, -- The APHIS suggests that the continuation of current regulations will result in no change in the potential impact on the human environment.72, -- To the contrary, this opening could unlock latent trade and investment opportunities that will bring Brazil and U.S. economies and countries closer together.78, -- Also the pork industry is currently facing its own epidemic in the PEDv virus that is killing millions of pigs.
column10: 89, -- I am opposed to importing meat from a country with endemic Foot and Mouth Disease.103, -- Importing meat from that area I believe will open the possibility of disease entering our country - especially foot and mouth disease.47, -- Financially and emotionally the impact of small farms and ranches, as well as large ones, having to slaughter ALL of their animals is incalculable.29, -- This disease not only affects cattle but all animals including wildlife.76, -- Additionally, there appear to be no safeguards to prevent contaminated and diseased Brazilian beef from entering the marketplace.61, -- Not only would all cattle need to be killed but also Mule deer, Whitetail deer,  Pronghorn Antelope, Buffalo, and Big Horn Sheep.8, -- We need economic incentives to increase our national herd.78, -- At the very minimum place a geographic "buffer zone" of disease free area around the region that we propose to accept animals from.81, -- Jim Washington 1901 160th Street Basehor, KS 66007 913-620-2001 Kansas State University  Security Studies Program jpwashington@sbcglobal.net95, -- These would concern me because that would be taking a chance that we would lose a lot of US cattle including my own.27, -- The last European outbreak was caused by imported pork that was thrown out of a restaurant.46, -- Classic example - remember the tainted pet food that killed tons of our animals from China.27, -- For obvious reasons, meat imported from Foot and Mouth Disease infected countries is not welcome in countries that have healthy livestock and wildlife.78, -- We are facing the lowest cattle numbers since the 1950's.78, -- An epic drought in the mid-west has forced the cow herd to decline.78, -- We are seeing markets and pastures come back into alignment to offer opportunity to begin to rebuild the U.S. cow herd.
column11: 60, -- Does our government even have the funds and personnel necessary to ensure this bill's safety?22, -- How they control the laboratories and test of diagnosis?34, -- The price of raw Brazilian Fetal Bovine Serum is $70 per liter.44, -- I have seen with my own eyes how the system is manipulated.22, -- There are any test to ensure presence of e-coli and mad cow disease?33, -- Thank you for listening to my opinion and hopefully this will NOT happen in the country.34, -- The biggest scientific breakthroughs in research are happening using Fetal Bovine Serum.34, -- In Europe, Brazilian FBS has been used in cell culture for the past 20 years.34, -- It is used as the primary product in cell culture research throughout Europe by 80% of the potential users.72, -- Bleeding heart and emotional comments may lack the perspective outlined above.
column12: 61, -- I am very concerned about Foot and Mouth and how easy it transfers.48, -- Many of our neighbors both within a 30 mile radius and as far away as 80 miles were effected by this infection.61, -- We live next to the Badlands National Park in South Dakota.27, -- The initial infection is usually survived and the animal suffers a long and often incomplete recovery.27, -- The U.S. has uncontrolled feral hogs in 38 states that are rapidly spreading to other states.

column2: ly misused and  abused and should be forever banned from ALL CIRCUSES.  The same is true for  zoos.  Ellies do NOT belong in zoos, unless a particular zoo makes an expensive,  long-term commitment to provide the elephants with many acres of natural habitat,  proper diet/nutrition and enrichment.  Elephants should NEVER be confined to  small spaces, locked in barn stalls, forced to remain on concrete, or abused by  brutal means such as chains, hooks, anal tasers, whips, or beatings.  If a zoo  cannot obey the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) and provide ellies with everything they  are supposed to provide under the AWA, including dignity and respect, then the  zoos should be forced to give up their elephants to proper, licensed and approved  elephant sanctuaries that can give the animal life-long, gentle care and humane  treatment.  NO EXCEPTIONS.  Elephants need their families, stop destroying  their family units for inhumane human amusements and the greed of the zoos and  circuses.', "I am writing to express my support for all efforts to drastically improve conditions  for captive elephants in this country. New strick standards must be set to prevent  the abuse, neglect, and lack of compassion for elephants. Please set new  standards to ensure that:  ? The use of bullhooks be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act must include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants.  ? Exhibitors of elephants be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  Zoos and circuses have gotten away with abusing elephants and providing the  cheapest housing for them long enough. If elephants are going to continue to be  kept in captivity there has to be strict regualtions to ensure that their health and  well being is the first priority.", 'Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants  with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.  Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in zoos and circuses they  suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that  eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot  disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying  and head bobbing.  Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the  zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended  periods during the cold winter months.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and  aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'Firstly, I dont think elephants should be kept in captivity. The closest thing to  being caged, is an elephant sanctuary. They should be able to walk on grass, not  concrete. They should have many acres to roam and forage just like they would if  they were free.      Elephants are used to warm climates, so they should NEVER be held captive  in cities where the temperature goes below 60. Since they are highly family  oriented, families should never be separated! So maybe they should stay in the  wild where these things can be met.      No bullhooks or chains should ever be used on them, they deserve respect, as  any animal does.', 'Please find attached the comments from the RSPCA.', 'Please change the rules so Elephants are guaranteed the humane treatment that  other animals have.. no chaining by the leg for life.. exercise.. safety.. health  care.. no electric prods etc. Thank you for listening.', 'Please improve enforcement of the Animal Welfare Act and strengthen its  regulations regarding care and treatment of elephants in captivity.', 'I support any and all efforts to dramatically improve the conditions of captive  elephants in the US.  New standards are needed for provide large, naturalistic  environments for these gentle giants.  These are social creatures who need to be  with other elephants in a healthy, non-concrete, non-abusive habitat.  Why in the  world man thought he should take this giant creature out of the wild and break it\'s  spirit by beating/shocking it into submission is beyond me.  Do you honestly  wonder why some circus elephants "freak out" and trample their trainers?  These  are intelligent animals who are forced to endure the mundane activites we as  humans put them through, not to mention the abuse endured while "training" them  to do stupid tricks.  Just let them be animals for crying out loud!  At the very least, zoos and circuses need to abide by the Animal Welfare Act and  treat these amazing animals with the respect they deserve.
