After all, they\'ve put  up with our inane demands long enough.  They never asked to be chained to a  concrete cage or asked to perform under a big tent.  If they could answer you, do  you think they\'d say yes?', 'I am writing to support all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country. It is abhorrent that the Animal Welfare Act does not have any standards or  regulations that address the special needs of elephants. Please, I urge you,  create new standards that are tough and enforce them. Some suggestions are to  1) Prohibit the use of bullhooks. These barbaric devices serve only one purpose  which is to inflict fear and pain. The federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and any instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. 2) Exhibitors of elephants should be  required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble  elephants\' natural habitat- similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and the Performance Welfare Society in California. These two refuges  provide thousands of acres where elephants live, socialize and maintain their  health.  Also, elephants are highly social animals and mothers and babies  normally spend years together.  However, in circuses elephants are seperated and  kept alone in small and unappealing "shelters" unable to be famalies or social.   Please consider enacting standards and regulations that will put a permanent stop  to these cruel and inhumane atrocities that are a frightening and unapologetic  reality for these wonderful animals.  Check out PETA or circuses.com for more  horrifying information.  Thank you for your time and resources spent on potentially  stopping these horrifying conditions.', 'The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.   Please give these animals the treatment they deserve.', 'I support all efforts to improve the conditions for captive elephants!   I feel that new standards desperately need to be enforced.   Elephants need adequate space to roam and socialize. I remember going to a Four Bears waterpark as a teenager and seeing an elephant chained in the middle of the park swaying back and forth unable to move around at all. I was disgusted. Unfortunately, years later,  this type of unfortunate living condition is still being allowed to happen to elephants. Why???    I also feel that bullhooks and other similar and abusive instruments should be prohibited.   Please help elephants in captivity lead the most comfortable and stress free life possible. Many of these animals have been torn away from their natural habitat and their mothers to begin with, only to endure years of suffering and torture. It needs to stop.', "Elephants are the world's largest land mammals, and they require significant  amounts of space. In fact, in the wild, they can walk up to 30 miles a day. The  leading causes of death in captive elephants are foot disorders and arthritis, which  are caused by prolonged chaining, intense confinement, and forced inactivity.  Since 2000, more than half of the 49 elephants who have died at zoos accredited  by the Aquarium & Zoo Association never reached their 40th birthdays, dying far  short of their 70-year life expectancies.  Because of their intelligence, complexity, sensitivities, and unique social and  physical needs, elephants suffer immensely in small, unchallenging captive  environments. To make matters worse for elephants, in circuses, every instinctual  behavior is subject to discipline. If elephants reach for grass, try to comfort friends,  or extend their trunks to smell something new or different, they get hit with  bullhooks. If they blow a trick during a performance, they get beaten afterward.  Despite the fact that elephants fare miserably in captivity, zoos and circuses are  supportvociferously defending the status quo.  I am expressing my desire for all efforts to drastically improve conditions for  captive elephants in this country.  Tthe USDA MUST create tough new  standards, such as the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", "I am outraged that the St. Louis Zoo continues to ignore the suffering of Clara, an  elephant who is so physically deteriorated from 50 years of being confined to the  Zoo's tiny yards and concrete barn stalls that she is slowly and painfully wasting  away before our eyes.  At 53 years old, Clara is not (as the St. Louis Zoo claims) elderly for an Asian  elephant, a species that has a natural lifespan of 70 years, and her severely  debilitated condition is not a natural result of the aging process. Her painful  arthritis, chronic foot abscesses and sole erosions are a direct result of the  cramped and unnatural zoo environment. It is disingenuous, dishonest and hurtful  to elephants for the St. Louis Zoo to insist that Clara's health condition is a result  of her age.   Even five years ago, Clara could have healed from her captivity-induced ailments  had she been transferred to a sanctuary with the space and natural habitat  necessary for her feet to mend. Instead, the St. Louis Zoo chose to keep her in  the very environment that caused these problems the first place. It is almost  certainly too late to save her now.   A new baby, Ellie, has just been born at the St. Louis Zoo and faces the same  fate unless drastic changes are made. If the St. Louis Zoo cannot provide the  space and conditions elephants need to thrive, then it must send these elephants  someplace that can. I urge you to transfer Ellie, her family and all the elephants at  St. Louis Zoo to a sanctuary with the space and natural habitat elephants need to  be healthy.", "I'm writing to ask that you take action to remedy the plight of elephants in zoos  and circuses. I also want to encourage full enforcement of the Animal Welfare  Act?s adequate space provision at zoos and circuses.  Please do whatever is within your power to address vital humane issues regarding  elephant care, including lack of space, unnatural substrates, unnatural social  groupings, and the use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots, and other  instruments of force commonly used to control elephant  Thank you for your help in seeing to the ongoing needs of these magnificent,  intelligent animals.", 'I am writing on behalf of elephants in zoos and circuses. I strongly encourage the  enforcement of the federal Animal Welfare Act at zoos and circuses. It saddens  me that elephants provide laughter and entertainment to the young and old at  such a great price to them. Hence, the poor treatment and living conditions they  endure. Elephants deserve healthy environments, improved conditions and  gracious treatment.  All who are directly and indirectly involved with elephants  need to insist on the enforcement of AWA.', 'I am very concerned about poor living conditions for captive elephants in zoos and circuses.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', "I support efforts to improve conditions for elephants in this country.  The USDA  should create tough humane standards, including the following:  Prohibiting the use of bullhooks.  Providing appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats.", 'It would disgust me to think that you could view any of the horrible things these  elephants have gone through and not work to change this. They are living beings,  as we are, they simply have another way of communicating. Treat them kindly, as you must.', "The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space.  This is not happening.  Elephants need a lot of space to roam.   Roaming about in the open space with their herd families is crucial to their well  being and development.  Many times elephants are confined in barns and do not  get the exercise or social interraction with other elephants that they need.  Zoos  and circus' should be required to provide enough space for their elephants or the  elephants should be sent to a sanctuary without delay and tons of red tape.  We need our children to know that as a society we take care of all animals.   Elephants are majestic and social creatures who deserve the best care we can  give them or we should leave them in the wild.", "The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space for their health and well being. Neither zoos nor circuses currently  meet this requirement.  Elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and  social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? such  as  painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and  neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all  captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the  leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. In Los Angeles, we recently lost  an elephant who suffered for years from foot disease. Circus elephants often suffer prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day  standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars,  where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to  stand for hours in their own waste. This is not healthy by any stretch of the  imagination.  Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and  to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are cruel and unnecessary.   They must be outlawed. If the only way to contain an animal is with cruelty then  you shouldn't have them in the first place. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.  Elephants should not be in captivity under  any other circumstances.", "We are not in the late 1800's where mankind gets away with forensic mishaps and there are no  guidelines in taking care of abused people -- We are 2006 and still have inhumane ways of taking animals and abusing them for man's  entertainment. We should be civilized. In Japan they slaughter dolphins - in China they drain Bears  in torturing methods for their belief of medicine -- USA  should not be allowed to act ignorantly by  turning their heads away from how we take care of animals in captivity.  The circus tortures animals for entertainment. Zoos should be educational not prisons for animals. Animal testing for makeup ---- Is it OK to torment lives so that human kind can exist.  Unecessary torment in this day and age is unacceptable. Please help mankind become civilized.", "I am in agreement of APHIS-2006-0044. The animal welfare act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequete space. Zoo's and circuses are not meeting these requirments. Exhibotors of elephants must be required to provide large,naturalistic envorinments  similiar to those at  The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS  sanctuary in Northern California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam,socialize and maintain their health. The use of bull hooks,chains,electric shock devices and other instrumtnets of  force must be outlawed. I am extrememly concerned for the plight of these magnificant creatures. Their fate  is in our hands. They aren't your usual animal,due to size and special attributes. Do the right thing and support this act in favor of the elephant.", 'Please see the attached Word document for my concerns regarding the welfare of  elephants in the zoos of the United States.  Thank you.', 'I do not believe that zoos intentionally harm animals.  I believe the handlers of  elephants and other animals do care about the health and well being of their  charges.  However,  over the years, as we have gained more knowledge of animals  and their native habitats and their requirements for good health, it is irresponsible  not to change these conditions for the better.  Monetary gain is not justification to  confine animals for public viewing, or to transport them in circuses for public  enjoyment.  And, it does come down to business and profit at the expense of the  animals\' health.  It is no different than people who run puppy mills, or who sell  baby ducks right before Easter.  Animals are not in the world for our monetary  gain and enjoyment.  And if we do not represent their best interests, who will?     We live in the country and people drop animals, mostly dogs and cats, in front of  our house when they are tired of caring for them.  Last year a young Dalmatian  was dropped off.  What a beautiful dog, about a year old.  It was almost a year to  the day after the release of the second Dalmaitian movie. The dog was sold as a  puppy right after that movie release.    USDA is beset by many special interest groups with personal gain as a bottom  line.  You have the ability and the responsibility to represent those who can\'t  speak for themselves -- the animals.      If you wish to read about a shameful process in our and your history go to the  web site for the Elephant Sanctuary, elephants.com and read the log entries  about the sanctuary\'s efforts to rescue circus elephants from a corporation in  Illinois.  These elephants are "rented" out for public viewing so kids can go the the  circus. On the same web site read about the response of the elephants to being in  a natural habitat, one in which public viewing is forbidden.  Yes, they suffered the  death of a handler, and your writers make it sound like the only way to prevent it  is to chain them up and cage them.  What a shallow, uneducated view of animal  behavior.  Again, read about the analysis of this incident on the Sanctuary web  site.    Our country and our government agencies will be judged by how we treat those  least able to act for themselves.  I hope sincerely that you can look beyond the  special interests and the money and do what is right, not just for elephants but for  all captive animals.  Circuses should be closed down.  Now.  Zoos need strict  habitat regulations.  The information is out there.  It is time to stand up and act  responsibly.  Thank you.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal  Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new  standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres  over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force against elephants.   As a child, I remember being horrified to see how elephants (and other animals) were  treated at the circus and at zoos.  The time has come to change the way we treat  captive elephants.  These intelligent and compassionate animals deserve better.', "The use of bull hooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants.  Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'I support any regulation that supports and impements the welfare of all elephants in all types of confinements.  I also believe that they should not be allowed to be involved in circuses any more in our society.  It is unbelievely cruel situation and should be stopped.', "I have always been appalled and dismayed at the amount of space large animals  such as elephants are expected to live in at zoos.  Circus elephants have it even  worse, as they are usually chained all the time.  After recently being able to view  the facilites at the Elephant Sanctuay in Tennessee, I can attest to the difference  more space makes in the health and welfare of these animals.  The space alloted  should be somewhat consistent with the size of the animal.  I can tell you that my  horses, all of whom were rescued from bad situations have also recovered and  thrived on our property.  Not just from the fact that we actually feed them, but also  because they have 20 acres to roam around on.  The wild ones will even choose  to approach me now, since they feel safe and secure...and their anxiety level has  dropped.  I believe elephants are about the same.  Elephants in the wild travel  miles and miles every day.  To keep a social and active animal like this confined  to (often) a small hard paddock area is inhumane at the least, and immoral due to  fact that when we take on the care of any animal, we are morally obligated to  provide a reasonable alternative to what their life in the wild might have been.  To  top this off, zoos to have now changed the rules by stating that elephants only live  about 40 years, instead of 70, which is an elephant's actual possible lifespan,  without stating the truth-that this happens because of the way the elephants are  handled and forced to live while in captivity!  Thank you,  Karen Roberts", 'Elephants do not belong in zoos or used to perform in a circus. These beautiful  creatures need to be allowed to roam freely in Sanctuaries where they are well fed  and receive medical attention. To think of these beautiful creatures chained,not  being able to roam is inhumane.', "I am  writing to urge greater enforcement of  the Animal Welfare act's adequate  space provision at zoos and circuses. I believe we have plenty of information and  testimony from the leading experts that shows that elephants require much more  space than is currently afforded them. Also, i would like to see the issue of  domination over these magnificent creatures addressed. The use of bullhooks,  chains, electric shock devices and other such instruments  must be outlawed. I  fully support any actions required to improve conditions for captive elephants in  our care today. thank you.", 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.   Why Change is Needed  The reasons why the USDA must take action include:   1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when  the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for  extended periods during the cold winter months.   5. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These  methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to  elephants.   6. Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs,  elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these  unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.', "Elephants are the world's largest land mammals, and they require significant  amounts of space. In fact, in the wild, they can walk up to 30 miles a day. The  leading causes of death in captive elephants are foot disorders and arthritis, which  are caused by prolonged chaining, intense confinement, and forced inactivity.  Since 2000, more than half of the 49 elephants who have died at zoos accredited  by the Aquarium & Zoo Association never reached their 40th birthdays, dying far  short of their 70-year life expectancies.  They are very sensitve and intelligent animals and elephants suffer immensely in  small, unchallenging captive environments. To make matters worse for elephants,  in circuses, every instinctual behavior is subject to discipline. If elephants reach  for grass, try to comfort friends, or extend their trunks to smell something new or  different, they get hit with bullhooks. If they blow a trick during a performance,  they get beaten afterward.  Please support for all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants  in this country. We ask the USDA to create tough new standards, and mention  the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  Thank  you for your time", "I support all portions of IDA's (In Defense of Animals) Elephant Petition", 'We are in the 21st century.  There is adequate acreage, money and volunteerism  in this nation to care for these tired, sick and intelligent elephants.  Our  youngsters need no "education" on the elephant species.  They do need  education on mankind\'s wisdom and compassion for another intelligent species.   They need to have a sense that humans can actually be proper caretakers for the  planet.  Please release these elephants to proper sanctuaries that can care for  them.  Please innact the required legislation that enables these noble creatures to  live in proper conditions for their mental and physical health.  Thank you very  much for doing the right thing.', 'I am writing today to support the humane care for captive elephants in circuses  and zoos. These beautiful and unique mammals must be treated appropriately for  them to stay healthy. Elephants that are in situations where they are chained for  long hours or kept in limit
column3: nt time swimming with dolphins. The demeanor of the animals are amazing, and their interactions with us humans have helped me to respect them, cherish them, and love them. This would not at all be possible without such wonderful staff and facilities that enable me to learn and spread my learning with others.  It is clear to me that the dolphins, sea lions, and seals enjoy the sessions as much as the people.  They appear to choose to participate and are never forced.  As a visitor, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  I'd like to thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and that you did not feel compelled to unnecessarily change regulations.  Thank you!", 'Sea world and Bush Gardens do all they can to care for and release rescues animals back into the wild.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please keep our zoos and animal care facilities open', 'I have interacted with animals all my life and I want other people to be able to do the same.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please consider this letter and think of the loss of education when animal/mammal interactions can not take place.  It is not the same as a book.', 'I am a volunteer at Miller Park Zoo in Bloomington,  Illinois and work with members of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association.    IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I am a Senior Animal Trainer at the San Diego Zoo and have been a professional animal trainer for 10 years. I hold memberships in the following professional organizations: Association of Zoos and Aquariums, Animal Behavior Managment Alliance.  Interactive programs are designed with human and animal safety in mind. There is no scientific evidence that more regulation is needed. Zoos and aquariums that are members of the AZA and/or IMATA have exemplary safety records and additional regulation will not benefit the animals.  Placing limits on the amount of interaction that an animal receives per day ignores the inherent differences between animals, which are best judged by their keepers and trainers who work with them every day and know each individual best. Interaction is accepted to be enriching to animals\' lives throughout the animal training community. It is offered to each animal through its own choice, one of the pillars of animal welfare. No animal is forced to interact when it does not want to. However, many animals choose to participate in interactions, and making laws to prevent them from doing so would be deleterious to their welfare. Our training and enrichment programs are exemplary, leave the judgement of administering them to people who know what they\'re doing.  If you regulate that there must be one trainer to each animal, most of the animals will be denied the opportunity to participate in their training/interactive session, because it is too difficult to obtain enough qualified staff for that. Animal trainers with appropriate experience can easily work with more than one appropriately trained animal at a time. Again, this should be left to the judgement of those administering their programs. They know what they can and can\'t do, and I wish to emphasize that human and animal safety is a top priority for everyone involved.  As a trainer, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.  Thank you, APHIS, for your concern. I am sure you will hear from a lot of people who think that we are treating animals wrong. This could not be further from the truth. We are absolutely dedicated to their welfare, and these additional regulations will not benefit the animals. They are merely meant to mollify those who are uneducated about the exemplary care we provide, including the extremely important facet of enriching animals through training sessions and interactive programs. They ignore the peer-revied, scientific evidence available, and should not be enacted without such evidence supporting them.', 'I have read the text of the above mentioned document and am proud to see my government working to ensure a safe, healthy, and extremely satisfactory environment for marine mammals.  I have had limited opportunities to visit aquariums around our country, but, have spent many days at SeaWorld.  I have witnessed SeaWorld employees insuring the safety of the animals and the public during interactive experiences and think their facilities are top-notch. I applaud you for making sure that all facilities adhere to strict guidelines in the care of the very special creatures.    There are obviously many who think that all creatures should be in their natural, wild environments and would like to see every zoo, aquarium and circus put out of business.  I disagree with them.  I believe that through education and interaction we are given the unique opportunity to learn about the creatures with whom we share the planet and thus develop knowledge in how human actions often interfere with the balance of nature.  My nieces, who are now 3 and 5 years-old, are keenly aware of how pollution and litter affect animals.   I realized this when I took them to a Florida beach and they were very concerned about making sure the beach was clean for "their dolphins" and also their concern about the litter they see along the roadways.  Just this week they were greeted by a 9 foot black snake in their playhouse.  There was no fear.  They were intrigued by the encounter and participated in the snake\'s relocation.  Their interest in nature has been stimulated by adventures to places like SeaWorld, Gatorland, zoos in Pittsburgh and Tampa, and Living Treasures in Moraine.  It is important that we preserve these positive experiences.    Having said that, I also realize that regulations are imperative in order to assure that all businesses operate in the best interest of creatures who have no voice.  I appreciate your work in continuing to develop good regulatory policy and trust that APHIS will always consider scientific evidence over emotional rhetoric.', "In the late 1960's when I watched Sea World being in built in San Diego I was excited at what it proposed for the future.  Not only would there be wholesome family entertainment but education of how better to care for the sea and its inhabitants was one step closer to reality.  Sea World has never disappointed in either.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Sincerely yours, Very Rev. Msgr. Dennis L. Mikulanis Life-long San Diegan", 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Dolphins and whales have been shown by recent scientific research to be sensitive with likely more ranges of emotions than humans, with culture that is handed down through generations, and personal names.  They deserve our respect and the right to remain in the wild, free from harassment and harm.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'Zoos and aquariums provide a service of education to people of this great nation that a person can not get any where else. To change regulations based on a minority who fail to understand the importance of education that these agencies  provide is a travesty for the education system outside normal schools. Please let zoos and aquariums continue to provide these invaluable experiences to children and adults of our great nation.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'Sea World is extremely important to the education of marine life as well as the preservation of the life within it. I am a true supporter of Sea World, and the cause they embody, and would be extremely upset to see them close their doors for the main reason of care and conservation. Please hear my voice as it pleads for their approval.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for your time in reading my letter. I hope that in the end the vote finds the right voice, and not just the hidden agendas plan.', 'First time I saw a whale, live in person I cried. The emotions brought up in me were so strong. Made me think twice about what items I was throwing in my trash container. Because I learned that plastic bags have a big impact in the oceans. Seaworld cares and educates  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "Thank you greatly for providing the opportunity for comments and for taking the suggestions of the experts in this field into consideration. In this case, the experts are those that dedicate their lives to the animals in their care at marine mammal facilities, zoos, and aquariums. As an employee of one such facility, Gulfarium Marine Adventure Park, and past employee of Dolphin Quest, Marineland, and Long Marine Lab, my exposure to the care and training of marine mammals has been vast and I can personally attest to the commitment level of staff at accredited facilities to going above and beyond to provide the very best environment, enrichment, medical care, and training for the animals in their care. The organizations that can best speak on behalf of the expert animal care personnel are the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums (AMMPA) and the International Marine Animal Trainers' Association (IMATA). Their suggestions are based in science and experience and should be considered above all else.", 'I am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations keep the marine mammals best interest in mind at SeaWorld parks, and accredited facilities around the country.   In keeping their best interest at heart, please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who only stand to profit from keeping orcas and dolphins in captivity. I ask that you also stop these facilities from breeding dolphins in the future. Dolphins are not endangered,  therefore there is no need except greed to continue breeding them in captivity. Please consider forcing these facilities to revamp their business model and move their dolphins and whales to sea pens.   I thank you for your time and hope you do the right thing, based on the best interest of these animals.  Sincerely,  Dawn Younce', "I believe marine parks and aquariums educate our public about better protecting the wildlife and their environments. Without these facilities people will loose the chance to see the beauty and intelligence of these animals, which might increase the desire to seek them out in the wild which is invasive and dangerous for both humans and animals if not participated in a professional way. By listening to public opinion as well as skewed media and not actual scientific facts, we will loose the only real, true direct link we have to marine life.   These facilities care deeply for their animals and their passion is enriching to the animal's life as well as educating the public about the animals intelligence and habitat and how we can help take care of them in the wild. I saw this first hand at many facilities all around the country. The Georgia Aquarium and Sea World in Orlando are both facilities that I am greatly impressed with the information that is presented as well as the cleanliness and professionalism of their facilities. Closer to home, Dolphin Quest has always been a great resource for tourist and local people combined. Being open to the public to observe the dolphins as well as ask any questions from one of the employees is something that is rare among marine life facilities. I have always enjoyed every encounter I have had at Dolphin Quest and the staff's level of expertise and devotion to their animals really shines through. It's obvious that their animals are well taken care of and find their training reinforcing. I stand by these facilities because of their dedication to not only their animals but their support and outreach to the ocean and wildlife in general.", 'Dear Sir or Madam, I have been a Member of the Dolphin Research Center, Grassy Key, Florida USA for more than eleven years now.  I would like to thank APHIS first of all, for making sure that all the Mamal parks in the USA provide more than outstanding care and treatment of their animals.  I absolutely love going to the DRC and have no reservations about the welfare or treatment of their dolphins, sea lions or other creatures whatsoever.  The kindness of the staff, right down to the ladies that work in the Gift Shop, is more than just "doing their job" its a vocation for all of them.  I love swimming in the water with the dolphins, i do not think the water is murky or dirty, it is about as natural as can be.  I am not a very good swimmer, and i tell this to the trainer right from the start, i have the confidence to swim out and let the dolphin swim beside me and let me take hold of it\'s dorsal fin, sometimes two dolphins swim with me, sometimes they don\'t want to, which is ok, as they have their own little "dolphinalities" and will do exactly what they want to, which is fine by me! I understand that the welfare of these beautiful animals must be the priority here, but i really believe that the DRC has done and is doing the very best for them.  I am an ordinary working class person here in the UK, and it takes me some time to save up money and come over to the Florida Keys and swim with the dolphins.  I really love this Center and believe that it is a brilliant place for people to come and train to be Marine Biologists, or whatever the correct terminoligy is.  I have always been swimming with one trainer and two dolphins, but there may be other staff with them, they always seem to be extremely competent, and the dolphins seem to absolutely love what they are doing.  Swimming with the dolphins at DRC has been an absolute delight, and i hope that i can do this for as long as i can.  It is a wonderful place to visit, and has had a definate impact on my well-being.', "I and all the children I have taken to SeaWorld have been so very much educated and inspired by help marine facilities such as SeaWorld can give our area animals in our region who need rescue and the animals they care for. We know so much more now because of SeaWorld then we knew before going to SeaWorld and participating in their education programs.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Myself, my family and all the children of neighbors we've taken to the park support SeaWorld.", "Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services should adhere to a scientifically rigorous approach to inspecting Zoos and Aquariums for animal welfare. In the absence of such an approach emotion may lead to irrational decision making which can degrade the benefits our society receives from our Zoos and Aquariums. These benefits are numerous but the primary is education. Zoos and aquariums are a primary place for children to learn about their environment including mammals. It is difficult to care for something when you don't know what it is or perhaps even knows it exists , speaking about certain species. Adherence to scientifically rigorous inspections of our zoos and aquariums  will support continued education of our population on our beautiful planet.", 'I testify, without and hesitation, that the marine mammal facilities I have visited are absolutely the best. I have seen nothing but excellent care to and for the animals in their care. The human staff that works with and cares for the marine mammals in the facilities I have been to go above and beyond what is expected of them every day of the week.  The finest food, the cleanest food prep areas, safety for the animals, caretakers and visitors -- these are all a priority for the marine mammal facilities I have been to. Furthermore, the facilities like them, of which I intend to visit soon, offer the same level of care.   Dolphins Plus in Key Largo, Florida is one such place of excellence. I have had the privilege and
column4: n. Financially and emotionally the impact of small farms and ranches, as well as large ones, having to slaughter ALL of their animals is incalculable. Why even entertain such a possibility? We are fortunate currently to not have this particular challenge. The motivations for changing this law have nothing to do with science or protecting the middle class of this country. As usual, when you want to know why a law is changing you simply need to follow the money.  Please do not change this ruling.', "As a cow/calf producer I closely monitor the health of my cows . In 2005, we had an outbreak of anthrax that reduced our herd by 1/3. Many of our neighbors both within a 30 mile radius and as far away as 80 miles were effected by this infection. The disease traveled quickly and even though we immediately vaccinated our herd when we were informed that the infection was in the area, we buried animals for 6 weeks. Our state veterinarian's  office was on top of the epidemic and quarantined herds immediately. It still did not stop the spread of the disease.   The importation of animals from areas known to have hoof and mouth disease is extremely scary to me. We need to have secure food sources for our citizens and to do this we need to preserve the health of the United States herd. Being free of the threat of Hoof and Mouth disease since the 1920s it makes no sense to introduce that threat again. Lower beef prices will threaten an already low US herd. Defective food does not equal a low grade clothing designed to save consumers money!", 'I am writing in opposition to the proposal to allow the import of fresh beef from high risk areas of Brazil. Everything I have read on the subject concludes that the foot and mouth disease is prevalent in the area and the borders are not secure enough to insure the safety of our food supply.  The introduction of foot and mouth disease to the US would be catastrophic not only to the beef industry, but to the hotel and restaurant industries as well.  Common sense should tell you what that the collapse of the hotel and restaurant industries and in turn the tourism trade would send our entire economy into a tailspin.  Please do your job, protect domestic beef producers and American consumers by rejecting the ill advised idea of importing beef from such a high risk area.  Thank you for considering my comments.', "Please do not allow the importation of fresh or chilled beef from any states of Brazil. Given the fact that FMD (Foot and Mouth disease) is still endemic in that part of the world there is no way to ensure that FMD virus won't make it into the USA eventually in raw beef products from Brazil. And given the morbidity rate of the disease, currently accepted stamping out practices, and what would happen to the export market for USA beef and other meats in the event of an outbreak of FMD in the USA, the risks are just too high.", "This is detrimental to our producers. It should not be allowed. There is too much risk involved, also, we don't need the meat. Producers in this country have already suffered losses in their herds due to drought and blizzards. I t will take years to build up herds. I don't understand why the USDA is not protecting them instead of subjecting them to more harm.", 'Please do not allow importation of any meat from other countries, specifically Brazil.  Given the focus of the food safety act and its importance it would seem to me we are taking a back step if we allow this to happen.  Besides the sellers of this meat will still sell to the United States population at the same price as beef is sold here now.  In short it will not drop the costt of meat to the consumers of this country.  We need to keep our farmers and ranchers of our own country strong.', "I am a young farmer trying to raise a family on a small beef cow and calf operation. I with many others take great pride in what I do for a living and try to make the best and safest product available for the American people to enjoy. Allowing Brazil imports of fresh meat would be devistating to the American cattle farmer in so many ways. It would cause a loss of consumer confidence,  and loss profits for our hard working farmers. As I have all ready stated Iam 35 years old, 2 kids and a wife who depend on beef cattle to survive so I ask that you please think this threw and stop this before it destroys the us herd. We have the greatest reputation in the world and we want to keep it.  One case of foot and mouth disease in the us and not only mine but thousands of people just like me are ultimately destroyed and the blood will be on your hands ..so please don't let this happen ..thank you.", 'I oppose importing beef from a hoof and mouth area. We have the safest food supply in the world and we should keep it that way. All imported food should have the source and processing countries clearly labeled', 'I very strongly oppose the APHIS proposal to allow the importation of beef from 14 states of Brazil due to the presence of Foot-and Mouth Disease (FMD) throughout the country and neighboring regions of South America. I believe that beef imports should not be allowed from Brazil or any other country infected with FMD, period.  An outbreak of FMD is perhaps the most serious threat facing animal agriculture production in the United States. I say this as someone who has spent most of his lifetime in the beef and dairy industries. Given the seriousness of the FMD threat posed by Brazilian beef imports, an informed observer might reasonably expect such a dangerous scheme to have been hatched by a terrorist group like al Qaeda, rather than APHIS, the lead U.S. Government agency charged with protecting the health of Americas livestock.  The APHIS risk analysis report reveals that of the proposed Brazilian beef imports would pose significant risks to the United States, including: \tIntroduction of the FMD virus to the U.S. through infected meat; \tMassive economic costs of an FMD outbreak to U.S. livestock producers and consumers; and  \tQuarantines resulting in the loss of U.S. meat exports.  The APHIS proposal relies on regionalization, the failed concept underlying this failed proposal. Bill Bullard, CEO of R-CALF USA, a grassroots livestock producer group, correctly noted the problems with past regionalization attempts in a recent article published by The Milkweed, a dairy industry publication. See Bullards comment at http://www.themilkweed.com/The%20Milkweed%20Bullard%20Interview%20Mar%202014.pdf  The APHIS risk analysis report estimates potential economic costs in the range of $37 billion to $42 billion if an FMD outbreak were to occur in the U.S. Yet this estimate, costly as it is, may be too conservative. Maureen McCarthy, a Department of Homeland Security weapons adviser, in 2006 estimated an FMD outbreak would cost the U.S. agricultural economy hundreds of billions of dollars and close U.S. meat export markets for years. (See http://www.hlswatch.com/index.php?s=foot-and-mouth) Livestock prices have since increased in the following eight years, making Ms. McCarthys real cost estimate even higher.  Under either cost estimate scenario, rural communities in major livestock states would be devastated by the direct economic costs of an FMD outbreak and the resulting loss of meat export markets. Many rural areas have already lost population over recent decades due to lack of economic opportunities. An FMD outbreak in the U.S. would escalate this trend.  Were an FMD outbreak to occur in the U.S., federal and state government treasuries would be further stressed by the massive costs of cleanup and compensation, and the loss of tax revenues from livestock production. Massive tax increases would be necessary to offset the mounting costs of an FMD outbreak in the U.S., a thought that should discourage any conservative ideologues who might support Brazilian beef imports in the name of free trade.  American food security would be undermined at a time when U.S. cattle inventories are at a 60-year low and beef prices have reached record-high levels. Domestic production of beef, pork, sheep and other meat, along with dairy products, could be sharply curtailed. The resulting loss of animal protein production  and rising retail food prices  would cause further hardship for millions of American consumers whose food budgets are under pressure in todays sluggish economic recovery.  It appears that APHISs only concern is too facilitate global free trade by removing this vital sanitary barrier to trade, regardless of the potential costs of American livestock producers and consumers. I served as a member of the USDA/USTR Agricultural Policy Advisory Committee for Trade during the WTO Seattle Round negotiations, and have had extensive contacts with my foreign agricultural counterparts and government officials representing our major trading partners. I am aware of the issues, interests, and risks involved, and believe most U.S. citizens would strongly oppose the APHIS proposal if they were aware of its risks.  Considering the risks, the only rational response is not just to flatly reject the APHIS proposal. Congress should hold public hearings to determine who is responsible, and exactly how this dangerous proposal even saw the light of day. The responsible officials should immediately be shown the door, and the agency (and perhaps the entire department) should be massively reformed and reconfigured to carry out its basic mission: To protect the health and value of American agriculture and natural resources.', "This is ridiculous to even propose such an outlandish thing! Why would you try to destroy America's safe and affordable beef supply? This is a risk to consumers AND producers. If this passes it will put Americans out of the ranching business and consumers will be at risk for disease. Do NOT import beef from Brazil, unless you want food to be contaminated and a whole Agriculture sector put out of business. We can not be expected to follow all the rules that America imposes on us for healthy meat and then compete with beef from Brazil where not even a tenth of the care is taken of the animals and their health. We have a meat supply here......it is SAFE and AFFORDABLE!", "I am a cattle producer in Northeast Wyoming.  I have several concerns about importing beef from any place in Brazil.  First, and most important is the risk of introducing Foot and Mouth Disease.  The USDA might consider the risk to be minimal from certain areas but we know nothing about how cattle move in and around Brazil or how easily FMD could get back into one of these eligible states and thereby find its way to the USA.  Even if the risk is minimal, what would we gain that would be worth putting this nation's livestock industry in jeopardy?  Secondly, the cattle producers in the USA are more than capable of supplying the safest, best quality beef for the needs of this country.  Does Brazil have a safety inspection system in place that compares to ours?  Are their pesticides, herbicides, antibiotics, feed additives , etc. regulated at the same level as ours?  Are their slaughter facilities clean, humane, and able to pass EPA regulations?  Is their cost of production even close to ours?  Can their government be trusted to do what they say?  If the answer to these questions is no, then we would be importing an inferior product, possibly with disease or residues, through an inferior inspection process, with few if any trace-back regulations.  This product would enter the best, safest market in the world at a reduced cost and my product would have to compete with it.  Is my own government trying to put me out of business?", 'To who, it may Concern:      I find this very troubling and hope and pray that this is put to a complete stop.  Not only would this be an irresponsible move it is dangerous to consumers in the United States.    I urge you to do whatever it takes to STOP this regulation from happening.  Kristie Von Behren', 'I am strongly opposed to allowing beef from Brazil into our country.  The dollar has taken precedence over our common sense as well as our pride in our own products.  We should support ourselves.  That is part of American independence.', "The passing of this bill is too dangerous for a developed nation like ourselves to consider. Does our government even have the funds and personnel necessary to ensure this bill's safety? Moreover, we constantly face problems of jobs moving to places like Mexico, and India, and China, and here is our government basically doing it themselves. It was estimated that this bill would cost our cattle industry 165 million dollars and drop cattle prices over night. I realize the price of beef is a little high right now but give the nation time to recover from a severe drought and rebuild the herds. Prices will go back down gradually as the nations herd of safe, uninflected cattle rebuilds and keeps the gains right here in America. How are we supposed to recover if the market is saturated with foreign, foot and mouth diseased, unregulated beef that's not labeld as such? Passing this is not in the best interest of any American citizen and would make no sense to do so.", 'I am writing about the importation of beef from Brazil.  I am very concerned about Foot and Mouth and how easy it transfers.  All it takes is one fly,  one fly to infect the beef before processing,  one fly to transfer the virus.        We live next to the Badlands National Park in South Dakota.  Do you have any idea how devastating an outbreak of Foot and Mouth would be to this area.  Not only would all cattle need to be killed but also Mule deer, Whitetail deer,  Pronghorn Antelope, Buffalo, and Big Horn Sheep.  If beef is imported from Brazil you are putting a lot of faith in the fact that every single fly will be controlled.       How about the fly that gets in a vehicle and is transported miles just sitting in the back window, or the fly that is in the truck because refrigeration will not kill all flies.        I dont believe that all flies will be controlled and allowing beef that is not cooked in from any part of Brazil will bring a strong chance of Foot and Mouth to the USA .  Does the USDA really want to be responsible for the killing of all wildlife in an area because of a fly.      I am a rancher and I do believe this will be devastating to the cattle market but I am also a person who loves seeing deer every morning out my window and Foot and Mouth would be devastating to wildlife across the country.', "Please do not approve this rule.  WE need to inspect our own foods, without worrying about inspecting what comes from another country.  Support our cattle industry, not Brazil's.  I assume their own people need the food in their own country where they can inspect it and keep any diseases confined to their country.  Thank you", "I don't know how you would check for FMD or keep it from contaminating our cattle? I think you understand that the risk is quite high! You also know that if there were to be an out-break it would put cattle people in the same position as they were with mad cow disease. Do we really need too take that risk? Brazil can ship cooked product to this country so maybe they need to increase that type of product?", 'We do not need to import any kind of beef into these United States of America from Brazil or any other country and take the risk of contaminating our livestock industry with foot and mouth disease or other diseases. The people in our government must not have any common sense if they  even allowed the idea to be discussed. The people who import and those in authority who would allow imports such as this should be considered enemies of US industrial economy and dealt with like any criminal.', "Support the producers in the US, we know where it comes from and if it's safe.", 'I am strongly opposed to any legislation which would allow beef to be imported from countries without equal or higher standards than our government enforces.', 'Why on earth would you want to endanger the United States food supply. This is insane stop this now!', 'I am opposed to importation of beef from Brazil until they can demonstrate equivalent health control procedures as used in the States and until an independent agency can confirm that their herds are free from infectious diseases such as foot and mouth disease. There is no need for Brazilian beef that can not  be met from Domestic production and importation of a highly infectious disease could cripple our domestic production and would result in high costs for the consumer.', 'Even the low probability of bringing FMD into this country from an infected country would be devastating and just not worth risk.  We do not want Brazilian beef to be imported into the US.', 'I strongly oppose importing beef from South America because it will open the door to bring into the USA beef contaminated with internal and external parasites and diseases unknown to the U.S.  Your efforts would be better spent on encouraging those men and women in the U.S. who raise the safest and highest quality beef in the world!  Thank you, Frank Waitley Cattleman', 'I am opposed to the importation of Brazilian beef. Please do not endanger US cattle herds for the benefit of Brazilian ranchers.', "I believe the benefits of opening access to the U.S. market greatly outweigh the risks.  In terms of economic benefits, one must consider the benefits to the cold chain.  Imports of refrigerated cargoes will bring great economic impact to U.S. ports, cold storage warehousing, trucking and distribution.  More competition will likely put competitive price pressures on U.S. production, which could have positive externalities in increasing productivity and making U.S. producers even more competitive domestically and internationally.  Where U.S. import ports are also consumer regions, far from U.S. beef production, the arrival of imports might also be cheaper and more efficient in accessing these U.S. markets.  Your econometricians could do some Input-Output modelling on the economic impacts of added reefer container imports through the transport chain derived from activities starting with discharge and unloading at U.S. ports.  That alone, could be modeled and would show quite an impact on direct, indirect, and induced jobs and backflow in taxes to the government.  In the foreign policy arena, noting the WTO Cotton ruling against U.S. subsidies and the fact that Brazil, has, to this day withheld retaliation, opening access to Brazilian exports of beef could be considered a very adroit good-faith gesture and stave off Brazilian protectionism of higher value-added U.S. goods seeking access to the Brazil market.  On the eve of a potential trade war, the opening of U.S. market would be a very good signal for international cooperation.  It is also worth noting that opening the U.S. market to Brazilian beef may unlock even more foreign direct investment among Brazilian meatpacking firms coming to the U.S.  Market leader JBS has been in the U.S. for some time, as has Marfrig, but behemoth Brasil Foods and a number of highly productive Brazilian cooperatives may now see opportunities to invest in the U.S. creating jobs in U.S. and multiplying the international export opportunities from U.S. base.  I can see the same opportunities for U.S. meat companies going to Brazil. Already Brazil plays host to multinationals Tyson, Bunge, Cargill, ADM, Marfrig (Keystone), and JBS (Swift, Pilgrims Pride).   Patriotism and myopia aside, this is a good deal for the U.S. Bleeding heart and emotional comments may lack the perspective outlined above.
