Issuance of the new rule should facilitate leading edge cooperation between MAPA, EMBRAPA, ANVISA, USDA, APHIS etc.  A possibility emerges where the U.S. and Brazil and global champions can set international standards and practices to the benefit of U.S. producers and consumers.  While we do not know even yet if Brazilian beef and what types will be acceptable and competitive to the U.S. market, we know one result that could be negative to the U.S. economy.  Asian and European nations will acknowledge the rule and perhaps allow or facilitate more their markets for Brazilian beef exports. As has been shown with the Santa Catarina ruling on pork, it may be that the ruling helps Brazil's export to third countries other than the U.S., which could come at a cost to U.S. market share of foreign markets.  All told, I believe the employment, competition, FDI, lest we not forget consumer choice benefits outweigh any possible threat to U.S. production interest.  To the contrary, this opening could unlock latent trade and investment opportunities that will bring Brazil and U.S. economies and countries closer together.  In today's world, having stronger relations with countries that share federalism, continental dimensions, pluralism, democracy and ethnic diversity is not such a bad thing.", "To the knot heads that want Brizil beef in the U.S.A. Why would you do such a thing. They have a problem, why do We need it.. The meat supply is safe in the US why change that. PLEASE Don't let Brizil meat in the US We don't need or want it.", 'As a South Dakota beef producer, I find it abhorrent that the government would even consider importing beef from a country that has not shown itself to be free from fmd. I remember not being able to market my calves at an even breakeven price because of a mad cow discovery in recent years. I might add that this cow was traced to a Canadian herd. I believe that some countries in the world should maintain the highest standards in food production and to give this up for whatever economic reason would result in the demise of every producer and consumer in the nation. Maybe the powers that be should ask why.organic and drugfree produce is in such high demand and commands high prices.People need to have healthy food and they want it and they deserve it.  I do not believe that the cheapest and most mass produced options are always the best in all circumstances. THIS IS NOT A GOOD IDEA', "I strongly oppose the importation of beef from Brazil and surrounding areas. As a High School Agriculture Teacher, I do not agree with teaching my students about the possible diseases that animals may carry due to poor regulations,  and then turn around and support the importation of animals that don't follow the same guidelines as America.", "This should be stopped immediately.  In reality, it should have never been considered.  Cattle and beef producers across the United States are struggling to make a living.  This adds unfair and unneeded competition for American Producers.  Additionally, there appear to be no safeguards to prevent contaminated and diseased Brazilian beef from entering the marketplace.  Since there are no requirements for country of origin labeling, consumers won't know where the beef they are eating originated.  This is simply bad policy", 'I do not believe importing meat, animals, etc into the US is beneficial for anyone in the United States. This risk could be disasterous to not only livestock and ranchers but everyone. If people can get into the United States with illegal items what makes you think it can be proven that these animals, meat, etc do not have diseases? I understand nothing is fool proof, but why even take a chance? We need to support our own producers and not other countries!', 'After reading the proposed rule: Importation of Beef: Region in Brazil, I have several concerns. The first of which is the evaluation of pH at packing plants in Brazil, The rule proposal states "APHIS considers pH testing and calibration of pH meters to be critical mitigation measures in assessing the risk of importing the FMD virus in beef from Brazil. I could not find any secondary control measures to prevent infected beef from entering the U.S. borders. If a single pH meter is faulty or miscalibrated it then becomes possible to send infected beef into our country. Put checks in place in Brazil and also at the border crossing as the product enters our nation to double, triple and exponentially check that FMD is not entering our country.  Second the report states that APHIS concluded that as long as FMD is endemic in the overall region in South America, there is a risk of reintroduction from adjacent areas into the proposed exporting region. This is a fast moving disease that can grow at an epidemic scale. Brazil seems to be well on the way to eradicating the disease, but as U.S. producers we cannot afford to take the risk of introducing the disease into our herd. We need to wait until the country is 100%  FMD free! At the very minimum place a geographic "buffer zone" of disease free area around the region that we propose to accept animals from.   These risks are very real and the average producer and the local emergency management services in the United States are not prepared to deal with the disease if it is introduced in this country. Keeping our country FMD free is the only answer!  Next the report moves into economic impact. This is the most troubling section of the report for beef producers at all levels of the supply chain. The report states:   Due to the increase in supply, it is estimated that the wholesale price of beef, the retail price of beef, and the price of cattle (steers) would decline by 0.11 percent, 0.04 percent, and 0.14 percent, respectively....... The fall in beef prices and resulting decline in U.S. production would translate into reduced returns for producers in the livestock and beef processing sectors. Under the 40,000 MT import scenario, cattle producers and beef processors are estimated to incur declines in welfare of 0.68 percent and 0.14 percent, respectively....... The shift by consumers to beef due to the price decline would cause downward pressure on the prices of pork and other meats. The largest of these market declines, though still very small, would be for swine and pork. It is estimated for the 40,000 MT import scenario that the welfare of swine producers and pork processors would decline by 0.02 percent and 0.01 percent, respectively.  Beef producers today are faced with razor thin margins. We are facing the lowest cattle numbers since the 1950\'s. An epic drought in the mid-west has forced the cow herd to decline. We are seeing markets and pastures come back into alignment to offer opportunity to begin to rebuild the U.S. cow herd. It is devastating to our hard-working cattlemen to think that the Federal Government would consider actions that will hinder our forward progress after 5 years of difficult production. Also the pork industry is currently facing its own epidemic in the PEDv virus that is killing millions of pigs. They don\'t need any more international competition either.   In conclusion, my hat is off to Brazil and the leaps and bounds they\'ve made becoming a major factor in the international beef market. However, now is not the time to put our nations beef herd at risk of infection from FMD or to take dollars out of our producers pockets and put them in the pockets of Brazilian cattlemen. Let the Brazilians eradicate FMD from their entire country, let our domestic cattlemen have the opportunity to rebuild and recover from the droughts and adverse market conditions of the last few years, then re approach the importation of foreign beef.', 'I do not approve. Importing Brazilian beef is subjecting our food supply to an unnecessary risk of Hoof and Mouth Disease.', 'Do not do this. it is too risky, knowing that bringing foot-and mouth disease to the USA is a possibility. Beef owners and dairy cattle owners in this country have enough challenges to deal with on a daily basis without such a serious possibility. My husband and I have been dairy farmers since 1973. This country does not need imported beef at all.', 'As a PhD candidate in Security Studies with a focus on biosecurity, I object strongly to the opening of US markets to live beef from countries which have not secured WHO certification as Foot and Mouth Disease free. FMD has proven to be both economically and biologically devastating to farmers and ranchers and consumers in place after place around the world in the last two centuries as world trade has accelerated and facilitated exposure to this virulent pathogen.  Brazil has been OIE certified as FMD free in just two of twenty-six states and in the face of that limited certified disease free territory relaxed the vaccination regimen almost two years ago.  This does not bode well for the country to achieve country wide or even region-wide disease free status anytime soon.    The ostensible reason for the admission of this risky animal population is that the market price of beef has to be reduced for the consumer.  The amount of beef to be imported from Brazil will not provide significant price relief for the American consumer and should there be the exposure to a single diseased animal could very well result in a substantial increase in cost to all of us.    Finally, a short investigation determines that a single multi-national agricultural mega  corporation stands to benefit almost exclusively from putting the American consumer or the American Cattleman at substantial risk.  This is bad and risky policy and should not be allowed.   Jim Washington 1901 160th Street Basehor, KS 66007 913-620-2001 Kansas State University  Security Studies Program jpwashington@sbcglobal.net', 'I oppose the United States allowing the importation of Beef from Brazil.  Generally speaking I support free trade from foreign countries that have proper animal health and food safety protocols in place; however, Brazil lacks the proper protocols to protect against the importation of various diseases including foot and mouth disease into the United States.  Allowing the importation of Brazilian Beef will put our local food supplies at great risk and will ultimately put the American people in a highly dangerous and potentially deadly position.', "USDA       I want to express my concern about you opening up imports from Brazil. Brazil has FMD! It is very probable that FMD will be introduced into the USA if you do this. This would destroy our beef ranchers and their way of life. Please don't do this, please. The beef industry is one of the few things left that is the back bone of America. Our country needs this big industry to make it work. Finally the ranchers are able to make a living with the prices they are receiving now. This move by you will destroy this! Please don't do this.  Thank you for your time Vince Hulinsky", "DO NOT allow it.  Too much risk.  Customs and Border Patrol are already overwhelmed and we do not need any additional risk to our country's livestock population.  Please reconsider the proposal.", "I am strongly against this proposal not only from a disease standpoint but also from a economic. Its time to put our American farmers first, the price of operating is so expensive now that we can't afford to have the current prices of beef undermined by allowing imports! If you feel the need to import something find our farmers some cheap diesel fuel.", 'I realize that trade is important for our beef industry but not at the expensive of American farmers and ranchers.  I strongly oppose this proposed due to the possible risk of FMD being introduced into the U.S.', 'No importation of beef!  Support American farmers!', "Stop importation of Brazilian beef!!! It's unamerican & unsafe.", 'I am opposed to importing meat from a country with endemic Foot and Mouth Disease.', 'I vehemently disagree with the proposed rule to import beef of any kind from any part of Brazil.  It would put the entire American Cattle industry and Beef supply at catastrophic  risk.  We must never jeopardize our domestic food supply in any way, and this law would create entirely too much opportunity for failure and unnecessary risk.  Let alone the threat to the lively hoods of the American Cattleman and Women. Regards, Mike Briggs Briggs Cattle Co>', 'I oppose the proposed rule allowing the importation of fresh beef from Brazil. Brazil lacks the proper protocols to ensure that exported beef is disease free, and has failed to control foreign animal diseases such as foot and mouth disease.', 'I am strongly opposed to allowing fresh beef imports from Brazil and Argentina.  These countries lack the systemic protocols to prevent foot and mouth disease.  Breaking the barriers to prevent this disease in the US would be catastrophic to the beef, pork, lamb, and goat industries.', 'I oppose this proposal due to the high risk of importing FMD.', 'Bob & I are very much opposed to allowing beef or beef produc
column5: and the Australian Government.  3. The proposed ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings.  The ban should not cover the use of magnets by adults.  The appropriate response is warnings -- not a ban.", 'Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don\'t ban them! And as Zen Magnets pointed out in a statement, "...there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them. That is a good thing.', "The Federal government will never stop idiots from doing stupid things-look at what happened in the recent election.   Why don't you turn your attention to products- made in China- that are dangerous- mislabled and do real harm to children.", 'The warnings are very clear on this product! They should not be banned for peoples poor choices!', "I am so happy that these magnets are being banned because they are very dangerous. I have kids and would never buy anything that I know could jeopardize there health. My little one loves putting things in his mouth although my older kids would find them interesting. They pay attention to him if he played with them. I couldn't take that chance at all.", 'Please do not ban/set size limits on magnetic toys.  Do realize that many of these come with age recommendations which are ignored.  There are tons of toys that kids have that are marketed to them for which do more damage.', 'I understand that children have been harming themselves by ingesting spherical magnets that pinch off sections of their intestines. I understand that this danger exists but i do not feel that it is justification to ban Bucky balls. Many toys have similar risks for children and are allowed to exist anyways. Bucky balls to my understanding are not directly marketed to children and there are warnings telling people not to ingest them. There should be a middle ground to allow this product and those like it to stay on the market. More awareness to those who purchase them to keep them out of the reach of children who do not realize what they are doing. To me, this is an issue of parents being negligent and not taking proper safety precautions to keep children from ingesting Bucky balls.   Parents need to realize that young children will put anything they can in there mouth up to a certain age. it is not like Bucky balls are being advertised as something that can safely be put in your mouth. This is just a product that is relatively knew that parents need to realize is dangerous to leave around kids. thanks for reading this.', 'Please do not ban these toys that stimulate interest in science. Our country is sorely lacking in school funding right now, and as hard as it is to keep kids interested, we should be finding *more* ways to keep kids interested, not fewer.  Add whatever kind of labeling or product caveats are needed, but please do not remove these fascinating toys from the market.', 'These games should be labeled properly instead of banned.', 'I would like to register my objection to Safety Standard for Magnet Sets. If some action must be taken labeling requirements or child proof containers seem a far more reasonable response than an out right ban. Please, let us keep our magnets.', "Greetings.  Thanks for the chance to give some feedback. I've been a long time user of the magnet sets. They are clearly a toy targeted to adults. It would be reasonable that it couldn't be purchased by kids. But to have it outlawed entirely seems like an over reaction. I've had these magnetic balls in my office for years now and almost everyone that comes into my office ends up handling them. They are quite a popular toy. I would recommend against outlawing them. Kids can choke/ingest lots of small things (like coins) which we don't outlaw. Perhaps a law to prevent kids under 12 from purchasing them. That would seem more reasonable than an outright ban.", "The banning of these magnets is not necessary. While I don't want small children to be harmed, it is not that challenging to keep things away from them. If you want to ban something that harms a child, you may as well ban nearly every toy on the market today. These toys have warning labels and people need to abide by them. Banning these toys is not the solution.", "I believe it is absolutely insane to ban the sale of small magnets just because ingesting them can do damage to intestines and insides of children, or anyone for that matter.  How many products are sold currently that cause more injury to children and are specifically targeted to children? Lego's are a children's toy and there are just as many small parts available for a young child to swallow. But they are allowed to keep selling their product with a warning label.  Everyday consumer items which are found in every household, pushpins, earrings, paperclips, dice, beads, they are all small enough to be ingested by a child.  Why can't we place blame where blame is due? If children are getting their hands on these magnets, somewhere there is a parent who didn't do their job. We keep beer and liquor in our fridges and cleaning supplies under the sink, and nobody is calling to ban these items although both are easily accessible to children.  Even if you are claiming beer and liquor are on a high shelf and cleaning products are in a cabinet which probably has child preventive snap hooks, you are making the same argument I am. The parents took precautions to keep those things away from their children. If improperly stored, they become accessible to children.  One final argument. There are no laws against me owing a gun and keeping it in my house. In fact, there are no laws stating I have to keep my gun locked up securely in my house. If I decided to leave my gun loaded on my night stand every night, I would be well within my right to do so, and the only time this would become an issue is if my child gets to it and an incident occurs, at which point I would be held accountable for child endangerment.   So why can't I be trusted to own magnets and keep my children away from them?   This proposed rule is a waste of government time and tax payers dollars.", "You shouldn't blame a product for an incident of human stupidity. It's like blaming the rug for tripping someone instead of blaming them for not looking down.   All this tells me is that people need to watch their kids a little closer.  The package of certain magnet sets --like Buckyballs-- actually have KOOROC (Keep Out Of Reach Of Children) and Choking Hazard disclaimers and should not be subject to ban or strict regulation.  You wouldn't blame the car if the driver didn't wear his seat belt and got seriously injured or killed in a crash, you would blame the driver.", "Banning a product that has been specifically labeled that it is to be kept away from children because caretakers have ignored the warnings and allowed children access to them is absurd. These magnets are perfectly safe when in the hands of a responsible adult, and if a child is injured as a result of palying with these magnets, then that is the responsibility of the caretaker who allowed access, rather than the company who sold the product. This flat-out ban is just as absurd as, eg. banning the sale of bleach because someone might kill themselves by drinking it. As a responsible adult owner of this product, I have never allowed children anywhere near this product, and derive great enjoyment from them. I feel that it would be a gross misuse of your regulatory powers to remove this enjoyment from me and other consumers like me because some caregivers take no responsibility for their children's well-being.", "I am a Pediatric Gastroenterologist and I am urging our lawmakers to ban these magnets.  They are extremely powerful, yet small, and are easily swallowed.  They can be extremely destructive causing intestinal perforations if more than one is swallowed at any given time.  I have personally cared for a teenager who was trying to simulate a lip ring and swallowed two magnets.  He wound up in the operating room to have them surgically removed when they became lodged in his small intestine.  He was fortunate to not have been perforated but wound up being hospitalized for a week and had invasive surgery.  This was not a small child but rather someone who should have known not to put non food items in his mouth.  Now imagine how tempting they would be for a toddler!  I dread getting a phone call from the emergency room about a child who swallowed these magnets because since they are so small, they quickly pass out of the stomach and out of the reach of an endoscope.  This practically ensures a surgical procedure.  Now if a small child or a frightened child swallows these and the parents are unaware, he/she can quickly perforated and become septic.  I realize the company that makes these will be seriously affected by the ban.  But how many children need to suffer and die before actions are taken to protect them? Package warning labels are completely ineffective since small children can't read and most parents don't realize how dangerous these magnets are.. Even the most hyper vigilant parent can't possibly watch their children every second of every day.  I see children swallow things they shouldn't all the time (even my own) but very few things cause the extent of damage that these magnets do in such a short time.  Please ban them.  I am happy to do less procedures, and make less money if that means children will be protected from this dangerous toy.", 'I am against banning Zen magnets and similar products.  There is nothing risk free in this world but Zen Magnets are pretty close.', 'I am deeply disturbed by what you are proposing.  To attempt an across the board ban on an item marketed to adults, based on the poor judgement excercised by a few, is ridiculous.  The reasons why have been enumerated in other comments, so I will not repeat them.  I trust that you will reconsider your position.', "The Division of Pediatric Gastroenterology within the Department of Pediatrics at the Vermont Children's Hospital at Fletcher Allen Health Care and the University of Vermont's College of Medicine supports the CPSC's action in it's attempt to protect children from these dangerous objects.  Our national society, NASPGHAN (the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition) holds the same position and has published a position statement outining the details of this is issue.  It can be found at this link:  http://www.naspghan.org/user-assets/Documents/pdf/Advocacy/July%202012/NASPGHAN%20Website%20Statement%20July%202012.pdf", 'Do not ban items on the basis of what a few people do with them.  Put warning labels on them, or make them restricted to certain sorts of shops, but allow responsible people to make their own decisions as to what they purchase.', "The ban on magnet balls is extremism and alarmism to say the least. I've had a set for over 4 years and have not suffered any injury. I played with them so much they got worn out and i ordered a new set last week.   The fact that the frequency of injury caused by these ADULT marketed desk toys is lower than injury caused from party balloons marketed towards children makes this ban mind bindingly dense.   I was unaware that digesting these magnets caused serious harm. How about that's the actual issue? Public knowledge regarding the digestion. That said i would have never attempted to swallow any of them. Also, how is this any different than any other type of magnets you can get at a hardware store or online? there isn't and those aren't being banned.   Do not follow through with this ban. It's ridiculous and not the right solution. The correct solution is requiring better warning labels that are listed on the product websites as well as what comes with the toys.   In protest I'm going to go buy another set, that i dont even need, just to cast my vote on this silliness with my wallet.", "They're so much fun. And educational. Don't let a few bad cases ruin this for everyone. Let Darwinism run its course.", "Magnet sets that are not marketed as childrens' toys and are clearly marked as ingestion dangers don't need to be taken off the market.", 'All cited instances of injury in document ID CPSC-2012-0050-0001 are resultant of a) blatant misuse of these products or b) negligence of a guardian or parent.  It would be unfair to alter the nature and functionality of an intelligent product because of the solecism of a small minority.  Hold those responsible for misuse accountable (warnings are clearly applied to these products); do not punish others for such errors.', 'I believe these [rules are in violation of] 706(2)(a) as they are arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion. This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing under 556&557 should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.', "Magnets in all forms are an tools for education and investigation of the natural forces that are all around us. Banning one form of them is simply will do nothing but hinder education and innovation in the mind of any age. There are many more dangerous things in our lives that are not banned but have can create much more damage to them. A simple warning label is all that is needed and parents to have to be involved with their children to make sure that they don't eat something.", "These magnets are not proven to be sufficiently dangerous to merit a ban. The CPSC should listen to Nancy Nord, the CPSC's own commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don't work undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.     The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tonguing their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products that have not demonstrated similar risks.     These magnets have much more utility, and a lower instance of hazard, than other products on the market.", 'Ban rocks too. Kids will swallow anything...amIrite?', 'Please do not make BuckyBalls illegal.    As an adult, I use these in personal hobbies and for tools.  Place warning labels on them, and repackage so as not to appeal to children.', 'OUTRAGEOUS!!!! The company who makes these Buckyball\'s and it\'s lack of responsibility will only dig their hole that much deeper. Whoever is in charge and agreed to a positive spin on such a clear disregard for child safety, will undoubtedly "attract" a lengthy time in jail as well, God willing. Hopefully the charges against them will include "reckless endangerment to a minor" as well as "depraved indifference". I don\'t even have children and I am outdone by this company\'s complete disassociation with mankind. I can\'t imagine that they\'ll be in business much longer, and if they are, then something is terribly wrong with how the word "toy" is used.', 'I strongly oppose the restrictions proposed.  As an adult, with no children in my household (And as planned there will be none ever) and no children in my workspace I find the magnetic construction sets very relaxing, and a good use of creative energy.  While it\'s certainly true that the safety issue exists, I feel it could be a solvable problem with consumer education - certainly the press that this has already gotten is a good start!    Parents and caretakers already know that certain classes of things are not child-safe (obviously sharp objects, medicine, weapons, etc.)  and they take measures to keep kids away or not have the objects in homes with kids.  Strong magnets are in that class and as long as everyone who would purchase them is made aware of it, then the magnet sets will be no more dangerous per capita than any other "toys" meant for adults which are not banned.  (Think collectible knives)  and less dangerous than many things that Are meant for kids (I see balloons, kiddie pools, and even buckets mentioned a lot)', 'I think it is absurd that the Federal Government wants to ban a product that has encouraged so much enthusiasm towards learning more about Magnets. The Federal Government has no business banning products like this. Bucky Balls has gone to extreme measures to warn people of the possible risks if their products are swallowed.  They have had to completely rebrand their packaging in efforts to address your concerns. Please do not ban this wonderful product.', 'Creating legislation to ban a particular product due to a labeling deficiency sets a terrible president which may greatly diminish product innovation in the future.   Other products and toys that have a choking hazard or even contain chemicals are regulated and labeled in such a fashion that the general public and/or consumers are made aware of the risks involved in the use of or the possession of said products.   I believe that this is a labeling and educational issue, not a an issue worthy of banning an entire, albeit small, industry from selling its products to the general public.   Fix the packaging, not the marketplace.', 'I am a pediatric gastroenterology fellow at Johns Hopkins and I am writing here in complete support of the safety standard and proposed ban on high powered magnet sets.  I have seen first hand the effects that these magnets can have on children, both young and old, who ingest them.  Pediatric patients who are found to have ingested these magnets must undergo emergency endoscopy or surgery to have them immediately removed from their stomach or else they are at risk of the magnets adhering to the walls of their intestine causing perforation or death to the cells.  These surgical procedures are not benign, at put children at risk of complications from anesthesia, bleeding and cause a significant amount of pain.  As pediatricians and gastroenterologists, we have all seen or heard about children who have ingested these magnets and then needed to have some part of their intestines removed because of the complications these dangerous products can cause.  Children with parts of their intestines removed are at risk for poor growth due to a lack of absorption of minerals and nutrients they need to grow and thrive.  All of these horrible outcomes can be prevented by banning the sale and distribution of these high powered magnets so that no child can get their hands on them and suffer from an accidental ingestion.', 'An amazing tool for science, these should not be banned. Children can fall and stab themselves wit a pencil:  should they be banned too?', 'I do not believe that banning magnetic toys is necessary, or that it serves the public interest. While it is unfortunate that some children are injured, this would not happen with proper parental supervision. Many toys require adult supervision. Labeling toys and educating the public is much better than blanket bans.', 'Banning science toys like this is silly.  Label them, educate, or put a not children sticker.  But we can not wrap everyone in bubble wrap and think we did some good.  These toys are brilliant for adults smart enough not to eat them.', 'Please do not ban magnet toys, they are marketed to adults and have warning labels on them. I do not stand for having good things banned because of stupidity and/or negligence!', 'Why would you ban such a useful toy/tool that can be used to stir the imaginations of so many children. There are so many things that are more dangerous for children that are in households all over the United States, but with parental supervision and guidance, accidents (such as swallowing) can be prevented. The use of warnings seems like a much more appropriate action to take in this circumstance, than an all out ban.', 'These toys have practical scientific applications, so they should not be banned as they can be used responsibly.', 'Making magnets that were never intended for children illegal is wrong. Buckyballs have always been intended for adults and going out of your way to make their product illegal and forcing them out of business and making everyone that worked for the company unemployed is unacceptable. The government has far better things  to do (fix economy, getting our troops out of the Middle East) than pass nanny state regulations like this.', 'I do not support banning or even regulating magnet sets.  The magnet sets have utility value for teaching older children science.  There are many inherit dangers that we parents should be responsible for protecting our children from.  What next? Are they going to ban vinegar and baking soda because they read Bill Nye "The Science Guy" died due to a failed experiment.', 'Buckyballs are perfectly safe. If children are playing with them, they need to be supervised by an adult. That is all. Dont stop selling them', 'I disagree with the banning or sale restriction of magnetic toys as long as sufficient warning is provided that the toys can be harmful. Many toys can cause damage when unsupervised. This sets a terrible precedent where consumers are restricted from buying something they can be responsible for simply because the object garnered negative news publicity. Awareness is the resolution not banning the magnet set altogether.', "Don't ban these because parents aren't being responsible for their children! These aren't a kids toy, and aren't marketed as such. This is a good way for children to learn about science and to get them interested in it. Please don't let the irresponsibility of some people destroy the fun for others.", 'As a pediatric gastroenterologist who has spent many hours in the middle of the night retrieving these difficult to remove magnets, it is imperative that parents are aware of the risks of this product!', 'Instead of banning this, they should fine any parent that let\'s their child swallow one of these in the first place. As a foreigner this is once again me looking at America and their mind boggling "rules".', 'Spherical sculpting magnets should not be banned by the government. They should have a warning label packaged with them, but an outright ban is uncalled for. People who use these for their entertainment can use them responsibly and should not have their safe actions outlawed by an overprotective government. Thank you for reading my comment.', 'Please do not outlaw ban Bucky Balls, Zen Magnets and similar magnetic spheres....', "I think if anything needs to be regulated by these people, it's the red tape that will eventually kill us all. People complain over and over about children dying because they ate these things. How did they get them? Who was responsible for watching them, gave them to the kids, and didn't read the MANY warnings plastered all over these magnets? The Parents! If you start banning products because they can hurt people, take one look under your kitchen sink and ban every single thing under their. Paint? Bleach? Gasoline?...all out! All easily available to kids, and all hazardous. Worry about important things, like irresponsible parents, not magnets clearly not made for kids.", "Do not ban magnet sets.  We've used them successfully to interest people in science and demonstrate scientific principles.  Err on the side of freedom and responsibility.  Adults can supervise children and keep them safe without a ban.  Don't hurt the businesses that make, sell, advertise and ship these outstanding items.", "In a world where there are hundreds of warning labels on every product you buy, and yet frivolous lawsuits still happen, it seems rather draconian to ban an entire product line because a few people didn't read the safety instructions.", "It is ridiculous to ban the manufacture and sale of adult magnet toys because of parental negligence in a few cases.  Children swallow many things they shouldn't. You do not have the right to limit free enterprise because of this.", 'I use these high power magnets for Alternative Medicine ( Bio magnetism).  I try to keep the cost down for my patients and if these magnets become inaccessible  then I will have to obtain them at higher prices and that will bring the costs up.  I beg you to you keep these magnets available for use.', 'Magnets and toys containing small pieces with magnets should be banned from the market. These are very dangerous and carry a huge hazard on our kids health. They are easy swallowed, and then they sit in the stomach or the small bowel (intestine) and create complications that range from ulcers, bleeding, sticking to other magnets in the small or large bowel and creating fistulas (tracts within the body, that should NOT be there). I have seen kids go through procedures like endoscopies and/or surgeries to attempt removal of magnets. This is a very serious issue that we should vote against.', "It is not the manufacturer's fault that parents give potentially unsafe toys to children. It should be required instead to have parents successfully complete a basic aptitude test related to the product.  If the score is not 80% or higher, then they should be put on a list banning *them* from purchasing innovative and complex toys that may cause injury to children unable to rationalize consequences.", "We don't need the state to protect us from ourselves. There is no way you can buy these magnets without coming across tons of warnings letting you know what you are potentially getting yourself into. Once informed, one should have the choice to proceed anyway.    Please don't stop us from getting these awesome magnets.", "Of over 2 million sets of Buckyballs sold in the past 3 years, there have been at most 1700 incidents of ingestion, extrapolated from 72 cases that may be from magnet spheres.  At worst, that's 1.5 incidents per day.  For some perspective, on average 5 American children a day will die daily from choking on food, (hot dogs are a known choking hazard, and don't require warnings.) 30 children will drown in buckets every year in the US. And there have been more American skate board deaths in 2011, than magnet sphere injuries in the past 3 years. There are many more products that shouldn't be handled by children, and cause far more injuries that CPSC doesn't take issue with.   The CPSC is a necessary organization in the protection of consumers. But by pushing for an unfair ban that's drastically inconsistant with the hazards of other products, the CPSC wastes federal tax dollars, and dilutes the strength, power, and reputation of their organization. Not only do they endanger a product with proven educational, theraputic and artistic benefits, they endanger your rights and liberties. The CPSC has the power to immediately stop targeting the magnet sphere industry, and if thousands of Americans voiced their concerns, they would be forced to listen.  The CPSC may have the best intentions in trying to protect kids, but a one size fits all ban is not the right way to go about it. Just as is the case with firearms, swimming pools, and balloons, the solution to the safety problem is education and not prohibition. When it comes to product safety, every one of the links is responsible: companies, parents, children.   This is why I am asking the US CPSC to *retract the stop-sale and recall requests of magnet spheres.*", 'This seems to be a rather symbolic gesture in response to an increase in injuries from a new, popular novelty toy.  The magnets have a certain risk to consumers, but it seems like a fairly drastic step to ban them outright.  The number of things that are electric shock/choking/strangulation/slip-trip-fall hazards far outnumber any real threat these magnets have.    According to the CDC, there are approximately 2 million poison exposures in the United States each year (57 percent amont children under the age of six).  30 children die each year due to accidental poisonings.  So within the past three years: 1700 hospitalizations from these magnets vs 6 million poison exposures, 90 deaths.    It appears as though this is a knee-jerk reaction to something that has caused a fairly miinimal amount of injuries compared to other hazards.  I generally scoff at any mention of a "nanny state" but banning small magnets because they cause injury when used not for their intended purpose seems extreme and reactionary.    I think most people would agree that working towards solutions for actual problems that plague society is a better use of time than performing symbolic gestures.', 'Bucky Balls are a learning toy.  Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don\'t ban them! And as Zen Magnets pointed out in a statement, "...there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them. That is a good thing.', "I do not believe the outright banning of Small Rare Earth Magnets (henceforth referred to as SREMs) is an appropriate response to the situation.    Comparing the cases listed in the document of injury due to interaction with SREMs to reports of injury from other items, ones which are actually intended for children, lends to the opinion that they do not pose a great threat to the safety of our society.    At the very least, they do not pose as great a threat as children's bicycles and skateboards (assuming that the safety standards already in place for the SREMs are continued).  There are hundreds of thousands of injuries as well as hundreds of deaths from those activities, but they are not outright banned as this document proposes we do for SREMs.  I suggest further consideration into both methods of detecting when SREMs are used improperly and become hazardous, as well as steps to take when such situations do occur.  Banning SREMs will not solve the problem of parent not educating themselves and their children on proper handling of things   In conclusion, I suggest more emphasis be placed on teaching parents to properly understand and take head of provided warnings, rather than target each and every item which could be hazardous to children when used improperly.", "Many more kids are injured or killed while climbing trees or playing on furniture or riding their by bicycles biter don't outlaw sofas or melt down all the skateboards and bicycles. Label items but don't remove them because some idiot hands a toddler something like this. Otherwise you must outlaw all potentially useful items like draino! Educate don't eliminate!", 'This proposal is not well thought out. The argument used are equally applicable to common household items -- small hardware (nails), stationery (thumbtacks), prescription medicines, household cleaners, etc.  All of these items are commonly available in just about any household and present a risk of being found and ingested by children. However, none of these are being banned or restricted in any significant way. At best, mild restraints are put in place (e.g., childproof medicine containers), but in general, it is assumed that the adults in a household are responsible for keeping these items out of reach of children.  Strong magnets are not significantly more dangerous than prescription medicine or strong household cleaners, and do not warrant such strong measures if these other items, which are much more readily available items and thus have a higher probability of being ingested, are not controlled in a similar fashion.', "Constantly pandering to the lowest common denominator has not been an effective strategy before nor will it be now. I have three children and if I'm worried about something being unsafe, I don't have it near them. To deny others the utility of a product because irresponsible people might screw up only justifies and promotes more irresponsible behavior. This has gone too far and it's time to stop.Save prohibition for legitimate sources of danger, not to protect people from their own inattentiveness and stupidity. No more nanny state, please.", 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. \xa0They\'

column2: ed space can end up with preventable ailments from  painful arthritis to foot disease and digestive and social disorders. We know that  elephants are highly social creatures and require interaction within their species  for their social health. Elephants that are kept alone and segregated display social  discorders such as head bobbing. As a nurse we first saw these behaviors in  human orphans left isolated in cribs for long periods. They too demonstrated head  bobbing and developed mental problems that could never be reversed! As a  mammal, elephants can and do display these same symptoms of isolation.  Please act to provide large, natural environments for these beautiful and unique  creatures. It is our responsibility to provide for humane treatment such as that see  in The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennesse and the Performing Animal Welfare  Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California.', 'The intelligence and social nature of elephants is well known; it should not be in dispute that  keeping elephants in confinement at all constitutes cruelty. Given that the USDA is not likely to  insist on freedom for all captive elephants--businesses who own elephants have invested  significant capital in their purchase and upkeep and these economic concerns will weigh heavily  with the department, not to mention that existing elephant sanctuaries cannot accomodate all  captive elephants in the US today--the very least it can do is enforce existing protections for those  elephants unfortunate enough to be in captivity and to release those whose captors refuse to  comply with regulations into the care of sanctuaries.', "Please support these majestic creatures.  If we are to keep elephants captive,  then we need to ateast provide them Food, space and the respect they deserve. I  no longer attend circus's due to the fact of the mistreatment these elephants go  through, its a crime.  Please be humane and do not turn another blind eye to the  torture that is going on behind the scenes with these beautiful creatures.", 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.  Please help these elephants w/humane treatment and legislation.', "I spend my free time off of work (I'm a nurse) fighting for the rights of animals used  in entertainment-  Speaking to people on their way into zoos and circuses about  what really happens behind the scenes and the reality of the lives of animals in  captivity.  My son will never go to an animal circus or the zoo.  I have seen the  elephant handlers at The Philadelphia Zoo use bullhooks on the elephants and  I  have seen much worse at Ringling Bros. and other circuses before the shows.   How people could be so cruel I have no idea, how their cruelties can go  unpunished is even more incomprehensible.  The treatment and living situations of  captive elephants NEEDS to change.  It cannot go on this way anymore!!!  I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive  elephants in the U.S.  I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive  elephants in the U.S.Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions  they require for their health and well-being. Elephants are big animals who need  big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space,  unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and  digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  To make matters worse, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least  12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres  over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.", 'Please protect and care for the elephants! Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the  conditions they require for their health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos  and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet  this requirement. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space,  but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable  ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and  neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive  elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of  euthanasia in captive elephants. Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining,  spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling  in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and  to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged  chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. Circuses and many  zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and  other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments  are unnecessary and must be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide  large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and  the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain  their health.', "I am writing to express support for all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country. I urge the USDA to create tough new standards to ensure these improvements, including the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  Thank you for taking action on this important issue.", 'I do not believe that humans should use elephants for entertainment purposes.  I  think it is cruel.  I do not go to the circus because of the obvious confinement of  the elephants who are forced to "perform" silly acts.  I think that these large  animals should be protected in the fiercest of ways and elephants performing in  circus acts should all be free to live out the remainder of their lives in an elephant  sanctuary.  The same would be true of elephants confined in zoos.  It is just a  shame.  They need acres and acres where they can be free to roam.', 'I request that the USDA consider implementing required regulations regarding the  treatment of elephants in zoos and circuses.  These magnificent animals require  very large spaces and the freedom of movement and association with their own  species.  Elephant experts can tell you they have very strong family ties.  The  lack of space and ability to move as they are meant to causes them to develop  painful arthritis, foot diseases and neurotic behavior which can lead to disasters  as have occurred when they "go mad" because of the treatment by humans.   Circus elephants, especially, are chained for long periods of time, required to  perform ridiculous stunts, kept in very small enclosures for transportation, and  many other forms of abuse and torment just so some humans can benefit  financially.  They are left to stand in their own waste during transportation and the  means used to make them "obey" are often cruel and very painful.  Imagine  yourself in these types of situations.  They are not "just animals;" they are living,  breathing, feeling beings and should be accorded decent treatment or, even better,  left in their own environment.  Thank you for your consideration.', 'I am outraged at the treatment of captive elephants in many zoos and circuses in the United States  and urge action be taken to remedy their suffering. Too many are in emotional and physical pain. Our compassion towards these creatures is a measure of our own intelligence, morality and  consciousness.     Please demand that profit, convenience, nor apathy allow these animals to be kept in too-small  environments, and mistreated with the use of bullhooks, electric shock and abusive treatment.  Please do not allow suffering animals, with feet, skeletal and emotional problems to remain in an  environment that does not remedy this!      These elephants need dramatic recourse to be taken, and as the individuals and representatives  enabled to effect this, please, please do!  It is reflective of the very value itself which we place  upon life and creation.', 'Just a note to request that the USDA strengthen its regulations regarding the care  and treatment of elephants in captivity.  I\'m sure you are aware that they were  recently added to the list of animals who possess "awareness".  We animal lovers  knew that all along.  Some of these captive animals are so cruelly treated and we have the opportunity  to do something.  Please protect them.    "The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its  animals are treated" Gandhi (1869-1948)', "It's time this country provided for the humane care for the first of God's creatures.   They were here before we were and weren't put on this earth to be treated cruely  and inhumanely.", 'I am an animal lover and feel elephants are deserving of our respect, and if we are  going to hold them captive and take away their homes, then we better provide them with  the means to enjoy their long worthwhile lives.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement. Elephants are big animals who  need big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space,  unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable  ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive  disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.   Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo  is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods  during the cold winter months.   Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination  and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.   I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country. I also support the elephant sanctuary in tennessee that provides elephants  with a home they can enjoy and live out their lives in happiness.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in  California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which  elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.   The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force  must be outlawed.', 'I agree to the petition received from the In Defense of Animals.  There should be continuation of regulating the handling, care, treatment, and transportation of elephants. I do believe animals require as much exercise as possible.  They need to stretch to build strong muscles so they can support their weight.  Exercise helps them relax and reduce stress as well.  This is especially helpful for female elephants because it helps build stronger abdominal muscles to aid in a fortunate delivery.    There should be prevention of unsanitary living conditions of these animals.  This could help reduce the short term life span and death of elephants.', 'To Whom it may Concern,  I am not a member of any animal rights group. I am, however, aware of the  ongoing abuse of elephants at circuses and some zoos. I would urge the  government to ensure that captive elephants are provided sufficient space in a  healthy, respectful environment. I would also ask that the use of bullhooks, chains  and  electric prods be prohibited.  Please see that the Animal Welfare Act is strictly construed to protect elephants.   Thank-you.', "I am very concerned that both zoos and circuses are not living up to the spirit of  existing animal welfare regulations and that, even if they were, the regulations are  not sufficient to meet the animal's basic needs.", 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.   In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.   An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', "I urge you to create tough new standards that look out for the welfare of circus elephants.   ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  There are other ways to train elephants that don't involve such pain and misery. Please take this issue in to serious consideration.  Thank you.", 'I am concerned over the treatment of elephants by zoos and circuses.  Elephants are magnificent animals who need to be provided for as such.  They have been shown to be social animals, recognizing and remembering fellow elephants from their past, as well as compassionate for their young and others.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well being and do not even meet the requirements of the Animal Welfare Act.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments, similar to those provided at the Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) in California.  These refuges provide hundreds of thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.  It is the humane thing to do.  Elephants deserve it.', 'Elephants need a vast amount of space to move and a natural environment in  which to live and on which to walk on.  Also, any form of physical instrument  which could hurt or abnormally restrain the animal, such as a bullhook or chains,  should be prohibited from use.', 'Please FORCE ALL circuses to give up ALL their elephants to humane  sanctuaries that can care for them properly.  Elephants do not belong in circuses  AT ALL.  The same is true of zoos.  However, if a zoo makes a natural  environmental habitat that mimics an elephants natural wild habitat, that is  acceptable.  The elephants in zoos need many acres in which to roam, natural  foliage/trees on which to feed, and soft ground to walk, NO CONCRETE for  standing and/or sleeping upon.  Elephants need familial groups headed by  matriarchs, babies stay with their mothers for over two years.  No forms of abuse  should be used to force elephants to behave in unnatural manners or to "perform"  for human amusement.  No bullhooks, stun guns, tazers, whips, chains, or any  other brutal form of abuse should be used on elephants.  If zoos cannot comply  with these rules, they should release the elephants to approved sanctuaries where  the animal will get proper nutrition/medical care, dignity and respect.', "The USDA needs to enact tough new standards to drastically improve the lives of  captive elephants in this country.The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. The  Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices,  chaining and instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants.   Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that reflects elephant's natural habitats-such as those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Welfare Society sanctuary  in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants  socialize, and maintain their health.  These poor animals fair miserably in captivity. This must end.", 'Zoos and circuses CANNOT properly provide for elephants.  Time and time again  zoos & circuses violate the AWA and receive only "a slap on the wrist" as  punishment.  It\'s time for change!  Elephants constantly suffer in captivity- they are  abused with bullhooks, electric prods, deprived of socialization with other  elephants, suffer debilitating health problems, lack proper space, aren\'t given  proper mental stimulation and spend large portions of their lives in chains.  I  support any actions by the USDA to improve the lives of captive elephants, better  yet, put an end to elephants in captivity altogether!  For example- make the use of  bullhooks illegal- after all- if the bulklhook is only used as a "guide" (as circus &  zoos claim) and not used to inflict pain then common sense would make us  ask "then why not use a plastic tipped guide instead of a sharp, pointy metal  tipped bullhook?"  It\'s time to start showing these beautiful, amazing beings the  respect and care they deserve.  It\'s time for the USDA to make a change for the  better for elephants in captivity!', 'I am concerned about the care of elephants in zoos and circuses. Zoos and circuses do not currently provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being.', '"The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its  animals are treated? -Quote by Mahatma Gandhi  "Do something wonderful, people may imitate it.?- Quote byAlbert Schweitzer  Our great nation can and should demonstrate that its citizens and legislators care  deeply about the welfare of all living creatures. The situation that the magnificent  elephants are suffering is an unecessary embarrassment. We have the means  and the resources to place these magnificent creatures in sanctuaries right here  in the USA where they will live their lives as nature intended. Can we not come  together and legislate to ensure the right to the qualifty of life that ALL LIFE  deserves? Please, let\'s do the moral and HUMAN thing. The time is NOW!', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.   In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.', 'Our current knowledge/understanding of elephants - their family and social  sructure, their intelligence and emotions, their needs for sustaining good health  and welfare - leaves no room for deniability.  We now KNOW that zoos and  circuses do not, probably cannot, provide the conditions/environment that these  magnificent mammals require and deserve.  We can no longer justify, rationalize,  nor excuse our cruel and callous treatment, nor withhold whatever remedy may be  required to alleviate their suffering.  However, if we acknowledge our mistakes and  take action to correct them without delay, perhaps we can eventually forgive  ourselves for our unconscionable actions of the past.  Please join in  this effort.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  The USDA should require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic,  climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide  hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and  maintain their health.   The USDA should prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and  other instruments of force against elephants.   The reasons why the USDA must take action include:   1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation  that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and  foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like  swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when  the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for  extended periods during the cold winter months.   5. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These  methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to  elephants.   6. Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs,  elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these  unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.   It is critical that the letters are personalized and in the writer?s own words. Please  feel free to talk about your personal experience seeing elephants in zoos and/or  circuses, your profession, whether you are a parent who wants his or her children  to be properly educated, etc. A personalized letter will have much more impact  than a form letter.  Thank you for the opportunity to comment.', 'WHY is this even an issue - proper care and space for these animals should have already been established.  There should be minimum acerages and minimum environments and if the owners cannot meet those needs then they do not need an animal of this caliber!  Cruelty is against the law, and this constitutes cruelty.  PASS LAWS NOW!', "I'm writing to ask you to protect the South India's wild elephants. Zoos and  circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health  and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide  elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this  requirement.In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of  space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause  a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease,  reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and  head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and  foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive  elephants. Please help Improve living conditions for elephants in zoos and  circuses.", 'Thank-you for accepting my comment.  It is my belief that animals such as  elephants need strict regulation to protect them from untrained and uncaring  individuals and companies.  Unfortuanately, as you are aware elephants are kept  as novelties in zoos, circuses, and other situations which often results in their  mistreatment.  Elephants too often suffer from maltreatment and disregard for their  health, safety and general well-being for greed and profit.  This is wrong and must  be corrected by those in a position to do so.  Elephants are beautiful, intelligent  creatures who can suffer the same emotional and physical trauma as you or I.   Please do something to protect these beautiful creatures from any more harm.', 'The Government does not do an adequate job overseeing the welfare of animals  (particularly captive elephants). With all of the research that has been done about  them, we as an informed society, know what it would take to make a suitable  environment for these majestic animals. However, due to greed and apathy no one  seems to care about the emotional and physical wellbeing of these animals. They  require so much space and freedom to thrive and no one seems to care about  giving that to them. We are a sad society, and need to work toward creating  habitats that are suitable if we are going to continue to keep elephants and other  amazing wild animals captive. We know better and should definitely do better!', 'Despite their massive size, elephants are sensitive animals, both physically and  emotionally. They currently suffer inhumane conditions and treatment, which lead  to a host of preventable physical and psychological ailments. Please enforce the  Animal Welfare Act and also enforce/create humane laws to ensure that all captive  elephants have sufficient living space and that they are no longer abused with  bullhooks, whips, clubs, electric shock devices, and excessive chaining. These  animals are desperately in need of your protection and we are all depending on  you to do your job and protect them. Thank you.', 'Dear Sirs and Ms\'s: I am writing because I am passionately interested in the plight  of elephants. They are wonderful, intelligent, amazing, social and sensitive animals  and are treated so shabbily and shamefully in zoos, circuses and the like. I\'ve  been corresponding with the St. Louis Zoo about a poor elephant named Clara,  who, because she has been trapped in a small cement and metal cage, unable to  move around, now has advanced arthritis. She is receiving no medical care. She  has another 20 to 30 years of life left, yet, the Zoo is content to let her die of  neglect.  She is in terrible physical and emotional pain. However, the Zoo has  used her up and is abandoning her. The letter I got back from the Director was  filled with fibs and rationalizations and not one shred of concern. Here in San  Diego, some years ago, our "world famous Zoo" enjoyed some very unpleasant  publicity when the head elephant "handler" was found to have abused the  elephants in his care with his bayonet-like hook that all elephant trainers seem to  use. The elephants he maimed had visible scars. The Director of the Zoo showed  the TV reporter the angry letters he\'d received and spoke of the Zoo\'s commitment  to the animals\' welfare. Right. The vicious animal handler, however, was not fired. I  am furious when I hear about elephants finally going berserk at a circus or petting  Zoo, where they are routinely abused, worked to death, chained, forced to live in a  totally unnatural environment...and then, they are shot. Who are the real villains?  Not the elephants, who didn\'t sign on for these miserable gigs!  Where is their  protection?  They can\'t count on their exploiters and abusers.', 'Elephants belong in the wild!  Failing that, conditions where they live should be as close to natural as it is  possible to make them. Elephants are intelligent, social beings who deserve  better than cramped quarters or chains. Please, do all you can to make their living  conditions more bearable.', "I am in favor of vastly improving conditions provided for elephants in zoos and  circuses. Currently they do not provide adequate conditions for elephants' health  and well-being. The Animal Welfare act requires that zoos and circuses provide  elephants with adequate space; neither complies with this requirement.  Sadly, in most zoos and especially circuses, elephants suffer from lack of space,  unnatural conditions, and social deprivation that can cause a variety of ailments.  These include arthritis, foot disease, and reproductive probl
column3: the pleasure of learning from the staff about the animals in their care. I have enjoyed the Sea Lion swim and the natural swim program, more than once. Both swim programs start with an educational and safety lesson. These are necessary for both inexperienced and experienced swimmers as the lessons provide solid information about the animals included in the programs, and safety information it relates to animal and swimmer. Every safety precaution is taken.   I have swum with Bottlenose dolphins of different ages in the natural swim. Not only was this particular swim fun and a learning experience for me, but it was for the dolphins also.    I have sat on a platform with a sea lion pressing her large tusked and whiskered fact on my cheek for a kiss. I was keenly aware of the size and strength of that sea lion. Her caretaker/trainer ensured me that I was safe. The caretaker/trainer, with his vast knowledge and experience with that animal, was all I need to know everything was ok. THIS is what APHIS needs to know.   Every caretaker/trainer I have spent time with in and out of the water was someone whose knowledge and experience I trusted.   It worries me that the radicalized animals rights people want to shut down all marine mammal facilities under their misinformed and misguided "empty the tanks" rant.
