These people know nothing about the day-to-day operations or a marine mammal facility, nor do they care to. They do not know or want to know of the rescue and rehab work these places engage in when needed. They merely sit at their keyboards and pound away a diatribe that holds know education, knowledge or experience in marine mammals or marine mammal care.   I spent seven years as a volunteer with a marine mammal rescue and rehab organization. I have put my time in with the caretakers and trainers from different marine mammal facilities, including SeaWorld. Would I trust my own animal, if I had one, to be cared for by these professionals? Yes. Without doubt. Because it is their level of care, their compassion, their education and professionalism that keeps the marine mammals healthy and happy every day.   Thank you for opportunity to comment on this proposal. In closing, please keep in mind that there is nothing wrong with the way marine mammal facilities in the US are run.', "People can only love and protect the beings they know.  Please do not kill the education of our next generations.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  More people visit zoos, aquariums and parks like Sea World than Nascar, etc.  Please do not let the small group of haters take all of that away from the Majority who love it. Why are we letting a documentary filled with falsehoods question what is right.  Sea World has loved, cared for, rehabilitated and released thousands of creatures around the world.  Special experiences share that knowledge with us and we are left with love and caring for those creatures and the world around us.  Please don't take that away.", 'Research and education are key to every success. Without it, as with any animal rescue and/or positive educational facility, we take the chance of ignorance, inawareness, and extinction of some of the most amazing creatures known and still unknown to man today.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please geel free to contact me personally if you have any questions.', 'I have been a professional animal trainer for 17 years. As a member and past president of the Animal Behavior Management Alliance (ABMA),  an organization representing individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to providing daily care, enrichment, and training to all animal taxa in a zoological, laboratory, or domestic settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.    ABMA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.  After reviewing the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.    If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.  Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis.  Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s welfare.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.    Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.   I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing exemplary care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I strongly support updating the animal welfare laws for marine mammals. I actually would like for the end of captivity of marine mammals. However, the update does address deficiencies in the current law. Chief among these is the lack of oversight of "swim with dolphins" programs, which have been unregulated since 1999. I would like to strongly support more oversight for these dolphins care in these settings. Also, while the proposed rule does not make any significant changes to the minimum space requirements for the primary habitat for marine mammals which really seems essential to add, it does require that sufficient shade be provided for animals in outdoor pools to allow all animals to take shelter from direct sunlight. This seems like a basic need and I am glad that it has been written in. Overall, the improvements proposed in this rulemaking are necessary to improve the overall welfare of captive marine mammals, which have not been addressed since 2001.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I know some of the trainers at Sea World. They love the animals there more than anyone else and truly want what is best for them. Many of the animals have established great relationships with them. The wonderful relationship between the trainers and the animals is truly inspiring.', "We as a society, must have zoos and aquariums available to educate and inspire love for animals so that we care for them and want to protect them.  If we do not know anout them, we don't care about them.   Sea World does so much to inspire people to love and care for the marine animals in their care. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  SeaWorld remains one of my family's favorite parks.  It is eveident that they all love and care about the animals in their care.", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Best regards,', 'I began visiting Sea World San Diego over 30 years ago with my children.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'The U.S. Department of Agriculture\'s (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) has released a long-awaited proposed update to the Animal Welfare Act regarding marine mammals. While individuals advocating for the end of captivity of marine mammals are disappointed in the proposed rules, the update does address deficiencies in the current law. Chief among these is the lack of oversight of "swim with dolphins" programs, which have been unregulated since 1999. Also, while the proposed rule does not make any significant changes to the minimum space requirements for the primary habitat for marine mammals, it does require that sufficient shade be provided for animals in outdoor pools to allow all animals to take shelter from direct sunlight. Overall, the improvements proposed in this rulemaking are necessary to improve the overall welfare of captive marine mammals, which have not been addressed since 2001.  We support revisions to the Animal Welfare Act to better protect marine mammals, and anticipate this proposed rule could be even better.', 'Good Day, The important role that marine parks and aquarium have in educating the public about the ocean is unmeasurable. In a world where it is getting harder and harder to have our children have an interest in the natural environment we need places like Marine parks, Zoos and Aquariums to have us make a connection. Marine Parks and Aquarium are the reasons I found a passion in the marine world and truly found my calling, and this was a young child.  All Marine parks and Aquarium need to have a high standard and many do and strive to be even better. They want the best for their animals on a daily basis and do anything to make sure they are their top priority. The care these facilities give is only possible because of the amazing dedication of staff who love these animals like family and take care of them with top notch care and consideration.  I have had the chance to witness many Marine Parks and Aquarium and I believe any decision which is made on these facilities needs to be based on many factors but the most obvious is scientific evidence. We know the good these places due through research and we know without them we would be at a loss not only through the lack of interaction the public will get but also the vital research and conversation these places work on every single day.', 'To those who are making the decisions,  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I hope that you make the right choice so that my son and other generations can learn about the animals these facilities care for. Exposure to the animals makes the connection to the environment real.', "My mother worked her whole working life for the APHIS division in Minneapolis, MN.  I know what fine work you do!    Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.   I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities. Our family recently had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest. We also watched many sessions between the dolphins and trainers. In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's expertise and dedication to the animals.    As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation. They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  My son worked for 7 of the last 8 years at Dolphin Quest Hawaii.  He would never had the love of these animals had I not had the chance to take him to places like the MN Zoo or SeaWorld in Orlando.  He got his marine biology degree because he was exposed to these fabulous creatures.  Please don't listen to those who would take this away from the majority and who fight with uneducated and inflammatory reasoning.", "Please read carefully below. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I trust Sea World in all animal matters and know they have the interest of them at heart as well as people getting to know them. I would be sick if I couldn't view and interact with them in the future. Please stop listening to naysayers and other doomsday overzealous need-to-get-a-life people who want to pick on Sea World and we animal lovers.", "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. As a former employee of Sea World, I witnessed first hand the reverence the staff had for the animals. I personally was involved in two rescues.  I can say without a doubt that Sea World's mission is sacred to the company.", 'As a father & grandfather, I have immensely enjoyed bringing my children and grandchildren to gulfariums which care for marine mammals. Our visits have been very educational and has even prompted one of my granddaughters to pursue a career training dolphins. I hope that we will not close a door to the marine world by limiting our ability to observe and learn about these wonderful mammals. Please do not impose further restrictions on our gulfariums. Thank you - Dusty', "Aithough the main body of this letter is a Seaworld sponsored form letter, I agree with it's content, and I passionately feel it only scratches the surface of how important these facilities are. I am fotunate enough to have traveled a significant amount, and been a scuba diver for many years. I have put fourth effort to learn about a variety of marine, and terrestrial life. I also live on a coast which would make it easier for me to take much of our marine neighbors somewhat for granted. I hate to think how people from places farther from the ocean would get exposed to such diversity of life without places like Seaworld and other aquariums. I feel that if there is a wider separation between people and these animals then the desire to protect them will dimunish over time. I feel studying these creatures, even in captivity can only enhance our prospects for ensuring tbey have a better chance to thrive in the future. The good of the many must surely outweigh the good of the few. We need research and rescues and people need to know about our sea and land animals.  Sea World and zoos teach important  lessons and promote survival of the species.  They are not harming any creature.  They take the upmost care.  As an agency you are causing more harm than good and I as a tax payer am tired of this.  You already caused harm to a whale program that did do much to educate and protect but you still keep doing more harm all in the cause of what?", "First, I would like to thank you for taking the time to read this letter.  I realize your time is precious as is all time, but this is something I have felt a need to direct your attention to.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I myself have volunteered at different humane organizations and have people tell me I must hate animals to work there.  But on the contrary, it has been my experience that the people who are there are people who love and admire and care for the animals most.  Just as that is true, I feel the same is be true about the people who work at SeaWorld.  You cannot devote the amount of time these people do to something you care nothing about.  Thank you again for your time and I hope that in 50 years we can still see many of the oceans creatures wild and alive in the oceans thanks to SeaWorld's efforts toward rehabilitation and education, as opposed to hearing about them and what used to be in some museum.", "I am currently the director of volunteer resources at Dolphin Resource Center in Grassy Key, Florida.  I began my relationship with DRC as a visitor and was so impressed by the love that was shown by the staff and volunteers for the dolphins in their care that I continued to visit the facility every time I was in the Keys.  When I eventually
column4: ts to be allowed to be exported from Brazil to the United States.   The ranchers in the US have worked hard to provide a safe supply of beef,  we do not need imported beef .                          Karen Meyer', "From a ranchers and concerned citizen point of view, I would be absolutely against importing Brazilian beef.  There are several reasons in why I would be against it.  The first reason is that it would tank a lot of small ranching families livelihoods because all the Brazil beef would food the economy and cause the prices of beef to drop extremely.  We are talking about families that have been the backbone of ranching in this country.  I mean I would hate to see if my Grandparents would have to give up the ranch that is on third generation with the original homestead still owned by the family.   Plus, main reason in why there are not many ranches producing more beef than what they did in the past is that people keep buying up the prime farm or ranch land (aka subdivision).  This causes us to try to produce the same amount on smaller amounts of land which is not going to happen because range can only handle certain stocking rates.  So if the government was smart they would try to protect the farm and ranch land that we currently have that isn't under concrete.      The second reason is why take a chance of introducing Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) back into the US is just pain irresponsible.  These would concern me because that would be taking a chance that we would lose a lot of US cattle including my own.  However FMD doesn't only affect cattle it basically  affects any animals with hooves like deer, sheep, and pigs.  So you would be taking a chance in affecting multiple industries.  Another thing whether I can personally get foot and mouth from infected animals and meat if that is case then hell no about importing beef.   I know that they would have to let us know about the outbreak if happen but I don't trust them since they already haven't told us about cows die of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) twice.   As the saying goes fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me.  So I wouldn't trust in Brazil letting us know about anything.  That would scare the heck of me about the meat in the grocery store which I only get every great once in a while.  There is a reason why I raise my own beef and not buy from the grocery stores.  I know what is in that beef.  I just hope the government makes a wise decision and all I have to say is that they need to listen to the people and not just themselves.", 'All nations should strive for self sufficiency in their food supply, and stay away from importing ~  Be safe.', "Paul from Rocking A Ranch. I raise beef cattle to support myself and family. Why do you want to expose my livelihood to Foot and mouth disease by importing suspect beef from Brazil. Please don't allow!", "Do NOT allow the import of Brazilian beef into the United States as long as Hoof and Mouth Disease are present in that country....I realize there are a very few areas that are supposedly safe, but there are NO BARRIERS for diseased animals to cross into the so-called safe area....and since it's a virus, it can be carried in raw meat!!  I live in an area with Buffalo (very sacred to the Oglala people) and this disease would decimate their herds as well as those at Badlands National Park and Custer State Park.... it would also decimate the antelope, the elk, the deer, the sheep man and the hog producer.......   Again.......do not allow beef from Brazil to be imported into this country.....not fresh/chilled or alive!!                                                              Thank you for your time,                                                                                      Paula Vogelgesang", 'We do not need to import diseases from another country our ranchers have enough problems. I urge you to ban animal imports from any country with communicable diseases.', 'Why would this country import beef from a country that has been known to have FMD for many years?  What are you people thinking?', 'do not allow import beef from out of the us, it is too dangerous', "If the USDA still stands for United States Department of Agriculture, why in the world is Brazilian Beef even being considered as allowable for import into our nation?  Are we being run by a Cartel or is someone getting a political payoff?  The tremendous risk and potential harm to our US cattle producers is incalculable!  Devastation, elimination, annihilation, irreversible, dangerous, irresponsible, dasterdly, corrupt - there are not enough words to explain what this will cause!  Please rescind this rule!  We heartily support the beef industry by consuming more than our fair share of it.  We want to know that it came from the United States and that we are supporting our fellow Americans.  Once the water goes over the waterfall, you can't put it back.  Thank you.   Mike and Julie Mueller", 'Please do not pass the "Import Beef from Brazil Proposal".  Importing meat from that area I believe will open the possibility of disease entering our country - especially foot and mouth disease.  It could have terrible effects on our cattle industry.   There is no need for this country to import beef from Brazil.  Please do not pass this proposal.', "I am totally against bringing these cattle into the United States.  As a cattle producer we work hard to raise healthy cattle of good quality and it takes years to do!  We do not need to risk bringing foot and mouth disease or any other diseases to our cattle herds!  Don't do it!", 'We believe that beef should not be allowed to be imported to the US from Brazil.', 'As a struggling rancher in South Dakota, I totally urge you to NOT allow the importation of Brazillian beef to the United States.  I do not understand how it can even be considered that the USDA would risk the health of our domestic beef industry.  This will not make beef "cheaper" for our citizens - it will just "cheapen" it.  It will make for more profits for the packing plants at the sacrifice of domestic beef producers.', 'Why do we want to take the chance of destroying our beef industry with imported diseases? It only takes one disease to slip through the cracks of our overworked controllers to destroy a whole herd. So who loses the American farmer of course!!!', 'Please  consider the hazards to our United States beef industry as well as our consumers/food industry, with any imports from Brazil, or any country with  FMD concerns. We need to keep our food safe. We need to consider the reputation of our clean US industry and food services. Please ban imports of beef of any kind that are not completely safe. Thank you.  Joan Wollschlager Beef producer and consumer', "PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW BRAZIL TO IMPORT FRESH BEEF OR LIVE CATTLE TO THE U.S.!!! Brazil is a known FMD country, and has shown in the past that their saftey protocals do not come close to ours here in the United States.  Brazil continued to ship processed meat into the US for nearly 2 years before notifying us they had a positive BSE case.   Brazil is a 3rd world country and does not have the ability to monitor it's boarders the way we do here in the U.S., there for I believe that allowing imports from certain areas of Brazil would in all reality be opening up imports from the entire country, and most likely adjoining countries. There is video documentation of cattle moving freely between Paraguay and Brazil in the last 2 years.  Paraguay has dealt with many FMD outbreaks.  For these reasons, I would ask the USDA not fold to the pressure of the large packing companies, and keep the  FOOD SAFTEY OF THE UNITED STATES as it's main goal.  Thank you, Bryan Hanson Ft. Pierre SD", 'Why jeopardize the livelihoods of 700,000+ farmers, ranchers and their families for the sake of huge profits for 4 multinational packers?  I invite you to western South Dakota to view what a pit full of dead cattle looks like because with the lack of borders and inspection in South America the risk will be much higher than you can fathom.  Livestock production in the U.S. is one of our last renewable resources and one of the few national industries which supports the U.S. economy; so why take a chance on further decimation of our economy just to satisfy the corporate greed of the meat packing industry.   Our industry has had enough problems with drought, disease, inflation and not to mention other government regulations and now is the time for rebuilding not dismantling our industry.   It has taken 10 years to regain our foreign markets since BSE was discovered and U.S. livestock producers do not need another financial set back.  This proposal to import beef and live cattle will not only endanger producer livelihoods but also consumer food safety.   Please abort this proposal and support the sovereignty or this great country as our fore fathers intended.', 'Please do not allow the importation of beef from Brazil. This would prove devastating to the American cattle ranchers and the risk of contaminated meat products is too great.', 'Stop this asap!!!', 'I find it very disturbing that our government claims to have been to Brazil for a fact finding mission but cannot produce any document supporting where they visited, which ranch or region and reciepts from hotels where they may have been.  As a rancher I disagree with importation of any beef or hoofed animal from  Brazil. After all Brazil has claimed to be disease free on several occasions to export to Argentina only to have the border closed by Argentina.  It appears our US government will do anything to suppress the American beef market even with the possibility of tainted meat products.', 'I write to express my opposition to the Department of Agricultures proposed amendment to allow the importation of fresh (chilled or frozen) beef from Brazil. The proposed changes set forth by the Department of Agricultures Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) puts the United States at risk for contracting foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) and does not benefit the economy in any major way. It is imperative that the risk versus reward analysis is taken into great consideration in order to secure the health of United States citizens. Up to this point, sufficient research has not been conducted in regards to cost-benefit analysis.   Although the APHIS considers the likelihood of exposure to FMD-infected species is low, the consequence assessment conducted shows severe potential impacts. Reported in the risk analysis conducted by the APHIS, The consequence of an FMD outbreak in the U.S. would be extremely highDepending on the magnitude of the outbreak and the eradication strategy, the sum of consumer impacts, direct costs and trade losses over a 25-year period, would be between US$37 billion to US$42 billion (in 2011 dollars) (APHIS, 8). FMD is still prevalent in some countries in South America and consequently there is risk of reintroduction. As a beef consumer, I do not want to consume beef that could have originated from, or commingled with, animals from affected neighboring areas.   I do not see that the benefits out weigh the costs. Not only do domestic producers take a minimal hit from foreign competition but also the United States does face a risk of contracting FMD. The United States should not be importing meat and animal products from countries that the APHIS does not consider free of FMD.  From an economic standpoint, international trade generally does benefit both countries that engage in trade.  However, because the producers will only sustain a 0.01 percent decrease in production this means the importation of beef will barely affect the United States beef economy. Yet, the risk and potential damage to human health and future trade could be very high.  For a logical and rational person, the risks of this endeavor far out-weight the benefits.  I cannot express my opposition to this amendment enough, why take such a great risk for so little reward?   If the Department of Agriculture decides to proceed with proposed changes - stringent labeling requirements should be implemented, ensuring that meat is accurately labeled with the country of origin. Consumers should be allowed to make a well-educated decision on which meat they choose to buy. The Department of Agriculture should also consider a plan to ensure that Brazilian methods of production are in coordination with U.S. standards and regulations.   The APHIS suggests that the continuation of current regulations will result in no change in the potential impact on the human environment. With the current regulation in place the United States has maintained low disease risks and negligible environmental effects. I believe the high-risk potentials are a strong deterrent and are sufficient for continuing the restriction on the importation of Brazilian beef.', 'I feel that this proposal to import fresh and chilled beef from 14 states in Brazil is anti-American, irresponsible and dangerous. It will increase our risk of introducing FMD, destroy US cattle markets, and drive even more U.S. cattle producers out of business. Please do not open our borders to Brazil and ruin the livelihoods of our US cattle producers!', 'The USDA proposal to import fresh and chilled beef from 14 states in Brazil is anti-American, irresponsible and dangerous. It will increase our risk of introducing FMD, destroy our cattle markets, and drive even more U.S. cattle producers out of business. Our country is in enough of a turmoil without ruining the US Cattle Market, and bringing FMD to our soil and livestock!', 'This cannot happen! We have eliminated FMD from our herds and cannot open the door to a country with a known, documented, ongoing, disease problem.', 'As dairy farmers in New York State, we are against importing beef from Brazil where it is known that they have hoof and mouth disease and a reported mad cow case. Where livestock are free to travel in and out of Paraguay which has a significant problem with FMD. The importation of beef from Brazil not only affects our livelihood it affects the beef and dairy industry as well as our country.', 'I am absolutely opposed to the import of Brazilian beef into our food chain. The figures and statistics that the USDA has configured and said would be such an "inconsequential difference" in beef prices, are very pertinent to the American rancher. We struggle through droughts, then get socked with a killer blizzard that killed thousands of cattle and then the government wants to import beef in that has in the past, been known for FMD. We need to support our own country\'s food producers in every aspect. It really does not matter what kind of testing they have done in Brazil to make sure their beef is safe for our country or theirs, all it takes is one missed animal in the mix and we have just introduced a big problem into our country. I really do not trust the USDA inspections that much to guarantee that would not happen. Can you? We American ranchers take pride in our cattle and the meat that is processed from them. Is it honestly fair to say that Brazil has the same standards and the same pride in their product? To put it bluntly, NO to the Brazilian imports, America cannot afford it!', "As a US consumer, I am frustrated that you would consider importing beef from ANY country that suffers from foot and mouth disease.  Our beef industry is suffering enough from horrible cattle loss over the past years due to drought and deadly snow  storms.  Now you want to add another possible disaster. I believe we need to grow our own beef so let's put some of our farmers and ranchers back to work here in the US growing up our beef stock.  Say NO to bringing in beef from  Brazil.  We can't afford another disaster for our beef industry.  Sincerely, L. Black", 'As a 4th generation rancher, a former Inspector for a government regulatory agency, and an Educator, I oppose the importation of uncooked meat from Brazil, or any country with the same history of Hoof and Mouth Disease.   I was involved in past efforts to identify products containing meat from those countries, remove them from sale, and prevent their importation into the United States to prevent animal diseases to wreak havoc on the livestock producers of this country.  Likewise, I opposed the creation of a new research facility in Kansas, near countless stocker and cow-calf operators, to replace Plum Island.  As one of the last outbreaks in the U.K. was linked to a nearby HMD research facility, I am skeptical as to our ability to prevent something from going wrong.  As I tell my "kids": 1. Have a contingency plan in case something goes wrong. and 2. Something always goes wrong. Finally, as a rancher who must consider the possibility that I may be biased due to economics, I have kept these cows through drought, ice storms, heat waves, floods that washed out fences, frozen my nose and toes, pulled calves in the mud at 2:00 A.M., fed in darkness for weeks on end, and all the rest of the usual hardships we face.  Now that the market is finally showing a  profit, I\'d like to see the American ranchers get the income they have earned without the government taking steps to reduce the value of our beef.', 'I believe that our society in America doesn\'t need imported food resources from another country such as Brazil. America has great beef sources all of the country. The state of Texas is the leading state in America for beef production. We have clean production of beef in the USA. "We The People" cant risk contaminated resources from another country, as we ourselves have just overcome major disease.', 'As a producer I strongly oppose allowing Brazilian Beef into the United States for multiple reasons.  We know of the hysteria that can occur with even an appearance of disease in the food supply.  I have seen pictures of whole herds of cattle that were destroyed, burned in pits and then buried from FMD.  I am young enough I did not see it personally, but how can our lawmakers even consider taking this risk?  Why are we required to ID our livestock and secure a safe supply and on the other hand import beef from an area where a known, very infectious disease, is present?    The other reason has to do with the cost of production which has risen sharply in the last 10 years.  The private, family owned operation is struggling to stay afloat and they do not need the government allowing a "cheaper" form of beef into the country while at the same time increasing the difficulty of domestic production by increasing regulations and taxes.  We are a medium sized family ranch that has operated for 125 years.  We have made it through hard times in the past, high interest rates, drought, inheritance tax, blizzards, all the hardships inherent in this industry.  We do not need more obstacles thrown at us.', 'I would encourage APHIS to not allow the importation of beef, beef products, or other meat sources from animals with the potential of bringing the devistating Hoof and Mouth disease pathogen into the U.S. Our family has been raising beef and ranching in the U.S. since 1882 in what was then Dakota Territory. We have worked hard and endured many problems along the way but have continued to provide cheap, healthy food for the American people and now people of the world. If we open this up we are risking our own safe food supply but our ability to sell to other countries. We also are very involved as a hunting outfitter that works hard to increase wildlife and habitat. Opening this up could also cause disaster for our wildlife populations and ruin our outdoor lifestyle for the American people.', 'We have adequate safe beef right here at home, and do not need their beef. If we do let it in then let us have the COOL in place so consumers know where their beef is coming from.', "I'm a rancher's daughter.  Please don't hurt our American farmers and ranchers by importing Brazilian beef.  You do know they have foot and mouth disease there, don't you?  Are you vegetarian or just dumb?  This is a ridiculous and dangerous option and one which will do America and her people only harm.  I'm opposed.", "Why do you want to implement such a critical situation to an industry that continues to do the best to keep our food safe and healthy for the people from all over the world?  Is there implementation in place that every carcass be checked for drugs that are not allowed in this country? United States producers do our very best to bring to the people that buy our products the very best that can be produced, safe, affordable, and worthy of a product of the USA stamp.   We are cattle and food producers for the world, they buy our products for a reason SAFETY they know what we produce is the best, that's why they buy it. What purpose is their in bringing in a product from a country that has a hard time regulating their own product? Why can't they get anyone who wants to import their product directly from their own country? Why do they have to go through our markets, and drive down prices that we as cattle producers have worked tirelessly for years to bring to our own markets?    Thank you", "We are very much opposed to allowing the importation of fresh beef from Brazil.   The risk of foot and mouth disease entering the US is too great.   Even if those 14 states are safe, the borders between them and other areas that could have FMD are too fluid and porous to take the chance.  Do we really want to take the chance of destroying the U.S. beef industry for what APHIS says would be less than 1% of the total U.S. beef imports?   We own and raise commercial beef and take pride in supplying a safe and nutritious product for consumers.  Please don't gamble with the US beef industry.", 'Allowing beef to be imported into the U.S. from a country with Foot and Mouth is crazy.  How can the U.S. guarantee that fresh meat from only approved Brazilian states will be from only approved Brazilian states.  You mean to tell me that the Brazilian government can guarantee that no affected animals for infected states will cross the borders from one state to another, dream on.   The USDA is risking the U.S. beef industry on a guess that we wont import affected meat products.  This is the same USDA and the same experts that called South Korea Foot and Mouth free a month before there was an outbreak and they were killing and burying animals. I have a question, does this beef trade deal have anything to do with the wool payments the U.S. is making to Brazilian farmers from the WTO ruling against the U.S. from several years ago.  I know the U.S. wants that to go away.  Is this the trade off, taking questionable beef from a country that has Foot and Mouth and risking our entire beef industry in the process, stop this madness.  Rick Keith', 'This is from Drovers;     ... A long-running cotton trade dispute, brought by Brazil against the U.S. at the World Trade Organization (WTO), resulted in a ruling by the WTO that Brazil could impose countermeasures against the U.S. that included a fixed amount of $147.3 million for cotton payments and an amount for export credit guarantees that vary based on program usage related to U.S. cotton subsidies. In April of this year, U.S. trade representatives met with Brazilian officials to negotiate a settlement in an effort to avoid the imposition of counter-measures on U.S. cotton. The negotiated settlement included a U.S. agreement to publish a rule recognizing the Brazilian State of Santa Catarina as free of FMD...  What is really behind the USDA allowing a country with Foot and Mouth to enter the U.S. markets.', 'If the import of meat is allowed from Brazil. I think we should ask for the disbanding of the USDA. I think they have always been a thorn and of no value to the hard working ranchers. The funds used in their support could very well be spent on better management tools. Lloyd Olbricht', 'Importation of beef from Brazil is a poor decision, not only because of the risk of Foot-and-Mouth Disease, but also because cattle in Brazil graze primarily in the rainforest, or better said, areas that used to be rainforest before cattle grazing.   Thank you.', 'I am opposed to the importation of beef from any region in Brazil due to the risk of contacting FMD into the herds of America. There should be zero risk tolerance in allowing any foreign disease from entering the USA. Even one incidence of this disease into the livestock of the US would devastate the industry over night causing untold millions of dollars to be lost and untold cost in mitigation that would take years to remedy. Do not allow Brazil or any other country with known disease risk to import beef into America!!', "As a cattle producer, raising high quality Limousin (Lim-Flex) cattle is our goal. Since we also raise our animals according to organic practices, we must adhere to a high standard of herd health without the use of antibiotics and many feed additives common in the industry. We have unique genetics that would be lost forever if our herd was to be destroyed by an outbreak or quarantine. Allowing live cattle to be imported from a Brazil, a country with a current history of foot-and-mouth disease, is far too risky. Please don't jeopardize the US' reputation as a producer of high quality, safe, affordable beef. The short term benefits of lower domestic beef prices do not make up for the potential losses if foot-and-mouth is to get a foothold here again. American beef is cheap enough.", 'Now is not the time for the United States to be even considering allowing Brazilian beef into the economy. With the Natural National Disaster known as Blizzard Atlas damaging the rural way of life, and the heartland of america, the livelihood of many families is in danger with the cattle market being as gratious as it is. With tens of thousands of producing cattle taken away from us ranchers, we can not handle the chance of disease scares and inaddicuet beef to flood our market. Please take into consideration the rancher when you make your decision. I am 24 years old and am trying to build a ranch, a family, and a future. After I lost 26 cows, 2 yearlings and 3 calves (with the value of $65000) , my chances of fullfilling my life long dream of being a rancher is slim to none if the cattle market takes a turn for the worse. Please make a decision that the american cowboy would be proud of.  Thank you sicerely Cole Elshere.', 'The disease potential is to great to allow imports.  There is no way to effectively monitor or prevent the diseases on the imports.', 'Too much risk to import meat from a country with past history of Foot and Mouth Disease. Would country of origin be placed on end product so consumers would be in the know?', "Please don't allow imported beef or any other meats from Brazil. We need to support our own farmers and ranchers. Let boost our own economy by supporting us within our boarders. If something were to contaminate imported meats it would be pure devastation.", 'I am a US cattle/beef producer opposed to beef imports from Brazil. There is no reason to knowingly endanger the health and safety of our American population, both bovine and human, by importing beef from a country known to have FMD. Further, it will compromise profitability for US cattle producers, many of whom already operate with very thin profit margins. Importation of Brazilian beef could eventually cause further dependence on foreign suppliers for our American food supply, and it would be hard to imagine any American citizen or politician thinking that would be an optimal situation.', "We need to remember that agriculture is a major component of our economy. If we start importing beef we are opening ourselves up to multiple risks. If Foot and Mouth disease were to re-enter our country it would wipe out the lively hood of several farmers and kill the economy of several states. I think this is a terrible idea. Quit exporting all our beef and sustain our country first and we wouldn't have to worry about importing more beef. Herds are rebuilding, which in turn will increase supply. Protect our country!", 'My name is Melissa Livingston.   I was raised in a family who has been in the cattle industry for 40 plus years.  I still own and raise American beef and I strongly oppose the imports from Brazil and Argentina.   I feel that we would open our industry up to diseases and dangers that could drastlcly affect our ability to produce top quality product.   Argentine beef in particular is not inspected and the rules if enforced by a very corrupt government  are not strict enough to be safe to import any beef from that country.', 'I feel as if it is an unnecessary risk you are taking in importing beef and beef products from Brazil.  This is area is severely contaminated with Hoof and Mouth disease and I absolutely do not agree with your decision.  I would strongly recommend that you reconsider your course of action on this matter.', "As a beef producer I oppose the proposition to import beef from the Brazilian region. We work hard here in the United States to produce a quality product for our consumers and strive to maintain healthy livestock herds. To allow under regulated and potentially harmful meat products into the U.S. would be insolent to our country's livestock producers. We must first look after the economical health of our nations agricultural markets and think twice about allowing lower quality imports to come into our country.", 'As a beef producer we work hard to raise the best meat in the world for our people to take home to there families.  Allowing this Brazil beef in would be insane and a blow to the hole food industry in the United States.  It is not safe like are meat is.  DON"T ALLOW it in our borders.  We don\'t need there diseases to destroy our ways of making a living.  Thank you', "This is an interesting proposal being that the USDA is wanting to bring potentially dangerous beef into the United States and compete with American beef which is getting harder and harder to raise. Cattle feeding in general appears to be being taken over by corporate yards that can withstand an off year where as your smaller guys would most likely be out of the business if all the sudden the value of their inventory was reduced fifteen, twenty, even thirty percent (which the USDA wont admit but will happen). By no means am i an expert on the topic but it looks to me like one of the worlds largest international meat packers is trying to strong arm the USDA into this sweet arrangement where they bring in high risk beef from Brazil purchased and raised dirt cheap and mark them up to your local grocery stores. In the mean time your american based farmers will be forced to take a major hit, declare bankruptcy or even feed them personally and export their product if that's their only option to come out on the plus side. Another angle to look at is that it is a win win scenario for the major packers who will not only be making a killing off of Brazil but also buying the same cattle here significantly cheaper than in years past. Personally i would like to see the American beef producer thrive and generate the necessary income to expand and serve nothing but a safe, quality product raised on our own soil, benefiting our economy from the ground up. If you look at raising a calf from step one to the dinner plate there is a lot of money trading hands before the animal is even conceived. Just a quick scenario that could take place...So i want to get in the cattle business all of the sudden...I am going to first have to either buy or lease land (taxable), go out and purchase a set of cows (valued from one to two thousand dollars), go buy enough bulls to guarantee all of your females conceive, buy all necessary vaccines and means to keep the animals alive (this can get very expensive and again taxable), and most importantly buy the necessary feed to keep them moving. So now you have a bred cow. From there you have roughly ten months of labor, bills, and variables that are making it harder and harder everyday. I think by all means we need those dollars trading hands here not there. Brazil has enough cattle that if we wanted to serve only Brazilian beef we most likely could but again i don't think this is the direction we want to go. Compare it to Apple using China's work force to make I pads. Yes, they are made cheaper but hardly any of those salaries wind up benefiting our economy. Yes, Apple makes more money but you, me and the millions of unemployed are without the to chance to contribute. If anything we should vamp up production here and smooth things out with China and
column5: ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:  \xa0  The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress. \xa0  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products that have not demonstrated similar risks. \xa0  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard', "Please do not ban buckyballs or zen magnets. It makes no sense to ban such a amazing toy when just because of the fear of safety. The toy itself commits no intentional harm and if you ban these tiny magnets you might as well ban everything that is small and can cause harm to the youth. It isn't the governments place to ban such things, only to regulate them. Please don't turn our nation into a regulating overly controlling regime.", "Hi, I am writing this request in regards to the proposed rule banning the sale of loose magnet sets. I understand that this is in response to a few terrible instances of buckyballs (small round magnets) resulting in a child's injury, due to parental neglect. I am all for warnings being added to the labels for the parents who aren't smart enough to monitor their kids. But a ban in ridiculous.  Do not hinder free market for the sake of a few idiots.  Anyone who has ever used buckyballs knows how strong they are and that any standard toddler would try to eat them. But by all means add the warnings anyways, just don't make everyone suffer for the ignorance of a few individuals.", 'I would to register opposition to proposed rules banning magnetic spheres due to safety concerns.  This ruling is unnecessarily strict and out of proportion with the scale of the problem.  Sufficient safety concerns can be addressed with warning labels and age restrictions.', 'Pediatric gastroenterologists and surgeons have a high level of concern for ingested magnets of all types.  High powered magnets in the form of easily swallowed toys are very dangerous.  Anytime a magnet is ingested with another magnet or a metal item, a patient is at risk of having these 2+ items stick together.  Subsequently, 2 parts of the digestive tract can be "stuck" together, create pressure necrosis, and possibly bowel perforation. Bowel perforation can cause death.   Surgeons and GI doctors have always retrieved 2+ magnets in the past for this danger.  The "Bucky Balls" high powered type magnets have caused a great increase in the number of bad outcomes due to these particularly magnets being ingested.  They are particularly strong and cause damage much more quickly.   For an item that is solely used for entertainment, I can\'t imagine that the PUBLIC would want something so dangerous in their homes. This product needs to be banned.', 'Please don\'t ban buckyballs(and other magnet toys), there are clear warnings on the side of the box that say that it is an adult toy ans should be treated like one. I love them and would be greatly disappointed to see them go. They make sure you know not to give them to children and if you do it is entirely your fault! There is a danger, yes. but doesn\'t every toy have a danger? toys come with "small parts" warning yet there are no issues with them! Please, buckyballs(and other magnet toys) don\'t deserve this if they come with appropriate warnings and signage! They are fun and innovative and very stress relieving. I hope I have made my point!', "This is really ridiculous. The government should stop trying to legislate people's own stupidity and personal lives, and get back to the important things.", "I have not heard of any instances where Zen magnets, or any of it's competitors have been responsable for any injury, illness, or casualties due to indiscretion of their products.  Therefore, they couldnt possibly be such a risk to require banning of their sale or even their production.", "The shear idiocy of this ban bewilders me. Parents should be responsible enough to keep these away from their children and if not, shouldn't have children. Do you ban household cleaners because they are poisonous if ingested? NO, they are kept clear of children.", 'These magnets should not be banned. Used properly, they are a good source of education.', 'Labeling is sufficient. The rest comes down to bad parenting.', 'Save our magnets. Quit regulating every small part of out lives. There are many other more dangerous things to worry about.', "This is the most ludicrous ban I've ever heard proposed.  So because some lazy parent couldn't watch his kid I can't buy a cool educational toy anymore?    These magnets have tons of educational and valuable uses.  And proposing to ban them because of lazy parents is frankly insulting.  I hear young children choke on steak and other type foods in their parents are silly enough to give it to them.  Where's the ban on steak?  I child could choke on the plug of my USB cable, are you going to ban my phone?  Have some pride and self respect and stop wasting time and pointless laws like this.", 'this is ridiculous!  Parents need to show some responsibility.  The government cannot and should not regulate everything.  I enjoy the magnets and I do not want to see these banned.', "I'm totally against this ban. It's entirely baseless epidemiologically. If they apply the same logic to almost any product out there, it qualifies to be banned. Why is buckyballs being singled out? They are targeting adult consumers, have labels all over the products. If parents are careless, why should buckyball pay the price. Even without warnings, parents should be able to tell what is potentially dangerous at home, and keep that out of reach of little children.   The CPSC should stop being senseless and shifts its attention to real killers like cigarettes. They should show their muscles on big tobacco, but they obviously cannot stand up to those criminals, and choose to target (unfoundedly) small business owners instead. Well done.", 'Banning loose magnetic spheres due to a fear of consumption is comparable to proposing a ban on glass shards, insects, all poisonous chemicals used for cleaning purposes. The inherent risk of an inanimate object being dangerous due to misuse is prevalent in all products, not exclusive to magnets. This level of regulation will not reduce the chances of someone ingesting a ferrous substance since magnetism exists in nearly all facets of modern, industrial use.  Have we, as a society, stooped to a level where every item and tool must be checked for sharp edges, consumable sizes, and likelihood of causing the most minute of damages? How would it appear on a global front, that our country has such a poor education that our population is incapable of basic survival? The solution to the cited incidents through banning will be ineffective and and non-permanent. If magnets have become so dangerous to us, we have bigger problems to worry about.  ===== This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'Do not regulate or ban Bucky Balls, Zen Magnets, or anything similar. They are properly labelled, not intended for children, and the number of children who manage to ingest them is negligible in comparison to the number of children who are hurt on bikes, roller skates, and skateboards.  In fact, just the daily activities of children are significantly more dangerous than these products. Simple stairs, that are not banned or required to have warning labels are far more dangerous and cause far more injury each year than magnets do.', 'Did you know that drinking too much water can cause death? It\'s called "water intoxication." It\'s a real thing. Yet water is everywhere and we just give it to our kids! Yes, I\'m being facetious, but to prove a point. Almost anything (anything!), if used improperly can cause serious injury or death. This includes something that actually gives us life. These magnets, when used as intended, are harmless. My family and friends get hours of entertainment and creativity out of them. We find it incredibly absurd that because of some irresponsible parents, you think it\'s fair to ban everyone from acquiring them. Why not ban sugary snacks and cereals instead? I can guarantee you that those cause far more harm to far more people than a set of magnets.  Please look at this issue with a logical mind and see that it isn\'t right to punish the consumer and these companies for the irresponsable actions of the (relatively) few parents. My heart goes out to them, but I can\'t blame an inanimate object over a person who should know what they are giving their child. Especially when the websites and packaging clearly state that they are meant for adults and that they should not be ingested.', "I don't think it is reasonable to ban projects that use magnetic spheres causes un unnecessary risk to the public. We should be spending our resources on more important matters. Why should myself a responsible adult be banned from enjoying a product that has established safety programs and standards.  I also find it curious that the CPSC finds other products warning labels sufficient when they cause a higher rate on inquiry to children.   Please don't take away this safe product.", 'This ban makes no sense. This is akin to banning crossing the street because it is dangerous. People need to be responsible for themselves and the young ones in their care and around them. The Federal government has no place "protecting" me from magnets, which instead removes access to a fun learning tool.', 'I think this ban is an unnecessary regulation. These products are not unsafe. This proposed rule attempts to solve a problem that does not exist.', 'I oppose adoption of the Safety Standard for Magnet Sets. Once again, the federal government is trying to overstep its bounds and eliminate the need for personal responsibility. Our household has owned a set of small magnets for years, which we purchased as an entertainment/educational toy for our older children. We are careful to keep them out of reach of smaller children, as all astute adults should. All of us recognize that just about everything we encounter in life could be a potential danger if used in the wrong way (toothpicks, sharpened pencils, razor blades--the list goes on). However, the answer is not to simply ban all of these items. I encourage common sense and personal responsibility, not more government regulation. Thank you.', 'I love them!', 'I fully believe that the proposed rule is an insult to the common sense of consumers. There is no danger with the use of these magnets when used as directed.        Many purchasable items which have specific safe applications of use may also be used in ways which may lead to serious injury or even death. Specifically if the unadvised method of use is ingestion, the list of purchasable items which may lead to serious injury or even death is nearly infinite. Granted, many of these purchasable items (including magnet sets sold by companies such as Zen Magnets) are sold with warnings against ingestion and against the use of the item by children. As example, it would be silly to ban cleaning agents from the consumer market because a subset of the population uses them to achieve an inexpensive albeit dangerous high despite the clear warnings.         This reasoning leads me to fully agree with the following quote from Zen Magnets:       "This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:    (1) The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.   (2) The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.   (3) These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market."', 'These are a great way to educate kids, much more so than trampolines. These should absolutely not be banned.', "I'm not here to debate if the injuries caused by these magnets can be dangerous if given to children or taken care of irresponsibly.   What I am here to say, however, is that the ban of this product is nonsensical. The only thing it accomplishes is putting a legitimate US based company out of business, and will force more imports of neodymium magnets from elsewhere.   Please reconsider this ban of BuckyBalls.", "I do not see how the federal government has the grounds to monitor what private citizens purchase. These items are no more dangerous than anything that is mishandled or misused outside it's prescribed directions. it's unfortunate that some people were injured by these products, but that in no way is the responsibility of the manufacturers. It falls on the owners and parents of the children to know that this item (as they are clearly marked) are not for small children. As a parent I know what my child does and how they behave and would not for an instant believe that this products are suitable for them. That being said it's not fair to punish the many for the sins of the few.", 'Please focus your misguided efforts toward actually dangerous products, not those marketed to adults for use by adults. If the logic your organization is using is to be verified through action first, then research on effectiveness, please again focus on things that are actually causing statistically significant rates of injury, not 10 cases per 100000.', "As a science-minded person, it deeply saddens me to see this attempt to ban some of the most well-known scientific toys around. Buckyballs and zen magnets are a wonderful way to demonstrate what strong magnetism can do, and visually convey this to children and adults alike. Not only are these toys great tools for science, they are also a great stress reliever to many of my coworkers who keep them on their desks. As you can see, banning these toys would not only send a negative message to children, solidifying the line between learning and play, but it is plainly ridiculous to ban something that is so widely available and accepted in American society. I believe that warning labels for these products regarding their safety around children should be put into place, and come in a hard to open container. In closing, you can take them away from the public, but you can't take stupid out of people.", "Outlawing magnets is absurd.  Items that are not marketed to children and are plastered with warnings should not be banned due to negligent parents.  This is typical of government beurocracy, legislate common sense and put people out of work at the same time.  If I let my niece play with my kitchen knives, would you outlaw knives or call me negligent and press charges?  I own several sets of BuckyBalls and they were all very very clearly labeled as desk toys for adults.  There are many things that should be a focus of regulators, desk toys aren't one of them.", "These magnets are not marketed towards children. The fact that children are swallowing them lies with the parents/guardians of the children. They are marketed towards adults and if children are swallowing them it's because an adult bought them and then left their child unsupervised with access to the magnets.  Again, they're marketed towards adults. Any incidences where someone was damaged by a magnet sphere or spheres is the fault of an irresponsible or unintelligent individual.", 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:      The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.     The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products  that have not demonstrated similar risks.    It is absurd and inefficient to be using time and money to ban something because you don\'t trust people to do what is right.', "All that is needed here is a warning on the package.  These are not children's toys, just as cigarettes or band saws aren't children's toys.  Banning them out-right is ridiculous.", "Do away with all the pointless litigation. Make parents actually parent their kids. If they have these toys in their house and their child ingests the toy, it was not placed in a proper location away from the child. If not, allow natural selection to take place.  While you are at it, why don't we ban electrical sockets because little Johnny can place his little fingers in there and get hurt or die. The products you are looking at banning can be useful teaching tools but nobody cares about that. Stop dumbing down the world and let natural selection work, there are enough people lacking common sense in this world.", 'It is absolutely absurd that a product meant for adults with specific instruction to prevent children from playing with the product has to be taken off of the shelves because a single bad parent has thoughtlessly allow this to happen.  We cannot continue to form a Nanny State in which a person can hold others accountable for their own thoughtless actions.  This sets a precedent as bad as the now infamous McDonalds Hot Coffee case.  There are no additional safety standards needed.  How many thousands of these things have been sold?  How many children have been hurt?  The percentage is incredibly small.  Better labeling and warnings?  Sure- absolutely.  Make it clear no child under a specific age should be near these products.  But lets not over step our bounds as a society.  And lets not shut down businesses due to some bad apples.  I often joke with product development professionals (of which I am one) that in today\'s climate of over-zealous legal protection, a company could not invent the Knife, if it had never previously existed.  It is so obviously harmful, and can be nearly fatal, but is perhaps the most basic and most useful of all man made tools.  Yet if one would look at the number of wounds and deaths annually from knives, even limited to kitchen knives, the percentage rate of harm is ridiculously high.  By the standards set for these "Bucky balls" magnet toys, the knife should be banned, every last one rounded up and smelted into finger cuffs to prevent us all from harming ourselves.', 'Do not ban or restrict the sale of these magnets. If not unconstitutional, it is hypocritical. These "toys" are perfectly safe when used appropriately. Thank you.', "Why in the world should we BAN buckyballs on the basis that kids are getting hurt?  We still sell chemicals in stores.  We still sell lawnmowers.  We still sell sets of knives.  We sell *rocket engines* in hobby stores and small amounts of explosives around the 4th of July.  But you're telling me that you want to ban a set of magnets!? This is absolutely insane. Parents need to be responsible enough to tell their children not to eat the magnets. If the child is incapable of following that command, then the child should not be allowed to have the magnets to begin with. This is not a regulatory issue. This is a parenting issue.  Stop this madness.", 'I am in support of banning these small magnets that are seriously dangerous to children who continue to put small things in their mouths and swallow them unintentionally leading death or serious harm.', "To ban a product that has provided countless hours of fun for adults over the years simply because some adults are stupid enough to let children get hold of them is not only incredibly unfair, but very un-American. If we were to hold everything else to the same standards you are holding these magnets to, we would have to start banning everything that could cause harm to anyone. Cards, knives, cheeseburgers, you name it. Don't punish the rest of America because of the bad choices a few absent minded parents made.", 'Bucky Balls and Zen Magnets cannot be made illegal due to risk of injury to kids. Almost every small toy or item can be dangerous to kids if ingested. Making these illegal because of that is akin to making any small toy illegal. It is the parents responsibility to not have the child ingest them', 'I am a pediatric gastroenterologist in the United Kingdom.
