I support the ban on magnets in toys for very young children as foreign body ingestion, because of the potential hazards in children.', 'Please do not ban the sale of bucky balls or zen magnets.  These items are not targeted to young children and have plenty of warnings stating this.', 'It makes about as much sense to illegalize these toys as it does to outlaw dog poop because kids eat that and get sick all the time. Kids will always be kids, no matter what toy you give them.', 'This is ridiculous.  Trampolines cause more deaths per year than magnet ball ingestion, and those are actually marketed towards kids.  Stop this now.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:   The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.   These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'This is an abuse of power to launch an attack on a product that is meant for adults and that does not pose any significant risk when used responsibly.   It would make more sense to ban cars, pharmaceutical drugs, and gravity, all of which cause orders of magnitude more injuries and deaths than small, relatively low-power magnets. Is the insanity becoming apparent yet?', 'I think that it would be against everything American to ban these types of objects from consumers.   They are fun, educational, and useful.   Perhaps stressing the importance of safe storage and responsible use is a better alternative to banning them.   There are hundreds of potentially dangerous objects in the average household.   Reasonable use, storage, and education allow people to keep them safely, and the same should apply to the objects in question.', "Please do not propose a ban on something because people don't read the warnings .  Cigarettes get ingested by young people too, but cigarettes aren't being banned because of it.", "The move to ban certain magnetic toys like Bucky Balls is nonsensical. There are many magnetic toys with similar issues with ingestion and like many other toys is marked as not being a food source. Now amazingly, the children who are most at risk of eating magnets can't read so warning labels are insufficient. They're a fun toy and kids play with them, extremely young children like putting things in there mouth. Small toys are not for young children. Banning Bucky Balls will not have an impact on young children putting (and subsequently swallowing) things they should in their mouth. What can be done is to make sure the warning indicates it is not a childrens toy so parents do not buy them for young children (Lego is a good example of where this has been done previously before and it works; Lego also has a young children specific product line called Duplo to work around the whole mouth/swallow thing).  Children die regularly from eating coins, but we aren't banning those. Children die regularly from putting bags on their heads, but we don't ban those (instead we use warning labels that they can't read). Just like banning either coins or bags is ineffective, banning Bucky Balls is also not an effective solution.", 'This is unnecessary, the problem with this is not the product, but use/storage by the end-user. You cannot regulate stupid out of the marketplace.', 'You are idiots if you ban these.  Blame the dumb people that swallow them, not the manufacturer.  That is all.  Oh and think you for making me waste my time with this.', 'These Magnet Sets allow children to be interested in science and are not nearly as dangerous as trampolines (which are marketed to children). Please keep them!', "These magnets are not marketed towards children.  They're not advertised to them.  There are warnings on the packaging that outline the dangers of ingesting high powered magnets.  If these sets were being sold in children's toy stores, that's a problem, but otherwise I believe it is wrong to force the ban of these magnet sets.  There are many other more common household items that children can ingest that are just as dangerous, if not more dangerous.  The extremely small number of complications and deaths so far outline the limited impact of the magnets' availability.  We're always going to have outlier cases... but these do not necessitate a complete ban.  A ban would be overreaching and punish the creativity and success of the manufacturers.", "Don't ban them, just make them harder to buy.", "It is unacceptable to ban a product that some may have hurt themselves with. Personal responsibility is required from the moment one wakes till the moment one sleeps. I implore you not to ban a product so many people enjoy because others cannot manage their children's actions.", 'I oppose this proposed rule. As a tax payer I want my taxes to be used in a RESPONSIBLE manor. The associated lawsuit with companies selling magnets is NOT a responsible use of taxes. Furthermore, the possible restrictions from the CPSC winning the lawsuit or passing the proposed rule will take one more freedom away; as minor as it is, it is still a freedom. I demand that the CPSC immediately cease and desist these actions against these companies. Though the injuries caused by accidents and disregarding warnings are unfortunate, it should remain the responsibility of the owner of the magnets to use them in a safe manner and to keep from children. The responsibility should remain on the people.  A responsibility that is lost or taken is one more freedom gone.', "Banning these magnets is stupid and controlling and shouldn't even be an issue.", 'Please recognize the practical application these toy magnets have for independent research. The magnets that come in these toy sets are readily available, and strong enough to be used for experimentation.  Classifying the set as an adult toy seems like a reasonable solution to a consumer health issue.', "This lawsuit filed by the CPSC is effectively removing parental responsibility. These products are marketed to Adults only, and able to be purchased by adults only. There are several warnings, and the packaging can only be removed by an adult (unless said child has access to knives/scissors, a safety issue of it's own)   Parents should ultimately be responsible for their children's well being. Do not punish companies for the Parents failure to teach their children", "I think it's ridiculous for the government to ban the production of a product simply because IF its misused by the consumer it could result in the injury of a minor. It should be the responsibility of  the consumer to make sure the magnets are never in the hands of children who don't understand the dangers of misuse. Furthermore the governments banning of magnet sets will have a major negative impact on the economy as a whole.", 'I strongly disagree with banning these magnets.  I understand that they may be harmful, however, they are not intended for children and include warning labels as such.  I have a set of magnets such as these in my house.  I do not let my kids near them.  I also have guns, knives, space heaters, candles and such and do not let my kids near those either.  Many of those things would be a tempting "toy" just like these magnets.  However, I do not believe that an item with a high potential to be perceived as a toy to a young child warrants it being banned.  My son recently cut his finger on a pair of scissor manufactured and marketed towards children.  Do we need to ban those?  Or perhaps I should have taken on a little more parental responsibility.  Additionally I feel that this is a government intrusion.  Here we have a product marketed towards adults, that is now being banned due to a relatively low injury rate (as stated in another comment) which is .06%, taking into account injuries that occured before warning labels and better consumer education went in place.  There was no due process before the CSPC convinced major retailers to stop carrying these products which I think is totally unfair to companies manufacturing these items, especially given the fact that these companies already complied with requests to add warning labels and change their marketing.  What really confounds me though, and with all sincerity I am at a loss with this one, is why the CSPC chooses to ban these magnets and not ban backyard swimming pools and bathtubs.  I understand guns, that is not under their control.  However, on the CSPC website there is a ton of information and studies on the dangers of pools/tubs and the huge numbers of child deaths that I was not aware of until now.  We are talking over 80 child deaths a year by CSPC\'s own admission and many times that in injuries, many of which involve brain damage.  By their own admission a tub/pool is more dangerous than these magnets.', "This should not be a discussion on the dangers of magnets, but a discussion as to why the CPSC wants to show off its power and claim that warnings labels aren't effective for these magnets. Warning labels are included on everything from children's McDonald's toys, to plastic packaging, to kitchen knives, to cigarettes, to your common household cleaners. But the CPSC doesn't claim we should get rid of all these items as well. It is up to consumers heed warning labels and recognize risks. Not the CPSC to ban all magnet spheres.  Even Nancy Nord, the CPSC's own most expe

column2: ems. Perhaps more  disturbing is that these captive elephants display behaviors such as swaying and  head bobbing, which indicate extreme stress.  Circus elephants have it the worst; they often are made to stand in chains for 21  hours a day, and most of the year they must travel in uncomfortable boxcars in  extreme temperatures, standing in their own waste. Zoo animals are also subject  to chaining and confinement. Circuses and many zoos control elephants through  unnecessary and cruel instruments such as bullhooks, whips, clubs, and electric  shock devices. These must be outlawed.  There are two refuges in America that provide natural environments for elephants:  The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  (PAWS) sanctuary in California. They both provide hundreds of thousands of acres  for elephants to roam and socialize naturally, as they would in the wild, and live a  healthy, stress-free life. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide such  habitats for them.", 'To whom it may concern:  While many of us may appreciate the appropriate display of select charismatic megafauna in zoos and other venues for the purposes of education, it has become increasingly clear over the years that a number of facilities have chosen to display elephants in order to increase the number of visitors. Unfortunately, it has also become clear that the size of these animals is not always dealt with in an appropriate fashion, causing the animals to suffer.  While this sort of thing may have been acceptable decades in the past, we have learned a great deal as to the nature of these animals and the degree to which they suffer as a function of their confines. While some zoos and entertainment venues contend that their facilities are adequate, it is clear that a few- perhaps one or two- have enough space to allow natural, relatively unconfined behavior. In the absence of adequacy, elephants are reduced to walking on concrete, or are held in tiny patches of earth- frequently only during those months of the year when it is sufficiently warm. Still others reduce elephants to being used for entertainment such as for rides, as with Six Flags Marine World, whose flatly inexcusable trail of elephant mortality should have caused them to lose whatever licenses they have by now. Equally unacceptable is the confinement of solitary animals such as that kept at the Alaska Zoo, which must be kept indoors for months at a time.  For too long the emphasis has been on maintaining elephants as if they were livestock, rather than highly sensitive and remarkably intelligent charges that demand far more space and specialized care than can be maintained at the majority of facilities that currently tend to these animals in the United States. I urge you to take action requiring dramatically increased outdoor space per animal, as well as improved facilities for indoor storage when and where necessary. I recommend comments as put forth by In Defense of Animals to be something we can strive for in order to properly care for those elephants maintained in captivity.', 'All animals need better treatment and people to speak out for them. Animal  activists are not terrorists!!!', 'Elephants do NOT belong in circuses AT ALL and should be released from ALL  circuses in the United States to approved humane sanctuaries, where they will get  the proper nutrition/medical care, dignity, respect and love that these massive  giants deserve.  Elephants do  not belong in zoos, either.  However, if a zoo  follows and obeys the Animal Welfare Act and provides many acres of ground for  elephants to roam free, with natural foliage/trees that mimics the elephants natural  habitat in the wild, then that is acceptable.    As it is today, most zoos provide scant space for elephants, most of it is on  concrete, where they become arthritic and suffer pain, social deprivation, unnatural  conditions, and forced abnormal behavior by brutal forms of abuse.  Wild  elephants live in familial groups headed by a matriarch, babies stay with their  mothers over two years, they travel many miles a day on the ground, NOT  CONCRETE.   All forms of torture should be explicitly banned such as bullhooks,  tasers, stun guns, whips, chains and domination.  Elephants should NEVER be  made to "perform" for the amusement of humans.  They should not be locked in  barns,  stalls or other small enclosures.  They should have a veterinarian and  animal nutritionist trained specifically in elephant medical care, who is aware of  the many foot problems that can affect these massive animals in captivity.  In short, unless a zoo is willing to go to extraordinary lengths and expense to  provide elephants everything they need in a natural environment, then the zoo  should be forced to release their elephants to The Elephant Sanctuary in TN or the  PAWS in CA.  I happen to be a long-time donating member of both charitable  organizations.', 'I am commenting on the issue related to elephant care of captive elephants for the  following reasons: 1) Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses  currently meet this requirement.   2) In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space,  but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range  of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.   3) An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   4) Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   5) Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', 'I think that the use of bullhooks on elephants should be made illegal.  I also think  that to chain up an elephant is cruel and legislation should be made that limits the  amount of time an elephant can be chained or housed alone.  Elephants live inteh  wild in herds and when they are alone they get stressed and upset.  Sometimes  they go mad and stand their lifeless or exhibit self destructive behavior.   ANyone who owns an elephant should be required to provide it with a large area of  land to roam on.  They should be housed in accomodations that simulate their  natural environment and should never be kept alone.  They should have access to  a variety of enrichment activities and materials to keep them mentally nourished.   Furthermore, there should be strict fines and punishments imposed for owners  who do not comply withe these standards.  Elephants are beautiful, intelligent  creatures and they should be treated with the utmost repect and care.  Their lives  should be made as normal as possible so that they can live a  life that closely  resembles the one they would have had in the wild.  It is our duty as citizens and  lawmakers that their welfare is looked after.', "Elephants don't belong in the circus or in a Zoo that can't provide enough space or  care for such large animals.  The use of force, i.e., bullhooks, chains, electric  hotshots, and other instruments, are clearly inhumane and should be a very strong  indicator that these animals do not do well in enforced captivity.  Their life spans  are shorter and there have been more and more instances of elephants rebelling  and hurting people.  Of course, it's the animal, who has been so abused, that pays  the ultimate price.  Please do all you can to help these intelligent animals.", 'I am deeply committed to our planet, to the wild places, wild life and  elements/components that matter - because of their functionality (our human  sustenance and continued life on Earth) and their intrinsic beauty.  But mostly for  their beauty.  We all know that once humans screw everything up and there is no  more HUMAN life on Earth, there will be life on Earth, it just won\'t look like it does  now or include us.  Meanwhile, there is growing awareness, albeit a little late, that we have a mandate  to change our behavior to hopefully offset what is now termed "global warming,"  among other things.    I have been an environmentalist all my life.  It started at a young age because my  parents would take us on vacations that consisted of places like Sequoia National  Park, Kings Canyon, Yosemite, Mammoth, Big Sur, Carmel, etc.  I was blessed  then and still am now that I have my own family.  We try to do the same type of  trips with our daughter.  My love for Earth has always infused me with deep passion and unspeakable  rapture - a sense that our Earth is our Heaven on Earth - that the places I love so  much are the cathedrals in which I could not only find God, but find my love for all  things natural - including humans and other animals.    Not surprisingly, my mother - 50% of the inspiration known as my parents - picked  up and brought in every stray animal near the hills where we lived in Southern  California.    Our devotion to our pet cats and dogs was probably not too unusual,  but she, like I, became increasingly more aware and concerned after learning  about primates from Dr. Leaky and his family and chimps from Jane Goodall.  She  became an activist and began with first educating herself and becoming a docent  at the Los Angeles Zoo.  Eventually, she became a specialist in endangered  species and the elected docent chair with GLAZA, the Greater Los Angeles Zoo  Association.    My devotion and dedication to animals and all things environmental really became  imprinted when I saw, in the early seventies, footage of a whale being harpooned  and the crazy Greenpeace activists putting themselves in danger to try to protect  it.  Something clicked in my head and said these guys are the heroes of the  world.  The corporations of today might call them "terrorists," as they are  interfering with a money making venture.  However, I have always seen the  terrorists as the whalers - be they Norwegian, Japanese, or from Spain - the  results are the same - the beautiful and gloriously graceful beings have been  brutally murdered - and put on the brink of extinction - by us humans...  And it isn\'t  necessary or morally without penalty.    We, as the dominant beings on this planet, are creating an imbalanced world by  not observing common, natural law.  And that is that we must observe the natural  web that exists if we are to continue to exist.  Ultimately, it is that simple.  We  have everything to loose if we do not stop and reassess our behavior and  arrogance.  We must or it will kill us.  So it is that I approach this particular docket APHIS-2006-0044.  All animals are  magnificent and none more important or special then the next.  However, there are  few more sweet and loving and family orientated than the Elephant.  They are  special and dear to me and to so many.  I am seriously upset about the recent  death of Rosie at the Los Angeles Zoo and my mother would have been an active  part of protesting Rosie\'s situation - along with the other two - at the LA Zoo and  would have been in total pain and anger had she learned about the regrettable and  avoidable loss.    Elephants are very social - namely they love their children, their friends and their  mates.  They love to go out for long walks together.  They love to play and do as  they please.  Just like us.  Containment in areas that do not allow this not only  dampens their spirits but is actually detrimental to their health.  Just like it would  be for us.    One of the things my mother knew is that Zoos are problematic, too.  Learning  about endangered species, she saw the need to have places to educate and  inspire people about animals but she also saw the problems associated with  putting an animal - a free, living thing, behind bars for the sake of our education or,  worse, entertainment.  I learned how circuses are evil for the treatment of the  animals (namely the elephants) and how inhumanely and even sadistically they  are handled so that there will be a "show tonight."   It is a crime against our  humanity, if you will, to mistreat another being.  It should be a crime to destroy the  habitats that wild animals need to survive if not thrive.  And it is a crime to put  something as large as an elephant in a contained site and have them chained for  any length of time.  This is an outrage!  And on behalf of my mother, I ask that we  create laws that punish animal abusers for a long, long time.    In the case of Elephants, which are so unique in size and are specific not just to  zoos, but to circuses, we should create new laws that govern their management  and wellbeing.  We are responsible for their death and demise if we do not take an  extreme stand on their behalf as they are not designed for the manner in which  they are presented when in a zoo or a circus.  We are more advanced and have  become more conscience about animals over the last 100 years as we see them  more than prey or entertainment, but as essential to the web of our lives and as  part of the whole that we are included in.    I ask that we mandate all elephants currently in zoos and circuses be moved to  the elephant sanctuary and or the one in California.  We also must recognize that  the businesses that do this, voluntarily hopefully, and by court order if necessary,  be given some type of acknowledgement - either a financial reward or  governmental grant of some kind - something to compensate them and recognize  their great commitment to the beautiful struggle known as animal awareness and  stewardship.  It is time that we reevaluate our relationship to this Earth and our  four legged, winged, and fish.  It would be a great new day when we are deeply  committed to our planet and its entire population - not just our own.  Thank you.   PS - So, to be brief, at the end, I do not believe that we should be shipping and  storing Elephants, period.  They should be kept in the wild because of their simple  yet specific needs.  Space.  Family.  And no harsh treatment by humans.', "I'm Asking the USDA to create tough new standards, and institute  the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only  one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act  should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other  instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate- appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to  those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare  Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres  where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Please, bring us up to date. Please start here to return  us to the caring country we seem to have lost.', 'It is time to help, save, protect and take care of these wonderful creatures!', 'To Whom It May Concern:  I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive  elephants in the U.S. It is such a horriblel life for this gentle giants. Forced to live  in enclosures that are to small for them so we can be entertained. If we are going  to continue this outdated practice, we should be humane about it.   I strongly urge the USDA to improve enforcement and standards for captive  elephants in the U.S.Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions  they require for their health and well-being. Elephants are big animals who need  big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space,  unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and  digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  To make matters worse, many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least  12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are  confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres  over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.', 'I want to request that the USDA take steps to dramatically improve the conditions  of captive elephants in this country.  Most zoos and circuses are not giving  elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being, and while  some are making efforts to improve their facilities, there is a need for the USDA to  set standards for all.  The USDA should rigorously enforce existing adequate  space requirements, and in addition should create new, higher standards of  elephant care that would (1) prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, shock devices  and other instruments of force against elephants, and (2) require exhibitors of  elephants to provide larger, climate-appropriate, and naturalistic environments  similar to sanctuaries like PAWS in California and The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee.  The time is right ... I implore you to act now to improve conditions for  these magnificent animals!!', 'I am very concerned about the living conditions and space currently provided for  elephants in captivity at zoos and in circuses. Animals as large as elephants  suffer greatly from inadequate excersize, space or proper flooring. Regulations  need to be enforced providing much larger enclosures, with soft surfaces, for  elephants in zoos. Elephant sanctuaries like The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California are examples that should  modeled after. The use of elephants in circuses needs to be prohibited as it is  never possible to transport such massive animals in a humane way. The use of  bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force used in  circuses are extremely cruel and must be outlawed.', 'Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses  provide elephants with adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  Many zoos lock their elephants in barn  stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos,  elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter  months.  Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through  force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining.  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force must be outlawed.', "I'm a concerned citizen (who ALWAYS votes) and I'm begging that we do the right  thing for these noble animals.", 'Please end the needless suffering of elephants in U.S. zoos and circuses. I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California which provide hundreds of acres over which  elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force and abuse.  Why the USDA must take action:   1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. Too often they suffer from lack  of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range  of preventable ailments from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and  digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in stalls for 12 hours or more when the zoo is  closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods  during the cold winter months.   5. Circuses and zoos often control their elephants through force and aggressive  use of the bull hooks and prolonged chaining. These methods cause constant  stress as well as physical and psychological injury.  6. Because of their intelligence and unique social and physical needs, elephants  endure endless suffering in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Elephants  need and deserve much higher standards.', 'It is important that these enforcement standards be enacted, to prevent  abuse/neglect. Please help the elephants maintian their exsistence.', 'I?m appalled by the exploitation of the elephants by zoos and circuses. The cruelty and deprivation of the elephants in circuses is obvious to everyone  who has even a speck of compassion and reason, but the zoos don?t fare better. After the death of the 3 elephants at LPZ  which, I hope, will never get a permit to  house another elephant, I visited a few other zoos to compare their enclosures. Here are my observations:  The Brookfield zoo prides itself to have a miserable .25 acre ? a joke! The winter enclosures are not much bigger then the average living room and that?s  the standard for the elephants in cold climates ?any the zoos which have to house  the elephants indoor during cold winter months should not be allowed to keep  elephants at all.  The Omaha?s zoo elephants looked so parched on a hot summer afternoon (Sep.  2005);  Tiny water holes and droplets of water from the hose are definitely not enough for  the elephants ? and why the two were separated?  Hogle zoo, Salt Lake City, might be a showcase for a public, but does not offer  much space for the elephants and certainly not for Hi-Dari,  a lonely, older elephant separated from the two younger ones by a high fence and  still living in her old, tiny space ? a typical example of incompabilities between the  elephants who have no choices of companionships in all too small, unnatural  enclosures and groupings that the zoos offer them.  The elephants in Wildlife Safari, Winston OR looked by far the best, even though they offer controversial elephants? rides; still, their living area is much too small.  The elephants in Oakland zoo had the most of space  (the male was not on a display). Even though this was the only zoo that didn?t make me cringe from disgust, the  poor history of breeding, the tragic deaths of many calves in this as many other  zoos proves that the elephants don?t belong in the zoos.   Portland zoo left the impression of outright cruelty to elephants: Small, barren enclosure for the females on one hand,  the male banging his head against the metal door was shocking and horrifying.   It is obvious that the zoos drive the elephants (as well as other animals) to  neurosis as well as cause their premature death. As a daughter of a veterinarian and being married to one I have seen many cases  of cruel treatment of animals and, to my mind, the lives of elephants in both,  circuses and zoos, are not only sad but cruel. Unless USDA intervenes, bans the elephants from the circuses altogether,  forces the zoos to drastically increase the space and improve the enclosures,  the elephants will continue to suffer a sad and tragic consequences.', 'This is just one last plea for these poor elephants who have been kidnapped from  the wild, chained, and brutalized into submission by the wildlife pimps of the world  for their own financial gain.  Our great forefather, Abraham Lincoln, fought for the  rights of slaves and he believed in the rights of animals as well.  Let us not shame  this great country of America by denying these living, feeling creatures their right  to live in peace.  Sweden, Austria, Costa Rica, India, Finland, and Singapore have  all banned or restricted the use of animals in entertainment?it?s time for the U.S.  to do the same.   I am in favor of animal rights as well as human rights.  That is the way of a whole  human being.  Abraham Lincoln', 'The mistreatment of any animal is not only repulsive but also heart-wrenching.  They are living creatures that serve man and deserve our respect and care. Since  the elephants are creatures that are used for entertainment purposes, they are in  the spotlight; and the public is not blind to what goes on behind the scenes as far  as mistreatment goes. So, please, look into this matter from an empathetic view.  They need our help. And if you choose not to sympathize with them, at least  consider what they do for our economy and how they stimulate travel. Thank you  for your time and consideration.', 'The more educated we have become, we know elephants need acres to walk in,  not the area of six parking spaces. They need this amount of land to help maintain  healthy feet, prevent or slow down arthritis, for mental and emotional well being.  Lets throw away the chains, bullhooks,electric devices and bring the elephant  treatment into the 21st centuary. Thank You', "Comment on docket APHIS-2006-0044  All animals have the right to be protected and treated respectfully. Elephants that  are in captivity are no exception. Circus elephants are beaten and abused by so  called 'trainers' on a daily basis. Electrical prods, bullhooks and chains are what  is used to train these animals. These devices are used simply to inflict pain unto  elephants in hopes of breaking their (elephants) spirits so that the elephants will  perform as they are needed to. I do not believe that any animal being severly  beaten and living in spaces that do not conform to their needs is appropriate.  These animals need laws that protect them and that can improve the quality of  their life, especially if they will never have the opportunity to enjoy the environment  that is their natural habitats. Please fight to make sure that the elephants in  captivity are being cared for in every way that they deserve.", "Elephants do not belong to American ecosystem to begin with. So I request more  stringent and researched regulations governing the home and care of captive  elephants living in 'harsh foreign conditions'. Confining them to restricted cramped  spaces and inhibiting the social needs should be addressed and prevented in the  future. Making them do tricks in the name of circus should be banned once for all.  We need to adopt the cirque du soleil way of enjoying circus.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.  Thanks.", 'Please review and change the rules for circus animals, in particular elephants who literally become  ill and demented from lives lived so cruelly and so against their very nature.  The Animal Welfare  Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor  circuses currently meet this requirement, why has this been allowed to slip through the cracks?  We must treat these animals a great deal more humanely, or even better, have our circuses  without them (animal-less circuses do very well).  Enforce the rules for our zoos.  Thank you.', "It is obvious from the premature deaths of several elephants in zoos and their  suffering from diseases that these animals don't belong in zoos. Zoos cannot  accommodate an elephant's
column3: moved to the area, I began volunteering at DRC and saw first hand the individual care given to the marine mammals who call this place their forever home.  I monitored hundreds of guest encounters as a volunteer and have never seen any problems occurring from there being more than one dolphin participating in an in-water encounter with one trainer.  Our trainers are all professionals who have personal relationships with every one of our dolphins and can read their behavior so well that they know how to manage each encounter.  The dolphins also enjoy when they can work together to give a dorsal pull or imitation.  We never ask a dolphin to participate unless they want to do so and I can honestly say that I have seen this to be true.  The dolphins are enriched by their experiences together and with our guests.  I continued to volunteer here because I am an animal lover and I could tell that this family of dolphins was happy and healthy and that the staff made this their priority.    I have also participated in the in-water encounters both as a guest and as a practice for training. I have probably done more than 30 in water programs.  At no time when there were 2 dolphins working with one trainer did I feel it wasn't safe.  It was great to see the dolphins choose to cooperate and take turns.  The trainer each time was experienced and loving with the dolphins and both the guests and dolphins had a great time.  I have heard over and over from our guests that they had a life changing experience when interacting with our dolphin family. Many of our guests who interact with the dolphins come back again and again.  The dolphins here at DRC are fortunate to live in a natural water lagoon. Sometimes the water is murky or choppy and some days it is clear. This is part of living in the natural lagoon.  Some of our lagoons are very deep which is also great for the dolphins because they can dive, which is something they love to do. Some of the lagoons are so deep that we cannot see to the bottom.  This has never been a safety issue or a concern to the participants or staff.   We can always see when the dolphins are interacting with the guests. This is always done above the water or on the surface.  The deep lagoons are especially fun for the guests and dolphins when the dolphins are imitating the guests while bobbing up and down.  The guest goes up and down on a platform but the dolphin bobs up and down all the way from the bottom which takes a lot longer!  Quite fun for both!  Because of the excellent care and love the staff shows the dolphin family, I began working at DRC full time. I believe there is not any other place like DRC. The animals' care is our priority. We always put our animals' welfare first. Our animals are our family. This caring and love is apparent to our guests.  When our guests come and make personal connections with the animals in our family, they are more likely to encourage conservation and support our dolphins' cousins in the wild.  By educating the public and facilitating these personal connections, I feel that we are contributing to marine mammals' welfare all over the world.   Sheri Pieloch Dolphin Resource Center Director of Volunteer Resources", 'Growing up in Georgia, the ocean was something that was more of a thing you learned about in a text book, not something you could easily go out and see. Having aquariums such as the Georgia Aquarium, Shedd Aquarium, and SeaWorld, I was given the opportunity to explore and fall in love with the ocean and all of its creatures. I was able to see up close and personal what a Beluga whale looked like, what they felt like, and learn all kinds of amazing things about these creatures that I would have never known and no one would have without having them under human care. Having zoos and aquariums have given me a love and appreciation for animals that I never would have had. I now am an animal trainer, working at Dolphin Quest. My love for the animals lead me to a career where I could work hands on with Bottlenose Dolphins and learn so much about them on a day to day basis. I also have the privilege to inspire guest to learn and help protect these animals. Many of the guests that come through are ones that are just like me, ones that did not have access to marine animals. Now I have the pleasure of touching hearts and minds every day and giving people the experience they could only dream of. Our guest get to see the amazing health care that is provided to our animals, learn facts about our animals and their species that we learned from animals under human care. Places like Dolphin Quest, Georgia Aquarium, Shedd Aquarium, and SeaWorld are the reasons that people just like me are given the opportunity to learn, appreciate, and protect animals that they do not see on a daily basis. Please keep this in mind when making the modification to the APHIS Regulations. Also keep in mind the most current science, what they research shows, and all of the research that is able to be done in these amazing facilities. Touching hearts and minds across the world every single day. WE LOVE DOLPHINS EVERYDAY!', "Thank you for the opportunity to comment. I'm pleased that this revision to the marine mammal regulations is being considered as there have been many scientific advancements during the past 20 years. As a result, our knowledge of marine mammals has increased exponentially.  My comments are as follows: 1)\tNoise and its impact on marine mammal hearing and well-being is not addressed. Marine mammals have hearing capabilities far exceeding humans. Ideally baseline noise levels within tanks, pools and other settings should be performed and monitored.  Upcoming resources that can assist with development of guidelines should be available by the end of this month. See NOAA's Technical Guidance for Assessing the Effects of Anthropogenic Sound on Marine Mammals. http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/acoustics/guidelines.htm  2)\tEnrichment is another aspect that is not addressed in the docket (yet should be) as marine mammals live complex social lives in the wild. While many licensed facilities have excellent enrichment programs, not all do. Every effort must be made to ensure the animals are stimulated mentally and physically.  3)\tShade is crucial for the well-being of marine mammals in order to protect their skin, eyes and is important for thermoregulation. \tIf natural or artificial features are to be used instead of erecting shade structures, then areas housing marine mammals must have shade available to the animals throughout the day.  \tWhile there may be shading in the early morning, many features cannot provide shade through the entire day.  \tSWTD program have an even more important role in providing ample shade as the dolphins heads are out of the water for long periods of time during interactions.  4)\tWater quality and what's considered acceptable has evolved considerably over the last 20 years.  \tAs noted in the docket, sterilization of water is no longer a desired outcome as it can in turn cause disease by compromising immune function. \tA healthy water microbiome is critical and being able to see with absolute clarity is likely not possible if algae and other organisms are allowed to exist.  \tIn addition to Enterococcus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus, consider adding Clostridium perfringens as an additional test.  \tIn interconnected pools exist, all pools should be sampled as water flow is not consistent  \tParticular attention should be paid to pools with angular edges that may harbor dead spaces and poor water circulation.  Thank you cjm", "Dear APHIS Representative:   As a past Chief Deputy Director of the CA Dept. Of Fish & Game in the 1980's, I have seen first hand the value of private sector marine mammal rehabilitation, as well as the huge value of regulations based on the use of best available science.  I am also a native San Diegan's and have seen the ongoing efforts of Sea World in collecting and rehabilitating stranded marine mammals.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  My entire immediate and extended family has enjoyed learning, touching, exploring and providing for the love and care of all animals.', "I have had the privilege of seeing guests of all ages see aquatic animals and ecosystems they may never see in their lifetime and strike a deeper understanding of the one world ocean that connects us all. I've personally had this experience and have since dedicated my life to the care of marine mammals and the conservation of their species and habitats.  All of us at Georgia Aquarium are committed to providing our guests with a positive and impactful experience to inspire conservation of our aquatic world. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of people the ability to see magnificent animals, learn more about them, and be inspired to take part in conservation efforts large and small. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practices standards.", "I worked at Seaworld from 2000-2002. I also have my degree in marine mammal behavior. As a San Diego resident and mother of 3 I respect Seaworld and all of the good they do for Marine life. Without Seaworld several different animal populations would be extinct or in serious trouble. And what about all of the animals they rehabilitate from the wild and return them to their home healthy. And not to mention the importance of educating humans on marine life. Black fish was a disgrace and unbelievable how much false information was released.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please understand the damage that would be done if Seaworld didn't exist anymore??????.", 'I am proud to be part of the Georgia Aquarium and the greater community of accredited zoos and aquariums. I applaud APHIS for evaluating, and updating the regulations on the best practices for care of these incredible animals. I encourage APHIS to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based upon on the merits and current best practice standards, not upon second-hand information.', 'we have been to the interaction programs w / our daughter & now w / our grand children . it would be a shame not too let other families have this great experience w / their families  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  i think the people who are doing this protest should get a job & buy a ticket to sea world for their kids', 'I have learned through my experience at Georgia Aquarium that exposure to a normal flora of bacteria is helpful for animals to maintain a healthy immune system.  It concerns me APHIS is considering an increase in standards for water quality toward a more sterile environment.  I urge APHIS to review the latest information from industry professionals to ensure the best, most appropriate water quality environment for the animals.', 'NOAA NEEDS TO START MAKING ALOT MORE REGULATIONS TO PROTECT FISH AND TURTLES AND MARINE LIFE. IT IS BEING DECIMATED ALL OVER. ALMOST EVERY TURTLE IN NJ IS TRAPPED AND SENT TO CHINA FOR BOILING THESE DAYS. WHALES ARE BEING RUN OVER BY THE BOATS THAT ARE 4 FOOTBALL FIELDS LONG AND DO NOT BOTHER TO USE RADAR TO WARCH WHAT THEY HIT AND KILL. FISHERMAN ENTANGLE ALL KINDS OF ANIMALS IN NETS AND CAGES AND THEY ARE ON THE BOTTOM OF THE OCEAN DYING IN THEIR CAGES. FISHERMEN ARE ALLOWED TO USE LEAD SINKERS WHICH POLLUTE WATER. WHY DO WE HAVE AN AGENCY THAT SITS ON ITS BUTT AND DOES EVERYTHING THE COMMERCIAL FISH REC FISHERMEN WANT BUT NOTHING TO PROTECT TH EFISH THAT BELONG TO ALL 325 MILLION OF US?   WE ARE SICK AT YOUR LACK OF ACTOIN IN PROTECTION AND PRESERVATION WHICH IS THE CORE OF THE RESPONSIBILITY YOU WERE CREATED TO HANDLE. INSTED YOU HAVE BEEN REGULATORILY CAPTURED AND WE WONDER ABOUT BRIBES BEING OFFERED AND MONEY CHANGING HANDS TO ALLOW THIS WHOLESALE KILLING OF OUR FISH. FISH AND MARINE MAMMALS FEEL PAIN. YOU ARE ALLOWING THE SHARK POPULATION TO BE ABSOLUTELY EXTINGUISHED. WHEN WILL THE MEMBERS OF THIS AGENCY WAKE UP AND DO THE JOB THEY ARE PAID  SALALRY TO DO FOR ALL OF US. YOUR GRADE FOR WORK IS F MINUS AT THIS POINT. WE NEED NEW MANAGEMENT. THE MANAGEMENT THERE IS SITTING ON THEIR BUTT COLLECTING A SALARY FOR DOING NOTHING.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please listen to those of us that care about animals instead of those who only care about being politically correct. Thank you.', "Three years ago I was fortunate enough to become an employee of Dolphin Research Center.  During the time I have worked at DRC, I have participated in a number of interactive programs and also spent many of my lunch hours watching sessions between the dolphins, sea lions and their trainers. The mutual affection between the mammals and the trainers is very evident. It is clear to me that the dolphins participate in the sessions for their own enjoyment.   When I participated in interactive programs I did not feel that my safety was ever at risk, even when one trainer worked with more than one dolphin at a time.  Nor do I feel that the natural water environment and deep lagoon added any risk to my safety during the relatively short periods of time when the trainer and I might not be able to see the dolphins. I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation mostly from narrated sessions that go on throughout the day.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me. I have become avid about reducing, reusing and recycling. I have a new respect for the dolphins in the wild and a concern for protecting their environment that I would not have without getting to know the dolphins at DRC.  I'd like to thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education. Thank you!", 'I am going to school to became a veterinarian and work as a veterinary technician because I wanted to be like the amazing animal care staff at SeaWorld Orlando since I was a small child!  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please let SeaWorld keep inspiring our future', 'I have been going to SeaWorld my entire life and know the importance of being able to interact with animals to truly learn from them and understand the need to help them.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'There is a saying..."if it\'s not broke, don\'t fix it".  We have some of the finest zoos and marine facilities in the world and the animals are well cared for.  Any changes to regulations for the care of these animals should be based on scientific studies and NOT on the rhetoric of zealots who have little or no knowledge of these species or their needs.   As you review these regulations, please keep this in mind.  Do not cave to emotional rhetoric but rather, stick to scientific fact as a basis for your decisions.', 'With the advancements of technology it is obvious people can look online and get information on the animals cared for at Sea World. However, nothing can replace the up close and personal viewing of the magnificent animals to get a much better appreciation for them.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  We make it a point to get passes every year to learn more about these beautiful animals and pass the knowledge gained to our Grandson and other family members.', 'I have been a professional in the marine mammal field and dedicated over 7 years of my life caring for marine animals but also educating and inspiring our guests. I am thankful that the agency cares about the animals\' welfare; however, some of the proposed changes will limit our ability to provide exceptional care for the animals. I have been an IMATA member for several years. Everyone at my facility, Oceans of Fun, and all other US marine mammal facilities always put the animals\' welfare first. I have been at the Oceans of Fun Hershey Park location for the past seven years. In the past the show at Hershey had been very theatrical with other marine mammal companies. Oceans of Fun\'s goal is to educate guest about these animals in the wild and how we can all do our part to preserve their species as well as their natural habitat. Since Oceans of Fun has been in Hershey we have been able to change the mentality of the guests who enter our facility and inspire thousands to do their part. I feel privileged to be making such an impact with the help of these amazing animals. Recently we interacted with a child who was inspired by our presentation. She was assigned as a school project to research a topic she cared about. She felt so strongly to help these animals she decided to write her paper about seals and sea lions and how people can help them. She contacted Oceans of Fun and came in to learn and experience a day of a trainer, and learn how she could teach her friends about these animals. She was amazed by the exceptional care the animals receive on a daily basis and how much dedication the trainers have.   The proposed changes relating to marine mammals will not benefit the animals themselves. As trainers, we all know our animals and how they each have different needs. To limit the amount of daily interactive time, or changing the requirements of trainer/ animal ratios will negatively impact the variety that can be experienced on a daily basis. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care. Trainers ensure that all animal interactions are positive for themselves, the animals, as well as any guests.   As a trainer I have dedicated my life to these animals. In many ways the animals I care for come before my family. I have spent countless, holidays, nights, and almost every weekend of my life caring for the animals. This job is so much part of my life, that even when I am not physically at work, mentally I am always thinking about their needs and well-being.   Without the existence of accredited zoos and aquariums, many people wouldn\'t get the opportunity to experience exotic animals. In a world where people only care about what directly affects themselves, zoos and aquariums are a great way to reach out to people about what is in our world and how we are effecting it and the animals which inhabit it, but more importantly how people can act to help animals in the wild. As best said by Baba Dioum, "In the end we will conserve only what we love, we will love only what we understand, and we will understand only what we are taught." I would like to thank APHIS for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and that you did not feel compelled to unnecessarily change regulations. Thank you!', 'There are certain deficiencies in the current proposed rules to update the Animal Welfare Act regarding marine mammals.  One important aspect dealing with captive dolphins is the lack of oversight of "swim with dolphins" programs, which have been  unregulated since 1999. Also, the proposed rules make no significant change to the minimum space requirement for the marine  mammals\' primary habitat. Overall I support the proposed rule changes, but I think they could be made even better.', 'I am from Ontario, Canada and a few months ago I attended at the Minister\'s office with a well known marine biologist to discuss with them the new Standards of Care for Marine Mammals which have since been implemented.  Many of our suggestion were entered into the Standards of Care, in particular shelter, more transparency, access to fresh air and natural sunlight and added enrichment to the tanks.  I commend you for finally updating your standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine animals, however the current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In
column4: export some of that top end choice product that we cannot consume elsewhere. It all starts here and the USDA is in a position where unfortunately they speak for these farmers and ranchers. We need somebody on our side going to bat for us day in and day out, not someone who wants to bring in unfair competition and hang us out to dry. I really don't understand what goal the USDA is trying to accomplish here and also cant believe this has not hit the mainstream media (I know there is a reason but I couldn't tell you). Go out tonight and buy an AMERICAN beef steak and support your AMERICAN beef producer!", "We are a family ranch operation in Wyoming.  We produce cow-calf, yearlings, and finish cattle in custom feedlots in Nebraska.  If this import regulation change is allowed, it will jeopardize our business, as well as almost all agriculture and supporting industries.  The real threat of foot and mouth disease being brought to our country is a legitimate concern. If this were to happen, it would be devastating to the whole country.  Please think of our country's best interest, instead of a few multi-national companies, who would ignore this health issue all for profit motives at other's expense.  Marlin Geier", "I strongly oppose the USDA's proposed rule for the importation of fresh, matured, deboned beef from regions in Brazil and Argentina.  The chance of bringing FMD to the US is too great.", 'Why sell out on our local ranchers?  We need to support the citizens of the United States!  In my eyes this is just as bad as buying an American flag that was made in China.', 'The USA should not allow import of fresh meat from regions in Brazil.  The health regulation and standards for meat consumption can not be obtained in other countries as they are in the US.', 'The risk is huge if beef is imported from Brazil. If FMD entered the United States the livestock industry would be devastated.', 'Please do not allow beef from Brazil. It could introduce foot and mouth disease(FMD). Beef ranchers are finally getting a fair price for their investment and labor and it will lower our wages and force more small ranches to sell their land for recreation and housing. If FMD enters our land it will be very bad.']
column5: rienced commissioner, says: --The assumption that warnings don't work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress. --The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks. --These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.", 'Please do not ban these magnets. I am a middle school teacher and I need to buy a new set each year for my kids, for several reasons:  1.) My kids with ADD/ADHD are able to play with these to keep their hands busy and to focus their minds  2.) They are a fun way to teach my kids about magnetic poles and magnets!', "The fact that these sets, especially Buckyballs which have in no less than five places warnings not to let children play with these as they aren't toys, as required by the CPSC themselves, are in danger of being banned is ludicrous.  These are not toys, and should not be considered as such. They are for adults to use. The misuse of the few should not dictate the removal for the many of the product in question. Considering the parents of the children affected by the misuse of these products are the ones at fault for giving them to the children in the first place, it does not seem fair to dictate that they cannot be sold because of their gross misuse.  Please reconsider and allow these to continue to be sold, as they are great for those who enjoy science, design, patterns, and other things to pass the time or work out the brain.", 'Please allow these magnets to be sold to the public. They are incredibly useful and a great learning aid. Safety issues can be mitigated with polices and warnings without making the product illegal.', "Please do not ban them!
