They are a great education tool and for those who cannot control their children and access, they are at fault.    So many things around the house can cause worse things then these.  Simply because they are small and therefore appear safe, doesn't mean that they are for people who are not in control.  I have three children, who have all grown up with these in their lives and it has encouraged them to explore science and design and everything else creative.  All we had to do as parents is watch them closely and make them understand that they are not toys to be played with and never to put them in our mouth.  The same we do with batteries, barbies, hair spray, dice, mouse poison and everything else around the house that is potentially dangerous.  Commonsense is all it takes and the government should not interfere with things this simple.    Yes, they should not be marketed as a young childs toy, but come on, stop the stupidity.", 'Banning Bucky Balls and other magnet sets would be disgustingly over-reaching.  There are many products that can possible pose a hazard to small children.  It is the responsibility of parents to not have these products in their home or to keep them out of the reach of children.  A good product and those that enjoy it should not have to suffer because of the idiocy of some parents.', "This ban is asinine. These toys are wonderful things. They inspire minds, both young and old, to create. They show patterns. They teach. They are magnets. Plenty of other magnets are readily available--many are smaller and more powerful...yet they aren't being banned. The labeling clearly states that these aren't intended for unsupervised children. They have done no wrong. Do not ruin the joy of these wonderful inventions because a few parents couldn't be diligent enough to watch their children as they played with magnets. Make larger warning labels. Do not ban.", 'I urge the CPSC not to regulate the sale of magnet sets.', "Dear Chairman Tenenbaum: As a pediatric gastroenterologist and member of NASPGHAN, I appreciate the opportunity to comment in support of the US CPSC proposed rule on safety standards for magnet sets. I have dealt with cases of children accidentally swallowing multiple magnets that have been found around the house.   Despite the laudable efforts by CPSC  to educate the public about the dangers of high-powered magnet sets and manufacturers' warning labels, the rapidly increasing number of cases that are being documented are showing us that warning labels do not work in this case. Magnet ingestions and the serious, and potentially life-threatening, injuries that they cause to children are preventable, and the most effective way for preventing these ingestions in children is by banning the sale of such high-powered, high volume sets as defined in the proposed rule.   Swallowing magnets is very different from swallowing most other foreign bodies. Typically most other foreign bodies pass through the gastrointestinal tract without causing damage. But in the cases of these magnets the need for surgical repair of a perforation (hole in the intestine) or fistula (tunnels between 2 parts of the intestine) is high due to the significant attraction these magnets have for each other.   These high-powered magnet sets are toys. Should we really allow children to continue to be injured for the sake of a toy? I would hope not.  Thank you for considering my comments.", 'Zen Magnets cannot be banned!! They are an art form!', 'The product in question, Buckyballs, do not offer a sincere threat when used appropriately. The usefulness and ingenuity of this product largely outweighs potential harm caused by inaccurate use.', 'At our institution, we have provided care to young children who have eaten magnets. Due to the small size, children are putting them in their mouths and eating them. This has led to visits in the   emergency rooms, and ultimately they have required endoscopies and surgeries.  The CPSC magnet ban is a really great idea.', 'why dont you ban cars too, or guns, how about fire... yea lets ban fire there are people playing with fire all the time and sometimes they end up dead. sorry but banning buckyballs wont solve stupid', 'Please do not ban Bucky Balls. Bucky Balls have made me and several others in my school care about physics, making the classroom experience fun and interesting rather than monotonous, and I would hate to have the same experience denied to others because a few kids swallowed the things. There has to be a less drastic approach to the situation.', 'It is inconceivable that you want to BAN such a meaningful product. Will you BAN pins and needles? It seems you will guarantee the dumbing down of America by preventing the simplest of learning experiences. Discovery.  Use your own brains and stop this nonsense!', 'I find it disturbing that the CPSC wants to ban the sale of small high-power magnets as toys. Will the CPSC also ban the sale of the same magnets for industrial use? Isn\'t it also conceivable these could also be misdirected by "Magnet Pushers" into the hands of children? Couldn\'t you be creating an unregulated black market for miniature rare-earth magnets?  I am insulted that the CPSC believes I am not responsible enough as a parent to know what toys are appropriate and safe for my children.  I am appalled that the CPSC feels compelled to attempt to shutter an American business because the CPSC feels their safeguards against children\'s use are too lax.  I do not support this regulation. I feel it is too broad and that the regulators are targeting specific companies. I do not believe that it is the Government\'s job to protect me and my family from all harm.', 'These are some of the best toys to inspire curiosity in science in children, and should not be banned. Put warning labels on them, but do not ban them. They are awesome.', "Banning magnetic spheres seems really silly and overly broad. From what I've read there have been there have been very low numbers of reported incidents when compared to the number of units sold. I'm really tired of the constant 'Think of the children' philosophy when it comes to crafting and passing bills. This bill will only serve to kill the small businesses that produce these interesting and unique products. There are plenty of other products that are far more dangerous for children.  Like cigarettes. They carry harsh warnings on their packaging and are illegal to sell to minors but are still used by them. Why not ban those as well considering the health implications for children? Seriously though. I would love to see a ban on cigarette sales. That would be amazing.", 'I was recently made aware of the possibility that small spherical high powered magnets may be regulated by the government. Our country was built on the idea of freedom. Over the years these freedoms have been re-interpreted and regulated. I am in favor of government regulation when it comes to human life, crime and atrocities, but not for such small details and consumer affairs. My children enjoy building things with these small magnets and they make for fun family activities. I would think with the current state of affairs in this country that we would have more improtant things to worry about.', "Please don't ban these magnets.  I have been sculpting using this wonderful medium for over a year would hate to see them removed from the marketplace.  Surely there are other more dire items that should be removed from the hands of consumers like guns.  I feel that the age warnings are sufficient  for the purpose of keeping these magnets out of the hands of small children.  Let the consumer decide.  Thank you.", 'Magnets set are no dangerous. My 7 years old girl play with those magnets since I bought it.  They are great for creativity. The only problem with this product is the price. May be if you can do some regulation for give some of this sets to any school in the country for free it would be great!', "Seriously!  I am 37 y/o and I am just learning about Physics and Electromagnetism. I have a 5 y/o that I will not let him use, not to mention he doesn't even have the fine motor skills to manipulate them yet.  I don't think this is a fair regulation/ban and it is a slap in the face for us who are utilizing these wonderful spheres to understand the laws of physics and excited about teach my child about them, WHEN HE IS OLD ENOUGH!  Why in the world would you do this???  Please, do not implement this ban!", 'How does a few dozen instances of kids swallowing magnetic toys targeted at adults fall under "unreasonable risk", but significantly more incidents of injury for things like balloons, which are specifically targeted toward kids does not qualify as unreasonable?  Why are you targeting these magnetic sets?  I find it unreasonable what this rule is attempting to do, i.e. require magnets be a certain size.  There are warnings, and it is up to individuals to protect themselves.  It is belittling and demeaning to assume that parents and teachers are so incompetent as to protect their kids, and it is an infringement of our freedom to purchase and the freedom to manufacture and sell.  If we put ourselves in a bubble, we will destroy our pioneer spirit and ingenuity.', "If you choose to take this option with regard to banning magnets, many adult users of this artistic medium such as myself will have a much more difficult time obtaining magnet spheres for their work.  There are many reasons why magnet spheres (with proper warning labels) make excellent toys for children as well. So long as it is understood that ingesting magnets or putting them in one's mouth is dangerous, they are otherwise quite safe to play with, and make an excellent way to teach interesting concepts about geometry, number, symmetry (group theory), and recursive structure.  You should also understand that even if you think these are inappropriate toys for children, there are many adults such as myself who use them to construct sculptural artwork, and would like the companies who supply us with these magnets to continue existing and supporting our work.  Would you ban the sale of chemicals used in photography because they're unsafe for children? How about dyes used in silk-screening? Surely many of those would similarly be unsafe for children to ingest.  Would you ban various pieces of sports equipment? Hockey skates and baseball bats have the potential to cause major injuries if misused.  But if the proper precautions are taken and it's properly understood what is not safe to put in one's mouth, it's quite safe to play with magnets.  Many other things which we expose children to are similarly quite potentially dangerous, if not treated with a minimum of respect required to remain safe. Nearly everything could be seen as dangerous, in one way or another, but failing to come to terms with that would make life not worth living.  Quite frankly, your current position in this matter is heavy handed and ridiculous in the context of our society, and I sincerely hope that you will reconsider it.", 'they should not be banned! people need to take responsibility for thier children!!!', "Dear Chairman Tenenbaum: As a practicing pediatrician and member of the American Academy of Pediatrics, I appreciate the opportunity to comment in support of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commissions (CPSC) proposed rule on safety standards for certain types of magnet sets. As a pediatrician, my number one goal is to keep children safe. Yet, the powerful, tiny magnets contained in the toys and other similar products that would be banned under the rule are not safe for children. These products have caused unnecessary surgeries, debilitating injuries, irreversible gastrointestinal damage and other lifelong health impacts in infants, children and adolescents. Despite efforts by the CPSC to educate the public about the dangers of high-powered magnet sets and improvements in manufactures warning labels, recent data provide compelling evidence that warning labels are just not working. Magnet ingestions and the injuries they cause to childrenwhich can include bowel perforations or fistulas, twisted bowels and severe infections, among other serious gastrointestinal injuriesare preventable. The most effective way to prevent ingestions is to ban the sale of high-powered magnet sets, as defined in the proposed rule.  Children sometimes swallow things they shouldn't, but these magnets pose special risk to children. Unlike other commonly swallowed products like coins or marbles, when these high-powered magnets are swallowed, endoscopic or surgical intervention is required in nearly all cases to prevent bowel damage.  Magnet ingestions by children are no longer a rare occurrence.  Manufacturers claim there have been few injuries from ingestion of these magnets, which is not true.  Injuries from magnet ingestions are often difficult to diagnose by health care professionals, especially since toddlers cannot convey that they have swallowed the magnets and the magnets can come in sets of 200 or more, making it difficult for parents to notice when one is missing.", 'These magnets are amazingly fun to play with and inspire kids to learn about magnetism, as well as be creative. Label them as hazards to infants and let parents do their jobs. If they can keep their prescriptions away from kids, they can keep some magnets away as well. Besides, these make awesome Christmas gifts!', "It is absurd to punish a company who makes a unique product for the failings of a guardian.  Many things possess the potential to cause harm and caution should always be used when interacting with any such item.  Magnet spheres are no different. We need to practice good parenting and not blame a company who has done no wrong.   Many people may not be able to understand how neat of a product Magnet spheres can be and that is fine.  What they should understand is that different people have different hobbies and they should respect them.  To each his own.  This, seems to be difficult for many individuals.  Since they see no use for an item or hobby in their lives they call it 'trivial' and 'stupid' and wish to take it away from responsible individuals who do care.  Particularly when it means they can point the finger at someone else and remove themselves from any sort of responsibility for the negligence of their own actions or lack thereof.  Practice responsibility not bigotry for hobbies they don't partake in.", "As an American citizen and a lover of all things magnetic, I am highly disappointed by the proposed prohibition of Buckyballs. I have played with magnets my whole life, and have yet to swallow a single one. The problem here is not with the magnets, but with the people. Irresponsible people leave them out in the open where a small child can accidentally swallow them, which you have noticed can cause various health problems. Let's be honest, though, almost anything is a potential health hazard to someone. People need to stop being reckless. Don't prohibit magnets.", "I agree with the pediatricians that these little magnets are incredibly dangerous to children.  I do not believe we should be putting company profits ahead of our children's safety.  These should be banned immediately.", "Please do not ban these amazing magnets. They inspire creativity and that's a good thing.", "Recommending a ban on magnetic building sets designed for and marketed to adults is inappropriate and does not advance any demonstrable public interest.   Far more reasonable measures could easily be taken without harming the manufacturers and importers of these adult products.  For example, restricting the sale to those stores or retail outlets that do NOT market exclusively to children (e.g. children's-only toy stores that do not sell or market items for use by those over 14, or 16, or 18).  Or, require labeling much as California's Proposition 65 does or as cigarettes are labeled to ensure those purchasing are aware that these items should not be left where children or pets could access them.  Either of these would fall in line with existing norms and expectations of the public for proper labeling of items that pose a risk if used inappropriately.   An outright ban would set a dangerous precedent for the CPSC, both in terms of the items that the public believes the CPSC have dominion over and items that are safe enough to have around children.  The current methods of restricting or labeling items not intended for children is sufficient for those items and there is no demonstrable difference with magnetic building sets as evidenced by the CPSC's own proposed rule research.  The number of reported cases is quite small, both in number and per capita based on ownership of these sets, yet the CPSC has extrapolated to a farcical number of serious incidents.   It is inappropriate to ban magnetic building sets when there are many other dangerous items (e.g. watch batteries, laundry/dishwasher detergent packs, lower-strength magnets that are more easily frangible than rare-earths) that are sold with appropriate warnings, in appropriate containers, and in appropriate locations that there is no doubt as to their intended use and yet, like many things in this world, would be dangerous to children if ingested.", 'Labeling these products designed for adults and adding a hazard warning to the boxes should be sufficient.  These products should not be banned.  They are meant for adults, not children.', "Please do not ban these items. It is hard enough to build and maintain children's interest in science.", "I agree that educating the public by enhancing labels on these products explaining in graphic detail what hazards these magnets can produce. But like over-the-counter medications, ammunition, alcohol and tobacco products, and other hazardous and potentially fatal products, should be sold in appropriate locations,  e.g., not in toy shops, and their sales should not be banned. Prohibition makes these products more alluring. History is the best teacher.  SUMMARY:  1. Educate--YES 2. Sell in children's toy shops --NO 3. Ban-- definitely NO", 'This proposed rule is ridiculous.  These should be kept away from small children by parents or adults responsible for caring for them.   I enjoy using these products and am opposed to banning them.', 'While these magnets do pose potential danger if ingested, they should not be banned, eliminating their usefulness as a teaching tool.  Regulate sales to adults only or require giant warning stickers instead.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.  The simple fact of the matter is that if magnets such as Bucky Balls and Zen Magnets are deemed a safety hazard because people cannot be trusted to follow the safety warnings, then all chemical products such as Draino, shampoo, dishwashing liquids, anti-freeze, candy flavored medicines, etc should also be banned from the markets.', "Don't ban them bucky balls etc", 'Magnets should not be banned and I know have less respect for the government and more respect it buckyballs and zen magnets because they are standing up for what\'s right.   I own zen magnets and I have them for about a year and they keep me occupied. We went down to North Carolina and all I did the whole time in the car was play with the magnets. These magnets are not 100% safe but we all know that. The reason there not safe is because of there size and magnetism it makes it not safe for children. So if you have kids don\'t get these and there will be no problem. So what should happen is that the companies should put a " keep away from small children" on whatever their selling it in.  Please don\'t ban these magnets because 85%+ people will be furious at you because they can get their educational magnets.', "if bucky balls are to be banned, then so should power cords, bath tubs, children's toy, dressers, windows, pills, and stoves. As all of these products have a much greater chance of injuring a child than these magnetic toys.", 'I strongly object to the proposed new Safety Standard for Magnet Sets. They do not represent an unreasonable risk of injury. The judgment of the proposed rule in this matter is deeply flawed and inaccurate. Millions of households enjoy the educational value, hobby use, and entertainment from small, spherical, high-flux magnets without incident (as well as other high flux magnets that have numerous practical uses). Limits on the flux value effectively bans the product at a period when the U.S. Government is seeking to support the growth of small businesses and the middle class jobs they provide. Limits on distribution accomplishes the same effect.  Household chemicals (to pick just one category of in-home hazard) injure 120,000-160,000 people per year. They are not banned, even though many of them could easily be replaced by practical, non-toxic alternatives. The reason they are not regulated out of existence is because the government has taken the stance that freedom of commerce is a core value in this country and American should be aware of and exercise due diligence whether they are climbing a ladder, cleaning with bleach, disposing of plastic bags, or handling anything around children with small parts that can be swallowed.  Spend your resources on public education and you will have a much greater impact than you will by shuttering small businesses. Remember, these magnets are already safely used in millions of homes, and you will be more productive by increasing caution in those homes than by ending future purchases.', "I would argue that magnetic sets are no more dangerous than many other children's toys. The issues arise when they are misused, much like when a trampoline is misused. Proper labeling, and perhaps more limited marketing to older age groups seems like a much more reasonable response than banning such valuable learning tools outright.", 'I believe these rules are in violation of 706(2)(a) as they are arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion. This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing under 556&557 should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.  These organizations have worked with the CPSC and done everything needed, and now the organization is acting in such a manner contrary to their previous prior dealings with the effected companies.  As a consumer, I think the CPSC is overreaching. Personal responsibility is key. We don\'t let children play with ball bearings, and we have not banned every magnet out there because of the potential (ab)use by children. Parents should be responsible and not let these ADULT TOYS fall within their hands.  I believe that there should be a category promulgated that is classified as an "ADULT TOY" wherein the CPSC can designate particularly age-inappropriate items and disallow their sale at establishments where children may express an interest.', 'As a pediatrician, I am very concerned about the risk these small and powerful magnets pose for children.  While small children can ingest and choke on many objects, these rare earth magnets pose a particular risk because they can attach to another magnet (or any other metal object) in the intestine and cause perforation, which can only be corrected by surgery.  In addition, because of their small size and shiny metal character, they are very appealing to young children.  Clearly, most parents do not intentionally let young children play with these magnets; but children are curious and like to explore and find things.  In addition, parents can easily lose or drop these magnets, inadvertently allowing young children to find them. The magnets are an entertaining toy for adults, but they serve no essential or practical purpose.  They pose a risk to young children that cannot be justified by any utility.  I urge the CPSC to ban these magnets for the safety and health of children.', 'A ban on magnets and magnet sets of this sort is patently unnecessary, and will do far more damage to the world by diminishing the opportunities for generating interest in science and physics, than any harm it might theoretically prevent. A move to ban products that inspire and educate simply because misuse has potential consequences are are a move in the wrong direction. Establishing policies of such a meddlesome and nannying nature is exactly the sort of thing that will leave america weak, stranded and stupid, unable to compete against foreign powers who do not waste time on such things.', 'Do not ban Buckyballs or Zen Magnets. This is a gross misuse of government power. Parents needs to parent their children better to avoid mishaps rather than the government banning everything remotely dangerous.', 'Please do not ban or in any way restrict the sale of magnet sets such as Bucky Balls. They have always been labeled as an adult toy and as such should not be restricted because of a small group of irresponsible adults who allow children to play with them unsupervised.', 'What rational adult looks at those little balls and says "Hmm, yes, this would be a WONDERFUL thing to give my child whom identifies what he likes by putting it in his mouth?"  This is a great tool for learning. Its should simply have a label or warning lettign the users know it\'s dangers.', 'There is a proposed safety standard that would ban the sale of all small high-powered magnets.  While such a toy or item might be dangerous for small children, this change should not be allowed to happen.  The idea of this country is not to limit what people can do or to limit everything that adults or teenagers can buy to what is safe for an infant or toddler.  Making such a limit would ban the sales of many items that creative people would want.  When I heard about this ban, I researched it and found an item it would effect, called "Bucky Balls."  I ordered two sets, one of Bucky Balls and one of Bucky Bars and I, a fifty year old man, sat down to look over just what the Government is considering banning.  I did not want to comment until I had a chance to see a product that would be effected.  These products are ones that many of my artistic and creative friends would be interested in.  It\'s a toy I would like to have on my desk.  I work 10-12 hours a day at home, and often need to take breaks so I can rest my mind and manipulate things with my fingers (to avoid repetitive stress issues).  I\'ve found these two products wonderful for playing with while thinking or to work out 3D geometric designs.  It would be a shame if adults or teens or even older children were not allowed to buy such products simply because infants or toddlers cannot use them.  Our government is about allowing people to make choices, not about taking them away.  Banning such things would be a prefect example of the "nanny state" or "government red tape" that so many Americans frequently complain about.  Please do not ban smaller magnets in manipulative sets.  Mark them as unsafe for children under 10 or 12 (or 8, or whatever), but do not ban them.', "Banning magnetic spheres is an insane proposition. There is absolutely no inherent danger in magnet spheres. If we ban things because they have caused a few dozen injuries or deaths, we would have nothing. Looking around my office, nothing seems safe from these arbitrary, knee-jerk ban-reactions. My reusable metal water bottle could be used to bludgeon someone to death. My stapler or pen could put someone's eye out. My burger could give me heart disease.  Thousands of times as many people die from a number of other things that the government still allows to be sold. Cigarettes, alcohol, fireworks, gunpowder, soda (diabetes has caused millions of deaths). And we're afraid of magnetic balls sold by vendors who are responsible enough to specifically state that they are not to be given to kids, yet we still want to put these manufacturers out of business?", 'Please do not outright ban small magnetic toys.  To quote Gizmodo: "Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don\'t ban them! And as Zen Magnets pointed out in a statement, "...there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them. That is a good thing."  Banning a product will likely create an unlegislated black market as well.', "The line of logic for banning magnets as I see it is: A child, unwatched and unattended by it's parents, could consume these magnets and die, so they should be hard to obtain.  By this logic, what else should be illegal? Cleaning supplies, automotive supplies, guns and ammunition, small toys. In fact, my uncle almost died because of a plastic straw. almost anything in a household has lethal potential.  The benefits of freely available high-power magnets are largely to this country's most important people: inventors, innovators, and scientists.   Is banning magnets as a knee jerk reaction to a child's death really a sensible thing to do?", "This is an utterly non-sensibility once again wasting resources by the US government. If we are going to eliminate all chocking hazards. Even those that already include warnings for the ignorant, let's not exempt anything. We should start with food, beads for crafters, nuts used on bolts, marbles, eyeglass screws, broken crayons or chalk, replacement erasers, dog food, potpourri and all things small enough to be swallowed. Stop wasting time an

column2:
needs, no matter what kinds of cages they devises. Elephants suffer needlessly and horribly, and they die decades earlier than they would in the wild. Please don't allow their suffering anymore. There's enough animal suffering in the world; don't be the deliberate cause any more of it.", 'Please help our animal friends. Elephants included. If it is a fact that they are dying from poor living environments or abuse, do what you can to step up and help these precious creatures. Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants.', 'It makes me sick to think of intelligent animals being used as "entertainment" for children (or adults). I never liked the circus as a child and would never support it now. I remember as a child feeling sad seeing the faces of the elephants, tigers, monkeys, and other exotic animals being used in that way. The means used to "control" them are not humane and completely unnecessary since so many people hate to see them in shows anyway. Elephants are naturally family oriented and travel in groups - often defending each other in very intelligent ways. No animal deserves a life of being chained and exhibited and cruelly forced to perform for humans. They deserve our compassion and should all be- free to be with their own kind in the wild. We\'re supposedly the intelligent animals on this earth. Please do everything you can to stop allowing elephants and other wild animals from being in displays, shows, circuses, and other inhumane human enterprises. Thank you.', "Elephants die young in captivity - about half of that in the wild. We know they die of painful foot diseases that don't exist in the wild. We know they don't breed well in captivity. It is about time we institute strict habitat requirements that give elephants the room to roam and walk miles that is critical to their health. If this cannot be accomplished, the animal should be required to be released to a place that it can get it's needs met. The zoos and circuses have an agenda to make money - they are a business - and the welfare of the elephants comes second.", "I am a school teacher and I encourage my students to show compassion and empathy towards others and to all of God's creatures. It is our moral obligation to stop circuses that exploit and torture animals for a profit!! Circuses send the wrong message to children. Child psychologists warn that observing such mistreatment stifles the development of empathy in children. Furthermore, studies show that people who commit acts of cruelty to animals often engage in domestic violence and child abuse. For example, Ringling elephant trainer Sacha Houcke has been videotaped hooking elephants with a bullhook, and in April 2005, he was charged with assault in University Park, Pennsylvania, after employees at the arena where the circus was performing called police and reported that they witnessed that Houcke choked his daughter, pushed her to the ground, and punched her in the face. Houcke pleaded guilty to harassment and disorderly conduct charges. The USDA is a law enforcement body whose job is to ensure that animals are afforded the minimum protections intended by Congress in its creation of the AWA. The USDA must reinstitute its policy of issuing detailed news releases in a timely fashion when charges are filed against circuses, zoos, and other licensees and must announce the outcome of the cases. By concealing enforcement actions, the agency is protecting animal abusers. THE USDA MUST DO THE RIGHT THING AND PROHIBIT THE USE OF BULLHOOKS AND THE USE OF ELECTRIC-SHOCK DEVICES, CHAINING, AND OTHER INSTRUMENTS THAT CAUSE PAIN, INJURY, AND SUFFERING TO ELEPHANTS. STOP THE EXPLOITATION AND TORTURE OF ANIMALS NOW AND MAKE THIS A GREATER NATION!!", 'Please provide for improved care of elephants living in captivity.', "better conditions for these great emotional animals who are proven to bond, require their 'family' around them would only ensure a 'happier' more relaxed animal. elephants do go insane and are then unpredictable and deadly when emotionally unstable or made to perform stunts that they normally would not do in the wild - probably because it hurts them. isolating them from other elephants or removing 'family' members will only make them emotionally unbalanced - as it would for any of us.....elephans are very family orientated...the emotional well being is crucial. humans are the caretakers of the earth and all of gods creations....it is our responsibility to care for them and ensure their safety especially since we are the ones making todays world unsafe for them. thank you....", "I urge you to consider the long history of abuse that these magnificent animals have suffered at the hands of humans for centuries. Elephants are intelligent and highly social animals and they have a basic right to decent care when in the custody of humans. As a world leader, it is vital that the U.S. demonstrate it's commitment to compassionate and humanitarian treatment of elephants in captivity. They must have adequate room and shelter, clean water to drink, fresh food to forage, small bodies of water in which to cool off and bathe. How can anyone with an ounce of decency in them not provide all that these animals need to be happy and healthy? I provide for my animal companions as anyone would their children. I believe that it is reprehensible and inhuman to treat these animals as they have historically been treated in the name of making a profit. Zoos and circuses have a long history of mistreatment of these animals. We've all seen the news stories of an elephant on the rampage driven to the brink of insanity after a life of insufferable abuse and neglect. The USDA is in a position to make a difference and it is time that we take a stand on this issue.", "Elephants are incredibly gentle, beautiful and intelligent creatures. They are featured in zoos and circuses because humans are so enamored of these gentle giants, yet they are not given the care and consideration they need. I support any measures to dramatically improve the welfare of elephants across this country. Elephants need more space than they are given in zoos and circuses. They should not be locked up for 12 hours at a time, or during the cold winter months of harsh climates they are not born to live in. Elephants cannot maintain a decent standard of living unless they are given many acres to roam in a climate that is closest to their natural habitat. The Animal Welfare Act requires zoos and circuses to provide elephants with adequate space but it's obvious they are not following these rules. Elephants should not be subjected to the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force and these implements should be outlawed. Thank you for your time and consideration.", "I feel so bad to see the elephants and all the other animals suffering in the circus in horrible conditions that I won't ever go to another circus that has animals. It's upsetting that the elephants are chained up, and can't run around free like in their natural environment. I see them bobbing their head up and down.They don't seem to do that in the wild. It's like being in jail. Can't you do something to help them have a better life? I hear that there are elephant sanctuaries that they are living a happier life. At least send these animals to the sanctuaries. I don't even want to look at another elephant, tiger or bear get whipped from their trainers again.", "RE: Docket APHIS 2006-0044 I am in support of changing the AWA to include the zoo and circus Elephants and other animals to change their living conditions so they can have clean conditons and not tethered and chained where they cannot move or exercise. Zoo and circus animals have been abused and neglected for 60+ years. We didn't have any laws for animals then but we do now and it needs to be changed to help these wonderful creatures. It's bad enough they are not in their natural environment and are forced to live their lives just for the pleasure of humans but at least let's take good care of them. That is the right thing to do. Many changes are needed in the Animal Welfare Act and this is diffently one of them.", 'I would like to offer my comments and observations regarding the situation with elephant?s in captivity. I feel the current situation involving zoo?s, circus?s, game farms etc. are just not working. Elephants in captivity rarely receive the 5 things they need most to survive let alone thrive. Elephants need space, they need a variety of foods (grasses, hay, vegetables, fruit) they need water and fresh air and most importantly they need a variety of substrates to walk, stand and sleep on. Zoo?s for the most part are built on and of concrete. Concrete is not a forgiving substance. Endless standing around and laying down with little room to move about freely or to get relief creates pressure soars and eventually leads to the breakdown of the bones and joints in the legs and feet of the elephant. Circus?s again by their very nature of traveling and having to house the elephants in confined spaces for extended periods of time enforce this condition of restricted mobility. Although zoo?s and circus?s etc. have access to veterinary services the life span of the elephant has decreased significantly rather than increased. You would think with the elimination of natural predators and risks that the life span of the elephant should increase significantly. This has not been the case. More and more elephants are dying from arthritis, bone disease etc. It doesn?t take a genius to figure out that zoo?s and circus?s can not provide adequately for the elephant. Most zoo?s don?t have the space or the ability to expand ADEQUATELY. A number of zoo?s do not have the funds to look after 3 elephants ? the absolute minimum that should be kept together. Zoo?s and Circus?s can not provide what is required to enable the elephant to live out their nature lives, they can not provide a stress free environment to allow elephants to NATURALLY breed. They have lost the ability to help save the elephant and are fast becoming a major threat to the health and welfare of the elephant. There are several sanctuaries in the United States that seem to have developed an ability to properly look after the elephants. They seem to have a fundamentally different philosophy from zoo?s and circus?s. Sanctuaries put the welfare of the animal first and foremost. Zoo?s and circus?s put profit and politics first and foremost and the animals lastly.', 'Progressive zoos and elephant experts are realizing that elephants do not adapt in captivity. They are dieing very prematurely and have immense physical and psychological maladies. In captivity, elephants statistically develop unnatural health problems such as arthritis, foot and joint problems, reproductive problems, and psychological problems that are especially seen in an elephant in our Tucson zoo ? an unnatural, stereotypic swaying, as well as head bobbing and pacing that results from severe confinement and stress. Asian elephant Connie swings her head back and forth non-stop, all day at the Reid Park Zoo in Tucson, AZ. The zoo tries to put the public?s conscience at ease by lying and saying she does this because she is ?happy?, turning their backs to the fact that such behavior is well documented as a sign of stress and boredom.

In the wild, elephants walk up to 50 miles daily foraging for food. While zoos and circuses provide food for elephants, so that aspect of walking is not necessary, the walking serves another purpose - the prevention of the aforementioned arthritis and foot and joint problems. Elephants in the wild do not have these issues like zoo and circus elephants, and the missing factor from these unnatural, typically concrete-floored environments is walking. Also considering the great expanses elephants need to walk for their health, zoos, and circuses especially, cannot provide for these creatures. The largest elephant enclosure in the US is eight acres, which is still horribly small for the world?s largest land mammal.

Elephants are intelligent, social animals, which prefer to live in herds of at least a half-dozen. It was elephants\' complex social patterns, in fact, that prompted the Bronx Zoo\'s decision not to replace its three female elephants when they die. Elephants show humor and express compassion for one another with intense interactions. The reality of their lives in captivity is that many are in chains up to 18 hours a day, mainly referring to circuses. They are enclosed in steel pens, many times alone, broken and controlled by fear and intimidation. Trainers often use bull hooks and electrical prods, and such inhumane training has even been well documented via first-hand accounts and undercover footage. Tim Frisco, a trainer at a circus named Carson and Barnes, has been shown telling would-be trainers how to dominate elephants and make them perform circus tricks, saying,
?Sink that hook into ?em. When you hear that screaming, then you know you got their attention.?

The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) does not prohibit the use of this type of cruelty and the following of this law is loosely monitored. Many cities in the US already have banned circuses and rodeos, or the use of chemical, manual or electrical means to force an animal to perform, and internationally, multiple cities in 12 large countries have banned animal acts for entertainment all together. It is recognized that abuse in the animal entertainment circuit is common and widespread, and such places have taken a stand to not support such behavior. But it really should be banned altogether, at least on a national level.

Leaders of the American Zoo and Aquarium Association depict critics of elephants in captivity as a small minority of animal-rights "extremists." This is not accurate at all. This subject has been focused on by mainstream channels like CNN, PBS, and Discovery, on shows like 20/20, and even National Geographic magazine has covered this debate.

Even my grandmother and her friends, all conservative Christians, get very upset about this issue and were crushed when Tucson?s City Council voted to keep our elephants here instead of sending them to The Elephant Sanctuary in Hohenwald, TN. Despite public outcry in countless letters to our area?s papers asking to send the elephants to a sanctuary, it was largely evident that there were many other factors at work here ? one of the council members and the city manager were both closely working with the zoo through the whole fight, and our zoo used tactics like bringing uninformed and manipulated children of zoo employees to Tucson City Council meetings to speak about keeping the elephants here. Something must be done on a greater scale to help elephants in zoos and circuses because this is a difficult fight from a grassroots level ? the American Zoo and Aquarium Association has mastered tactics, which they teach to zoos, to defeat citizens against them.

It should also be noted that the American Zoo and Aquarium Association?s standards for elephants are completely absurd ? they require a minimum only 1,800 square feet of outdoor living space. Plus, their survival depends on the revenue of zoos and circuses, so to say they are bias and not truly fighting for the welfare of these animals is an understatement. Often, they tote the argument that zoos are working for conservation. In no way do zoos aid in developing a conversation ethic; millions more are spent on keeping these animals pent up in miniscule habitats instead of being given to the actual conservation effort. With elephants, we are currently destroying their habitat faster then ever before, and Asian elephants are even endangered. Also, captive breeding of elephants had been grossly unsuccessful. Conservation is carried out by habitat protection and anti-poaching measures. If these two things are not focused on and given the immense funding they lack, elephants will not survive regardless of how many we put on display for the public?s enjoyment.

People directly connected to or deliberately mislead by the zoo and circus business continually fight the logical and compassionate masses, reputable scientists, and progressive people in the Zoo and animal-care industry. For instance, Ron Kagan, the director of the Detroit Zoo, last year gave up two of his elephants out of concern for their welfare. Kagan sent them to a sanctuary near Sacramento, CA. "By many indices, elephants just don\'t do very well in captivity," Kagan told the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. In addition to the Detroit Zoo, at least eight other American Zoo and Aquarium Association accredited zoos have recognized that they cannot adequately provide for the needs of elephants and have closed their exhibits, sending their elephants one of the two American elephant sanctuaries.

Close to my home is another "extremist", David Hancocks, former director of the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum, a very ethical and natural zoo in the heart of Tucson\'s Saguaro National Monument. Hancocks wrote in a Seattle Times commentary last year that "the history of elephants in zoos is full of mental and physical pain."

Then there is The Humane Society of the United States. "We don\'t think that elephants can be kept humanely in zoos," Richard Farinato, a Humane Society executive, bluntly told a Portland, Oregon weekly newspaper. Even the USDA, in a 1998 elephant course document, has said, ?The absence of walking ... must have dramatic long-term effect on the elephants\' physical and mental stability and must ultimately affect its longevity and propagation.?

I understand that people enjoy taking their children to the zoo, but children are so very compassionate by nature when given the reality of a situation. They do not want elephants to suffer at their expense.', 'Please create legislation which will put an end to the misery and life long suffering of any animal, but in particular elephants....I beg you. Thank you.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country. As of right now, zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being such as adequate space and natural environment for them to thrive. In too many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force must be outlawed', 'I wholeheartedly encourage a drastic improvement in conditions for captive elephants on our shores and submit that this must occur under the Animal Welfare Act if we are to continue to keep captives of this very special species. The first requirement by dint of the elephant\'s size is adequate space. Zoos must .provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize, and have a chance to have good physical and mental health. These refuges are examples to be copied of responsible, humane care of elephants. Circuses, by their very definition, cannot house or keep elephants humanely and the use of elephants in circuses should now be prohibited just as bear-baiting and other barbaric practices were a century ago. Furthermore, the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices, and other instruments of force against elephants must be prohibited in zoos. When elephants lack sufficient space, are forced to live under unnatural conditions, and suffer from social deprivation, they become neurotic and succumb to physical ailments such as arthritis, foot diseases, pneumonia, tuberculosis, reproductive and digestive. When elephants lash out at circus "trainers" it should be seen for what it is: a highly intelligent, emotionally and culturally (socially) complex suffering animal that is rebelling against human exploiters. It is not safe for humans to be around mistreated elephants. It has come to my attention that zoos often lock elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. Moreover, in northern climes, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months. This is not humane. In summary, circuses and most zoos are not following the law according to the Animal Welfare Act. In order to be allowed to keep captive elephants responsibly and humanely, zoos must be made to follow much higher standards of care than they do at present. There can be no quesiton that elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. In all good conscience zoos must recognize this scientific fact and provide much more for these wondrous creatures to receive the care they deserve and we owe them. Circuses must be prohibited from keeping elephants altogether. It is simply not possible for a circus to keep an elephant humanely.', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', "Thank you for allowing me to express my comments on this important matter. I am asking the USDA to create tough new standards which would include the following: ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks. These devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health. It is long overdue that we consider all the needs of these animals and afford them the best protection possible. Thank you.", 'APHIS-2006-0044 I am a teacher appalled by the lessons we are teaching children concerning responsibility. Maggie, the elephant in Alaska, a well as other elephants are in poor cramped, isolated, unexercised conditions. What are we teaching by our lack of care? That it is acceptable to ignore facts, pretend things are fine and that a treadmill solves exercise and socialization needs? Children love animals. Their education is not improved by watching elephants suffer. Please take action to enforce standards for the treatment of elephants, a social, intelligent animal. Then elephants like, Maggie, can be in places able to care adequately for them. We have the creativity, ingenuity and technology to teach our children about elephants without keeping elephants in cement barns and inhumane conditions. Please act to protect elephants and thus teach our children to be responsible, caring human beings. Pamela Weaver', 'Most zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with their minimum requirements for health and well-being. Of particular concern is the lack of space for these large animals, and inappropriate handling procedures such as the use of bullhooks, whips, electrical shock devices, etc. Circuses, in particular, also tend to confine their animals in very small spaces for prolonged periods. We must require all zoos and circuses to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'Reasons to safeguard the well-being of circus elephants! 1. Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being. 2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. 3. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. 4. Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. 5. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed. 6. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. Please act for the safety and well-being of all creatures!', "I support all efforts to improve the conditions for captive elephants, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act and creating tough new standards. 1. Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health. 2. Prohibit the use of cruel instruments of force against elephants, such as bullhooks. 3. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide with absolute, adequate space. They are not anywhere near this requirement. 3. Common sense must prevail. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. Currently, too many zoos and circuses are severely lacking space and provide unnatural conditions which results in social deprivation that eventually cause a multitude of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. I am from Los Angeles and was witness to the loss of two elephants, (one recently) which suffered horribly with foot disease for years. The Zoo continually down played this condition and finally had to own up to it, when this poor elephant sat down in her small pen and suffered 6 hours in this unnatural position before she was found, dead, by zoo officials. 4. Many zoos keep their elephants in small pens for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter months. This is completely unnatural and detrimental to their health. 5. The use of bull hooks and prolonged chaining are common and widespread. These methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to elephants. Head bobbing is common in captive elephants and is not present in the wild. 6. Elephants are intelligent, complex beings and have unique social and physical needs. They deserve much higher standards than those currently available. Please don't let anymore elephants suffer.", 'I support all efforts to improve conditions for captive elephants in America, including enforcing existing space requirements under the AWA and new tough standards to prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, etc. and force of any kind against elephants.', "Dear sir/madam, Please stop locking elephants up in zoos and please stop using them in circusses! These animals are not made to entertain us and they are often forced to do stupid tricks by use of 'elephant hooks' and other torture objects. Elephants are sentient beings and they deserve our respect and protection. Human beings have exploited animals long enough. It has to stop now!!!", "When I was growing up and even through college, I really enjoyed zoos. However, once I started getting into animal welfare rights and learning about the conditions animals are subjected to, I took a different stance. I will not go to a zoo that has an elephant exhibit. It is common knowledge, in the animal welfare community, that elephants in zoos do not have nearly enough room to walk. Elephants in captivity live an average of half their normal life span. A big reason for that is that elephants develop severe foot problems from hours upon hours of standing because they don't have enough room to move. The word is getting out: elephants should not be kept at zoos, they just don't have enough space! More and more people will and are joining me in boycotting zoos.", 'Elephants in zoos do not have
column3: sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  In the words of the great Steve Irwin..."If you love something, you want to protect it." It is by the exposure and interaction that people experience at Sea World parks, that past, present and future generations have grown to love and respect these amazing animals, and in return wish to protect them. If that is taken away, the personal attachment to these animals may be lost as well. The old saying that out of sight, out of mind, is rooted in common sense. Keep Sea World and other accredited facilities as they are, and keep the interest and love for these animals alive.', 'My family frequents the Gulfarium every year while vacationing in Florida, it is one of the highlights.  The animals appear happy and well cared for, the staff very caring and nurturing. My daughter learns about sea life by being up close and personally seeing the demonstrations. It helps her to understand and respect sea life more because she can see the creatures as living things.', "I've been a member of the Dolphin Research Center since 2012 & I've made many visits. I have always felt that the trainers of the dolphins & sea lions not only have  the welfare of each animal in mind, they genuinely have strong relationships with them. I've never ceased to be amazed at how knowledgeable the trainers are, or at their wonderful interactions with each one. The love between the animals & their trainers is phenomenal! The dolphins love being together in sessions & interacting with each other & the visitors at DRC. I have learned so much about the the dolphins  & the sea lions. I do not feel that one trainer working with more than one dolphin at a time has ever been an issue, nor the natural environment at DRC. The trainers are professionals, & as professionals their wealth of knowledge is fantastic, & they would be the first to notice any issues that needed handling & bring them up to the appropriate persons for resolution. Thank you for diligently being committed to animal welfare, & for recognizing that US marine mammal parks like DRC are absolutely dedicated to educating the public & to providing the absolute top quality care.", "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Don't let the voices of a few override the benefits that Sea World offers to the community in the education and entertainment it has provided through the years and I hope for years to come.", "APHIS                                         5/2016 Thank you for the time, care and thoroughness you take to insure safety for marine mammals in facilities across the United States.  Your recognition of these institutes as providing outstanding treatment, care and maintenance of healthy habitats is greatly appreciated.  Thank you!  I spent a week at Dolphin Research Center as part of their Dolphin Lab program.  There I got a closer look and better education of a marine mammal facility.  During my time at DRC I participated in multiple in-water dolphin interactions, signal exercises, observation time, followed trainers on boardwalks, and watched other programs and training sessions.   During these times I had opportunities to watch trainers working with more than one dolphin at a time.  I was impressed with both the dolphins' interactions with the trainer and each other  and also with how the trainer interacted with multiple dolphins during this time.  There was no confusion and the animals seemed to enjoy themselves.  Being a dog trainer myself, I know the benefits and difficulties of a trainer working with more than one animal at a time. There are many enrichments and learning opportunities that the individual animals receive during sessions where multiple animals are involved. Please allow one trainer to work with multiple dolphins at the same time.  I would also like to make a comment on your proposal that the dolphins remain visible to the trainer during interactions.  This would not be beneficial to some facilities, such as Dolphin Research Center, which are located in the dolphin's natural habitat. During my visit to DRC, I observed that although at times the water was not easy to see very far through, it never appeared to cause problems.  The trainers still seemed to know just about where the dolphins would surface when they were asked for a behavior. And for the most part, the dolphins remained visible on or near that surface during guest interactions, such as for dorsal tows or imitations.  Please reconsider these two proposed regulations and not implement them.  Once again, thank you for your care and protection of both marine mammals and the people who work with and visit them.  Thank you also for your time to read this comment.  Sincerely, Deborah Kurz Dolphin Research Center Member", "It's time to stop the political correctness in this Institution, who has been one of the few places where they really care for our world!!! The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", "o\tI work with California sea lions at Georgia Aquarium and have years of experience working with this species.  Given the number of years this species has been successfully and safely managed in zoological settings, I am confused by APHIS's suggesting to move this species to a Group II pinniped.  While males occasionally display dominance behavior, in my opinion they are highly compatible and thrive in situations where they can exhibit species appropriate social behaviors.  Given the history of caring for this species, it seems unnecessary to make this change which will ultimately limit social interactions and reduce holding capacity for a species in need given the recent dramatic increase in stranded, non-releasable sea lions.", "I'm writing you today because I'm very passionate about this issue.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild.
