The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Now my seven year old son is being insipered by the amazing work sea world does. I can only hope that this will continue for many more years", 'Please don\'t allow "activists" who are more concerned with power and control than the well-being of the animals make decisions for these said animals. The trainers and caregivers know them best and the decisions involving their care should be left to them alone  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'As a former member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association, and a current member of The Animal Behavior Management Alliance, and having dedicated my 30-year career to connecting millions of people with megavertebrates and increasing our scientific knowledge about them, I am very concerned about these proposed rules changes.     IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I have worked in the marine mammal care field for 4 years and have enjoyed educating and inspiring guests during our interactive programs with common bottlenose dolphins.  Our interactive programs are overseen by experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers.  Given the tremendous safety record related to supporting interactive programs at our facility and other marine parks throughout the country, I personally do not see a need for APHIS to impress animal welfare regulations related to interactive programs.', 'I support sea world in all regards  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I am a season pass holder and thus a frequent visitor to Gulfarium Marine Adventure Park in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.  During my visits, I have observed educational presentations and also spent time watching many sessions between the dolphins, sea lions , seals, and their trainers.  In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's dedication to loving and caring for the animals and the clean environments in which the animals live.   As a visitor, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  They emphasize some of the beach litter that are dangerous to marine animals and this has  impressed the young visitors who have been my guests to be more careful.   I'd like to thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and that you did not feel compelled to unnecessarily change regulations.  Thank you!", "Thank you, in advance, for your attention to this letter. It is important to me that organizations like zoos and Sea World continue to be supported in order to provide for, care for, and restore stranded, injured, and ill wildlife. Limiting caretakers' access to the animals could inhibit their ability to provide the highest quality of oversight and care. Likewise, the educational advantages gained through close monitoring and observational interaction would be lost if these interactions are limited. Because I am interested in the preservation and promotion of the welfare of animal populations around the world, granting trainers and caretakers adequate access to their animals is paramount. Limiting human / animal interactions will limit their observations and will limit the education that comes from such relationships. In a world where species are threatened and dying off, the last thing we want is for there to be less education.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Stewarding the wildlife of this planet is a difficult, valuable, and essential task. Please do not make it harder for dedicated animal professionals to do their job. Thank you again for your attention.", 'I have been informed of the updating of the regulations in regards to marine mammal care facilities. With the added momentum of animal rights advocates, I needed to add my voice to those who advocate for science based reasoning and logic. As a 36 year old woman pursuing a career in a science field, emotion is not a place where one can critically think and form accurate opinions. This is where animal rights advocates form their opinions, from emotions. I request for these updates to be focused on animal welfare and science. Providing the best possible care to any animal is priority #1 for many accredited institutions.  In addition, I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Please revise and update your proposals and standards to reflect current scientific understanding of marine animals, and the care and treatment they deserve!  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I believe the facility at seaworld orlando is some of the best in the world. Don't let the protesters win, they only want their 5 minutes of fame, they don't care about the animals because they wouldn't take their opportunities zoos and aquariums give them, taken away.", 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  The agency has decided not to change the space requirements for the several marine mammal species covered by the regulations, even though those space requirements were originally established over 30 years ago. In 1984, the last time the space standards were updated, the science on marine mammal movements in the wild was not very advanced. Within the past 15 years, however, technology has emerged that allows scientists unprecedented access to the world below the waves inhabited by marine mammalsand an outpouring of studies has ensued. Yet, APHIS stated in its proposed rule that it was unaware of any science supporting changes in the space requirements. That APHIS could imply that such science is lacking (or claim to be unaware of it) strains credulity.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging te
column5: d money; you'll never be able to regulate intelligence.", "I'm sorry, but I feel this proposal is absurd. You are considering banning a product that is marketed to adults and is clearly labeled to keep away from children because it sends less than 600 children a year to the emergency room, while skateboard injuries are responsible for 50,000 visits a year to the emergency room (AAP, March 2002). In addition, hospital emergency rooms and doctors offices treat hundreds of thousands of trampoline-related injuries each year. Both trampolines and skateboards are marketed to and intended for use by children.   And the argument that there is no way to know if any in the set are missing is patently false. There are many structures that can be quickly assembled that require all the magnets to be present, for example a set of 216 can make a 6-sided cube, one large, flat hexagon, or twelve 2-layer hexagons. I routinely return my sets one of these shapes when I am finished playing with it to ensure that none have strayed.   I love my magnetic balls. They are a great stress reliever and I enjoy creating with them.", "Yes, there is value in these being labeled as dangerous but to ban a product because some people are not vigilant enough to watch to be sure their young children aren't ingesting the product is ridiculous.", "Please, do not ban these wonderful toys. Yes, make sure they're clearly labeled and that people know that they can't be near kids who aren't old enough to know that they shouldn't eat them. But something this cool that also teaches scientific principles is rare. We need more toys like that, not fewer. Please reconsider.", "Don' ban bucky balls unless your willing to ban back yard trampolines.", "don't bann buckey balls, they are far more vaulbe as teaching tools than any damage they can do.", 'do not ban!', "Don't treat these magnets as a hazard. They are nothing but fun, creative timespenders. There are plenty of more dangerous, less entertaining things around. Focus on those, rather than on these innocent ones...", 'I am appauled that "Buckey Balls" have not been taken off the market knowing all the serious dangers and events that occured to children from swallowing them.  No parent can be watching their children every second, and that is all it takes to swallow two or more  of these magnets.  You have the evidence, what are you waiting for?  Do more children have to have endoscopic proceedures, to death of their entire bowels while you listen to the money- hungry corporation who doesn\'t care about our children and grandchildren\'s safety?  Remeember you are the "consumer product saftey commission".', "I find it appalling that the CPSC is considering banning something due to the inability for other people to parent their children. Balloons, trampolines, bicycles, skateboards, swimming pools, and countless other products cause more injury and death to children and the difference is these things are ALL marketed to children yet magnets are NOT. It's sad that one can go out and buy ammunition but can no longer go out and buy magnets. Get your priorities straight CPSC!", "I am a customer of Zen Magnets and Bucky Balls.  I find the product very interesting and fun.   I understand that there are dangers associated with swallowing the magnets, but pretty much any small toy can have dangers in swallowing. When I was 3 years old, I ripped my mouth open from the hook on a swing requiring major surgery. When I was 9, I inhaled a Lite-Brite peg, which ended up in my lungs.  When I was 12, I fell on the sidewalk from rollerblades that required surgery in my hand.  I have had stitches several times from falling off my bicycle.  I have had multiple shoulder surgery's from basketball injuries.  Aside from proving my being very prone to injury, I hope it illustrates that all toys can be dangerous.  We can't just regulate everything away in the name of safety.  Parents need to have some responsibility with their children, and realize that some toys (such as these magnets) are not for young children that would put them in their mouth.  And even for older children, should be used with adult supervision.   If giant labels on the product are required to help people realize that they can be hazardous, then that is fine.  But banning a product in its entirety seems a little overkill.  I am surprised products like magnets are being considered to be banned when other products on the market are sold that are known to cause cancer and other life threatening injuries (cigarettes, tanning beds/salons, etc).    And yes, cigarettes are marketed to kids too. But all they need is a warning label, and it's fine.  So why is a label not enough in the case of magnets?", 'Magnetic toy sets should not be banned. It is the parents responsibility to make sure that their child is mature enough to use any toy.', 'I oppose this standard which will limit the use and/or power of small magnets. More often than not these toys are used safely and responsibly without incident. The government should work to eliminate ignorance by attaching the proper safety labels and warnings to these products, but should not prevent those who would use them responsibly from doing so.', 'These magnets represent a clear health risk for children.  Since the only benefit is as an amusement toy and the dangers are signficant, serious and frequent, I strongly support the proposed ban.', "While it is understood that small powerful magnets can be a hazard for small children who swallow them, the same can be said for thumbtacks, earrings, safety pins, and other small metal objects that are commonly available in US Households. The idea that things that are dangerous for children must be banned outright it preposterous. Thousands of items per year are sold that would be dangerous, poisonous, or otherwise harmful for children to ingest, and it is up to the children's caretaker to prevent them from doing so.", "Children who are at risk of swallowing these things shouldn't be left alone with them in the first place.   These things aren't unsafe when used with proper supervision.", "This safety standard for magnet sets is the most ridiculous nonsense I have ever heard of.   What's next, banning thumbtacks?   Rat poison is not meant to be ingested either....shall we ban that?  I have an Idea, it's called parenting.   Let's have all parents not feed their kids magnet's, paper clips, thumbtacks, or rat poison.   Meanwhile, we can skip ridiculous ban's of otherwise harmless objects.", "I am incredibly disappointed at the CPSC for banning these magnets.  While we're at it, lets ban Knives, (Kids can cut themselves!!), forks (they can stab themselves 4 times!!!), bicycles (they can fall on the road, and never mind sharing the road with cars!!!), etc.  The CPSC needs to grow up and learn how to do their jobs.  There are far more dangerous devices, directly marketed to children (Buckyballs are not directly marketed to children) that can cause death, for example, a trampoline can cause INSTANT DEATH if the child lands on the ground and breaks his/her neck.  What a waste of taxpayer's money...", 'I have used a variety of very small objects my entire life even as a very small child and I have never misused them. Although I never read directions for any "new toy" I may acquire I always read safety information. Just because some people are to ignorant, stupid or unintelligent to either read the warnings, attempt to understand them, or use their apparently uncommon sense the rest of the public should not suffer. Company\'s put warning labels on thing for a reason, those people that do not listen to them deserve the consequences they get. As for the parents that leave the potentially dangerous things lying about despite the fact they have small or "inquisitive" children, they lived and they will learn for the next time. If one really thinks about it eventually there will be a ban on simple eating utensils because you can cut your self with them. A line needs to be drawn and it needs to be done now while there are still people competent enough to do it. I believe that if more restriction must be made maybe an age requirement to purchase would help some. Coupled with a ban on magnets in any toy intended to children under a specified age. I have much more to say but I would only be driving on the same point. Although it is a choice directly out of my hands there are other like me and the more of us there  are the less powerful you, the decision maker, become. Keep that in mind whilst you pass your final judgement upon this matter.', 'Do not ban these magnet toys!  Instead opt for better warning labels on packaging!', 'Banning a particular type of magnet building set due to improper use by consumers is idiocy.  The government in general, and the CPSC in particular, should not be in the business of protecting people from themselves.  Every single person has the right and responsibility to decide for themselves how to live.', 'Magnets should not be illegal.', 'As a parent, I see the need for safe products for children. Furthermore, hazards presented by the consumption of magnets by children undoubtedly arise from their possession by small children.  However, magnet sets are not used by small children alone. These sets provide educational utility, entertainment and sometimes hardware utility.  As I read it, It appears the government would effectively prevent access to small magnets by all citizens.  In lieu of a complete ban on small powerful magnet sets, perhaps a notice of the hazard and a recommended age-set on the packaging would suffice.  I am against a ban preventing sale of powerful magnets to, and therefore ownership by, citizens.', 'The proposed safety standard for magnet sets is flawed in its basic premise. These sets are an adult toy sold to adult individuals, and should no more be subject to child safety standards than other objects intended for adult use. If an adult gives a child such a magnet set, that adult should be considered responsible for any harm that may befall that child just as much as if that adult had given the child a knife or other dangerous object intended for adult use.', 'Stop making fun illegal please.', 'I am firmly opposed to regulating the sale of magnets in this manor.  I am frankly appalled that this is even an issue. As a consumer and a parent, I am deeply bothered by the lack of personal responsibility that leads to this kind of regulation.', "If you're going to ban these magnet toys, you should be prepared to ban all potentially harmful products to children, such as pencils, books, bicycles, etc.  The fact that my tax dollars are being spent on something so asinine hurts my brain.", 'Removing Bucky Balls, Zen Magnets, and the like would be a tragedy.', 'I believe BuckyBalls and Zen magnets are no more dangerous than other products that have been on the market for decades.  Trampolines, remote control helicopters, bb guns, etc. are many such products that remain legal to sell, despite the danger for misuse.  Responsibility should remain with parents to protect their children and teach them to use due care in the presence of such products.  Thank you for your consdieration.', 'Small magnets should not be banned.  The common household has an array of items and chemicals which are dangerous or fatal to any individual who handles them inappropriately.  Small magnets should not be an exception, and should be allowed to be bought and sold within the United States.  Banning small magnets sets an inappropriate precedent for future innovations that try to create a space in the US market.', 'Keep the magnets! They do no harm if used properly!', 'I do not think that this should be enacted.  There are very few documented cases of injuries.  Most, if not all, could have been avoided if parents had taken appropriate, common sense precautions.    There are thousands of more dangerous things out there that the government should be focusing on than this.', 'There are more dangerous objects in the marketplace that do not provide an opportunity for captivating demonstrations of scientific principals.  A ban of these  items vs a labeling requirement would be another example of our government stifling business instead of providing functional change and regulation in the consumer market.  A mistake as far as this taxpayer is concerned.', 'I think this regulation is STUPID. Parents should control their children.  I love these magnets and I should be able to buy them. This is America and freedom of choice rules.', "There are millions of products out there that can cause harm if used improperly.  A company with an ingenious, innovative, creative product should not be penalized for the inappropriate use of their product.  Warning labels can be and have been added but when it comes down to it, parents should take the time to research a product before buying it, as should any caregiver of anyone who may not make appropriate decisions.  No company should be held liable for a person who knowingly uses a product inappropriately. Surely, cars, tools and household chemicals could easily be 'banned' if the same consideration was applied.  It is immensely unfair to dismantle a company, a business that is creative and provides jobs for others, because consumers are unwilling to take responsibility for their decisions and their purchases.  This happens far too frequently these days and needs to stop.", 'How can you put such a strong ruling against something like this yet you do nothing about the laundry packets that are being ingested by children at an alarming rate!', "I don't a need for a law when simple parental supervision will do.  If anything put an age restriction on purchase of 18.", "Stop trying to kill business'  Science can be taught using these.", "This is beyond ridiculous. I just cannot understand the ban on small magnetic balls. I don't particularly like them but I do believe this is an example of the government over-reaching. There are so many other items out there that are harmful. These are not sold to children. A little parent responsibility and common sense would solve 99% of these problems How about single individuals? Why can't they purchase them? Why don't we ban kitchen knives? Electrical outlets? If people don't like them then they don't have to buy them.", "I have been using buckyballs for a while, and they are fun and enjoyable. Please do not ban these. Instead; you should be focusing legislation on punishing negligent parents who allow their kids to get access to toys or injure themselves. You can't ban stupidity. But you can make stupid people learn that they need to think about what they do, including giving their kids magnets, dish soap, kitchen knives, or any other dangerous object.", 'I want to make a few things abundantly clear I love these products, I have currently nine sets of Bucky products in my household. I take extreme care when using them, and I ALWAYS check to be 100% sure none are missing when putting them away. If one is missing I do not leave my room until it is found. I have no children in my household but I do have pets. I take extreme precautions as a pet owner to be sure my pets do not ingest them, it is my responsibility to do so. If I were a parent I would bear the same level of responsibility.   I am a 25 year old college student and these regulations are simply going to far and could potentially put a muti-million dollar company out of business, which is not what this country needs during a recession.   My point of writing this is to illustrate one simple point: you cannot save people from themselves. 165 teens and children are rushed to emergency rooms every day due to getting a hold prescription drugs. Since 1973 112 children have died choking on baloons. In 2008-2009 over 5000 children were killed by firearms, the youngest of which was 3 years old, the father did not have a firearm secured properly and the child accidentally shot themselves, no charges were filed against the parents.  Buckyballs has sold 2.5 million sets and by using your own numbers there have been 1700 incidents, which means that of the sets in the market 99.999932% of the sets were used in a responsible manor resulting in zero injuries.   Banning, restricting and fundamentally forcing a company to change and alter their product based on a relatively small number of incidents is unfair and ridiculous. Buckyballs have 5 safety warnings on their package, instructional videos on their site, they are a company that has taken a very proactive approach for safe use of their products.  Responsibility ultimatly lies with consumers.  This letter will be sent to my representative and senator and will be published on the web.', 'I think the banning of sphere magnets is a foolish one. While there might be problems with them, there are problems with everything in the world. The problems of these are very minor. There are better things to go after than magnets. It is silly and will save very little.', 'I\'m sure you\'ve heard this before but throwing my name in the mix as well.  I understand the danger with presenting these to children.  Simple fix: don\'t present them to children.  Let\'s not take away all possible dangers in the world - let\'s rely a bit more on parents being good parents.  Should we ban all household cleaners that would be poisonous if ingested?  Should we ban all cutting knives?  Should we ban all motor vehicles?  I\'m pretty sure a motor vehicle would be dangerous if a kid attempted using it.  Please don\'t ruin this for the adults who safely "play" with these "toys."', "Please do not ban these! It would be an absolute travesty! I have been buying extra just in case you go through with it, but there is no reason to deprive millions of people of fun because of a possibility of danger. Consider button batteries, and numerous other things which are much more dangerous than these magnets. Just look at the statistics. There have been orders of magnitude more kids injured from button batteries alone than these magnets.   Every product on the market has a potential for danger when misused. You cannot ban everything.   But especially not Bucky balls or zen magnets! They are without a doubt the most fun product I have ever owned, and I have given at least 20 as presents over the years to my friends. It's simply not right to ban them when you consider the minuscule danger involved. I understand that some people will get hurt, but it's such a small number when you consider how many people own these magnets.", 'The rules that apply to this product should be the same that apply to other toys with small parts.  The company should issue a warning that the product is not intended for children of a certain age and younger.  It is really up to parents to ensure the safety of their children, as the product itself it not dangerous.', 'The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets]', 'It is my opinion that this proposed rule against strong magnets in consumer-targeted magnet kits is unfounded.  I understand the risks to small children and animals as the Consumer Product Safety Commission has put forward.  However, the products that have these small magnets have clear warnings labeled on them, and the items are not for sale to children.  The risk that is claimed against products of this nature is not valid.  For example, cleaning products, personal grooming products (including razors) are indeed as dangerous or more dangerous, but steps have been put into place to prevent these items from becoming accessible to children and animals.  It is my strong belief that the responsibility ought to rest solely on the person who purchases such magnets to ensure that they are kept from the reach of small children.  In this specific case, I do not believe that it is the role of the Government to decide what is best (to be the "babysitter")  in this proposed rule against these magnets.  These magnets can allow for people of the appropriate age to learn about magnetism and science in general.  In my own personal use, I used these magnets to prototype a design of a product I hope to be able to bring to the commercial market in the next few years.  These magnets are useful for: (1) teaching, educating, inspiring children (of appropriate age), (2) prototyping, building, simulating a product/design/mechanism.  Please don\'t allow them to be banned! They do more good than bad, and there are plenty of worse items out there.  It\'s existence should not be threatened by anything other than the will of the overall Marketplace (consumers at large). Thank you.', 'This is a safe product as long as you follow the instructions. The same as any other product that can hurt you.', "It is unreasonable to ban these toys outright.  They can be marketed to adults.  Warning labels on the products clearly show the risks they may pose to small children.  How is this any different than choking hazards or other potentially dangerous situations which involve younger children using a toy that is designed for an older audience?  This is the parent's fault for allowing the child to play with a product designed for a specific age group.  I see this as an abuse of power by the consumer product safety commission, which will ultimately hurt the economy and curb creativity and ingenuity.", 'Please do not ban Bucky Balls or Zen Magnets. There are plenty of products on the market that if used incorrectly can cause injuries or death. Bucky Balls if used properly are completely safe. If someone decides to put something in their mouth that should not be there then there are plenty of other items they can find that will cause serious damage as well, but that does not mean those products or these should be banned. Please do not ban these wonderful adult toys and cause the layoffs of their workers.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:   The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.   Seriously, you folks stick warning labels on everything, and yet you believe that warning labels and responsibility are not enough to prevent abuse of these magnet sets, when a statistically zero percent of the population has been injured, and yet thousands of children are seriously injured riding bicycles every year?', "Hands off my balls. My Bucky Balls.  Label them, restrict them, but don't ban science!", "Very simply, this is a colossal waste.  You're taking a product off the market because someone failed as a parent?  What's next?  Television?", "One of my favorite toys as a child was a set of magnetic marbles, but I was always frustrated by their weakness, and inability to form complex shapes. Certainly, that set was a lot safer for me to play with as a child, but while child safety in toys is an important issue, there are MANY things that are both dangerous and inappropriate for children to play with. Just because something isn't suitable for children does not justify banning wholesale. And I'm a lot more worried about children (and adults) being injured by vehicles and handguns, then magnets that their parents should not allow them to have in the first place.", "I am a 33-year-old adult without children of my own. I have owned a set of Buckyballs for a few years (and ordered 4 more sets after I learned of this ridiculous action by the CPSC).   I have two cats and currently live with two dogs and my 13-year-old nephew, yet not one of them has ever been hospitalized for magnet ingestion. Why? How have I accomplished this remarkable feat?   By keeping my Buckyballs in their case in a desk drawer.   By keeping careful track of them when I have them out, quickly picking them up if they drop, keeping them away from the animals, making sure all are accounted for before putting them back in the drawer. (It's not that hard - if you form them into their starting cube shape at the end of each play session, you can easily tell if any are missing!)  AND by instructing my nephew about not putting non-food items in his mouth, especially magnets.   Buckyballs has FIVE warnings on the packaging alone, warnings on their website, warnings on their store displays. And common sense dictates that anything so small should be kept far away from children who still put things in their mouths, regardless of age (& older kids should be educated). The limited number of incidents caused by careless people who don't heed those warnings and/or let children anywhere near an item that is clearly marketed as an ADULT TOY does not warrant a full-on ban of the item. They didn't follow the rules, they are the victims of their own lack of personal responsibility. There is no need to punish Buckyballs or those of us who are responsible magnet owners.  I don't understand what more you expect Buckyballs to do. Send a personal agent home with every product purchaser to ensure they don't let their children swallow them? There has to be a sane stopping point where you 1) admit that this company has done more than most to point out the hazards and 2) hold the parents to some measure of accountability.  I do not need the CPSC to save me from my own desk toys, thank you.", "For the people, by the people...what a joke, I have badly wanted a mandala set, by zen for the longest time.  Now I might not ever be able to buy one?  Why, you might ask, because of our government, there are plenty of more dangerous things right under my kitchen sink.  I've had enough this rediculous, I'm sooo upset, just thinking about it stresses me out.  I can't type this anymore, have fun crushing peoples dreams, damn dream crushers. Government A*Holes", '"Small and potentially harmful" should not be the standard by which we ban things.    These are clearly labeled as "not toys."  You know what else can be swallowed by a child? A fishing hook. Rat poison. A paper clip.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:      The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.     The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.     These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', "I think you should not ban the magnet sets.  Guns cause thousands of deaths and three times more injuries per year. You have not, and are not banning gun sales in the US.  Please focus on things that are truly a danger to ourselves and our children.  Firearm injury in the United States has averaged 32,538 deaths annually between 1970 and 2002 .  It is the second leading cause of death from injury after motor vehicle crashes and, in several states, is the leading cause of injury death.  An estimated two nonfatal injuries occur for every firearm death.  That is 97,614 injuries per year, on average.  You're going after magnet toys with only 850 injuries a year over a 2 year period?  http://www.uphs.upenn.edu/ficap/resourcebook/pdf/monograph.pdf  Even bottles pacifiers and sippy cups lead to an estimated 2270 injuries to children under 3 per year, lets ban those first, who knows how many 4 and five year olds get hurt also!", 'We do not ban guns and we do not ban toy knives. Both can do more damage than some magnets. Banning these is the very definition of a nanny state, and the citizens will not stand for it!', 'This is ridiculous! We should be able to buy whatever we want to buy', "Magnet spheres are infinitely entertaining, and it's disgusting that a government agency thinks they can step in and attempt to outlaw them just because they think some kids will ingest the spheres. Listen to Nancy Nord - she's got the right idea.", "I am the proud owner of Buckyballs desk toys. They are clearly marketed as ADULT toys and we are very careful to keep them away from our 2 year old. We have several sets. These toys are only dangerous to children because their parents are too careless to do their job. Don't punish the company! Punish the parents! Ruining a successful company, and removing adult only toys from the market will not help the economy. These toys are fun, educational, and stress relieving for ADULTS.. Do not take away my fun, and ruin a company because some parents are careless.  Educate the public (which Buckyballs is doing)!!!!", 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market. -----', 'This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.  These organizations have worked with the CPSC and done everything needed, and now the CPSC is acting in such a manner contrary to their previous prior dealings with the effected companies.   As a consumer, I think the CPSC is overreaching. Personal responsibility is key. We don\'t let children play with ball bearings, and we have not banned every magnet out there because of the potential (ab)use by children. Parents should be responsible and not let these ADULT TOYS fall within their hands.  I believe that there should be a category promulgated that is classified as an "ADULT TOY" wherein the CPSC can designate particularly age-inappropriate items and disallow their sale at establishments where children may express an interest.', "Please do not ban or add restrictions on certain magnet types.  We do not need more regulation, promote education instead. The magnets are important for experiments and projects, banning them is a waste of everyone's time and money.", "I am opposed to the banning of these magnet sets. They inspire creativity and hands-on learning for everyone who takes the opportunity to handle them. I have 3 sets myself, and it's not enough! My kids love them, and I love them.   Please, please do not ban these!", "What has happened to common sense in this country?  If parents and other responsible adults

column2: adequately living conditions and are often treated  inhumanely.  The Federal Government needs to make certain that they have  decent living conditions, are not treatly inhumanely and are allowed socialization  with other elephans. Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', "I am contacting you to express my support for all efforts to drastically improve  conditions for captive elephants in this country. Ask the USDA to create tough  new standards, and mention the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards including: Exhibitors of elephants should provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.', 'Elephants should not be warehoused in small exhibit areas of zoos. They should  be banned from use by circuses, which have a history of abuse with bullhooks and  extreme neglect. Elephants belong in the wild ... but for those now in captivity,  only sanctuaries dedicated to their care offer a state in which an elephant can live  some semblence of a natural life. For their physical and mental health, elephants  require ares of space, on natural earth, trees to rub against and bodies of water to  bathe in. Most elephants should not be alone, as they are social animals. Any  and all steps that the USDA takes toward sanctuary life are improvements over  the treatment and conditions to which captive elephants are now legally subjected.', 'I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this country,  including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as  requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California.  These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force  against elephants.   Please consider these efforts in improving the lives of these animals.  Thank you.', 'Please tell the USDA that you support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough new standards  that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California.  These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force  against elephants.', 'I AM GREATLY CONCERNED THAT WE USES THESE GREAT ANIMALS  FOR  OUR HUMAN AMUSEMENT AND THEN WHEN THEY AGE AND WE FIND  THAT THEY ARE NO LONGER APPEALING OR THEY BECOME TO ILL WE  CAST THEM OFF LIKE TRASH .................LET THEM RETIRE WITH OUR  RESPECT AND CARE ..........................THEIR ALSO NEEDS TO BE  REGULATIONS FOR ZOOS AND CIRCUSES REGARDING PROPER SPACE  AND TREATMENT WHILE IN THEIR CARE .........EXHIBITORS OF ELEPHANTS  MUST BE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE LARGE  NATURAL AREAS FOR THE  HEALTH  AND WELL BEING OF THESE GREAT ANIMALS ...............TO LIVE HEALTHY  LIVES', 'Conditions for elephants in zoos and especially in circuses are horrible.  Chaining  and the use of weapons like bullhooks and electric prods should not be permitted  under any circumstances.  Elephants run for up to 12 hours per day in their  natural environment, so when they are forced to live in small areas, they develop  severe health conditions such as arthritis and painful foot conditions.  It is  extremely cruel to keep elephants confined and is made even worse by the  brutalities they are forced to endure in order to perform tricks.  There are  sanctuaries in Tennessee that should serve as models for captive elephants.', 'I support all efforts to improve conditions for captive elephants in this country,  including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the Animal  Welfare Act.  New and stonger standards need to be created that require provision  of large natural climate-controlled environments similar to those at The Elephant  Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. The use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other such methods  need to be prohibited once and for all.  Zoos and circuses are not providing necessary provisions. They are not meeting  decent requirements.  I request that USDA officials do whatever is necessary for better treatment of our  country\'s elephants. I can only wonder what people from India think when they  come here and see how Americans treat these "gentle giants".  How do you think  this makes us look in the eyes of the rest of the world?', "I have worked as an elephant keeper for the last 12 years at the Oakland Zoo in  Oakland, California.  I only say that as a point of reference and wish to add that  the views are mine and may or may not totally agree with the Zoo's offical position  on these issues.  We maintain 1.3 African elelphants in a protected contact  environment.  Arthritis has been documented as a relatively common issue with captive  elephants.  I believe several factors contribute to this problem.  Among these are  the substrates the elephants are exposed to, the weight of the animal, general  inactivity and prolonged chaining.  Like many of those who have previously responded I agree that hard surfaces  such as concrete, asphalt and hard packed soils put undue pressure on legs and  joints.  We have attempted to mitigate this somewhat by the use of rubber mats in  the indoor holding areas.  Outside holding areas that provide only hard packed  surfaces to little to alleviate this issue.  Ideally a substrate that provides some  cushion and which allows for necessary sanitary considerations would be best.  Captive elephants tend to be heavier than those in the wild.  Increased activity  levels and somewhat inconsistent diet due to climatic and seasonal changes work  to keep elephant weights lower than in captivity.  Excess weight puts additional  stress on joint/cartilage and increases wear rates.  General inactivity with captive  elephants adversely affects their ability to maintain healthy weights.  Chaining as  a management tool only adds to the problem.  Chains can and do provide a useful  tool in very specific situations but should be restricted to necessary health issues.  Proper foot care is a very subjective issue.  At a minimum each elephant's foot  needs to be cleaned and examined daily.  Some elephants need only minor  trimming and others require a more agressive approach.  Perhaps the best  approach would include more frequent inspections by knowledgeable experts to  ensure proper care is being maintained.  Various field experts report walking distances of 7 to 13 miles a day for free  roaming eleplhants. (Moss, 1988,  Sukumar, 2003)  We recently tripled the  outside holding area of our facility and attempt to maintain a minimum walking  distance of 3 miles per day.  Accredited zoos are required to meet the American Zoological and Aquarium  Association (AZA) standards for health care.  These are minimum standards and  do not necessarily provide the highest quality care.  For example, AZA standards  call for a minimum of 1800 sq ft for one elephant and 900 sq ft for each additional  elephant for outside holding area.  By this standard 41 elephants could be kept on  an american football field.  Common sense shows this is not acceptable.  I  endorse the standards as set forth in The Best Practices by the Coalition for  Captive Elephant Well-Being, 2005 (Kane, Forthman and Hancocks).  Wherever possible, I believe we should use nature to assist us in our decisions on  how best to care for captive elephants.  Unlike others who have responded I  strongly disagree that elephants should only be chained and housed indoor at  nights.  If facility design requires overnight chaining and no ability to single stall  animals then it is time for that facility to get out of the elephant business.  In conclusion, I would agree with the argument bigger is not necessarily better.   However, I will add that our elephants use all of the space provided.  In the two  years they have had access to the larger area they have all showed weight loss,  improved muscle tone and healthier feet.  Large does not mean better in and of  itself but it provides options that smaller spaces can not.", "I strongly urge you to protect the physical and emotional health of elephants.  In  many zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and  social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from  painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  I recently visited a zoo, and was  saddened by the conditions in which these animals live.  It's an average zoo, not  sub-standard or especially cruel, but it's still not a good environment for elephants.", 'I am contacting you to express my feelings on the way the elephants in captivity  are being treated and i would like to say that i believe the use of bullhooks should  be prohibited. As well as electric shock devices, chaining and any other device  that causes pain, suffering, injury to elephants. Also that all exhibitors of  elephants should be required to provide large cimate appropriate enviroments that  resemble there natural habitats. A very good example of this would be the  elephant sanctuary in tennesse and the performing animal welfare soceity  sanctuary in california.', 'It does not make sense to me to have these animals in unhealthy living conditions,  conditions that include lack of space, unnatural substrates, unnatural social  groupings, and the use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots, and other  instruments of force commonly used to control elephants.  This cruel and unecessary treatment of these animals needs to stop and needs to  stop now.', 'The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.   Anything that can be done to ensure better care for these captive animals should  have been done yesterday....please work to give them more space.', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being.  Even though the Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space, neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time.  Both circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  Thank you for this opportunity to comment.', 'Elephants, those mighty beasts, one of the most beloved African and Asian  species, but sadly one on the most abused of all exotic animals in captivity. These animals are highly intelligent, and very social, however zoos and circuses  are failing miserably to meet their physical and mental, as well as emotional  needs.  Something must be done to ensure that elephants have a good quality of life.  Currently elephants live a imprisoned existence:  -Chained up to 21 hours a day in one spot -traveling in a trailer with circuses nearly 365 days a year  -lack of  adequate space for normal every day walking  All of the above leading to devastating health issues as painful arthritis, digestive  disorders, neurotic behaviors to name a few. We as a society must ensure the health and well-being of these animals in  captivity.   Elephants suffer physical abuses in many  zoos and circuses. These abuses  consist of domination, force,  and aggressive use of the bull hook and other tools  to intimidate such as whips, clubs and electric shock. It is important  to protect  these animals and ensure they have a good quality of life by providing large  naturalistic environments similar to the wild with compassionate care. The  greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals  are treated. "Gandhi"', 'I invite you to carefully study the circumstances in which elephants live. From my  observation zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they  require for their health and well-being.   I understand the Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide  elephants with adequate space and that zoos and circuses currently fail to meet  this requirement.   It seems to me that in too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from  lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually  cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease,  reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and  head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and  foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive  elephants.   Recently I learned that circus elephants are still subjected to prolonged chaining,  spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the  year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure  extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo  elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn  stalls for extended periods of time. I also understand that circuses and many zoos  continue to control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use  of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric  shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.   I invite you to do everything in your power to require exhibitors of elephants to  provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary  in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in  California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which  elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.   Thank you for your thoughtful and prayerful consideration of and action in this  matter.', 'Zoos and circuses are violating the Animal Welfare Act by denying elephants  adequate space.  Elephants need to move freely and need to be on surfaces other  than concrete.  So many captive animals suffer from arthritis or foot disorders  which are extremely painful.  Circus elephants, like their zoo cousins, are  subjected to domination through force--we have all seen the bull hook in action.   My family and I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for elephants,  especially by eliminating elephants from zoo and circus settings by sending them  to elephant sanctuaries, in California and Tennessee.  There, they would have  hundreds of acres to roam over gentle terrain, as they would in nature.  There they  could enjoy good health and security.  We must end our domination of other  species, a crime we commit in the name of human entertainment, by outlawing  bullhooks, chains, electric prods and other pain-inducing, fear-inducing  instruments.  We owe these gentle giants so much more than we are currently  providing.  We urge USDA to continue the work begun with the Hawthorn  elephants--get them away from zoos and circuses.  Give them sanctuary.  Thank  you.', "I am writing because of my concern for the conditions that elephants are kept in zoos and  circuses. Research shows that elephants are extremely intelligent, social creatures. In many circuses  they are kept in chains and work constantly and are treated with force and controlled with pain.  In many zoos they are kept isolated and in very small enclosures which cause physical and  mental problems. To me it is a moral issue to treat all creatures humanely and with respect. This  is especially true for beings with emotions, intelligence and social interaction, which is the case  for elephants.  I have been to Africa three times and have had the privilege of seeing elephants in their natural  surroundings. They definitely had a complex interaction between herd members and were always  aware of where the humans were and what they were doing. Of all the animals I saw, including  lions, elephants were the most aware of human actions. I don't  even want to imagine what they  would go through if kept captive.  Please use your  authority to ensure that these magnificent creatures are kept in situations of  dignity and which allow them to thrive. Thank you.", 'If we confine a wild animal, we have a responsibility to maintain its physical and  psychological health by replicating the natural conditions in which it can thrive.   This includes normal range of activity, and social settings such as family groups,  herds, or packs.  Elephants in the wild spend their entire lives in family groups.  Because of their  massive size they must walk 30-40 miles on soft earth each day to avoid damage  to bones, joints, and feet.  Isolating elephants in small concrete or hardpack  enclosures condemns them to constant physical and emotional pain.  The USDA   must halt this practice at once.  Americans do not consent to inflicting a lifetime of  misery on helpless animals for entertainment.  With each passing year, zoos have more alternatives to the historic exhibition of  captive wild animals.  Children to not want to see, nor do they learn anything of  value from seeing, a solitary animal in pain and misery.  Robotics, holograms,  projections, ele-cams -- dozens of imaginative and playful technologies can teach  about elephants without sacrificing a single beast.   I urge the USDA and APHIS to confiscate all elephants confined in spaces less  than 10,000 acres per capita, and in groups of fewer than three adult females, and  to order them released to sanctuaries.  To understand the urgency of this request, please consider being locked in your  car for the rest of your life.  Thank you for your consideration.  Phyllis Elliott', 'Elephants are large animals and as such require appropriate accomodations. Zoos and circuses must be accountable to the Animal Welfare Act when taking on stewardship over these animals. Elephants need plenty of space and natural conditions to include socialization with other elephants. Elephants are often left chained for over 20 hours each day in enclosures and box cars enduring extreme temperatures and standing in their own waste, thus leading to preventable painful diseases that are the leading cause of euthenasia in captive elephants. Furthermore, the use of force and intimidation through bullhooks, whips, clubs and electric shock devices for managing these elephants is unnecessary and inexcusable. It is outright abuse to use any animal for exhibition while depriving it of conditions necessary to its health and well being. There are existing places already providing excellent models for humane elephant captivity: The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and The Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. There is every reason to expect this standard for all captive elephants. It is a matter of responsible stewardship.', 'As an animal lover I wish all animals would get fair treatment from everyone. As a  human being worried about our childrens future I ask the people to set an example  to the young children that all living things must be shown respect. Knowing that  children see that it is ok to have Elephants in habitats that are FAR from their wild- life settings will only lead the them to believe that they can be around for our  entertainment.', 'Elephants are highly complex, social animals who have very close family  connections in the wild.  However, zoos and circuses often sever these ties  without a thought to the elephant\'s wishes as they move elephants around, and  this causes extreme anguish.    Elephants in zoos are given inadequate space, because in the wild elephants will  roam 20 or more miles each day.  In addition, the concrete floors on which they  are forced to stand produce painful leg and foot problems such as arthritis.  The  confinement will also produce neurotic behaviors such as pacing or self-harm.   Reproductive system shutdown and high infant mortality rate are also common  problems. The AZA, a zoo industry trade organization, provides an inadequate set  of standards for the care of elephants. These standards include a minimum  outdoor enclosure size of 1,800 square feet for one elephant, the equivalent of six  parking lot spaces. The standards also allow the prolonged chaining of elephants.  Elephants are genetically designed to move and forage constantly during the day;  zoos do not even come close to providing the resources necessary for this sort of  behavior.    Circuses also provide cruel living conditions for elephants.  In addition the the  cramped quarters similar to the zoos, elephants must endure agony at the hands  of their trainers and handlers.  Ringling\'s head elephant trainer Troy Metzler was  recently observed on two occasions sinking his hook into an elephant\'s trunk and  yanking the hook toward him with great force, likely tearing the elephant\'s  sensitive skin.  In addition, he forced elephants to travel, perform, and endure  terrible conditions even when sick or painfully injured.    Animals used in circuses are subjected to violent training, continual confinement,  and grueling routines. Whips, bullhooks, and chains are used to punish and  control animals. Many people are beginning to reject the notion that a fleeting  moment of fun is worth the agony that these magnificent animals must endure  daily.   Ringling Bros. has a lengthy history of animal abuse and neglect. Currently, the  USDA has four open investigations into Ringling for the deaths of a lion and an  elephant, for a December 2005 incident in which two elephants ran amok inside  an arena in Puerto Rico, and for a videotaped incident last August described by an  elephant expert as "clear abuse" in which a handler hit and jabbed a 7-year-old  elephant with a bullhook.  Ringling is a for-profit corporation that constantly puts  business interests ahead of animal welfare.  Please improve the situations of these magnificent creatures, and allow the the  respect they deserve.', 'Given what we know of the social nature of elephants, it is a clear act of cruelty to  deprive captive elephants of the space and social interaction that they need for  health and well-being.  We know that they suffer from physical, emotional, and  social disorders akin to human post-traumatic stress syndrome when they are  enclosed in too-small spaces and isolated from others in their social groupings.
