Knowing all that we do, we must take action to ensure the well-being of this  amazing creature when it is put into our care.  Please ensure that regulations are  formed and enforced to provide adequate space, care, and social interaction for  elephants.  Thank you for your consideration.', "I don't believe elephants belong in zoos, and am so happy that the San Francisco Zoo decided to retire the remaining elephants. I happily support the SF Zoo and continue to take my children there because I know they care about the welfare of the animals. I think it's very important that elephants are given adequate space and food sources to make their existances in an unnatural environment as comfortable as possible.  You have a chance here to do something beautiful, and since the government doesn't always get that opportunity, I think you should enforce this effort to your greatest ability. Happy Holidays", "Please put an end to the torture of elephants.  It is absolutely horrendous what these poor  creatures have to endure in the name of circus' and side-show attractions.  Laws must be enacted  to protect their security from these horrible abuses and atrocities.  Please do all you can to ensure  their safety.  Thanks.", 'Aspects of elephant care that I believe are of concern and must be addressed  include:  lack of space, unnatural substrates, unnatural social groupings, and the  use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots, and other instruments of force that are  commonly used to control elephants . Please advocate for  humane standards for  the industry that contains elephants in enclosed and artificial environments.', 'I believe that elephants do not belong in zoos or circuses.  Neither zoos nor  circuses can provide the animals with the conditions they require to stay  physically and psychologically healthy.  The Animal Welfare Act requires zoos  and circuses to provide elephants with adequate space.  None of them are able to  do that and some of the more caring facilities have recognized that fact, sending  their elephants to The Elephant Sanctuary or the PAWS Sanctuary where they  have hundreds of acres to roam. There have been more than enough elephant deaths in the past couple of years  due to painful arthritis and foot disease, digestive disorders, and neurotic behavior. Animals that are meant to wander over hundreds of acres are not meant to stand  all day on concrete surfaces, be locked and chained inside for many hours each  day, and controlled by abusive bullhooks. All one has to do is to spend a few minutes watching elephants acting naturally on  the web cam at The Elephant Sanctuary to know that the life zoos and circuses  provide these animals is inadequate and actually cruel.', 'Dear USDA ;  I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens Petition) and creating tough  new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.   Why Change is Needed  These are the reasons you must take action:   1. Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their  health and well-being.   2. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement.   3. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and  circuses they suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful  arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing.  4. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when  the zoo is closed. And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for  extended periods during the cold winter months.   5. Additionally, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force,  domination and aggressive use of the bull hook and prolonged chaining. These  methods cause constant stress as well as physical and psychological injury to  elephants.   6. Because of their intelligence, complexity and unique social and physical needs,  elephants suffer in small, unchallenging zoo environments. Because of these  unique qualities and complex needs, elephants deserve much, much higher  standards than the ones that currently exist.   Thank you for your time', "Elephants' natural home is in the wild; the farthest they can get from this is the circus.  Circuses are extremelycruel.  With elephants chained down for long periods of time, boxed up in train cars for even longer periods of time, and forced to perform on stage, there is nothing justifiable.  Often, such conditions lead to sickness -- psychological and/or physical -- in the elephants.  Using bullhooks and other sharp instruments, elephant trainers use fear and aggression to train these gentle a
column3: chnology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'i have been a member of dolphin research center for over 25 years!on my numerous visits i believe them to be the best  place for caring for  dolphins as well as other mammals etc.. they do studies and educate guests when coming there to visit..it is a wonderful place to see how much they care for all marine mammals.it is by far the best place for those dolphins that live there.i went there myself on a visit as i said over 25 yrs ago and was so impressed i joined!the dolphins do what they want, when they want ,and arent stressed to  do shows and perform as in theme parks! THEY ARE WONDERFUL AT DOLPHIN RESEARCH CENTER IN MARATHON FLORIDA!THANKS FOR CARING!', "I have been working with marine mammals now for about two years, and continue to learn about and love them more and more. I would never have the compassion that I have now if it wasn't for facilities like Georgia Aquarium, Sea World, and Marineland. Being able to interact with them in such a personal atmosphere and learn hands on is an unforgettable experience for anyone. To be a part of a team that has a purpose, to inspire each and every person to want to make a change on this planet. These people walk away with a life changing experience and also with more love for these amazing animals. I am a very hands on type of learning type of person, as I believe most of us are, and without aquariums and zoos that give us an up close learning experience. I believe that every creature would be less and less cared about. Almost every trainer I have met started wanting this career at a very young age, and usually because of their first trip to Sea World. Without that experience, where would we be? I love my job and I love caring for these amazing animals and educating the public how they can make a change. These animals don't have a voice, so hopefully we can all speak up and help make a difference.", 'We love sea world and have been going since 1987. My children. Now enjoy everything I did but more thanks to research. Research is how we learn and make things better not only for captive animals but wild animals as well. What if we stopped scientific research on cancer treatments, how would we be able to help people. By stopping killer whale research, we are hurting wild and captive killer whales.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "May 2, 2016  Docket No. APHIS-2006-0085 Regulatory Analysis and Development PPD, APHIS Station 3A-03.8 Attn:  Dr. Barbara Kohn Senior Staff Veterinarian 4700 River Road, Unit 118 Riverdale, MD  20737-1234  Re:  Docket No. APHIS-2006-0085  Dear Dr. Kohn:  I'm reaching out to APHIS to share my professional insight regarding the proposed new language regulations.  I've been a long standing specialist of Dolphin Quest dating back to the period of time when the National Marine Fisheries conducted their initial studies on Swim with the Dolphin programs.  I have served on the board of the International Marine Animal Trainers' Association (IMATA) and continue to be an active member of the trainer community.  Currently, I serve on the board for the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums (AMMPA) as Director at Large.  From these collective experiences, I have committed my full professional career to advancing the science and wellness of marine mammals, promoting conservation through guest interactions, collaborating with like-minded scientists and marine mammal activists and fostering learning and development for our next generation of marine mammal advocates.      It's from this vantage point that I am able to recognize the importance of weighing in on these very important regulatory measures.  Thank you for providing the platform to do so.  Dolphin Quest is proud to meet and exceed the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) standards regarding dolphins under human care.  We pride ourselves on leading by example and value collaborating with those in our community who, like us, dedicate their lives to the animals under our care.  Our relationships with our animals run deep, often times, garnering our time and dedication to the same level or more that we provide our family members.  Through these long standing and cherished relationships comes a secure experiential understanding of the needs of our dolphins and the rich lifestyles they lead.  Their days, filled with social enrichment, learning challenges and large natural stimulating environments, are robust of mental and physical stimulation.  They flourish with species typical opportunities to play with each other in their ocean home while benefiting from an added advantage of the human animal bond.  This is the ultimate sanctuary for any animal.  From our long standing bonds come the privilege and responsibility of ensuring our animals' wellness is a top priority.  This is where government regulations come into play.    For close to three decades, Dolphin Quest has successfully conducted interactive programming with our family of dolphins and the guests who choose to join us in our ocean conservation campaign.  These programs have fallen under the current AWA standards and have a strong historical record of accomplishment, all with the animals' best interests at heart.  I feel that the general standards and guidelines have demonstrated an efficacy indicating no need to further regulate any type of interactive programming.  Our depth and breadth of experience handling our collective groups of animals only continues to flourish over time.  Attempting to blanket regulations over a large variety of marine mammal species and programming types will only limit our ability to continue expanding our learning horizons and animal management practices.  Our performance based standards speak for themselves as a community and should be enough to validate the current regulatory oversight we follow.    Our time is best spent nurturing our animal relationships, connecting and sharing with our guests and supporting new scientific understanding of the species in our care.  To have to divide our time managing additional regulations and standards that don't further the goals of the AWA seems to be an unreasonable request considering our history.  At the same time, APHIS will be burdened with follow through on reports and more intrusive inspections without furthering a meaningful goal.    Please default to your well stated recognition of the success and safety of interactive programming and focus on updating and fine tuning general standards and guidelines for regulating marine mammals under human care.  To date, it's been an effective way to ensure the AWA goals are met and the animals within the care of these organizations adhering to them are thriving.    Thank you for your time and consideration.  Michelle Campbell, MS Vice President of Animals Dolphin Quest / Quest Global Management", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Recently visited SeaWorld on a field trip with my grandchildren.  Wonderful experience in every way especially Samu and the animals.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I am a trainer at SeaWorld. Not only do I get to facilitate "the light bulb" go off for kids and adults but things I train the animals I care for could save lives.   My father was my biggest supporter in reaching my dreams of training killer whales.  He passed away before he was able to see me reach those dreams. Today the animals I work with are participating in a study that I helped train them to do.  Not only do they love participating in the study but it will someday hopefully be able to save someone like my father. Please make sure that places like SeaWorld will be here for my children. They foster a love for our earth and all of the animals in it. Through training and working with these animals it supports a safe and fun life for the animals who make SeaWorld a home. They also contribute in an enormous way to animals all over this world, including humans.', "The proposed modifications to the ventilation and lighting requirements seem reasonable in thatbased on the background information providedthey are beneficial to the animals and not very onerous on most facilities. The proposed rule's requirement that the ventilation maintain relative humidity at a level that prevents condensation in order to minimize the potential for bacterial, fungal, or viral contamination from condensation is one such example. The specific modification is expected to reduce risks of skin and mucous membrane irritation and bacterial and mold growth without imposition of any substantial costs.  Similarly, the proposed rule's specific lighting requirements also seem to be favorable to the animals. As indicated by the background information, the specific requirements would ensure normal functioning of metabolic systems for animals and provide facility personnel sufficient light to observe animals and to operate safely. Moreover, this can be done through the imposition of small, if any, expected costs due to the fact that most facilities are already in compliance. Also, the proposed requirement that shade must be accessible and must cover sufficient area to afford all the animals within the enclosure protection from direct sunlight seems very reasonable as it protects the animals from overheating, sunburns, and eye-damage.", 'To Whom It May Concern: \t \tThe proposed rule issued by the the Animal and Planet Health Inspection Service (APHIS) would greatly increase the health and well being of marine mammals in captivity. Captive marine mammals encounter more stress than their counterparts that remain in the wild. Implementing the proposed rules would provide a more comfortable living environment for all species involved. The revisions of the indoor facilities, outdoor facilities, space requirements, water quality, and the swim-with-dolphin programs would promote better living environments, and in-turn could potentially facilitate longer captive life spans, better breeding conditions, and overall a better quality of life. Studies have shown that captive marine mammals have a shorter lifespan vs. marine mammals in a natural habit.  In conclusion, I fully support the proposed rule that APHIS has implemented. I believe it will provide a better overall living condition for the marine mammals in captivity, and will increase their lifespans.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Please do not look at the numbers of people who visit those prisons but look at the numbers of people who do NOT visit those prisons. Investigate how many people are shocked and will never go back. If you choose for not making those prisons bigger then at least reduce the numbers of animals by not permitting the the facilities to take in more. For each rescued mammal they should mandatory give up and send back a healthy one to his or her natural habitat.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'According to these records, a proposed rule in the Federal Register was published on February 23, 1999. 13 sections were resolved but four were not. Those four are to be dealt with now. With the last of the resolutions in 2001, it has been 15 years that these four sections have sat still and those years that marine animals have suffered. It doesn\'t take a scientist to tell you that all animals deserve to be treated in the best facilities and with the highest quality of regards. I believe we should address these last four sections as well as re-address the other 13, as science has been making strides and animals should reap the benefits as humans do. This proposed rule also states a handful of new lingo for around and in pertinence to the term "swim-with-the-dolphins" and all with the highest regard to keeping every party involved safe. All actions in this ruling ensue protective and safe courters for all creatures involved. I support this proposed rule.', "My love of Dolphins grew expediently after having an in depth interaction course.  My son has learned about sea creatures by interacting with them at Sea World.  Every animal we've seen at all the SeaWorld parks have been well cared for.  You can see in their caregivers how much love they have for those in their care.   We have seen personally how they come to the rescue of stranded sea animals.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'I work with the millions of guests that are welcomed at Georgia Aquarium each year. I have had the experience of seeing guests of all ages see aquatic animals and ecosystems they may never see in their lifetime and strike a deeper understanding of the one world ocean that connects us all. All of us at Georgia Aquarium are committed to providing our guests with a positive and impactful experience to inspire conservation of our aquatic world. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of people the ability to see magnificent animals and learn more about them. Without the ability to see and appreciate these beautiful creatures, most will keep a "Why should I care?" attitude toward them and their fragile environments. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practices standards.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Sea World goes beyond the limit to take care of all the animals.  Their employees are knowledgeable and dedicated.  Please continue to let them do the necessary work to keep all animal safe and well cared for.', 'Please understand the importance of this message for marine life and for  the general public to share in the wonders of the deep that would otherwise be lacking.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.
