I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Again, thank you.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  There should be no captive marine mammals .  It is not possible to recreate even a small rendition of their natural home. It is cruel to keep Marine Mammals captive.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I definitely agree with the proposed amendment for the Animal Welfare Act. Given the fact that these animals are being kept captive and in most cases used for entertainment and human benefit, I think that they deserve to at least live in the best conditions possible. I think it\'s very important to keep in mind that the world is constantly changing and especially that new technologies are continuously being established. This means that we will continue to make new scientific discoveries and must realize that different methods can be improved, as is the case with the water temperature, ventilation, and lighting that captive animals would require in order to simulate their natural habitats as best as possible. And even congress members, Jared Huffman and Adam Schiff, issued a statement urging that the Animal Welfare Act be updated since "sound, modern science should inform our regulations on marine mammal captivity." And with the over 300 public comments submitted, this is clearly an important topic, where many people consider these updates overdue.  I also find it deeply unsettling that the regulations on the swim with the dolphin (SWTD) programs were suspended in 1999, especially considering the boom in the demand for these interactions. There should definitely be some sort of amendment made to this act that more clearly covers the requirements and regulations to carry out these SWTD programs and more enforcement to make sure that these animals aren\'t being mistreated. These programs are already quite risky considering that "captive dolphins may exhibit an assimilation tendency, expecting humans to fulfill the naturals roles of their wild counterparts." They could potentially become more sexually aggressive and agitated due to the "stressful conditions of forced interaction." These behaviors could result in not only harm to the animal, but also to humans. It is a definite necessity to implement more checks and controls on these interactions.  And even then these a
column5: using these magnets exercised their responsibilities to their children, all the pediatric GI doctors wouldn't be complaining.  I believe this ban is absurd and the CPSC should change its stance.  Parents, put down your smart phones, books, iPads, or whatever is occupying your time and watch your kids.  And if you have one or more sets of these magnets, I would suggest keeping them in a container or drawer that locks and put the key in a place where only you or other trusted adult would know where it's at.", 'Re: CPSC-2012-0050  Safety Standard for Magnet Sets   Dear Chairman Tenenbaum: As a practicing pediatric gastroenterologist, I appreciate the opportunity to comment in support of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commissions (CPSC) proposed rule on safety standards for magnet sets.   I am deeply concerned with the increasing frequency at which pediatric gastroenterologists and surgeons are treating infants, children and adolescents for ingestion of high-powered magnets. Despite laudable efforts by the CPSC to educate the public about the dangers of high-powered magnet sets and improvements in manufactures warning labels, data collected by the North American Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (NASPGHAN) provide compelling evidence that warning labels are not working. Magnet ingestions and the injuries they cause to children are preventable, and the most effective way to prevent ingestions is to ban the sale of high-powered magnet sets, as defined in the proposed rule.    Children sometimes swallow things they shouldnt, but these magnets pose special risk to children. Coins, marbles, and even thumbtacks often pass without incident. In contrast, when these high-powered magnets are swallowed, endoscopic or surgical intervention is required in nearly all cases to prevent bowel damage.   Magnet ingestions by children are no longer a rare occurrence. Manufacturers claim there have been few injuries from ingestion of magnets sold as part of their magnet desk toys. The experiences of pediatric gastroenterologists across the country who are treating children who have ingested high-powered magnets suggest otherwise.    The proposed rule accurately describes the injuries, which can be very serious and even life threatening, that result from ingestion of magnets from high-powered magnet sets. The vast majority of magnet ingestions require endoscopic or surgical intervention.', 'The idea of banning these is mind numbing. People need to take responsibility for their own stupidity.  Do not do it.', "I am opposed to this ban.  Do you plan do ban all items marketed to adults that are dangerous to children?  Of course not, it is well understood that there are a wide variety of items, including 'toys' that are not appropriate and/or safe for children.  This ban is overstepping your power, or even congress' power.  It would be understandable to require warnings and ensure that marketing was directed towards adults, for example following the precedent of restrictions on advertising alcohol, but an outright ban on a product that is useful, creative, and benign is ridiculous and undermines legitimate authority of the CPSC.", "Why?  Why attempt to regulate everything that *might* be dangerous?  I don't need a nanny.  And I don't need the government to be a nanny for my kids.", 'I actually have two comments/questions:  1.\tWhy cant emergency room personnel (or even parents) PRIOR TO INTESTINAL DAMAGE simply degauss the magnets with a bulk tape eraser and let the now non-magnetic material simply flow through and out of the intestines? 2.\tIn cases where ingestion of a magnet is even SUSPECTED, do a quick test with a compass before x-rays or expensive tests?  Perhaps emergency room personnel could be trained to make this standard procedure.  Im sure the manufactures of these magnetic toys would be happy to donate some $5.00 compasses to emergency rooms if it avoided the need to ban their products', 'Buckyballs should not be banned. Put a sticker on it!', 'Rare earth magnets are incredibly dangerous and even in families with good supervision pose a large threat to the safety and well being of children of all ages. Although they are not marketed to children, many children and teens have access to these "toys" and accidentally swallow them. They cause severe damage to the gastrointestinal track in a very short period of time and can result in serious morbidity. They should be withdrawn from the market.', 'I am opposed to any ban on these magnetic balls as long as appropriate warnings are included on the packaging.  When, in this country, are we as individuals going to take personal responsibility for anything!  To punish a manufacture who properly creates a product and properly displays any dangers that the product might pose, should not be punished because of the stupidity of the end user. Any parent with half a brain should understand the inherent danger to small children and should either closely monitor their play or not allow them to play with these magnetic balls.  I have grandchildren that thoroughly enjoy playing with them...but not alone! I am there with them making sure that they play responsibly. I have also instructed them not to put these in their mouths.  With adult supervision...they have had hours of safe fun. Is that just too much trouble for most adults? At some point, this nation has to stop trying to blame others for their own stupidity. We have become a nation that sues the other guy when we screw up.  Look at the warning labels on products these days. Many of them are so crazy until you realize that the company had to put that additional warning on their product because some fool did it and then sued the company. We might as well ban everything, because some idiot will use it incorrectly and then we all loose.', 'Label them dangerous and for children older than 12 but do not forbid them.', "Please do not ban magnets!  The proposed rule justifies the ban citing ingestions but not other actual physical harm from ingestion, and the benefits of magnets as instructional tools, artistic tools, and scientific tools vastly outweigh the unspecified damages.  This is a foolish rule.  Please, don't do it.", 'Its clear from reading the provided case studies that most of the ingestion incidents happened out of the supervision of the adults who purchased the magnets and therefore it seems unlikely that additional warnings would be effective. In the Navy we call those Administrative Safety Mechanisms and while they require the least effort they are also the least effective. Mechanical Safety Mechanisms like the one proposed by the CSPA are much better. It also bears noting that theyre not proposing to eliminate a literacy aid or a cultural fetish. Its a shiny toy for adults who probably should be doing more interesting things. As for children having access to them I cant think of any other industrial product which would be given to a child for use without supervision. You wouldnt dream of allowing a child to play with matches, staplers, acid or mercury and thats exactly why those products dont require as much regulation. The dangers are evident and recognized. Not so with magnets and therefore the CSPA is correct in proposing a rule. Furthermore, by regulating the size and flux of magnets they are acknowledging that potential of manufacturers to produce the product in a manner that will significantly reduce the risks posed without closing off the potential for revenue from this technology. The laudable efforts of the CSPA to include the major importers of this product in the regulatory process have met with limited success and only underline the need for a strong regulatory agency and I for one am glad to see that they are doing their job.', 'Vigorously OPPOSE the safety standards for magnets proposed rule.  Safety in the home is the irresponsibility of the parents of young children.  Education on risk factors or even product labeling is a much better idea than the outright  banning of useful everyday products.', 'The government will be breaking the Constitution by imposing this law.  Do not do this.', "I have problems with anxiety and playing with magnet spheres really helps me deal with the stress. When don't have them with me I'm always biting my nails off and chewing on my thumbs. Please don't ban them.", 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says: The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.  The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.  These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'Do not ban magnetic toys.  They inspire creativity and curiosity.  Label them, make a waiver but do not ban them.', "Just because something can be dangerous when used wrongly does not mean that the product needs to be banned. You could say the same of a pencil, or paint. Increase awareness of the age appropriateness of the product and make sure parents follow said rules. If we can't trust ourselves with an educational product, how can we trust ourselves with recreational devices that don't teach anything at all?", 'I am a pediatric gastroenterologist and had a case of young teenager autistic child who swallowed two "dragon-egg" magnets which inpinged on his stomach. The eggs ultimately had to be removed surgically (endoscopic manouvers failed), which shows the serious danger toy magnets can carry for children.', "I understand that these magnets can be harmful if swallowed, but how is it at all the responsibility of either the manufacturer or the distributor if they are swallowed.  It falls on the parents of the child who may swallow the magnets to keep the magnets in a place that is inaccessible to the child.  To ban a product that isn't harmful when used in its intended fashion is ludicrous.  Magnet sets have warnings to keep them away from children, just like bottles of bleach have warnings to keep them away from children.  If a child drinks a bottle of bleach, you don't suddenly ban bleach, you take the child away from its negligent parents.", "Plenty of toys on the market that are harmful to kids, don't ban one of the few that can inspire kids to exercise their creativity", 'Father of 5 here. I would like to say that the proposal to ban these items is about the stupides thing I have ever heard from the government. Unfortunately, it would be just the latest in a long line of stupid ideas from our government.  Regulating product safety should be about requiring features on products that improve safety without adversly effecting cost. Not completely removing products from the market that cannot be made 100% (or even 80 or 90%) safe.  Your goal is to improve safety in products, not require that products be 100% safe.', 'there will be about 100,000 injuries every year in the United States due to backyard trampolines which require Emergency Room treatment, and trampolines are marketed to children." But these are different! They are captivating for kids and adults, and they inspire curiosity in virtually everyone who holds them.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power. They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:    The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.   The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.   These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'This isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:     The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.', 'This rule is ridiculous on products marketed to adults, not children. A more reasonable rule would be safety warnings required warning of the risk of ingestion and not to allow children to use them unsupervised.', 'Please do not ban the sale of magnet toys, i.e. "Buckey Balls".  This is an unnecessary overstep of authority.', 'Please do not ban magnetic spheres.', 'Magnet spheres are clearly labeled as an ingestion hazard. If you enact stringent regulation on the sale of such products, logic insists that you must also similarly regulate the sale of other (much more common) dangerous household products. For your convenience, I have included a brief, in-exhaustive  list:  ammonia bleach motor oil laundry detergent disinfectant spray/wipes surface cleaners oven cleaners furniture polish pest and rodent killer mold and mildew cleaner uncooked meat alcohol tobacco motor vehicles kitchen knives hammers scissors sewing needles nails screws thumb tacs ELECTRICITY ...  The list goes on and on, my friends. I ask you, if consumers can be trusted with these clearly dangerous things, what makes magnets any different?  When clearly labeled and handled with care, they are decidedly less dangerous than any of these products.', 'I believe that current standard are okay. Save buckyballs!', 'This new standard outlawing magnetic balls is ridiculous. These novelty items are specifically labeled as not for small children, that can\'t even be said for plenty of other products that children would consider \'fun\' to play with. If we start regulating something just because a child can be hurt with it if left with it unsupervised, even when their parents are warned not to do so, then what product is next? Let\'s look at other things one might keep on their desk, as where most would keep their magnetic balls. Thumbtacks under a foot long and with a sharp point are right out, and you had better stock up on staple\'s before the next "completely reasonable" safety outcry begins. After all, those little things can really cut up your child\'s insides the next time that you misplace their favorite doll and need something to occupy their attention.   You may think that I\'m being a little over sarcastic and unreasonable but this is exactly how unreasonable all of this is. This is a product that fills a certain use and it is being discriminated against because it does a very poor job at a use it was never made for and even clearly stated that it wasn\'t to be used for. Even certain toys that are for children are equally as dangerous if used in the same inappropriate way and they are considered lawful because they provide the same warning that this product already provides. Just because someone provided small objects to small children, something that has been warned about on toys and objects for decades, why should the product be targeted. I\'m all for requiring that the companies clearly state that their product is not for small children, even though they already do, but the blame for these unfortunate accidents is not with the product. You wouldn\'t blame soap for making a child sick after they ingest it, why would you blame magnetic balls for the same. The solid fact is that this product is perfectly safe when used correctly and until that isn\'t true they shouldn\'t be banned', 'Restricting sales of these magnets is absurd, in light of the fact that there has been no health hazards documented.', "Ban the parents that let their kids around this, not the product. It's a magnet.. This can't be serious.", "As long as they are clearly advertised as being dangerous to children if ingested I don't see why these should be treated any different than any other product on the market.  What's to stop a child from eating a handful of paperclips and then crawling near a large floor standing speaker that contains a giant magnet?  The same end result would ensue, tons of torn up internal organs.  Does that mean we should ban all paper clips and speakers that contain large magnets?", 'As long as the magnets state that they are not for children, and should not be put in the mouth or nose on the package,  I see no reason for production to stop.', 'Please do not ban Bucky Balls! They are awesome!', "there is no reason magnet sets like bucky balls and zen magnets should be banned or forced to lower the magnetic force in the product. These products are clearly meant for older kids and adults. They are fun and very educational. I do believe they should come with warnings and clear labels for people that have trouble with common sense. There are many toys and other products that children get their hands on from poor supervision that are not up to be band. I understand these may have a higher rate than other products but that could be a poor communication to consumers. I believe that the products should be labeled with proper warning labels and any store selling them for children should be fined since many of the companies selling these types of products have already recalled items without the proper warning labels and started selling them with the correct ones. It's like trying to band a video game because of the violence in it when it was marked for mature audiences and a parent buys it for their 5 year old.", "Once again the CPSC is trying to make laws that are not necessary.  The instances of people being seriously harmed by magnets are less than that of those harmed by ingesting light bulbs but no one is suggesting to ban small light bulbs.  Again this ruling is too broad to be piratical and harms far more people than it will ever protect.         The assumption that warnings don't work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.    The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.    These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.  Please attempt to bring some common sense and piratical reasoning back to this organization.", "As a Pediatrician and a Pediatric Gastroenterologist, I feel very strongly about these magnet toys.  I have seen families so upset and blaming themselves when their children come into the ER after swallowing theses and require a procedure under general anesthesia (endoscopy) or a surgery (and possibly removing some intestine!). Families aren't aware of the dangers, and it is up to us to make sure that these destructful toys remain off the market and out of the hands of our young children.", 'I believe that the Magnet Sets should be regulated as a sale for adults and not banned completely. Power is given to the government by the people in order to protect the people. The people can and should protect their own children by keeping them away from hazardous materials, but these offer much less risk to an adult interested in the science behind magnets.', "Please remove ban on Buckyballs and other magnetic small objects. I understand having bans on some truly dangerous products or chemicals - this isn't one of them. Why isn't tennis banned? Skateboarding? Skydiving? Significantly more injuries and deaths occur from those. Buckyballs, statistically, ARE SOME OF THE SAFEST HOUSEHOLD ITEMS for children, period. SAFEST. This is ridiculous, insane, unthinkable. Let's not start a revolution here.  Thank you.", 'Do not move against Bucky Balls or Zen Magnets.  They are not dangerous when used properly (i.e. externally)  and are labeled appropriately.  We cannot ban everything a small child could hurt themselves swallowing and it is up to parents to do parenting and not give their child such objects.', 'We do not need a nanny state.', 'I support the safety standard to prevent further injury to children in particular.', 'The New Mexico Safe Kids Coalition supports all and any efforts by the CPSC to create standards for household products based on the safety for small children, given that they are infinitely inquistive, seek to touch and taste anything, as well as to attempt to put objects in their mouths.  Small children can be in danger in any environment, such as an office, even if they are only present for a few hours per month.  The potential for a child accidently swallowing a magnet or a battery has increased dramatically over the past decade due to the proliferation of games, toys and technology that include and require the inclusion of either or both.  Home safety workshops produced by the New Mexico Safe Kids Coalition for home daycare providers, home visitation counselors for new, young, low income, disabled, foster, adoptive, grand or otherwise "at risk" parents, babysitters, and other caregivers consistently educate the public regarding ingestion hazards, and promote the concept of avoiding the selection or use of any product that may endanger a child that visits or resides in their respective homes.', 'I disagree with a proposed ban on the sale of magnetic sets such as Buckyballs. I think that any problems encountered with such sets could be averted with more clear marketing that the product is not intended for children.', 'While I appreciate the concern of all the medical professionals commenting in support of the ban, their argument that "children will ingest anything therefore we should ban these magnets" reveals the reactionary nature of this proposal.  Indeed, if children will ingest anything does that really support the idea that we should ban a specific thing?', "I am opposed to this ban.  It seeks to ban a product that is not harmful unless used  improperly, and in a way that is easily avoidable.   The label warnings already present clearly state that this is a danger to children under 5, and should not be near them. Warnings regarding the danger of children accessing a product have been accepted as effective on many, many products-- toys, cleaning products, tiki torch fuel, etc.  The CPSC's own commissioner, Nancy Nord, opposes these changes.  I urge common sense here and an approach that permits adults to be adults and respects the need for parents to do their jobs.  Thank you for your time.", "Banning magnet toys is ridiculous. This is a parenting issue. Parents still keep household poisons in reach - they were not banned. Medications have not been banned either. Parents are responsible to keep these things out of children's reach. Blaming the toy for stupid parents is crazy. My child has played with magnetic toys since she was 3 - but then again she is smart and never put things in her mouth.   How about letting natural selection do its thing? Instead the government spends more time protecting the less capable and thus dumbing down the population.   Accidents happen, and I don't blame all parents, but banning a toy that is not made for children is not the answer.", "It would seem prudent to keep the relative strength of magnets used in toys to a low flux value. Neodymium magnets are very powerful and should not be used for toys. In light of the kind of damage that is too easy to occur in children, young and older, when magnets as strong as neodymium magnets are ingested, relative size and strength of magnets used in toys should be limited. I don't know if the flux index of 50 is sufficiently low to prevent issues like those seen with higher values. I'm not sure how this value was determined, but I sincerely hope that it will be sufficient. Relative size of magnets used might also help but I'm not sure what that size might be or how to determine that.   For now, no more neodymium for any toys. Science experiments at a school might be alright however, since someone with some sense of their power and danger is in charge. But not in toys.  Respectfully submitted...", 'do not ban magnetic balls. it is the parents who are responsible. other products , water balz, laundry colorful balls, hearing aid batteries also cause child damage. if you ban magnetic balls, you should also ban the other products.. actually you should not ban any of them.', "There are many other toys that are at greater risk in hurting people and kids. It's pure stupidity to ban magnets. But then again, the american Goverment seems to only consist of stupid ignorant people.", 'Stop the ban on magnets.  Focus on other dagerous consumer product that have been around much longer and have killed far more, sure as cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.', 'BAD!', 'magnets are very unsafe and shoulod be restricted', 'Please do not discontinue bucky balls. They are one of my favorite chemistry models and I find the regulation to be frivolous.  Attach warning labels, do what you have to do to make people aware they are a potential choking hazard, but the bucky balls do not need to be discontinued.', "This Ban simply wont happen, it's too big of a market. Don't waste good American money on stupid meaningless goals like this. Put the money to good use like working on real problems here on our soil.", "These small magnetic building sets are very specifically puzzle sets marketed to adults and older teens as noted in the regulation being commented on.  The document contains only incidents related to people outside of the age group using the sets inappropriately.  Therefore there is no reason to outright ban these sets rather than require an appropriate warning on the packaging.  This situation is completely different from the other issues mentioned in the document relating to children's toys that contain magnets and may break, thereby releasing the magnets.  While the CPSC has already driven almost every single company selling these out of business, there is no reason for it.  These are for adults and pose absolutely no risk to them.", "I really like buckeyballs/zen magnets and don't think they pose a threat to anyone's health.  Taking them off the market would be stupid.  There are few toys so elegant and creative.", "This impending ban is ridiculous. I have purchased several sets of these magnets and allowed my young cousins (3-10) years old to play with them, under my supervision. Not once did I have to tell them not to put it in their mouths, even the youngest ones. Yes some people are stupid and won't supervise their kids or won't teach them not to eat things that aren't food, but why should the rest of us be punished. People should be fully aware (and if they're not, it is only their fault, so they should be ready to accept the consequences) of the risk involved with small magnets such as these, but it really is a huge overreaction to ban them altogether. It seems akin to a small child choking on a Lego block and then having not only Legos banned, but Megablocks, Duplo, etc. banned as well.  Coming from a happy customer of these products from several different brands, please think twice about this decision and please do not ban these magnets. Thank you.", "Obviously, when it comes to child injuries, we are very much anti, but that doesn't mean that one of the best science-oriented toys ever created should be made illegal. Especially now, when our schools are struggling, and when it's been so hard to get kids interested in science.   Label the heck out of em! Make people sign a waiver before they purchase! Do whatever it takes but don't ban them!", 'I urge the Commission to permit the continued sales of Buckyballs and Zen Magnets.', "People can find a way to injure themselves on just about anything.  I'm sure apples and grapes and hot dogs each represent a greater risk of children dying from choking than these educational toys.  Perhaps requiring additional labeling would be appropriate but I don't believe that banning sale is remotely reasonable.", 'I do not dispute that these magnets can be dangerous if swallowed. And I do not doubt that children would put them in their mouths if they are available to children. However, these are categorically not toys and are clearly labeled as such, and should not therefore be judged by the standards of toys.  You know what else can be harmful if swallowed by a child? A fishing hook. Rat poison. A paper clip. Household cleaners. A quarter. Dime size refrigerator magnets. Batteries. Toothpaste. Alcohol. Medicines.   "Small and potentially harmful if swallowed" should not be the standard by which we ban things. Especially things that are not designed for small children and are clearly labeled as NOT A TOY, KEEP AWAY FROM CHILDREN.  These magnets engage and delight adults and teens. This group knows better than to swallow magnets. There is no reason we should engineer our laws to the lowest common denominator. Parents should be allowed to parent, and this includes child-proofing your child\'s environment to prevent potential injury. Are you going to ban bleach too? A child could swallow that. What about my Tylenol? Neither of those common substances have a child proof cap (if bought generically).', "I am here to tell you how stupid, unneeded, and a waste of time this bill is.  The magnets in question are currently around my wrist as I type this. They are not a danger to anyone with common sence. If some punk teenagers want to put them in their mouth, then it is purely their fault. The site clearly says that it is not for small children, and is a swallow hazard.  I know, we cannot put a safty label on each magnetic sphere, but the hazard for swallowing two magnet is one that you are aware of when you buy them. It is a Common sence rule. Just like paperclips, or even LEGO's. If you ban Magnetic balls, then i expect to hear that LEGO toy sets are going to be banned as well.  This is a flawed, useless bill, one that should not even be considered for how much of a waste it is.", 'Our institution has seen multiple magnet ingestions, leading to hospitalizations, procedures and several surgeries. We are very experienced with foreign body ingestions of all types and see these as extremely attractive to young children and almost unavoidable that they will go in kids mouths. The idea that they could be made aversive to swallowing ignores the reality that children already swallow pins, safety pins, toxins like lye just to mention a few. These magnets serve no need and place an additional risk on an already vulnerable group--our kids.', "I really feel that this is a terrible standard, as this pretty much amounts to banning small magnets.  This seems like the actions of a few, limiting the actions of many.  Lets just keep these things away from children and educate them on the dangers.   Lets not limit everyone because a few people don't feel comfortable with that inherent responsibility.  If we're going to be banning things based on what could happen, we have a very dismal future

column2: nimals.  It's not only me; the USDA has cited Ringling Bros., along with several other circuses, for their neglect and care (or lack thereof).  Please do something about this travesty.  I trust you will.", 'reaphs20060044--please strictly enforce regulations tailored to the unique needs of  elephants. Too many elephants are housed in zoos and other sites that are totally  inadequate for the physical and mental health of elephants.', 'Please make bullhooks and other "torture" devices illegal.  Elephants are hurt by  these everyday.  It is bad enough that they have to perform and do so many things  that are now instictively correct, but to be beaten into submission is awful.  I  would love to see a ban on elephants performing in circuses.  These are Gods  beautiful creatures.  If people want to see a circus they can see an animal free,  cruelty free circus.', 'In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.    Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time.    Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.    Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', "It doesn't take a rocket scientist to realize that elephants do not belong in zoos.   They need a lot of room.  There are many instances where elephants have not fared well at all in zoos and circuses.  If I had my rathers, I would rather see them in a  zoo than a circus, but the do not belong in either.  There has to be another way to  educate children and the general public about elephants.", 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses  currently meet this requirement.   In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', 'I urge you to support all efforts to improve the conditions for captive elephants in  our country. Not only should existing requirements laid out in the Animal Welfare  Act be enforced, but also more stringent standards are needed to ensure the  humane treatment of these majestic beings.   Those exhibiting elephants should have to provide large, naturalistic, climate- appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee  and the PAWS sanctuary in California, so that elephants can roam, socialize, and  maintain their health. Elephants are big animals, it only makes sense that they  need large spaces in which to live and thrive. Unfortunately, in many zoos and  circuses elephants suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social  deprivation, all of which lead to a range of ailments like painful arthritis, foot  disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors like swaying  and head bobbing. That many zoos lock elephants in stalls for 12 or more hours  while the zoo is closed, or worse in winter months, is quite honestly, a moral  outrage.  Also the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of  force against elephants should be summarily banned. Circuses and many zoos  control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bull  hook and prolonged chaining. These methods cause constant stress as well as  physical and psychological injury to elephants.   I thank you for your time and consideration of this urgent matter, and I trust you  will make the right, and humane, choice.', '"Sink that hook into ?em ... when you hear that screaming then you know you got  their attention. ? Right here in the barn. You can?t do it on the road. ? I?m not  gonna touch her in front of a thousand people. ? She?s gonna f---ing do what I  want and that?s just f---ing the way it is."  ?Elephant trainer Tim Frisco  The USDA cannot let this go on.  The American people have seen the undercover  videos and we know how these magnificant animals are being tortured and we are  angry about it.  Asian elephants belong in Asia - not in America.  These animals  finally crack from the abuse and then they pose a dangerous threat to the public  and end up being shot by police.  This is absurd.  We\'re supposed to be a  civilized nation?  I am deeply ASHAMED that this is tolerated in America!', "I am writing to express my emphatic support for any legislation which will improve the position of captive animals in this country. I sincerely request that you consider implementing new, tougher standards including the following: ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'Current regulations for elephants are inadequate. The conditions in which  elephants are kept in zoos and circuses is inhumane.  Elephants need a much larger amount of space than is found in most zoos.  In the  wild elephants walk over 30 miles a day.  In zoos they mostly stand around on  hard surfaces.  This leads to chronic foot problems, accompanied by a great deal  of pain, and an early death.  Elephants also need to live in large social groups.  In the wild, female elephants  stay together in large families.  This is important for their psychological health.  It  is exceedingly cruel to isolate an elephants, such as the lephants at the Alaska  zoo.  (It is also exceedingly cruel to have an elephant in a cold climate like  Alaska, where she needs to be kept indoors for most of the year.)  Zoos and circuses should not be allowed to beat their elephants or use bullhooks  on them.  Elephants are very sensitive to pain.  I am appalled that a zoo like El  Paso can get away with abusively beating its elephants  Circus trainers are even  more violent with elephants than zoos are.  Elephants are beaten enough to make  them be submissive enough to peform unnatural and uncomfortable acts.  Elephants are also currently kept in unhealthy conditions.  Many circus elephants  suffer from TB and do not receive adequate treatment.Elephants are chained or  confined to boxcars for long hours.  They do not receive an adequate diet.  Clearly, existing regulations are inadequate to protect these wonderful animals  from both physical and psychological damage.   Many progressive zoos have  decided to close their elephant exhibits because they are aware of the needs of  elephants and know that their faacilites are not able to meet those needs.  We  need stronger regulations, however, to protect elephants in zoos and circuses  from those who exploit them with little regard for their suffering.  Please revise your regulations so that elephants have an adequate amount of  space and are able to live in large social groups.  (It would be much better to have  several very large places where people can go on vacation to see elephants than it  is to have elephants kept in smaller enclosures where their needs cannot be met) in cities all around the country.  Please enact regulations (and enforce them) which will put an end to the abusive  treatment of elephants by circuses.  Elephants should not be in circuses at all.  The exisitng legislation is not enough to protect these magnificent animals from  extreme cruelty.', 'I support that there should be very strict and highly enforced standards of care and  provisions for elephants in captivity.  They should not be held in zoos and the  elephants that are presently in zoos should be sent to sanctuarys to live out their  lives as normally as possible.  They should also not be in circuses or any other  form of entertainment.  With the expansion of TV, Animal Planet on cable, the  Internet, and more than 10-20 movies at the theater at one time, children can see  and learn about elephants rather than to see them standing still in a small lot.   We must think of the benefit of others and not be a selfish People.', 'Elephants are magnificent, intelligent animals that require very wide open spaces  in order to have a decent life.  Unfortunately, the vast majority of zoos in the U.S.  are nowhere near providing adequate habitat for these animals that did not choose  their circumstance of captivity.  In addition to inadequate space, zoos and  circuses very often mistreat the elephants with hooks and chains and also deny  them the chance to form the social structure that they enjoy in the wild.  If a zoo  or circus cannot provide good stewardship for the elephants, then they should not  be allowed to have them and profit from them.  The sorry circumstances of elephants in our zoos and circuses are contrary to the  Animal Welfare Act, and it is imperative that the USDA enforce the AWA as is  their mandate to do so.', 'I wish to assert my support for the Animal Welfare Act, which wouild address and  help to police the unspeakable abuse visited upon circus animals.  Higher  standards of care must be established and enforced in the animal entertainment  industry, particularly for elephants.', "All wild animals should be banned from circuses.  It sickens me that in this day  and age it's still ok with some people to exploit animals health and happiness to  entertain people.  Let the people entertain the people.  At least they can decide if  the voluntarily want to be there.  Circus animals live appalling lives and should be  a lesson in what people should NOT be allowed to do to animals.  Shame on  anyone who blindly pays to see a circus.  Please do something about elephants living in such awful conditions.", 'It is imperative that exotic animals which include the elephant are cared for and receive  the care they need for their health and well being.   It is not right to keep them unless  those conditions are met and maintained.  Any organization that cannot meet this  obligation should not be allowed to keep these animals.   Their  needs and feelings are  just as important and they should be treated with dignity not as objects for frivolous  entertainment.   Chaining and controlling them  by using barbaric force should be  outlawed permanently and participants in this behaviour should be penalized.', 'Elephants, nor any animal, should have to suffer the force, mistreatment, and  habitat deprivation of living in zoo, circus, or other confining surroundings.  Suffering creates anger, anger creates unpleasant or even dangerous behaviors,  then animals suffer even more for simply trying to resist the pain we humans place  them in. I hate to quote Dr. Phil, but his question "What the hell were you  thinking?" sums up the insanity of allowing old, barbaric traditions of imprisoning  animals to continue even one more day. PLEASE, immediately enforce every  available regulation to provide comfort and safety for elephants (and all other  animals, domestic or exotic) in all situations involving their imprisonment and  forced work.No abuses, no unsuitable environments can be allowed to  continue.Animals who act out have been abused and pushed beyond their limits of  tolerating their own suffering. You would act out too! So HELP THEM, RESCUE  THEM, SPRING INTO ACTION NOW! Get all of them possible to sanctuaries! And  put abusers in jail for a long time.', "I was appalled to learn about the dismal conditions in which captive elephants in  zoos and circuses are kept.  Human 'entertainment' is no excuse for animal  cruelty and/or neglect.  Furthermore, it is my firm belief that all life is sacred, and  thus worthy of being treated with dignity and respect.  For these reasons, I  support all efforts to dramatically improve the conditions for captive elephants in  this country, including enforcing existing adequate space requirements under the  Animal Welfare Act, and creating new standards that require exhibitors of  elephants to provide expansive, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments  where these animals can engage in natural behaviors.  The new standards should  also prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of the kind against elephants.    As the agency responsible for protecting and promoting animal welfare, the  Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) is in a key position to make  a difference in this regard.  APHIS has not only the opportunity to demonstrate its  leadership in supporting high ethical standards in the treatment of animals, but  also the obligation to protect those creatures who cannot speak for themselves.    I urge APHIS to place a higher priority on animal welfare than on business profits,  and adopt sensible policies that promote the well-being of animals rather than  defend inhumane practices by zoo and circus owners.  Anything less is doing a  disservice to the community it is meant to serve.", "Zoo's are cruel to elephants due to there lack of space for free movement.  Zoo's are also abusive to elepahnts to the limited herd sizes that zoos can maintain for a social animal.  Thank you, Richard Zapor", 'In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. Lack of space, unnatural substrates, unnatural social groupings, and the use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots, and other instruments of force commonly used to control elephants.  For these reasons and others just as important, it is imperative that the subject of captive elephants be addressed appropriately and dealt with without further delay.', 'I am writing to speak on behalf of Elephant care. I know you must have received a  ton of comments about this, but they need a voice. Circuses and zoos are not  meeting the proper requirements for giving these beautiful and smart creatures  care. There are so many animals out there that need to be unleashed from the  chains that bound them. They were not born to be captive. They were born with  feelings and emotions. The excessive mistreatment and punishment they receive  is a crime and although there are so many things going on in the world, this too is  an outrage and cannot be overlooked.  Please help make sure that they are provided proper environments and sufficient  treatment to prevent neurotic behaviors, disease and death. Thank you for hearing  my voice and your consideration.', "Re space and living conditions for captive elephants in the United States:  I have long been very concerned about the plight of captive elephants. Although the  Animal Welare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space, the reality is that neither zoos nor circuss meet this requirement,  nor do zoos and circuses provide elephants with the conditions they require for  optimum health and wellbeing.   Because of this lack of oversight, elephants suffer from lack of space, social  deprivation and other unnatural conditions. Elephants suffer from painful arthritis,  foot disease, digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors --all of which are  preventable.  It is tragic that half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and  foot disease and that these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in  captive elephants. Even worse is that elephants are much too often subjected to prolongued chaining-- up to 21 hours a day and in circuses, chained in traveling boxcars for 11 months of  the year.  They are forced to endure extreme temperatures and stand for hours in  their own waste.  I don't believe elephants belong in circuses under any  circumstances, but at the very least, if these people are going to make money off  of these animals, they should be forced to treat them humanely and properly. Bullhooks, whips, clubs and electric chock devies and all other tools of  intimidation should be outlawed.  If circuses treated theri animals properly there  would be no need to abuse them with these objects. Finally, exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, natural  environments similar to the Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society sanctuary in California.  These two refuges provide  hundreds to thousands of acres for elephants to roam, socialize and live  more  normal and natural lives.  If zoos cannot provide such habitat, then they have no  business exhibiting elephants.  And circuses should be prohibited from having any  elephants at all.   Thanks you for considering my views.  I hope you place as much weight on the  public's support for a better life for captive elephants as you are sure to do with  protests from industries that make money from exploiting elephants.", 'Elephants suffer greatly in zoos.They suffer foot and joint problems from standing  on hard surfaces for long periods of time. They suffer psychological problems  because they are confined to small spaces. Elephants should be sent to  sanctuaries where they would be free from the suffering they endure in zoos.', 'Please stop the maltreatment of Elephants in circus and zoos. They are big  animals that require big places and a high standard of treatment. They are not  meant to live in small places or been punished with electric shocks at the circus.', "I am writing to ask that you make sure that ALL Elephants in captivity are treated  better. The elephants NEED to have MORE space. They need to be treated with respect  and not with any type of cruelty.  Please stop using chains on them.  Let them  roam free with no chains and no whipes or any other type of mistreatment. Please do NOT allow the use of bullhooks, chains, electric hotshots or anything  else that is used to force the elephants to do what people want them to do. Let them live in the same type of social groups that they live in when they are  free.  Stop hurting them.  They need alot more4 space to live in.  Don't let them  get emionally hurt by keeping them in a small area so they can lose it like other  animals do when tied to a small space.  These animals are wonderful beautiful  animals.  They don't deserve to be treated cruelly. It's time that the United States starts taking care of the animals that we kidnap  from their homes and hold them in a zoo. Please make sure they are treated right. thank you", "I want to support the petition presented to you by In defense of wildlife.  They said  it most eloquently and are most knowledgable of these atrocities on a day to day  basis as they are out there exposing themselves to painful experiences and a lot  of opposition by the zoos, circuses and others who exploit these animals, and  then abuse them.  I can not even go and see it directly.  I've seen it in pictures  and video for many years.    Let's show that we are a society of compassion for those who can not speak for  themselves. We have stewardship to protect, not emminent domain over using  these living creatures who do no one any harm, but are dependent upon us for  their care and survival.  I believe it was Gandhi who said that is how a society is  really measured.", "research shows elephanst need ample space to roam and move which can't be obtained in confined environmentsst such as circuses and zoos either require zoos to provide more adequate space or provide funding supprt to the elphant sanctuary in Tennessee that has ample space and cares for them", 'I am a citizen merely writing to encourage the USDA the support any and all  efforts which would improve conditions for elephants in capitivity in the United  States and across the world.  This would include not only enforcing the current  standards in the Animal Welfare Act, but also by creatigng tough new standards  that requires exhibitors to provide larger and more natural environments for these  highly intellegent beings.  I urge the USDA to take this action because Elephants  are big animals who need big spaces. But in too many zoos and circuses they  suffer from lack of space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that  eventually cause a range of preventable ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot  disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic behaviors like swaying  and head bobbing.  Although it is important to have zoos and other educational  opportunities as well as sancturaries for these magnificiant animals, it is important  that we (as individuals and a society) appreciate and respect these animals by  providing them with an comfortable and fullfilling place to live out their years.    Thank you for your consideration.', 'Elephants are highly intelligent, social, and sensitive creatures deserving of  humane living conditions in natural-like settings such as those found at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Scoeity  sanctuary in California.  Elephants should not be chained, isolated from others, or  confined to cages for extended periods.  Thank you!', 'Please understand that elephants are large animals who need big spaces. Many  zoos and circuses limit the space provided to these magnificent animals causing  disease and other disorders as well as documented neurotic behaviors.  Domination and agressive use of bull hooks must be outlawed. Elephants must be  allowed room to roam rather than be confined for extended periods. I support the  elephant sanctuary movement in this country and ask that you help to improve  conditions for captive elephants in this country. Thank you very much.', 'The treatment of circus animals in this country is atrocious. I am FOR any  legislation that will greatly improve the freedom, feeding, roaming, comfort, health,  sanity and longevity of elephants in any kind of captivity in this country, whether it  be in a zoo or with a circus or in virtually any other kind of captivity.  My concerns are the following:  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.   In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', 'If our society is going to allow capitivity for non-domesticated animals, it needs to  provide proper care for these creatures.  Elephants, as well as so many other animals, are subjected to inhumane living  environments and treatment.  This needs to stop now.  Ask the experts to prescribe "proper conditions." Monitor the environments and care of the animals.  Penalize the offenders, and  remove the animals. Ask the media to exploit those who do not maintain proper conditions. Ask the sanctuaries to adopt the animals that have not been properly cared for.  Our society doesn\'t approve of abuse or neglect, whether it be of humans or  animals.  It is your responsibility to change things.  The public expects you to.   The animals beg you to.  I respectfully request that you give this issue a lot of  thought.  I believe it\'s really very easy to "know what is right."  Please step up  and "do what is right, as well."  Thank you for your consideration.', "Elephants don't belong in zoos.  Zoos are in the business to make money and as a result they have repeatedly been shown to provide inadequate care to their charges. It is good that the USDA is finally showing significant concern for the creatures who are forced into an unnatural existence rather than pandering to those trying to make a buck by exploitation.", "In regard to APHIS-2006-0044 rights for elephants.  I think this should be upheld. Zoos and circuses must provide elephants with ample space. Zoos are not  meeting this requirment. Circuses when transferrring elephants,curtainly don't  meet these requirments. Exhibitors must provide large,natural enviornments similar to The Elephant  Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in Northern California. These  two refuges provide hundreds if not thousands of acres for the elephants to  socialilze and have amples space for movement and a healthy living space. The use of bullhooks,chains,shock devices and other instruments of force must  BE OUTLAWED. This curtainly pertains the circuses. This is there form of torture  on these creatures. If elephants wanted to be in a circus environmnet the only form  needed would be food for positive reinforcement, not the forms of torture mentioned  above.  This Act must be initiated now. This is 2006.  The laws and guidelines are  extremely outdated. They have no voice and it is up to us to make the proper  choice to  faciliate proper guidlines.", 'I implore you to please consider putting regulations in place that will improve conditions for captive elephants.  I am saddened and concerned with the realities that most captive elephants face:  1. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement. 2. In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. 3. Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time. 4. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.', 'Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well- being. The Animal Welfare Act (AWA) requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate  space. Zoos are not meeting this requirement. Elephants are big animals who need big spaces. But in zoos and circuses they suffer from lack of  space, unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable  ailments -- from painful arthritis and foot disease to reproductive and digestive disorders to neurotic  behaviors like swaying and head bobbing. Many zoos lock their elephants in barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when the zoo is closed.  And, in northern zoos, elephants are confined indoors for extended periods during the cold winter  months. Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination and aggressive use of  the bull hook and prolonged chaining. Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those  at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their  health.', "To the USDA:    I used to be someone who enjoyed zoos until about te
column3: re just a couple of the risks and issues that could be clarified and improved with the proposed amendments to the Animal Welfare Act. And because I feel that new discoveries are being made that result in us learning what better benefits those captive animals, I think that this proposal should be accepted.   http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/captive_marine/facts/swim_dolphins.html http://www.takepart.com/article/2014/05/31/congress-asks-usda-update-captive-dolphins-standards', 'Attached are the comments of Miami Seaquarium and Sea Life Park as well as Exhibit A to those comments', 'I work as an educator with the staff, volunteers, interns as well as thousands of students that are educated at Georgia Aquarium each year. At Georgia Aquarium we are committed to educating staff, volunteers, guests and students of all ages about our aquatic ecosystems and the animals that live within them. Students from primary to doctoral levels are able to see marine mammals that they may never see in their lifetime and foster a deeper understanding of the ocean that connects us all.    Georgia Aquarium is located in Atlanta, GA, a land-locked city, students are able to see thousands of different animals from all over the world in one location to connect their learning even further. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of students the opportunity to connect what they learn in the classroom with real-world applications at an accredited zoo and aquarium.   APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards. I think that any new or revised animal care regulations such as these should be based on scientific studies and knowledge from experts who have years of experience caring for marine mammals.  The rules should not be based on opinions that are unsupported by the facts or experience.', 'Would you believe that SeaWorld has proven repeatedly for 3 years plus that it is committed to helping and aggressively supporting the care of wild whales?   Can you and your organization be OBJECTIVE?  I would like to see you prove that.  SeaWorld has proven its commitment to preserving the wild whales with major positive changes in its organizational structure.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Respectfully,', 'I have personally been working with animals at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my time working with the animals at SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "Let's be reasonable and let science guide regulations instead of letting whacked out left wing loons screw everything up.", "Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.  I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities. Our family recently had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest. We also watched many sessions between the dolphins and trainers. In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's expertise and dedication to the animals.    As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.", "For many years now, I have been a  member of Dolphin Research Center.  During my multiple visits over the last 15 years, I have participated in a number of interactive programs and also spent time watching many sessions between the dolphins, sea lions and their trainers.  In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's dedication, their high level of expertise, and the clean environments in which the animals live.  It is clear to me that the dolphins enjoy the sessions as much as the people.  They appear to choose to participate and are never forced.  In the dolphin swim programs, I have always particularly enjoyed observing how visitors got to play with two dolphins at a time.  They sure seemed to like teaming up for the dorsal pull or fun imitations and other behaviors.  The trainers do a superior job.  I do not feel that any one's safety was ever at risk, even when one trainer worked with more than one dolphin at a time.  Nor do I feel that the natural water environment and deep lagoon added any risk during the relatively short periods of time when the trainer might not be able to see the dolphins - this kind of setting is far better for the dolphins than an artificial pool, however transparent.   I'd like to thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education. But please do not micro-manage by regulations - trust the trainers and the researchers... Thank you!", 'Sea world carries out not only great work but educates the public too !! We need sea world for not only animal wellbeing, rescue but overdue education too  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.
