It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please leave seaworld and the great work they do many animals would not survive if it was not for their committed and great work', "I fully support animals in respectful human care. If we all tried to view dolphins in the wild then we run a very strong risk of ruining their natural habitat in the meantime. Places like large aquariums, show parks and related theme parks are usually staffed with people who have had life-long passions for these animals and greatly care for their nature. I have had incredible personal experiences at places like Marineland of Florida and SeaWorld that have added great value to my life and helped me deal with some of life's challenges. I will forever be grateful to well-run establishments like these. They have done wonders also educating me about the world around me that I might otherwise never get the opportunity to experience in person without threat.", "I hold a M.S. in Biology and spent 35 years in secondary and adult education in the sciences in New York State Public Schools and State Universities.  I own homes in uptate New York and Florida as well as a vacation home in Northern New York.  I spend a great deal of time at Universirty research centers, animal sanctuaries and preserves.  I've spent a great deal of money and time rescuing and caring for abandon domestic animals.  I find legislation in this area sorely lacking.  However, I do not want my government using my tax dollars to support the cause of extremists.  They are taking away my right to enjoy other animals on this planet.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Just as man has always controlled domesticated animals to enhance his life, facilities maintaining animals not ordinarily observed should continue to exist for those of us who elect to support them.  Please do not assume all of your influence from those with enough time to stand with a sign in one hand, a bag of Doritos in the other in their new leather Nikes  on their exclusive high moral ground.", "I've been involved with the Dolphin Research Center since 1989 when I did my first swim. Since then, I've completed two of their week-long programs and have volunteered both on-site and off-site. I continually visit the facility as a contributor and participant.   In my countless visits, I've always been very impressed with the level of professionalism shown by trainers and all staff regarding both the animals in their care as well as visitors and participants. At no time are dolphins forced to participate and always seem to enjoy the in-water interaction with human participants. Safety concern has never been an issue, either for myself as a participant, or for others I've observed, both casually and as a volunteer monitor. This applies to both having a single trainer handling more than one dolphin during a session and for the brief times when a trainer or I (or a participant) may be unable to see the dolphins due to the natural seawater environment. These trainers have a wealth of knowledge about their animals and have obviously created trusting relationships with them.  My positive experiences with Dolphin Research Center have inspired me to advocate on behalf of dolphins and ocean conservation by presenting information to school, scout, and social groups in my area, and I've been doing so since 1994 on behalf of DRC.  Finally, thank you for your concerns about animal welfare. In light of the barrage of inaccurate information shared on social media recently, I appreciate that you are working to ensure quality care in marine parks as well as accurate dissemination of information about them.", "I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I'm going to keep this short, but I've learned SO much from Seaworld over the past 22 years. It's my favorite park ever. I'm there all the time, seeing how their animals are and its to the point I can tell when they're having a bad day or when they're not feeling their best. Please don't do this...", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  The Long Beach Aquarium is another place that is valuable for the protection and conservation of sea creatures. I am a Charter Member of the Long Beach Aquarium of the Pacific. I visit the Aquarium frequently and take out of town guests when they visit. My grandsons from VA look forward to visiting both both Sea World in San Diego and the Aquarium in Long Beach every year when they come to see us.', 'Please protect these sentient creatures and end their captivity forever!', "I am in full support of the proposed rule. Like a lot of other individuals I to am against animals being held in captivity unless it is to rehabilitate them and eventually get them back into the wild, or if they can no longer survive in the wild by themselves. Though I do not agree with such programs as Swim-with- the Dolphins, I do believe that it is of  great importance that they are treated humanely while they are in captivity. Since new and updated scientific research has become available about different aspects of caring for theses animals, then I think the current regulations need to be trained. Marine mammals need to have adequate space to swim around and to be comfortable, they should not be in tight quarters. The information on water quality is another reason I agree with this proposed rule. We need to make sure that marine mammals are not swimming in water the is filled with pathogens that could harm them and the same goes for the overall water quality. In reading over everything it does not seem like a lot would have to be changed, it's just that things need to be updated and there is no problem with that. If we as people want to keep having animals in captivity for our own personal amusement or research etc. then we need to make sure that we are doing all we can to keep them healthy and happy.", "I've personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I love SeaWorld', "Aloha,   My name is Cameron Dabney, Regional Education Supervisor for Dolphin Quest.   At Dolphin Quest, our mission is to touch hearts and minds through fun, innovative experiences that create a connection to nature and a passion to learn more.   Each and every day, we fulfill our mission.   We inspire thousands of people each year through our hand-on, interactive programs with our Common Bottlenose Dolphins. We support local schools by offering School Programs that are aligned with State and National Science Standards. We align ourselves with the world's most renown Marine Mammals Scientists, Behaviorists, and Veterinarians and are among the elite when it comes to neonatal care. Our innovative natural habitats are on the cutting edge of offering ocean-based sanctuaries for our animals. This has been so for almost 30 years.  As members of the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums, we are held to the highest level of animal care standards. We wholeheartedly understand what it takes to allow our animals to thrive under our care.   For this, we thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.    As a scientist, active conservationist, and passionate animal lover, I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current scientific studies and information from the aforementioned marine mammal specialists who have the necessary experience needed to fully understand the best care for these animals.   It is crucial that marine parks and aquariums continue to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including myself, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it were not for facilities like Dolphin Quest. In fact, I pursued a career in Marine Biology after visiting the Monterey Bay Aquarium in California as a child, where I got to see a Sea Otter up close. So I know from first hand experience what meeting an animal (that is illegal to touch or come close to in the wild) can do to spark an interest and even a career! For that, I work diligently each day to inspire the next generation of ocean stewards.  As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  I hope that you will consider reaching out to facilities, like Dolphin Quest, for input on any changes in regulations regarding our animals.   Again, thank you for your thoughtful consideration on this important matter.   Sincerely,  Cameron Dabney Regional Education Supervisor Dolphin Quest  www.dolphinquest.com", 'As a concerned citizen and consumer, I want to be sure that the regulations are not too numerous or onerous. They should be based on science and not emotion. And they should balance the best interests of both man and marine mammals. Educating people about these wonderful animals is the best way to preserve them and engender respect for them.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I urge you to take a visit to Seaworld and see for yourself the fantastic work being done to save and rehabilitate all types of fish and mammals', "I am in favor of this proposed rule to improve the standard quality conditions for captive marine animals. Unfortunately we will never be able to perfect conditions for captive animals, but we always need to strive for improvement to make their lives as happy and healthy as possible when they do not have the option to leave. With the recent exposure of Sea World's history of poor captivity conditions for their orcas (and their denial of it) along with the recent upgrade of animal abuse to now being considered a Group A felony alongside homicides and arson, improvements in standards are more likely to be universally accepted and willing to be funded at this time.  Although I do find captivity for marine mammals to be more inhumane than land mammals, they are important because it saves the lives of animals that are from well-known poacher locations or are saved after abandonment (and a variety of other factors), and it gives the animals a chance at life that would have otherwise been taken from them.  Any improvement or request for upgrades is one step in the right direction, and when these changes are enforced it will provide more opportunity for even more improvements to be created.", 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  To not change the space requirements for marine mammals would be immoral and cruel. The best thing for them would be not to be held captive in the first place but since for now that is not the case the very least they deserve is to have ample space and depth for them to survive in. Studies aside although for the last 16 years there have been many to support this change all you have to do is look at the enclosures they are kept in. It\'s more than obvious that they are not kept in the size that they need to survive in. 30 years ago was the last time anything happened regarding this and that was years before scientific advancements in this resrarch. Science and studies adamantly support this change. Technology has came a long way in 30 years enabling studies that could have never been done at that time. The time has come to make those changes so that they at least have a proper living environment. Captivity is cruel enough but to not give them what they need is is inhumane immoral and ethically unacceptable. Thank you  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and r
column5: ahead of us.", 'This is ridiculous and stupid. It looks like someone was bored and wanted to make a scene.', "These are not children's toys, do not ban them because children and parents are stupid.", 'These absolutely should not be banned, but carry a warning label. I love to teach science and banning these is senseless.', 'It makes very litter sense to ban a product not meant to be consumed because someone might it eat.  Knives are sharp, someone might cut themseleves.  Anyone buying these products understands that they are not intended for childern and should be handled with care.  Please do no let someone who misused these products to ruin it for the rest of us.', "Put bigger warnings, have a minimum age for purchase, anything. It's hard enough to get students interested in science but taking a cool item like these magnet sets off the market at make it even harder yet. These magnet sets encourage creativity and wonderment.", 'This proposed regulation is inconsistent with other CPSC actions.    The magnets are not intended for children, but the rule is being made on the basis of use by children.  I own these magnets and enjoy their use.  They serve valid scientific, entertainment, and artistic purposes.    There are many products on the market that cause vastly more injuries and deaths, but are not under attack.  There are products for adults, which cause millions of dollars of injuries each year, in medical treatment, yet the CPSC does not regulate them or require simple and effective additional safety improvements.  There are many products for children, which cause many deaths and injuries each year, but are not being regulated by the CPSC, and few of the objects that are regulated are facing a ban, and the bankrupting of multiple companies.    It makes no sense to regulate a product for adults, which has caused few if any injuries to adults or children, when more dangerous products are being ignored.  The pursuit of this misplaced regulation shows the agency to be capricious, unfair, and incompetent.    Many regulations and safety requirements are needed.  This one is not.  Put your attention where it is warranted by solid statistical evidence.  End this witch hunt.', 'In your summary, you state "In contrast to ingesting other small parts, when a child ingests a magnet, the magnetic properties of the object can cause serious, life-threatening injuries."  There are many products I can buy that will have fatal results if ingested. Most medicines. Rat poison. Household cleansers. Razor blades. Lightbulbs. These things are all deadlier than little magnets, none are marketed towards children, and they should all be kept out of reach of children. The difference is that you can still buy all the deadly products I\'ve listed above. Why are you singling out little magnets?', 'Requirements for these should be left to individuals, along with the responsibilities.  Government should not be wasting time on regulating magnets.', 'As a practicing pediatric gastroenterologist and a mother of a toddler, I understand firsthand the real danger of high energy magnets.  I have personally removed magnets from the stomach of a curious toddler who found the magnets stuck to his parents metallic garbage can.  His parents had read about the risk of these "bucky balls" and had thrown them out weeks before.  Unknowingly, a few balls had stuck to the can and were found and ingested by their son.  He was lucky that his only risk was the anesthesia required for an endoscopy as we were successful in removing the magnets.  My colleagues have cared for other less fortunate children who have required emergency surgery and removal of parts of their intestines for perforations (or holes) caused by the magnets.  This can be fatal and/or require lifelong impairment, which is particularly devastating as these children were completely healthy prior to ingestion.  While these bucky balls are advertised as an adult toy, I have seen them sold in museum book stores, gift shops, etc where children would easily have access.  In my own home, my 2 year old son\'s favorite toys are anything his parents use (even better if he is not supposed to have it).  I have babyproofed our home and supervise him at all times. But, I have witnessed how he explores new things with all senses including taste.  I also know how fast he has developed and how quickly he could ingest these magnets in our home even if kept in a "safe" place.  For the safety of my patients and my son, I strongly encourage the government to take a stand and support the ban of these high energy magnets from sale.', "What's this I hear about magnets not being safe? What about the 100 - LB lift super magnets that you can buy from websites that offer the exact same magnets as Zen Magnets? Those are worse than these little spheres and if anyone is willing to swallow them, then they shouldn't be anywhere near children when they do it at the least. These 'TOYS' are great stress relievers and I have spent hours just modeling with my little set that I have. No small toys should be near any little person/s mouth at all and especially not when there is no adult supervision. Disabling websites from selling these will only only make people buy them from stores. I had a box of magnets and stick magnets from Wal-Mart and the magnets would break and come loose but Wal-Mart still sold them. Being over-cautious is only going to make U.S. and Canada afraid to do anything except eat and sleep. What's next, CD-ROMs are going to be banned because they are 'too sharp' around the edge? The only reason anyone ever gets complaints about anything is because it is being used wrong.", 'This Rule is an excessive response to a rather minimal risk. Less extreme forms of regulation should be more than adequate to ameliorate the risk associated with products of this type.  Moreover, products of this type also provide many benefits that often go unmentioned.  Magnets used for sculpting enhance creativity, reduce stress, promote understanding of the principles of magnetism, and can be used in a variety of ways, including educational scientific experiments.  Additionally, I have personally used them in my educational self-management practice to promote attention regulation and enhance executive functioning.  Do not rob responsible consumers of the right to benefit from access to this class of products.    \tBesides,this isn\'t so much a discussion about the dangers of magnets, but more the CPSC and Pediatric Gastroenterologist organizations trying to flex their power.  They\'ve organized their members to submit comments that continually repeat that "people cannot be trusted to listen to warnings", while never addressing the arguments against theirs. If the CPSC won\'t listen to the 85%+ public consensus against the ban, perhaps the CPSC should listen to Nancy Voice-of-Reason Nord, the CPSC\'s own most experienced commissioner, when she says:    The assumption that warnings don\'t work, undermine past safety standards deemed acceptable by the CPSC and US Congress.   The ban is overly broad. There are two distinct hazard patterns that should be addressed: Children under 5 tounging their environment, and teenagers mimicking piercings. And the ban includes products [like Zen Magnets] that have not demonstrated similar risks.   These magnets have much more utility, and lower instance of hazard than other products on the market.  If you truly believe that these products, as they are currently sold, do expose consumers to untenable levels of risk, then by all means add additional protections, but a ban is clearly excessive.', "Listen, I know you guys are just trying to be helpful. You want to look out for people's safety and make sure that we aren't taken advantage and swindled. But here's the deal, these magnet companies don't want to hurt people and have gone to extraordinary methods to take care of people. We reasonable adults can take it from there and do the right thing. If some individuals can't handle the responsibility, there's no reason to take the joy from the rest of us. Already word has spread far and wide via the internet on potential dangers and at this point it's ridiculous that we are still trying to decide how to deal with some little metallic balls. Here's an idea: personal responsibility. Make those who are negligent and misuse the product liable, not those who make it as safe as possible and prominently publish warnings. You don't need to do this, because we can take care of it ourselves.", 'The ban on magnetic toys is arbitrary and ridiculous.  While it is upsetting that improper use of these magnets can cause injury, that is true of virtually every toy in existence.  Buckyballs are just commodity magnetic spheres which have been repackaged for consumers.  Thus the ban will be totally ineffective and easily bypassed by anybody with a computer.  Consumers can still go to one of many online magnet retailers and buy an identical product.  Are you going to go after these small businesses too?', 'Currently own several sets of "Bucky balls" and my 2 year old child has enjoyed playing with them for the past year, since he was one. Although he is always supervised, I\'ve never had any "close calls" that would have seemed to have injured him if un corrected. I think banning bucky balls is an over reaction.', "The responsibility for the safety and well being of children is ultimately given to parents (not the government).  Rare earth magnets balls, are meant for adults and should be used as such.  Taking such objects away from responsible adults in an effort to curb bad parenting is reprehensible.   Dangers to children from objects in the home are not limited to just the magnets in question.  The following household items pose threats to children as well.  1) Electrical outlets- small children are naturally curious and tend to stick their fingers where they should not go.  Responsible parents provide adequate supervision or put covers over sockets to protect their children.  2) Compact fluorescent light bulbs - these bulbs contain mercury (dangerous) as well as pose a sharp object cutting and puncturing hazard.  Responsible parents keep them out of reach of children.  3) Kitchen knives - can seriously injure a child if he/she were to get one.  We keep them out of reach of children to keep them from hurting themselves.  4) Pillows/blankets - for newborns, these objects can lead to suffocation.  We rely on parents to ensure that these objects don't pose a hazard to their little one.   These examples are only a few of the myriad of hazards to children that exist in the home.  Ultimately children are going to hurt themselves in spite of all government regulations and even under the best parenting conditions.  It is our responsibility as parents to look after the children that are in our care and use objects, such as the magnets balls, in a manner that will not put children at risk.  There will always be bad parents that will allow harm to come to their children no matter what law/regulations are enacted, we see stories on the news all the time.  Adult consumers should be allowed the freedom to purchase any object they desire provided that the object is not illegal.  We should not restrict magnet ball sales.  They pose no greater threat than those already present in our homes.", "I find it difficult to convey how ridiculous I find this proposal.  From an article I just read:  These rare earth magnet toys are inherently unsafe; there is no amount of warning or parental vigilance sufficient to prevent their misuse, writes another pediatric gastroenterologist, Bryan Rudolph.  Clearly, we also need to ban bleach, ammonia, butane lighters, firearms, etc.  Parental vigilance, apparently, is the job of policy makers.  There are reasons for government control, we should be protected from bad-faith products.  I don't want strychnine in my baby formula, for example.  But regulating toys?  I'm a very left-leaning liberal, and this is exactly what I imagine people become so exasperated about when describing a nanny state.", 'There\'s no need for a ban on magnet sets. These sets are meant as a sort of "desk toy" for adults, not for children. To contrast, there are many other "dangerous" things that are made specifically for children, and those are not banned. For instance, trampolines, bicycles, ripstiks, legos, etc. Yes, magnets are dangerous, but there\'s no need for a ban. The companies already post warnings. If parents aren\'t going to supervise their children, that\'s none of the government\'s concern.', "I can see the concern but banning something should always be the last resort and its clear other steps available.  Please don't outright ban buckeyballs!", 'This is a ridiculous waste of tax payer money.  Batteries are far more lethal to children than magnets and yet they get pass because they are not a "toy"?  There are plenty of toys that use those batteries and not all of them have secure enclosures that cannot be opened without a tool (screwdriver).    Yes - those toys that have insecure battery disclosures are marked with age restrictions, however if that is all it takes, shouldn\'t the same logic and conventions apply for the magnets?', 'Please don\'t ban these magnets! Why should everyone suffer for the mistakes of a few parents? The boxes of Buckyballs are all clearly marked "Not for Children" in multiple places!', "Label packages appropriately but please don't ban this science based toy.", 'Despite the concern over the magnets, parents  continue to purchase these potentially lethal products. Recently I had 2 children who had ingested the magnets.  An 18 month old who presented with an obstruction with signficiant vomiting and dehydration and the magnet was "stuck" in his pyloric valve requiring a prolonged endoscopic procedure to remove.  The second case was a 5 yo who had ingested 5 magnets, had multiple perforations, and has required extensive gastrointestinal sugeries.  From my limited experience these "toys" are causing significant morbidity and potential mortaliites among children. Not only is the public unaware of these consequences, but also one cannot forsee an ingestion and prevent an ingestion from occurring other than EXCLUDING these objects from the public market/domain', "We must ban the sale of all scissors, because they can be harmful to children. This is the level of absurd reasoning behind this proposed safety standard.  It boggles my mind that people think it's OK to initiate a total prohibition on something that was never intended as a children's toy. Yes, unsupervised children may harm themselves with such magnets. They can also harm themselves with lighters, knives, pencils, stairs, and water.  I'm all for limiting the sale and availability of this item to children, as well as requiring proper safety warnings on packaging. But this prohibition will do nothing but shut down American businesses, while the same product will still be available to order from China.", "I most strongly urge the CPSC to ban the sale of rare earth magnets of a size small enough to fit in the human mouth.    From the alarming number of, and increasing rate of, teens and children swallowing these magnets it is clear that warning labels are not sufficient protection for the public.  There have been heartbreaking suffering and lifetime adverse medical outcomes, which could be completely preventable.  Rare earth magnets are not toys, and not for consumer amusements.  Manufacturers who turn rare earth magnets into fun shapes and colors are putting profits ahead of children's lives.  Those manufacturers who refuse to take corrective action, such as the makers of Buckyballs and the Zen labels, should be criminally prosecuted for child abuse and voluntary manslaughter, as well as lesser charges for medical damages short of death.  Thank you for the opportunity to speak out on this vital consumer issue.", "The concept of outlawing magnetic spheres because they are unsafe is so utterly ridiculous that I can't grasp how this is seriously happening.  We are asking people to use their judgement to protect themselves and their children from improper use of vehicles, firearms, matches, fireworks (in many states), alcohol, cigarettes and over the counter medications but we can't expect these same people to use their judgement with a set of toy magnets?  This 'regulation' obviously has ulterior motives and should immediately be disregarded.", "I'm shocked and appalled that banning magnets is even undr consideration.", 'Please do not make Bucky Balls illegal. Serious overstep in govt regulation. Thanks', 'As a practicing pediatric gastroenterologist I strongly recommend that these magnets not be manufactured. I personally have had 3 toddlers have serious internal complications from swallowed magnets. These children all required emergent surgical intervention which has left them scarred for life and with compromised esophageal and bowel function. No amount of legislation or warning labels will keep toddlers from swallowing small objects. Ban these dangerous magnets!', 'In regards to the proposed banning of the scientic toys Zen Magnets and Bucky Balls. I believe these [rules are in violation of] 706(2)(a) as they are arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion. This promulgated rule violates the due process requirements for those affected as this will put organizations out of business. I believe a formal hearing under 556&557 should be implemented in light of the facts, even if not statutorily required, in an abundance of caution and respect for the companies affected.  These organizations have worked with the CPSC and done everything needed, and now the organization is acting in such a manner contrary to their previous prior dealings with the effected companies.   As a consumer, I think the CPSC is overreaching. Personal responsibility is key. We don\'t let children play with ball bearings, and we have not banned every magnet out there because of the potential (ab)use by children. Parents should be responsible and not let these ADULT TOYS fall within their hands.  I believe that there should be a category promulgated that is classified as an "ADULT TOY" wherein the CPSC can designate particularly age-inappropriate items and disallow their sale at establishments where children may express an interest.']

column2: n years ago, when I  realized the zoos don't always operate with their animals best interest in mind. This is especially true of elephant programs across the country.  These large and magnificent animals are often kept in confined spaces and in climates that require them to be kept inside for long periods during the winter months. This treatment is in contrast to their life in the wild, where they would walk miles each day and are involved in complex social relationships.  Too often at zoos, we can see elephants swaying, nevously back and forth, showing the stress created in their situations. And, this stress can sometimes lead to aggression toward other elephants.  More serious are the various foot ailments caused by inactivity.   This includes painful infections that can lead to imobility and sometimes death.   Such foot ailments do not exist in the wild where the elephant can achieve its required level of activity.    Elephants are often a source of major income for zoos.  Please require  zoos to live up to their responsibilities and provide adequate living conditions for these magnificent and wonderous creatures.  Make zoos operate with the best interest of the elephant in mind.", 'Elephants are migrating creatures.  Being forced to be chained for 21 hours a day  goes against everything in them.  I want better care for elephants in zoos and  circuses!', 'In 1986 I had the privalege to observe elephants in the wild in Kenya.  Their family  structure, far roaming habits, and foraging activities were in sharp contrast to the  daily activities of elephants in zoos. My last zoo visit a few years ago to Brookfield Zoo just a few miles from my home,  and a zoo I have visited since childhood, displayed animals who spent the day  swaying and bobbing in a small barren enclosure. Please uphold the provisions of the Animal Welfare Act and change the habitats of  these captive zoo elephants.  Increase the sizes of holding areas.  Provide for  socialization by grouping several elephants at a location.  And enrich their lives  with activities which would be natural to the species, like bathing, wallowing, and  foraging. It is the least we can do for these intelligent creatures.', '"The idea that it is funny to see wild animals coerced into acting like clumsy  humans, or thrilling to see powerful beasts reduced to cringing cowards by a  whipcracking trainer is primitive and medieval. It stems from the old idea that we  are superior to other species and have the right to hold dominion over them."   ?Dr. Desmond Morris, anthropologist, animal behaviorist, author.  Not only are  these animals tortured and exploited for money, they pose a health risk as  elephants have tested positive for TB at Ringling breeding compounds and  Ringling hides this information.  In a sworn deposition, Joel Kaplan, a private eye  who for 20 years had performed security and wire-tapping services for Feld  Entertainment, which owns Ringling, stated, ?[A]bout half of the elephants in each  of the shows had tuberculosis and [it] was an easily transmitted disease to ?  human beings. ? I was asked ? to find a physician who would test the people  [in] the circus to see if they had tuberculosis but who would destroy the records  and not turn them [in to] the Centers for Disease Control [and Prevention].?  Who  will the USDA protect:  these circus criminals or the public?  Circuses put our  children in danger and send the wrong message:  that\'s it\'s okay to take an  animal out of the wild and exploit it for profit.', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well- being.These intelligent creatures lack adequate space and are forced to live in unnatural conditions.  As a result, they suffer from painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and  neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. Both  circus elephants and many zoo  elephants are subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in tiny stalls for extended  periods of time. Moreover, circuses and many zoos control their elephants through cruel and painful means. Whips  bullhooks and electric devices are unnecessary and should be outlawed. Elephants need and deserve large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant  Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California.', "As members of In Defense of Animals (IDA), we are in complete agreement and  fully support IDA?s citizen?s petition seeking enforcement of the federal Animal  Welfare Act at zoos and circuses.  We also concur with IDA's request to the  USDA to seize elephants suffering from captivity-provoked infirmities.  It is well- known that captive elephants are dying prematurely from foot diseases associated  with lack of space and hard surfaces, including concrete and compacted dirt.  We  are in complete disagreement with The American Zoo and Aquarium Association  (AZA) setting a standard elephant enclosure at only 1,800 square feet per  elephant.  That is the equivalent of six parking spaces for the world?s largest land  mammal.  Captive elephants have also developed zoochosis, a psychological  behavior including head bobbing and swaying, from the lack of space for exercise  and/or socialization with other elephants.  Tuberculosis also spreads among  elephants in captivity.  An ongoing lack of space, exercise, and social enrichment  demonstrates the USDA's failure to uphold an AWA provision requiring zoos and  circuses to maintain settings consistent with the welfare of elephants.", "In this day and age we have NO reason for any suffering...seems that the  government doesn't care about people OR animals....Help stop the cruelty to   elephants and  other animals in need.", 'Please show some compassion and humanity for the elephants who are stuck in  Zoos. They are NOT here for our amusement or entertainment...Elephants MUST be  given the space and life that they require and deserve. Please free the elephants imprisoned in Zoos to acredited sanctuaries!', "I am writing this today because I think that something needs to be done to protect  these amazing animals. Elephants in captivity look miserable. They do not receive  proper care in zoos and especially circuses. They have limited space, unnatural  conditions and are even subjected to painful controll methods.Some of these  animals spend up to 20 hours a day chained up, or most of the year in a tiny  boxcar for a traveling circus. How torturous that must be. Elephants are such  emotional, intelligent beings, and they should be shown some respect. These are  animals that we are not meant to controll, and yet people are using bullhooks,  electric shock and other painful method to try to do just that.  If people insist on having these animal in captivity, it is only for the people's  benefit, not the elephant's. Therefore, we should make the least possible stress  on the animal. Zoos should provide a natural type habitat, hundreds of acres for  the elephants to roam, so they can enjoy the life that God gave them. I don't belive  that these animals should be in circuses at all!!! It is such an unnatural  environment, traveling all the time. I belive that this is where the majority of the  cruelty is taking place. Many of the people have no real knowledge about these  animals, and therefore use painful methods to try to controll them. In my opinion  we need to step in and really enforce the Animal Welfare Act. Any organization  that is not following the law should be punished and banned from working with any  animals. People in our world are blinded by dollar signs, and we need to teach  them that life, whether it's human or not, is more precious than a dollar.  Please read this and really consider how heartwrenching it is. If we don't do  something to stop it, then we are just as guilty than the people doing it. I wouldn't  be able to sleep at night if I didn't do at least SOMETHING!!! Thank you for your  time and consideration.", 'I am a private citizen who is extremely concerned about the treatment of captive  elephants.  Please help ensure humane treatment for these magnificent animals.    My concerns are as follows:  *Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being. The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and  circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses  currently meet this requirement.   *In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.  An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   *Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   *Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   *Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.   Thank you for your consideration of these issues.', 'It should be common sense that keeping other forms of life in an unnatural setting for most of their  lives soley for the purpose that another form of life on earth can be entertained is inherently wrong.   Life on earth has evolved to the state is is today to exist in certain natural settings that are  necessary for that species to survive and lead a normal life. Every fiber of it\'s being is directly tied  to that setting from the time it\'s born and throughout it\'s life.  To remove it from that natural  environment and force it to live in a restricted, artificial environment amounts to nothing less than  torture on a daily basis. No different than putting a human being in jail; only they did something  wrong to bring about that situation. No animal taken from their natural habitat in the wild ever did.  What are they being punished for ? It\'s time for the world to come out of the Dark Ages and co-exist with our fellow "earthlings" who  have as much right to live on this planet as they were intended as we do.', 'We have learned much more about elephant behavior in during the last  decade.Mostly, we have learned that these animals require social interaction, and  that to have a good elephant, it needs to be brought up and learn from its herd, or  older stable elephants in their sorroundings.. (Recent TV program about "Killer  Elephants"in Africa hilighted this). They also need ample acreage to roam and  excercise or they will develop leg joint and arthritic problems forcing  them to live  their long lives in pain and discomfort. This is a cruel inhumane punsihment for  such a magnificent creature. We do this so that someone who goes to a Zoo or a  circus can have their 10 minutes of fun...we are better than this.  Do what is propper. Enforce rules and regulations that will force their keepers to  provide a suitable environment for their well being, and if they can not, they must  transfer them to Wild Animal Parks or santuaries where their needs will be met.  Baby elephants should under no circumastances be born and brought up in zoos  unless they will grow in a herd and exposed to other members of their kind. The  laws must have teeth, and it must hurt them where it counts, namely their  pocketbooks', "It is bad enough that elephants are taken out of their natural environments and  made into entertainment slaves.  But they aren't even given enough space to have  a somewhat natural life.  Respect for these mighty animals is sorely needed.   Please help those that, in the face of human exploitation, are unable to help  themselves.", 'Response to Question #6:   In order to identify any health or care issues related to elephants in captivity; all  zoos, circuses, sanctuaries - any facility that houses and manages elephants,  should provide the medical records related to those animals for a complete  analysis.  If tuberculosis/trunk washes are monitored, so should any other  problems related to the welfare of captive elephants, including arthritis and  osteomyelitis.  Indeed, the zoos and circuses are the ones who should be doing  the research and creating the ?science? behind the findings.  Zoos and Ringling  Brothers Barnum and Bailey Circus, especially, should be involved as they have  stated repeatedly that they are working to conserve elephants.  A truly ?natural? death of an elephant is starvation, which happens when the last  set of teeth is worn down and the animal can no longer chew food.  An animal that  has the nutritional and medical advantages of good veterinary care, regular  food and exercise; and none of the perils of life in the wild (drought, poachers,  human  expansion, falling down a well, snake bite, etc.) should meet the longer lifespan of  60-70 years, not the 35-40 year lifespan elephants in captivity currently experience.  Other captive animals have a longer lifespan in captivity than in the wild; why not  elephants?', 'I do not believe elephants or any wild animal for that matter should live their lives in captivity.   These animals are prevented from acting on any of their natural instincts such as migration,  socialization, forresting, grooming...  Zoos and circuses can never give animals any life resembling  the life they were meant to live.  Both exploit animals for the sake of human entertainment.   Regulating the size of a cage in an attempt to improve their quality of life is misdirected  intervention.  Circuses should have their permits revoked and the remaining animals should live out  the rest of what life they have left in sanctuaries.', 'Elephants are one of my favorite animals.  They are majestic and so very  intellegent.  They can cry and they morn their loved ones.  Please don\'t give any  elephant a reason to cry. Some may disagree, but I know in my heart that animals should have the same  rights to a certain quality of life as we all do.  Besides, a healthy happy elephant  will live longer and bring more people (therefore money) to their "homes." I am an RN who hopes to have children who learn that humankind IS kind and not  cruel.   Therefore, I support all efforts to dramatically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country, including enforcing existing adequate space  requirements under the Animal Welfare Act (as requested in the IDA Citizens  Petition) and creating tough new standards that:  ? Require exhibitors of elephants to provide large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands  of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  ? Prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other  instruments of force against elephants.', 'Please discontinue the use of bullhooks on circus and animals to be eaten!  Please ban the use of electric shock devices everywhere! Those in charge of animals have been abusive and inhumane. Please stop cruelity of animals, they feel pain like the rest of us.', 'APHIS should issue a policy that clarifies the space and living conditions for  captive elephants. APHIS must promulgate new standards for elephants, that take  into consideration the size and social needs of these gentle creatures. APHIS  should work with In Defense of Animals and other organizations to create new  standards. APHIS must require that ALL exhibitors fully comply with these newly created  regulations and inspect the exhibitors more often.  Many elephants in the US live  in deplorable conditions, including spending countless hours chained up or on  concrete flooring. The current standards create unnecessary physical and mental  health problems for elephants. Minimum space requirements per elephant,  maximum performance time limits, and a specific requirement for living conditions  should be included in the new standards.', 'Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.', "The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include  a ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants.  Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  Sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'In many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from  unnatural conditions and social deprivation which leads to a wide variety of  preventable ailments including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.   An extimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants. Circuses are notorious for subjecting elephants to prolonged chaining, and  spending more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they  are again chained and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for  hours in their own waste.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic  environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the  Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in Caifornia.  These two  refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam,  socialize and maintain their health.', "I support all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive elephants in this  country. Please create new standards, including the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'Please improve the living/traveling conditions of Captive Elephants here in the  United States.', 'Please enforce some regulations in favor for these elephants!', 'Elephants by their very nature do not belong in zoos nor in a circus. They are  highly social creatures who suffer from isolation and the freedom to move at will.  Because zoos and circuses lack the resources to properly care for elephants they  must be released to qualified sanctuaries like PAWS and the Elephant Sanctuary  in Tennnesse where they can live out the rest of their natural lives in an enviroment  that is suitable for their comfort and well being.', 'Elephants are intelligent animals with complex family groups.  They require a great deal of space to move in.  Circuses and most zoos do not provide adequate space.  In addition, they are subjected to prolonged chaining in the circus and at many zoos and are not able to develop the social groups so important to them.  Some have to deal with extreme weather conditions.  Add to this the "training" forced on them especially by circuses using such devices as bullhooks and electric hotshots and it seems obvious that steps must be taken to protect these animals.  Our government must step in to regulate the health, care and conditions for elephants.', "PLEASE take care of these animals.  They didn't ask to be taken from their native  lands and forced into these situations or distress!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  It's obvious that left up  to man's own devices, they will NOT be cared for properly.  Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for  their health and well-being.   The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with  adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  In too many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but  from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An  estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and  these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.   Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.   Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments  similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges  provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize  and maintain their health.", "Please end the misery that these beautiful and innocent creatures are going  through. It's time to take a stand.", 'Elephants in captivity must be provided with the adequate conditions they require  for their health and well-being, as shown by a multitude of research. This includes  adequate space and opportunities for socialization, as well as more naturalistic  environments that include grass and other soft surfaces for them to stand on and  enough room to roam (similar to conditions found at The Elephant Sanctuary in  Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in  California.)   Not only do most captive elephants suffer from lack of space, but also from  unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of  preventable ailments such as painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and  digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing.   An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease,  and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  Circus elephants often spend up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more  than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars.   Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement  in barn stalls for extended periods of time. These conditions lead to a majority of  the above mentioned ailments.  Elephant exhibitors should be strictly prohibited from using such implements as  bullhooks, whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are  unnecessary and serve only as tools of intimidation and aggression against  elephants. They must be outlawed, and replaced with humane methods such as  those that are being successfully used at the elephant sanctuaries referenced  above.  Thank you for your consideration in this important matter.', 'Re: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service APHIS-2006-0044  The Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space. Neither zoos nor circuses currently meet this requirement.  The ways that zoos and circuses treat the animals are cruel,  make them sick and miserable in life, and kill a lot of them.  The law ought to be enforced.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  Organizations that keep elephants in conditions that harm them ought to be prevented from having custody of any.', 'Elephants are beautiful, extremely intelligent, and emotional creatures. I believe  the fact that we have them in captivity is shameful in and of itself. However, if they  are provided an adequate space and living environment it would not be nearly as  disgraceful. To see children feeding elephant?s candy and plastic at the  Albuquerque, New Mexico Zoo is tragic.  I remember going to the circus as a child and watching the elephants dance and  parade around in costume. We are teaching children that these creators are made  for our entertainment when we should be teaching them to respect and appreciate  their magnificence. Elephants will mourn the loss of a family member just as  humans do. They deserve and need our respect and protection.', "I support all the efforts that will really improve conditions for captive elephants in our country, which includes the enforcement of existing adequate space requirements under the Animal Welfare Act and create tough standards like:  (1) providing large, naturalistic, climate-appropriate environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the PAWS sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health and (2) will prohibit the use of bullhooks, chains, electric shock devices and other instruments of force against elephants.   The USDA must take action because Zoos and circuses are not giving elephants the conditions they require for their health and well-being.  They are cruel places for these intelligent and awesome creatures.  I have been to these places and watched elephants swaying back and forth and at that time, didn't realize this was a sign of just plain going crazy.  I, personally, have not been to a zoo or a circus in many, many years...won't take my grandchildren to them and, whenever I am able, always try to let my friends or neighbors know what goes on there and for them not to frequent these places either.    I am an animal lover since childhood and can't stand the thought of any animal being treated without compassion and love.  The elephant is a magnificent creature and deserves to live their lives as much as the wildlife they came from and not for our entertainment.  I sincerely hope you will take all this into consideration and make the right decision for these animals.  Thank you.", 'Circus elephants (and all circus animals) lead lives of unspeakable torture. Any country which allows this is not civilized.', 'Please enforce the current law protecting elephants.  These animals should not be  allowed to be used in Circuses or any other type of show business.  They are tortured, scared, beaten, tied up and screamed at so that they could submit to the people taking charge of them.  If you care for animals, you will make the law in favor of the ELEPHANT.  These gentle giants do not deserve the life that they  are leading with these gready bastards making money off their pain.  They should have plenty of space to roam, they should not be tied up, or placed  inconfinement.  They should be socialized with other elephants.  Most  importantly, they should not be tortured.  Thank you.', 'It is so exciting that this country is being given a chance to improve the lot of such  intelligent, magnificent animals.  It is to be hoped that the U.S. will, as usual, take  the lead on this issue, and provide the world with an example of how elephants  should be treated.  Elephants should not be forced to perform in any capacity and  should be banned from circuses.  Those currently in circuses should be given safe  havens.  With ivory poaching still going on in Africa, who knows, maybe North  America will become the new elephant habitat!  God bless us all in our efforts and thank the U.S. for giving us this golden  opportunity.', 'Help to protect elephants in circuses,etc.,and all circus animals in general.', 'To whom it may concern:  I have been studying the plight of the "confined elephant" for a few years, and I  have to say, as with many other animal related situations in this so called civilized  society, I am appalled. Too hard to fathom are the conditions elephants have to  suffer for the sake of that almighty dollar. It is horrendous that we do this with any  animal, much less these intelligent, magnificent and sensitive creatures. It is their  nature and their need to roam many miles a day on earth, not cement. I\'m sure  you are already aware of the arthritic and crippling conditions these animals suffer  from being confined.                          The greatness of a nation and its moral                           progress can be judged by the way its                           animals are treated.                                                         Gandhi                                     Its a man\'s concern for all creatures that                          make him truly human.                                                Albert Schweitzer                                                    You see, in the final analysis, it was                             never between you and them, it was                             always between you and HIM...                                                 Mother Theresa', "Something must be done. It's bad enough that we remove these elephants from their natural  habitats. We are ALL beings of
column3: ehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward for everyone to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I am not a marine mammal trainer, but I am someone who has visited marine animal parks and has had up close and personal interactions with marine mammals in a marine mammal park setting. I am also a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers Association (IMATA) because I believe in and support what marine animal trainers do. I believe that the standards of animal care and the regulations as they currently stand are adequate, and there is no need to modify what is currently in place unless irrefutable and scientifically proven data suggests otherwise.   I also firmly believe that if any modifications or revisions to current protocol are warranted they should come from established professionals with factual data, and not from animal rights activists with an anti-marine park agenda. I have always firmly believed that the welfare of these animals should be left in the hands of the loving and caring professionals who care for them daily. They are the ones who truly know these animals, and know what these animals need. I have experienced firsthand, and I have seen the care and attention these animals receive, and I believe that care is superior. Allow me to offer an example. In 2014 I participated in the Trainer for a Day program at Discovery Cove in Orlando, Florida. Under the direct and constant supervision of a Discovery Cove trainer I interacted with birds, small mammals, dolphins, and sharks. Throughout my entire experience I observed nothing but the utmost in superior care and maintenance that these animals receive. These animals were free to interact with guests at their own choosing. In fact, one dolphin kept returning to our group to interact with us entirely of its own volition with no commands given by any trainer to do so. At no time did any animal exhibit any signs of stress or non-compliance. No animal was forced to participate or confined to our group in any way. These animals were free to swim away from our group in a vast and spacious area. At any time any of these animals could swim away from us, but none did.    If ANY changes are indeed warranted with regard to animal welfare, I believe that these recommendations should come from experienced animal care professionals with fact based data to prove their points. I also believe that the claims made by animal rights activists should have no bearing on changing clearly established animal care protocols. Animals deserve to be respected and cared for to the best of our human abilities, but they are still animals. We as humans have been granted dominion over them since the Biblical times. We should always treat them with the utmost respect and care, but animals are not equal to us. The animal rights groups would seek to declare them as non-human persons. Clearly they are intelligent beings capable of learning the behaviors that humans teach them, but they are not human. The animal rights activists have a very clear agenda of trying to influence the public that keeping these animals in captivity is wrong. Abusive forms of captivity are wrong and should be abolished, yes. HOWEVER, the vast and overwhelming majority of captive animals in this country are treated with respect and a high standard of care in accordance with or exceeding the federal standard. In every single instance in which I have interacted with a marine mammal as part of the guest programs at SeaWorld and Discovery Cove, I saw animals that were maintained in the highest standard and quality of care. These animals appeared healthy and happy and eager to interact with guests of their own free will. These animals were never forced or compelled to do anything they didn't want to do, nor were they punished for refusing. Quite frankly, I don't understand these proposed changes in your current rules when the existing ones work perfectly in my assessment.   As I said, if ANY changes are warranted, they should be presented by established and reputable animal care professionals, and backed up by irrefutable data and research. If we start letting radical animal rights activists dictate the level of care these animals get, you will set a dangerous precedent that will have a negative ripple effect across the entire planet. I say just leave the rules as they are, and leave the care of these animals in the qualified hands of their trainers and other trained caregivers. They work with these animals every day and know them intimately. They are the ones who should be consulted on any proposed rules changes, not a group of radical animal rights activists with a clear agenda of ridding the world of all captive animals.", 'Please help these facilities help our planet!  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I understand that animals in captivity is not ideal; however, they are ambassadors for the wild animals and will help us understand and preserve the species.  In addition, most people never get the opportunity to see marine mammals in the wild, but seeing well cared-for animals in captivity helps the world understand and want to care for them ourselves.', 'Strict solid regulations on any captive animal enclosure is important.   That said, surely wise regulations should be based upon solid science.  My experience with Dolphin Quest in Bermuda was exceptional.', 'Dolphin Quest are doing fabulous, educational work.  let them carry on!', 'NO additional regulations should be placed on organizations such as Dolphin Quest.  New regulations that are being suggested by the misinformed.  There is great value of organizations such as these for humans and Dolphins alike.  The animals are treated in a humane manner and well cared for.  I believe in the "swim with the dolphin programs" as they provide very positive experiences for people and dolphins.  And these programs ultimately lead to active participation by many people in the caring for these animals in and out of their natural habitat. I am very familiar with these programs and will vouch that these programs should not only continue, but must be expanded.  The addition to current regulations are not done through science,  but by people who have no understanding of animal welfare and only have their personal "feelings" as to what they perceive as something that does not exist. Please do not waste our governments resources and the citizens of this country\'s time to enact regulations  or laws that have no valid scientific data behind these ridiculous decisions which are made by people who do not have the ability to do so. NO changes. Leave things alone.  These programs exist to promote the care and respect these animals need  by allowing understanding and interaction between these animals and humans.
