Please feel free to contact me, for comments or information:', 'As a close friend of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.    IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.  After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.  If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.  Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.    Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.   I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  All one needs to do is OBSERVE mammals in their NATURAL environment to understand their innate needs to live as intended.  There is NO SEA PARK that can SIMULATE THE OCEAN, therefore we must work toward the goal of no captivity allowed at all.  These mammals need global laws for protection if they are to survive the many perils they now face.  (There are entirely too many nonhumans in dwindling numbers due to humans\' negative impact).  I vote for NO MORE SEA PARKS, a gradual transition to sanctuaries for mammals who cannot live free, and the introduction of Sea Life Learning Centers for the public. These educational facilities could actually become quite profitable & provide positive entertainment as well as ensure that our future sea life will continue to exist for generations to come.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Seaworld is vital!', 'My family and I have taken part in several SeaWorld animal encounters, as well as, the tour through there backstage area for animal rescue and care.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. Having participated in scientific research, I know how important places like SeaWorld are in increasing our knowledge of animals in the wild and helping endangered species begin to flourish again.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I went to SeaWorld for the first time when I was 8 years old and have been 6 or 7 times since, I am know 58 years old and still look forward to going every chance I get, I have carried our children, our grand children and can't wait to carry the great grand children.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I think it would be a crime to stop SeaWorld performances because it brings so much enjoyment to people lives and especially the children.", 'I am in complete support of the proposal of revisions of the Animal Welfare Act. If these animals are going to be kept in captivity, then they should have the best care possible. Any changes are better than none at all. I am in complete agreement that sufficient shade be provided for these marine mammals in outdoor pools to allow them to be protected from direct sunlight.  There has to be better oversight with these "swim with the dolphins" programs.   The next significant change that seriously needs to be addressed to improve the lives of these marine mammals should be the minimum space requirements for the primary habitat.  These animals deserve anything positive that can be done to aid in their day-to-day existence to make their lives more meaningful. That is the least that they are owed.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  End animal captivity..  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'More regulations that would be problematic for us who LOVE Sea World.  This is crazy.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please reconsider these offensive regulations.', 'I am the Education Outreach Coordinator for Hollywild Animal Park in South Carolina.  I have been in the zoological field for 13 years, not including three years of internships during college.  I have been a member of AZA and AAZK throughout my employment at AZA facilities (SeaWorld Orlando, Brevard Zoo, Greenville Zoo).  I am currently working at a non-AZA facility in hopes that my knowledge and skills can assist them in reaching their desired AZA accreditation status.  Throughout my career I have cared for and trained numerous species including marine mammals.  I have had the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the regulations and would like to submit the below comments for consideration.  The additional regulation components specific to interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of programs. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation, or how further regulation would benefit marine mammals.  As a trainer, I feel that if interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, programs in which trainers bring marine mammals, such as, but not limited to pinnipeds, into a public area under stimulus control.  I cannot support the proposed rule, which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day. With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.  As a trainer, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision-making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.  I do understand that with the events that have transpired in the past several years, policies and procedures are being looked at closely and updated.  I do want to stress that when looking at policies, do not ignore the science or the successes due to the overwhelming voices of those not in the profession who spout emotion and not science.  Please look to those scientists who are doing research to help us

column2: one source...  Peace, Chris", "The force and domination that circus trainers use to make the animals do what  they want them to is horrible.  These animals should be treated like any other  breathing creature - with respect.  Let's help them get to a large natural  environment - i.e., The PAWS sanctuary in CA.  In too many zoos and circuses,  elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and  social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ?  including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and  neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all  captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the  leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.", 'Circus elephants are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21  hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in  train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme  temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are  also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for  extended periods of time.   Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and  aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips,  clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are unnecessary and must  be outlawed.', "Zoos and circuses do not provide elephants with the conditions they require for their health and well-being.  Even though the Animal Welfare Act requires that zoos and circuses provide elephants with adequate space, neither currently meet this requirement.  In fact, in many zoos and circuses, elephants suffer not only from lack of space, but from unnatural conditions and social deprivation that eventually cause a range of preventable ailments ? including painful arthritis, foot disease, reproductive and digestive disorders, and neurotic behaviors such as swaying and head bobbing. An estimated half of all captive elephants suffer from arthritis and foot disease, and these ailments are the leading cause of euthanasia in captive elephants.  For circus elephants, it's far worse.  They are often subjected to prolonged chaining, spending up to 21 hours a day standing in chains and more than 11 months of the year traveling in train boxcars, where they are again chained, and forced to endure extreme temperatures and to stand for hours in their own waste. Many zoo elephants are also subjected to prolonged chaining, and to confinement in barn stalls for extended periods of time.  Circuses and many zoos control their elephants through force, domination, and aggressive use of the bullhook and other tools of intimidation such as whips, clubs, and electric shock devices. These instruments are cruel and unnecessary and must be outlawed.  Exhibitors of elephants must be required to provide large, naturalistic environments similar to those at The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society (PAWS) sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide hundreds to thousands of acres over which elephants can roam, socialize and maintain their health.  Thank you for your consideration.", 'I am writing to ask the USDA to create highly needed, tough new standards for captive elephant  conditions.  The use of the following barbaric devices must be prohibited: bullhooks, electric-shock  devices, chaining, and any other instruments that cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants.   They are merciless and inhumane for use on ANY living being.  Additionally, exhibitors of  elephants must be required to provide large, climate-appropriate environments for the elephants,  resembling their natural habitats.  The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society sancturary in California provide good examples of captive environments  that others who insist on taking part in elephant captivity should employ.  On this issue,  inconvenience to the organization is not an excuse: elephants have to right to thousands of acres  where they can roam, socialize, and maintain their health. Please USDA, choose compassion for all living creatures!!  Thank you.', 'The recent publicity about the deplorable conditions in which many zoo and circus  elephants are housed and transported reveals a need to address their plight and  insure their humane treatment.  When elephants transported in a trailer die from  heat, there is incontrovertible proof that this problem needs to be resolved.', "I hope that you will lsiten to my voice since these aniamls don't ahve one. If you  are allowed in captivaty Its  my job and YOUR job to make sure they are taken  care of and NOT hurt. Thank you for your time.", 'There have been many cases of elephants turning on their trainers (handlers) and  bystanders in the last couple of years.  Why?  Because these gentle by nature  animals are beat with whips, and clubs and shocked with electric shock devices.   Bullhooks are often used to dominate elephants.  Any animal would eventually turn  on their handler if treated in this manner.  Elephants do not belong in circuses.  If  they continue to reside circuses and zoos then their conditions and treatment  should be regulated. Elephants need exercise, and socialization.   How long can  we continue to abuse those we consider beneath us?', 'As a nation we must put an end to the cruel and abusive treatment of captive  elephants.  Struggling to surive in the wild, we permit these animals to be abused  as they lead completely unatural lives.  And all of this abuse and cruelty so  humans can go ooh and ah as they perform  tricks so we can get a good laugh. Elephants shoud only be allowed to be kept in sanctuaries that replicate a natural  existence. For once, do the morally right thing.', "Following scrutiny from the media and the public over the plight of elephants in  circuses and zoos, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is currently  seeking public comments regarding all aspects of captive elephant care, including  cruel training devices such as bullhooks and electric prods, chaining, and lack of  space. The federal Animal Welfare Act does not have any standards or regulations  that address elephants' special needs.  Circuses and many zoos control elephants through the use of force and  domination, aggressive use of bullhooks, and prolonged chaining. In many zoos,  elephants are confined to barn stalls for at least 12 hours a day when zoos are  closed, and in zoos in cold climates, elephants often spend weeks at a time  indoors during cold winter weather.  Elephants are the world's largest land mammals, and they require significant  amounts of space. In fact, in the wild, they can walk up to 30 miles a day. The  leading causes of death in captive elephants are foot disorders and arthritis, which  are caused by prolonged chaining, intense confinement, and forced inactivity.  Since 2000, more than half of the 49 elephants who have died at zoos accredited  by the Aquarium & Zoo Association never reached their 40th birthdays, dying far  short of their 70-year life expectancies.  Because of their intelligence, complexity, sensitivities, and unique social and  physical needs, elephants suffer immensely in small, unchallenging captive  environments. To make matters worse for elephants, in circuses, every instinctual  behavior is subject to discipline. If elephants reach for grass, try to comfort friends,  or extend their trunks to smell something new or different, they get hit with  bullhooks. If they blow a trick during a performance, they get beaten afterward.  Despite the fact that elephants fare miserably in captivity, zoos and circuses are  vociferously defending the status quo.   I VEHEMENTLY SUPPORT all efforts to drastically improve conditions for captive  elephants in this country. Ask the USDA to create tough new standards, such as  the following:  ? The use of bullhooks should be prohibited. These barbaric devices have only one  purpose: to inflict pain. In addition, the federal Animal Welfare Act should include a  ban on the use of electric-shock devices, chaining, and other instruments that  cause pain, injury, and suffering to elephants. ? Exhibitors of elephants should be required to provide large, climate-appropriate  environments that resemble elephants' natural habitats?similar to those at The  Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing Animal Welfare Society  sanctuary in California. These two refuges provide thousands of acres where  elephants can roam, socialize, and maintain their health.", 'I serve on several animal boards and in connection with my work have researched  thoroughly the issue of elephants in zoos.  Our elephants in the El Paso zoo have  totally inadequate space yet at every turn we are told they "comply"  with the very  low standards applied to zoos.  Our two elephants live in less than 7/8 of an acre,   with most of that space taken up by buildings and boulders.  The elephants suffer  the typical foot disease suffered by most zoo elephants.  We need stronger  standards so that elephants either are released to a sanctuary or zoos spend a lot  more money to give them the type of habitat they need,  which would require  miles and miles of space on which to roam so that they maintain their health.', 'According to the Animal Welfare Act, zoos are required to provide "adequate" space for elephants.   Anyone familiar with elephants and their basic needs, who doesn\'t have a money making agenda,  will confirm that the confined spaces of a zoo are severely detrimental to elephants.  In addition,  zoo and circus personnel who use punitive instruments are severely damaging the physical and  psychological health of these animals.  I respectfully request that all measures possible be taken  to protect these wonderful creatures.', "All elephants in all zoo's should be transferred to sanctuaries.  Zoo's cannot  properly maintain elephants due to their specific requirements and size. These  animals to maintain their basic health need to walk for extensive period of time  over natural terrain not stand and pace on concrete floors.  Please do the correct thing for these animals and close all elephant exhibits,  do  not allow any further elephants to be brought into this country, transfer all existing  elephants to proper sanctuaries.     These are a very intelligent and family oriented  species,  the way they are now treated is tantamount to putting one of our  species in solitary confinement.  This needs to be addressed and corrected for now and the future.", 'Dear Sirs,  It is time to improve the living conditions of captive elephants in the United States!  We  urge you to develop tough new standards to protect these fabulous animals!  We  believe in the following for our elephant friends:  1.  Bullhooks are barbaric devices used to inflict pain!  They and electric-shock  devices, chaining and other instruments that cause pain, injury and suffering to  elephants must be banned!  2.  Elephants deserve to live in large, climate appropriate environments that resemble  their natural habitats!  The Elephant Sanctuary in Tennessee and the Performing  Animal Welfare Society in California provide thousands of acres where these majestic  animals can thrive by roaming, socializing and maintaining their health!  These wonderful animals have suffered far too long; concern for their welfare is long  overdue!  We Americans must be respectful and compassionate of our animal friends!   It truly is the right thing to do, and the elephants so deserve it!!', 'My comment refers to Docket Nr. APHIS-2006-0044.    Elephant care is minimal at zoos and circuses.  Much stronger regulation is needed.  Elephants are  extremely intelligent and sensitive animals.  They are being forced to perform degrading and totally  unnatural tricks.  When not performing they are usually chained in tight quarters.  Training is most  often brutal, using elecric shocks. bullwhilps,and prods with hooks on the end that hurt their flesh.   They are normally very social creatures and are being denied this natural life.  Disease is common  and great psychological stress as well.  They should have much  larger natural environments to  live in.  They deserve far better care than what they are usually receiving in zoos and circuses.   Please  help them.', 'Please consider MUCH stricter regulations for these large, sensitive  creatures.  They should definitely not be subjected to ANY type of training  technique that involves pain, i.e. electric shock, whips, bullhooks.  It is  inhumane.  Their transport in small, overheated enclosures is  inexcusable.  Every living thing deserves respect and, although they do  not even belong in captivity, should at least have enclosures (zoos) that  provide them with as much living space and stimulation to mimic their  natural surroundings as possible.', 'Please ensure that elephants who are unfortunate enough to be kept in captivity  are ensured proper care, shelter and adequate space as per In Defense of  Animals recommendations.  Thank you.']
column3: understand animals and their behavior; not those who have ulterior motives and spout twisted, incorrectly calculated data.  I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'Marine mammals often get neglected when it comes to animal cruelty laws, so organizations, like Sea World, can abuse them in the name of "education."  As a child, I went to Sea World & we were blind to the horrors that these poor animals endure.  I didn\'t learn a thing...this was in the name of entertainment!  If we knew of their torture, we wouldn\'t find this entertaining at all!  Anyone entertained by cruelty, abuse, & torture is needs mental help!  It HAS been proven that even fish are sentient beings, so marine mammals are as well.', 'In the recent publication of propaganda towards the anti-Sea World movement, we have noticed a large group of individuals making rash judgements without completing thorough research. Their arguments and rants have placed a lot of pressure to modify the structure of aquatic environments, which are unnecessary, as marine life needs organizations such as Sea World to help research and educate on oceanic life as our zoos are used for wild animals on land.   Before such rash decisions are made, we need to gather appropriate research to see if any changes will harm the animals as well as the human beings that come to learn. Sea World has always been an educational facility, but they are also a business. In order to perform their research, they need money, and let\'s face it- it\'s a pretty big ocean out there.The entertainment aspect is what attracts people in to their parks more than zoos- they get to see these animals in a way that connects to them- it entrances them, entertains them, and that causes a positive emotion and reaction. And you must admit- it worked- because their income and attendance at their parks far surpassed their neighboring zoos. Through their income, they have been able to research and educate thousands of people.  As I look back on my life, I notice how I learned more about oceanic life from Sea World than I learned in school. The reason: schools have books and instruction- Sea World provides experiences. And we learn better by doing and experiencing. It was through Sea World that I learned to love the ocean and the life within it. It opened my own personal world beyond what a book or video could ever offer.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Before any decision is made, we need to consider that if this decision is influenced by "Blackfish", the film needs to be viewed again, through the eyes of a person educated with the knowledge base of propaganda. The film did not mention that the animals were treated poorly, abused, or living in squalor within the last 20-30 years. Any negative references to the treatment of animals were directed at foreign marine parks, and marine parks 30-40 years ago. Such practices have changed over the last 30-40 years. In addition, if any changes are to be made, then offer support to help create larger, more life-like areas for the animals to live in. Also look at the environments in zoos- because if the choice is being made to alter that of one animal park, it should be made for all- and we can easily see what a slippery slope that can turn out to be.', 'I really like this proposed regulation. I believe that if an animal is going to be in captivity there has to be very strict rules and regulations for that animals health and well-being.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Stop letting radicals force changes that will negatively impact the good sea world does.', "I have been visiting the dolphinarium at Grassy Key,  Florida since the early 1970s and the Dolphin Research Center (DRC) since its inception in 1984. I thoroughly enjoyed every visit as a spectator and participant in DRC's interactive programs. I have attended many other marine mammal parks both nationally and internationally and I chose the DRC to become a more serious student of marine mammal biology, care, and training as well as conservation and preservation. Recently I completed DRC's week-long adult dolphin lab program in March.   I have also committed to attending DRC's  career series education program offered in May and June.  I truly appreciate that APHIS works to ensure that high standards are met for the optimum care of all marine mammals in captivity and recognizes the value of U.S. Marine Mammal Parks in their role to provide education to the public.    Having had the opportunity to be fully immersed in an interactive dolphin experience, I observed that the entire dolphin population residing at DRC appears to be happy, well cared for and that they enjoy their various human interactions.    For me, the most memorable connections are when I have the opportunity to be in the water with the dolphins. The Dolphin Encounter program is DRC's swim program. Each time I have participated, the dolphins seem to enjoy the session as much as I do. It is always a special treat when I'm able to interact with two dolphins at the same time, especially during a tandem dorsal pull or when they try to imitate my actions into an appropriate behavior.  I stand in awe watching the interactions between the dolphins and the trainers.  I felt total confidence in the knowledge of all the trainers and view them as true professionals.  DRC's trainers and staff work diligently to maintain a clean habitat for the dolphins.  I have watched staff members routinely clean and maintain the docks, fences, and gate enclosures and remove any debris that may have floated or been blown in from the surrounding environment. The dolphins at DRC are fortunate to live in their natural habitat.  As can be expected, water clarity of the DRC lagoons can varyoften the water is very clear but sometimes after inclement weather or natural dolphin play, the water can appear a bit cloudy.  Since water clarity can be affected by natural causesI assume these conditions are not too dissimilar from the experiences of dolphins in the wild.  I do not believe my safety was in any way encumbered on days when the water was less clear.  Nor did it seem to affect the dolphins' welfare or the trainers' ability to care for them.  I thereby think the proposed regulation on water clarity is unreasonable when it relates to marine mammals living in their natural habitat.   I have been fortunate that DRC has provided many educational opportunities for me to grow and share knowledge.  I hope to one day share the knowledge I gained at the DRC with landlocked adults and children who have not had the opportunity to connect with the oceans or its inhabitants, and to spread my passion for ocean conservation.  There is no question that the dolphins residing at DRC are loved and cared for deeply. I have witnessed that every aspect of their care and well-being is continually addressed. I felt truly confident in the expertise of each trainer that has been dockside. They know the individual personalities of each dolphin and their exuberance and genuine passion enable these dolphins to engage in human interactions with enjoyable challenges.    Thanking you for this opportunity to express my opinion regarding the agency's proposed rules.", 'To who it may concern  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for your attention', 'I am a teacher  and know the importance of educating future generations.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments on your proposed rules for marine mammals.  Because excellent animal health and welfare are the goals of APHIS regulations, we are fortunate to have  a strong community of professional marine mammal specialistsveterinarians, trainers, and handlerswho, collectively,  have a long history of working hands-on with all the species of marine mammals that are in marine parks and zoos,  as well as those that have stranded on beaches in every coastal state. These specialists work with the animals every day,  around the clock, year after year. Their demonstrated expertise, experience, scientific knowledge, and dedication to the health and welfare of these animals are unsurpassed. I urge that any modifications to the regulations be based on the most current science and information from this marine mammal professional community of specialists that have the most  experience with the animals.  At our Dolphin Quest facilities, the animals are given exemplary care in large and enriched environments. We are proud  that we meet and exceed the Animal Welfare Act standards regarding animals under human care. We also have a strong  historical record of success and safety in our human-dolphin interactions. Based on that record, I believe that additional  regulations on interactive programming are unwarranted.   Marine parks and zoos provide the only reliable and safe opportunities for the public to see, learn about, and, in some cases,  to interact with living marine mammals. Over the four decades that I have been a marine mammal conservation educator, I  have visited almost every marine mammal public-display facility in the U.S. and I know that these facilities play a crucial  role in raising awareness and knowledge about ocean animals, the environment, and conservation. Seeing and interacting  with marine mammals create emotional connections that result in people caring about the animals; and these experiences inspire people to engage in stewardship behaviors. Given the deteriorating conditions of wild places all over our planet,  marine mammal public-display facilities are sanctuaries for the animals where humans are learning and reconnecting to nature.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for your time and consideration.', 'We are long-time members and supporters of the Dolphin Research Center (DRC) and, as such, are vitally interested in the proposed changes for regulation of marine mammal facilities and husbandry.  We have participated in many different kinds of interactions with both dolphins and sea lions at DRC over the years, including swim programs, shallow water programs, and dry programs.   We appreciate APHIS\'s work and laud the effort to keep both animals and people safe.   Two of the proposed changes are of particular concern. First, the stipulation that the dolphins are visible at all times during an interactive program. The natural-water lagoons at DRC vary in depth and are subject to the vagaries of wind and weather. The trainers are able to see the dolphins at all times when interacting with guests, but may not have clear visibility when the dolphins are demonstrating behaviors away from the docks and people.  Secondly, the stipulation that each dolphin must have its own trainer is excessive. The dolphins and trainers at DRC are accustomed to working with two or three dolphins per trainer, and have been trained to "take turns," and wait at their "stations" until their turns come around. There are also circumstances in which young dolphins choose to accompany their elders when performing behaviors with guests - much to the delight of all participants.   The dolphins at DRC live joyful lives at this wonderful, natural-water facility. Safety for both the human guests and marine mammal residents has always been the primary concern in all interactive programs.   Additionally - DRC continues to enrich our lives and those of every single guest, with narrated sessions educating us about these wonderful animals and messages of conservation and treatment of their wild relatives. We have seen and experienced the powerful impact getting to know these animals has made on many lives - from the children\'s eyes widening in wonder watching the dolphins\' athleticism, to the glee of splash imitations, to our own appreciation of their intelligence, ability to learn, and willingness, even eagerness, to share their world with us.  Continuing support of marine mammal facilities is vital. At DRC there is a prominent display of the words of conservationist Baba Dioum: "In the end we will conserve only what we love; we will love only what we understand; and we will understand only what we have been taught."', 'I love visiting the Seaworldparks Park & know how much care & love their animals.Animals are well fed ,with the best of care & protection.In many instances a breeding pattern is established to prevent extinction. From my very first visit there I was deeply impressed with the care and love the dolphins receivedso much so, that I took time away from my career to do volunteer work there one summer. Being on the "inside" as it were, I became even more appreciative of how consciously and carefully the dolphins are treated and how well-trained and skilled the trainers are.  Last week, I came back to the DRC after an absence of over six years. How wonderful it was to see such familiar dolphin faces like Aleta, who was the first dolphin I swam with back in the mid 80\'s. I was flabbergasted to see that Molly was still around in her mid 50\'s and doing well. It is because of the extreme care that she and all the dolphins and seals at the DRC receive that these beloved dolphins live such long and happy lives. I was also very glad  to see Kathy Roberts again. She has been there for 35 wonderful years.  She, Mandy, and so many others have dedicated their entire lives to this tremendous facility. I have witnessed their expertise and commitment to the well-being of every dolphin and seal throughout the years.    I gave myself a 79th birthday present: a swim with the dolphins. It was a deeply moving. Kat, the trainer, was brilliant in the calm and loving way she dealt with both the dolphins and us five participants. She so easily handled the two dolphins who seemed to be having as much fun as we were.  I am so heartened by the fact that this facility is run by a family, like a family. Help save the animals for future generations and don't listen to the people who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.", 'I believe in the research that is being done by Sea World is very important to our world!  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  thank you for you time', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Marine mammals deserve much better conditions than proposed.  Enormous changes are necessary to meet minimum "humane" treatment for creatures that should never be in captivity at all!  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'As an educated engineer and scientist I regret that government officials are pressured to make important decisions that are based on a flawed understanding of facts, nature, and science by well meaning anti-scientific extremists.  I hope you will do the right thing and not be influenced by the unknowing offering flawed support for their position.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'As a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.     IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I am a supporter of accredited zoological facilities and aquariums and marine parks and have been personally inspired by my experiences at Georgia Aquarium.  I applaud APHIS for evaluating, and where necessary, updating the regulations by objectively assessing the latest peer reviewed science and input from industry experts on the best practices for care of these incredible animals. I am concerned that individuals and groups opposed to marine mammals in a zoological settings misuse the process of updating marine mammal care regulations in their attempts to end the display marine mammals.  They do so by encouraging APHIS to impose rules which are not necessary, counter to decades of successful care programs and processes, and impede the great education and conservation work done by the zoological community.  I encourage APHIS to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based upon on the merits of applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards; in cases where insufficient literature exists, input and observation of successful practices within the industry should be strongly considered. I work directly with the millions of guests that are welcomed at Georgia Aquarium each year. I have had the experience of seeing guests of all ages see aquatic animals and ecosystems they may never see in their lifetime and strike a deeper understanding of the one world ocean that connects us all. All of us at Georgia Aquarium are committed to providing our guests with a positive and impactful experience to inspire conservation of our aquatic world. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of people the ability to see magnificent animals and learn more about them. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practices standards. I work with the thousands of students that are educated at Georgia Aquarium each year. At Georgia Aquarium we are committed to educating guests and students of all ages about our aquatic ecosystems and the animals that live within them. Students are able to see marine mammals that they may never see in their lifetime and foster a deeper understanding of the ocean that connects us all.  Georgia Aquarium is located in Atlanta, GA, a land-locked city, students are able to see thousands of different animals from all over the world in one location to connect their learning even further. I believe changes to the APHIS rules that could ultimately end the display of marine mammals would deny millions of students the opportunity to connect what they learn in the classroom with real-world applications at an accredited zoo and aquarium. APHIS should take careful consideration to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based on the merits of the applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards. I think that any new or revised animal care regulations such as these should be based on scientific studies and knowledge from experts who have years of experience caring for marine mammals.  The rules should not be based on opinions that are unsupported by the facts or experience.    I have participated in the dolphin interactive programs at Marineland Dolphin Adventure and was inspired to care about the magnificent bottlenose dolphin. The interactive program was incredible, safe, and well executed by professional trainers. During our program, the staff clearly emphasized the safety of the animals AND the participants was their top priority, and while they certainly hoped we had a positive experience, it was also essential the animals had a very positive experience as well. It is clear, through this experience, Marineland is managing the needs of both guests and the animals that participate in the programs. Therefore, I do not see a need for further regulations on interactive programs. They are very sage and the dolphins appear to thrive and enjoy it.', 'I love SeaWorld and the Columbus Oh Zoo and see how well the staff and trainers take care of and support the animals in their care.  I so miss the water interaction with the trainer and killer whales at SeaWorld.   The interaction was so awesome and always touched my heart you could see the love between the whale and trainer.  There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world. Marine mammal parks, along with other zoos and aquariums, are the best resource we have to educate the public about the natural world and to inspire them to protect it.  Any attempt to limit public interactions with animals at these facilities would hurt conservation efforts. APHIS and the USDA should focus on protecting animal related jobs and human-animal interactions, be they in zoology, training, rescue, farming, performing, veterinary, service, or private ownership, from the unfounded and emotional attacks of uneducated animal rights zealots.  Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit their ability to care for the animals.
