The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.", 'I believe accredited zoological facilities, aquariums, and marine parks are critical to the education, inspiration, and even overall care of animals world wide    I think institutions like APHIS are a cornerstone for maintaining the quality of care needed to perpetuate populations of animals in human care.    My concern is that we may be tempted toward a reactive response to what may be a misguided knee-jerk, or emotionally driven goal of the elimination of those facilities that maintain animals in human care    I work directly with much of the public that passes through Marineland Dolphin Adventure and can see the inspirational value of our interaction with them.    While I consider quality care to be a critical component of what we do, ( in itself is a lesson of respect of the wellbeing of animal life in general.), it is important that the regulatory agencies not find themselves being used as a tool by those that have much more on their agenda than the quality of care toward these animals while being presented to the public to educate, and inspire consideration for these animals in their natural habitats.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Please acknowledge current scientific information and UPDATE 30 year old policy.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-sc

ale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.   I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people, including me, might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities. Our family recently had the opportunity to experience a dolphin interactive program at Dolphin Quest. We also watched many sessions between the dolphins and trainers. In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's expertise and dedication to the animals.    As a long time supporter of marine parks and aquariums, I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation. They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  Cynthia Williamson", 'I feel it is very important for us to interact with water animals and dry land animals.  It is so important to know what they can do and how they interact with us.  We have studied human in many aspects of life and health. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Let us know and love the water animals.  Next people will say the zoo animals should go free.  Also, people will say Busch Gardens should let their animals go.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.     As an annual pass holder, I have taken my children to SeaWorld throughout the years as they were growing up and now take my 3 grandchildren. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'I have been a supporting member of the Dolphin Research Center for over 10 years.  I have had the good fortune to visit this facility and participate in interactive programs on 2 occasions.  In both occasions, I was very impressed with the staff\'s dedication to the safety and enjoyment of the program for both the human participant and also the dolphins.  During my day as "Trainer For A Day", I had the opportunity to play with 2 dolphins at the same time for a swimming session.  The 2 dolphins really appeared to enjoy interacting together with myself and the trainer.  Even though there was only 1 trainer present during this activity, I felt completely safe.  Both dolphins were very attentive to the trainer\'s signals and very gentle with me.  I also did not feel any risk to my safety in the natural water environment at this facility, even when there might be a short period of time where we could not clearly see the dolphins.  I am very impressed with the dedication to the safety and welfare of the dolphins displayed by the trainers at DRC.  Thank you for your commitment to the safety and welfare of the marine mammals at our U.S. Marine Mammal parks.', 'Please see attached comments of Miami Seaquarium and Sea Life Park and exhibit A to those comments.   (Filed a second time to provide contact information for the second filer, Sea Life Park)', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  My family has been going to SeaWorld for many years. My children began their love of animals there and one is working with animals as an adult. I now watch my grandchildren learning how to protect animals. They have participated in beach clean ups and other eco friendly activities because of the things SeaWorld has educated them about. Our sea life is at the greatest risk from our damage to their natural habitat. It is crucial for places like SeaWorld to have the ability to educate the public and their staff because they are the ones using that knowledge to help the animals that others are harming in the wild.', 'My family and I have been long time supporters for animal rights and have personally seen the value that facilities like Sea World play in caring for and protecting sea life and the environment.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I know that others may feel like animals in marine parks are better off in the wild, but this is not true.  Parks and facilities like SeaWorld not only provide protection, care and education but also conduct important research that helps us all understand how promote the health of our oceans and their inhabitants.', 'I am a resident of Ontario, Canada and I am with an organization called Ontario Captive Animal Watch.  My organization participated and spoke at the hearing of Bill 80 seeking to ban the importation and breeding of orcas into this Province and the Bill became law.  I also attended at the Minister\'s office with Dr. Ingrid Visser, marine biologist and the only researcher specializing in orca in New Zealand waters, in order to provide input regarding the Standards of Care for Marine Mammals which has since been implemented in the Province of Ontario.  I would first like to applaud your decision to amend the regulations of the Animal Welfare Act concerning the humane handling, care, treatment and transportation of marine mammals in captivity. I wish to provide the following comments supported by current science and/or industry best practice:  1. I vigorously encourage you to review the scientific data referenced in the comments submitted by Animal Welfare Institute with regard to improving the welfare of captive marine mammals.  The scientific understanding of marine mammals has grown exponentially since the captive marine mammal regulations were last revised and I encourage you to reflect this growth in knowledge in the revised regulations.  In particular, I urge you to consult the following publication: Aquatic Mammals (the journal of the European Association of Aquatic Mammals, a professional association of the regulated community), entitled "A survey of the environments of cetaceans in human care" (Couquiaud 2005).  I strongly urge APHIS to consult the full range of available scientific literature on relevant aspects of marine mammal biology and ecology to inform its efforts while finalizing this rule.  2.  Of particular concern to me is APHIS has chosen not to amend the current space requirements, which is simply unacceptable given the large body of recent research demonstrating the fine-scale daily movement patterns of various species of marine mammals.  I urge you to re-examine the research in finalizing your determination regarding space requirements.  Even though captive cetaceans are provided food and do not have to forage and travel long distances for that purpose, science has proven that if they do not exercise or remain active then they suffer serious health consequences.  The failure to revise the current space requirements in light of current science on this topic in my opinion is the greatest shortcoming and failure of the proposed rule to make significant improvements to captive marine mammal welfare.  Lolita currently resides in an inexcusably small tank in Miami which is clearly detrimental to her welfare..  3.   As well, the proposed rule does not include any noise standards for indoor or outdoor facilities, nor does it explain or justify this omission in any way. Yet in several instances, licensee noise levels, particularly in-air, are extremely high (e.g., in some theme parks, virtually every night, there is a fireworks display directly over marine mammal enclosures; in others, roller coasters are placed in close proximity to marine mammal enclosures . The publication I referenced earlier Couquiaud (2005) includes a section on noise concerns (pp. 344- 345) and offers some common sense recommendations to mitigate noise. I strongly recommend that APHIS formulate noise standards and consult Couquiaud (2005) when doing so.  4.  i oppose feeding/petting programs which allow the public to handle and provide food to the animals, an activity that is otherwise restricted to trained personnel in the regulations (see  3.105(c): "...food...must be given by an employee or attendant responsible to management who has the necessary knowledge to assure that each marine mammal receives an adequate quantity of food to maintain it in good health" By definition, feeding/petting programs violate this section of the regulations and thus cannot simply be ignored.   5. I strongly support the proposed change to require shade for marine mammals housed outdoors.  I personally proposed that change to the Minister to include in Ontario\'s Standard of Care for Marine Mammals and it was in fact implemented.  6.  I strongly  oppose interactive programs (eg. swim with dolphin programs), as science has proven them to be an additional stressor for species already stressed by baseline captive conditions, a hazard for the human participants, and, an activity that perpetuates an inconsistent message to the public about the appropriateness of close contact with wildlife. I also strongly oppose the space requirement proposed changes as the proposed changes to the space requirements for bottlenose dolphins in current  3.104 are already completely inadequate to safeguard the welfare of the animals, let alone protect the safety of swimmers.  7. I oppose reducing the time period during which records must be kept from 3 years in the current regulations to 1 year in the proposed, and that interactive programs be required to keep records.', 'I have worked in no less than 3 facilities in which animals are in human care. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "I am a frequent visitor to Gulfarium Marine Adventure Park in Fort Walton Beach, Florida.  During my visits, I have observed educational presentations and also spent time watching many sessions between the dolphins, sea lions , seals, and their trainers.  In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's dedication to loving and caring for the animals and the clean environments in which the animals live.   It is clear to me that the dolphins, sea lions, and seals enjoy the sessions as much as the people. I brought my young daughter to the park where she was able to interact with the dolphins.  They were very friendly and absolutely chose to participate.  They were never forced.  This interaction increased my family's commitment to conservation and support of the environment that we live in.  These animals brought so much joy to us and have helped me teach my young daughter about compassion and animal welfare.  The Gulfarium has my undying gratitude for the work they are doing to educated the public and care for the animals in their facility.    Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I will see you next year. and looking forward to work with you one day.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  free them all from captivity.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I particularly hope that for generations yet to come, they will be able to visit SeaWorld and other well managed animal facilities to see first hand the beauty and wonder of what God has made and given to us to care for.  Please do not let all animals become endangered humans who are not educated on conservation needs.', 'I am a frequent visitor to Marineland Dolphin Adventure in Marineland, FL, SeaWorld Orlando, and many other zoological facilities that APHIS oversees. I have seen firsthand the impact that an encounter with an animal can have. These facilities give people the chance to observe and interact with animals that they may never get a chance to see in person otherwise. Myself and countless others have been amazed by these interactions and were inspired to make changes in our daily lives to protect their wild counterparts. My visits to SeaWorld and then Marineland and the wonderful staff that I met there were what inspired and continue to motivate me to pursue a career in marine science, and I continue to share my passion for animals and conservation with everyone I meet. I know many others who share this sentiment: their experience at a zoological facility taught them how to be a better steward of the environment.  The standards set by APHIS ensure that all facilities are giving their animals top-quality care, and I appreciate that these standards are being evaluated. It is important that there is a place for people to go to learn about and admire marine mammals in an environment that is safe for them and the animals. It is also important that these standards are continually reviewed as we learn more about animal care through research and experience.  Unfortunately, there is currently a vocal minority who feel very strongly that marine mammals do not belong in human care. While this is a valid opinion, there is no scientific evidence that marine mammals are not thriving in zoological facilities because the standards of care are so high. Those people who oppose marine mammals in human care are free to choose not to visit, but it is important that those places are still available for the rest of us who see their great importance to society and the environment.', 'Inhumane, plain and simple', 'Interactive exhibits:  It is a good safety feature to always have a second staff person out of the water and ready to respond in case of anything unforeseen happening.  However, putting more people in the water is not an effective measure to improve safety.  A person in the water is not very effective at managing a marine mammal. People, especially children, go to these facilities to learn and connect with nature and they then leave with a new perspective, changed forever with a new respect and motivation for conservation. We need these facilities in order to give everyone this same opportunity. Thank you for your time', 'Have you ever heard an old saying that, "If it ain\'t broke, don\'t fix it"?  While I am appreciative of the government\'s intentions I am reminded of one thing.  Experience and history are better bases for decisions than good intentions.  I truly believe that Dolphin Research Center is the most qualified voice for marine mammal treatment.  So I would advise APHIS to avail themselves of and heed their counsel.    My wife and I have been members there for over twenty years.  We have had the memorable experiences of both the dock activity "Meet the Dolphin" and lagoon swim "Dolphin Encounter".  As with an adolescent\'s first kiss, you never forget your first dolphin kiss.  And the dorsal fin pull is an exhilarating experience that you will relive the rest of your life.  I was able to get a picture of my wife as the dolphins pulled her around the lagoon and there was sheer ecstasy on her face.  At the dock activity we had a single trainer with a single dolphin.  In the water we had a single trainer with the two dolphins.  To put things in perspective, my wife is a natural strong swimmer......I swim like a rock.  I can swim but have always been tentative around water.  However, in neither of the above instances did I have any feeling of fear or apprehension.  I was able to relax and enjoy the inter-action with our two beautiful dolphins.  I can see absolutely no reason to require a trainer for each dolphin during activities.  These are docile gentle creatures.  To think that it requires a trainer for each one to handle them is ludicrous.  When was the last time you saw eight drivers with the Budweiser Clydesdales?    If you want clear water viewing of sealife go to Mote Marine or Disney World.  But for the natural true life viewing you go to DRC where Mother Nature handles the water and recirculates the lagoon continually.  Many a time I would love to see what is testing my bobber in the creek.  But that is just not "natural".  At the fish market you "see what you get".  In the creek it is just whatever happens to be down there.  We have become ambassadors for our wonderful marine mammals over the years.  I am not afraid to tell somebody to "not feed the wild dolphins" or to another "slow down to idle no-wake speed in manatee areas".  In fact, after we introduced our daughter-in-law to dolphins she became so enthralled with them that she changed her college major and went into animal behaviorism.  After interning at Mote and DRC she has now been in research at Disney World for over ten years.  Consequently, our granddaughter has become a new generation of ambassador due to our initial membership at DRC.  There is even a paving brick with her name and date of birth on it in one of the walkways.      Please permit Dolphin Research Center to continue their exemplary work as they know best how to do it.', 'I am a lifelong ocean and marine animal enthusiast. There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  As a Mother, Educator and Scuba Diver.. I support the efforts of Sea World to expose the masses to our Oceans and the beautiful creatures we must protect.', 'As the Assistant Manager of Behavioral Management and Education at the National Aviary, and an animal care taker for over 8 years, I have always been concerned with providing the best welfare of those in my charge.     In my career I have cared for and trained many different animals including marine mammals. The one constant I believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of all animals including marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best.  Each animal should be treated as an individual requiring different variations in training based on the individuals welfare.  In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesira

ble" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'I  have been a professional animal trainer for 34 years. I hold memberships in the following professional organizations:  AZA, IAATE and AMBA. I have had the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the regulations and would like to submit the below comments for consideration.  INTERACTIVE PROGRAMS The additional regulation components specific to interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of programs. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation, or how further regulation would benefit marine mammals.  As a trainer, I feel that if interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, programs in which trainers bring marine mammals, such as, but not limited to pinnipeds, into a public area under stimulus control.   TIME LIMITS FOR SESSIONS  I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. That would be like saying someone shouldn\'t walk their dog or give it attention for more than 3 hours a day when that dog lives for the attention from it\'s owner/trainer. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day. With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   TRAINER TO ANIMAL RATIOS  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.    UNDESIRABLE BEHAVIOR  As a trainer, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.  PART 3: CONCLUSION  I would like to thank APHIS for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and that you did not feel compelled to unnecessarily change regulations. Thank you!', 'I believe that it is extremely important for people to be able to have up close and personal experiences with animals in order to create a bond and a passion to protect them in the wild.  Zoos and aquariums exist to educate and foster a desire to make changes and conserve the environment for animals in the wild. I strongly believe that any changes made to the APHIS regulations should be carefully considered and backed by the most current science and research.  Dolphin Quest and other marine mammal facilities not only give people like myself and my family the opportunity to get up close and personal with  animals that we otherwise will have never been able to see, but they also employ the best animal health care and provide invaluable research opportunities that are only possible with trained dolphins that have created mutually trusting and beneficial relationship. Thank you,  Lyndsey Warmuth', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Most of the folks I know now believe captive marine mammals businesses should be phased out.  The public wants an end to captivity businesses.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'With all the misinformation being spread about Sea World, other aquariums and zoological facilities, it is concerning to see the federal government side with militant animal welfare organizations such as PETA.  These organizations are well funded propaganda machines that thrive by sowing the seeds of confusion in the American Public.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I believe there should be preservation and care facilities for animals of all kinds.', 'I understand the concern about how animals in captivity are kept and cared for. I myself am very active in dog rescue and have seen and dealt with the aftermath of deplorable conditions, neglect, and poor nutrition. Places that keep animals in those situations should be shut down.   That said, the places who follow protocol and have happy, healthy animals, like Oceans of Fun at the Milwaukee County Zoo, must be kept running. Oceans of Fun is NOT your regular "sea lion show". It is education in one of its purest forms. The "tricks" are to show the audience things like bone structure, diet, and special abilities. Each show ends with the sea lion picking up "garbage" to bring home the fact that pollution in our oceans effects their natural habitat.  Oceans of Fun makes these animals real for their audience. My 8 y/o wants to make the world a better place because of the conservation tips and facts she learned there and because of the real life animals she saw there. If the show were shut down, people would lose that face to face connection. Out of sight, out of mind. If people cannot see these magnificent creatures, there will be a disconnect and we will not be able to understand how our actions are part of something bigger. We\'ll lose the importance of sea creatures in our ecosystem.   Please allow the show to go on.', "Improved conditions is an absolute priority.  We've seen so many cases recently of sick animals, particularly marine mammals, in captivity.  These improved conditions are indisputable.  However, temporary variances for size requirements should not even be considered.  Transition periods are particularly stressful on these animals and the least we can do is afford them the legally required space mandated. It hurts my heart to see places that genuinely care for animals be demonized by radical groups. Seaworld and other accredited zoos and aquariums care about preserving our species for generations to come', 'Please consider banning all marine mammal "encounter" programs, not just make a new rule for "better treatment" of these smart, social creatures. Better treatment would be stopping the captivity of them. We know too much about these long lived, social mammals and we should be better stewards of the earth, not be about enslaving mammals for " entertainment". I work with wild marine mammals, viewing them from afar, and people are being educated on how smart and social they really are. We  need to do the right thing and you have the power. Please ban captures and look at the tanks, like Miami Seaquarium, that are inhumane, by the very nature of their size, for a full grown orca to "live" in. It\'s just wrong on so many levels. Thank you.', "I am a member of Dolphin Research Center.  During my multiple visits over the past years, I have participated in interactive programs and also spent time watching many sessions between the dolphins, sea lions and their trainers.  In every instance, I was impressed by the staff's dedication to loving and caring for the animals, their high level of expertise, and the clean environments in which the animals live.  It is clear to me that the dolphins enjoy the sessions as much as the people.  They appear to choose to participate and are never forced.  In the dolphin swim programs, I have always particularly enjoyed when I got to play with two dolphins at a time.  They sure seemed to like teaming up for the dorsal pull or fun imitations and other behaviors.  The trainers do a superior job.  I do not feel that my safety was ever at risk, even when one trainer worked with more than one dolphin at a time.  Nor do I feel that the natural water environment and deep lagoon added any risk to my safety during the relatively short periods of time when the trainer and I might not be able to see the dolphins.  I have learned so much about the animals, the environment, and the importance of conservation.  They have inspired me to improve my personal actions in my daily life and in my support of the environment around me.  I'd like to thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare.  I appreciate that you also recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education Thank you!", "As humans we never should have taken animals from the wild.  In the USA that is no longer done unless the animal is unable to return to the wild (example the dolphin winter with no tail).  We can not undo what we have done by releasing animals that have be handled by man into the wild.  We can care for them in the best way possible.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and many other such parks and zoo's and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and that important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld and many other such parks and zoo's it is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks and zoo's for years to come.  One last thought if the animals are happy; they will reproduce on their own and should be allowed to if they so desire.", "We recently went to Hawaii and had the experience of a life time with Dolphin Quest, I am pleased that this company cares for these animals as much as I do.  We chose to go to Dolphin Quest because of their commitment to marine mammals.  Their care for these animals are unsurpassed. Their education program that goes along with every dolphin encounter.  They program is enlightening and vital to the survival of these beautiful creatures.   Please consider that many organization such as Dolphin Quest do not do this solely for the money.  They provide these encounters to teach the public about dolphins.  They spend precious dollars on research.  They spend the most money on care.   It would be a shame to lose such an organization due to government regulations. Another reason we chose Dolphin Quest is for our son.  Just as equine therapy is important to people with autism, dolphins are equally as sensitive.  This encounter brought out a child who doesn't usually express emotion properly.  It was a beautiful symbiotic relationship if only for 40 minutes.", 'First of all, I want to thank you for what your organization does. Animals that are in human care need to be so to the best of all abilities.    I have had some experience with dolphins at the Dolphin Research Center, located in Grassy Key, FL. My first visit, which was almost 20 years ago, changed my life. I had previously seen dolphins at aquariums, but to see them in their natural environment was amazing! They seemed so happy to be interacting with each other and with the guests.I did not do an interaction on that first visit, but went away with the feeling that my young daughter would love this place. Since then, I have spent many days  at DRC, mainly because my daughter studied hard in college and then was hired in the Animal Care and Training department. I have also been in the water many times with numerous dolphins with just one trainer. Never did I feel in danger or feel that the trainer did not have a great sense of control over the entire session. The dolphins seem to really enjoy interacting both with the other dolphins and the humans. In fact, it is my understanding that no dolphin is ever forced into interaction. If they don\'t want to, they don\'t have to. That is one way to ensure safety.    One other issue I feel strongly about is the water. I do not feel that a dolphin needs to be seen at all times. Not one time did I worry because I couldn\'t see where a dolphin was. This is their natural environment! And also the "not clear" water helps protect their skin from the sun. They are allowed to swim deep which is important for them. I don\'t think that any guest has ever been injured due to the water clarity level.    In closing, I want to mention how deeply dedicated the staff at DRC is. They care so deeply about the birds, dolphins and sea lions in their care and work tirelessly to educate the guests about not just the dolphins,  but also the environment and the world around them. I\'m not sure that you can find a more caring group of people.    Once again, thank you for caring about the animals.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'IF you are going to continue to allow captive animals, I believe the rules should consist of the following:  1) TANKS need to be made significantly larger, at the expense of the marine park holding the animals. 2) NO MORE animals can be taken from the wild.  NO MORE subsidizing the dolphin slaughters in Taiji, Japan, and other countries. 3) NO MORE THAN 1 swim-with-dolphin per day...it is unfair to the dolphin to make it do things for strangers more often than that. 4) Optimally, marine captive animals should be given open water to swim in, a lagoon...  that animal welfare rules have not dramatically changed is ridiculous, and only shows that USDA and government is in the hand of special interests once again, as always.;', 'I believe that ALL animals should be well cared for BUT I feel that regulations being implemented by the USDA and local ordinances are trying to turn animals into lab experiments.  Animals do need proper space, feed and care but those spaces do not need to be sterol, they just need to be clean.  The spaces need to allow an animal to move naturally but does not have to be so large that it makes it difficult to mange the animal and the space it is in.  Too many regulations that are too specific for any species can be harmful to the individuals within that species or prohibit the reasonable care of that species.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Regulations that prevent or discourage the use of animals for display, contact, work or breeding are wrong and potentially harmful to individual animals and the species as a whole (wild and captive).  Man has learned so much from captive animals of ALL species.  To overly restrict the ownership of any species that can be maintained in a healthy and secure state is wrong.  Please do not base regulations on advise from organizations that have no real interest in the responsible keeping, breeding and use of animals in captivity. Allow science based organizations with intimate experience with the species being regulated to advise on what minimal care should be set as to maintain a healthy, safe individual.', 'I am a retired animal health regulator. Thank you for your time and consideration.', "I am writing as a current animal care intern at the Oceans of Fun facility located at the Milwaukee County Zoo. I believe that the ongoing review that APHIS is conducting, regarding its regulations, is a great idea, and I am glad that APHIS acknowledges that marine mammal parks and facilities in the United States are dedicated to making sure that they provide outstanding care and treatment of their animals. Oceans of Fun is one of those facilities that goes above and beyond to care for their animals and educate the public as well. Facilities such as Oceans of Fun are imperative for the education of the public on marine mammals and for the conservation of these species out in the wild. Oceans of Fun has held a large influence as to why I have pursued a career in animal care. When I was a child I remember going to educational shows and interactive programs that educated me about why it is crucial that we help protect these animals and our planet, while doing so with animals that are healthy and living in outstanding conditions and habitats. I participated in a program called Sea Lion Splash, which educates children about the importance of marine mammals, such as California Sea Lions and Harbor Seals, and allows the children to learn what a marine mammal trainer does in a day on the job. I made a connection with a male, California sea lion named Slick, and I still have a picture with him, from the program, to this day. When I started as an intern at Oceans of Fun, almost 14 years later, Slick, now nearing 30 years old, is still thriving and educating today's children, due to the outstanding care and environment that the trainers at Oceans of Fun have dedicated their lives to providing to animals such as Slick. Oceans of Fun has helped educated me further on why marine mammal facilities are necessary to help educate others, conserve these animals, and provide an education on the proper way to care for these animals.  Their incredible passion for these animals' well-being and conservation has inspired me to continue to educate others about marine mammals, in hopes that future generations will be able to experience and fall in love with these magnificent creatures, as I did 14 years ago. Please stop these attacks on Zoo's, Sea World and other special groups that care for educating people and caring for all sorts of critters!!!", 'I support this proposed change that deals with amending certain regulations to make sure marine animals are being taken care of while in captivity. I am strongly against any animal being held in captivity unless it is for rehabilitation or other health reasons. I do not believe that animals should be held in captivity so individuals and corporations can make money off of them. However, this is a separate issue that will be hard to change. If animals must be held in captivity, then I believe it is only fair to give them proper living conditions. This rule will allow animals to have more space to roam, better quality water, better ventilation, shaded areas of shelter, and minimum qualifications for individuals working with these animals. These are all basic necessities that these animals should already have. These animals should be entitled to have the happiest and healthiest lives possible while in captivity. Also, many of these changes will require little to no costs to implement. It is our duty to protect these animals who cannot speak up for themselves. These are just a few of the many reasons of why I strongly support this proposed rule change.', 'I\'m not a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), but I know some members of IMATA who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that the  first priority of these people is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.     IMATA members and colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species  to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.   After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'Sea World Cares for sure, Adam Tominsky  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. Sea world has fostered a caring for our natural world and their educational programs have taught me much about what can be done to save our natural world.  From my personal experience withe the training and rescue personnel, I can attest to their expertise with and passion for the animals in their care.', 'I am a member of the Dolphin Research Center. I was there in February and participated in the Trainer Experience which was truly amazing. I then returned 2 more times within a week to enjoy other presentations. So, I got to see the facility at various times and in different kinds of weather.  As the trainer is working with the dolphins, the trainer is fully engaged and always looking out for the dolphins\' best interests. I saw many interactions with trainers and dolphins and the trainers are immensely capable of overseeing more than one dolphin as a time. It was obvious to me they truly care about them.  In regards to water clarity and that APHIS wants the trainer to be able to see the dolphins at all times during interactive sessions, that seems unrealistic with the dolphins in ocean water and the wind, churning of the water by the dolphins, etc. The dolphins are in a natural environment which is so important. Obviously, that could be achieved if they were in a pool in a zoo, which we wouldn\'t want for them. It\'s much better to be in a natural environment.  When I spent one-on-one time with the dolphin Talon, the overwhelming emotion I felt from Talon was "pure joy". Talon showed so much happiness, clicking and affection toward me that I in turn felt immense joy.  It was truly a spiritual experience.   Thank you APHIS for your commitment to animal welfare. I also appreciate that you recognize that the U.S. Marine mammal parks are dedicated to high quality care for these incredible animals.  In appreciation,  Janice Huss', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  The murder of animals in their native habitat due to man made reasoning (which is flawed) has to stop.  Stop playing God!  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all

outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'Sea world has been a long time rescuer an educator on behalf of our wildlife!!!  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care a worldnd important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.
