Leave Sea World alone so that our grandchildren will be afforded the same opportunities as my children to learn about Marine Mamals!', "Thank you for your dedicated work to protect and preserve our natural world and its animals. As others have stated, I recommend that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and information from the marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals and would like to share my perspective on why I believe this to be true.  I believe it's essential that we have marine parks and aquariums to educate the public and increase our collective knowledge of these animals to better protect them in the wild. Many people might never have the opportunity to see these amazing animals if it weren't for these facilities.  As a supporter of marine parks and aquariums, and as a person who is passionate about the welfare of animals and preservation of species, I have learned so much from these facilities and believe they are beneficial to understanding and inspiring crucial conservation efforts.   I have worked at Dolphin Quest, alongside animal specialists and professionals, for the past eight years.  We are committed to animal wellness, inspiring conservation through guest interactions and providing a setting conducive to research support where scientists learn from our animals and how they can be better served in the wild.    Dolphin Quest meets and exceeds Animal Welfare Act (AWA) standards regarding dolphins under human care.  The animals under our care live lives filled with enrichment, social, mental and physical stimulation.  Our specialists are dedicated to providing a nurturing environment, strong bonds and trusted relationships.  It is my belief that the animals under our care have more than just their needs met, this is their sanctuary, this is where they thrive.    For almost thirty years, Dolphin Quest has successfully and safely conducted interactive programming.  To introduce additional unnecessary regulatory standards would be both burdensome to the regulatory body and unreasonable given the effective AWA standards that currently exist.", 'I am an active volunteer at Oceans of Fun in Milwaukee, WI and participated in a 5 month long internship with this facility. Through my internship I learned so much about the animals, our environment, and conservation. I also witnessed the dedication the trainers put into building a solid relationship with our animals in order to give the best care they can by training. The amount of passion they have for the work they do never goes unnoticed and the work they do is always to their fullest potential. They not only have the dedication to give the best care to our animals, but they are also dedicated to teaching their interns and volunteers to provide the best quality care for our animals by working to maintain the environment that our animals live in. Everything I have learned and witnessed at Oceans of Fun has inspired me to improve my daily actions to help with the conservation of our environment.    Oceans of Fun provides many interactive programs along with shows that educate the public on our animals, the environment, and conservation. Through my time assisting some of these programs I have seen the amazing effect it has on the public. I see people leave our facility everyday inspired to improve their actions in their daily life to support our environment, and that to me is what facilities like this are all about.   As an Alliance-accredited facility I know the staff members are the experts in the marine mammal care field and the highest standards of animal care are in place. For that reason I ask that you please reconsider making changes to your regulations based on the input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.  Thank you for your commitment to animal welfare and for conducting the thorough review of existing regulations and for recognizing that marine mammal parks and facilities in the United States provide outstanding care and treatment of the animals in their families, including maintaining healthy habitats suitable to their needs.', 'Sea World provides an excellent source of valuable scientific information and research on Marine animals.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you for allowing  Sea World the opportunity to continue this valuable work.', 'I suggest that any modifications to the APHIS regulations should be based on the most current science and information from marine mammal specialists who have the most experience with these animals.  I have been to Dolphin Quest and Bermuda Zoo quite a many times during my stay in Bermuda and I think it is important for accredited zoos and aquariums to exist for public education, conservation and increasing our scientific knowledge of these animals.    Having natural animals is in the best interest and collective well-being of the society.  ', 'Our family has been long time supporters of Oceans of Fun in Milwaukee, WI. This facility has always amazed me in their care for the marine animals.  Our daughter has attended multiple camps at Oceans of Fun and has learned an amazing amount of conservation from their educators.  Her interaction with the animals has taught her about their behavior and the importance of constant enrichment for the animals.  We are fortunate to have a facility in the Midwest willing to educate us about marine animals, this makes us more aware nationally about these beautiful animals and their triumphs and struggles in the wild.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I want you to know that I am very much an animal lover and want only what is best for them as a species.', 'I am in support of this proposed rule.  After watching the documentary "Blackfish", I have had a growing concern for animals in captivity.  I feel that the treatment of this animals being forced to live in a place that is not their natural environment, so be treated a lot better.  I believe animals who are being removed from their natural environment should at least be in an environment that accommodates to their welfare.  Living in a confined living space can not be easy for them.  They don\'t need added stress of not having the appropriate temperature water or space to be active and live.  I support the need for revisions in a regulation that has not been changed in well over 10+ years.  Times have changed since the last revision and the animals\' welfare should reflect that.', 'I work with the sea otters at the Georgia Aquarium and we currently have a geriatric female that is 19 years old.  As her mobility has become a challenge and her ability to get out of the pool has become more difficult, we have explored various ways in which to assist her.  In her case, we did install a ramp, but she does not utilize it. Our team found that raising the water level of her habitat was a more successful way of assisting her in and out of the water. I feel the mandate from APHIS to make ramps a permanent fixture in all sea otter and pinniped enclosures is unnecessary - as this would not have supported the goal in this case. As animal care professionals, we are charged with making whatever accommodations are necessary to help address any issue that arises in the care of these animals. I feel APHIS should accept modifications on a case-by-case basis.', 'The dastardly do-gooders are trying to stymie inspiring education again. There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  SeaWorld is a unique organization that provides a service we desperately need.  Please do not allow a few outspoken professional protesters ruin what is an organization that truly cares for the animals.', 'My name is Nicole Enright, and I am a professional Dolphin Care Specialist currently working at The Mirage Dolphin Habitat. I have been a professional marine mammal trainer for over 5 years, however I have been a professional animal trainer for over 10 years all together. I am currently a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers Association, and as such, I am proud to be among the top professionals in the animal care, husbandry and training field. I have had the opportunity to review some of the suggested changes to the current regulations regarding marine mammals in a managed care environment and I have a few comments I would like to submit for consideration. Interactive programs: In my experience, there is no evidence to support, peer reviewed or otherwise, that animal and guest interactions are inherently harmful to either the animal or the guest. There are a number of safety regulations already in place, and I believe, rather than implementing further blanket regulations, that safety inspections should be done on a case by case basis, taking into consideration a facilities safety record, and animal health and enrichment programs. Also, the definition of an interactive program should take into consideration the extreme differences between a program in which a guest is either on a dock or behind a barrier, or a situation where an animal is brought out from their enclosure under stimulus control, vs. a situation where a guest is completely free contact in an animals enclosure/ in the water with the animal. Both these scenarios offer significantly different degrees of guest and animal variables. Time limits for sessions: Again, there is no scientific evidence to support that guest interactions with the animals are inherently damaging, and while I am open to limiting the amount of time an individual animal is asked to spend in direct contact with the public (excluding viewing areas), I do not believe this should apply to the animal caretakers/ trainers. This decision should not be made with the idea that these guest interactions are in any way harmful to the animals, but rather as a means to support more time for other training(husbandry, research etc.) and to prevent over working of the animals. Our interactions with the animals are an essential part of their daily husbandry and enrichment. Limiting the time we can work with the animals will inherently limit the amount of world class care we can provide them, and thus possibly limit their quality of life. I do, however believe that the amount of time guests will be allowed in direct contact with the animals, should be an amount determined by unbiased scientific studies, not an arbitrary number decided upon by anybody. The guest interactions are simply a part of the animals training day, and enrichment, and by limiting this arbitrarily, we could hinder opportunities to further their quality of life. Trainer to animal ratios: In my experience, a facility that is adequately staffed is able to work more efficiently and care for the animals more thoroughly. With that being said, the animal to trainer ration should, however, not be applied to training or interactive sessions. The reason for this is that it would limit our ability to work very important social sessions with the animals, as well as providing variability to their day. Being able to work with animals together, in  "teams" can help support good social compatibility within the social structure, as well as provide enriching opportunities. IF an animal to trainer ratio should be implemented, it should refer to trainers on staff, not trainers per session. Undesirable behavior: As animal BEHAVIORISTS, it is our experience and expertise that should be referenced when determining the best way to manage undesirable behavior. The general public has a very limited understanding on operant conditioning and how it is used to manage undesirable behavior. Therefore, the best people to determine appropriate courses of action, based on an individual animals learning history, the specific scenario the target behavior was demonstrated, and the future learning goals of that animal, would be professionals who understand that animals behavior, and behavior as a whole, IE: members of IMATA. In conclusion, I would like to thank APHIS for their recognition of the outstanding care marine mammal facilities in the US have provided thus far, and for further diligence in ensuring that marine mammals in our care receive the best possible care. I ask that as always, you continue to consider animal welfare as a priority, and do not feel compelled to change regulations based on a vocal minority of the public who speaks not based on scientific knowledge, but on emotion. Thank you!!', "Dear Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Over the past couple years I have done many programs at many marine parks like, Oceans Of Fun, Clearwater Marine Aquairum, Gulfarium, Gulf World, Discovery Cove, Seaworld, and etc... In each program I participate in I make a connection to the animals. Throughout each of these programs I have learned and noticed all the work trainers dedicate there time into caring for the animals. The staff provides a clean and safe environment for the animals, and use much enrichment and positive reinforcement to stimulate the animals. Another way the staff enriches the animals is by human interaction. It is very clear when you visit a facility that the animals enjoy their training sessions and interactions with humans. It is also clear to see the trainers never force there animals to do anything. I notice they have different ways to enrich an animal by toys, food, and more. These programs I have done have inspired me and taught me much about conservation. They have inspired me to improve my daily life actions and support the beautiful environment around me. I very much appreciate the work they do at Oceans of Fun and other marine mammal facilities, because they take great care of their animals and as I've seen provide daily entertainment for them. Thank you for your commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that the U.S. Marine mammal parks are providing top quality care for the animals and education to the public, and that you didn't feel compelled to unesseccarily change regulations. These programs have made an influence in my life by, teaching me about marine mammals and protecting their environment.  Thank you!  Cami Nate", 'I urge you to use science not emotion.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Again science is proven and Sea World uses science and very caring staff that are very knowledgeable.', 'I am a supporter of accredited zoological facilities and aquariums and marine parks and have been personally inspired by my experiences at Georgia Aquarium.  I applaud APHIS for evaluating, and where necessary, updating the regulations by objectively assessing the latest peer reviewed science and input from industry experts on the best practices for care of these incredible marine mammals. I am concerned that groups opposed to marine mammals in zoological settings misuse the process of updating care regulations in their attempts to end the display of marine mammals.  They do so by encouraging APHIS to impose rules which are not necessary, counter to decades of successful care programs and processes, and impede the great education and conservation work done by the zoological community.  I encourage APHIS to evaluate the marine mammal care regulations based upon on the merits of applicable peer reviewed literature and current best practice standards; in cases where insufficient literature exists, input and observation of successful practices within the industry should be strongly considered.', "This rulemaking would slightly amend Animal Welfare Act regulations concerning the handling, care, treatment, and transportation of marine mammals in captivity, but would not change the space requirements, which were last updated in 1984. At that time the science on marine mammal range patterns and typical travel distances in the wild was not well established.  More recently, however, a variety of longitudinal field studies have documented the geographic outlines of normal movements of a wide range of marine mammal populations, especially dolphin species and in particular Orcinus orca. These photo-identification and genetic studies have documented vast ranges and long distance travels for many dolphin species, especially bottlenose dolphins and again, most especially, orcas. Demographic studies have shown that these cetacean species live as members of multi-generational extended families, which are in turn associated at the population level with complex social systems.  Much of these mammals' behavior patterns are now understood to take place within tradition-bound, cultural societies. Technology has also emerged that allows scientists access to not only the vast distances traveled, but also the descents to hundreds of meters below the waves. Yet, APHIS states in its proposed rule that it is unaware of any science supporting changes in the space requirements, straining credibility. APHIS must substantially increase space requirements before finalizing the rule. With the research now available describing what marine mammals do in the wild, to continue to support obsolete and constraining space requirements for those in captivity is unjustified scientifically and unacceptable morally and ethically. The below references are intended to provide a sense of the current consensus of the scientific community establishing the vast space needed by the dolphin species typically held captive, especially orcas, the extensive social and familial networks dolphin species have evolved within, and the cultural capabilities dolphins have amply demonstrated.  References: Andrews, et al. 2008. Satellite tracking reveals distinct movement patterns for Type B and Type C killer whales in the southern Ross Sea, Antarctica.  Baird and Whitehead (2000). Social organization of mammal-eating killer whales: group stability and dispersal patterns. Brent, et al. Ecological Knowledge, Leadership, and the Evolution of Menopause in Killer Whales. Connor, Richard (2007). Dolphin social intelligence: complex alliance relationships in bottlenose dolphins and a consideration of selective environments for extreme brain size evolution in mammals. Parallel cultural and genetic lineages in Alaskan resident type killer whales.", "I have visited marine parks several times and have observed the interaction between the trainers and animals. Training and performing are enrichment activities that the animals seem to enjoy. Requiring that the animals be in sight at all times would REQUIRE  that the animals always be kept in shallow artifical geometrically uninteresting environments. Behavioral research done in a captive environment cannot be duplicated in the wild and the research being done has led to better stewardship of wild populations. One of the reasons we need marine mammal facilities is that they are the facilities that step up to rescue and rehabilitate injured wild animals who,most often, we're injured through human stupidity.  Before initiating changes DO YOUR RESERCH! Use studies that are curre

nt not 30 years old.", 'Having seen firsthand the rescue operations performed by SeaWorld and visited the behind the scenes animals rehabilitated in their care I ask for your assistance in continuing to support this very necessary program.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Having visited SeaWorld San Diego as a child, I was inspired to work there during college, participating in a research program in the aviary dept.   Now I continue to visit the park as a tourism representative sharing the park and their programs with visitors both international and domestic.   They never fail to leave the park inspired and impressed with the dedication and passion of the employees, trainers and rescue workers.    Please continue to respect the care and compassion which is the guiding force for SeaWorld and the animals in their care.', 'I have been to many parks and zoos over the years and have always been amazed how much the people in these facilities deeply care for the animals. It breaks my heart to see people who claim to want to do what is best for the animals but act only out of emotion and never take the time to really understand what they are asking for. I have had the opportunity to see both the public and behind the scenes parts of SeaWorld and have been amazed at the love and care that is given to the animals that are entrusted to them.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I implore you to please use the science and facts, not emotions, to make regulations that are beneficial to all the animals and allow our superb facilities to continue to care fore them.', 'Stop the Killing!!!!!', 'As a member of the International Marine Animal Trainers\' Association (IMATA), an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.   IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of physical settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in an even wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations for schoolchildren, from peer-reviewed research designed to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.  After having the opportunity to review the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.   If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.  Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day. With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.  With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.   Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using broad examples followed by "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.   I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', 'Sea world does great work  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Thank you.', 'Dear Dr. Kohn,  First of all, I would like to say that I am in full support of the comments submitted by the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums (AMMPA), as well as by the Georgia Aquarium and Marineland Dolphin Adventure.  This is my 30th year in the marine mammal care and training field. I suspect that I am part of a very small number of commenters who have extensive experience with marine mammals in human care in addition to marine mammal stranding responses, marine mammal field research and, perhaps even more uniquely, the rehabilitation of bottlenose dolphins from zoological settings either deliberately or inadvertently released to the wild. I have cared for marine mammals in tropical and temperate climates, in both sea pens and in concrete habitats.  I feel that my perspective is well-rounded from all angles. I also want to recognize that the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) is a well-established and valuable regulatory document that has been crafted with decades of scientifically-based information, and any commenters who detract from the value of this document are either unfamiliar with the realities of animal care, or have an agenda that runs contrary to the proper care of animals in human care settings.  As a long-time animal care specialist, I am quite familiar with the tactics and manufactured "facts" of many of our opponents, and I trust that you and the rest of your team are well-versed in science and in reality so as not to acquiesce to simple propaganda. As you well know, we have just come out of a bottlenose dolphin Unusual Mortality Event (UME) which killed at least 1,700 dolphins (that we know of; who knows how many were not found) in the past 2+ years along the eastern seaboard from the coasts of New York to central Florida. The threats facing our oceanic and riverine marine mammals deserve so much more attention and protection from various animal "rights" groups. The marine mammals in the care of accredited zoos and aquariums simply make convenient targets for keyboard warriors, who seem to refuse to acknowledge that they are already well- regulated by the USDA, and continue to thrive in their homes...many, if not most, surrounded by family members since they were born in human care and not collected from the wild. It is distressing to see how many people continue to believe that our cetaceans came from Japanese drive fisheries, or that stranded and rehabilitated animals that are deemed un-releasable by NOAA Fisheries are kept in our facilities out of greed. I realize that many of your commenters may be better educated on the intricacies and nuances of this topic than these examples, but a quick spin around social media shows that this is indeed part of the narrative to drive emotion-provoked activity. I have the utmost confidence in the knowledge and expertise of you and your team to rely upon the opinions of professional experts in the further development of these modifications, and to not be swayed by the emotional pleas of the well-intentioned but frequently misinformed masses who are assuredly filling your in-box with form letters.  Thank you for your time and for your commitment to leaning on performance-based standards for many of your proposed changes to the AWA, and again, I fully support the comments from the AMMPA, Georgia Aquarium and Marineland Dolphin Adventure!', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Why does our government claim to be so ignorant?  I wish we had better people to vote into office.  The people that are running our goverment now are just greedy, selfish, and could care less about the people.  How are they suppose to care about Orcas when they are so driven by money that they can\'t see past the green?  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'In support of the Alliance of Marine Mammal Parks and Aquariums, as well as the adoption of any new regulations based  solely on hard science and the best interest of animals as opposed to animal rights activist politics.  "The value and contribution that Oceans of Fun makes to the education of the public is instrumental in raising the level  of awareness and understanding of our youngsters and adults. These visual and mental connections with our marine  life are so valuable, without this facility, where else would the opportunity occur?  The scientific and medical research that is done to further enhance the well-being of the marine mammals is beyond  important.  Oceans of Fun is an impeccably safe and well run facility, we are so fortunate to have it in the Milwaukee area! Robbin Magnuson, art educator"', "Thank you for your time, I know it is valuable to you.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Sea World and Zoos are all great places to visit and learn about our world in a very different way.  Although it is important for animals to be given quality care, most organizations exceed those requirements.  As, I'm sure you're aware, activists can be very vocal and try to do whatever it takes to gain attention.  Those who oppose zoological organizations are basing their findings on misinformation and beliefs.    It is important that we put our whole world first and science based research is very important for our world.  It's also important, in the United States, that we remain competitive with our fellow nations in such research.  It pushes us all forward, whereas animal rights activists want to push us backwards.  I admire their passion for animals, but what they want is not good for anyone, including the very animals they are fighting to protect, which in some cases, have never been in the wild.  Sea World and organizations like it care deeply about these amazing creatures and set the standards for what animal care really should be.  I am proud to support them and their mission to further study and care for these amazing creatures.", 'It is my opinion that Seaworld does an exceptional job of balancing the rescue and care of wild animals who are too injured or sick to survive in the wild with humanely interacting with the animals in their care and showcasing their unique gifts to the world through their educational and entertaining presentations. To steal the opportunity for children of the future to actually see the incredible beauty and power of these whales and other animals up close would be incredibly short-sighted. It is much easier to dismiss the plight of something seen only in a book or movie than to ignore a living creature whom you have personally seen interacting and communicating with others of its own species as well as its human caregivers.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Objective observation of the work of SeaWorld and other marine and animal parks clearly indicates their benefit to the animals both in their care and still in the wild as it raises the level of appreciation and concern that we all have for all creatures.', "Though I understand the emotional reaction some have about closing zoos and marine animal parks I am not in favor of this at all. If zoos and parks like Sea World are closed or limited in what they do where will we take our children to learn about animals and sea creatures. Most people would never see a lion or a whale in nature. Most people cannot afford safaris and boats large enough to come across orcas or dolphins. I have loved going to zoos and marine parks all over the world, it is often our first stop when we travel. As a young child my dad made huge efforts to take me and my brothers to the Bronx zoo when the zoo in Springfield Mass closed. We went to the circus to see elephants and zebras in the parades, we loved the tiger acts. We never thought those animals were being treated badly. I follow this tradition with our boys and their children. Now that we live in San Diego we love to visit Sea World and the SD zoo. There is nothing better than seeing a young child be amazed as the orca swims by the glass, a dolphin tosses a ball your way or laughing with glee at the seals antics.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      I love being in San Diego and reading about our Sea World rescuing the baby seals and other marine animals that need help.There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   I love going to SeaWorld by myself to visit the dolphins. I see that  the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  I am afraid that technology, the internet and children being given phones will also change the way our society and others views zoos and marine parks.Wouldn't it be terrible if we allow phones to take over our children's learning , or that we all sit in our living rooms looking at computer screens for everything we do--which is not so far away I am afraid.   Please help protect these places in the regulatory process you are doing. Please do not be influenced by the film Black Fish. I have seen the film, I understand what they were trying to convey. I have a marine scientist son and another is in the environmental protection regulation field. I see both sides of the issues, but I do not agree that closing and limiting the scope of work at places such as Sea World is the solution, especially ignited by inflammatory  films and organizations that seek to close everything in the name of humane treatment, letting animals back into the wild etc.  Our zoos and marine parks in the US are wonderful places to learn, to relax, to bring families together over a picnic lunch. I understand and have seen some places that are not up to Sea World's standards. But this has not been in the US. I think it belittles the good works of Sea World to put them in this category.  Thankyou for your work, I know how much reading you have to do, and that you will be spending long hours around conference tables and you hash out these issues. Thankyou for reading my thoughts.", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at facilities such as SeaWorld in my youth, which has shaped my devotion for conservation, and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that zoological facilities like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "All animals in zoos and aquariums are ambassadors for their cousins in the wild.  I am a current college student studying zoology. I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts. The animals at SeaWorld seem to have better health care and receive more attention than what most people would even expect from a zoological facility. Staff are on call around the clock ready to help care for their animals at anytime. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. This can also be seen first hand through seaworlds behind the scenes tours. Just as you see the bond between people and their pets, you can see the bond between SeaWorld staff and the animals they care for. My experience instills me, my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world. Although I have seen many wildlife documentaries as a child, I owe my passion and motivation to study zoology to the connections I made with marine mammals at SeaWorld and other zoological facilities.  Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  You'll never be the same again after looking up close into the eyes of any animal.", 'As a weekly visitor to SeaWorld, I appreciate the opportunity of seeing so many marine animals up close. The trainers, handlers, employees are always eager to educate us; they share their passion and love of animals with us. We have learned so much from SW employees. Nothing makes me want to save wild whales more than looking into the eyes of a SW whale. What a majestic mammal that I never could have seen up close except at SW.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country. It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Please help SW continue educating people, rescuing animals and sharing their passion.', 'I am strongly in favor that any modifications to the APHIS regulations be based on the most current science and are in the best interest of the animals.  The marine mammal parks and aquariums that I have visited not only provide great care and show compassion for the animals, they are also excellent at educating the public about these wonderful creatures.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Since other animals do not belong to humans at all, the least we

can do is assiduously try to protect them as much as possible, after all the harm people have inflicted on them.  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  I am a practicing eye surgeon in Florida who frequently evaluates caustic eye injuries.  I can tell you from experience that chlorine in these dolphin tanks are causing permanent eye damage and vision loss by damaging and killing the corneal tissue of these captive dolphins.  Not only are these dolphins taken from the wild but they are then subjected to caustic tank conditions which results in eye pain and vision loss.  This practice needs to stop. In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I\'m not sure what the world is coming to when humans cannot help animals have a better thriving life. IF any place has backed the best interest of all the animals (from the dolphins to the neutering the iguanas), it\'s Dolphin Research Center.  They make sure the dolphins only do what they feel like doing, just like you would do with any living being that you have come to understand & love.  The people who work at DRC are not your average everyday ppl. They are very patient & exceptionally kind people, and are very in tuned to the animal\'s needs.  They are studying these animals daily, and are sharing knowledge with others marine facilities that are striving to do the same.  I wish these animals could speak for themselves b/c if they could there would be no need to have to consider changing such an amazing place.    If ever there is an example of JOY & THRIVING, it\'s these dolphins and sea lions at DRC.  I have been a member of DRC for 8 years b/c I fully support what they have done for the dolphins and the environment in general.  The dolphins in particular are very social animals and like interacting & playing with the other dolphins.  They have been doing this over 30 years, so what you are trying to say "stop doing" would be a disruption to how this "family" of people & beautiful animals operate.  Please come & visit more than one day. You will find what they are doing is working very well.  There is NO need to fix "what is not broken" as the old saying goes. Trust these good people to continue doing amazingly good things for these animals.  Be supportive of what is working.  Watch & learn!  You will find that your heart & mind will understand DRC is doing above & beyond  what is needed for these dolphins and sea lions to be happy, safe, & thriving.  Thank you for your time & please think this thoroughly through.  Don\'t put everyone in a box as to what works. Thank you Seaworld.', "Thank you for your concern and all of the efforts made on behalf of the welfare of Marine Mammals.  It is truly a unique combination to be both an aquatic animal as well as a mammal!  I am a long time member of Dolphin Research Center and spent a summer there as a volunteer.  I was able to participate in many interactive programs including the dolphin swim programs, as well as leading groups of visitors around the lagoon at Dolphin Research Center.  The dolphins greet their visitors as all stroll around the walkways and it is absolutely clear that the dolphins enjoy the interactions and sessions with the visiting groups of people.  The dolphins have been so cared for and loved by the staff and trainers here, that if Dolphins could grow legs and get out of the water to be with us, there would be the compassion and loving relationship that exists between pets and owners.  The staff at Dolphin Research Center are so dedicated, that all take turns in the care of these marine mammals here.  Tasks are rotated and all spend a day, on a rotating basis, in the fish house for cleaning, sterilizing and loading coolers, as well as being available early mornings for any animal husbandry that may need to be performed before the Center opens.  The trainers  do an excellent job at working with the dolphins on training and initiating behaviors and fun interactions with the dolphins and the visitors and it is always the Dolphin's 'choice' to participate in the encounter.  At no time do I feel that safety was an issue when one trainer worked with more than one person at a time or that the natural lagoon environment posed a safety risk to myself during the short times the trainer or myself could not see the dolphins.  I have learned so much from my experiences and visits at Dolphin Research Center and the natural lagoon setting enhances the experience  of appreciating the world of the dolphin.  Again, thank you for your commitment and dedication to Marine Mammals and public learning opportunities such as Dolphin Research Center. ", 'I have worked in the marine mammal care field for 7 years and have enjoyed educating and inspiring aquarium guests during our interactive programs with dolphins.  Our interactive programs are overseen by experts in the field and we have been trained to facilitate programs that are safe and engaging for the animals, guests, and trainers. The continue research and learning about these mammals will help them from going extinct.  I would never know what most of these creatures look like. Nor would my children.     SEA WORLD WAS THE SOLE REASON MY KIDS. ARE GOING INTO MARINE BIOLOGY.', 'Before finalizing the rule, APHIS should substantially revise its proposals to revise and update the standards governing the humane care and handling of captive marine mammals. The current proposal ignores a wealth of scientific evidence obtained over the past three decades and essentially maintains a long-outdated status quo for the captive marine mammal industry.  Thank you  While the agency has proposed several improvements to the standards, such as requiring shade for all outdoor marine mammal enclosures and ramps for older or injured seals, sea lions, polar bears, and sea otters to exit pools more easily, these are minor compared to the significant failures in the proposed rule.  The agency proposes no changes to the space requirements, claiming it is unaware of any science on which to base such changes. In fact, there is a tremendous body of recent research using increasingly sophisticated tagging technology to monitor fine-scale movement patterns of individual marine mammals, especially cetaceans and polar bears. These species travel tremendous distances and dive very deep, making the current minimum space requirements totally inhumane. The best available science for seals, sea lions, and sea otters--even for the slow, plant-eating manatee--also supports major space increases.  The current space standards were set over 30 years ago and have no basis in science or even best practices within the captive display industry. As an example, for up to two orcas, a facility need only provide a circular tank with a diameter twice as wide and a depth half as deep as an average adult orca is long. This standard does not even allow the animal to position itself fully in the vertical plane (its tail would touch and drag on the bottom before the animal reaches full upright orientation). This cannot be considered adequate!  While the rule refers to peer-reviewed papers for proposed changes to some standards (e.g., lighting requirements), it claims the agency is unaware of such papers for other standards (e.g., temperature requirements) and therefore proposes no major changes. Yet a considerable amount of research has been conducted within the past 15 years related to most if not all of the affected standards.   The proposed rule would still allow pinnipeds to be housed in enclosures with tanks filled with fresh water. Allowing the maintenance of a marine mammal in fresh water is clearly an inappropriate welfare standard.  Several standards have been weakened, particularly regarding interactive programs such as swim-with-dolphin encounters. For example, the standard for the interaction time for each cetacean per day has been increased from two hours to three hours, not based on science or even industry best practices, but simply "on information provided by licensees ... which suggested that the marine mammals would not be harmed by a modest increase in interactive time per day." Facility "suggestions" represent a clear conflict of interest and should never be the sole basis for changes to standards.  The agency asked in previous notices if noise standards should be established. In several instances, noise levels, particularly in air, are extremely high (in theme parks, virtually every night there is a fireworks display directly over the marine mammal enclosures). Noise standards must be established for marine mammal facilities.  In sum, the proposed rule is grossly inadequate and fails to take into account current scientific understanding of the needs of marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  As marine parks (in general) are at the forefront of marine animal rescue, if such facilities are forced to downgrade or even close, it appears evident that far fewer such rescues could be facilitated...', "Wow!  You guys really missed the point - many of your changes are for the WORSE!  Your committee needs to talk to members of IMATA and look at ALL the CURRENT research and get up to date on what is humane and what isn't.  Sticking a marine mammal in a tank with fresh water and nothing to interest it is merciless and completely inhumane.  Many of the marine mammals need deep water and much more space.  And they ALL need SALT water.  Also, forcing them to work another hour can shorten the life of a marine mammal.  They work enough as it is!    Plus many marine mammals need to be in family units not by themselves in a concrete and glass tank.  Also, being able to see the bottom of a habitat is absurd and wrong.  When they are housed in actual waters of the Gulf or Atlantic, and in the deep waters as they are SUPPOSED to live in, it is impossible to see the bottom and the tides change the waters all the time.  A better solution would be to test the water for contamination on a regular basis so that an inspector doesn't confuse particulate matter in the water as something unhealthy or toxic.    I live in the Florida Keys and the Dolphin Research Center, a non-profit group that protects and does extensive research with marine mammals, can be of great assistance to your committee because it seems that you have made grievous errors in this proposed rule to animal welfare for marine mammals.  This rule will cause HARM to marine mammals. APHIS must substantially strengthen the requirements for keeping cetaceans in captivity before the rule is finalized.', "Having worked for over a decade in the zoological education field, mostly at SeaWorld Orlando, it concerns me when any party outside of the park itself becomes too involved in making policies regarding animal training. I have seen firsthand the care the veterinary and training staff put into their animals, and don't believe that anyone without their expertise is capable of making better decisions for the animals in their care. The parks work to maintain their accreditation with IMATA, AZA, and AMMPA, and no one outside of that field knows their work better than the people in the field. I'm completely in favor of parks being open with their practices, with letting the public know what they do, as well as why, and how, but I'm opposed to what seem like fairly random regulations which don't take into consideration the aptitudes and personalities of the individual animals.", 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect the important animal care and education that is provided at SeaWorld.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to the well-being of animals  but also to the continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers, and caretakers love and respect the animals and the animals care for them. The experience has given me and my friends and family a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to visiting SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', 'I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. Please guard against making changes to your regulations based on input from those who fail to recognize the critical educational and inspirational importance of zoos and aquariums.   Based on my visits to SeaWorld there is no question that the animals are thriving and well cared for by passionate animal care experts.  It is obvious the veterinarians, trainers and caretakers love the animals and the animals love them. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.  Our cHildreth needs close up chances to see live animals and fish.', 'I have been in the marine mammal field for 18 years and have worked in many capacities with a variety of marine mammals. As a professional member of IMATA, an organization representing the individuals who have dedicated their professional lives to actually providing daily care to marine animals in zoological settings, I can assure you that our members\' first priority is to act as the guarantors of the welfare of those in their charge.    IMATA members and our colleagues care for and train marine mammals in a wide variety of settings, from inland habitats to ocean enclosures, and engage with the animals in a wider variety of contexts: everything from dynamic stadium performances to intimate interpretive chats, from in-water guest interactions to educational presentations, from peer-reviewed research to enhance understanding of ecosystems and species to veterinary care focused on the welfare of an individual patient. No matter the context, the one constant we believe is essential to ensure the health and welfare of marine mammals in any managed setting is providing them the opportunity for robust, diverse, and positive interaction with a qualified, professional staff with knowledge in best-practices and expertise in state-of-the-art animal training and care.  After reviewing the proposed changes to the APHIS regulations related to marine mammals, the additional components specific to marine mammal interactive programs seem unjustified based on the strong safety record of these types of encounters. To my knowledge, there is no peer-reviewed scientific data that demonstrates a need for additional regulation or how further regulation would be a benefit to marine mammals.     If interactive programs are defined as "any human-marine mammal interactive program where a member of the public enters a primary enclosure for a marine mammal with the intent of interacting with the marine mammal(s)" - I believe that the definition should explicitly exclude guest contact programs in which the participants may sit/stand on a floating platform or shallow ledge, or remain poolside, as well as programs in which trainers bring marine mammals into a public area under stimulus control.   Additionally, I cannot support the proposed rule which stipulates that interactive sessions must not exceed 3 hours per day per animal. Based on my professional experience, I believe that the amount of daily interactive time should be based around the best interests and capabilities of the animals as determined by the caregivers that know them best. In general, training sessions have proven to be a very enriching part of an animal\'s day - providing physical/mental stimulation. The notion that somehow limiting or reducing this interaction would provide some benefit to marine mammals is not data-driven and has no scientific basis. Any changes to the management of the marine animals in our care should build on the high quality of our existing animal care and training programs, and provide additional opportunities for the animals to engage and interact with the professionals to whom their care has been entrusted. At its core, an interactive program session is simply a training session - which is a highly beneficial and important component of an animal\'s day.  With that said, in my experience, there is no indication that any restriction in time for interactive sessions is needed, and, is likely not in the best interest of the individual animal.   With respect to the proposed changes in attendant/animal ratios, creating a requirement that there must be at least one attendant per marine mammal in each session and at least one attendant positioned to monitor the session is not necessary. Since the inception of interactive programs in the late 1980s, trainers have safely conducted interaction programs with various ratios of animals to attendants based on the situational circumstances. As such, trainers have learned that having the flexibility to interact with animals in "teams" can be an enriching part of the animals\' training.     Finally, I have some concerns with the language used to describe "unsatisfactory" or "undesirable" behaviors. Using "not limited to" could create confusion for trainers leading these programs. A performance-based approach focusing on unsafe behaviors specific to an individual, the circumstances at hand and the location in which they reside is a preferable way to ensure safety-based decision making. Trainers are in the best position to best determine if an animal exhibits unsafe behavior and facilitate behavioral redirection or the termination of its participation in a session due to such behavior.    I would like to thank the agency for its diligent commitment to animal welfare. I appreciate that you recognize that U.S. marine mammal parks are dedicated to providing top quality care and public education and trust you will not feel compelled to change regulations that limit our ability to care for the animals.', "To Whom it my concern we need SeaWorld to continue there work and care for and with our beloved sea animals. I have worked, in various capacities, at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, and the National Zoological Park, Smithsonian Institution.  Marine mammals under my care at the National Zoo are some of the longest lived, of their type, in captivity (Ca sea lions:  Norman:  27 years, Maureen: 30 years, Grey seals:  Gunnar: 38 years, and Selkie, still living at 43 years of age)   Definitions:  Section 1.1:  I agree that the revised definitions are more descriptive and useful.', 'These facilities care for animals in a way that helps mitigate the impact of human alterations to their natural environment. They are aiding, not interfering. We should continue to support them and their efforts to preserve and protect marine mammals.  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.      There is no question that marine parks like SeaWorld are critical to not only the well-being of animals in human care but to continued rescue and rehabilitation of those in the wild. The experience instills me and my friends and family with a deeper understanding and respectful appreciation of the natural world.   Thank you for your diligent commitment to animal welfare. I look forward to have the opportunity to visit SeaWorld and other marine mammal parks for years to come.', "I have worked with dolphins and sea lions as a guest photographer for over 3 years now. I have seen dolphin interactions change peoples lives and educate them about things they didn't know before. I believe that some of the proposed rules will encumber people from gaining insightful and life changing opportunities.   I do not think each dolphin needs its own trainer during public in water or from shore interactions. I have seen dolphins thrive on a variable environment, rather than a boring structured, military like existence. Requiring the dolphin to stay with one trainer at a time and only having one dolphin per trainer, will severely limit dolphins ability to have a variable interaction on a day to day basis. Variety is the spice of life.   I also believe that the water clarity question is unnecessary. I agree that bacteria and other contaminants should be monitored, but water clarity, especially in a place that has ocean water enclosures, is not a realistic barometer of health or cleanliness. Through my job observing dolphins and humans interacting, the humans rarely leave eyesight. They are always safe even though you can't always see the dolphins. If the water levels are contaminant free or within levels, I do not believe that water clarity will enhance safety.  Finally, more record keeping is only going to create needless work and material that will rarely if ever be utilized. The current recording scheme is more than adequate, and provides detailed descriptions of every trainers dolphin interactions throughout their day already. There is no need for more records. They stink.  Overall, I see dolphins interacting with guests daily, in a happy for dolphins, happy for humans setting. It takes mutual respect and an ability to be flexible to meet everyones needs, human and dolphin. Please don't add rules that will make it harder to provide life changing opportunities to people while still achieving a happy, variable, and socially stimulating environment for the dolphins.  Thank you for your time.", 'they have done great work on educating kids on animals  I have personally been educated and inspired at SeaWorld and am writing to respectfully ask that your new regulations for U.S. marine parks continue to reflect that top quality animal care and important education is provided daily at their parks, and accredited facilities around the country.
